Large deposits of rich magnetic oxide, as yet untouched, exist in the ridges east of the capital near the banks of the navigable river Myit-ngoe, and the same district contains lime in great abundance, and of remarkable whiteness; while statuary marble, equal to the best Italian kind, is found about 15 miles north of Mandalay, and east of the Irawadi. Mines of amber are wrought, among other places, at Hukhong or Payendwen, near the sources of Kyen-dwen. Nitre, natron, and salt are found in various quarters. Sulphur also occurs in some places, as in the district of Sale-Myo, and in the neighbourhood of the petroleum wells; but the quantity is comparatively small. Coal has been discovered in various places, and seems likely to prove the most valuable mineral of Upper Burma. Petroleum is found in Kyauk-hpyu, the Boronga Islands, Thayet-myo, and Ye-nyaungyaung. The precious stones produced are chiefly the sapphire and the ruby. They are found about 60 or 70 miles in a north-east direction from Mandalay, over an area of about 100 square miles.

In Lower Burma, agriculture is the main employment of the people, and it may be assumed that the production and distribution of rice occupies three-fifths of the whole population. Cotton, sesamum, and tobacco are also extensively grown; gardens and orchards are found near every village; but rice covers about six-sevenths of the total area under cultivation. The enormous foreign demand, and the large profits recently obtained, have greatly increased the cultivation of the cereal. The Burmese are content with a single annual crop, corresponding with the aman ropa of Bengal. It is sown in June, transplanted in September, and reaped about December or January. Their soil is lavish in its yield, requires little labour, and no artificial stimulus beyond the ash of the past year's stubble, which is burned down and worked into the land. Year after year, without a rest, the heavy rains and this primitive manure suffice to ensure an abundant harvest. The Irawadi valley and its delta furnish about three-fifths of the whole rice produce.

The commercial prosperity of Lower Burma has more than kept pace with its rapidly-increasing population. Rangoon absorbs about 90 per cent. of the whole foreign import trade, and about 60 per cent. of the foreign export trade. The chief articles exported are rice, timber, cutch, hides, petroleum, and precious stones. The chief imports are piece-goods, silk, cotton and wool, cotton twist, gunny-bags, betel-nuts, liquors, tobacco, iron, mill machinery, and sugar.

The main commercial industries are those connected with the rice and timber trade. The indigenous manufactures of the country produce little beyond what is required for home consumption. Silk, lacquered ware, and gold and silver work, are among the most justly-admired of Burmese manufactures. The characteristics of Burmese art are vigour and novelty of design, but want of delicacy and finish in execution.

The dynasty which till recently reigned in Upper Burma was founded in the year 1752 A.D., by Alaungpaya, who, in early life a hunter, then a dacoit leader, established himself on the throne and extended his authority over the whole of Burma, including Arakan, Pegu, and Tenasserim, to the sea and the borders of Siam. The early relations of the House of Alaungpaya with the Indian Government are matters of history. In the reign of Bagyidawpaya, the seventh king and fourth in descent from Alaungpaya, occurred the first war between England and Burma, terminated in 1826 by the treaty of Yandabo, whereby the provinces of Arakan and Tenasserim were ceded to the British. In the reign of Bagyidawpaya's nephew, Pagan Min, occurred the second Burmese war, at the conclusion of which, in December, 1832, Lord Dalhousie by proclamation annexed to the Indian Empire the province of Pegu, including the deltas of the Irawadi and the Sittaung, and the valleys of those rivers as far north as the parallel of latitude six miles north of the fort at Myede. Ten years later the province was organised, and a Chief Commissioner appointed. The territory which remained to the Burmese king was the country now known as Upper Burma. The pacification of the newly-acquired province of Pegu was a work of much labour, and was not satisfactorily completed till ten years after the annexation.

Almost immediately after the end of the second war, Pagan Min was deposed by his brother, thenceforward known as Mindon Min, or King Mindon. Mindon Min was an enlightened prince who, while professing no love for the British, recognised the power of the British government, was always careful to keep on friendly terms with them, and was anxious to introduce into his kingdom, as far as was compatible with the maintenance of his own autocratic power, Western ideas and Western civilisation. He sent envoys to Europe to study the arts and manufactures of European nations; and, throughout his reign, young representatives of the families of leading men about the court were sent to England, France, and Italy, to study the languages and manners of those countries. Though the king's zeal was not always tempered by discretion, he did much to increase the revenue of the crown, and to promote the commercial prosperity of his country. In 1867, a treaty was concluded at Mandalay between the British and Burmese governments, providing for the mutual extradition of criminals, the free intercourse of traders, and the establishment of permanent diplomatic relations between the two countries. So long as Mindon Min lived, though he clung to the obsolete ceremonials to which he was accustomed, and thus debarred the British resident at Mandalay in his later years from access
to his presence, there was no breach in the friendship between England and Burma.

In October, 1878, Mindon Min died, and was succeeded by his son, the Thebaw prince. Early in 1879, the execution of a number of the members of the royal family at Mandalay excited much horror in Lower Burma. Executions of this kind were the usual incidents of a change in the occupancy of the throne of Ava. But, hitherto, owing to the remoteness of the capital of the Burmese kingdom from our own territories and to difficulty of communication, these relics of barbarism had not been forcibly presented before the eyes of the civilised world. In 1879 a British resident was stationed at Mandalay, telegraphic communication was open between Upper and Lower Burma, and trading steamers passed constantly between Mandalay and Rangoon. The cruelties which marked the accession of the new monarch attracted more notice than on previous similar occasions. The British resident was instrumental in securing the escape of some members of the royal family, and was energetic in his protests against the barbarities with which the new reign was ushered in. Indignation among Englishmen at the state of affairs in Mandalay, and resentment in the minds of the courtiers of the king on account of the attitude of the resident, combined to render imminent a breach of the friendly relations between the two countries. The immediate apprehension of war passed away; but throughout the year the tension continued, and in October, 1879, in view of the passive unfriendliness of the Burmese government, and the unsatisfactory nature of the position of the British resident in Mandalay, the government of India withdrew their representative from the Burmese court, and, as long as the native government continued to exist, no fresh agent was appointed.

These occurrences were sinister omens for the reign of King Thebaw. Nor did the progress of events afford prospect of the re-settlement of the relations between the Indian and Burmese governments. Although upon two occasions—once in 1879-80 by means of an envoy who, not being accredited with full powers, was not permitted to proceed beyond Thayetmyo; and once in 1882, when an embassy visited Simla—attempts were made to re-establish cordial relations on a satisfactory footing, there was no real restoration of confidence and good feeling between 1879 and 1886. The action of the Burmese government gave much reason for complaint. British subjects, travellers and traders from Lower Burma, were subjected to insult and violence by local officials in Upper Burma, and representations to the central administration were often fruitless in obtaining redress. In contravention of the express terms of the treaty of 1867, monopolies were created to the detriment of the trade of both England and Burma. Owing to the weakness and corruption of the Burmese government, society became thoroughly disorganised, and the elements of disorder on our frontier became a standing menace to the peace of the British provinces. At the same time, the Burmese government showed a marked and persistent anxiety to enter into alliances with foreign powers, in such a manner and to such an extent as to give ground for apprehension that grave political trouble might hereafter result. While the Indian government was unrepresented at Mandalay, representatives of Italy and France were welcomed, and two separate embassies were sent to Europe, one under the guise of a merely commercial mission, for the purpose of contracting new and, if possible, close alliances with sundry European powers. Neither of these missions visited England, or showed any desire to win the friendship of the representatives of the British government residing at the courts to which the Burmese envoys were accredited.

Notwithstanding these grounds of complaint,—though frequently and vehemently urged to interfere in the interests of the peace and commerce of British Burma—the government of India from time to time, on review of the situation, found it unsatisfactory, but not yet intolerable, and decided that interposition in the domestic administration of Upper Burma was not necessary. Such was the state of affairs at the beginning of 1885. Early in that year, the Burmese government found or made reason for complaint against the Bombay-Burma Trading Corporation, a company of merchants, chiefly British subjects, who had extensive dealings in Upper Burma. The claim which the government advanced against the corporation was for several lakhs of rupees. In view of the magnitude of the interests which the corporation had at stake, the chief commissioner addressed the Burmese government for the purpose of securing an impartial investigation of the cause of complaint. Disregarding this attempt at mediation, the Burmese council decided the case against the corporation without giving them reasonable opportunity of being heard, and condemned them to pay a fine amounting to £230,000. Acting under the orders of the supreme government, the chief commissioner protested against this arbitrary act of the Burmese authorities, and invited them to stay proceedings against the corporation, and to refer the matter to an arbitrator appointed by His Excellency the Viceroy. The reply of the Burmese foreign minister was that on no account should proceedings against the corporation be suspended. In view of this decisive and discourteous refusal to accept the mediation of the British government in a case where the interests of British subjects were largely involved—and bearing in mind the accumulated causes of dissatisfaction with the existing state of things—the government of India decided once for all to adjust the relations between the two countries. The chief commissioner was therefore instructed to send to the King of Burma an ultimatum requiring him to suspend action in the execution of the decree against the corporation, to receive at Mandalay an envoy from the Viceroy with a view to the settlement of the matter at issue, and, hereafter, to permit the residence at the capital of an agent of the Indian government, who should be received and treated with the respect due to the government which he represented. It was further intimated that the Burmese government would in future be required to regulate the external relations of the country in accordance with the advice of the government of India, and to afford facilities for opening up British trade with China. A letter embodying these terms was despatched by special steamer to Mandalay on the 22nd October, 1885. The Burmese government were informed that a reply must be received not later than the 10th November, and that, unless the conditions laid down were accepted without reserve the Indian
government would deal with the matter as it thought fit. In view of the possible refusal by the Burmese government of the terms offered to them, preparations were made for the despatch to Rangoon of a military force of 10,000 men. On the 9th November, a reply, amounting to an unconditional refusal of the terms, was received in Rangoon. On the 7th November, three days after the date of the reply from the Burmese minister, and two days before the receipt by the chief commissioner of that reply, the King of Burma issued a proclamation calling on his subjects to rally round him, and to resist the unjust demands of the British government, and expressing his determination to efface these heretic foreigners and conquer and annex their country. In accordance with the terms of the ultimatum, and in view of the hostile tone of the king's proclamation, the expeditionary force was ordered to advance. The frontier was crossed on the 14th November, 1885. On the 17th, Minhla, on the 23rd, Pagan, and on the 25th, Myingyan, were successively occupied. Except at Minhla, scarcely any resistance was encountered. Before the expeditionary force reached Ava, an envoy from the Burmese court arrived, and, after some negotiation, the unconditional surrender of the capital and of the royal family was arranged. On the 26th and 27th November, the forts at Ava and Sagaing were surrendered; and, on the 28th, General Prendergast and his force occupied Mandalay. The king and his two queens, with their mother, were at once sent down to Rangoon, whence the former were afterwards transferred to India, the latter to Tavoy. Simultaneously with the advance on Mandalay, operations were undertaken with success on the Thayetmyo and Toungoo frontiers.

Immediately after the occupation of Mandalay a provisional administration was constituted. All the members of the Hlutdaw, or great Council of State, professed themselves willing to continue to take part in the government. They were therefore retained in office, under the guidance of Colonel (now Sir E. B.) Sladen, and the control of General (now Sir Harry) Prendergast. Theoretically there was to be no breach of continuity. The state council was to continue to discharge all its functions, and all civil officers, whether British or Burmese, were to work under its direction. The council began by issuing proclamations to this effect, and ordering Burmese officials to continue in the regular performance of their duties.

On the 15th December, 1885, the chief commissioner arrived at Mandalay, and assumed charge of the civil administration. On the 1st January, 1886, by the Viceroy's proclamation, Upper Burma, was declared to be part of Her Majesty's dominions, and placed under the direct administration of the governor-general. The shape which the settlement of Upper Burma should take was not at that time finally determined; but, after the visit of the Viceroy to Mandalay, it was resolved to incorporate Upper Burma in British India, and this was effected by command of Her Majesty with reference to the statute 21 and 22 Vic., c. 106. From the 1st March, Upper Burma, with the exception of the Shan States, was constituted a scheduled district under the statute 33 Vic., c. 3.

The constitution of Upper Burma into a scheduled district removed it from the operation of the statute law, which applies to the rest of the empire. It was clearly impossible that, under the conditions subject to which the administration was being carried on, the whole body of the Indian civil and criminal law should be at once introduced into Upper Burma. The condition of the law in that province between March and November, 1886, resembled that which prevailed in the Punjab for several years after its annexation, in that the civil administration of the country was being conducted under instructions issued by the Chief Commissioner. By these instructions, civil officers were enjoined to be guided, as far as possible, by the provisions of the Indian Penal and Procedure Codes, and in matters relating to marriage, succession, &c., to be guided by personal law and local custom, or, in the absence of these, by justice, equity, and good conscience. The 'Upper Burma Laws Act' passed by the Governor-Generals Council, September, 1886, was the first stage in the process of suspending these provisional arrangements by laws formerly enacted. It was the necessary preliminary to the further legislation for the province which was to be effected by regulations made by the Governor-General in Council, as empowered by Statute 33 Vict. c. 3, under the operation of which Upper Burma had been brought. The Laws Act defined the province of Burma, distinguishing between its two divisions of Upper and Lower Burma; and it declared the Indian enactments which were to be in force in Upper Burma.

The administration of the province was further placed during 1886–7 upon a legal basis by the enactment of Regulations, under the Statute 33 Vict. c. 3, Sec. 1, relating to Registration, Municipalities, Forests, Revenue Stamps, and Village Officers. The Revenue Regulation provided merely for the realisation of Government dues. The large question of the revenue administration of the country is under consideration; no radical change and no permanent adoption of the existing revenue arrangements will be attempted until the fullest information is obtained. The Village Regulation gave the headmen the position and the powers which they have exercised under the ancient régime as near as may be, and it enforced with much strictness the joint responsibility of the village in criminal matters. This is in accordance with the practice of Burma. The Regulation has strengthened the hands of the district officers, and assisted them to maintain order. Under this Regulation a great many petty criminal cases can be disposed of by the Village Officers, who are also responsible for taking immediate action, and for reporting to the nearest police station in the case of heinous crime.

The military occupation of Mandalay was effected without the smallest difficulty, and in a manner which reflected credit on all concerned. To this, as was foreseen, succeeded a period of disorder and of straggling warfare which assumed dimensions somewhat, though not materially, exceeding what was anticipated. The same difficulties, however, were encountered upon the annexation of Lower Burma, and were not finally overcome for a period of eight years after the occupation of that province, although the general pacification of the country may be said to have been effected at the end of the third year.

The province of Upper Burma has an area
larger than that of France, and contains a population which has been roughly computed at 4,000,000.* A considerable portion of this vast expanse is impenetrable jungle, and even in the more thickly populated districts there were, at the date of the annexation of the country, no proper roads or bridges. During the rainy season the difficulties of communication are very much increased by the sudden rise of the rivers and numerous streams which intersect the country in all directions, and often for weeks at a time large tracts remain under water. The population, though it cannot be described as warlike in the ordinary sense of the term, has a traditional and deep-rooted love of desultory fighting, raiding, gang-robbery, and similar kinds of excitement. Villages had long standing feuds with villages, and many young peasants, otherwise respectable, spent a season or two as dacoits without losing their reputation in the eyes of their fellow-villagers. If there were any under the old régime who had scruples about engaging in dacoity pure and simple, they always had plenty of opportunity for leading a very similar mode of life as partisans of one of the numerous pretenders to the throne, one or more of whom were generally in open revolt against the de facto sovereign. As the monarchy was hereditary only in the sense of being confined to the members of a particular family—the descendants of the famous Alompra—each scion of the royal line considered himself justified in raising the banner of insurrection if he imagined that he had a fair chance of success, and he could generally plead in justification of his conduct that his successful rival on the throne had endeavoured to put him and all his near male relations to death. These various elements of anarchy no King of Burma was ever able to suppress. Sometimes a sovereign of unusual energy obtained comparative tranquility for a short period by executing or imprisoning all his more formidable rivals, and by employing energetic leaders who could break up the larger gangs of dacoits; but such periods of tranquility were never of very long duration.

King Thebaw was in administrative capacity below rather than above the average of Burmese sovereigns. In his reign the authority of the Government did not extend much beyond the district of Mandalay and the immediate vicinity of the main channels of communication, and even within this limited area there was always a very large amount of anarchy and maladministration. Not a few of the men who had been raised to high office by the favour of the Court of Mandalay were in league with the dacoit leaders who roamed about Thebaw's dominions and occasionally threatened the tranquility of the contiguous British districts.

These numerous difficulties, inherent in the nature of the country, in the character of the people, and in the existing political organisation, were considerably augmented by the manner in which the overthrow of Thebaw was effected. The care and completeness with which the expedition had been prepared by the departmental and local authorities, and the promptitude and accuracy with which the plan was executed by General Prendergast and his subordinates, made all serious resistance impossible, and when our troops arrived in Mandalay after an almost bloodless campaign of a few days' duration, they found that nearly the whole of the undisciplined levies called out to oppose our advance had spontaneously melted away. This easy and rapid success, though in many respects most fortunate, tended greatly to retard the work of permanent pacification. The inordinate national vanity which forms a prominent trait of their character had preserved among the Burmese a vivid recollection of the period when they were a conquering race, very formidable to Shans, Kachins, Assamese, and other neighbouring tribes, and has enabled them to forget the reverses which they have since suffered from British and Indian troops. Unable to comprehend that their country could be permanently conquered by a ten days' campaign, they naturally regarded the dethronement and deportation of Thebaw as merely one of those 'royal incidents' to which they had been long accustomed, and to which they attributed very little significance. Without some more tangible and striking proof of the power and intentions of the invaders, they were not to be convinced by declarations or proclamations that, through the folly of their rulers, the old order of things had come to an end. This national feeling, however, savoured much more of childish vanity than of stern patriotism, and it rarely assumed an aggressive form. The ordinary villagers and townsfolk, that is to say the great mass of the people, when not afraid of subsequent vengeance at the hands of insurgent leaders, generally received British officers and troops in the light-hearted friendly spirit which endears the Burmese to all foreigners who come in contact with them. Even in those localities where our troops met with some show of resistance there were no symptoms of fanaticism, political or religious; and in Mandalay itself, and in all the tranquillised districts, our officers were able to move about without fear of assassination. At the same time this feeling of national vanity, or whatever else it may be called, in conjunction with the rapidity and bloodlessness of the initial campaign, enabled the gang leaders and other ambitious chiefs both to augment the number of their adherents, and to establish at various points a good many centres of resistance to our rule. If the Burmese had been from the first duly conscious of their own national weakness, or if an adequate impression of our power had been made on the popular imagination by one or two decisive battles, they might have been more capable of understanding the real situation, and more disposed to recognise that for themselves and their country immediate submission was the wisest and most patriotic course.

The subsequent history of the pacification of Upper Burma consists of the measures taken to establish order in the country and to enter into favourable relations with the Shan States. In the Autumn of 1886, a large addition was made to the military garrison, which was raised to about 24,000 men. In the Summer of the following year, however, the garrison was somewhat reduced, and certain posts were taken over by the military police. There had been little loss to our troops from the enemy, but there had been much sickness. In the cold season of 1887-88, operations were again actively carried on in the districts where large rebel bands still remained. The two Shan columns visited all the chief Shan States, and chiefs west

---

* Burma Blue Book, c. 4952, p. 103.
of the Salween River. Over the whole of this vast tract the Shan political agent received the personal submission of all the principal Sawbwas, confirmed them in their positions as tributary chiefs, settled their relations with the Government and with each other, fixed the amount of tribute to be paid by each chief, and succeeded in placing the administration of the States on a satisfactory footing. The result is that the supremacy of the British Government is cordially acknowledged throughout this vast tract of country, tribal disputes are referred to the arbitration of the superintendent, and fighting between individual States is strictly forbidden. This result was attained without a single attack on our columns, and almost without firing a shot.

Before the rainy season of 1838, all the districts of Upper Burma, except two, namely, Sagaing and Minbu, had been pacified.

The only expeditions in 1838-9 on which considerable military force was required were in wild tracts outside the borders of Burma proper, namely:

(a) The two expeditions through the Southern and the Northern Shan States;
(b) The expedition into Karennee;
(c) The operations in the Mogoung district;
(d) The expedition against Kachin rebels in the Bhamo district;
(e) The expedition against the Chin tribes.

The two expeditions in the Shan States occupied several months. The political officers, accompanied by adequate escorts, visited and received the submission of all the important and most of the lesser Shan States on the right bank (to the west) of the Salween river. The British representatives were well received everywhere, and the Shans fraternised with the Indian soldiers of the escort.

The expedition into Karennee was undertaken because the Chief would not desist from attacking neighbouring Shan States, and would in no way acknowledge British supremacy or accept friendly overtures. The Karennees, or Red Karens, dwell in a mountain country, and were famed for their courage; after one small action their resistance ceased.

The Mogoung district, whence come large exports of jade-stone, rubber, and teak is dominated for the most part by Chin tribes; the tract was never reduced and was hardly occupied by the Burmans. The Chins consist of brave highland clans, allied to if not identical with the Singphos of the Patkoi range in Assam. A force penetrated to the jade mines, and some desultory fighting occurred. British influence is gradually extending, but the wilds in that direction are not yet pacified.

The expeditions against Chins in the Bhamo district were undertaken to put down raiders on British villages and on caravans. Some progress has been made in pacifying the Chins of that quarter, and in relieving the anxieties of Bhamo traders.

The expedition against the Chin tribes was a more serious affair. These tribes are the congeners of the Kukis and Lushais, who even at the present time harry British villages in the eastern frontier of Bengal; they occupy the hilly country which stretches nearly 200 miles from the Chittagong border on the west, to the Chindwin river on the east, and about the same distance north and south from Manipur to the bank of the Irrawaddy plain. The hills reach to 7,000 feet in height, the valleys are deep and narrow, and there is, so far as the region has been explored, no level country. The Chin tribes make their homes during the rainy season on the hill ridges; and in the dry weather they have from time immemorial raided on the Irrawaddy and Chindwin plains, burning villages, killing men and children, and carrying off the women captives. In Burman times little was done to check the Chin raids; their ruthless deeds were much dreaded by the plainsmen; and broad tracts like the Tamu valley were practically depopulated by their incursions.

The Chins continued to raid after British power had been established, they repelled all friendly advances by British officers, and they gave asylum and support to Burmese pretenders who made the Chin hills a starting ground for their attacks on British districts. An expedition was therefore sent into the Chin country, more especially against certain tribes that had been prominent in their hostility. The physical features of the country, the forest, and the lack of even footpaths made marching difficult; but in the end considerable loss was inflicted on the Chins; two of the principal tribes made submission, surrendered their captives and plunder.

In the interior of Upper Burma the work of settling the country has proceeded. In the 17 districts of Upper Burma proper, not including the Shan States, the only tracts which are still more or less disturbed are parts of Bhamo and Mogoung on the Kachin border; parts of Pokoko and the Chindwin on the Chin border; the rugged country round Popa Hill, in the Myingyan district, and parts of the Minbu and Magwe districts.

In the year 1837-83 the military garrison of Upper Burma consisted of 26,400 men of all ranks, of whom 4,300 were Europeans; and more than 150 cantonments and ports were at one time occupied by troops. It has been found possible in the past year to reduce the military garrison of Upper Burma to about 12,000 men, distributed in 30 cantonments and outposts; to unite all troops in Upper and Lower Burma under one General, and to reduce considerably the complement of staff officers. Most of the work previously done by regular troops in the interior, and much of the frontier work have been undertaken by the police, of whom 17,000 have been enrolled. Out of these about 14,000 belong to the best fighting races of India, are armed and drilled like regular troops, are distributed in battalions and companies, and are commanded by European officers. The remainder of the police are Burmans, Shans, and Karens.

By the middle of 1839 all the large gangs of rebels that had given trouble in the plains were completely broken up and the remnants of once powerful bands had taken refuge in the inaccessible broken tracts which form a marked feature of the upper country. Under the altered conditions of things columns of troops were no longer required to scour the country and attack strong bands of rebels. The military garrison was reduced by 7,000 men and numerous military posts were withdrawn. The posts of military police had also been reduced from 192 to 173 before the end of 1839, and the police force thus set free was able to pursue the broken remnants of the various gangs and make a vigorous effort to stamp them out completely. Whilst every effort was being made in the plains to stamp out
the remnants of the rebel gangs, expeditions were undertaken in more remote regions. The operations against the Chin tribes were continued, and the pacification of the less warlike Chinhoks was secured by the Chin battalion of military police. The Shan States remained almost undisturbed throughout the year.

At the same time measures were taken for improving the administration of the country and developing trade, and the pacification of the country made it possible to extend a larger measure of clemency than had hitherto been possible to the prisoners who had been convicted in the early days of the occupation. Over 1,000 of such prisoners were released during the year. The revenue administration was further improved and a small beginning was made in the work of introducing an educational system into the country.

Upper Burma, though inferior in point of fertility to the low-lying tracts of Lower Burma, is far from unproductive. The chief crops are rice (of which the Burmese count 102 different sorts), maize, millet, wheat, various pulses, tobacco, cotton, sesamum, mustard, and indigo. The sugar-cane appears to have been long known to the Burmese; but, though the climate and soil are extremely favourable, it is not generally cultivated. A cheap and coarse sugar is obtained from the juice of the Palmyra palm, which abounds in the tract south of Mandalay. The cocoa-nut and areca palms are not common. The tea-plant, which is indigenous, is cultivated in the hills by some of the mountain tribes at the distance of about five days' journey, and by others in still greater perfection at the distance of about ten days' journey from Mandalay. It seems, however, to be another plant, probably the Elaeodendron persicum, which furnishes the principal ingredient in the hlapef, or pickled tea, that forms a favourite Burmese delicacy, and is an essential accompaniment to every social or ceremonial incident. Cotton is grown in every part of the kingdom and its dependencies, but chiefly in the dry lands and climate of the upper districts. Indigo is indigenous, and is universally cultivated, but in a very rude manner; it is still more rudely manufactured, so as to be wholly unfit for exportation abroad.

One of the most urgent wants of the country is land communication. There is abundance of waterway, however, throughout the delta all the year round, but the Sittang valley has no such advantages.

The railway from Toungoo (the then terminus of the Sittang Valley line), for which a preliminary survey was sanctioned in November, 1886, was opened for traffic in March, 1889. The cost per mile was Rx. 9,300. The construction was begun when that part of the country was greatly disturbed; survey parties and working parties were carefully guarded; and no successful attacks were made upon the labourers or the work. The construction gave employment and wages to a large number of Burmans, at a time when the labouring classes would have been otherwise in great straits. Since the railway was opened the districts through which it runs have been the quietest in Upper Burma. The traffic on the line is already considerable. Large outlay has been incurred and still continues upon barracks, hospitals, roads, and necessary civil buildings; the best way of quieting the border highlands will be to pierce them with roads as funds are available.

A valuable test of the improved state of the country is the revenue collected, and the returns everywhere show a satisfactory increase. The revenue under the principal heads has been:

| Year | Land Revenue | Stamps | Excise |
|------|--------------|--------|--------|
| 1888-89 | 436,540 | 13,848 | 43,669 |
| 1889-90 | 539,524 | 19,863 | 45,591 |

Difference +102,984 +6,015 +1,922

In 1888-89 the total revenue amounted to Rx. 768,345; in 1889-90 it rose to Rx. 1,010,315. Rx. 126,497 of the receipts of the last financial year are due to the railway, and cannot be taken into account for the purposes of comparison. After deducting this amount there still remains a surplus of Rx. 105,472 over the revenue of 1888-89. Everywhere it is reported that cultivation is extending, lands abandoned during the disturbances are being taken up, and jungle land being broken up. In 1888-89 the number of houses assessed to the capitation or house-tax had risen to 323,693 from 286,571 in the previous year. The house-tax figures of the year 1889-90 are not yet fully known, but they will probably show a further increase over those of 1888-89.

NATIVE STATES.

That the territories of the Native States of India occupy no small proportion of the entire Indian peninsula and contain about one-fifth of the whole population of the country will be seen from the statistical table printed at page

Many of the Feudatory States are governed almost independently by their own rulers, but they are all subject in a greater or less degree to supervision and guidance at the hands of the British Government. They may be divided into two main heads: (1) States holding direct relations with the Governor-General in Council; and (2) States holding relations primarily with the several Local Governments of India.

STATES UNDER THE DIRECT SUPERVISION OF THE GOVERNOR-GENERAL IN COUNCIL.

1. Hyderabad.—The Hyderabad State is roughly co-extensive with the Deccan or central plateau of Southern India and takes its name from its capital city. With the exception of the assigned districts known as Berar, a tract of some 17,000 square miles, the whole of this province is governed by the Nizam. The total area including Berar is about 98,000 square miles, and the population is estimated to be about 12½ millions, one-tenth being Muhammadans. The ruling dynasty is of Turkoman origin, the name of the first Sovereign being Chin Killich Khan, also known as Asaf Jah, who was appointed to be Viceroy of the Deccan by the Mogal Emperor Aurungzeb in the year 1713. During the dissensions in the Empire subsequent to the death of Aurungzeb, Asaf Jah succeeded in asserting his own independence. The Assigned Districts of Berar are administered by British officers in trust for the Nizam, and the Government maintains out of their revenues an auxiliary force
of four cavalry regiments, four field batteries of artillery, and six regiments of infantry. The raison d'être of this force was primarily that it might be of use to the Nizam, but it is available also under treaty for general service with British troops when required. The surplus revenue derived from Berar, after paying for the cost of the administration, is paid to the Nizam's Government, and now amounts to nearly 20 lakhs of rupees per annum.

2. Mysore.—The Mysore State is situated in Southern India between $11^\circ 40'$ and $15^\circ$ N. lat., and between $74^\circ 40'$ and $78^\circ 30'$ E. long., and is surrounded on all sides by British territory. Its total area is 24,723 square miles, and it contains a population of over 4 millions. The inhabitants are almost exclusively Hindus, who constitute more than 94 per cent. of the whole population. In early times Mysore was the principal seat of the Jains, who have left many interesting memorials of their occupation. The State has always been under Hindu rulers except during the short interval caused by the usurpation of power during the 18th century by Haidar Ali and his son, Tippu Sultan. After the defeat of the latter, at the siege of Seringapatam in 1799, A.D., the English restored a representative of the ancient line in the person of Krishna Raj, son of Chama Raj of Arakotara. His subsequent misrule, when admitted to power on attaining his majority, led to the resumption of the administrative control of the province by the British Government in the year 1831. The government, however, continued to be carried on in the name of the Native Prince, and at his death an adopted son was recognised as successor. This Chief was duly installed on coming of age in 1831. The British Chief Commissioner thereupon handed over office to the Native Diwan, and a Political Resident was appointed to represent British interests.

3. Baroda.—This State includes all the territories of his Highness the Gaekwar. Its total area is 8,570 square miles, and it contains a population of 2,185,000 souls, the majority of whom, over 89 per cent. are Hindus. The province of Guzerat was at one time included in the Mogal Empire, but, in the early part of the seventeenth century, the Mahrattas, under the leadership of Damaji Gaekwar, and afterwards of his son, Pilaji, succeeded in wresting all power out of the hands of the Mogal officers. From that time Baroda has remained continuously under the sway of the Gaekwar family, who held it in the first instance under the Mahratta Peshwa subject to a tributary payment, but afterwards threw off their allegiance and became feudatory to the British Government under the guarantee of a treaty executed in the year 1817. The British Government is represented at the Court of the Baroda State by a Political Officer, called the Governor-General's Agent.

4. Kashmir and Jammu.—This Native State includes, in addition to the district of Kashmir proper, Jammu, Punch, and the Governorships of Ladakh and Gilgit. The area is estimated to be 80,900 square miles. There has been no census since the year 1873, but the population may be roughly stated at 1,600,000. Kashmir became part of the Mogal Empire in 1586 A.D., but it was afterwards subjugated both by the Afghans and the Sikhs. At the time of the Sikh War the State was under the government of Gulab Singh, a Sikh officer, who ruled as a feudatory of the Maharaja of the Punjab. After the victory of the British forces in 1846, the possession of the kingdom was confirmed to Gulab Singh, under certain specified conditions of alliance and subordinate co-operation, by a separate treaty executed at Amritsar in the same year. A Political Resident is permanently stationed with the head-quarters of the Kashmir State to represent the authority of the Governor-General, and to carry on the political relations between the two Governments. The Maharaja pays a small annual tribute in token of the supremacy of the British power. The ruling family is Hindu, but the greater number of the inhabitants of the country, considerably more than half, are Muhammadans, and chiefly of the Sunni sect.

5. Kalat.—The Khan of Kalat is head of the Baluchistan tribal chiefs whose territories are comprised under the following divisions:—Jhalawan, Sarawan, Makran, Las, and Kachh Gandava. These districts form what may be termed Kalati Baluchistan, and occupy an area of about 80,000 square miles. The inhabitants of the country are either Brahuis or Baluchis, both being Muhammadans of the Sunni sect. The country is sparsely populated, the total number being roughly estimated at 350,000 persons only. It derives its chief importance from its position with regard to Afghanistan on the North-Western Frontier of British India. The Khan of Kalat is under a treaty obligation of subordinate cooperation with the British Government. The Governor-General's Agent in Baluchistan is the Political Officer who conducts the relations between the Government of India and the Khan.

6. Rajputana Agency.—Rajputana is the name of a great territorial circle, situated between $23^\circ$ and $30^\circ$ N. lat., and between $69^\circ 30'$ and $78^\circ 15'$ E. long. Within these limits are twenty Native States, having each its own autonomy and separate Chief, together with the British district of Ajmere-Merwara. Of the Native States, 17 are Rajput, 2 are Jat, Bharpur and Dholpur, and 1 only is Muhammadan, Tonk. Their combined area is about 130,000 square miles, and they contain a population of over 10 millions. The chief administrative control of the British District is vested ex officio in the Political Officer, who holds the post of Governor-General's Agent for the supervision of the relations between the several Native States of Rajputana and the Government of India.

7. **Central India Agency**.—Central India is the name given to the country occupied by the Native States grouped together under the supervision of the Political Officer in charge of the Central India Agency. These States lie between 21° 24' and 26° 32' N. lat., and between 74° 0' and 83° 0' E. long. The British Districts of Jhansi and Lalitpur divide the Agency into two main divisions—Native Bundelkhand and Baghelkhand lying to the east, and Central India proper to the west. The total area covered is not less than 75,000 square miles, and the population amounts to over 9 millions. The great majority of the people are Hindus. The principal States are 6 in Number—Gwalior, Indore, Bhopal, Rewa, Dhar, and Jaora, of which two, Bhopal and Jaora, are Muhammadan, and the rest are Hindu. Besides these there are a multitude of petty States held by their rulers under the immediate guarantee of the British Government, but having feudal relations with one or other of the larger States. The total number of States amounts to 69, and the petty Chiefships to 79—total, 148.

**STATES UNDER THE LOCAL GOVERNMENTS AND ADMINISTRATIONS.**

1. **Under the Government of Madras**.—The Madras Presidency includes five Native States covering an area of 9,638 square miles, with a population of 3,344,349 souls. Revenue, £921,300.

Of these States, Travancore and Cochin represent ancient Hindu dynasties. Pudukota is the inheritance of a Chieftain called Tondiman. Banganapalli and Sandur, two petty States, of which the first is ruled by a Nawab, lie in the centre of two British districts. The principal States are:

2. Under the Government of Bombay.—The Native States in this Presidency number about 370. Area, 71,935 square miles. Population, 6,976,109. Revenue, £2,996,000.

The characteristic feature of the Bombay States is the excessive number of petty principalities, governed mostly by Rajput and Bhil Chieftains. The Peninsula of Kathiawar alone contains no less than 188 separate States. The recognition of these innumerable jurisdictions is due partly to the circumstance that the early Bombay Administrators were induced to treat the de facto exercise of civil and criminal jurisdiction by a landholder as carrying with it a quasi-sovereign status, and partly to the fact that some of the minor States have at various times been partitioned amongst members of the ruling families.

3. Under the Government of Bengal there are twenty-nine States. Area, 39,234 square miles. Population, 2,853,405. Revenue, £245,900.

These States may be divided into two groups: the first consisting of the petty States attached to the Orissa and Chota Nagpur Divisions, 26 in number; and the other comprising the States of Kuch Behar and Sikkim to the north, and Hill Tipperah to the east of Bengal. The inhabitants of the first group are hillmen of Kolarian or Dravidian origin, and their condition is still very primitive. Kuch Behar is inhabited by an Indo-Chinese people, the Koch. The population of Sikkim consists of Lepchas, Bhutias and Limbus. Hill Tipperah is the home of a race, partly Indo-Burmese, and partly drawn from the Eastern Himalayas.

| Tehri (Garhwal) | 1,180 | 199,836    | £14,200 |

Rampur is nearly equally divided between Muhammadans and Hindus. The inhabitants of Tehri are chiefly Hindus.

5. Under the Government of the Punjab there are thirty-four States, varying considerably in size and importance. Area, 35,817 square miles. Population, 3,361,683. Revenue, £1,119,100.

The Punjab States may be grouped under three main classes. The Hill States, 23 in number, lying among the Punjab Himalayas and held by some of the most ancient Rajput families in all India. Along the western half of the southern border lies the Muhammadan State of Bahawalpur. The remaining States, including the Sikh Principalities of Patiala, Jind, Nabha, Kapurthala, Faridkot and Kalsia, and the Muhammadan Chiefships of Maler Kotla, Pataudi, Loharu and Dujana, lie east of Lahore, and, with insignificant exceptions, occupy the centre of the eastern plains of the province.

The list below gives details of the area, population, and revenue of the more important States:

| Patiala            | 5,887  | 1,467,433  | £493,346|
| Sarmur (Nahan)     | 1,077  | 112,371    | £21,000 |

6. Under the Chief Commissioner of the Central Provinces are fifteen States. None of them is of any size or importance. Their total area is 28,834 square miles, with a population of 1,709,720 persons. Revenue, £77,700. The inhabitants are chiefly Hindus and aborigines.

7. Under the Chief Commissioner of Assam there is only one State—Manipur. Its area is 8,000 square miles, and it has a population of 220,000, principally Hindus. Revenue, £9,000.

8. Under the Chief Commissioner of Burma there are some Shan States and other petty Chiefships, the population and revenue of which are at present unknown.

RECORD

OF THE

PUBLIC SERVICES OF OFFICERS AND OTHERS.

[The following List includes Officers of the Home Establishment of the Secretary of State, Officers of the Covenanted Civil Service, and those appointed under the Native Civil Service Rules, other Officers in Civil Employment in India whose SUBSTANTIVE pay is at least Rs. 1,000 a month, and Officers of those classes who have retired since 1886. It has not been found practicable to include more than a limited number of the Officers still surviving who retired before 1886.]
THE INDIA OFFICE LIST.

RECORD OF THE PUBLIC SERVICES OF OFFICERS AND OTHERS.

DESCRIPTION OF SERVICES.

ABBOTT, Henry B., Lieutenant-Colonel Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1861; arrived in India, Nov., 1861; served with the 109th foot; served as assistant resident, Aden, 1865 to 1869; from Oct., 1869, to Feb., 1874, served as assistant agent, Rajputana, and acted as magistrate of Abu, and assistant general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti department, 1872-73; officiating settlement officer, Ulwur, 1874-75; officiating political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, 1875; political assistant, Maunpoor, and deputy Bhel agent, 1875-76; on special duty at Jhallawar, 1876-77; superintendent of Jhallawar, from March, 1876; graded as additional political agent, 1st class.

ABDUL GHAFUR, Khan of Zaida, Punjab Commission.—Appointed probationer under native civil service rules, 14th Feb., 1889, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

ACKLON, Robert Evatt, Police Department, Government of India; appointed assistant district superintendent of police, 18th April, 1867, and district superintendent, June, 1872; appointed superintendent Rajputana-Malwa railway police, and judge of small cause court, May, 1883.

ACWORTH, Harry Arbutinot (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Brighton College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector of stamp revenue and political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; acting under secretary to government of Bombay, revenue, financial, and general departments, Oct., 1879; acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, March, 1881; from April, 1881, served as assistant collector, deputy collector, and acting junior collector of salt revenue; member of the mixed commission at Goa, Dec., 1884; deputy municipal commissioner, July, 1885; deputy collector of salt revenue, Aug., 1885; acting junior collector and magistrate, Aug., 1887; municipal commissioner for city of Bombay, April, 1890.

ADAMS, George, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Christ's Hospital; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1861; from April, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; deputy commissioner, Lalitpur, in the Jhansi commission, April, 1877; officiating commissioner, Jhansi, in 1878 and 1880; and of the Benares division, Oct., 1889; commissioner in Oudh, Nov., 1889.

ADAMSON, Charles Henry Ellison, C.I.E., Major M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, royal artillery, Jan., 1868; served with 5th brigade at Kirkee and Rangoon till 1870; admitted to the Madras staff corps, 1870; joined the Burma commission, Dec., 1871, and served as assistant magistrate, assistant commissioner, and officiating magistrate, and president of municipal committee, Rangoon; deputy commissioner June, 1885; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1885; deputy commissioner, Bhamo.; C.I.E., May, 1889.

ADAMSON, Harvey, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at the Gymnasium, Old Aberdeen, and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived at Rangoon, 17th Dec., 1877; served as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; 1st grade settlement officer, June, 1886; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, April, 1888; 3rd grade, Dec., 1888.

ADDIS, David Foullis, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Universities of Glasgow and Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, assistant settlement officer, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Dec., 1883; 1st grade, August, 1887; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1890.

AGHA ABU TURAB, Khan (North-Western Provinces).—Native civil service; appointed by the Government of India a probationer under the statutory civil service rules, 16th April, 1889.

AGNEW, Patrick Dalreagle, Bengal C.S. (Punjab)—Educated at Bedford Grammar School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India 2nd Dec., 1889, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

AGNEW, William Fischer (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Burma.—Reporter for Indian law reports, high court, Calcutta, from Feb., 1877; officiated as editor in 1879, 1882, and 1883; law lecturer, Presidency College, 1879; advocate, high court, Calcutta, 1879; recorder of Rangoon, March, 1884; officiating judge, high court, Calcutta in 1885 and 1886, author of 'Law of Patent,' The Statue of
Frauds,' 'The Law of Trusts in India,' 'The Criminal Procedure Code,' and 'Index to Indian Acts.'

AHSANUDDIN AHMAD (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Appointed assistant magistrate and collector on probation under the native civil service rules, Dec., 1881; confirmed in the statutory civil service, Oct., 1887.

AIKMAN, ROBERT SMITH, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Madras College, St. Andrew's, and St. Andrew's University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1867, and serve in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was transferred temporarily to Bengal on famine relief duty, Feb. to Oct., 1874; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, Jan., 1879; from March 1884 served in the judicial department, and was appointed judge, 3rd grade, Oct., 1886, and 2nd grade, March, 1890.

AINSLIE, WILLIAM, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1845; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments in the grades of assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector in Cuttack; and was specially employed in 1850-51 and 1851-52 in the suppression of Meriah sacrifices in the Khond districts; magistrate of Rungpore, July, 1852; railway commissioner, East Indian railway, Jan., 1856, to March, 1857; magistrate and collector, Bhagulpore, March, 1857; railway commissioner, Eastern Bengal railway, 1858, and subsequently of the South-Eastern railway also; from Aug., 1863, served in the judicial department, and was appointed civil and sessions judge of Patna, Jan., 1864; president, tea commission, Nov., 1867, to April, 1868; officiated as judge of the high court, Calcutta, from Nov., 1870, and was confirmed in that appointment May, 1873; retired, April, 1880.

AITCHISON, SIR CHARLES UMPHERSTON, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., M.A., LL.D., D.O.L., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1856, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant commissioner and magistrate; transferred to Punjab, May, 1857; personal assistant to judicial commissioner, July, 1858; officiating under secretary, government of India, foreign department, Nov., 1859; deputy-commissioner, Punjab, Jan., 1865; officiating commissioner, Lahore, Aug., 1867; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, Nov., 1867; from April, 1868, served in the foreign department, government of India, as officiating secretary, and was confirmed in this appointment, Aug., 1870; on special duty in Thagi and Dakaiti department, Oct., 1877; chief commissioner, British Burma, 31st March, 1878; provisional member, governor-general's council, July, 1880; lieutenant-governor, Punjab, 4th April, 1882, to April, 1887; member, governor-general's council, and April, 1887, from which date he resigned the civil service; resigned his seat as member of governor-general's council, 1889; has published "Manual of the Criminal Law of the Punjab," 1860; "Treaties, Engagements, and Sanads relating to India and the Neighbouring Countries;" and "The Native States of India."

AITCHISON, JOHN R., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Clapham Grammar School; supernumerary writer, 14th Feb., 1860; clerk in registry department, Oct., 1860, and employed in military department, 1867; junior clerk, Nov., 1872; funds department, 1873; military department, 1874; deputy resident clerk 1880-84; senior clerk, March, 1885.

ALCOCK, JOHN BACKHOUSE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, and railway magistrate; from Jan., 1884, served as assistant judge and sessions judge, and as acting judge and sessions judge.

ALEXANDER, ERNEST BRUCE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1874, to March, 1881 served as assistant settlement officer and officiating settlement officer in Fatehpur and Moradabad, and was appointed junior secretary to the board of revenue in addition to his other duties in 1877, and was placed on special duty under the orders of the board, Feb., 1879; served subsequently as assistant magistrate, and joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and acted for various periods as small cause judge, and magistrate, and collector; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Sept., 1885; deputy commissioner, June, 1889; magistrate and collector, Oct., 1889; author of "Gazetteer of Gorakhpur," and "Settlement Report of Moradabad."

ALEXANDER, JAMES WILLIAM, Public Works Department, Government of India. Joined the service June, 1865; assistant engineer, Dec., 1866; assistant secretary to Government of India Public Works Department, Jan., 1868; executive engineer, March, 1870; served in various divisions, and from Nov., 1886, to May, 1887, had charge of the Rohilkhand executive division; 3rd superintending engineer, Feb., 1890.

ALEXANDER, MOSES, India Office Stores Department.—Appointed 2nd class clerk, March, 1888, retired March, 1890.

ALEXANDER, NATHANIEL STUART, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 10th July, 1858; from Oct., 1859, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1879; commissioner, Dacca division, Aug., 1884; commissioner of Bhagulpore, Dec., 1885; and of Burdwan, Aug., 1887; retired March, 1890.

ALISON, SIR ARCHIBALD, Bart., G.C.B., General.—Member of the council of India; 1st commission ensign 72nd foot, 3rd Nov., 1846; captain, Nov. 1853; major unattached, Dec., 1856; brevet colonel, March, 1867; lieutenant-general, Nov., 1882; served in the Crimean campaign of 1855, and was present at siege of Sebastopol (medal and clasp and Turkish medal); served in the Indian mutiny, and was military secretary to the commander-in-chief, Aug., 1857, to March, 1858; was present at relief of Lucknow (wounded—arm lost), medal and
clasp; brevet of lieutenant-colonel and C.B.; in staff employment adjutant general's department at headquarters, and in the south western district, and at Aldershot, 1862 to 1873; served in the Ashantee war of 1873-4 as brigadier-general of European brigade, and was present at the battle of Amoaful, capture of Bequah, action of Ordashu, and taking of Coomassic; received thanks of both houses of parliament, medal with clasp, and K.C.B.; deputy adjutant general headquarters Ireland, Oct., 1874, to Dec., 1877; commandant staff college, Jan.-April, 1878; deputy quartermaster-general intelligence branch, May, 1878-Aug., 1882; served in the Egyptian expedition of 1882 as major-general in command of troops at Alexandria, and on the Mahmondiyeh canal, and in command of 3rd brigade, 2nd division, at battle of Tel-el-Kebir; received thanks of both houses of parliament, medal with clasp, bronze star, 2nd class Osmanieh; promoted lieutenant-general for distinguished service; commanding division Aldershot, Aug., 1883, to Feb., 1885; and again Oct., 1885; adjutant-general to the forces, Feb.-Sept., 1885; appointed member of the council of India, Jan., 1889.

ALLEN, CHARLES FRANCIS EGERTON, B.A. (Cantab), late Judicial Department, Burma.—Called to the bar (Inner Temple) 1871; admitted advocate of high court, Calcutta, Nov., 1873; law examiner, Calcutta University, Dec., 1874, and again in 1875 and 1876; acting judge of the Calcutta court of small causes, 1875-76; lecturer on English law in the Presidency College, Calcutta, Feb., 1876, and professor of law (temporary) May, 1877; served as government advocate, Rangoon, and acted as recorder of Rangoon for various periods.

ALLEN, CHARLES GEORGE HILLERSDEN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Haileybury and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1886.

ALLEN, DAVID BIRD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant to director-general of statistics, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and under the director of the agricultural department, May, 1885; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1887; has also acted as magistrate and collector.

ALLEN, PERCY UNDERHILL, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces, &c).—Educated at University College School, Cheltenham College, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India 21st Nov., 1888, and served in the North-Western Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

ALLEN, THOMAS TAYLOR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Cork; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 7th Feb., 1861; from Nov., 1861, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1867; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, April, 1880; lieutenant-governor's council, Jan., 1881, and again, Jan. to Dec., 1883, and Nov., 1886, and Dec., 1888; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Feb., 1883.

ALLEN, WILLIAM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting railway magistrate, acting 1st class deputy collector in Scinde, acting assistant conservator of forests, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; 1st assistant collector, Dec., 1882; junior collector and magistrate, Nov., 1889.

ALLISON HAZLETT, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service as surgeon, Sep., 1873; arrived in India, 29th April, 1874, and served in military duty from July, 1874; acted as fort surveyor, Fort St. George, medical inspector of seamen, and professor of anatomy in medical college at various periods; surgeon-major, Sept., 1885; fort surgeon, Fort St. George, with fort and marine duties, and professor of anatomy in the medical college, and medical inspector of seamen, Jan., 1888.

AMBICA CHURN SEN, Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1884, on probation; confirmed in the statutory civil service, Feb., 1886; on duty under the director of the agricultural department, May, 1885.

AMEER HOSSEIN, SYED, C.I.E., Bengal Judicial Department.—Joined the service as officiating deputy magistrate and deputy collector, 20th Aug., 1864, confirmed 5th Feb., 1867; member of council of lieutenant-Governor, April, 1878; officiated as presidency magistrate, Calcutta, for various periods, and was confirmed in that appointment Nov., 1883; member of central examination committee, April, 1886; additional member of governor-general's council, June, 1886; C.I.E. Jan., 1888; coroner of Calcutta, Nov., 1888.

AMIR, ALI, C.I.E., Bengal Judicial Department, appointed judge of the High Court at Calcutta, Jan., 1890.

AMIRTO LAL CHATTERJEE, B.L.—From 19th May, 1862, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, and small cause court judge, Moorshedabad, April, 1873; subordinate judge, Nuddea, Jan., 1880; 1st grade subordinate judge, Jan., 1880.

AMOS, ROBERT, Customs Department, Bengal.—Served in the customs department from 4th Dec., 1876, and was appointed assistant collector and head appraiser July, 1882.

ANDERSON, ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Gordon's Hospital, New Grammar School, and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and forest settlement officer; on special duty, Jan.-May, 1878, and again, Nov., 1881, in the forest department; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Sept., 1883; 1st grade, Feb., 1887; deputy commissioner, March, 1889.
ANDERSON, FRANCIS CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, Oct., 1871; from Nov., 1871, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and acting deputy commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, Aug., 1881; commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Feb., 1882; acted as secretary to chief commissioner in Oct., 1882, 1885, and March, 1888; prepared excise manual for the Central Provinces, 1885.

ANDERSON, HENRY AIKEN, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Repton Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1873, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; was appointed officiating under secretary to Government, Punjab, March, 1880, and assistant political officer, Kurram, under the Government of India, Aug., 1880; on special duty, camp of exercise, Delhi, Nov., 1885; assistant commissioner, and grade, Dec., 1885; officiating district judge, May, 1886; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1888; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, May, 1889; officiating divisional judge, April, 1890.

ANDERSON, JAMES, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1884; on special duty connected with the Wahabi case, June, 1870; retired, 1888.

ANDERSON, JAMES DRUMMOND, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1875; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Assam, Jan., 1880, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Jan.-Dec., 1882; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, July, 1886; deputy commissioner, April, 1889; author of 'A Short List of Words of the Hill Tipperah Language,' 1885.

ANDERSON, JOHN ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Grammar School and University of Aberdeen, and was also a student of the Inner Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, and Dec., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Aug., 1886; officiating deputy commissioner, May, 1887; officiating divisional judge, March, 1888; district judge, 2nd grade, April, 1889.

ANDERSON, J. W. M., Colonel, late Bombay S.C. Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—First commission, Jan., 1855; from Nov., 1863, served in the revenue survey department, Mysore, as assistant superintendent and deputy superintendent; from April, 1881, served as superintendent of the Scinde settlement survey; 1st grade superintendent, Jan., 1885; retired, March, 1888.

ANDERSON, ROBERT HILDEBRAND, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1876; served as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating embarkation agent and superintendent of emigration, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; confirmed as joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1887, 1st grade, April, 1889; has also acted as district and sessions judge.

ANDERSON, W. R. L., Captain, Bombay S.C.—First commission, Oct., 1870, 63rd foot; admitted to the Bombay staff corps, Oct., 1871; aide-de-camp to Governor of Bombay, 1876; deputy accountant-general, military department, Jan., 1882; served in the Egyptian war, 1882; medal and Khedive's star.

ANDREW, DAVID CLAPHAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal S.C., late Survey of India.—Ensign, Bengal Infantry, Dec., 1859; arrived in India, 7th March, 1860; joined the revenue survey department as assistant surveyor, Dec., 1862; deputy superintendent of revenue survey, 3rd grade, Jan., 1878; was in charge of Bassein District, British Burma survey, Nov., 1879, and was transferred to the South Deccan survey, Nov., 1880; 2nd grade deputy superintendent, March, 1886; retired, March, 1889.

ANDREW, JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Kingstown School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and forest settlement officer; head assistant to collector and magistrate, March, 1888.

ANDREWS, W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 30th March, 1876.

ANLEY, GEORGE AUGUSTUS D'AUVERGNE, late Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the government of India as executive engineer, 4th class, 25th Jan., 1861; served in the Bengal public works department, and temporarily under the municipality of Calcutta; officiating assistant to chief engineer and assistant secretary to the government of Bengal, April, 1876; held charge of office of chief engineer, and secretary to Government of Bengal, Dec., 1878; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1882; 2nd class, March, 1886; retired, Nov., 1888.

ANNESLEY, ROBERT, Major, Bengal U.C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Served from 4th Jan., 1871, as assistant district superintendent of police and officiating cantonment magistrate, and was confirmed in the latter appointment, June, 1877; judge, small cause court, June, 1880; 1st class cantonment magistrate, Oct., 1886.

ANSON, GEORGE WEMYSS, Major, B.S.C. (N.W. Provinces).—1st commission, 11th Jan., 1867; private secretary and A.D.C. to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, May, 1871, and Feb., 1875—June, 1878; from April, 1872, served as officiating cantonment magistrate and officiating
assistant commissioner; confirmed in latter appointment, Sept., 1875, and in the former, Sept., 1877; agent, Belrampur estate, June, 1886.

ARBUTHNOT, Sir Alexander John, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Madras C.S., member of the Council of India.—Educated at Rugby, and Haileybury College, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1842; arrived in Madras, Sept., 1842; served in the revenue department as assistant collector and magistrate, and also held the posts of Malayan translator to government, secretary to the college and university boards, and deputy and acting registrar to the Sudder court; director of public instruction, March, 1855; chief secretary to government and additional member of council for making laws and regulations, Oct., 1862; member of Madras Council, Oct., 1867, to Oct., 1872; temporary governor of Madras in the absence of Lord Napier, Feb.-May, 1872; retired from the Madras civil service, Oct., 1874; member of governor-general's council, June, 1875, to 1880, and acted as president of the council, Nov., 1878, and March, 1879; vice-chancellor of the university of Madras, Oct., 1871, and of the university of Calcutta, Oct., 1878; counsellor of the Empress of India, Jan., 1877; appointed Member of the Council of India, 1 Nov., 1887; is the author of various publications on educational and other subjects in connection with India, among which are 'Reports of selected cases determined in the Court of Foujdarai Adawlut,' 1851; 'A compilation of papers relating to public instruction in Madras,' 1855; 'Memoir of Sir Thomas Munro,' 1881, &c.

ARBUTHNOT, Sir Charles George, Lieut.-General, K.C.B., R.A.—1st commission, Royal Artillery, June, 1843; served in the Crimean campaign, 1855, and was present at the siege and fall of Sevastopol (medal and clasp, brevet of major, 5th class Medjidieh, Turkish medal); deputy adjutant-general, R.A., in Bengal, March, 1873, to Sept., 1877; acted as inspector-general of ordnance, Oct., 1877, to Sept., 1878; inspector-general of artillery in India, Sept., 1878, to July, 1880, during which period he served as brigadier-general in the operations in Afghanistan (medal, K.C.B.); deputy adjutant-general, R.A.; with the headquarters of the army in England, Sept., 1880, to Aug., 1883; inspector-general of artillery in England, Sept., 1883, to April, 1885; president, ordnance committee, May, 1885, to Jan., 1886; commander-in-chief, and member of the governor's council, Bombay, 16th Feb., to Dec., 1886; commander-in-chief, and member of council, Madras, 9th Dec., 1886.

ARBUTHNOTT, John Campbell, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1879; assistant magistrate and collector, Bhagalpur, Dec., 1879; transferred to Assam, Feb., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner.

ARDAGH, John Charles, C.B., Col. R.E., F.R.G.S., Private Secretary to Governor-General of India.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; entered royal engineers as lieutenant, 1st April, 1859; captain, Aug., 1872; major, Nov., 1878; lieutenant-colonel, Nov., 1882; colonel, Nov. 1887; attached to the special embassy during the congress at Berlin, June, 1878, and was made a C.B. (civil), July, 1878; appointed assistant to Her Majesty's commissioner for the delimitation of the frontier of Bulgaria, Sept., 1878; appointed commissioner for the demarcation of the Greek frontier, June, 1881; was employed during the conference at Berlin on the Greek frontier in 1880, and during the conference at Constantinople on the same subject in 1881; served in the Egyptian campaign of 1882-4, including the operations at Alexandria, and the battle of Tel-el-Kebir (medal with clasp, bronze star, brevet of lieutenant-colonel and 4th class of Osmanlieh); served in the Soudan in 1884, commanding royal engineers and chief of the intelligence department; battles of Teb and Tamai; 2 clasps, C.B. (military), May, 1884; served in Soudan expedition, 1884-5—Nile; commandant of Base at Cairo, and in the expedition of 1885-6 with the frontier field force; has received the 3rd class of the Medjidieh; appointed private secretary to the Right Hon. the Marquess of Lansdowne, governor-general of India, Dec., 1888.

ARGYLL (Duke of). His Grace George Douglas Campbell, K.T.—Born in 1823; succeeded to the dukedom in 1847; took an active part in the controversy in the Presbyterian Church of Scotland relating to patronage, and published various pamphlets and essays in connection therewith, 1842-1848; elected chancellor of the University of St. Andrew's, 1851; lord privy seal, 1852-1855; postmaster general, 1855; lord privy seal, 1859; in 1860 he was again appointed postmaster general, and subsequently lord privy seal; secretary of state for India, Dec., 1868, to Feb., 1874; lord privy seal, May, 1880; resigned in April, 1881; elected rector of the university of Glasgow, Nov., 1854; presided over the 25th annual meeting of the British Association, held at Glasgow, Sept., 1855; president of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, 1861; is hereditary master of the Queen's household in Scotland, a trustee of the British Museum, and hereditary sheriff and lord lieutenant of Argyllshire; published the 'Reign of Law' in 1866; 'Primeval Man,' 1869; a small work on the history and antiquities of Iona, 1870; 'The Patronage Act of 1874,' 1874; observations 'On the important question involved in the relation of Landlord and Tenant,' 1877; and in 1879, The Eastern Question from the Treaty of Paris, to the Treaty of Berlin, and to the second Afghan War.'

ARMSTRONG, Francis B., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham Proprietary College, and King Edward's School, Birmingham; junior clerk, financial department, India office, 30th March, 1869; senior clerk, Sept., 1883.

ARMSTRONG, John Arthur, Lieut.-Col.
