R.E., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—1st commission, June, 1860; joined the public works department, Nov. 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant engineer; served in the Hazara Campaign, 1868, as assistant engineer in charge of field telegraph; executive engineer, Sept., 1869; assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to government, April, 1877; served in Kashmir on special road work, 1881-82; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1886; retired, March, 1887.

ARMSTRONG, John Scobell, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition
of 1864; arrived, 3rd March, 1866; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, and collector of customs, Calcutta, April, 1883; port commissioner, Calcutta, Nov., 1887; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, April, 1890.

ARNOLD, GEORGE, late Store Department, India Office.—Clerk in storekeeper's department, Royal Arsenal, Woolwich, Oct., 1855, to Dec., 1858; sub-inspector of stores, India store depot, Dec., 1858; supervisor, 1st grade, March, 1877, retired, 1886.

ARNOTT, JAMES, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.M. (Glas.) Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867, and was employed under the military department till Aug., 1868, including service in the Abyssinian Expedition (medal), and subsequently as assistant-surgeon in the David Sassoon Hospital, Poona, and in the European General Hospital, Bombay, and as professor of pathology in the Grant Medical College; also acted as civil surgeon, and registrar of marriages, Poona, and in medical charge of the Deccan and civil engineering colleges, and as superintendent of the lunatic asylum and jail; acting surgeon, Gokuldas Tejpal Hospital, Bombay, Jan., 1878; also acted as presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay; surgeon, European general hospital, Bombay, March-April, 1882; professor of midwifery, Grant Medical College, and obstetric physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital from April, 1882.

ARNOTT, NAPOLEON, Major R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commissioner, 22nd Dec., 1865; arrived in India 13th Dec., 1868, and served in Bengal and the Punjab on irrigation duty; executive engineer, Jan., 1879; officiated as secretary to agent to Governor General Baluchistan, and as secretary to defence committee in 1882; employed on special defence works, Aug., 1887; 3rd superintending engineer, Dec., 1889.

ARTHUR, SIGISMOND RAYNOR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay Civil Service after Open Competition of 1886; arrived in India 19 Nov., 1888; assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1889.

ARUNDEL, ARUNDEL TAGG, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; served in various districts of Madras from Aug., 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and acting collector and magistrate; private secretary to governor of Madras, July, 1875; acting deputy director, revenue settlement, April, 1878; president of the municipal commission, Madras, June, 1881; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1882; principal assistant to collector and magistrate and agent Vizagapatam, Oct., 1884; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Dec., 1884; collector and magistrate, Kistna, Dec., 1885.

ASHBURNER, LIONEL R., C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1848; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Broach, Surat, and Kaira; on the outbreak of the mutiny in 1857, was appointed superintendent of police, Kaira, and organised a body of horse and foot for the protection of the eastern frontier; special commissioner for trial of rebels, 1858; collector and magistrate, Kandeish, 1861; revenue and police commissioner, N. division, 1872; member of council, Bombay, Aug., 1877; retired, 1883.

ASHTON, G., Correspondence Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 7th April, 1884; attached to financial department.

ASHUTOSH GUPTA, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules; assistant magistrate and collector, Lohardugga, on probation, March, 1885; confirmed, July, 1885; has officiated as magistrate and collector.

ASTON, HENRY FAURE (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay, C.S.—Educated at the South African College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 9th Oct., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting political assistant in Kathiawar (April, 1871, to June, 1874), acting judge and sessions judge, railway magistrate and cantonment magistrate; on famine duty, Sholapur, Sept., 1877; acting under-secretary to government of Bombay in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, Dec., 1881, to March, 1883; 1st grade assistant judge and sessions judge, Aug., 1883; judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, March, 1885; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, Nov., 1886; acting 1st grade judge, 1887; on special duty in connection with settlement cases, Baroda.

ATKINS, JOHN DE COURCY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University College School, London University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; acted as under-secretary to government, Bombay, revenue, financial, &c., departments, in 1886.

ATKINSON, FREDERIC JAMES, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as probationer, 8th July, 1873, and served in Bengal as district grain accountant and on audit duty and as officiating accountant-general; served also as assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Bengal, and N.W. Provinces; assistant comptroller, Burma, December, 1888; officiating comptroller and commissioner of paper currency in 1890.

ATKINSON, JOHN NATHANIEL, Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant sessions judge; on special duty under the commissioner of salt revenue, April, 1885; acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, Oct. to Dec., 1885; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Sep., 1886.

ATLAY, VENERABLE B. T., M.A., late Ecclesiastical Department, Bengal.—Arrived in India, 12th Oct., 1867; chaplain of St. Paul's Cathedral and of the general hospital, Dec., 1867; senior chaplain, Oct., 1877; chaplain of Naini Tal, Feb., 1879; senior chaplain, St. Paul's Cathedral, and chaplain of the general hospital and presidency.
jail, Jan., 1882; commissary to the Lord Bishop, and officiating chaplain in charge of the diocese, March, 1883; Archdeacon of Calcutta, Sept., 1883; retired 1889, and appointed vicar of Willesden.

AUCOTT, Elliott, Funds Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, Feb., 1886.

ATUL CHUNDER DUTT, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Free Church Institution, Calcutta, and at Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Madras, 14th Jan., 1890, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

AULAD HUSSAIN, Khan Bahadur, C.I.E., Central Provinces.—Joined the service, 29th July, 1844; served in various subordinate posts till Dec., 1864, when he was appointed extra-assistant commissioner; on special duty at the Delhi assemblage, Dec., 1876; made C.I.E., Jan., 1882; acting small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, July, 1883; assistant commissioner 1st class, Sept., 1883; settlement officer, 2nd grade, Raipur, Jan., 1885.

AUSTIN, Ware Plumptre, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, and Gloucester School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial department from May, 1866, as assistant magistrate and collector, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector, magistrate, and political agent; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1884; collector and magistrate, Nov., 1886.

AYLING, William Bock, Madras C.S.—Educated at Weymouth College and Magdalene College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competition of 1886; arrived in Madras 30th Jan., 1889, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

BADCOCK, Francis William, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1866; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant-magistrate, joint-magistrate, and deputy collector, and officiating district and sessions judge, and was placed on special duty, as settlement officer, Bhagulpore, Monghyr, and Purneah, July, 1873, and also in the office of the board of revenue, Calcutta, Jan., 1879; officiating inspector-general of registration, March, 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1883; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Jan. 1888.

BADEN, Edmund, Auditor's Department, India Office.—Writer, 4th Jan., 1859; senior inspector, Sept., 1860.

BADEN-POWELL, Baden Henry, C.I.E., late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at St. Paul's school; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; assistant commissioner, May, 1862; officiating postmaster-general, Punjab and Scinde, Aug., 1865; from July, 1866, to April, 1869, served as small cause court judge, Lahore, and subsequently in the forest department as officiating conservator and officiating inspector-general, and was placed on special duty, Nov., 1872, and April, 1876; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, April, 1880; on special duty in Madras, Oct. 1880, to Oct. 1881; additional commissioner, Lahore and Rawulpindi, Oct., 1881; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1882; officiating judge, chief court, Punjab, May, 1883; and again April, 1884, and Jan., 1887; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 1st grade, Sept., 1886, but to continue to act as judge of chief court, confirmed in latter appointment March, 1889; retired, May, 1889, but employed on special duty under Government of India, revenue and agricultural department; has published 'Punjab Products,' 'Punjab Manufactures,' 'Manual of the Land Revenue System and Land Tenures of British India,' and 'Manual of Jurisprudence for Forest Officers.'

BADGLEY, William Francis, Colonel, B.S.C., late Survey of India.—First commission, April, 1857; arrived in India, May, 1857; served during the mutiny in Central India and Oudh, and afterwards with the Lushai expedition in charge of a survey party (medals and clasp); appointed to the Topographical Survey, May, 1865, and was employed in Rewah and Bundelcund, and in the Khasi, Garo, and Naga Hills; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Dec., 1880; in charge of Guzerat survey, March, 1884; officiating assistant surveyor-general in charge of photographic and lithographic offices, March, 1886; retired, June, 1889.

BADOCK, Henry W., Accounts' Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 11th Feb., 1876.

BAGNELL, Henry William James, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eastbourne College, Keble College, Oxford, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India 1st Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883; forest settlement officer, Aug., 1887.

BAGSHAWE, C., Forest Department North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as temporary sub-assistant conservator, 26th Oct., 1859; assistant conservator, 14th Aug., 1871; deputy conservator, Oct., 1876; employed in the military department in the Kuram Valley, Aug., 1879, and at the Forest school, Dehra Dun, Dec., 1879; conservator, 3rd grade, Jan., 1880.

BAILEY, Frederick, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as lieutenant, R.E., 12th Nov., 1864; served under the military department till July, 1867, when he was appointed assistant engineer, 1st grade, P.W. department; executive engineer, 3rd grade, June, 1871; from Aug., 1871, served in the forest department as deputy conservator and superintendent of forest surveys; conservator of forests, and director of Indian forest school, in addition to his duties as superintendent of forest surveys, Sept., 1878; promoted to 2nd grade of conservators, April, 1883.

BAILLIE, Duncan Colvin, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Inverness Academy, Glasgow Academy, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; assistant settlement officer, 1st grade, April, 1883; settlement officer, June, 1889; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Sept., 1890.

BAINBRIDGE, George, Surgeon-Major, L.R.C.P., M.R.C.S., L.S.A. (London), Bom-
bay Medical Department.—Joined the service st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Khandesh, Feb., 1871; acted as deputy sanitary commissioner; also as ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic medicine and surgery and of comparative anatomy, Grant Medical College, May, 1873; surgeon-major, April, 1879; acting Presidency surgeon, Aug., 1882; acting senior surgeon of Sir Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of surgery, Grant Medical College, Feb., 1885.

BAINES, JERVOISE ATHELSTANE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent, acting educational inspector, and cantonment and railway magistrate; on special duty at Bombay as compiler of general administration report, Sept., 1878, and again Sept., 1879; acting under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, March, 1880; deputy superintendent of census operations in Bombay Presidency, and under secretary to government, general department, census, April, 1880; and assistant collector and forest settlement officer, Dec., 1882; on special duty to supervise the work under the Income Tax Act in the Bombay Presidency, May, 1886; also acting as director of agriculture from Dec., 1886; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Oct.-Nov., 1886; acted as junior collector and magistrate, 1887, 1888, and 1889; on special duty, June, 1888; served under the Government of India as census commissioner from Aug., 1889.

BAIRD, ANDREW WILSON, Lieut.-Col., R.E., F.R.S., A.I.C.E., F.R.G.S., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, R.E., Dec., 1861; arrived in India March, 1863; served from May, 1864, in the Bombay Public Works Department as assistant engineer, and was employed on the harbour defences and reclamations; executive engineer, Oct., 1867; served in the Abyssinian Expedition as assistant field engineer, 1868 (medal); from Dec., 1868, served in the Trigonometrical Survey as assistant surveyor, and was employed in Kattywar and Guzerat; assistant superintendent 1st grade, Oct., 1871; in July, 1877, was appointed to the general superintendence and control of tidal observations upon the Indian coasts; on deputation as commissioner, Venice Geographical Congress and Exhibition, Aug., 1881; deputy superintendent, July, 1882; officiating master of the mint, Calcutta, in 1885 and 1886; 3rd grade deputy superintendent, March, 1886; mint master, Calcutta, Aug., 1889; is the author of various contributions to the Bombay Gazetteer, and of papers and reports on tidal observations, including a paper read before the British Association, 1876, and an account of the spirit-levelling operations of the great Trigonometrical Survey of India, read before the British Association in 1885; joint author of the annual tide tables for Indian ports.

BAKER, EDWARD NORMAN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Finchley; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1878; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; services placed at disposal of census commissioner, March, 1881; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, May, 1882; and in addition to his own duties, April, 1884; under secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1885; deputy commissioner 3rd grade, June, 1890; has also officiated as magistrate and collector.

BAKER, FRANCIS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Berkhamstead Grammar School and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; first assistant secretary to government, Nov., 1873, and again in 1879; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, April, 1874; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1878, and officiated as secretary, Sept., 1878; officiating junior secretary to government, March, 1881; under secretary to government, May, 1881; superintendent of Dehra Dun, March, 1884; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Aug., 1886; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, March, 1888; magistrate and collector, March, 1886.

BAKER, MONTAGU BERNARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1864, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and acting judge and sessions judge; acting judicial commissioner in Scinde, and judge of the Sadar court, April, 1879; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Kandesh, May, 1882; 1st grade judge, Nasik, Jan., 1884.

BAKER, OSWALD, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Burma.—Joined the Bengal medical service, 1873; was employed under the military department up to May, 1874, and served subsequently in Burma as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail; medical officer to the mission to Siam under Major C. W. Street, Feb., 1879; surgeon-major, April, 1885; junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, and port health officer, Oct., 1885; civil surgeon, Moulmein, May, 1887; appointed joint medical officer, Simla, Sep., 1889.

BALFOUR, EDWARD GREEN, Surgeon-General, late Madras Medical Service.—Educated at Montrose Academy, and at the Edinburgh University and Medical Schools, and is a Licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh; joined the Madras medical service in 1836; served under the military department, 1836-1854; political agent at the Durbar of H. H. the Nawab of the Carnatic, and paymaster of Carnatic stipends, 1849-1861; formed, and was in charge of the Government Central Museum, Madras, 1850-1859, and formed the Madras zoological collection, Jan., 1856; acted as assistant assay master, Madras mint; Persian and Hindustani translator to government, and member of the board of examiners of oriental languages, 1854-1861; commissioner investigating the debts of H. H. the Nawab of the Carnatic, 1856-1861; formed the Mysore museum, Bangalore, 1865; examiner of medical accounts, military finance department, 1861-1862; from 1862 to 1870 served as deputy inspector-general of hospitals in Pegu, the Straits Settlements, the ceded districts, Mysore, and Hyderabad,
successively; surgeon-general, Madras medical department, 1871-1876; was hon. secretary to the Madras central committee for the Exhibition of 1851, for the Paris Exhibition of 1855, and for the Madras Exhibitions of 1855 and 1857; was a fellow of Madras University, and is corresponding member of the Imperial Royal Geological Institute, Vienna; has published works on cholera (in 1849 and 1852), on the commercial products of the Madras presidency, on the Mollusca (1855) on the government central museum, on the timber, trees and woods of India (1853), and on the agricultural pests of India; also a Cyclopaedia of India and Eastern and Southern Asia, 1857, 'Selections from the Persian and Hindustani poets,' 1851, 'The Vydan and the Hakim,' 1875, 'Eminent Medical Men,' 1875, and a statistical map of the world, 1854; has translated into Hindustani 'Conquest's Outlines of Midwifery' and 'Gleig's Astronomy,' and has made frequent contributions to various journals on subjects connected with India.

BALFOUR, Sir GEORGE, General, R.A., K.C.B., F.R.G.S., M.P.—2nd lieutenant, Madras Artillery, Dec., 1825; served with the Malacca field force, 1832-1833, in the Kurnool campaign, 1839, and throughout the China war, 1840-1842 (medal); consul at Shanghai, March, 1844, to Oct., 1846; member of the military and marine boards, Madras, Feb., 1851-1857; C.B., 1854; inspector-general of ordnance and magazines, Fort St. George, May, 1857 to 1861; member of the military finance commission, 1859-1860, and president of that commission, 1860-1862; served on the royal commission on recruiting in 1866 and 1868-70; assistant to the comptroller in chief, war office, 1868-1872; K.C.B., June, 1879; from Dec. 1872, has sat in the House of Commons for Kincardineshire; general, Oct., 1877; retired from the army, Dec., 1879.

BAMBER, Henry William John, Police Department, Bengal.—From 1st Oct., 1857 to May, 1862, served as assistant superintendent, and superintendent of salt chowkies; from May, 1862, served in the Bengal police department, and was promoted to district superintendent, 1st grade, Aug., 1885.

BANKS, Samuel Henry O'Brien, F.R.C.S.I., Brigade-Surgeon Bombay Medical Department.—Joined the service 1st Oct., 1866, and arrived in India, 17th April, 1867; served in the Abyssinian campaign, and afterwards on civil, military, and Jail duty; surgeon-major, Oct., 1873; presidency surgeon, 3rd district, Nov., 1888; presidency surgeon, 2nd district and marine surgeon, Nov., 1889; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1889.

BANNERMAN, Patrick Wilson, Colonel, Bombay S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Bombay Army, June, 1852; assistant to the superintendent, Neemuch, July, 1859; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, 1860; political assistant, Bhopawar Aug., 1865; also Bheel agent and commandant, Malwa Bheel corps; political agent, Rewah, March, 1871; political agent, Bhopal, 1880; resident, Eastern States, Rajputana, Oct., 1881; resident, Gwalior, March, 1882; acted as agent to governor-general for Central India in 1883-1884, and again in 1887.

BANTON, William, Accounts Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 29th Dec., 1848; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, India office, Sept., 1853; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; also assessor of income tax, 1879.

BARBOUR, Sir David Miller, K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1863; served in Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; under secretary, government of India, financial department, Aug., 1873; accountant general, Punjab, and deputy commissioner, paper currency, Lahore circle, June, 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1878; accountant-general, Madras, and commissioner of paper currency, Jan., 1880; on special duty with the government of India, May, 1881; accountant-general, Bengal, Sept., 1881; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Jan., 1882; Bengal legislative council, Jan., to Oct., 1882; secretary, government of India, department of finance and commerce, July, 1882; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; on special duty in India, Sept.-Oct., 1886, and on special duty in England to serve as member of the Royal Commission on Currency in 1886; ordinary member of council of governor-general, 22nd Nov., 1883; K.C.S.I., Jan., 1889.

BARCLAY, Arthur, M.B., Surgeon-major, Indian Medical Department.—Arrived in India 28th March, 1875, and served on civil and military duty; officiated as resident surgeon presidency general hospital and as professor of physiology, Calcutta Medical College; secretary to the surgeon-general with the government of India, April, 1885; surgeon-major, Sept., 1886; served in Afghan war, 1879-80 (medal and clasp).

BARCLAY, Ernest, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 18th Sept., 1861, as French interpreter to the supreme court, Madras, acting deputy clerk of the crown and acting assistant registrar, and was appointed government solicitor, Feb., 1876.

BARCLAY, Pringle David, Railway Department, government of India.—Joined the department, March, 1875, as assistant traffic superintendent, Rajputana state railway; class 2, revenue establishment of state railways, Jan., 1880; traffic superintendent, Punjab Northern railway, March, 1881; Eastern Bengal railway, June, 1884; class I., Jan., 1888.

BARING, Sir Evelyn, Major, K.C.B., K.C.S.I., C.I.E.—Lieutenant, R.A., June, 1858; captain in 1870, and major in 1876; A.D.C. to Sir Henry Storks, in Ionian Islands, in 1861, and secretary to him in 1865, during the enquiry into the outbreak in Jamaica; private secretary to the governor-general of India (the Earl of Northbrook), 1872 to 1876; commissioner of the Egyptian public debt, 1877-9; comptroller-general in Egypt, Sept., 1879; financial member of council of governor-general of India, June, 1880; agent and consul-general in Egypt, and a minister plenipotentiary in the diplomatic service, Aug., 1883; financial assistant at the conference in London, on Egyptian finance, June to Aug., 1884; has 1stclass of Medjidie.
BARKLEY, David Graham, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; officiating small cause court judge, Delhi, Sept., 1863; personal assistant to commissioner, Umballa, Nov., 1864; officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, Aug., 1866; on special duty in the chief court, Nov., 1870, and again at Simla, June, 1871, and at Lahore, April, 1872; assistant sessions judge, March, 1873; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1874; additional commissioner, Delhi, May, 1876, and subsequently at Jallundar and Lahore; officiating judge, chief court, Punjab, Aug., 1878, and again in 1880; civil and sessions judge, Nov., 1880; commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, Sept., 1881; additional judge, chief court, Jan., 1882; additional member of Governor-General's council for making laws and regulations, May, 1883, and again in 1884; judge of the chief court, Punjab, Feb., 1886; retired Jan., 1887; has published 'Directions to revenue and settlement officers, non-regulation law.'

BARLOW, Sir Richard Wellesley, Bart., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed acting judge, small cause court, Tellicherry, Nov., 1869; acting civil and sessions judge, Chingleput, Feb., 1870; from 1871 to 1878 served as collector and magistrate of Chingleput, and subsequently as commissioner, Nilgiris, 1878-1880, and again in 1881; government member of the Lawrence Asylum committee, April, 1878; major commandant Nilgiri Volunteer Rifles, Dec., 1878, to Nov., 1879; acted as member of the Board of Revenue in 1880 with charge of the Inam department, and again in 1881, in charge of settlement department, and in 1886; collector and magistrate, and additional sessions judge, Nilgiris, Feb., 1882; collector of sea customs and of the Madras district, and protector of emigrants, Madras, Jan., 1883; acting president, Travancore and Cochin, Feb. to Aug., 1884; additional member of the council, Madras, Sept., 1885; chairman of the Harbour Trust Board, May, 1886; superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1887, in addition to his other duties; retired Nov., 1889.

BARNES, Francis Carnac, Financial Department, Government of India.—Served in the financial department from 9th November, 1872, and was appointed assistant to accountant-general, N.W. provinces, Jan., 1877; assistant comptroller-general, Calcutta, Nov., 1878; private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, April, 1882; class 4 of financial department, Aug., 1885; services retained under the government of Bengal as superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1887.

BARNES, Hugh Shakespeare, Bengal C.S., Foreign Department, Government of India. Educated at Malvern College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to financial department of government of India Dec., 1876, and appointed assistant to accountant-general in the N.W. Provinces; private secretary to the financial member of the governor-general's council, Dec., 1876; acted as under secretary in the home department in 1878; on special duty under the foreign department, Nov., 1879; assistant to resident, Kandahar, Nov., 1880; served in the Afghan campaign, 1881, as political officer with General Wilkinson's brigade; assistant to the governor-general's agent in Beloochistan, 1881-83; political agent in Quetta and Pishin, June, 1883; in charge of arrangements, supplies, &c., for passage of Afghan boundary commission across Belooch Desert, Aug., 1884; officiating under-secretary to Government of India, foreign department, April, 1889; and was confirmed in that appointment, May, 1890; officiating deputy secretary to Government of India foreign department, May, 1890.

BARNETT, Ebenezer M., late Store Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 10th Nov., 1852; junior clerk, store department, July, 1860; senior clerk, March, 1868; retired, March, 1887.

BARODA CHURN MITTRA, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed under native civil service rules an assistant magistrate and collector, March, 1886, on probation; confirmed, May, 1888.

BARR, D. W. K., Major, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Sept., 1864; served in Abyssinian expedition (medal); boundary commissioner, Rewa Kantha, and Malwa Bheel agency, 1869; political assistant and boundary officer, Bhopal, July, 1869; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, 1870; officiating political agent, 2nd class, Jodhpur, 1878-79; political agent, Bhagelkund, July, 1881; also superintendent, Rewa state; resident 2nd class at Gwalior, May, 1887.

BARRETT, Edwin Clifford, Survey of India.—Appointed probationary assistant surveyor Indus-Sind revenue survey, 18th Nov., 1862; and assistant superintendent, 2nd grade, Dec., 1868; accompanied Lushai expeditionary force, 1871-2 (medal and clasp); assistant superintendent, 1st grade, July, 1882; 4th grade deputy superintendent, Oct., 1884; and 3rd grade, May, 1889.

BARRON, William, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, Dec., 1858; arrived in India Feb., 1859; served with the Peshawur mountain train battery in the Mahsood Wuzuree expedition, 1860; assistant revenue surveyor June, 1862; served as assistant surveyor with the Umbeyla expedition, Oct., 1863 (medal and clasps); assistant superintendent of survey, 1st grade, June, 1866; was employed in the Punjab and N.W. frontier districts, and also in Assam; deputy superintendent of survey, April, 1870; was subsequently in charge of the N.W. frontier revenue survey, and afterwards of the Moradabad and Budaon surveys; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Aug., 1884, and 1st grade, Oct., 1889; author of a 'Handbook of Instructions for Cadastral Survey Parties in N.W. Provinces.'

BARROW, Frank, Lieutenant-Colonel B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—1st commission lieutenant 2nd Dragoons, 18th Sep., 1867; admitted to Bengal Staff Corps, 18th Sep., 1867; from Aug., 1860, served under the Government of India, in the foreign department, as assistant
commissioner in Oudh, and in 1870 and 1871 officiated as junior secretary to the chief commissioner, and as cantonment magistrate and deputy commissioner for various periods; appointed deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, June, 1880.

BARROW, FRANK HUNTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bruton and Felsted Grammar Schools, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1870; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1884; magistrate and collector, March, 1887.

BARROW, OSCAR THEODORE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Gloucester College School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1877; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to financial department, government of India, Oct., 1882; assistant accountant-general, Bengal, Feb., 1884; officiating deputy accountant-general, May, 1885; assistant accountant-general, Bengal, Sep. and Nov., 1885, and deputy accountant-general, Oct., 1885; comptroller of Indian treasuries, Nov., 1886; assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Mar., 1887; class 4 of enrolled officers, May, 1887; enrolled officer, class 3, Nov. 1887; deputy accountant general, Bombay, class 2, April, 1888; officiating accountant-general and deputy commissioner, paper currency, N.W.P., May, 1888.

BARROW, REGINALD POCKOCK, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oxford University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India 13th Nov., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1886.

BARRY, WILLIAM, M.R.C.S., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Glasgow, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 14th Feb., 1863; from Dec., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; employed on famine duty under the government of Bengal, Dec., 1873, to Jan., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Banda, Aug., 1877; from May, 1881, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1882; 2nd grade, April, 1887; retired March, 1890.

BARSTOW, HENRY CLEMENTS, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from July, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating small cause court judge; served under the Government of India, foreign department, Jan., 1874, to Oct., 1875, as officiating political agent, 1st class, Bhopal; officiating superintendent, Dehra Dun, Feb., 1876; officiating civil and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Banda, Jan., 1880; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Cawnpore, April, 1880; retired, Nov., 1886.

BARTER, JOSEPH FRANCIS, Brigade-Surgeon, Medical Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the Madras medical service, July, 1859; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1860; from April, 1862, served in the Central Provinces as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and acted for various periods as inspector-general of jails and as sanitary commissioner; rank of surgeon-major, July, 1873; sanitary commissioner, superintendent of vaccination, and inspector-general of dispensaries, Central Provinces, Dec., 1878; civil surgeon and superintendent of lunatic asylum, Nagpur, July, 1883; brigade-surgeon, March, 1886.

BARTHOLOMEW, ROBERT, Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Cavalry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 2nd April, 1862; from 1st Aug., 1866, served in the Punjab commission as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, 2nd grade, Aug., 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884, Delhi, officiating as divisional judge; deputy commissioner, July, 1886; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1887.

BARTLETT, HUBERT FREDERICK, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; transferred to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1880, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, June, 1885; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Aug., 1885; magistrate and collector, July, 1889.

BARTON, EBENEZER JOHNSTONE, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 10th Nov., 1862; from Sept., 1863, served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1882; also served as officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, Sept., 1871, and was on special famine duty, Banagalore division, Dec., 1873; retired, Aug., 1887.

BATCHELOR, STANLEY LOCKHART, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Edmund's College, Ware, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay Civil Service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1889, and served in Bombay as assistant magistrate and collector.

BATESON, ROBERT SANDER, Brigade-Surgeon, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1856; arrived in India, and was attached to military department as assistant surgeon, 7th Aug., 1856; placed in medical charge of the civil station and in executive charge of jail at Umballa, Nov., 1871; civil surgeon, 2nd class, Oct., 1877; brigade-surgeon, Oct., 1882; retired Sept., 1886.

BATTEEN, HALLET GEORGE, Burma Commission.—Joined the service, 17th Oct., 1869, and on 13th Feb., 1871, was appointed extra assistant commissioner, Burma; assistant commissioner, Nov., 1877, and deputy commissioner, May, 1888; served also as assistant cantonment magistrate and judge of the small cause court in 1886.
BATTEN, JOHN KAYE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury College, and at Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in Madras, 29th November, 1887, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

BATTEY, HERBERT, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay, C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1879, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, professor of logic and moral philosophy in the Deccan College, Poona (1872-75), assistant judge and sessions judge (1st grade, Feb., 1885), and acting judge and sessions judge; under secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, Nov., 1885; acted as district and sessions judge between 1886 and 1888; acting chief presidency magistrate, Bombay, April, 1888; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, May, 1888.

BAYLAY, CHARLES ALLEN, Colonel, B.S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, Dec., 1857; assistant commissioner, Berar, Jan., 1866, and subsequently in Loodianah; political assistant, Rajputana, 1868-70; assistant general superintendent for suppression of Thagi and Dakaite, Dec., 1870; political agent, Haraoti and Tonk, 1876; additional political agent, 1st class, Kotah, Dec., 1879; acted as resident, western states of Rajputana in 1884; political agent in Kotah, 1888; retired, May, 1890.

BAYLEY, CHARLES STUART (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow and Heidelberg; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1877; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, January, 1878; officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, July, 1880; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, general and revenue departments, March, 1881, and subsequently in the financial department, Oct., 1882; member of the executive committee, Calcutta International Exhibition of 1883-84, Aug., 1883; officiating under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural departments, Feb., 1884; officiating registrar, high court, March, 1884; under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural departments, April, 1885; assistant commissioner, Ajmere, Sept., 1886; political agent, Bikainir, June, 1888; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Jan., 1889.

BAYLEY, LYTTELTON HOLYOAKE (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Advocate-general, Bombay, 17th March, 1866; judge of the high court, Bombay, June, 1869; acting chief justice, May-Dec., 1883, and Nov. 1887, to Feb., 1888.

BAYLEY, SIR STEUART COLVIN, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived in India 4th March, 1856; assistant magistrate and collector, 24 Pergunnahs, Nov. 1856; junior secretary to government of Bengal, Feb., 1863; officiated as secretary to the government of Bengal in 1865, 1867, and 1871; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Monghyr, Feb., 1867; officiating civil and sessions judge, Shahabad, May, 1867; commissioner, Dacca division, July, 1873, and subsequently of the Patna division, Sept., 1873; secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1877; additional secretary, government of India, financial department, Aug., 1877; personal assistant to H.E. the Viceroy, for famine affairs, Sept., 1877; additional secretary, government of India, public works department, famine branch, in addition to his own duties, Dec., 1877; secretary, government of India, home department, June, 1878; officiating chief commissioner, Assam, June, 1878; officiating lieutenant-governor of Bengal, July-Nov., 1879; chief commissioner of Assam, June, 1880; resident, 1st class, Hyderabad, March, 1881; governor-general's council, 6th May, 1882; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, April, 1887; retired Dec., 1890; appointed secretary political and secret department, India office, assumed charge, 13th Jan., 1891.

BAYNE, CHARLES GERWIEN, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Uppingham, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1880, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, and officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner; junior secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1886; under secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1887, and officiating secretary to chief commissioner, Feb., June, and Aug., 1888; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Nov., 1888.

BEACHCROFT, FRANCIS PORTEN, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Sept., 1881; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1883; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; 2nd grade, April, 1886; officiating judge of chief court, Punjab, April, 1890.

BEADON, CECIL, Colonel, Madras Cavalry, Punjab Administration.—Arrived in India, 24th March, 1858; from May, 1862, served in the Punjab commission as assistant commissioner, cantonment magistrate, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, March, 1877; on special duty in connection with viceregal durbar, Nov., 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, June, 1883, and subsequently in the Lahore division; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Feb., 1885, Simla; officiated also as divisional judge and sessions judge.

BEAMAN, FRANK CLEMENT OFFLEY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant superintendent of police; acting assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, March, 1882, to Jan., 1883, and again 1885-86; acting junior collector and magistrate and political agent, March-April, 1883; from April, 1883, served in the judicial department, and was appointed acting judicial assistant to political agent, Kathiawar, May, 1884, and 3rd grade assistant judge, May, 1885; special settlement officer, Baroda, May, 1886, and November, 1887; acted district and sessions judge, Oct., 1887; 2nd grade assistant judge, April, 1890.

BEAMES, JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 16th March,
1858; from March, 1859, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and from Dec., 1861, in Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1873; officiated as commissioner, Orissa division, Aug., 1873, and subsequently as commissioner of the Chittagong, Rajshahiye, and Cooch Behar and Dacca divisions; commissioner, Burdwan division, Nov., 1881; officiating member of Board of Revenue, March, 1887, and April, 1889; Commissioner of Bhagulpoor, Aug., 1887; author of 'Outlines of Indian Philology,' 1867, 'Comparative Grammar of the Modern Aryan Languages of India,' 1872-1879; edited Sir H. M. Elliot's 'Races of the N.W. Provinces of India,' 1869.

BEARD, H. G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; writer, India store depot, 1st Feb., 1866; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

BEATSON, JOHN FULLARTON, Surgeon-General, M.D., C.I.E., late Bengal Medical Service.—B.A. and M.D., University of Glasgow; licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh; assistant surgeon, Bengal, 16th June, 1843; served with the army of the Sutlej, 1845-46, taking part in the defence of Ferozepore, and battle of Ferozeshah (medal and clasp); served in the Punjab Campaign, and was present at various actions (medal); surgeon, June, 1857; in charge of the Allahabad General Field Hospital during the period of the Mutiny; surgeon-major, June, 1863; garrison surgeon, Allahabad, 1865-68; medical storekeeper, Umballa, 1868-69; deputy inspector-general Meerut, May, 1869; surgeon-general, Nov., 1875; Companion of the Order of the Indian Empire, Jan., 1878; retired, March, 1880.

BEATTY, JOSEPH, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1852; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1855; served in the Madras public works department from March, 1855, as assistant engineer, and executive engineer; supervisor of the canals, Godaveri, May, 1874; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, Aug., 1877; promoted to 1st grade, Oct., 1878; retired, May, 1889.

BEATTY, THOMAS BERKELEY, Surgeon-General, M.D., late Bombay medical service.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin (A.B. and M.B.); joined the Bombay medical service, May, 1851; arrived in India, 27th June, 1851; civil surgeon, Karachi, July, 1853; superintendent of vaccination, April, 1856; acting civil surgeon, Poona, 22nd May, 1866, and again in 1872; superintendent, Matheran, Dec., 1867; deputy-surgeon general, Poona, Oct., 1876; principal medical officer, Malta Expeditionary Force, May to Sept., 1878; surgeon-general with the Government of Bombay, April, 1880; retired, March, 1885; is the author of various contributions on medical subjects in the Transactions of the Medical and Physical Society, Bombay.

BEAUMONT, THOMAS, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., F.R.C.S.I., late Madras Medical Department.—Arrived in India, 13th Sept., 1857; served under the military department till Feb., 1864, when he was appointed residency surgeon, Indore; residency surgeon, Hyderabad, June, 1881; also superintendent of vaccination and superintendent of medical school; retired, Oct., 1885.

BEAUMONT, WILLIAM, late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras revenue survey department from 27th May, 1858, as assistant superintendent, and deputy superintendent; reorganisation committee, Madras, March, 1871; promoted to 1st class deputy superintendent, June, 1877; board of examiners, Nov., 1882; retired, Nov., 1887.

BEAVAN, REGINALD, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India Department.—Ensign, 4th May, 1860; arrived in India 11th June, 1860; served in the military department, and in Sept., 1867, was appointed to the staff corps, and in July, 1868, to the topographical survey department as assistant surveyor; served with various survey parties, and in July, 1880, organised and took charge of the Baluchistan topographical survey; deputy superintendent, 4th grade, Nov., 1884, and 3rd grade, June, 1889; in the military department, served in Southern Afghanistan, from Oct., 1878 (medal); accompanied the Marri field force and the Bozdar field force in 1880 and 1881.

BECHER, ALFRED READ, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Joined the P.W. Department, July, 1868; arrived in India, 14th Oct., 1868; served in the Punjab as assistant engineer on the Sirhind canal; from April, 1873, served in the accounts branch, Punjab, as assistant controller, and deputy controller; transferred to Bombay, Nov., 1875; served subsequently in Hyderabad, Oudh, Rajputana, and Mysore; examiner of accounts, Calcutta, June, 1886; 3rd class examiner, Sept., 1886; officiated for short periods as deputy accountant-general and under secretary to Government of India in 1888, 1889, and 1890.

BECKETT, HENRY BARRON, Punjab Administration.—Served from 10th May, 1860, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating inspector of schools, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Peshawur, Aug., 1884; from Dec., 1884, officiated as divisional judge, and was appointed district judge 1st grade, Oct., 1885, and deputy commissioner, and grade, Aug., 1886; 1st grade, May, 1889.

BEDFORD, JAMES PERCH, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Madras, 14th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

BEGGIE, ALFRED GLYNN, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, July, 1861; arrived in India, Nov., 1870; joined the public works department, Feb., 1871, as assistant engineer in the railway department, Central India; executive engineer, Oct., 1871; Agra-Gwalior railway survey, Nov., 1872; officiating deputy controller of accounts, Bengal, Aug., 1874; officiated as examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, at Calcutta and Bombay, 1874-75; controller of accounts, Mysore, Aug., 1875; examiner guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, 1878; Punjab Northern railway accounts, 1880; deputy accountant-general, and ex officio under secretary to Government of India, Jan., 1886; officiating accountant-general, public works department, and deputy secretary, government of India, April, 1886, to March, 1887; examiner, 1st class, May, 1886; officiating accountant-general and deputy secretary to government of India, public works
department, May to Oct., 1887, and Sept., 1888, and confirmed in those appointments, Oct., 1889.

BEHARY LAL GUPTA (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Colootola Branch School, Calcutta, Calcutta University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 29th Sept., 1871; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1871; on famine relief duty, Sept., 1874; presidency magistrate, Calcutta, and coroner of Calcutta, June, 1881; officiating district and sessions judge, April, 1884, March, 1885, and Feb., 1887, and confirmed, Nov., 1888.

BEIGHTON, THOMAS DURANT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward's School, Birmingham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived 4th Dec., 1867; served in Bengal in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating small cause court judge, officiating district and sessions judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty in connection with boundary disputes on the Bhutan frontier, Jan., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, May, 1885, and 1st grade, Jan., 1889.

BELCHAMBERS, R., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Registrar of the high court, Calcutta, from 1862; is also keeper of records, taxing officer, accountant-general, and sealer; author of 'Practice of the Civil Courts,' and other legal publications.

BELL, HORACE, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed probationary assistant engineer, 7th July, 1862; served in the Central Provinces and Central India, and was promoted to executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; subsequently served on the Punjab northern state railway, and on the Rajputana state railway, as superintendent of way & works, and as acting manager, also as officiating engineer-in-chief on the Sindia and Neemuch state railways; supervising engineer, 3rd grade, Jan., 1880; transferred to Bengal, Nov., 1881; engineer-in-chief, Dacca and Mymensingh railway surveys, Dec., 1881; while on furlough superintended assistant engineers on practical course in England; supervising engineer, 2nd class, Jan., 1883; on special duty, Aug., 1883, on committee for considering reorganisation scheme for public works department; manager and engineer-in-chief Tirhoot state railway, Feb., 1884; held charge Nalhati railway, July–Sept., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; acting director, North-Western Railway, July to Oct., 1887; engineer-in-chief and manager Jirhoot State Railway, Oct., 1887, to March, 1888; engineer-in-chief Great-Western of India railway survey, Sept., 1888, and of the Moghal Sarai Howrah railway survey, Feb., 1889; author of 'Laws of Wealth,' a work on political economy for native readers.

BELL, MATTHEW DENNY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; acting senior assistant collector, Ganjam, March, 1887; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Jan., 1890.

BELL, NICHOLAS DODD BEATSON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton Bank, St. Andrews, Edinburgh Academy and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service, after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

BELLETT, G., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Appointed to the Bengal educational service, 9th Oct., 1860; served successively as 2nd master, head master, and professor, Dacca College; inspector of schools, Nov., 1868; professor, Presidency College, Dec., 1873; principal, Berhampore College, May, 1875; 2nd class, educational service, March, 1876; subsequently served as officiating principal, Patna College, inspector of schools, officiating principal, Presidency College, and officiating director of public instruction (Jan., 1883); 1st class educational service, June, 1887.

BELLEW, HENRY WALTER, C.S.I., Surgeon General, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1855; arrived in India, 24th March, 1856; served under the military department up to Jan., 1868, and subsequently as civil surgeon in the Punjab; on duty with Ameer of Kabul, March, 1869; deputed to Kashmir, April to Nov., 1869; served with the Seistan and Yarkand missions in 1871 and 1873; residency surgeon, Nepaul, Feb., 1876; on special duty under the government of India, in the foreign department, April, 1876; rank of surgeon-major, July, 1876; sanitary commissioner, Punjab, Nov., 1877; served under foreign department of government of India in connection with Kabul mission and Kurram field force, 1878 and 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Nov., 1881; retired, May 1886; has published a dictionary and grammar of the Pashtu language, a report on the Eusafzais, and a political report on Seistan, also 'Journal of the Kandahar Mission,' 'Indus to Tigris,' 'Kashmir and Kashgar,' 'Afghanistan and the Afghans,' 'The Races of Afghanistan,' 'History of Cholera in India from 1862 to 1881,' and a vaccination manual.

BENETT, WILLIAM CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd class, and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed to take up land for railway purposes in Fyzabad, Feb., 1870; manager of encumbered estates, Gonda, March, 1872, to Feb., 1875; officiated as city magistrate, Lucknow, in 1878 and 1879; officiating secretary to government, Oudh revenue department, Sept.–Nov., 1879; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1882; director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1882; secretary, board of revenue, May, 1886; officiating secretary to government, Oudh revenue, and judicial departments, June, 1886, confirmed, Nov., 1888; officiated as chief secretary in 1887, 1888, 1889, and was appointed secretary in revenue and judicial departments, April, 1889; member of lieutenant-governor's legislative council, Feb., 1889; author of 'History of the Chief Clans of the Rae Bareli District,' the Gonda Settlement Report, and contributions to the Oudh Gazetteer.
BENGER, Alfred, Auditor's Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 20th Nov., 1866; junior examiner, June, 1867; senior examiner, July, 1877.

BENNETT, J., M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1865; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1865; services placed at disposal of civil department, Sept., 1870; civil surgeon, Murrce, Dec., 1872; superintendent of vaccination, Punjab, July, 1877; superintendent-general of vaccination, Punjab, March, 1880; deputy sanitary commissioner, Eastern Circle, Dec., 1881, to April, 1884; civil surgeon, Mooltan, Jan., 1883; also superintendent of central jail, Dec., 1883; civil surgeon, Rawalpindi, April, 1884; civil surgeon, 1st class, Sept., 1884; medical adviser to his Highness the Maharaja of Patiala, Aug., 1885; retired Sep., 1890.

BENSLEY, Edwin Clement, Surgeon-Major, late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1859; served from 22nd July, 1863, as civil assistant surgeon at Midnapore and Rajshahye; civil surgeon, Rajshahye, Oct., 1875; rank of surgeon-major, Feb., 1871; retired, Nov., 1885.

BENSON, Ralph Silbery, M.A., LL.B., Barrister-at-law (Middle Temple), Madras C.S.—Educated at Rathmines School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate (Salem), acting head assistant collector and magistrate of Cuddapah during the famine of 1876-78, acting assistant commissioner and acting commissioner (Nilgiris), 1878 to 1881, and acting collector and magistrate; was specially appointed as officer for the settlement of lands in the Nilgiri districts; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, North Arcot, June, 1882; on special duty as secretary to the local self-government committee, Oct., 1882; forest settlement officer, May, 1883, and secretary to the committee for drafting new municipal and local board bills; acting under-secretary to government in the chief secretary's department, Jan., 1885, and again in Oct., 1887; acting registrar, high court, July, 1885; acting secretary to the commissioners of land revenue, Nov., 1887, to April, 1888; sub-collector and joint magistrate and acting district and sessions judge, April, 1888; district and sessions judge, Nov., 1888; author of the 'Settlement Registers and Descriptive Memoirs of the Nilgiri Districts, and of the Report on the Settlement of the Nilgiri District,' 1885.

BENSON, Thomas, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Tavistock Grammar School, Marlborough College, and St. John's College, Cambridge.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, manager of the Awa estate under the court of wards, officiating district and session judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Oct., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1883, district and sessions judge, April, 1887.

BENTHALL, Ernest, late Store Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India Office, 19th Dec., 1865; junior clerk, Nov., 1866; senior clerk, Dec., 1877; retired, Dec., 1889.

BENTON, Alexander Hay, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the University and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1861; arrived in India, 20th Feb., 1864, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Aug., 1883; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Peshawur, Oct., 1885; 1st grade, April, 1889; judge of Chief Court, Punjab, Nov., 1889.

BERESFORD, John Stuart, M.E., M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India; assistant engineer, N.W.P., 26th July, 1867; executive engineer, Sept., 1872; had charge of various divisions of Ganges Canal; personal assistant to chief engineer, irrigation, May, 1877, and from Nov., 1884, to March, 1885; employed on Betwa Canal in 1884; superintending engineer, Dec., 1889.

BERESFORD, Lord W. Leslie de la Poer, Lieutenant-Colonel, V.C., C.I.E., 6th Lancers.—First commission, cornet, June, 1867; served in the Jowaki-Afreedee expedition, 1877-8 (medal and clasp); served also in the Zulu war of 1879, and was present at battle of Ulundi (Victoria Cross, medal, and clasp); served in the Afghan war, 1878-80, and was present at the capture of Ali Masjid (medal and clasp); A.D.C. to Viceroy of India, 1875 to 1881; military secretary on the personal staff of the viceroy and governor-general, 13th Dec., 1881; served with the Burmese expedition of 1886, as military secretary to governor-general (brevet of lieutenant-colonel and clasp).

BERKELEY, James Cavan, C.I.E., Colonel, M.S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Oct., 1857; served in civil employ from June, 1862, as assistant to the governor-general's agent in Central India; also served as boundary settlement officer, deputy opium agent in Malwa, assistant general superintendent for Thagi and Dakaiti, and sessions judge and registrar for Mhow; political agent, Haraoiti and Tonk, 1873; political agent, Bhagalpur, Jan., 1879, to Nov., 1882; political agent, Jacobabad, 1882; officiating resident, Gwalior, March, 1883; on special duty, Kashmir, April-Aug., 1884; political agent, Bundelcund, 1884; officiating resident, Nipal, 1885; resident, 2nd class, and governor-general's agent at Baroda, April, 1886.

BERNARD, Sir Charles Edward, K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S., Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Department, India Office.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1853, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and was appointed under-secretary to government of India, financial department, Aug., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the Central Provinces as judge of the small cause court, Nagpur, settlement officer, secretary to the chief commissioner (July, 1864), commissioner of Nagpur division (Feb., 1869), and acting judicial commissioner; from May, 1871, to Jan., 1875, served in Bengal as member of the lieutenant-governor's council, and acting secretary to the government, first in the judicial department, then in the revenue department, and lastly in the scarcity and relief department; from Nov., 1876, served as commissioner of Nagpur division; secretary to Sir
Richard Temple, Bart., K.C.S.I., deputed on a special mission to the Bombay and Madras Presidencies, Jan., 1877; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1877; additional secretary to the government of India in the department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Aug., 1877, and in the financial department, Dec., 1877; served as secretary to the government of India in the home department, May, 1878, to July, 1880; Secretary to government of India in revenue and agricultural department, July, 1881; from July, 1880, acted as chief commissioner of British Burma, and was confirmed in this appointment April, 1882; retired, March, 1883, and was appointed secretary in the revenue and statistics department, India office.

BERNARD, JAMES HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India 30th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Midnapore, Jan., 1883; personal assistant to the chief commissioner, British Burma, May, 1886, services replaced at disposal of government of Bengal, Feb., 1887; officiated as magistrate and collector and as under secretary to government of Bengal.

BERRILL, EDWARD, N.W. Provinces, police department; adjutant military police, Central Provinces, 14th Aug., 1858; inspector of police, N.W. Provinces, 27th Feb., 1861, and assistant inspector-general, Dec., 1861; acted for various periods as district superintendent, and was appointed to that post, May, 1867; assistant inspector-general, railway police, Oct. 1885, and of the special branch, June, 1888; served in the mutiny in Barrow's volunteer cavalry, July, 1857-April, 1858.

BEST, JAMES WILLIAM, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Wimborne Grammar School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate in various districts; from Jan., 1875, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, South Canara, Sept., 1877; officiated as judge of High Court, Jan., 1890.

BETTINGTON, ALBEMARLE, late Bombay C.S.—Entered the Bombay civil service from Haileybury, 1830; served in the usual grades in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed deputy collector of continental customs and excise, 1843; collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, 1849; inspector-general of prisons and commissioner of police, Bombay, 1855; retired 1861. Has published a work on 'The Destruction of Life by Snakes and Hydrophobia.'

BEVAN, JAMES FORBES, Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as assistant 21st June, 1866, arrived in India 14th Sept., 1866, and served in various lines in Bengal and the Punjab; superintendent, 19th June, 1880; held charge of the Indore, Rajputana, Arakan, Bengal and Bombay divisions.

BEVERIDGE, HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 20th Jan., 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating deputy commissioner, Cooch Behar, and magistrate and collector (2nd grade, April, 1874); on special duty in Munipore under the government of India, foreign department, Nov., 1863; from Oct., 1874, served in the judicial department as officiating district and sessions judge, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1879; member of the central examination committee, April, 1886.

BEVERLEY, HENRY, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sedbergh School, Yorkshire, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived 31st Oct., 1861; from May, 1862, served in the revenue and judicial department as assistant magistrate and collector, deputy commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1865, and Aug., 1867; registrar-general of assurances, March, 1867; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Dec., 1870; inspector-general of registration, Dec., 1870; superintended the first census of Bengal in 1872, superintended the census of Calcutta, 1876; officiating judge of Nuddea, April, 1875; officiating inspector-general of jails, Lower Provinces, Aug., 1876; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, and additional judge, 24-Pergunnahs and Hooghly, Dec., 1877; member of the prison conference, 1877; member of the census committee, 1878; officiating commissioner of police, Calcutta, and chairman of the corporation, March, 1880; special census officer of Calcutta and suburbs, Dec., 1880, and published a report on the census, 1881; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Nov., 1883; member, Bengal legislative council, Jan., 1884; member of sanitary commission, Calcutta, Sept., 1884; officiated as judge of the high court, Calcutta, 6th April, 1884, to 15th Sept., 1884, and again from 12th Jan., 1885, until confirmed as judge, 8th May, 1885; published 'Registration Manual' and 'Land Acquisition Act.'

BHAGWAN CHUNDER CHAKARBUTTI.—From 9th October, 1861, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, May, 1884.

BIDDULPH, CUTHBERT EDWARD, M.A., Political Department, Government of India.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; joined the service as probationary assistant settlement officer, Sind, 19th Jan., 1878; services placed at disposal of agent to governor-general for Baluchistan, Nov., 1878; assistant to the political superintendent, Sawant Wari, in charge of the Sir Dasai, Feb., 1880; from Aug., 1880, to June, 1881, served in the commissariat department; assistant survey and settlement commissioner, Baroda, Nov., 1883; revenue settlement officer, Meywar, Dec., 1886; served during the Afghan War of 1878-80 in political charge at Dadur in Kutchi, in 1878-9, of Sibi district in 1879, and in commissariat charge of Bolan Pass, 1880 to 1881 (medal); author of "Our Western Frontier of India," "Afghan Politics," and "Afghan Poetry of the 17th Century."

BIDDULPH, JOHN, COLONEL, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Cornet, Bengal cavalry, Jan., 1853; arrived in India, 4th March, 1853; served with various cavalry regiments, and received the mutiny medal; aide-de-camp to the Viceroy, May, 1872; to
Feb., 1877; on special duty as member of mission to Yarkand, &c., 1873-74; employed on a secret mission to the countries beyond Gilgit, 1876 (brevet of Major); on special duty in Gilgit, Sept., 1877; acting agent to governor-general, Beloochistan, May-Nov., 1882; political agent, Bhopawur, Dec., 1882; acted as resident and boundary settlement officer in Meywar, 1885; political agent in Haroati and Tonk, April, 1886; resident 2nd class and commissioner, Ajmere, March, 1890.

BIDDULPH, THOMAS HENRY STILLINGFLEET, Financial Department, Government of India.—From July, 1869, to March, 1871, served as accountant, public works accounts, in Central India and Punjab, and as examiner of railway accounts; probationer in financial department, March, 1871; assistant to the accountant-general N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1874; on special duty at Durbangah in Bengal, June, 1874, to May, 1875; from Jan., 1879, served as assistant accountant-general in the N.W. Provinces, and also in the Punjab, Nov., 1881, to April, 1882, and as deputy accountant-general in Madras, April-Oct., 1882; officiated for various periods as deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, and Oudh; controller, Hyderabad, Dec., 1884, confirmed in class 3 of enrolled officers, June, 1888.

BIDEN, W. M., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Mark's College, Chelsea, and King's College, London; provisional assistant, art library, South Kensington Museum, 1870; clerk, 2nd class, India Store Depot, 1st July, 1875; supervisor, 2nd grade, June, 1886; B.A., London University, 1880.

BIDIE, GEORGE, Surgeon-General, A.M., M.B., F.L.S., F.R.C.S.E., F.R.G.S., C.I.E., late Madras Medical Department.—University of Aberdeen; joined the medical service as assistant surgeon, 20th Feb., 1856; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1856, and served under the military department till June, 1859; was subsequently employed as civil surgeon of Guntur, 1859-61, medical officer of the Mysore farm commissariat establishments, and medicinal garden, Hoonsoor, 1861-64, professor of botany and materia medica in the Medical College, acting principal medical storekeeper, and superintendent of the lunatic asylum, Madras, and served in Mysore and Coorg, Nov., 1867, to Feb., 1868, on special duty in the coffee districts; secretary to the surgeon-general, Indian medical department (military), March, 1870; superintendent of the government central museum, Aug., 1872, to Dec., 1884, and again Jan., 1885; on special duty at Ootacamund in connection with cinchona commission, Oct., 1873; fellow of Madras university, April, 1879; secretary to the surgeon-general, H.M.'s forces, left wing, April, 1880, to Nov., 1884; brigade surgeon, Feb., 1883; board of examiners, May, 1883; served in public department, Nov.-Dec., 1883, in connection with Calcutta International Exhibition, and special committee for promotion of art and manufacture; deputy surgeon-general, H.M.'s forces, British Burma division, Dec., 1884-Jan., 1885; sanitary commissioner, Madras, April, 1885; member of committee in connection with the scheme of technical education, Sept., 1885; acting surgeon-general with the government of Madras from April, 1886; confirmed in appointment, Oct., 1886; retired April, 1890; author of numerous publications connected with the botany and zoology of the Madras Presidency.

BIERNACKI, ANDREW, Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st sub-engineer, Punjab Northern railway, temporary, Jan., 1870, confirmed 10th Oct., 1871; revenue establishment of state railways, Class IV., as assistant locomotive superintendent, Jan., 1876, Class III., Nov., 1878, and Class II., Jan., 1882; locomotive and carriage superintendent, Sind section N.W. railway, May, 1887; deputy locomotive superintendent in class I., July, 1889.

BIGG-WITHER, ARCHIBALD CUTHBERT, Lieut.-Colonel, General List, Infantry, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant engineer from Thomason College, Oct., 1866; executive engineer, Sept., 1871; served chiefly on the Indus Valley State Railway, and in Baluchistan from 1885, where he was employed on the frontier road circle in 1888; secretary to agent governor general Baluchistan, and superintending engineer, May, 1890.

BIGGE, WILLIAM, Attorney-at-Law, Judicial Department, Burma.—Acted as 1st judge of the Small Cause Court from 19th January, 1886, and was appointed to that office 28th Sept., 1886.

BIGGS, C., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 3rd April, 1882.

BIGGS, T. HESKETH, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, 26th Sept., 1868, and served as assistant to accountant-general in Bombay, the Central Provinces, and Madras; assistant to comptroller-general, Dec., 1873; on special duty in Madras in connection with the inquiry into certain frauds in the stamp department, Dec., 1873, to Feb., 1874; served subsequently in the Punjab, the Central Provinces, Bengal, Bombay, and Assam, as assistant to accountant-general, officiating for various periods as deputy accountant-general; appointed comptroller, Assam, Aug., 1880; assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Jan., 1883; officiating comptroller of Indian treasuries, Oct.-Nov., 1883; deputy accountant-general, Punjab, in 3rd class of the financial department, 1885; comptroller, Burma, 1887.

BIGNELL, WILLIAM KYD D'OYLEY, Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian Telegraph department, Feb., 1857; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Nagpur, Jan., 1868; served in the Punjab from 1873; 1st grade superintendent, Aug., 1881; officiating director, construction branch, director-general's office, Nov., 1883, to Feb., 1884; officiating director, Nov., 1886, to Feb., 1887; superintendent Class IV, Oct., 1887.

BIRCH, EDWARD ALFRED, Surgeon-Major, M.D., F.R.C.S., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1866; Behar famine, March, 1874; civil surgeon at Hazaribagh, May, 1874, and subsequently at Darjeeling and Nuddea; from Nov., 1881, officiated as surgeon superintendent, Presidency General Hospital, and also held charge of the office of sanitary commissioner, Bengal, June-July, 1882, and acted as professor of midwifery at the Medical College, and obstetric physician, Eden Hospital, May, 1883; surgeon superintendent, Presidency Hospital, sub-pro tem., Dec., 1883; confirmed in this appointment, Jan., 1885; civil surgeon, Hooghly, July, 1889; principal and professor of medicine, and first physician, College hospital, June, 1890.
BIRCH, ERNEST G., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1849; served in the revenue and survey departments, Bengal, and was appointed superintendent of survey, northern division, 1854; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Baraset, 1858; magistrate and collector, Burdwan, 1860; civil and sessions judge, Moorshedabad, 1864, and subsequently of Shahabad; additional judge of Chittagong, 1870; district and sessions judge of Burdwan, 1872; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1873; retired 1879.

BIRCH, FREDERICK MACDONALD, Colonel B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 15th May, 1854; from Jan., 1860, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty in Cashmere, July, 1864, and again, Dec., 1878, and with the financial commissioner's office, May, 1866; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Oct., 1879, to Oct., 1880, and subsequently in the Mooltan and Hissar divisions; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st class, Nov., 1880.
