BIRCH, WILLIAM BRETTON, Colonel, B.S.C., late Punjab.—Arrived in India as ensign, 30th Nov., 1858, and was posted to 32nd Native Infantry, Bengal; served with the China forces 1861-62 (medal); joined the Bengal police department, July, 1863, and served as superintendent in various districts; member of Calcutta examination committee for judicial and police officers, March, 1867; vice-chairman, Burdwan municipality, March, 1867; officiating deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, and a visitor of the Presidency jail and lunatic asylums, Feb., 1869; commanded Sylhet frontier police battalion, on Looshai expedition, Sept., 1871, to March, 1872; 2nd assistant superintendent, Andamans, April, 1873; 1st assistant superintendent, 1873; services replaced at the disposal of the military department, March, 1883; officiating cantonment magistrate, 2nd class, Punjab, July, 1889; retired Nov., 1890; author of a report on sugar manufacture in the N.W. Provinces and Bengal (1881), a report on jail manufactures in India (1881), and of the Andamans and Nicobar Manual, 1886.

BIRD, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, late Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from June, 1866, and was appointed principal assistant collector, May, 1881, district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Oct., 1884, and collector and magistrate in the same district, Feb., 1885; district and sessions judge, Godavari, Sept., 1888; retired, Aug., 1890.

BIRD, CHARLES PAVIN (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; district judge, 2nd grade, Sept., 1885; officiating divisional judge, Feb., 1888; district judge, 1st grade, March, 1889.

BIRD, HUBERT MOORE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portarlington School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate and assistant commissioner, and also acted as deputy commissioner and magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1884; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Sept., 1887.

BIRDWOOD, SIR GEORGE C. M., Kt., K.C.I.E., C.S.I., M.D., LL.D., Statistics and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at the Plymouth Grammar School, and University of Edinburgh (M.D. and M.R.C.S., 1854); Bombay Medical Service 1854; between 1855 and 1857 served under the military department, and held temporary charge of the civil station of Sholapore, including the jail; served in the Persian War of 1856-57 (medal and clasp); from April, 1857 to 1868, held successively the professorships of anatomy and physiology, botany and materia medica in the Grant Medical College, Bombay; curator of the Government Central Museum, Bombay, 1857, and with the assistance of Dr. Bhau Daji and the leading natives of Bombay founded the Victoria and Albert Museum and Victoria Gardens, Bombay; Sheriff of Bombay, 1864, and subsequently registrar of the University of Bombay; special commissioner for the government of Bombay at the Universal Exhibition at Paris, 1867; appointed to assist Dr. Forbes Watson in connection with the annual exhibitions at South Kensington commenced in 1871; special assistant in the statistics and commerce department, India Office, Jan., 1878; is also visitor to the India Museum; C.S.I., 1877; Kt., 1881; LL.D., Cambridge, 1886; chairman of the committee of the Indian section of the Paris exhibition, 1889; author of the following publications: The 'Economic Vegetable Products of the Bombay Presidency'; a paper 'On the Genus Boswellia (Frankincense Trees),' Linn. Trans. of 1869; 'Handbook to the British Indian Section of the Paris Universal Exhibition of 1878;' an official 'Report on the Miscellaneous Old Records of the India Office,' published in 1879; a work on 'The Industrial Arts of India,' published in 1880 by the Science and Art Department; the 'Arts of India,' a handbook to the collection of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, 1881; and of several other handbooks on Indian art published by the department in connection with Indian exhibitions held at York, Berlin, Copenhagen, Stockholm, and Amsterdam; author also of various contributions to the 'Quarterly Review,' the 'Asiatic Quarterly Review,' &c., &c.; was a royal commissioner for the Colonial and Indian Exhibition of 1886, and a member of the finance committee appointed to assist the Prince of Wales in connection with the exhibition; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

BIRDWOOD, HERBERT MILLS, M.A., LL.D. (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University and Peterhouse, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858, and afterwards transferred to the Bombay service; arrived in Bombay, 26th Jan., 1859, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the judicial department, and secretary to the legislative council, Bombay, acting political assistant in
Kathiawar, senior assistant judge and session judge, and registrar of the high court; judge and session judge, Surat, March, 1875; 1st grade judge, Dec. 1877; on special duty at Oodeypore, Sept., 1880; judicial commissioner in Scinde and judge of the Sadar court, Feb., 1881; on special duty in Bombay, March, 1881; judge of the high court, Bombay, Jan., 1885; edited vols. iv. and v. and (in collaboration with Mr. H. J. Parsons), vols. vi. to xi. of 'West's Code of Acts and Regulations'; is compiler of a catalogue of Bills introduced into the Bombay Legislative Council in 1882-5, and also of papers relating to the constitution and functions of the Legislative Council (Selection No. xcii. N.S. from Records of Bombay Government).

BIRKS, ARTHUR RAWSON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Highgate School, and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1873, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner; transferred to Burma, April, 1874; served in the grade of assistant commissioner, and acted as collector of customs, Basseein, March, 1878, and as judge of Moulmein, 1880-1882; on special duty in Rangoon, Aug., 1882; officiating director of public instruction, Aug., 1882; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, May, 1884; 3rd grade, Aug., 1886; 2nd grade, Jan., 1889.

BISHOP, EDWARD F., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 15th March, 1866; senior clerk, June, 1882.

BISSET, WILLIAM SINCLAIR SMITH, C.I.E., Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Dec., 1866, as assistant engineer, Rohilcund; railway branch, Bengal, 1870; assistant consulting engineer, Bengal, July, 1870; also officiating manager, Calcutta and S.E. State Railway; superintendent Darjeeling railway survey, Oct., 1870; Holkar state railway, Nov., 1870; executive engineer, March, 1871; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, April, 1872; manager, Holkar State Railway, Dec., 1875; on special duty, Madras famine relief works, 1877; served in the Afghan war, 1878-80 (medal); manager, Rajputana and Scindia Railway, Sept., 1879; class 1, grade 2, state railway revenue establishment, June, 1881; agent, Bombay, Baroda, and Central India Railway Company, Jan., 1885; supernumerary, class I., grade 1, Nov., 1885; C.I.E., June, 1888.

BITTLESTON, SR ADAM, Knt.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1841; was a puisne judge of the supreme court, Madras, 1853-62, and of the high court from its establishment in 1862 to 1870, when he retired.

BLACK, CHARLES E. D., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Harrow; supplemental clerk, science and art department, 1866-69; writer, India office, 20th Sept., 1869; geographical department clerk, July, 1873; detached in 1880 to be assistant private secretary, and subsequently, from May, 1884, principal private secretary to H.M.'s, secretary of state, home department (Rt. Hon. Sir William V. Harcourt); secretary to the royal commission on the blind, the deaf and dumb, &c., July, 1885; clerk for geographical records, India office, Sept., 1885; author of the 'Abstracts of the Reports of the Surveys, and of other Geographical Operations in India' from 1873 to 1878.

BLACK, SAMUEL, Major-General, C.S.I., Bengal S.C.—First commission as ensign, Bengal N.I., Dec., 1844; served in the Punjab campaign, 1848-49 (medal); from May, 1854, served in the public works department, Lower Provinces, embankment circle; staff officer, Punjab irregular force, Jan., 1857; medal for service in the mutiny; executive engineer, public works department, Punjab, Jan., 1860; military secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1862-83; attained colonel's allowances, Dec., 1882; services replaced at disposal of Government of India, military department; appointed governor, Aitchison College, Oct., 1886.

BLAKESLEY, EDMUND HOLMES, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Charterhouse and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1877; arrived in India 30th Oct., 1889, and served in the Central Provinces as Assistant Commissioner.

BLANC, HENRI JULES, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., F.R.C.P., M.R.C.S. (Lon.), late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 10th Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 7th Aug., 1859, and served in the military department and also as acting civil surgeon in various stations, and as superintendent of vaccination; served in the China War, 1860-62; was a member of the Abyssinian mission, 1864, and was confined in chains during 21 months by the Emperor Theodore; subsequently joined the expeditionary force, and was present at the storming of Magdala (medal); superintendent of Yerrowda central jail, April, 1875; senior surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, Bombay, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery, Grant Medical College, May, 1876, to Aug., 1882; also acted as professor of anatomy, and curator of the museum, May-June, 1879; physician, European General Hospital from Aug., 1882; retired, April, 1887.

BLANFORD, HENRY FRANCIS, late Meteorological Department, Government of India.—Arrived in India, and was appointed assistant in the geological survey, 1st Oct., 1855; in charge of geological museum, Sept., 1856, to May, 1857; in charge of geological survey party, Madras, May, 1857 to 1860; was subsequently engaged in the Calcutta museum, and in surveying in the Sonthal country; resigned the service, Dec., 1861; appointed professor in the Presidency college, Calcutta, Dec., 1862; 2nd grade, educational department, Jan., 1866; meteorological reporter to government of Bengal, April, 1867; meteorological reporter to the government of India for the purpose of organising the meteorological department, Jan., 1875; retired 1889; author of numerous reports and monographs, and contributions to scientific journals and societies, including reports on the geology of the Nilgiri Hills, and the cretaceous rocks of the Trichinopoly district ('Memoirs of Geological Survey'), in the Calcutta cyclone of 5th Oct., 1867 (in conjunction with Colonel Gastrell), on the winds of Northern India ('Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society'), and official reports on the meteorology of India, 1875, 1876, 1878 to 1884; is also author of a monograph of the Belemnitidae and Nautilidae of the cretaceous rocks of Southern India, of 'The Rudiments of Physical Geo-
graphy for the use of Indian Schools,' 'The Indian Meteorologist's Vade Mecum,' and a chart of the average rainfall of India; edited and contributed to the Indian Meteorological Memoirs (2 vols. and 2 parts).

BLATHWAYT, CHARLES GEORGE, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate, Kanara, Oct., 1882; senior collector, March, 1886; retired, July, 1890.

BLENNERHASSETT, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton, and Wimborne Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; from Feb., 1882, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district judge, 3rd grade, March, 1883, and 2nd grade, July, 1890.

BLISS, HENRY WILLIAM, C.I.E., B.A., Madras C.S.—Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; on famine duty, July, 1877, to Feb., 1878; from Feb., 1878, served as commissioner of salt revenue, and of abkari revenue, and was appointed customs collector throughout the Madras Presidency under the Sea Customs Act of 1878, Aug., 1882; on duty to Bombay, Oct., 1879, and to Calcutta and N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1880, to examine the working of the salt department; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1882; on duty to Orissa to report on the system of salt administration, Jan., 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with the abkari committee, March, 1884; additional member of the board of revenue in addition to his duties as commissioner of salt revenue, Feb., 1886; member of the finance committee under the government of India, April, 1886; fourth member of board of revenue and commissioner of salt and abkari revenue, April, 1887; second member of the board of revenue, &c., Jan., 1889, and first member, Oct., 1889; C.I.E., May, 1890; acting commissioner of land revenue, June, 1890.

BLISSETT, T., late Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st March, 1859; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Arracan division, Aug., 1869; personal assistant to director-general, 1873-75; served subsequently in the Dacca and Scinde divisions, and in the store department, and from 1882 in Bombay; 1st grade superintendent, Aug., 1883.

BLOOMFIELD, ALFRED, Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission as ensign, March, 1856; served in the Central Provinces from July, 1864, as assistant commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, March, 1867; deputy commissioner, July, 1870; inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Oct., 1876; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Aug., 1881; 1st class, Aug., 1889; author of 'Notes on the Baigas of the Central Provinces,' 1885.

BLYTH, Ven., GEORGE FRANCIS POPHAM, M.A., late Ecclesiastical Department, Burma.—Archdeacon of Rangoon, Oct., 1879; retired, 1887.

BLYTH, WILLIAM DUNBAR, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Liverpool Collegiate Institution, and Queen's College, Cork; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1879; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, July, 1880; officiating under-secretary, government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointments departments in 1881 and 1882; under-secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1882; member, central examination committee, April, 1886; officiating chief secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1886; officiating inspector-general of registration, July, 1886; 1st inspector of registration offices, Oct., 1886; inspector-general of registration, April, 1887.

BODDAM, WELBY WROUGHTON, Colonel, B.S.C., late Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 12th Dec., 1851; arrived in India, 2nd July, 1852; served with the military police, 1857-61; district superintendent of Lahore police, Feb., 1861; deputy inspector-general March, 1878; promoted to 1st grade, May, 1881; officiating inspector-general, Punjab, March, 1883, and again, Feb., 1885; deputy inspector-general of police, 1st grade, Rawalpindi, March, 1887; retired, March, 1888.

BOILEAU, HENRY, Major, B.S.C.—Served under the military department from May, 1865, to April, 1873, when he was appointed officiating assistant commissioner, Burma; on special duty to Mandalay, May, 1873; assistant commissioner, 4th grade, and superintendent of immigration, Sept., 1874; also sub-registrar of deeds, Rangoon, Aug., 1875; on special duty in connection with the Imperial assemblage, Delhi, Nov., 1876; private secretary and aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, Jan., 1877; cantonment magistrate, Dinapore, and small cause court judge, July, 1878; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1885, continuing to be employed as cantonment magistrate; deputy commissioner, March, 1887.

BOLSTER, J. A., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 22nd Feb., 1872.

BOLTON, CHARLES WALTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College School, London, Royal College, Mauritius, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 7th Oct., 1872; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Oct., 1872; officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, April, 1877; under secretary, government of Bengal, March, 1879; officiating under secretary, government of India, home, revenue, and agricultural department, Feb., 1880; on deputation as under secretary in the judicial, political, and appointments departments, government of Bengal, Feb., 1883; officiating secretary, government of Bengal,
revenue and general departments, in addition to his own duties, March, 1884; officiating magistrate and collector, April, 1884; officiating inspector-general of registration, Oct., 1884; senior marriage registrar, Calcutta, Nov., 1884; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1885; magistrate and collector, Sept., 1888; officiating secretary to the board of revenue, July, 1889.

BOMPAS, CECIL HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Westminster and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1889, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

BONAVIA, EMANUEL, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 4th August, 1857; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1857; served under the military department up to Dec., 1861, and was present at the capture of Lucknow, March, 1858, and in the Trans-Gogra campaign; assistant civil surgeon, Lucknow, Dec., 1861; on special duty, May, 1866; health officer, Lucknow, and superintendent of museum, observatory, and agricultural society's garden, April, 1867; rank of surgeon, Aug., 1869; was engaged for some time in 1872 under the military department in analysing drinking water; principal of medical school at Balrampur, in addition to other duties, Jan., 1873; officiating sanitary commissioner, Oudh, Sept. to Nov., 1874, and again Jan. to March, 1877, also officiating as inspector-general of prisons, Oudh; officiating civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, Dec., 1877; civil surgeon, Etawah, Dec., 1881; retired, April, 1888; has published works on date culture in India, and 'The Villagers' Domestic Medicine,' 1885.

BONHAM-CARTER, NORMAN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1888, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

BONUS, ARTHUR RIVERS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India 17th Jan., 1887; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1887; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Aug., 1889.

BONUS, JOSEPH, Major-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay Engineers, June, 1855; arrived in India, March, 1857; during the mutiny served at the siege and storming of Jhansi, the capture of Calpee and Gwalior, and various other operations and engagements (medal and clasp); joined the Bombay public works department as assistant engineer, June, 1859, and was employed on the Bombay harbour defences, Oct., 1860; from Sept., 1861, served as deputy consulting engineer for railways in Sind; officiating deputy consulting engineer and assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, railway branch, March, 1870; from Nov., 1871, served as superintending engineer on Indus Valley state railway, and officiated as engineer-in-chief, Aug., 1872; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, July, 1873; engineer-in-chief, Sindia state railway, Sept., 1876; transferred to Punjab northern state railway, May, 1877; officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, July-Oct., 1878; engineer-in-chief, Pindi-Peshawur section, Oct., 1879; medal for services in the Afghan War, 1879-80; superintending engineer, 1st class, April, 1881; acting consulting engineer for railways, and joint secretary to government, Bombay, with temporary rank of chief engineer, 3rd class, May, 1882; and again Aug., 1885, to April, 1886; senior deputy consulting engineer and under secretary to government, railway branch, from Nov., 1883; chief engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; retired, Nov., 1888.

BOOTH, W., B.A., Bengal Educational Department.—Served in the department from 27 Nov., 1876, as professor in the presidency college, and officiating principal Hooghly College; principal Dacca College, June, 1884; class 3 of educational department, July, 1886.

BOSANQUET, OSWALD VIVIAN, Madras, C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 17th Sept., 1887, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate; officiating political assistant, 3rd class, and 2nd assistant to resident at Hyderabad, and assistant secretary for Berar, June, 1890.

BOUGHEY, GEORGE FLETCHER OTTLEY, Lieut.-Colonel R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, June, 1862; arrived in India, 5th Jan., 1865; served in the Bhutan expedition, 1865-66 (medal & clasp); joined the public works department, Nov., 1869, as assistant engineer, railway branch, N.W. Provinces; executive engineer, Rajputana railway, Sept., 1870; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, May, 1877; officiating assistant director, state railways, central system, 1878; assistant secretary, railway branch, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1879; served in the Afghan War, 1878-79-80 (medal); personal assistant to chief engineer, buildings and roads and railway branches, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1880; officiating manager, Nizam's state railway, Jan., 1881; manager, Indus Valley and Kandahar railway, Jan., 1882; 1st class, state railway revenue establishment, Oct., 1882; manager, Eastern Bengal State Railway, Nov., 1885.

BOULNOIS, CHARLES, B.A., LL.B., London, late Punjab Chief Court; educated at King's Coll., London, and London University; called to the bar (Middle Temple), 30 April, 1855, and in the same year was admitted advocate of the supreme court of Fort William, in Bengal, and practised at the bar of supreme court, 1855 to 1866; professor of law in the presidency college, Calcutta, 1857-61, and again in 1882-3; judge of the court of small causes, Bengal, 1860, and first judge of the court, 1861; officiating secretary to the government of Bengal, in the legislative department, 1862-4; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India, legislative department, 1864; appointed judge of the chief court, Punjab in Feb., 1866, and was senior judge in the court from 1867 until his retirement in 1877; in 1881 was appointed reporter of appeal cases, which appointment he still holds; member of the senate of the Punjab university college, 1869, and fellow of the Punjab university, 1882; editor of law reports
in the supreme court, 1856-60; joint author of 'Notes on Customary Law,' by Boulnois and Rattigan, 1876.

BOULTON, CHARLES FREDERICK, Colonel, Bombay S.C., late Sind Commission.—Arrived in India, 6th Aug., 1852; on military duty up to Sept., 1856, when he was appointed acting assistant collector and magistrate, Satara; from 1860 served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate; superintendent, Bombay, Baroda, and C.I. railway police, Jan.-Aug., 1866; served subsequently in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting judge and sessions judge; manager of encumbered estates in the Karachi, Hyderabad, and Shikarpur collectories, March, 1877; collector and magistrate Dec., 1879; acting commissioner in Sind, March-June, 1884.

BOURDILLON, JAMES AUSTIN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; officiating under secretary, government of India, financial department, Sept., 1874, and subsequently in the home department, March, 1876; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, Dec., 1875; from Aug., 1876, served in the registration department as inspector of registration offices, and officiating inspector-general; deputy superintendent of census, Dec., 1880; inspector-general of registration, Dec., 1881; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, April, 1887; 2nd grade, April, 1889.

BOUSTEAD, R., Surgeon-Major, F.R.C.S. (Edin.), M.R.C.S. (Eng.), late Bombay Medical Department.—Civil surgeon, Thana, 21st Jan., 1876; acted as superintendent of Vaccination, 1876; superintendent of Matheran, Feb., 1882; acted as surgeon, Gokuldas Tejpal Hospital, 1883; civil surgeon, Ahmednagar, July, 1887, retired, Feb., 1889.

BOUTFLOWER, W. N., B.A., Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the education department from 9th Aug., 1869, as professor in the Agra College, and officiated as principal, July-Dec., 1872; 3rd professor in the Muir Central College, Allahabad, Oct., 1874; officiating inspector of schools, July, 1875, to May, 1876; professor of mathematics, Muir College, March, 1876; 3rd grade of educational officers, April, 1878; officiating meteorological reporter to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April-June, 1881; 2nd grade of educational officers, Feb., 1890.

BOVILL, E., M.B., Surgeon-Major Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service 30th Nov., 1875, and served on general, jail, and hospital duty; civil surgeon, Dec., 1885.

BOWEN, CHARLES, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1858; arrived in India, April, 1863; joined the Madras P.W. department, Nov., 1863, and, from June, 1864, served under the Mysore Government; executive engineer, March, 1867; assistant to chief commissioner, Mysore, June, 1869; officiating engineer in chief and joint secretary to government, Feb. to June, 1880; served in the Madras P.W. department, April, 1883, to September, 1885, as deputy chief engineer and under secretary to govern-

ment; served again under the Mysore Government from Sept., 1885; superintending engineer, April, 1886; chief engineer, October, 1888.

BOWER, GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Caistor Grammar School, Eton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 10th December, 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner; officiated as under secretary to government, March, 1889; deputy superintendent, family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, April, 1890.

BOWIE, MATHEW MORTON, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Central Provinces.—Arrived in India, 20th June, 1858; from June, 1863, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, and deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty in connection with the Delhi assemblage, Nov., 1876; commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, C.C. & provinces, June, 1880; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Nagpur, Sept., 1880; inspector-general of police and prisons, Central Provinces, April, 1882; colonel, June, 1888; officiating commissioner, Sept., 1888.

BOWRING, LEWIN BENTHAM, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Mount Radford School, Exeter, and at Leipzig; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1843; assistant magistrate and collector, 1845; assistant to treasurer, Calcutta, 1846; assistant to resident at Lahore, 1847-49; deputy commissioner, Punjab, 1854-62; private secretary to Lord Canning, 1856-62; chief commissioner of Mysore and Coorg, 1862-70; retired 1870; has published 'Eastern Experiences,' and contributed papers to the Asiatic Society of Bengal.

BOXWELL, JOHN, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 31st Dec., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1883; also served as inspector of schools, July, 1865, and settlement officer, Midnapore, March, 1877; officiating commissioner, Patna, Sept., 1884, July, 1886, and Feb., 1887; commissioner of Dacca, Aug., 1889.

BOYS, HENRY SCOTT, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; from Dec., 1864, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed superintendent of the encumbered estates of Sitapur and Kheri, June, 1872; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1881; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; 1st grade, April, 1887; acted as commissioner of division in 1883, 1887, and 1888; retired, 1889.

BRACKENBURY, MAULE CAMPBELL, Major, R.E., Railway Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1865; arrived in India, June, 1875; joined the P.W. department, June, 1875; executive engineer, March, 1877; served in the Perak expedition, 1875-76 (medal and clasp), and the Afghan War, 1879-80 (medal and two clasps and bronze star), officiating deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, 1881; assistant mana-
ger, Punjab northern state railway, Feb., 1883; officiating manager and traffic superintendent, Mysore railway, April, 1883; acting deputy consulting engineer, Bombay, Oct., 1884; deputy manager, North Western State Railway, Sind Section, Dec., 1885; 1st class, state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1886; manager, Sind Section, March, 1887; under secretary to Government of India, railway branch public works department, Nov., 1887, and deputy director-general of railways, April, 1888; officiating deputy secretary to the Government of India, public works department, Feb. to June, 1889; Class I., grade 2, superior revenue establishment, June, 1889.

BRADBURY, JAMES FRANCIS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1868; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; also served as officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, Sept., 1876, and officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Aug., 1885; 1st grade, Feb., 1890.

BRADFORD, SIR EDWARD RIDLEY COLBORNE, Colonel, K.C.B., K.C.S.I., A.D.C., M.S.C.—Cornet, 6th light cavalry, Madras, Feb., 1854; proceeded to Persia under General Jacob in 1856; political assistant in Western Malwa, and in command of 1st Regiment Central India Horse, Nov., 1860; political agent, Bhagelcund, 1871; political agent, Bhurtpur, Jan., 1873; general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoitee, May, 1874; agent to governor-general, Rajputana, Dec., 1878; also chief commissioner of Ajmere; secretary, political and secret department, India office, Feb., 1887; accompanied H.R.H. Prince Albert Victor on his visit to India in 1889-90; K.C.B., May, 1890; resigned on his appointment as chief commissioner metropolitan police, London, June, 1890.

BRADLEY, HERBERT (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in South Canara as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting head assistant, and was in charge of the South Canara forests, Sept., 1883, to April, 1885; acting deputy commissioner, salt revenue, April, 1885, and on special duty with the commissioner, July, 1885; secretary to the commissioner of salt, Akbari and Separatpo revenue, April, 1888; member of the board of examiners.

BRADLEY, J. A., Legal Department, India Office.—Clerk to the legal adviser to the secretary of state.

BRADSHAW, JOHN, M.A., LL.D., Madras Education Department.—Educated at Enniskillen Royal School and Trinity College, Dublin; head master of Bishop Corrie's School, Madras, 1868; head master, Mangalore College, 31st Dec., 1870; acting inspector of schools, Sep., 1871; member of conference of inspectors of schools, Jan., 1873; professor of history, Presidency College, April, 1875, continuing to act as inspector of schools; fellow of University of Madras, July, 1875; from Sep., 1872, has served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to 3rd class of the department, March, 1884; member of committee for preparing a scheme for examination for the degree of licentiate of teaching, Oct.-Nov., 1883; board of examiners, Oct., 1884; member of committee for revision of the grant-in-aid code, 1885; president of committee for preparation of the pre-matriculation text, 1886 and 1888; president of Middle school examination committee, 1888; vice-chairman of Board of examiners for upper secondary examination, 1889-90; has edited the series of English reading books for government schools in Madras, and Milton's poetical works with notes, and published an English Anthology, 1885.

BRAJENDRANATH DE, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Hare School, Calcutta, Canning College, Lucknow, Calcutta University, and St. Mary's Hall, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 6th September, 1875; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1886, 1st grade, March, 1888; has also officiated as magistrate and collector.

BRANDIS, SIR DIETRICH, PH.D., K.C.I.E.—Educated at Universities of Copenhagen, Gottingen, and Bonn; lecturer on botany at University of Bonn, 1849; served in the forest department of the government of India from 16th Jan., 1856, and was appointed inspector-general of forests, April, 1864; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; retired, 1883; appointed a member of the board of visitors of the Royal Indian Engineering College, 1886; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887; author of 'Forest Flora of North-West and Central India, London, 1874,' of the article on 'Teak,' in the Encyclopaedia Britannica, &c.; &c.; is director of the practical course of forestry on the continent in connection with Cooper's Hill College.

BRANDRETH, ASHTON MILNES, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1855; arrived in India 30th Dec., 1857; served in the public works department from 8th Jan., 1858, as assistant engineer, assistant principal, Thomason College, and executive engineer; transferred to the Punjab, Sept., 1861, and served on the Western Jumna Canal; assistant secretary, government of India, May to Dec., 1863; assistant secretary, public works department, Punjab, May, 1867; officiating assistant to chief engineer and secretary to Government, Nov., 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; officiating superintending engineer, Western Jumna Canal, April, 1871; principal, Thomason College, Feb., 1879.

BRANDT, FRANCIS, B.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the revenue department, and in the departments under the chief secretary, acting sub-secretary to board of revenue, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty, board of revenue, 1872; acting collector of
sea customs, Madras, April, 1874; collector and magistrate, South Canara, Oct., 1877, and afterwards in the Nilgiris, 1883; district and sessions judge, Trichinopoly, June, 1878; member of rent law committee, Sept., 1882; judge of the high court, Madras, Sept., 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886; retired, Dec., 1887.

BRANFOOT, ARTHUR MUDGE, Surgeon-Major, M.B., M.R.C.S., L.R.C.P., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, 30th March, 1872; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1872, and served under the military department till March, 1873, and subsequently as civil surgeon at Cocanada, and Madras, and as resident surgeon at the general hospital, Madras, and professor of pathology in the Medical College, April-July, 1878; assistant physician, general hospital, and professor of hygiene, Medical College, July, 1878; superintendent of the lying-in-hospital, and professor of midwifery, Medical College, July, 1881; surgeon-major, March, 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886.

BRANSON, JAMES CHARLES EMERTON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 16th Jan., 1882, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, officiating deputy-commissioner, and officiating city magistrate of Lucknow; transferred to Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885; officiating assistant accountant-general Madras, March, 1886, and deputy accountant-general, Bombay, March, 1889.

BRANSON, J. H. SPRING (Barrister-at-Law) Madras Judicial Department.—Crown prosecutor and public prosecutor for town of Madras, 4th July, 1885; acting advocate general, March, 1887; additional member of Madras Legislative Council, March, 1887; advocate general, Madras, Sep., 1889.

BRASHER, ALFRED, late Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed traffic manager, Persian Gulf telegraphs, 1863; superintendent, London office, 1867; director of traffic 1880; had charge of London training school in autumn, 1863; had executive charge of examinations for Indian telegraph department from 1867 to the opening of Cooper's Hill College; projected mean tariff between India and Europe, which replaced rates to different countries; has been on special duty to Constantinople, Vienna, Berlin, and Berne; has made public translations of the international telegraph conventions of Rome, St. Petersburg, London, and Berlin; retired, 1888.

BRERETON, ASHLEY F., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Bedford School; supernumerary writer, 13th Feb., 1860; temporary clerk, Dec., 1866; clerk in registry department, Jan., 1869; junior clerk, financial department, April, 1874; senior clerk, Nov., 1885; transferred to revenue statistics and commerce department, 1886.

BRERETON, REGINALD HUGH, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, April, 1889.

BRETT, ALFRED CORBYN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 31st Oct., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1877; from May, 1878, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1880.

BRETT, CECIL MICHAEL WILFORD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Guildford Grammar School, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1885; member central examination committee, April, 1886; registrar, high court (appellate side), April, 1886.

BRIDGES, ALBERT, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1887, and served as assistant Commissioner in the Punjab.

BRIDGES, JAMES EMILE, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Royal College, Tournai, and University of Bonn; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1876, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, land revenue, and agricultural department, and officiating director of agriculture, Nov., 1884; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Aug. 1886, 3rd grade, Dec., 1888; officiating chief-secretary, March, 1890.

BRIGGS, W. H., Surgeon-Major, late Madras.—First commission, 30th Sept., 1875; surgeon-major, June, 1885; medical officer on personal staff of governor of Madras, Dec., 1886; served in the Jowaki campaign, 1877-1878 (medal and clasp), the Afghan campaigns, 1878-1880 (medal), and the Nile campaign, 1884-1885 (medal and clasps and Khedive's star).

BRIGHT, WILLIAM ROBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

BROADFOOT, RAMSAY DOUGLAS (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Kensington School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1888.

BROCKMAN, WILLIAM DRAKE, A.M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the Punjab as sub-assistant revenue surveyor, 1852-55; joined Thomason College at Roorkee, and from there was appointed to the public works department, April, 1858, and served in the N.W. Provinces in the buildings and roads branch as assistant engineer; transferred temporarily to railway department, Nov., 1859, to Dec., 1860; employed on famine relief
works on Ganges Canal in 1861, and again in 1877-78 in the Rae Bareli division; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1874; on special duty in the public works secretariat, Nov., 1878; superintendent of works, Agra, Oct., 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1886; superintending engineer 1st circle, provincial works, Oct., 1887, and superintending engineer, 2nd class, Nov., 1887; 1st superintending engineer, Dec., 1889; charge of 3rd circle of superintendence, buildings and roads branch, June, 1890.

BRODIE, NORMAN SOMERVILLE, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at University College School and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India 12 Dec., 1887, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

BRODIE, VERNOR ALEXANDER, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India 6th Jan., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; senior assistant to collector, magistrate, and agent, Vizagapatam, Feb., 1885.

BROJENDRO COOMAR SEAL, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 23rd Oct., 1865, served in the subordinate judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1880, and district judge, Bankura, and assistant session judge, Burdwan, April, 1881; has officiated as district and sessions judge, Jessore and Khoolna.

BROOKE, THOMAS HENRY BARSTOW, Colonel, M.S.C., late Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, April, 1855; arrived in India, 13th May, 1855; was employed under the military department up to 1864, including service in the China expedition, 1857-59; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as superintendent of the school of industry and central jail, and as judge of the small cause court, Jubbulpore, 1874; cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Nov., 1874; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, March, 1883; reverted to military duty, 1889.

BROOKE, WILLIAM ROBERT, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 13th Sept., 1857; superintendent, Bombay, Jan., 1866; served in the Punjab, 1869-1871; 1st grade superintendent, Aug., 1877, officiating as director of traffic; director, construction branch, June, 1883; officiating deputy director-general, Nov., 1886, to Feb., 1887; and Aug., 1887, to March, 1888; permanent, July, 1889; director-general of telegraphs, March, 1890.

BROOKE, WILLIAM SAURIN, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1853; arrived in India 3rd January, 1859; served in the Central Provinces from Jan., 1863, as assistant commissioner; acting assistant settlement officer, Chanda, Oct., 1865; acting registrar-general, Central Provinces, Jan., 1866; cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, May, 1869; acting inspector-general of police and jails, Aug.-Nov., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, May, 1886; and class, Aug., 1889.

BROWN, JOHN ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at foreign schools, University College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, April, 1888.

BROWN, CHARLES DALLAS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India 22nd Nov., 1887, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate.

BROWN, FRANCIS DAVID MILLETT, Col., A.I.C.E., V.C., S.C., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 8th Dec., 1855; lieutenant, 1st Bengal European regiment, June, 1857; served in the Indian mutiny and was present at siege and capture of Delhi and Lucknow; medal, 2 clasps, Victoria cross; also in the N.W. frontier campaign, the 2nd Enzufai expedition, and the Umbeyla campaign, medal and clasp; served in public works department, N.W. Provinces (irrigation) from Sept., 1865; executive engineer, March, 1871; assistant secretary, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1871; superintending engineer, April, 1889.

BROWN, GEORGE EUSTACE RIQU GRANT, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at St. Paul's School, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Burma division of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Burma 9th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant commissioner.

BROWN, JOHN CROMMELIN, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India 24th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; was employed in the public works department, Nov., 1879, to April, 1880; on special duty, Dec., 1880; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Feb., 1887.

BROWN, RICHARD CECIL, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Clergy Orphan School, Canterbury, and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1889, and served in Bombay as assistant magistrate and collector.

BROWN, THOMAS EDWIN BURTON, C.I.E., Brigade-Surgeon, M.D., late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1858; arrived in India, 11th Feb., 1859; from Nov., 1860, served as professor of chemistry and chemical examiner, medical school, Lahore; principal, medical school, March, 1872; professor of surgery and midwifery in addition to his other duties, April-Dec., 1876; also officiated as civil surgeon of Lahore on several occasions, and as meteorological reporter, July-Aug., 1879; author of a work on the symptoms and treatment of the poisons used in the Punjab; retired Oct., 1889; C.I.E., Jan., 1891.

BROWN, WILLIAM BARCLAY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Ayr Academy and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after competition of 1883; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1886; served in Bengal as assis-
tant magistrate and collector; transferred to Assam, May, 1889.

BROWNE, CLEMENT METCALFE, Major-Gen., R.E., late Public Works Department.—First commission, Bombay Engineers, 1854; joined the public works department, June, 1856, as assistant engineer; transferred to Punjab, May, 1859; executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1868; officiating assistant to chief engineer, Punjab, and assistant secretary, public works department, Oct., 1868; assistant to chief engineer, military works, Murree, April, 1872; officiating superintending engineer, military works, Allahabad, Aug., 1873; superintending engineer, Punjab (provincial), Feb., 1877; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; rank of chief engineer, March, 1886; chief engineer and secretary, public works department, Burma, Oct., 1886; chief engineer, 2nd class, Nov., 1886; officiating chief engineer and secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1887; retired, May, 1888.

BROWNE, LORD HENRY ULLIC, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College, Dec., 1850; arrived 1st Sept., 1851; served in the revenue and judicial department, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1866; also served as private secretary to the president of the governor-general's council, Feb., 1858, under secretary to the government of Bengal, July, 1859, officiating under secretary to the government of India, home and financial department, April, 1860, registrar of the Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, April, 1861, superintendent of stamps and stationery, Oct., 1865, and officiating additional judge, Jessore and Nudda, Feb., 1867; commissioner, Chittagong division, Dec., 1869, and subsequently of the Presidency, and Rajshahiye and Cooch Behar divisions; chairman of the justices of the peace, Calcutta, Feb., 1872, and officiating member, board of revenue, June, 1878; retired, Oct., 1886.

BROWNE, Sir JAMES, Maj.-Gen., K.C.S.I., C.B., R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Aug., 1858; joined the public works department, June, 1860, as assistant engineer in the Punjab; executive engineer, April, 1866; transferred to military works, 1873, and subsequently to the railway branch, Oct., 1874; superintendent of works, Indus Bridge, Indus Valley state railway, Jan., 1875; during 1878-79 served in the Afghan war as superintending engineer with the Quetta field force (medal); C.S.I., July, 1879; assistant secretary to government, buildings and road branch Punjab, May, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Oct., 1882, military works; served in the Egyptian expedition as commanding engineer, 1882 (medal and clasp, bronze star, 3rd class Osmanieh, C.B.); transferred temporarily to railway branch for employment on the Hurnai road, Biluchistan, 1883; engineer-in-chief, Sind-Pishin state railway, 1884; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Jan., 1884, 1st class, March, 1887; K.C.S.I., Jan., 1888; quarter-master-general in India, sub pro tem., with local rank of major-general, May, 1889.

BROWNE, Ven., JAMES FRANCIS, B.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Madras.—Divinity College, London; junior chaplain, Madras, 20th July, 1870; senior chaplain, July, 1880; archdeacon of the diocese of Madras and commissary to the Lord Bishop, Feb., 1884; senior joint chaplain of St. George's Cathedral, Feb., 1884; in charge of the diocese, May to Oct., 1884, and again in May, 1890; fellow of Madras university, March, 1886.

BROWNE, SAMUEL HASLETT, Surgeon-Major, Punjab Medical Department.—Joined the service, March, 1874, and arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1874; served on hospital duty and on military duty in Afghanistan in 1878; from Aug., 1879, served in the Central Provinces on general and jail duty; served under the government of India from Dec., 1886 in joint medical charge, Simla; appointed principal of medical college, Lahore, Oct., 1889.

BROWNE, WILLIS, F.I.A., Funds Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 15th Oct., 1867; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878; actuarial clerk, Feb., 1882; fellow of Institute of actuaries, 1887; actuary, 1890.

BROWNE, WILLIAM RICHARD, M.D., Ch.M., Surgeon-Major, Madras Medical Department; joined the service, April, 1873; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1873, and served on military and civil and jail duty in Madras; resident surgeon in general hospital, and professor of pathology, Medical College, Nov., 1883; surgeon-major, April, 1885; acted for various periods as surgeon in general hospital, and professor of surgery, Medical College, and was confirmed in that appointment May, 1890; field service in Rumpa Hill tracts and Jeypore territory in 1879-80.

BROWNING, COLIN ARROTT ROBERTSON, M.A., C.I.E., late Educational Department, Central Provinces.—Senior inspector of schools, N.W. Provinces, 26th June, 1862; acted as director of public instruction, Central Provinces, May, 1864, to March, 1865, and as inspector-general of education, Central Provinces, April-Oct., 1868, and again March, 1869, to July, 1870; director of public instruction in Oudh, July, 1870; inspector-general of education, Central Provinces, Oct., 1873; on special duty at Calcutta in connection with education conference in 1882; C.I.E., Jan., 1886; retired Jan., 1886; author of 'The Indian Official Thesaurus,' 'The Annals of the Indian Empire,' 'Mahomedan Education in Oude,' 'A List of Sanscrit Manuscripts existing in Oudh,' and various reports on education in the Central Provinces; has edited several school and text books, and was joint editor of the 1st edition of the Central Provinces' Gazetteer.

BROWNLLOW, HENRY ALEXANDER, Lieut.-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1849; deputy superintendent, Ganges Canal, Feb., 1852; and afterwards on the Eastern and Western Jamna Canals; during the mutiny served at the battle of Budlekeserai, the siege of Delhi, and in the Rohilkund campaign (medal and clasp); superintendent, Eastern Jamna Canals, 1858; superintending engineer, N.W. Provinces, irrigation, March, 1865; 1st grade superintending engineer, Sept., 1870; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1872; superintending engineer, Bari Doab, Punjab, April, 1874; acted as chief engineer and joint secretary, Punjab, Feb.-May, 1876, and as chief engineer and secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, irrigation, June, 1876; officiating inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of
India, April, 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1879; chief engineer and secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, irrigation, July, 1878, and afterwards in the buildings and roads branch; inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, Feb., 1882; retired, Nov., 1886.

BROWNRIGG, Francis William, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rossall, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1881, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Aug., 1880.

BRUCE, Alexander Bannerman, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Glasgow Academy, Chanowry School, Aberdeen, Milne's Institution, Fochabers, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

BRUCE, Henry Alexander, Principal Inspector-General, Her Majesty's Forces, M.D.—Educated at the University of St. Andrew's and the University of Edinburgh, where he graduated M.D. in 1829; diploma of the Royal College of Surgeons, Edinburgh, 1828; assistant surgeon on the Bengal medical establishment, 1830; arrived at Calcutta, Jan., 1831; was employed on regimental duty, and served through the Cabul campaign, 1838 to 1841; was present at the storming of Ghuznee, 1839 (medal), and with the garrison of Cabul, 1839-40; in medical charge of the force sent to oppose Dost Mahomed in the Hindoo Koosh, Sept., 1840; surgeon to the envoy of Herat, Jan., 1841; was posted to the Sirmoor rifle battalion, Feb., 1841; principal medical storekeeper to the army of reserve, Nov., 1842; served in the Sutlej campaign, 1846, and was present at the battles of Aliwal (medal) and Sobraon (clasp); rank of surgeon, June, 1847; medical storekeeper, Cawnpore, and staff surgeon, Dec., 1852; supervising surgeon, Sirhind circle, May, 1859; inspector-general of hospitals, Upper Provinces, April, 1862; principal inspector-general, medical department, November, 1865; retired, Sept., 1866; Fellow of the University of Calcutta, Jan., 1865.

BRUCE, Richard Isaac, C.I.E., Political Department, Punjab.—Served in the Punjab as extra assistant-commissioner, 1863-1868; assistant commissioner, Dec., 1868; prepared a gazetteer of the Dhera Ghazi Khan district, and a manual of the Biluch language; on special duty in connection with Major Sandeman's 2nd Kalat mission, 1876; 1st assistant to agent to governor-general, Biluchistan, Feb., 1877; compiled a history of the Marri-Biluchi tribe; acted as agent, Biluchistan in 1878 and 1885; political agent at Thal-Chotiali from 1882; rejoined Punjab commission and appointed deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, May, 1883; 1st grade, Nov., 1889.

BUCK, Sir Edward Charles, Kt., B.L., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; from May, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, settlement officer, and officiating secretary, board of revenue; director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1875; commissioner for the government of India at the Melbourne International Exhibition of 1880; officiated as secretary to the Government of India in the revenue and agricultural department, July, 1881, and was confirmed in that appointment, April, 1882.

BUCKLAND, Charles Edward (Barrister-at-Law), B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; attaché, foreign department, Nov., 1871; officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Barrackpore, Jan., 1874; on special duty in Behar, Jan., 1874; on famine duty, March, 1874; officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1875; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, April, 1874, to Jan., 1877; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1876; private secretary to Sir Richard Temple during his mission to Madras and Bombay, Jan., 1877; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May, 1877; officiating under-secretary, government of India, home department, May, 1878; private secretary to president of governor-general's council, Nov., 1878; officiating press commissioner with government of India, Feb., 1879; superintendent of stamps and stationery, Bengal, May, 1880; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1882, and again in 1883, 1884, and 1886; confirmed, May, 1887; officiating secretary to the Government of Bengal, general revenue and statistical departments, July, 1889; secretary to Board of Revenue, May, 1890; edited 'Excess Manual,' 1884.

BUCKLE, Henry, Burma.—Served in the Burma commission from 7th Aug., 1867, as assistant commissioner, and was in charge of the town magistrate's office, Akyab, Sept., 1871, to Nov., 1874, and of the Hill Tracts of Northern Arakan, Dec., 1874, to Jan., 1876; in command of an expedition beyond the frontier against the Shandus, Nov., 1870; from June, 1878, served as deputy commissioner in various districts, and was promoted to 2nd grade, April, 1882; president, Henzada municipal committee, Dec., 1884; officiating commissioner, Arakan division, March, 1888, and of the eastern division, March, 1890.

BUCKLEY, Llewellyn Eddison, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and at New College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 10th Sept., 1887, and served as assistant to magistrate and collector.

BULLOCK, Frederick D'Olbert, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kingstown Grammar School, St. Aubin's Grammar School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judge small cause court, Delhi, Jan., 1873; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1882; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Oct., 1885; and 2nd grade, Nov., 1889.

BULLOCK, Frederick Shore, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Chel-
tenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating cantonment magistrate, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, small cause court judge, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate, 1st grade, June, 1885; magistrate and collector, April, 1889.

BULLOCK, ROBERT, Colonel, M.S.C., Berar Commission.—First commission Madras army (infantry), 11th Dec., 1853; from July, 1862, served in the Berar commission as assistant commissioner, officiating assistant resident, officiating small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner (March, 1880); boundary commissioner for demarcation of the Dhans frontier, Feb. to June, 1886; judicial commissioner, sub pro temp., Aug. 1888; civil and sessions judge, July, 1889.

BULMAN, ALBERT ROBINSON, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Richmond Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, July, 1874; judicial assistant, 1st grade, March, 1878; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Dec., 1882; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Lahore, Aug., 1884; 1st grade deputy commissioner, March, 1886; officiating commissioner, Umballa, Jan., 1887, retired, April, 1889.

BUNBURY, CECIL EDWARD FRANCIS, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Wellington College and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1883, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

BURGESS, GEORGE DOUGLAS, C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1870, and served in the British Burma commission as assistant commissioner, assistant collector of customs, and deputy commissioner; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officer in charge of state prisoners, Jan., 1879; secretary to chief commissioner, July, 1881; officiating commissioner, Tenasserim, Sept., 1884, and subsequently in the Irrawaddy division; commissioner, Arakan, April, 1886; commissioner, northern division, Aug., 1886; C.S.I., 1 Jan., 1889.

BURGESS, JAMES, C.I.E., LL.D., F.R.G.S., M.R.A.S., M. Soc. As., Paris, late Archaeological Survey of India.—Was educated at Dumfries, Glasgow, and Edinburgh; archaeological surveyor and reporter for Western India, 15th Jan., 1874; also archaeological surveyor for Southern India, Nov. 1881; director-general of the archaeological survey of India, March, 1886; was a fellow of the University of Bombay; retired 1890; author of scientific papers in the Philosophical Magazine, 'The Indian Antiquary,' 'Views of Architecture and Scenery in Gujarat and Rajputana,' 'Reports of the Archaeological Survey of Western and Southern India,' and, conjointly with the late J. Ferguson, LL.D., C.I.E., 'The Rock Temples of India.'

BURKE, John, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department.—Joined the department, 2nd June, 1864; superintendent, 2nd grade, Aug., 1883; officiating director of traffic, Feb., 1886; superintendent, Class IV., and grade, Oct., 1887; has held charge of various divisions.

BURKIT, WILLIAM ROBERT, M.A., (Barister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; called to the bar at the Middle Temple, appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1875, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1880; district and sessions judge, Aug., 1887; acting judicial commissioner in Oudh, April and May, 1890.

BURLS, E. GRANT, Store Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 20th Oct., 1863; junior clerk, store department, Dec., 1865; senior clerk, Jan., 1875.

BURTON, HENRY MONTGOMERY BARTON, Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 5th Native Infantry, Bengal, Aug., 1855; served in the Indian Mutiny, 1858-59, and was present at the capture of Gwalior, the actions of Jaora and Alipore, and other operations (medal and clasp); served subsequently in the Bhutan campaign, 1862, and the Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68 (medal); assistant cantonment magistrate, Morar, 1870; cantonment magistrate, Mhow, 1881; cantonment magistrate, Morar, Dec., 1884, and at Umballa, Nov., 1886; cantonment magistrate, 1st class, March, 1887.

BURN, CHARLES WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India 26th Nov., 1889, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

BURNE, HENRY KNIGHTLEY, Lieut.-General, C.B., Bengal S.C.—Ensign, Dec., 1843; arrived in India, 25th May, 1844; served throughout the Sutlej campaign, 1845-46, including battles of Moodkee and Ferozeshah, and with the expedition against Kota Kangra (medal and clasp); during the Burmese war of 1852-53, was military secretary to General Godwin, commander of the force, and was present at the capture of Prome and Pegu (medal and clasp and brevet rank of major); acted as deputy assistant quartermaster-general, May-Oct. 1849; and as cantonment joint magistrate, Umballa, Nov., 1849; acting brigade major, Umballa, 1849-51, and as deputy assistant adjutant-general, Sirhind division, 1851-52; deputy judge advocate general, April, 1852; 2nd assistant secretary to government of India, military department, July, 1856; 1st assistant secretary, Jan., 1858; deputy secretary, March, 1862; secretary to government of India, military department, June, 1870 to Dec., 1881; C.B., May, 1875.

BURNE, KNIGHTLEY GREY, late Burma Commission.—Served in the Bengal police as assistant superintendent and acting district superintendent, from 26th Oct., 1865 to May 1872, and from the latter date in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, and acted as town magistrate and superintendent of jail at Moul-
mein, 1872-73; officiating director of public instruction, Aug.-Nov., 1882; deputy commissioner, July, 1886.

BURNE, Sir Owen Tudor, Major-Gen., K.C.S.I., C.I.E., Council of India.—Ensign, 20th foot, 15th April, 1855; served in the Crimea; also in the Indian Mutiny of 1858-59, and was present in fifteen actions (including the siege and capture of Lucknow); promoted for gallantry at Lucknow to captaincy and brevet majority. After serving in the field as adjutant of regiment, and brigade-major to a field-column, was appointed military secretary to the commander-in-chief in India (the late field marshal, Lord Strathnairn), 1861-62, and afterwards A.D.C., and at times officiating military secretary to that general officer when commander of the forces in Ireland, 1865-68; private secretary to viceroy of India (Earl of Mayo), 1869-72; political A.D.C. to secretary of state for India, 1872; assistant secretary in political and secret department, India Office, 1873; secretary in that department, 1874; on special duty in India as private secretary to the viceroy (Earl of Lytton), 1876-78; member of the council of India, 1 Jan., 1887; was a royal commissioner of the Health, the Colonial and Indian exhibitions of 1882 and 1886, and is member of special committee appointed by Prince of Wales for organising new Imperial Institute; vice-president of the Society of Arts, 1888.

BURNEY, Richard Thomas (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1858, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; superintendent, Chamba State, April, 1877; officiating additional sessions judge, Jan., 1880; deputy commissioner, 1st class, March, 1880; additional commissioner, Lahore and Rawul Pindi divisions, Dec., 1880; additional judge, chief court, Punjab, Nov., 1882; commissioner and superintendent, Dec., 1883; divisional judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884, Lahore; confirmed as judge of the chief court, Oct., 1885; retired, Oct., 1889.

BURRIDGE, Charles E., India Office Stores Department; appointed 2nd class clerk, 16 March, 1883.

BURROWS, Leonard Robert, M.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Lincoln Diocesan School, St. Nicholas College, Lancing, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1865; president of municipal commission, Madras, 1875-1880; sub-collector and joint magistrate, March, 1882; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, Sept., 1883; collector and magistrate and additional sessions judge, Nilgiris, Sept., 1884; retired, Aug., 1889.

BURTON, William Henry, Colonel, R.E., Madras P.W. Department.—Arrived in India, 26th July, 1857, and was appointed to the public works department, May, 1858, and served in Oudh and Hyderabad; executive engineer, July, 1865; exchanged for temporary service out of India, and appointed to Portsmouth district, and charge of Needles division, Aug., 1867; proceeded to China, Nov., 1875, where he acted for some time, in 1876-7, as commanding Royal engineers; returned to India, Nov., 1877; member of defence committee on coast defences, Dec., 1877; executive engineer, Madras, Jan., 1878; superintending engineer, 3rd class, April, 1880.

BUSTEED, Henry Elmsley, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., C.I.E., late Mint Department, Calcutta.—First commission, Indian medical service (Madras establishment), Aug., 1855; arrived in India, March, 1856; civil surgeon, Cuddalore, Jan., 1861; assistant assay master, Madras mint, Feb., 1865; acted as assay master for various periods, and also as mint master and commissioner of paper currency; deputy assay master, Bombay, April, 1868; from Feb., 1869, served in the Calcutta mint as officiating assay master, and was appointed deputy assay master, Nov., 1870, and confirmed as assay master, Sept., 1872; also acted as mint master in 1873 and 1875; retired June, 1886; C.I.E., Jan., 1887.

BUTLER, James, Major, B.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, 10th foot, Feb., 1866; arrived in Madras, 24th May, 1866; served in the Burma commission from Oct., 1868, as assistant commissioner and town magistrate; appointed a deputy commissioner, July, 1881; president of the Henzada Municipal Committee, Oct., 1884; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Aug., 1886, and 1st grade, Dec., 1889; author of 'Mergui Gazetteer.'

BUTLER, William G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Bradfield and Eton; junior clerk, store department, India office, 31st Jan., 1867; assistant private secretary and précis writer to secretary of state, 1874-78; senior clerk, Dec., 1889.

BUTTERWORTH, Alan, Madras C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived 15th Dec., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate; has acted as assistant secretary and under secretary to government.

BUTTS, Henry Hill (Barrister-at-Law), Oudh Commission.—Extra assistant commissioner, 3rd grade Gonda, 3rd June, 1863; from Nov., 1865, to Oct., 1873, served as assistant settlement officer and officiating settlement officer, and from the latter date as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1879; district judge, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1882; author of the 'Lucknow Settlement Report.'

BUYERS, John Walker, C.I.E., M.A., M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India. Appointed executive engineer, N.W. Provinces, 18th Nov., 1869; 1st executive engineer, Jan., 1880; engineer in chief, Garo Hills survey, Dec., 1881; superintending engineer, March, 1887; C.I.E., May, 1889; engineer-in-chief Mu-valley railway, July, 1880.

BYATT, J., Store Department, India Office.—Assistant clerk, education department, May, 1866; to May, 1873; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, May, 1873; supervisor, 2nd grade, Nov., 1880; 1st grade, July, 1888.

BYRNE, Edward Simpson, Financial Department, Government of India.—Head assistant to auditor-general of India, June, 1862; served in Hyderabad from Jan., 1865, to March, 1871, as deputy auditor and accountant-general, and was
ordered on special duty to Calcutta in connection with Berar finance, Dec., 1867; from March, 1871, to Feb., 1874, served in the Punjab as deputy accountant-general and acting accountant-general, and trustee, Punjab University; served subsequently as deputy accountant-general in Assam, Feb., 1874, to Jan., 1879, and in Bombay 1879 to July, 1882, and acted as accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency, Bombay, in 1879; from July, 1882, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as deputy accountant-general, and acted as accountant-general and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Allahabad, Sept.-Oct., 1882; deputy comptroller-general (afterwards designated deputy auditor-general) in 1st class of the financial department, July, 1883; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Sept.-Oct., 1885; deputy auditor-general, Oct., 1885.

CADELL, ALAN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, Guetersloh Gymnasium, Westphalia, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from July, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from April, 1867, to March, 1881, served in the settlement department in Allahabad, Mozaffarnagar, and Banda, and was placed on special duty, June, 1867, and again in March, 1869, to conduct the prosecution of the Munsif of Deoband; promoted to settlement officer, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, May, 1880; officiating commissioner of excise and stamps and inspector-general of registration, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, March, 1883; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1885; officiating civil and sessions judge, April, 1886; and as commissioner, Agra division, in 1888 and 1889; commission, Rohilkund division, April, 1889.

CADELL, ALEXANDER, Lieutenant-General, late R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 13th June, 1845; joined the public works department, April, 1848; executive engineer, Rawul Pindi, 1850; executive engineer, Nagpore, April, 1856; executive engineer in Oude road department, Dec., 1858; superintendent of works, northern road, and Saugor division, 1863; superintending engineer, Punjab, 1864; from 1867 to 1878 served in Indore, first as superintending engineer, and then as chief engineer, and secretary to the governor-general's agent for Central India; also officiated as chief engineer and secretary to government N.W. Provinces, 1874-75; chief engineer, 1st grade, Jan., 1879; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bengal, 1879-80; deputy inspector-general of military works, 1881-82; retired 13th March, 1882.

CADELL, THOMAS, Colonel, V.C., B.S.C.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, April, 1854; arrived in India, July, 1854; during the mutiny served at the siege of Delhi (medal, clasp, and Victoria cross); and subsequently in the operations in Oudh and Bundelcund; and in command, Malwa Bheel corps, deputy Bheel agent, and political assistant, April, 1861; officiating commandant, Malwa Bheel corps, and Bheel agent, March, 1860; political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, April, 1870; political agent, Ulwar, Nov., 1870; political agent, Marwar, Nov., 1877, and in Meywar, April, 1878; commandant, Erinpoora force, and political agent, Western Rajputana, Oct., 1879; chief commissioner and superintendent, Port Blair and the Nicobars, from Dec., 1879.

CALL, C.
