F., Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., late Store Department, India Office.—Entered the royal engineers, 16th July, 1866; served on the Indian establishment with the Bengal sappers and miners, and afterwards in the public works department, buildings and roads and railway branches, Feb., 1869, to Sept., 1881; served in the Afghan war, 1878-80, including the march from Kabul to Kandahar (medal and 2 clasps, bronze star, and brevet of major); assistant superintendent, India store depot, Jan., 1883, to Feb., 1887.

CALLAGHAN, T., Registry Department, India Office.—2nd class clerk, 27th March, 1885.

CALNAN, DENIS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at French College, Blackrock, Ireland, and Queen's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1834; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1886, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant commissioner.

CAMERON, ARCHIBALD, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Medical Department, N.W. Provinces and Oudh.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, April, 1868; arrived in India, Nov., 1868, and served as civil medical officer at various stations in Oudh; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, Dec., 1870; served subsequently in the same capacity at Bara Banki, Lucknow, Sultanpur, and other places; surgeon-major, April, 1880; in medical charge of camp of lieutenant-governor, Nov., 1884; civil surgeon, 1st class, Allahabad, Feb., 1886.

CAMERON, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces and Oudh.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th July, 1859; arrived in India, 28th Jan., 1860; was employed under the military department 1860-66, and served in the Bhootan campaign (medal); from April, 1866, served in the civil department in Oudh, as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at Bahraich and Rae Bareli; rank of surgeon, July, 1871; surgeon-major, Sept., 1875; served also as civil surgeon at Bara Banki and at Gonda.

CAMERON, DUNCAN, M.A., Bengal, C.S.—Aberdeen University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; confirmed as joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1887; has also acted as district and sessions judge.

CAMERON, LEWIS, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1866; from Feb. 1873, served as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon in Bengal; surgeon major, March, 1878; civil surgeon, Backergunge with charge of the jail, Dec. 1879; transferred to Champaran, Feb. 1883, and to Rajshahiye Dec., 1885.

CAMPBELL, ARCHIBALD COLIN, Assam Commission.—Served in Assam from 27th April, 1861, as assistant commissioner and personal assistant to chief commissioner; was personal assistant to the chief civil officer, Bhutan field force, 1865 (medal and clasp); superintendent
of emigration and embarkation agent, Dhubri, Sept., 1875; promoted to deputy commissioner, Dec., 1878; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, May, 1886.

CAMPBELL, ARCHIBALD EDWARDES, Colonel, B.S.C., late Assam Commission.—First commission, Jan., 1851; served the Sonthal campaign 1855-56, and in Central India, 1857-58 (medal and clasp); from May, 1852 served in the Assam commission and was promoted to deputy commissioner, Dec., 1866; inspector of labourers, Sibsagar, Feb., 1882; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Aug., 1883.

CAMPBELL, COLIN G., India Office.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; junior clerk, military department, 13th Jan., 1876; private secretary to permanent under secretary of state from 1877; senior clerk, 1889; appointed reading clerk to the council, 1890.

CAMPBELL, DUNCAN JOHN ALFRED, Bengal C.S. Burma.—Educated at Tonbridge School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1877, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate; transferred to Burma, Aug., 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, boundary officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, in 1883; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Feb., 1886; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1886; deputy commissioner, May, 1888.

CAMPBELL, FRANCIS JOHNSTONE GRAHAM, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 20th January, 1864; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1875, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, April, 1880; 1st grade, April, 1887; retired Oct., 1890.

CAMPBELL, SIR GEORGE, K.C.S.I., D.C.L., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at New Academy, Edinburgh, and St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College 1842; served in Rohilkund, 1843 to 1846, in usual grades of the revenue and judicial departments, and was in charge of several districts and political divisions of cis-Sutlej states, 1846-51; on furlough 1851 to 1854, during which he was associate of the Court of Queen's Bench, and published 'Modern India,' and 'India as it may be'; magistrate and collector, Azimgurh, 1854; commissioner of customs, N.W. Provinces, 1855; commissioner of the cis-Sutlej states, 1855-1857; took an active part in the events following the mutiny, and was present at several engagements; personal assistant to governor-general, Lord Canning, 1857-58; judicial and financial commissioner of Oude 1858; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1862-66; president of the commission to enquire into the famine in Orissa, 1866-67; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1867-68; while on furlough, 1868-70, published a work on Irish land tenure; D.C.L., University of Oxford; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1871-74; retired 1874; member of council of secretary of state for India, 1874-75; resigned on election as M.P. for Kirkcaldy burghs in 1875; presided over economy and trade department at the Social Science Congress at Glasgow, 1874; re-elected for the Kirkcaldy burghs in 1880, and again in 1885; is the author of numerous statistical, ethnological, and linguistic works on India, also of 'A Handy Book of the Eastern Question, 1876, and of various publications on different countries visited by him.

CAMPBELL, GERALD EDWARD LYON, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1884.

CAMPBELL, JAMES McNABB, M.A., C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Glasgow Academy and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant conservator of forests, acting under secretary to government in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and compiler of the 'Gazetteer' and 'General Administration Report of the Bombay Presidency'; on famine duty, April-Aug., 1877; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, April, 1880; acting under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, Oct., 1880; acted as collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery in 1881; 1st assistant collector, Bombay presidency, May, 1885; has acted as collector and magistrate.

CAMPBELL, JOHN SCARLETT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Grange, Sunderland; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1847; arrived in India, Jan., 1848, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate, Moradabad, 1856; during the mutiny was present at the siege of Delhi, and subsequently took charge of the Rohtuk district as deputy commissioner, 1st class; commissioner, Saugor division, Central Provinces, Jan., 1862; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, 1864; officiating chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1865; judge of the chief court, Punjab, 1871; on assassination of Lord Mayo in 1872, was deputed to enquire into and report on the administration of the convict settlement in the Andaman Islands; retired, 1878; author of a 'Memo. on proposed changes in the mode of selection and training of candidates for the Indian Civil Service.'

CAMPBELL, JOHN STRATHEDEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1883, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; senior assistant commissioner, Garhwal, Dec., 1886.

CAMPBELL, LORNE AUGUSTUS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1866; under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, Jan., 1875, to Feb., 1881, and acted on several occasions as secretary to Government, and as sub-secretary, board of revenue; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Oct., 1882; district and sessions judge, Nellore, Oct., 1884.

CAMPBELL, RICHARD HAMILTON, Madras
C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competitive examination of 1833; arrived, 18th Dec., 1835; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886.

CAMPBELL-WALKER, INCHES, Colonel, Madras S.C., Forest Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1859; from May, 1865, served in the Madras forest department as assistant conservator and deputy conservator; appointed by the secretary of state a commissioner for the Vienna Exhibition, April, 1873; knight commander of the order of Francis Joseph of Austria for services at the Vienna Exhibition; officiating inspector of forests, Feb., 1874, to Sept., 1875; on duty at the forest conference, Simla, Sept., 1875; member of the forest bill committee, Madras, Jan., 1876, and again, March, 1882; on special duty to New Zealand, March, 1876, to Nov., 1877, and in Nilgiris, S. Coimbatore, and Tinnevelly, Dec., 1877; member of forest draft bill committee, March, 1882; conservator of forests, 1st grade, Dec., 1884; author of reports on forest management in Germany, Austria, and Great Britain (1872), and on the forests of New Zealand.

CANDY, EDWARD TOWNSHEND (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; on special duty, Poonah, March, 1869; from Oct., 1873, acted as judicial assistant to the political agent, Kāthiāwār, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1878; acting judicial commissioner and judge of the sadar court in Sind, May, 1883; 2nd grade, judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, Aug., 1883; 1st grade judge, Surat, Feb., 1883; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, July-Nov., 1885; judge and sessions judge, Belgaum, Aug., 1885; officiating Judge of High Court, Bombay, Jan. 1889, to Jan. 1890, and again in May, 1890.

CANDY, RICHARD EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting educational inspector; acting director of public instruction, Berar, June, 1872, to Dec., 1873; first assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1877; junior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, May, 1885; senior collector, Sept. 1888.

CAPPEL, SIR ALBERT JAMES LEPPOC, K.C.I.E., late Indian Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the telegraph department, 10th Feb., 1857; 1st grade superintendent and personal assistant to director general, Dec., 1866; director of traffic, May, 1869; deputy director-general, Feb., 1879; director-general of telegraphs, June, 1883; K.C.I.E., Feb. 1887; director-general of telegraphs, Feb., 1888; retired 1889.

CAPPEL, EDWARD LOUIS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from May, 1882, served under the government of Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; transferred permanently to the Bombay civil service, June, 1883; acting junior collector, May, 1887; 2nd assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1889.

CARD, H.C., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 22nd Jan., 1875.

CARDEW, ALEXANDER GORDON, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Somersetshire College, Bath, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting deputy registrar high court, and acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments (July, 1885); on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1884, and again in 1885; on special duty as secretary to the Malabar land tenures committee, Dec., 1885; acting under secretary to government, revenue department, Oct., 1886, and May, 1887; assistant secretary, judicial and legislative departments, Sept., 1888; undersecretary, revenue department, May, 1889.

CARDOZO, HENRY O'CONNELL, Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras revenue survey department from 21st March, 1859, and was promoted to deputy superintendent, 1st class, March, 1883, and to superintendent, July, 1887.

CAREY, ARTHUR DOUGLAS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the City of London School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; served in the salt department from May, 1872, to March, 1877, and from May, 1877 to Feb., 1882, as assistant collector of salt revenue, and acting deputy collector, and was appointed collector of salt revenue, Bombay, April, 1881; on special duty to Sambarh, Oct., 1881; from Feb., 1882, served under the government of India as officiating commissioner, inland customs; commissioner, salt revenue, Northern India, Dec., 1882.

CAREY, LIONEL SLADE, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India 13th Dec., 1882, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acting district superintendent of police, July, 1883; acting inspector of schools, May-July, 1884; acting deputy commissioner, 1884; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, June to Dec., 1885; settlement officer, Bilaspur, Oct., 1886.

CARLYLE, ROBERT WARRAND, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Glasgow University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec. 1880; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; acting under secretary to Government of Bengal, April, 1888; confirmed, Dec., 1888; has officiated also as under secretary to the government of India home department, and as magistrate and collector.
CARMICHAEL, Charles Paget, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and subsequently at Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1849; arrived in India, March, 1849; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1854; officiating registrar of Sudder Dewany and Nizamat Adawlut, April, 1854; officiating civil auditor, Aug., 1854; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1856; deputed as civil officer with the relieving force to Shahjahanpur, April, 1853; magistrate and collector, Budaina, Feb., 1862; officiating commissioner, Kumaun, May, 1867, to Jan., 1868; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1870; from April, 1873, acted as commissioner and agent to governor-general, Benares, and was confirmed in these appointments, March, 1877; also held the substantive appointment of district and sessions judge, Jan., 1877; officiated as member of the board of revenue in 1877-78-79, and was appointed permanently to the board in 1882; retired March, 1884.

CARMICHAEL, David Fremantle, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury, 1851; assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1851; head assistant registrar, court of Sudder and Foujdaree Adawlut, Feb., 1855; deputy secretary to government, Oct., 1856; secretary to board of examiners, Oct., 1856; private secretary to governor of Madras, March, 1859; fellow of Madras University, Oct., 1859; collector and magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, July, 1863, to April, 1867, and afterwards at Ganjam; acting judge, high court, Madras, April to July, 1869; employed in preparation of Vizagapatam district manual; acting member, board of revenue, Aug., 1871; president of committee for examination of assistants, July, 1871; Inam commissioner, Aug., 1871; on special duty as president of the committee for inquiring into the action of government officials during cyclone in 1872, May, 1872; secretary to government, revenue department, Nov., 1872; additional member of council for making laws and regulations Feb., 1874; on special duty with government at imperial assemblage, Delhi, Dec., 1876; chief secretary to government, June, 1877; ordinary member of council, Madras, Dec., 1878; on tour as special commissioner through Hill tracts of Ganjam, Vizagapatam, and Godavari, Feb., 1881; retired, 1886.

CARMICHAEL, George, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen Grammar School and at University of Aberdeen and Balliol College, Oxford; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1836; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1837; forest settlement officer, Nov., 1838; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Aug., 1880.

CARNDUFF, Herbert William Cameron, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Collegiate School, University of Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1831; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1833; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1833; officiated as cantonment magistrate and as joint magistrate and deputy collector; appointed under secretary to Government of Bengal, May, 1835; acted as registrar appellate side high court, Calcutta, March, 1856.

CARR, Reginald Childers Culling, Madras, C.S.—Educated at Cheam school, the Charterhouse, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1888; additional special assistant to district magistrate and collector, March, 1889; acted as under-secretary to government in the revenue and chief secretary's departments in 1889 and 1890.

CARSTAIRS, Robert, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Edinburgh Collegiate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty under board of revenue, Nov., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1886; 1st grade, Jan., 1888; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Aug., 1888.

CARTER, Albert M., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College; temporary clerk, India office, 4th Nov., 1861; junior clerk, March, 1866; senior clerk, Aug., 1882.

CARTER, George Markham Strange, Burma commission.—Appointed chief inspector of police, June, 1875; assistant district superintendent, Feb., 1880, and district superintendent, Oct., 1882; appointed to the commission as assistant commissioner, March, 1886.

CARTER, Henry Vandvke, Brigade Surgeon, M.D. (Lon.), late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 27th Jan., 1858; arrived in India, 29th March, 1855, and served on military duty and as professor of anatomy and physiology, and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, and assistant surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital; also as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Satara; on special duty in England, May, 1874, and in Bombay and Kathiawar, 1875; appointed surgeon to the Gokuldas Tejpal Hospital, Bombay, Nov., 1879; brigade surgeon, Sept., 1882; principal and professor of medicine and clinical medicine, Grant Medical College, first physician Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, 1886; retired, Aug., 1888.

CARTER, Thomas Tupper, Colonel, R.E. (Bengal), late Survey of India.—First commission, Dec. 1857; arrived in India, Dec., 1859; served with the Sikkim Field Force, 1860-61, as survey officer; from May, 1861, to April, 1862, served as assistant engineer in the public works department, Punjab; appointed to the great trigonometrical survey of India, March, 1862, and served as assistant in the Kashmir and Kumaon and Garhwal surveys; served in the Umbeyla Campaign, 1863 (medal and clasp); surveyor, 3rd grade, April, 1866; in charge of the survey party with the Abyssinian expedition, Dec., 1867, to March, 1868; was subsequently in charge of survey parties on the Brahmaputra, in Madras, Guzerat, Kumaon, Gwalior, and Central India; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, March, 1886; retired, Jan., 1887.

CASEY, Arthur Edwin Comerford, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portora Royal School, and Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service
after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, Kumaon, May, 1882; retired, Oct., 1889.

CASPERSZ, CHARLES PETER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and London University.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and settlement officer; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1889; also officiated as district and sessions judge.

CASSON, HERBERT ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab)—Educated at Newton Abbot Proprietary College and Marlborough College and Hertford College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1889, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

CAVE-BROWNE, E.R., C.S.I., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the College School, Taunton; junior clerk in the treasury, East India House, 12th April, 1854, and from 1858 in the India Office; accountant-general's department, 1860; senior clerk, June, 1867; assistant in the accounts branch of the financial department, Jan., 1872; assessor of income tax 1872; deputy accountant-general, Feb., 1879; C.S.I., Jan., 1888.

CAYLEY, H., Brigade Surgeon, late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1857; from April, 1872, served as civil surgeon and officiating superintendent of vaccination, superintendent of royal botanical gardens, ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic surgery, Medical College, Calcutta (from Jan., 1876), superintendent of the eye infirmary, and marine surgeon; rank of brigade surgeon, April, 1884; medical board, India office, 1885; retired, April, 1887.

CENTER, WILLIAM, M.B., M.A., Brigade-Surgeon, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined Indian medical department in 1865; arrived in India, 11th April, 1866; from March, 1871, served under the government of the Punjab as chemical examiner and professor of chemistry and surgery in the Lahore medical school; officiating meteorological reporter in addition to his other duties, May, 1872; surgeon-major, Oct., 1877; served under the government of India, Aug.-Nov., 1882, as statistical officer in sanitary department; officiated as principal of the Lahore medical school in 1878, 1882, and 1883; civil surgeon, Lahore, and superintendent, lunatic asylum, 1884; civil surgeon, 1st class, Aug., 1885; professor of forensic medicine and midwifery, Lahore medical college, April, 1888; brigade surgeon, April, 1889.

CHAMBERLAIN, SIR NEVILLE BOWLES, General, G.C.B., G.C.S.I.—Ensign, Bengal Infantry, 1837; served through the Afghan campaigns of 1839-42 (medal); present with the governor-general's body-guard at the battle of Maharajpore, Dec., 1843 (bronze star); deputy assistant quartermaster-general to the army, 1843; hon. aide-de-camp to Lord Dalhousie, 1848; served in the Punjab campaign of 1848-49, including the actions of Chillianwallah and Goojerat (medal and two clasps); military secretary to the chief commissioner for affairs of the Punjab, March, 1853; commandant, Punjab irregular force, Dec., 1854; adjutant-general of the Bengal army, July, 1857; C.B., 1857; aide-de-camp to the Queen for services in the mutiny; commanded the force on the N.W. frontier of India in various expeditions against the hill tribes (medal and clasp); commander in chief, Madras, and member of the governor's council, Feb., 1876 to 1881; was appointed head of the special mission to Kabul, Aug., 1878, which, however, was not allowed to enter the Ameer's territory.

CHAMIER, FRANCIS EDWARD ARCHIBALD, Major-Gen., B.S.C., late Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, 7th April, 1850; aide-de-camp to General Outram throughout the Oudh campaign; commanded the Kapurthala contingent during its service in Oudh, in 1858 (medal and two clasps); from March, 1858, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, officiating settlement officer, and officiating commissioner in various divisions; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Bara Banki, April, 1873; district judge, 1st grade, Rae Bareli, Feb., 1882, and afterward at Fyzabad; returned to Europe, 1883.

CHANNING, FRANCIS CHORLEY, Bengal C.S (Punjab).—Educated at Corpus Christi College Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; settlement secretary to financial commissioner Jan., 1878; senior secretary to the financial commissioner, March, 1882; officiated as divisional judge, Nov., 1885, and again April, 1887; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, March, 1886; district judge, 1st grade, Jan., 1888, but to continue to act as divisional judge; on special duty, civil secretariat, Jan., 1889; divisional judge, 3rd grade, May, 1890.

CHAPMAN, CHARLES, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 6th Aug., 1884.

CHAPMAN, EDMUND PELLY, Bengal Civil Service.—Educated at Clifton College and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1889, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

CHAPMAN, ROBERT ALEXANDER BOSWELL, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces, &c.)—Educated at Haileybury College, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service, after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 15 Nov., 1885; and served in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector.

CHAPMAN, ROBERT BARCLAY, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1850; arrived 6th March, 1850; served in Bengal in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; under secretary to government of India, home, financial, and foreign departments, April, 1856, to April, 1860; called to the bar (Inner Temple) Jan., 1863; junior secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, June, 1863; acting commissioner, Nudder division, Nov., 1866, to Jan., 1869; served subsequently as secretary to government of India, financial department, and government director of Bank of Bengal; retired, 1881.

CHARLES, FENDALL LOWIS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Repton School; appointed to the
Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting railway magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty, demarcation of forests in Nasik, July, 1875; forest settlement officer, Dharwar, Nov., 1881; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Sept., 1883; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, Oct., 1886; junior collector and magistrate, April, 1890.

CHARLES, GEORGE GWYTHER, M.I.E.E., Telegraph department, Government of India.—Joined the department, 9th May, 1857; arrived in India, 3rd Oct., 1857, and held charge of various offices in Bengal and the North-Western Provinces; inspector, April, 1862; assistant superintendent, Feb., 1863; superintendent, April, 1864; class iv., 2nd grade, Oct., 1867; held charge of various divisions including the Punjab, Udhi, and Rohilkund, Nagpur, Ceylon, Malabar, Ellary, and Madras divisions.

CHARLES, JOHN GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition, 1864; arrived, 15th Dec., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, April, 1866; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1870; on special duty (member of cattle plague commission) June, 1870; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, July, 1871; officiating deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, March, 1876; officiating presidency magistrate, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; officiating chief magistrate, Calcutta, March, 1877, also judge of the court for the trial of pilots; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1880; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1885; additional district judge, 24-Pergunnahs, Jan., 1885, to March, 1887; member, central examination committee, April, 1886; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Dec., 1888.

CHARLTON, A., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 3rd April, 1882.

CHATFIELD, KYRLE MITFORD, M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Served from 29th March, 1866, as principal and professor of logic and moral philosophy at the Elphinstone College, Bombay; also acted as educational inspector and as director of public instruction, and was confirmed in the latter appointment, Nov., 1874.

CHATTERGEE, K.M., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Officiated as judge of the small cause court in 1833 and 1839, and was confirmed as 4th judge 3rd Oct., 1889.

CHATTERTON, FRANK WILLIAM, Colonel, Bengal Infantry, late cantonment magistrate, N.W. Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign 4th Nov., 1859; employed under the military department till Feb., 1869, from which date he served in Jhansi and Kumaon as officiating assistant commissioner; from May, 1873, served as cantonment magistrate of Roorkee; also appointed a small cause court judge, Roorkee, March, 1879; 1st class cantonment magistrate, Agra, Dec., 1880; commandant of Bengal Presidency volunteers.

CHESNEY, SIR GEORGE TOMKINS, Lieut.-General, R.E., K.C.B., C.S.I., C.I.E.—Joined the service, 1848; served in the public works department from 1851 as executive engineer in the Lower Provinces, N.W. Provinces, and Punjab; assistant to principal of Thomason College, 1856; controller and examiner of accounts, public works department, Lower Provinces, Nov., 1866; inspector-general of public works accounts, Bengal, Jan., 1862; also ex-officio under secretary to government of India; accountant-general, public works department, May, 1864; on the institution of the Royal Indian Engineering College at Cooper's Hill in 1870, was appointed president of the college, and continued in that post till 1880, when he was appointed military secretary to the government of India; military member of governor-general's council, May, 1886; served in the Indian mutiny, 1857-8, as brigade major of engineers Delhi field force, battle of Budkuksarai, siege of Delhi (very severely wounded); medal with clasp, brevet of major; K.C.B., Jan., 1890.

CHEVIS, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Lancing College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1885, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

CHIPPER, E., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Finchley; matriculated at London University, 1875; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 3rd Dec., 1875.

CHIPPERFIELD, A. E., late Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 27th June, 1881; retired, Jan., 1886.

CHISHOLM, JAMES WRIGHT, late Central Provinces.—Served in the Central Provinces from 24th Oct., 1856, as deputy collector, assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and settlement officer, and was appointed inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Oct., 1871; inspector-general of police and jails, Oct., 1876; secretary to the chief commissioner, June, 1880; commissioner of the Chhattisgarh division, March, 1883; retired, 1889.

CHISHOLME, JOHN JAMES SCOTT, Major 5th (Queen's Royal) Lancers.—Military secretary on the personal staff of governor of Madras (Lord Connemara, G.C.I.E.), 10 Aug., 1888; 1st commission sub-lieutenant 9th lancers, 10th Jan., 1872; captain, March, 1878; major, Dec., 1883; served in the Afghan war, 1878-9-80; battle of Ali Musjid, action of Siab Sung (severely wounded), and affairs around Kabul and Sherpur (wounded), medal with clasp; brevet of major.

CHITPAL SINGH, RAJA, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed a covenanted civilian under native civil service rules without probation, 12th Dec., 1881; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade; 2nd grade, April, 1886.

CHOLMELEY, NORMAN GOODFORD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Charterhouse, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1884; assistant commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1884; has officiated as deputy commissioner.

CHRISTIE, ARCHIBALD (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating judicial as-
sistant, and officiating district and divisional judge; on special duty, Kurram field force, Oct., 1878; under secretary to government of Punjab, Aug. to Dec., 1884; district judge, Dec., 1887.

CHRISTIE, CHARLES HOWARD PEREGRINE, Major, R.E., Public Works Department.—First commission as lieutenant, April, 1866; joined the Madras public works department, March, 1869; served as assistant engineer, assistant consulting engineer for railways, acting examiner of railway accounts, and acting deputy consulting engineer; deputy controller, public works accounts, Madras, irrigation branch, Jan., 1873; examiner, 4th class, Jan., 1880; transferred to Central India, Sept., 1880; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, April, 1881; 3rd class examiner, Sept., 1886; examiner, public works accounts, Madras, March, 1887.

CHRISTIE, JAMES THOMAS, C.I.E., Punjab Police Department.—Entered the accountant-general's office, Jan., 1853; served in the police department from March, 1861, and under the government of India in the foreign department, Sept., 1887, and Feb., 1880 (in Afghanistan); district superintendent police, 1st grade, Dec., 1886.

CHRISTIE, THOMAS B., M.D., C.I.E., Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh and of the Royal College of Physicians of London, and Edinburgh.—Medical superintendent of the Royal India Asylum, Ealing, 1870; was previously medical superintendent of Pembroke House Hackney.

CHUCKERBUTTY, ARTHUR GOODEVE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1886, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal.

CHUNDER MADHUB GHOSE.—Member of the legislative council of Bengal, 1883 to 1885; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 13th Jan., 1885.

CHURCH, WILLIAM THOMAS, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rugby, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1880; superintendent, Dehra Dun, Jan., 1882; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, July, 1883, 1st grade, Aug., 1887; officiated as commissioner, Rohilkund, in 1880; retired April, 1890.

CHURCHILL, RIGHT HON. LORD RANDOLPH HENRY SPENCER, LL.D. (Hon.) Cambridge.—Born 1849; educated at Eton and Merton College, Oxford, graduated B.A., 1871; represented Woodstock in the House of Commons from Feb., 1874, until Nov., 1885, when he was returned for South Paddington; secretary of state for India, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; chancellor of the exchequer and leader of the House of Commons, in the Marquis of Salisbury's second ministry, Aug., 1886, but resigned after a few months' tenure of office.

CLARK, JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Old Aberdeen Grammar School and the University of Aberdeen, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1887, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Assam, April, 1890.

CLARK, WILLIAM OVENS, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Portora School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; on famine duty, Bengal, Feb., 1874; on special duty in the public works department March, 1882; officiating cantonment magistrate Mooltan, April, 1883; assistant commissioner 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; on special duty in the Punjab civil secretariat, March, 1885; officiating additional divisional judge, May, 1885; officiating deputy commissioner, June, 1885; promoted to be assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Dec., 1885; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1888.

CLARKE, SIR ANDREW, Lieut.-General, G.C.M.G., C.B., C.I.E.—and Lieutenant, Royal Engineers, June, 1884; in 1848 was employed on special service in New Zealand, and was aide-de-camp to lieut.-governor, Tasmania, June, 1849, to June, 1853; governor and commander-in-chief, Straits Settlements, Aug., 1873, to May, 1875; member of council of governor-general of India in charge of public works June, 1875 to 1880; commandant, school of military engineering, Chatham, April, 1881, to June, 1882; inspector-general of fortifications and director of works, ordnance department, War Office, June, 1882, to June, 1886.

CLARKE, C.B., M.A., late Educational Service, Assam.—Appointed to the Bengal educational department, 8th Dec., 1865; served as professor at the Presidency College, and as inspector of schools; officiating superintendent of the Calcutta botanical garden, May, 1869; 1st class of the education department, March, 1876; on special duty in England, March, 1879, to April, 1883; officiating director of public instruction, December, 1884; transferred to Assam as inspector of schools, March, 1885; retired, June, 1887.

CLARKE, HERVY MORRIS STANLEY, Colonel, M.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, Madras Native Infantry, 13th March, 1854; served with the Central India Horse, during 1858-60; from Sept., 1861, served in the N.W. Province police department; district superintendent, April, 1863; personal assistant to inspector-general of police, Dec., 1871; acted at various times as assistant inspector-general, government railway police; deputy inspector-general, Oct., 1885; inspector-general of prisons, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1886.

CLARKE, ROBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Royal School, Raphoe, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant, and was in charge of the Jhelum settlement, Aug., 1878; officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, May, 1881; assistant commissioner, 2nd class, Oct., 1884, and 1st
grade, Nov., 1884; officiating divisional judge, Oct., 1886-Nov., 1887; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1886, and 2nd grade, March, 1890.

CLARKE, SYDENHAM CUBBON, Lieutenant-Colonel, Madras Public Works Department.—Arrived in India 9th Jan., 1862; appointed assistant engineer, Mysore, Oct., 1862; executive engineer, Sept., 1867; served at Chatham, March to Sept., 1874; acting professor of surveying, Royal Indian Engineering College, Cooper's Hill, Sept., 1874, to Dec., 1876; returned to Madras, Nov., 1876; served under the Government of India on the Peshawur-Jellalabad state railway, Nov., 1879, and in Baluchistan; temporary superintendent of works, Madras, April, 1883; officiated for various periods as superintending engineer, and in May, 1889, was posted for charge of public works, stores, and workshops.

CLARKE, TREDWAY GEORGE, Colonel, M.S.C.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, 1853; served in the Mysore commission from Oct., 1857; deputy superintendent, Mysore commission, Nov., 1862; deputy commissioner, Mysore, 1873; from 1875 acted as secretary to the chief commissioner, and was confirmed in this appointment, 1877; commissioner, Nagar division, May, 1879; commissioner of Coorg, 1881; officiating resident in Mysore and chief commissioner of Coorg, Dec., 1884, to March, 1885; and afterwards commissioner.

CLARKE, WILLOUGHBY CHARLES STANLEY, Colonel, B.S.C., late Assam Commission.—Commission as ensign, June, 1851; arrived in India, 15th Oct., 1851; was employed on military duty till 1862, including service in the Sonthal Expedition, 1855, and in the China Expedition, 1860-61; also served as superintendent of police and magistrate, governor-general's camp, Sept., 1859, to Jan., 1860; from June, 1862, served in the Assam commission, and was promoted to deputy commissioner July, 1867; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Jan., 1883; returned to Europe, 1889.

CLAY, ARTHUR LLOYD, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cholmeley Grammar School, Highgate, at Cologne, and at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 29th Nov., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1874; from Sept., 1874, to June, 1877, served in Assam as deputy commissioner, 1st grade, and district and sessions judge of Sylhet; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, July, 1879; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Manbhoom, Aug., 1879; officiating commissioner of Chota Nagpore, Sept., 1884; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Backergunge, March, 1886; has officiated as commissioner of the Chittagong and Burdwan divisions; retired July, 1890.

CLAY, WILLIAM MCKINLEY, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating deputy commissioner (wards' estate, Patna); on famine relief duty, 1873-74; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1877; retired, 1883.

CLEGG, ROBERT BAILEY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1885; acted as special assistant collector and head assistant collector.

CLEGHORN, JAMES, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical department, March, 1865; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1865; served in Bengal, and held various military medical charges, and officiated as civil surgeon of Howrah and Moorshedabad, 1867, and of Mooltan and Cawnpore, 1868-69; from Feb., 1870, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil surgeon, Azimgarh, June, 1870; junior civil surgeon and superintendent, district jail, Allahabad, April, 1873; held medical charge of the camp of the lieutenant-governor on several occasions, including Imperial assemblage at Delhi, 1876; civil surgeon of Naini Tal, March, 1876, and subsequently at Mirzapur, Cawnpore, and Allahabad; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877; on special duty to Calcutta, Dec., 1880; officiating surgeon superintendent, Presidency General Hospital, Calcutta, June, 1885 to March, 1886, when he was appointed civil surgeon of Lucknow; brigade surgeon, Dec., 1888.

CLERK, GEORGE PERCY, Madras Revenue Settlement Department.—Joined the service as probationary assistant director, revenue settlement, 14th Sept., 1871; assistant director, July, 1872; on special duty, North Arcot, in connexion with famine relief works; deputy director, Sept., 1880; deputy commissioner of revenue settlement, Jan., 1880.

CLEVELAND, CHARLES RAITT, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Christ's College, Finchley, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1835; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1837, and served in the Central Provinces, as assistant commissioner.

CLIFFORD, SAMUEL LE POER TRENCH, Punjab Commission.—From 1st April, 1861, served in the subordinate judicial department; officiated as deputy registrar of the chief court, and in Jan., 1872, was appointed registrar of the judicial commissioner's court in Oudh; deputy registrar of chief court, Oct., 1872; officiated for various periods as judge, small cause court, and as judicial assistant; appointed judicial assistant, Jan., 1884.

CLINTON (BARON), CHARLES HENRY ROLLE HEPBURN STUART TREFUSIS.—Educated at Eton, and at Christ Church, Oxford; M.P. for North Devon from 1857 to 1866; under secretary of State for India, July, 1867 to Dec., 1868; appointed a charity commissioner for England and Wales, 1874.

CLOETE, HENRY DANIEL, Colonel, M.S.C., late Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Army, Dec., 1849; arrived, 27th April, 1850; served in the Madras police department from June, 1860, as superintendent, deputy inspector-general, acting commissioner and acting chief magistrate of police for the town of Madras; inspector-general of police, Madras, from Dec., 1881 to 1885.

CLOETE, JOSIAS GORDON, Colonel, late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, Feb., 1857; arrived in India,
May, 1857; served in the Madras police as assistant superintendent, June, 1861, to June, 1863, and from the latter date in the revenue survey; deputy superintendent, Jan., 1872; on special duty preparing code of rules for survey department, July, 1873 to March, 1874.

CLOGSTOUN, HERBERT FREDERICK, Madras C.S.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1866; acting assistant superintendent of police, April, 1867, to April, 1868; acting deputy director of revenue settlement March, 1872; on special duty in connection with state relief works, Kurnool, Dec., 1876; acting principal assistant collector and magistrate and agent to governor, Vizagapatam, Jan., 1880; joint sessions judge in Rumpa cases, Jan., 1880; from March, 1880, served in the financial department as officiating accountant-general, Bengal, and deputy accountant-general, Madras; member of board of examiners, Madras, June, 1882; accountant-general and commissioner of issue of state paper currency, Madras, July, 1882; officiating comptroller and auditor-general and head commissioner of paper currency, Calcutta, Aug. to Nov., 1882; accountant-general, class 2, provisionally, Nov., 1887; fourth member of Board of Revenue, commissioner of revenue settlement, and director of land records and agriculture, Oct., 1889.

COAKER, WILLIAM HENRY, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India; arrived in India, 27th March, 1866; appointed 2nd assistant engineer, Madras, July, 1866; served in Abyssinia in 1867 (medal); executive engineer, Sept., 1870; assistant consulting engineer, railways Madras, Nov., 1870, and deputy consulting engineer, Jan., 1873; under secretary to Government of Madras, railway branch, Oct., 1884; officiated for various periods as consulting engineer and joint secretary to Government of Madras; class i., grade 3, superior revenue establishment; state railways, and deputy manager, N.W. railway, 1889.

COATES, JOHN MARTIN, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., late Bengal Medical Department.—First commission, 1855; in medical charge of 1st Bengal military police battalion, Dec., 1856; civil assistant surgeon, April, 1859; superintendent of jails, Hazaribagh, Nov., 1866; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; civil surgeon, Moorsheadabad, Dec., 1872; in joint medical charge, Simla, and in charge of commander-in-chief's staff, 1873; sanitary commissioner for Bengal, May, 1874; principal and professor of medicine, Medical College, Calcutta, and ex officio 1st physician to the college hospital, April, 1880; also officiated as inspector-general of jails, Aug., 1879; brigade surgeon, May, 1881; officiating surgeon-general, Bengal, in addition to other duties, June, 1884; president of a committee of enquiry on sanitary matters in connection with Kidderpore docks, March, 1885; has published a vocabulary of the dialects of Chota Nagpur; retired, 1890.

COBB, HENRY VENN, Madras C.S., LL.B.—Educated at King's School, Canterbury, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1886, and served in the revenue survey and settlement department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate; also acted as assistant secretary to government.

COBB, WILLIAM HEY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, Winchester, and New College, Oxford; called to the bar at the Inner Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1884; served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant-magistrate and collector, and assistant-commissioner; city magistrate, Lucknow, July, 1889.

COCKERELL, HORACE ABEL, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1853; served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; also as superintendent of survey, Sept., 1859, and as officiating chairman, justices of the peace, Calcutta, and commissioner of police, March, 1866, and Dec., 1872; commissioner of the Chittagong division, June, 1872, and subsequently of the Dacca and Burdwan divisions; secretary to the government of Bengal, judicial and political departments, April, 1878; lieutenant-governor's council, April, 1878, and again, March, 1880 and 1882; board of revenue, March, 1883; officiating lieutenant-governor of Bengal, Aug., 1885; retired, Aug., 1887.

COCKS, WALTER CAREW, Auditor, India Office.—Appointed 1st Aug., 1874.

CODRINGTON, GEORGE HENRY FORBES, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 4th May, 1857; served on military duty till Dec., 1865, and subsequently in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, April, 1883.

COGHLAN, ROBERT NESBIT, Customs Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd April, 1871; from March, 1872, served as general manager of the customs' bonded warehouses, Bombay, and as acting assistant commissioner of customs, salt, and opium, in charge of the tobacco department, Bombay; from March, 1874, served as assistant collector of salt revenue; collector of sea customs, Karachi, and assistant commissioner of salt revenue in Sind, Sept., 1882.

COLDSTREAM, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, officiating personal assistant to financial commissioner, officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Nov., 1876; officiating commissioner and sessions judge, Lahore, April, 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, Sept., 1883; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1883; deputed to Calcutta to act as one of the representatives of the Punjab in the committee on museum and exhibition held there, Dec., 1883; officiating commissioner, Lahore, Feb., 1887.

COLE, WILLIAM HAMMOND, M.A. Cantab., F.R.A.S., F.R.G.S.—Served in the education department, N.W. Provinces, April, 1862, to March, 1864, as professor of mathematics at the Government College, Agra; from Jan., 1867,
served in the great trigonometrical survey of India as assistant surveyor attached to the computing office, Dehra; assistant superintendent of surveys, Sept., 1866; deputy superintendent July, 1862; appointed to charge of head quarters office, Dehra Dun, and survey detachment in Kashmir, Jan., 1884; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; author of various contributions to the 'Account of the Operations of the Great Trigonometrical Survey of India,' and to the 'Synopsis of the Results of the Operations of the Great Trigonometrical Survey,' also of various translations relating to geodesy.

COLLEN, E. H. H., C.I.E., Maj.-Gen., B.S.C.—First commission, royal artillery, July, 1863; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, May, 1873; 3rd assistant secretary to government of India, military department, March, 1875; 2nd assistant secretary April, 1876; 1st assistant secretary, Dec., 1876; deputy secretary, military department, April, 1883; accountant general, military department, government of India, July, 1886; secretary to government of India, military department, 1887; C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

COLLETT, CHARLES, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; subordinate judge of Calicut, 1862; judge of court of small causes, Cuddalore, 1863; civil and sessions judge, Vizagapatam, 1863; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, 1866; retired in 1871.

COLLIER, FRANK ROBERT STANLEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1872; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating cantonment magistrate, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on famine duty, March, 1874; officiating collector of customs, Calcutta, May, 1884; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1886; magistrate and collector, April, 1889; published an annotated edition of the Bengal Municipal Act, 1884.

COLLIER, GEORGE H., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Uppingham School; junior clerk, India office, 17th Feb., 1876.

COLLIN, EDWARD WOODFIELD, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; private secretary to financial member of governor-general's council, Jan., 1880; served under the government of India, foreign department, Jan. to July, 1881, and in the financial department, March-Sept., 1885; settlement officer, Mozaffarpore, Jan., 1886; officiated as director of land records, Bengal, April, 1888; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1889.

COLLINS, ARTHUR HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1879; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Aug., 1880; has also officiated as magistrate and collector.

COLLINS, SIR ARTHUR JOHN HAMMOND, Knt., Q.C., Madras High Court.—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge, of which he was fellow; called to the bar, Gray's Inn, 1860; Q.C. and bencher of his inn, 1877; recorder of Poole, 1873-9, and of Exeter from 1879, until he was appointed chief justice of the high court of judicature, Madras, 28th Nov., 1885; vice-chancellor, Madras University, 1889.

COLLINS, S. A., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, Dec., 1885.

COLQUHOUN, ARCHIBALD ROSS, A.M.I.C.E., F.R.G.S., late Burma Commission.—Entered the public works department in Oct., 1871, as apprentice engineer; served in the grades of assistant and executive engineer in various divisions of Burma; on special duty as personal assistant to Major Street on his mission to Siam, Jan.-May, 1879; executive engineer, 3rd grade, Nov., 1881; was posted to special duty in Upper Burma as civil officer, and appointed a deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Feb., 1886; 3rd grade, Dec., 1888; author of 'Across Chryse,' 'Among the Shans,' 'The Truth about Tonquin,' 'The Opening of China,' 'Burma and the Burmans.'

COLVIN, SIR AUCKLAND, K.C.M.G., C.I.E., Bengal C.S., (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton; appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1858; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; officiating under secretary to the government of India in the home department, May, 1864, and in the foreign department, Jan. to Nov. 1865; settlement officer, 2nd grade, July, 1869; secretary, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, March, 1870; on special duty to Naini Tal, in connection with the revision of settlement in the Allahabad district, June, 1870; officiating secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, April, 1873, and again in 1875; officiating commissioner of excise and stamps, and inspector-general of registration, June, 1873; member of commission for investigating disturbances in Poona and Ahmednagar, Aug., 1875; magistrate and collector, Basti, Feb., 1877, and afterwards at Bijnor; officiating commissioner of inland customs under the government of India, Nov., 1877; transferred for employment in Egypt, Jan., 1879, and served as controller of Egyptian finance, and subsequently as finance minister to the Egyptian government; acted as consul-general in Sir E. Malet's absence; financial member of council of the governor-general of India, 11th Oct., 1883; lieutenant-governor of the N.W. Provinces, and chief commissioner of Oudh, November, 1887.

COLVIN, BAZETT WETENHALL, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1850; arrived in India, 29th June, 1850; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector till Jan., 1854, and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed assistant commissioner, Kumaon, April, 1855, magistrate and collector, Mainpuri, July, 1865, and civil and sessions judge, Allahabad, July, 1873; officiated as commissioner of the Jhansi division, April, 1873, and of the Rohilkund division, Nov., 1873; on special duty at Agra during the visit of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Feb., 1876 officiating secretary to
government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1876; commissioner, Meerut division, Jan., 1877; additional member, governor-general's council, Jan., 1877, to May, 1881; board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1882; retired, April, 1885.

COLVIN, Clement S., Public Works Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College, and by private tuition in England and on the Continent; temporary clerk, 1863; junior clerk, military department, 1864; funds department, 1867; private secretary to secretary of state (the Duke of Argyll), 1873-74; private secretary to permanent under secretary of state, 1874-77, and accompanied Sir Louis Mallet on his deputation to India in 1875-76; senior clerk, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, 1877; resident clerk, 1877 to 1885; public works department, 1877; government director of Madras irrigation and canal company, 1880-82; assistant secretary in the public works, railway and telegraph department, Sept., 1882; assistant government director of Indian railway companies, 1882.

COLVIN, Elliot Graham, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1883; transferred to Assam as personal assistant to chief commissioner, May, 1884; acting assistant secretary to chief commissioner, June, 1884; assistant political agent, Rajputana, Sept., 1886; political assistant, 3rd class, May, 1888; private secretary to lieutenant governor of Bengal, April, 1887; 1st assistant to Governor General's agent in Beluchistan, and political assistant, 2nd class, April, 1889; served under Financial Department of Government of India from June, 1890.

COMINS, Denis Wood Deane, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service, 22nd Oct., 1881, and served on general and jail duty, and as officiating first resident surgeon, medical college hospital, Calcutta; officiated as protector of emigrants, Calcutta, Sept., 1888, and was confirmed, Jan., 1889.

CONDER, James, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Sept., 1870; executive engineer, Neemuch railway, Oct., 1873; Punjab northern state railway, 1874; personal assistant to engineer-in-chief, Punjab northern railway, June, 1875; provisional assistant director of state railways, western system, 1877; traffic superintendent, Indus Valley state railway, in 2nd class of the state railway revenue establishment, May, 1878; officiating manager, southern section, Western Rajputana railway, Aug., 1879; manager, Holkar, Sindia-Neemuch, and Neemuch-Nusseerabad railways, Feb., 1881; officiating manager, Nagpur-Chhattisgarh and Wardha coal railways, Nov., 1883; traffic superintendent, Rajputana-Malwa railways, Sept., 1884; class I., grade 3, revenue establishment, April, 1887.

CONDON, James Hunt, M.D., Brigade Surgeon, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, Feb., 1850; arrived in India, 25th July, 1859; served under the military department till Oct., 1861, when he was appointed civil assistant surgeon in Oudh; from April, 1868, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was promoted to surgeon, Feb., 1871, and surgeon-major, July, 1873; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Cawnpore, March, 1871; brigade surgeon, Oct., 1886.

CONINGHAM, Henry Evelyn, Major-General, M.S.C., late Police Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 18th March, 1855; served in the Madras police department from Dec., 1861, as assistant superintendent and superintendent, and acted as deputy inspector-general, Sept., 1883, to May, 1884; 1st grade superintendent, Nov., 1884; retired, Feb., 1886.

CONNAUGHT and STRATHEARN, Duke of, H.R.H. Arthur William Patrick Albert, K.G., K.T., K.P., G.C.S.I., G.C.M.G., G.C.I.E., C.B.—Commander-in-chief, and 2nd member of council, Bombay, 14th December, 1886, to March, 1890.

CONNELL, Charles James, M.R.A.S., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1871, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating junior secretary to chief commissioner; from May, 1874, to Feb., 1878, served as assistant settlement officer and officiating settlement officer in Gonda and Fyzabad; first assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1878; from Nov., 1879, served as assistant magistrate and collector; junior secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1882, and acted on various occasions as secretary; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1884, and acted as secretary to government in 1884 and 1885; officiating secretary to Board of Revenue, Oct., 1885, confirmed in that appointment, Nov., 1888; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1886; author of 'Our Land Revenue Policy in Northern India.'

CONNEMARA (Baron), Right Hon. Robert Bourke, G.C.I.E.—Educated at Enniskillen Royal School and at Trinity College, Dublin; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, Nov., 1852; M.P. for Lynn Regis from Dec., 1868; parliamentary under secretary of state for foreign affairs, Feb., 1874, to April, 1880; a royal commissioner on the laws relating to copyright, Oct., 1875; privy councillor, April, 1880; again parliamentary under secretary for foreign affairs, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; appointed governor of Madras, Sept., 1886; took his seat as governor, 7 Dec., 1886; resigned, 1st Dec., 1890.

CONOLLY, Edward Robert, Colonel, B.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 9th April, 1888; from Sept., 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; on special duty as assistant to Major Cavagnari, Feb., 1879, and again at Khyber, Feb., 1880; judicial assistant, 2nd grade, Sept., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Bannu, Nov., 1884; also district judge; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1887; retired Aug., 1890.

CONSTABLE, Edwin T., M.A., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as mathematical professor, Bareilly College, 25th Feb., 1862; inspector of public instruction, 1st circle, Aug., 1870; inspector of schools, Meerut division, Dec., 1877; Benares division, Dec., 1882; officiating director of public instruction, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1883; 1st grade of education officers, April,
1833; inspector of schools, Meerut, and inspector of European schools, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Sept., 1834.

CONWAY-GORDON, LEWIS, Colonel, R.E., C.I.E., Public Works Department, India.—1st commission, 1857; joined the public works department, May, 1862, and served in the Punjab; assistant principal, Roorkee College, 1865; assistant consulting engineer, railway department, and examiner of accounts, Punjab, Oct., 1866; deputy consulting engineer and assistant secretary, railway branch, Punjab, Oct., 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, Punjab, Sept., 1870; deputy consulting engineer to government of India for guaranteed railways 1871; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, April, 1872; officiating superintending engineer, Indus Valley railway, March, 1874; controller of accounts, Madras, 1875 to 1879; 1st class examiner, Jan., 1879; officiating manager, Indus Valley railway, April, 1881; deputy accountant-general, public works department, and ex officio under secretary to government of India, Sept., 1881; acted as accountant-general and deputy-secretary, May to Aug., 1883; deputed on special duty to England in 1884, to give evidence before the select committee of the House of Commons on railways in India; temporarily manager, Eastern Bengal state railway, 1884; manager, North-Western railway, Jan., 1886; director, North-Western railway, March, 1887; director-general of railways and deputy secretary to government of India, public works department, May, 1887.

CONYBEARE, HENRY CRAWFORD ARTHUR, F.R.G.S., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Westminster School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty for preparation of provincial gazetteer, July, 1877; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, June, 1884, 1st grade, Nov., 1887; author of 'An Account of Pargana Dudhi, in South Mirzapur.'

COOK, HENRY, Brigade-Surgeon, M.D. (Ir.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 31st Aug., 1865, and served as civil surgeon at various stations, superintendent of vaccination, and superintendent of jail; acted as second surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of anatomy and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, 1870-80, and as senior surgeon and professor of surgery 1881-82; civil surgeon, Dharwar, Dec., 1881; civil surgeon, Poona, with medical charge of the Deccan College and College of Science, and superintendent of lunatic asylum, April, 1883, also superintendent and teacher of medicine and therapeutics at the medical school; acted as deputy sanitary commissioner, Oct., 1884; brigade-surgeon, April, 1887.

COOK, HENRY, M.D., F.R.C.P. (Lon.), F.G.S., F.M.S., late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 24th Jan., 1855; arrived in India, 28th July, 1855, and served under the military department up to 1859, also holding the civil surgeoncy of Karachi in 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force in 1857 (medal); appointed medical officer to political agency, Khelat, April, 1859; and accompanied H.H. the Khan of Khelat and Sir H. Green on a military expedition into Mekran; from April, 1861, served as civil surgeon in Ahmednagar and Satara, and as superintendent of Mahabaleshwar, and assistant collector and magistrate at that station; scientific officer, Abyssinian field force, Dec., 1867 (medal); from June, 1871, served in, Bombay as acting 2nd physician, Sir Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and acting professor of physiology and of hygiene at the Grant Medical College, and was confirmed in these appointments, May, 1873; 1st physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, principal and professor of medicine and hygiene, Grant Medical College, Sept., 1876; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, June, 1884; retired, Nov., 1886; author of various papers published in the transactions of the Medical and Physical Society of Bombay, on the geology, topography, and meteorology of different portions of Biluchistan, and on other scientific and medical subjects, also of various reports on similar subjects published by order of government, and of a paper read before the British Association, on the registration of atmospheric ozone in Bombay, with reference to epidemic cholera, 1869.

COOK, HENRY DAVID, M.B., C.M., Surgeon-Major, Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service as assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1870; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1870, and served on military, general and jail duty; surgeon-major, April, 1882; surgeon 1st district, and medical inspector of emigrants, Madras, May, 1888.

COOKE, CRAWFORD BOYD, Major, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission assigned, March, 1864; served under the military department up to Dec., 1863, and subsequently as assistant commissioner in Burma; acted as assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Jan., 1871 to Feb., 1874; from Feb., 1874, to May, 1877, served as political agent at Bhamo, Upper Burma, and from May, 1879, to Jan., 1884, as cantonment magistrate in Nowgong, Bundelcund; from Jan., 1884, served as deputy commissioner, and officiating commissioner in Burma, and was appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1885; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Aug., 1886, 1st class, June, 1886; author of the 'British Burma Manual.'

COOKE, FREDERICK JAMES, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Bath College and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1886, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

COOKE, G. H., Survey of India.—Joined the survey department, 6th Dec., 1866, and was appointed assistant superintendent, May, 1871; in 1871-2, served with the Lushai expeditionary force (medal); on special duty, Chittagong, Nov., 1872; served in various districts, and at head-quarters, Calcutta, and was appointed deputy superintendent, 4th grade, Oct., 1885, and 3rd grade, Aug., 1889.

COOKE, HENRY GIRAUD, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1869; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1882; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, June, 1886, 2nd grade, March, 1888.
COOKE, Henry Reade, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; compiler of General Administration Report of Bombay Presidency for 1879-80; first assistant collector, June, 1885.

COOKE, John Edward, Financial Department, government of India.—From Oct., 1863, to April, 1868, served as assistant secretary to the government of India in the financial department; officiated as deputy accountant-general, first in Bengal and then in Hyderabad, and as accountant-general in Bengal, 1868-99; deputy accountant-general, Central Provinces, Aug., 1870, and in Madras, Jan., 1874; officiating accountant-general, Madras, Aug.-Oct., 1874; assistant comptroller-general, May, 1875; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Oct., 1878, to July, 1883, and officiated as accountant-general in 1880, 1882, and 1883; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, July, 1883; acted as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, in 1884; deputy auditor-general, Dec., 1885; comptroller of Indian treasuries, April, 1886; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1886, and again, June, 1888; officiating deputy auditor-general, Oct.-Nov., 1887, and April, 1888.

COOKE, Samuel, M.A., F.I.C., F.G.S., A.M.I.C.E., Educational Department, Bombay.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin. Arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1863, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of chemistry and geology at the Engineering College, Poona, and also acted as principal of the college for various periods; promoted to 3rd grade of the education department, June, 1875.

COOKE, Theodore, C.I.E., M.A., M.I., LL.D., Educational Department, Bombay.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin. Arrived in India, Nov., 1860; from June, 1865, served in the Bombay educational department as principal of the Civil Engineering College, Poona, and also officiated as lecturer on chemistry and geology; 1st grade of the educational department, March, 1883; acting director of public instruction, Feb.-May, 1884, and April to July, 1889; C.I.E., Jan., 1891.

COOKSON, Hugh Cecil, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, Dec., 1883, and was appointed assistant commissioner, Punjab; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Oct., 1886; officiated for various periods as deputy commissioner, and in Dec., 1889, as under secretary to Government of Punjab.

COOPER, Charles Philip (Barrister-at-Law), Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 28th Jan., 1863; served from June, 1864, as examiner of the insolvent debtors' court, Bombay; also acted as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts, and taxing officer in the high court; police magistrate, Bombay, from Oct., 1871; acting first judge of the small cause court, Sept., 1873; senior magistrate of police and revenue judge, Bombay, June, 1874; chief presidency magistrate and revenue judge, Bombay, June, 1878.

COOPER, H. A., B.A., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, accountant-general's department, 3rd June, 1880; junior examiner, audit department, Nov., 1881; graduated B.A., London University, 1887.

COPESTON, Frederick Selwyn, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd October, 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma, as assistant commissioner, Sept., 1874; on special duty in Rangoon, Nov., 1879; on forest demarcation duty, Toungoo, Jan., 1880; deputy superintendent of census, Sept., 1880; judge under the Land Acquisition Act, March, 1881; officiating deputy commissioner, Dec., 1881; commissioner of excise and stamps, March, 1885; additional sessions judge, Tenasserim and Pegu, March, 1886; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1887.

CORBETT, Frank Vincent, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1866; assistant engineer, Feb., 1877; served on canal duty, and was appointed executive engineer, March, 1871; employed chiefly on the Betwa Canal; superintending engineer, Dec., 1889; has held charge of the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd circles, irrigation works.

CORDERY, John Graham, M.A., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 22nd Oct., 1856; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; from Oct., 1864, to Sept., 1868, served in the Hyderabad Assigned Districts as deputy commissioner and assistant resident; officiating director of public instruction, Punjab, Jan., 1872, to May, 1873; deputy commissioner, 1st class, March, 1877, officiating secretary to government of Punjab, April-Aug., 1878; commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, April, 1879; also acted as political agent and superintendent, Bahawalpur State, May-Nov., 1879; commissioner, Peshawar, April, 1881; resident, Hyderabad, April, 1883; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired, July, 1888.

CORNISH, Robert, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Lancing College, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal; on famine relief duty, May-Dec., 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct. 1884; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Dec., 1887, and 2nd grade, Aug., 1889.
