CORNISH, William Robert, Surgeon-General, F.R.C.S., C.I.E., late Madras Medical Service.—Studied at St. George's Hospital (scholar and prizeman); appointed to the Madras medical service, April, 1854; arrived in India, and July, 1854; served under the military department, and also as civil surgeon of Coimbatore, 1857-58; secretary to the director general of the medical department, Oct., 1858, to Feb., 1870; consulting physician to the Irrigation Canal Company, April, 1860; on special duty at Calcutta as Madras member and secretary to the commission for the reorganization of medical establishments, Nov., 1865, to April, 1866; sec-
secretary of Madras medical fund, 1864-70; on special duty for revision of medical code of regulations, 1869-70; sanitary commissioner, Madras, March, 1870, to April, 1880; member of committee for review of general hospital establishments, 1873-74; on special duty as member of the cinchona alkaloid commission in 1874 and 1879; during the famine of 1876-78, was specially engaged in organising a system of sanitary and medical inspection; surgeon-major, April, 1874; was superintendent of Madras census, and proceeded on special duty to Calcutta as member of census committee, Jan.-Feb., 1878; brigade-surgeon, Nov., 1879; appointed C.I.E., Jan., 1880; deputy surgeon-general, April, 1880; surgeon-general with the government of Madras, April, 1880-85; was member of a commission to draw up a code for famine relief, and member and president of a committee on local government; additional member of council, Madras, for making laws and regulations, Dec., 1883; retired from the service, April, 1885; was appointed fellow of Madras University, Feb., 1867, and president of the medical faculty, 1880-85; hon. physician to the Queen; author of various contributions to the medical press, of sanitary reports to government, and the Madras census report, 1873; was for some time editor of the 'Madras Quarterly Journal of Medical Science.'

CORNWALL, WILLIAM WOLFRAN GARDNER, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1861; from Dec., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating superintendent of Dehra Dun, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and assistant settlement officer; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Fatehpur, March, 1881; and afterwards at Farukhabad; retired, Aug., 1887.

COSSINS, WILLIAM HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King William's College, Isle of Man, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal C.S., after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 20th Jan., 1886; assistant commissioner in Assam, Jan., 1886.

COSTELLO, CHARLES PETER, Deputy Surgeon-General, Bengal Medical Department (Assam).—Joined the service as assistant surgeon, 10th Feb., 1859; served with the 6th Punjab infantry in the Umbeyla campaign, 1863-4 (medal and clasp); and in the Jowaki expedition, 1877-8 (clasp); served also in the Afghan war, 1878-80, with the Koorum field force, and the Khyber line force (medal); sanitary commissioner, Assam, Sept., 1883; deputy surgeon-general, Jan., 1889.

COTGRAVE, THOMAS MANSON, Salt Department, Bombay.—Joined the service as acting assistant commissioner of customs, salt and opium, 30th Jan., 1866; opium inspector, Bombay, May, 1866; confirmed as assistant commissioner, July, 1867; assistant collector, salt revenue, Feb., 1874; deputy collector of salt revenue, April, 1890.

COTTON, SIR ARTHUR THOMAS, General, Kt., K.C.S.I., R.E.—Joined Addiscombe, 1818; arrived in Madras, Sept., 1821, as 2nd lieutenant of engineers; assistant to superintending engineer, tank department, May, 1822; served with the Burmese expedition, 1824-26; from June, 1826, served as superintending engineer in the tank department, and in 1828 was appointed to the charge of the Cauvery irrigation, being also employed in the survey and improvement of the Paumber pass; in 1844 was appointed to the northern division of the tank department, and was employed in carrying out the systematic irrigation of the Godavari delta; promoted to chief engineer, 1852; in 1853 was ordered to Cuttack, and planned works for the irrigation of the Mahanadi delta, and was afterwards employed under the government of Bengal, reporting upon the water communication between the Ganges and Calcutta; resigned government service in 1862; in 1863, was employed under the Madras irrigation company, reporting on their works, and also inspecting the Ganges canal works, and proposed additional works, which were afterwards carried out as the Lower Ganges Canal; also projected works for the Sone irrigation, which have since been partially executed; general, 1876; retired from the army in 1877.

COTTON, HENRY JOHN STEDMAN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Masdalen College School, Brighton College, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1865; arrived, 29th Oct., 1867; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed officiating small cause court judge, Sealdah, March, 1872; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, June, 1873; officiating registrar, high court, Dec., 1873; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, June, 1875; junior secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1876; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Nov., 1876; officiating commissioner, Chittagong, Sept., 1879, and again, April, 1884; secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1882; officiating commissioner of police, Calcutta, and chairman of the corporation of the town of Calcutta, April, 1887; port commissioner, Calcutta, May, 1887; secretary to Government of Bengal financial and municipal departments, May, 1890; author of a 'Memorandum on the Revenue History of Chittagong,' 1880, 'Memorandum on the Land Tenures of Bengal,' 1884, and 'England and India—New India, or India in transition.'

COUCH, RIGHT HON. SIR RICHARD, Knt.—Recorder of Bedford, 1853 to 1862; judge of the high court of judicature at Bombay, 1862-66; chief justice, Bombay, 1866-70; chief justice of Bengal, March, 1870, to April, 1875, and was president of the commission appointed to inquire into the charges made against the Gaekwar of Baroda, Feb., 1875; made a privy councillor, and sworn in, 27th Nov., 1875; a member of the judicial committee, Jan., 1881.

COUCHE, T. B., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 22nd Jan., 1875.

COUPER, SIR GEORGE E. W., Bart., K.C.S.I., C.B., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sandhurst, and served in H.M.'s 15th regiment for two years before joining the East India College, Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1846; served in Bengal and the Punjab in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; under secretary, government of India, home and finance department, 1853; under secretary, government of India, foreign department, 1854; secretary to chief commissioner of Oudh, 1855; served
through the siege of Lucknow, and was present at several engagements during the mutiny as aide-de-camp to Sir H. Lawrence and Sir John Inglis, and afterwards to Sir James Outram; commissioner in Oudh, 1858; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1859; judicial commissioner of Oudh, 1863; chief commissioner of Oudh, 1874; lieutenant-governor of N.W. Provinces, 1876, as well as chief commissioner of Oudh; retired 1882.

COURT, MAJOR HENRY, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1840; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; compiled 'Statistical Report and History of the Budaon District'; magistrate and collector, Cawnpore, 1853, and subsequently at Allahabad; president of special commission on the police of India, 1860; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, 1861 to 1866; commissioner, Allahabad division, 1866, and subsequently of the Meerut division, 1869; retired 1872.

COURTENAY, ROBERT, B.A., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874; served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; compiler of the 'General Administration Report of the Bombay Presidency for 1883-84'; acted as assistant judge, first grade, at intervals from Dec., 1885; retired, Sept., 1890.

COURTNEY, DAVID C., Major late R.E., India Office Stores Department.—Entered the Royal Engineers, 17th April, 1866; served in the South African war, 1879; present at the battle of Ineyazane, defence of Etshowe and advance on Ulundi (medal with clasp); assistant-inspector of works, Royal Arsenal, Woolwich, 1880-83; served in the Soudan expedition of 1884-85, and was present at the action of Kirbekan (brevet of major, medal with two clasps, bronze star); retired from army, November, 1887; appointed assistant superintendent of the India store depot, 1st April, 1887.

COWAN, S. H., Colonel B.S.C., Survey of India.—First commission, lieutenant R.A., 9th Dec., 1859; arrived in India, 9th April, 1860; served in the military department, and on the 19th Jan., 1867, was admitted to the staff corps; assistant superintendent, survey department, Bengal, 19th Jan., 1867; held charge of the Cachar survey, Nov., 1878, to Nov., 1879; and of the Hooghly River survey, April, 1882, to July, 1883; deputy superintendent, April, 1883; 3rd grade, July, 1883.

COWIE, DONALD WILLIAM GARDEN, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in Madras, 30th Nov., 1886, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

COWIE, HENRY GEORGE, B.A., Financial Department, Government of India.—From Nov., 1868, to April, 1876, served in the grades of assistant accountant-general and assistant comptroller-general, and as assistant commissioner of paper currency, in the N.W. Provinces, and at Calcutta; from April, 1876, to March, 1883, served in the Central Provinces as deputy accountant-general and deputy commissioner paper currency; comptroller, Assam, March, 1883; class 3 of the financial department, Sept., 1883; deputy accountant-general N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1887, and officiating accountant-general, Aug. and Nov., 1887, and May, 1888; deputy accountant general, Madras, Jan., 1890.

COWIE, THOMAS RENNY, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 12th Aug., 1860; employed under the military department till Aug., 1869, from which date he served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, sub-judge, and deputy commissioner; cantonment magistrate, 1st class, Allahabad, Feb., 1881, and subsequently at Cawnpore, 1886; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Oct., 1888.

COWLEY, FRANCIS WILLIAM RICE, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived 2nd Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; services placed at the disposal of the public works department, March, 1873; deputy commissioner, wards' estate, Patna, June, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1877; from April, 1879, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge, and was promoted to the 1st grade, Aug., 1885; officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpore, May, 1886; confirmed, 14th Sept., 1887.

COX, ARTHUR FREDERICK, Madras C.S.—Educated at King's College School and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1871, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled 'The North Arcot District Manual'; on special duty in connection with visit of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Nov., 1875; from Sept., 1882, served in the financial department, and was appointed officiating assistant accountant-general, first in Madras and afterwards in Bombay; assistant comptroller-general, 3rd class, July, 1883; deputy accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1885; officiating accountant-general, Bombay, and commissioner of state paper currency, May, 1886; sub-collector and magistrate, Nov., 1887, and acting district and sessions judge, Oct., 1887; confirmed as district and sessions judge, April, 1889; employed under Government of India, in financial department, May, 1889, to March, 1890, as acting accountant-general, Bombay.

COX, HARRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Olave's Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1877; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1889; has also acted as district and sessions judge.

COX, HENRY WILLIAM HOLMES, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, Nov., 1857; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1857; served in the Madras police from April, 1861, and was promoted to superintendent, April, 1873; assistant inspector-general, Dec., 1881; acting commissioner of
police, Madras city, September, 1883; presidency magistrate, Oct., 1883; political officer in charge of ex-King Theebaw of Burma, Dec., 1885, to April, 1886; deputy inspector-general of police, Madras, Aug., 1886; acted as inspector general in 1890.

COX, JOHN HANDS MORRELL, Revenue Settlement Department, Madras.—Served from 18th March, 1861, in the revenue settlement department, Madras, as assistant director and deputy director; special assistant to collectors of Cuddapah and Kurnool for survey and settlement purposes, May, 1867, to April, 1871, and again in North Arcot, May, 1882; acting special deputy collector for state relief works, Jan., 1877; board of examiners, Nov., 1882; 1st grade of deputy directors, June, 1883; deputy commissioner of revenue settlement, April, 1887.

COXE, HENRY REYNELL HOLLED, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Bhagulpore, Nov., 1884; transferred to Burma, Nov., 1887, as assistant commissioner; under secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1888.

CRADDOCK, REGINALD HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Reading Grammar School, Wellington College, and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1884; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1884; assistant to commissioner of settlements and agriculture, Dec., 1888.

CRANBROOK, (Viscount), Rt. Hon. GATHORNE GATHORNE-HARDY, G.C.S.I.—Born 1st Oct., 1814; educated at Shrewsbury School, and at Oriel College, Oxford (B.A. in 1836, 2nd class in classics); called to the bar at the Inner Temple in 1840, and practised as a barrister for several years; contested Bradford unsuccessfully 1847; sat in the House of Commons for Leominster from 1856 to 1865, when he was returned for Oxford; under secretary of state for the home department, 1858; president of the poor law board, July, 1866; secretary of state for the home department, May, 1867, to Dec., 1868; secretary of state for war, Feb., 1874; raised to the house of peers as Viscount Cranbrook, May, 1878; secretary of state for India, March, 1878, to May, 1880; lord president of council, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886, and again, Aug., 1886.

CRASTER, GEORGE AYTON, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 11th Dec., 1849; served under the military department till 1853; from Nov., 1853, served as assistant and executive engineer in Assam, Oudh, and the Punjab; promoted to executive engineer 1st grade, April, 1865; transferred to N.W. Provinces as officiating superintending engineer, March, 1869; officiating superintending engineer and deputy secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, public works department, April, 1872; superintending engineer, 3rd class, April, 1872; promoted to 1st class, March, 1881; retired, 1886.

CRAWFORD, CHARLES EDWARD GORDON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent, railway magistrate, and cantonment magistrate; also acted as district superintendent of police, Aug.–Oct., 1878; from Jan., 1879, acted in the judicial department as assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; 2nd grade assistant judge, Aug., 1883; also acted as judge and sessions judge in various districts, and as judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, Feb.–May, 1885; registrar, high court, Bombay, September, 1885.

CRAWFORD, JAMES ADAIR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 17th Sept., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Feb., 1881, served in the political department, and acted as assistant to the governor-general's agent for Rajputana, boundary settlement officer in Meywar, and assistant to the resident at Hyderabad (June, 1881); attaché, foreign department of government of India, May, 1882; in charge of office of press commissioner, June, 1882, to Nov., 1883; acting political agent, 3rd class, and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, April, 1884; assistant secretary, foreign department, Jan., 1885; political agent, Quetta and Pishin, Nov., 1885, to March, 1886; junior under secretary to government foreign department, March, 1888; political agent, 2nd class, and acting first assistant secretary for Berar to president at Hyderabad.

CRAWFORD, JOHN THOMSON, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Perth Academy, Edinburgh University, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1864; from Feb., 1865, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Aug., 1879; from Nov., 1880, served as district judge, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, and from Jan., 1882, as deputy commissioner; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Unao, March, 1885.

CRAWFORD, RICHMOND IRVINE, Colonel, Bombay S.C.—First commission, Oct., 1857; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1857; served in the pursuit of the Gwalior rebels in 1858 (medal and clasp for Central India); from September, 1864, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, and (from April, 1867) as superintendent of police; from May, 1873, acted as political superintendent of Thar and Parkar, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1875; deputy commissioner, Thar and Parkar, Aug., 1881; collector and magistrate, Shikarpur, June, 1885; and subsequently at Karachi.

CRAWFURD, JAMES, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Collegiate School and University of Glasgow, and Dublin University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1868; assistant magistrate and collector, Rajshahiye, Jan., 1869; officiating under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1875; under secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1876; first inspector of registration offices, Dec., 1877; registrar, high court, Nov., 1878; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1885, and 1st grade, April, 1889.

CRAWLEY, CHARLES EDWARD, Financial
Department, Government of India.—Joined the department, and was attached to the accountant general's office, Bombay, 25th Feb., 1874; acted as assistant accountant general, Madras, May, 1877 to Jan., 1878; assistant commissioner paper currency, Bombay, March, 1878; acted as deputy comptroller general, Calcutta, Aug., 1883, and comptroller, Central Provinces, April, 1884; appointed to finance department, class 4, assistant accountant general, June, 1888.

CRAWLEY, GEORGE BURRIDGE, Captain, B.S.C. (N.W. Provinces), 1st commission, and Lieutenant, 29th Feb., 1880; served with the 2nd Queen's Own, Bengal, L.I., and with the 13th N.I., and was appointed cantonment magistrate, 2nd class, July, 1888, and 1st class, May, 1889.

CRAWLEY-BOEVEY, ARTHUR WILLIAM, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, special assistant to political agent, and acting political agent in Rewa Kántha; from May, 1873, to Dec., 1874, served in Baroda as acting assistant resident, and performed the duties of the cantonment and railway magistrate, and small cause court judge, May-Nov., 1873; in special charge of Sachin state, Dec., 1874; on special duty at Baroda, Feb., 1875; on famine duty at Kaládgi, Aug., 1877; Tálukdári settlement officer, Gujarát, June, 1879; pro tem. special officer for the settlement of claims to girás and watanas in Baroda territory, April, 1883, and again April, 1885; acting chief presidency magistrate and revenue judge, Bombay, May, 1887; junior collector and magistrate, May, 1889.

CREGEN, ARCHIBALD CRELLIN, M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1859, as assistant engineer, Central Provinces; transferred to Punjab, Feb. 1861; executive engineer, April, 1866; railway department, Central India, Holkar state railway, Oct., 1870; engineer-in-chief, provincial light railway survey extensions, Lucknow, June, 1878; Neemuch-Naseerabad survey, Nov., 1878; engineer-in-chief, Western Rajputana state railway, Aug., 1879; engineer-in-chief, Vizagapatam-Rajpur railway survey, Oct., 1882; member of committee on reorganisation of public works department, Sept. 1883; engineer-in-chief, construction establishment, Nagpur-Bengal railway, Oct., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1885; agent and chief engineer, Indian Midland railway, Feb., 1886; retired, Feb., 1888.

CRESSWELL, CHARLES ARTHUR, Major, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, royal artillery, Jan., 1866; arrived in Madras, 12th Jan., 1867; joined the Burma commission, Feb., 1871, as officiating assistant commissioner and cantonment magistrate at Toungoo; personal assistant to chief commissioner, Dec., 1875; boundary officer, Sandoway, March, 1881; president, Sandoway Town committee, April, 1884; deputy commissioner, March, 1885.

CROFT, SIR ALFRED WOODLEY, K.C.I.E., M.A., Educational Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the secretary of state, 8th Dec., 1865; served as professor, Presidency College, principal, Dacca College, inspector of schools, and officiating principal Presidency College, and officiating registrar, Calcutta University, and was promoted to 2nd class of the educational service, Feb., 1877; director of public instruction, Aug., 1878; president of the commission to draw up a code for European schools, Oct. 1881; on special duty with the government of India, as member of the education commission, Jan., 1883; C.I.E., June, 1884; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887; member of the legislative council of Bengal, Feb., 1887; on special duty with the Government of India for the preparation of a report on education in British India, May, 1887; is also fellow, member of the syndicate and president of the Faculty of Arts, of Calcutta University.

CROFTON, JAMES, Lieutenant-General, late R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 9th Dec., 1844; joined the public works department, Nov., 1847; assistant engineer, Punjab circle, Dec., 1849; superintendent, 1st division, Bari Doab canal, July, 1854; executive engineer, Punjab irrigation, 1858; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Jan., 1862; superintendent, Sutlej canal surveys; officiating superintendent, Eastern Jumna canals, 1863; chief engineer, irrigation, and under secretary to government, Punjab, Sept., 1864; chief engineer, 1st class, April, 1872; inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, public works department, April, 1874, to Jan., 1882, when he resigned the service.

CROLE, CHARLES STEWART, Madras C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh High School and Edinburgh University.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acted as sub-secretary, board of revenue, July-Sept., 1869, and as collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants in 1870-80; compiled Chingleput district manual; acting commissioner of salt revenue, Madras, Jan.-March, 1880; district and sessions judge, Kistna, June, 1881; collector and magistrate, Nov., 1882, in the district of Kistna, and afterwards in the districts of Madura and Anantapur; district and sessions judge, North Malabar, Aug., 1886, and North Arcot, Jan., 1887; acting 4th member of board of revenue, June, 1890.

CROMBIE, ALEXANDER, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1872; officiating resident surgeon, Calcutta Medical College Hospital, 25th Jan., 1873; professor of surgery, Medical College, in addition to his own duties, Oct., 1873; professor of materia medica, Sept., 1874; transferred to Burma, Feb., 1875, and appointed junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, and health officer to the port; from April, 1877, served in Bengal as civil surgeon, also at Simla as joint medical officer, March, 1880, to Feb., 1882; civil surgeon, Dacca, with charge of the jail, March, 1882; also superintendent of the lunatic asylum, medical school and Mitford Hospital; surgeon-major, March, 1884; officiating surgeon superintendent, presidency general hospital, Calcutta, March, 1886; confirmed, Jan., 1889.

CROOKE, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Erasmus Smith's Grammar School, Tipperary, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1871, and
served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Dec., 1836; deputy commissioner, July, 1839; magistrate and collector, Jan., 1840; author of a rural and agricultural glossary for the N.W. Provinces and Oudh.

CROSS (Viscount), Rt. Hon. Richard Assheton Cross, G.C.B.—Born 30th May, 1823; educated at Rugby School, and at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he graduated B.A. in 1846; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1849, and for several years went the northern circuit; represented Preston in the House of Commons, March, 1857, to March, 1862, and S.W. Lancashire from Dec., 1868; secretary of state for the home department, Feb., 1874, to 1880; bencher of the Inner Temple, 1876; hon. LL.D. of Cambridge, Oct., 1878; G.C.B. in 1890; again secretary of state for the home department, June, 1885; and was appointed president of the royal commission on the Education Acts; in Lord Salisbury's second administration, Aug., 1886, was appointed secretary of state for India, and raised to the peerage under the title of Viscount Cross; was formerly an ecclesiastical commissioner for England; is a deputy lieutenant for Lancashire, and late chairman of the Lancashire quarter sessions; author of two legal works—'The Acts relating to the Settlement and Removal of the Poor, with Notices of Cases, Indices, and Forms,' 1853; and 'The General and Quarter Sessions of the Peace; their Jurisdiction and Practice in other than Criminal Matters' (written in conjunction with Mr. H. Leaming), 1853, 2nd edition, 1876.

CROSTHWAITIE, Sir Charles Haukes Todd, K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S., (Central Provinces).—Educated at St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857; from Nov., 1858, to March, 1877, served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector and settlement officer, and acted as secretary to the board of revenue for two years from March, 1875; from April, 1877, served in the Central Provinces as commissioner of the Nagpur and Jubbulpur divisions, and was appointed judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1881, and additional member of the governor-general's council for the purpose of making laws and regulations, Dec., 1881; acting chief commissioner, British Burma, March, 1883, to April, 1884; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Jan., 1885; member of the public service commission, Nov., 1886; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; chief commissioner of Burma, March, 1887; K.C.S.I., May, 1888; appointed member of council of governor general, Oct., 1890; author of 'Notes on the N.W. Provinces' and 'Land Revenue Law.'

CROSTHWAITIE, Robert Joseph, C.S.I., B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty on the revenue committee at Naini Tal, July, 1872; assistant superintendent, sub-judge, and registrar of Dehra Dun, Dec., 1873; small cause court judge, Allahabad, March, 1875; registrar of the high court, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1878; acting judicial commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1878, to Feb., 1881; acting secretary to the government of India, legislative department, March to May, 1881; district and sessions judge, Allahabad, May, 1881; additional secretary to government of India, legislative department, Jan., 1883; acted as judicial commissioner of the Central Provinces in 1882 and 1883, and was confirmed in the appointment, Jan., 1885; C.S.I., May, 1890.

CROW, William, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk under the inspector-general of railway stores, 23rd Oct., 1883.

CROWDY, John Henry, Lieut-Colonel, R.E., late Military Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1857; posted to Indian establishment, Sept., 1879; from Dec., 1879, served as executive engineer in the Punjab; transferred to military works, 1872, and served in the Punjab, the N.W. Provinces and Bengal; superintending engineer, 3d class, March, 1886; retired, March, 1890.

CROWE, William Henry (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Godolphin Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, professor of mental and moral philosophy and logic at the Deccan College, Poona, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and assistant judge and sessions judge; editor of the 'Bombay Gazetteer,' Oct., 1868; acting special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, March, 1882; on special duty at Khairiwar, Nov., 1882; appointed and grade judge and session judge, Thana, Aug., 1883, and afterwards at Satara; 1st grade judge, Sept., 1885.

CROZIER, Robert G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College; temporary clerk, India Office, 30th Nov., 1865; junior clerk, Jan., 1867; senior clerk, March, 1887.

CRUICKSHANK, Alexander, M.A., late Madras C.S.—University and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in various districts of Madras from Oct., 1863, as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, principal assistant collector, and acting district and sessions judge; collector and magistrate, South Arcot, special agent, French settlement, and political agent for Pondicherry, Sept., 1878; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Nov., 1882; district and sessions judge, of Cuddapah, Jan., 1886, and of Kurnool, Aug., 1886; retired, Nov. 1887.

CRUICKSHANK, Alexander Walmsly, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and officiating magistrate and collector; junior secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1878; under secretary to government, N.W.P.; Sept., 1886; settlement officer, Gorakhpur, Oct., 1886.
CRUICKSHANK, John, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., late Medical Department, Bombay.—Appointed to the Indian medical service, 26th Feb., 1856; arrived in India, 6th April, 1856; civil surgeon, Dhárwár, Jan., 1865; from March, 1866, acted as surgeon to the governor of Bombay, also as private secretary, Oct., 1866; on special duty to Egypt as surgeon to Lord Mayo, Nov., 1868; superintendent of Mahábaleshwar, Dec., 1870; from April, 1871, served as inspector-general of prisons, Bombay, and was a member of the prisons conference at Calcutta, Jan., 1877; retired, April, 1887.

CRUMP, Charles George, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces; resigned, March, 1886.

CRUMP, Henry Ashbrooke, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1885; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Nov., 1885; assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1889.

CULLEN, Peter, Brigade-Surgeon, M.D., Medical Department (Central Provinces).—Joined the Bengal medical service, July, 1859; arrived in India, 24th Jan., 1860; was employed under the military department, including service in the China War; from Feb., 1862, served in the Central Provinces as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail; also superintendent of cotton affairs, May, 1865; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877, and of brigade-surgeon, April, 1888.

CUMINÉ, Alexander, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1874, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting superintendent of police, railway magistrate, and acting junior collector and forest settlement officer; acting special assistant collector and settlement officer, Ratnagiri, Nov., 1884; and assistant collector, May, 1887.

CUMMING, Charles Lennox Bruce, F.R.G.S., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India 26th Nov., 1867, and served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; principal assistant to collector, magistrate and agent, Ganjam, Nov., 1883; retired, March, 1888.

CUMMING, John Arthur, Madras C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen Grammar School, and Aberdeen University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 16th Dec., 1887, and served as assistant to magistrate and collector.

CUMMING, John Ghest, Bengal C.S.—Educated at High School, Glasgow, and Glasgow University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887.

CUMMING, William Gordon, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department.—First commission, Madras engineers, 1860; arrived in India 7th Oct., 1862; joined the public works department, Feb., 1864, as assistant engineer in Port Blair; executive engineer, April, 1866; transferred to Madras, Aug., 1868; Hyderabad, May, 1870; from Feb., 1874, served in British Burma; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, civil and military works branch, May, 1881; temporary superintending engineer, Rangoon, Jan., 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1884; officiating secretary to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, Oct., 1884; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, April, 1887; confirmed, May, 1888; chief engineer, 3rd class, special, May, 1888.

CUNNINGHAM, James Macnabb, Surgeon-general, M.D., C.S.I., late Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1851; superintendent of central prison, Bareilly, 1861, and subsequently at Meerut; officiating superintendent, government press, N.W. Provinces, 1863; surgeon, April, 1864; secretary to sanitary commissioner, 1866; professor of hygiene, Calcutta medical college, 1866; sanitary commissioner, Bengal, 1869; sanitary commissioner with the government of India, 1875; surgeon-general, March, 1880; retired, March, 1885.

CUNNINGHAM, William John, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Clapham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Aug., 1873, served in Mysore as assistant commissioner on special duty at Bangalore and Chitradurg, acting deputy commissioner, additional secretary in the famine department (Aug., 1878), and secretary to the chief commissioner, general department (Jan., 1879); political agent, assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to the chief commissioner, Coorg, April, 1881; political agent, 3rd class, and assistant to the resident, Hyderabad, Dec., 1883; under secretary, government of India, foreign department, Sept., 1885; acting secretary, Nov., 1889; deputy secretary, continuing to act as secretary.

CUNNINGHAM, Sir Alexander, Major-General, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., R.E.—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and Addiscombe; first commission, Bengal engineers, 1831; aide-de-camp to governor-general, 1834; sent specially to Cashmere, 1839; engineer to king of Oudh in 1840; served in the Gwalior campaign of 1843-44, and was present at the battle of Punniar (bronze star); from Feb., 1844 served as executive officer on the staff, Gwalior contingent; head of a mission to Thibet in 1846; engineer for laying down the boundaries of the N.W. frontier, Jan. 1847 to 1849; served in the Punjab campaign of 1848-49, including the battles of Chillianwallah and Goojerat (medal with two clasps, and brevet of major); executive engineer, Moulton, Dec., 1852; chief engineer, Pegu and Tenasserim, Oct., 1856; chief engineer, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1858; also secretary to government; archaeological surveyor to government, 1861; retired June, 1862. C.S.I., May, 1871; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; author of many articles on antiquarian subjects in the journal of the Bengal Asiatic Society, and other periodicals: 'The Bhilsa Topes, or Buddhist Monuments of Central India,' 1854; 'An Essay on the Aryan Order of Architecture,' 1846;
CUNNINGHAM, ALEXANDER FREDERICK DOUGLAS, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab (civil department), Sept., 1878; on special duty as political assistant to Major Cavagnari for employment in Afghanistan, Nov., 1878; political officer, Khyber, Oct., 1879; 1st assistant to chief political officer, Afghanistan (Kabul), Feb., 1880; officiating secretary to government, April–May, 1881; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, Feb., 1882; under secretary to government, Punjab, Dec., 1884; officiated as deputy commissioner at Dera Ismail Khan, Feb., 1885, at Hazara, 1886, and at Bannu, April, 1887; on special duty at Rawul Pindi durbar, March, 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1887; officiated as divisional judge, Jhelum, Aug., 1887, and deputy commissioner and district judge, Sept., 1887; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1888.

CUNNINGHAM, DAVID DOUGLAS, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1868; from 19th Dec., 1874, served as special assistant to the sanitary commissioner with the government of India; professor of physiology, Calcutta Medical College, in addition to his own duties, from June, 1879; also acted as government quinologist, and was in charge of the cinchona plantations, Sept., 1879; officiating superintendent of botanical gardens, Aug., 1880; appointed to conduct special cholera inquiries in immediate connection with the sanitary commissioner with the government of India, Dec., 1884; rank of surgeon-major, April, 1880; honorary surgeon to H.E. the Viceroy; author of many medical and scientific treatises the result of microscopical and physiological research in relation to cholera and other subjects.

CUNNINGHAM, Sir H. S., K.C.I.E. late Calcutta High Court.—Advocate-general, high court, Madras, and additional member of the governor's council, 1872–77; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, Nov., 1877; member of the famine commission, May, 1878 to Jan., 1881; member of the finance committee, March, 1886; resigned his seat in the high court, Calcutta, July, 1888; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

CURRIE, BERTRAM WODEHOUSE, appointed to the council of the secretary of state for India, 11th Dec., 1880; and on the completion of his ten years of office in Dec., 1890, was re-appointed for a further term of five years.

CURRIE, FENDALL, Colonel (Barrister-at-Law).—Arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1853, as cornet, 1st European light cavalry; assistant commissioner, Hazaribagh, Feb., 1863; from Sept., 1863, served in the Oudh commission, and was appointed small cause court judge, Sitapur, June, 1868, and junior secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1868; on special duty to collate laws and regulations in force in Oudh, May, 1869; on special duty for taking up lands for railway purposes, Oct., 1869; city magistrate, Lucknow, Feb., 1870; on special duty to review the Bara Banki forgery report, March, 1874; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1878; officiated as Commissioner in the Rae Bareli division, Aug., 1882; and subsequently in the Fyzabad, and Lucknow divisions; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Oct., 1883, commissioner Rae Bareli, March, 1888; author of 'The Penal Code, Act XLV. of 1880,' 'The Indian Code of Criminal Procedure,' 'The Oudh Rent Act,' 'The Oudh Land Revenue Manual,' 'a Commentary on Act XXII. of 1886,' and the 'Indian Law Examination Manual.'

CURRIE, GEORGE MAINWARING, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1884, and 1st grade, Aug., 1887.

CURSETJEE RUSTOMJEE (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, London; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India 29th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, April, 1886, and 1st grade, Oct., 1889.

CURTIS, GEORGE SEYMOUR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1888; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1889.

CUSHING, THOMAS, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk to inspector of scientific instruments, store depot, Dec., 1867; inspector of scientific instruments, May, 1876.

CUTHBERTSON, CLIVE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's, Adelaide, Glenalmond School, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived, 13th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885, officiating under secretary to government of Bengal, March, 1888, and confirmed Nov., 1889.

CUTTLE, G., Store Department, India Office.—2nd class clerk, India store depot, 5th April, 1882.

DALLAS, A. M., Deputy Surgeon-General, C.I.E., late Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India and was appointed assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, June, 1856; superintendent, central jail, Oct., 1859; inspector-general of prisons, April, 1863; surgeon, Feb., 1868; special duty, Calcutta, Jan., 1877; brigade surgeon, Dec., 1882; deputy surgeon-general, and surgeon-general, Punjab, Sept., 1884; inspector-general of civil hospitals, Punjab, April, 1885; retired, March, 1889.

DALMAHOY, PATRICK CARFRAE, Colonel, Bengal Infantry, late Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign 1st Jan., 1857; adjutant of the Hamirpur district police, Oct., 1858, to Sept., 1860; commandant of the same, Oct., 1861; from Jan., 1862, served as district superintendent of police up to April, 1867, when he was appointed assistant inspector-general, government railway police; officiating commandant of the Mhairwara police battalion Sept., 1869, to April, 1871; deputy inspector-general, Oct., 1882 to 1885.
DALTON, Godfrey John Bective Tuite, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Columba's College, Rathfarnham, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived 12th Jan., 1864; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1877, and deputy commissioner, 1st grade, March, 1886; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1887, and 1st grade, April, 1889.

DALY, Sir Henry Dominick, General, G.C.B., C.I.E.—Ensign, first European regiment, Bombay, Dec., 1840; served in the Punjab campaign, 1848-49, and was present at the siege of Mooltan, the battle of Goojerat, and the pursuit and surrender of the Sikh army (medal and two clasps); served in the campaign on the N.W. Frontier, 1850-51, including the passage of the Kotah Pass, and the expedition against the hill tribes; during the Indian mutiny served at the siege of Delhi, the siege of Lucknow, in the campaign in Oude, the action at Nawabganj, the passages of the Goomtee, Gogra, &c. (C.B., medal, brevet of lieutenant-colonel); commandant, Central India Horse, June, 1862; agent to governor-general, Central India, 1871, to Feb., 1881.

DALY, Hugh, Lieut., B.S.C., Burma Political Department.—Arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1882, and served in the military department from Nov., 1884, served in the political department as political assistant, Rajputana; on special duty in Upper Burma, June, 1886, and with the Northern Shan column in Nov., 1887; appointed superintendent, Northern Shan States, May, 1888; political assistant, 2nd class, May, 1889.

DALY, William Watt, C.I.E., Bengal Police.—Served in the police department from 19th Nov., 1862; attached to Looshai expeditionary force in command of frontier police, Nov., 1871-March, 1872; district superintendent, March, 1873; with Garrow Hills expedition, 1873-4; commandant of frontier police in command of Surma Valley division, May, 1883; district superintendent of police, 1st grade, April, 1888; has officiated as deputy inspector general of police; C.I.E., Jan., 1891.

DAMES, Mansel Longworth, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant and divisional judge; on special duty with the Kabul troops, Jan., 1879; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Feb., 1887; author of a Biluchi grammar and text-book.

DAMPIER, Henry Lucius, C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, Dec., 1843; arrived in India, 18th Sept., 1849; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1860; junior secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1861, and secretary, Nov., 1861; commissioner, Nuddea division, July, 1863; on special duty in the famine districts, 1866; between April, 1867, and Nov., 1874, served as secretary to the government of Bengal in the revenue and general departments, and as officiating secretary to the government of India, home department, in 1872; special member of the Bengal legislative council, Dec., 1874; board of revenue, Oct., 1877; Bengal legislative council, Jan., 1879; president of commission for amendment of rent law in Bengal, 1881; retired, 26th July, 1884.

DANCE, George Whitmore, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1880.

DANE, Louis William, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1876, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner and district judge; on special duty in the Punjab secretariat, Aug., 1879; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, Oct., 1879, to April, 1882; on special duty, Lahore Rakhs, 1884-85; officiating registrar, chief court, June, 1886; officiating district judge, April, 1887; settlement officer, Gurdaspur, Oct., 1887; officiating deputy commissioner, April to June, 1888, in addition to his own duties; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, May, 1889.

DANE, Richard Morris, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kingstown School, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; served under the foreign department of the government of India, July, 1878, to April, 1879; secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Nov., 1880; on special duty in public works department, Feb. 1882; officiating undersecretary to government, Punjab, March to Aug., 1882; on special duty under government of India, foreign department, as boundary settlement officer, Central India, Jan., 1883, to March, 1884, and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, Jan.-June, 1885; served subsequently as officiating deputy commissioner, Punjab; settlement officer, Gurdaspur, Nov., 1885; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1889; officiating commissioner of excise; inspector general of registration, &c., April, 1890.

DANIELL, Carnes Anthony, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1854; from Jan., 1859, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant under the commissioner of Meerut, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed superintendent, Dehra Dun, April, 1866; settlement officer, 1st grade, June, 1868; magistrate and collector, Moradabad, July, 1869; civil and session judge, Gorakhpur, April, 1877; commissioner, Benares division, and agent to the governor-general, March, 1881; member, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, March, 1884; retired, Nov., 1889.

DANIELL, Clarmont John, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1855; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, under secretary to government, deputy commissioner, Jhansi, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector;
magistrate and collector, Cawnpore, Aug., 1872; civil and sessions judge, Gorakhpur, Aug., 1878; fellow of Calcutta University, June, 1883; officiating commissioner, Allahabad division, Aug., 1881, and of the Agra division, Oct., 1883; 1st grade judge, April, 1885, Farakhabad; retired, Oct., 1886.

DANVERS, FREDERICK C., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and King's College, London, and, after a special training preparatory for Addiscombe, studied for two years for a civil and mechanical engineer; East India House writer, old establishment, 26th Jan., 1853; junior clerk, public and ecclesiastical department, India office, 1853; public works department, 1861; senior clerk, June, 1867; assistant secretary in the public works department, Feb., 1875; assistant secretary in the revenue department, 1877; registrar and superintendent of records Jan., 1884; in 1855 designed a salt-weighing machine, of which a number were manufactured in this country for the use of the Madras government; in 1859 was deputed by the secretary of state to Liverpool and Manchester to report on traction engines, with a view to their being used in India; author of articles published in 'Engineering' relative to public works in India, 1866-75; of a design for crossing the East India Railway under the Hooghly from Howrah to Calcutta, transmitted to India by the secretary of state in 1868; of 'Statistical Papers relating to India' (printed parliamentary paper No. 308 of 1869); of memorandum on Indian coals, with reference to their employment as fuel for Indian railways and steamers, 1867; of memorandum on coal-washing and artificial fuel, 1869; of 'Coal Economy' (printed by order of the secretary of state, 1872); of 'A Century of Famines, being particulars of all the Famines that have visited India since the year 1770, and an inquiry as to the best means of providing against them,' 1877; of 'Spon's Information for Colonial Engineers—India' (published by E. and F. Spon, London, 1877); of 'Agriculture in India,' a paper read before the Society of Arts, 1878 (Society's silver medal); of 'Famines in India, read before the Society of Arts in 1836; of a 'Report on the Records of the India Office,' printed by order of the secretary of state for India in Council, 1887; and of 'Chiefs, Agents, and Governors of Bengal,' 1883.

DANVERS, SIR JULAND, K.C.S.I., Public Works Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London; East India House writer, 22nd March, 1842; junior clerk, Feb., 1847; minuting branch, secretary's department, 1847; private secretary to chairman and deputy, 1848-53; senior clerk, Feb., 1852; assistant, minuting branch, secretary's department, 1857; assistant secretary in the railway and electric telegraph department, India office, and assistant director of Indian railway companies, Feb., 1858; secretary in the railway and telegraph department, and deputy director of Indian railway companies, Sept., 1853, to July, 1861; government director of Indian railway companies, 1861; secretary in the public works, railway and telegraph departments, Aug., 1880, continuing to be director of Indian railway companies, visited India in his official capacity in 1875-76; author of the annual official reports on railways in India presented to Parliament from 1859 to 1882; K.C.S.I., 1886.

DARLINGTON, EDWIN, Customs Department, Burma.—Joined the service as superintendent of the Burma secretariat, June, 1858; from March, 1872, served as collector of customs, Akyab; also in the Burma secretariat, on special duty, Oct., 1874, to Jan., 1875; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1875; officiating junior secretary to chief commissioner, Sept., 1876; collector of customs, Rangoon, July, 1877; vice-chairman of the Rangoon port commissioners, March, 1882.

DARRAH, HENRY ZOCH, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Rathmines School, Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1882; acting manager of the Awa estate, March, 1883; acting director of agriculture in Assam, June, 1884; acting secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, March-April, 1886; director of land records and agriculture, Assam, Jan., 1887; author of a 'Monograph on Cotton in Assam' and a 'Note on the People of Assam.'

DAUKES, FREDERICK CLENDON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Uppingham Grammar School, Blackheath Proprietary School, and Downing College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1866, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, April, 1872; officiating under secretary to government, Sept., 1873; assistant settlement officer, 3rd grade, Banda, Nov., 1873; attaché, foreign department, government of India, 1873; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1876-77; secretary, public service commission, Sept., 1886; under secretary, government of India, home department, from Dec., 1877; officiating secretary to the chief commissioner of Assam, June, 1888.

DAVIDSON, JAMES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the High School and University of Glasgow, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and cantonment magistrate; on famine duty in Mysore, Oct., 1877, to Aug., 1878; acting first assistant collector, Nov., 1883; second assistant collector, Nov., 1886; forest settlement officer, Nasik, Aug., 1887; first assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1888.

DAVIDSON, JAMES YOUNG, late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as assistant-engineer, 9th Dec., 1869, and served in the Central Provinces; executive engineer, Oct., 1875; from Jan., 1882, served as manager, in class 2 of the state railway revenue establishment, on the Wardha coal, and Nagpur-Chhattisgarh railways; in charge of Umaria colliery, Jan., 1886; acting engineer-in-chief Nagpur-Bengal railway, Feb., 1886; class 1, revenue establishment, April, 1887; retired, 1889.

DAVIDSON, LIONEL, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in
Madras, 22nd Dec., 1889, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

DAVIDSON, ROBERT, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1852; served as assistant to collector and magistrate in various districts; sub-judge of Cuddapah, 1860; small cause court judge, Chittoor, 1862; civil and sessions judge, Trichinopoly, 1867; district and sessions judge of Cuddapah, Aug., 1873, and subsequently of Chingleput; acted as collector and magistrate of Kurnool during the famine, 1877-78; third member, board of revenue, March, 1878; chief secretary to government of Madras, Dec., 1878; legislative council of Madras, 1880 to 1883; provisional member of the executive council May-July, 1881; 1st member, board of revenue, March, 1882; member of the special committee appointed to frame a famine code for Madras, Oct., 1882; retired, June 1884.

DAVIES, ARTHUR MATCHAM, Maj.-Gen. M.S.C., late Police Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 23rd Jan., 1849; served in the Madras police department from Sept., 1862, as assistant superintendent and superintendent; acting personal assistant to commissioner of police, Madras Sept., 1866, deputy inspector-general, Nov., 1881 to 1886.

DAVIES, CHARLES MERSON, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant locomotive superintendent, 15th Sept., 1875; superintendent, March, 1880; class 1, grade 3, Jan., 1883.

DAVIES, H. S. P., Captain, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 28th June, 1878; and from April, 1883; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; settlement collector, Oct., 1888.

DAVIES, J., late Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; clerk in principal storekeeper's office, Tower of London, under the board of ordnance, May, 1842; inspector of stores, 1851; sub-inspector of stores, East India House, July, 1855; senior clerk, June, 1860; assistant superintendent of the India store depot, March, 1877; superintendent, June, 1880; retired, Dec., 1888.

DAVIES, JAMES ACWORTH (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Denmark Hill Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1869, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, March, 1880; assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments, April, 1880; acting under secretary in the chief secretary's department, July, 1880; member of the board of examiners, Jan., 1882; acting district and sessions judge, South Canara, June, 1882; under secretary in the revenue department, Oct., 1882; acting secretary to the board of revenue, June, 1883; from Oct., 1883, acted as registrar, high court, Madras, and was appointed sub-collector and joint magistrate, Kistna, July, 1884; district and sessions judge, Tanjore, March, 1888.

DAVIES, SIR ROBERT HENRY, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1844; served in the N.W. Provinces and cis-Sutlej Territory as assistant commissioner; settlement officer, Barce Doab, 1851; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Azimgurh, 1858; secretary to government of Punjab, 1859; financial commissioner, Oudh, 1864; chief commissioner, Oudh, 1869; lieutenant-governor, Punjab, 1871; retired 1873; member of council of India, 3rd March, 1885.

DAVIES, SIR WILLIAM GEORGE, Maj.-Gen., K.C.S.I., B.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 5th Jan., 1849; from April, 1854, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; deputy commissioner, May, 1862; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Nov., 1876, and subsequently in the Jullundur division; financial commissioner, Punjab, Dec., 1883; additional member of the governor-general's council, March, 1886; author of a report on the settlement of the Shahpur district; K.C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired, April, 1887.

DAVIS, ARTHUR WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Rossall, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner.

DAVIS, JOHN SAMUEL CHAMPION, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at College School, Taunton, Rossall, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1880, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun, April, 1882, and officiating superintendent in 1882-83; officiating cantonment magistrate, Chakrata, Sept.-Oct., 1885; junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1886, and Feb., 1890; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Dec., 1888.

DAWKINS, CLINTON E., India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in June, 1883; junior clerk, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, India office, 6th Feb., 1884; political department, 1886; assistant private secretary, and précis writer to the secretary of state, Aug., 1886; private secretary to the chancellor of the exchequer (Rt. Hon. G. J. Goschen), Nov., 1889.

DAWSON, WALTER HILL, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, St. Peter's, Weston-super-Mare, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1888, and served as assistant commissioner in Burma.

DAY, ARTHUR S., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College, Bedford Grammar School, and Clifton College; writer, India office, 26th Oct., 1874; clerk, 2nd class, Nov., 1878.

DAYARAM GIDUMAL, B.A., LL.B., Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, and joined the service as assistant collector, 3rd Jan., 1885; acting small cause court judge, July, 1886; employed from May, 1885, to April, 1886, in compiling a Jaghir record for Sind; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, 3rd March, 1887; acting assistant judge and sessions judge.

DEAN, EDWARD JOSEPH.—Superintendent Bengal secretariat press, 1st May, 1868, and of the public works department press and deputy superintendent of government printing, April,
1869; superintendent of government printing, Calcutta, April, 1873.

DEANE, THOMAS, Lieut.-Col., B.S.C.—First commission, March, 1862; 1st hussars; lieutenant, Bengal staff corps, March, 1863; adjutant, governor-general's body guard, Jan., 1871; 3rd assistant secretary to the government of India, military department, Jan., 1877; 2nd assistant secretary, April, 1884; deputy secretary, July, 1886; director army remount department.

DEAS, JOSEPH, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1870, and served in N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, joint magistrate, and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1885; from April, 1886, acted as district and session judge; confirmed in appointment, Aug., 1887.

DE BEAUREPAIRE, E.L., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 31st March, 1885.

DE BOURBEL, RAOUl, Major-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, as lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 1850; joined the public works department, Nov., 1852; executive engineer, Lower Provinces, Dec., 1853; assistant to chief engineer, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1857; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1860; officiating consulting engineer and under secretary, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1862; superintending engineer, Gowhatta, June, 1865; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Oudh, Feb., 1870; superintending engineer, 2nd grade, railway branch, Oudh, Sept., 1870; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, 1871; in temporary charge of public works department in Biluchistan, 1879-80; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, 1886; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1884; retired, 1885.

DE BRETT, EDWARD ADOLPHUS, Bengal C.S., Central Provinces.—Educated at Winchester College and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

DE FABECK, WILLIAM FREDERICK, Surgeon-General, M.D., Medical Department.—Entered the army medical department, June 1855; joined the Madras medical department, June, 1857, and served under the military department from that date to May, 1871, also holding the civil surgeoncies of Kurnul, Chittur, Vellore, and Nagode (Central Provinces), during that period. From Nov., 1873, served in British Burma as acting garrison surgeon, Rangoon, and acting civil surgeon and superintendent of Lock Hospital, Moumein (May, 1874), and was confirmed in the latter appointment, 1877; also health officer, Moumein, Feb., 1878, and was in medical charge of the central jail for various periods; deputy surgeon-general, Nagpore force, and Central India regiments, March, 1886; surgeon-general with the Government of Madras, May, 1890; served in the Crimean Campaign, 1855-6 (medal and clasp) and in the Indian Mutiny, 1859 (medal).

DEIGHTON, KENNETH, B.A., late Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as professor, Agra College, 19th Feb., 1862; principal, Agra College, March, 1864; 2nd grade of educational officers, April, 1883; officiating principal, Benares College, July, 1883; inspector of schools, Rohilkund division, April, 1885; retired, 1890.

DE LAESSOE, ALBERT FREDERICK, Captain, C.M.G., C.I.E., Foreign Department Government of India.—Served in the Danish Army, from April, 1867; attached to foreign legion of French Army, Sep., 1870, to Aug., 1871; chevalier of legion of honour, 1871; from 1873 to 1880 served as instructor in Persian Army and chief to staff college in Persia; appointed translator to Government of India Foreign Department, Feb., 1881; resigned the Danish service, Aug., 1882; in charge of office of Press Commissioner, Nov., 1883; attached to Afghan Boundary commission, Sept., 1884; on special duty with Sir West Ridgeway in St. Petersburgh and London; political assistant and cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, Nov., 1887; political assistant, 1st class, Sep., 1889.

DENMAN, JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1880, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1888.

DENNISTON, JAMES LAWSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portland Grammar School, Mill Hill Grammar School, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1885; deputy commissioner, March, 1888; acting magistrate and collector, April, 1888.

DENNYS, CHARLES JOHN, Captain, Punjab.—Arrived in India, May, 1873; services placed at disposal of Punjab Government, July, 1881; officiating assistant cantonment magistrate, Aug., 1881, confirmed, Oct., 1882; captain, March, 1885; cantonment magistrate, 2nd class, March, 1886.

DE PALEZIEUX-FALCONNET, GRENVILLE PULTENEY, Major-General, R.E., late Military Works Department, India.—First commission, Madras engineers, 1852; joined the Madras public works department, Aug., 1854, as assistant engineer; from Dec., 1854, served in the Bengal public works department as executive engineer, Pegu; Mhow division, Rajputana, Nov., 1864; officiating superintending engineer, military works, Allahabad, 1872; superintending engineer, Meerut, April, 1874, and afterwards at Moradabad and Rawal Pindi; superintending engineer, 1st grade, June, 1879; officiated as inspector-general of military works, 1883-84; retired, 1886.

DERBY (EARL OF), RIGHT HONOURABLE EDWARD HENRY SMITH-STANLEY, K.G., D.C.L.—Born 21st July, 1826; educated at Rugby, and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he took a first class in classics in 1848; contested Lancaster unsuccessfully, March, 1848, but was elected for Lyme Regis, which he represented till Oct.,
1860, when he succeeded to the House of Peers; made tours to the West Indies and the East in 1850-52; under secretary of state for foreign affairs, May-Dec., 1852; secretary of state for the colonies, and sworn a privy councillor, Feb., 1853; president of the board of control, May, 1853; secretary of state for India, Sept., 1853-59; during his tenure of this office the management of the Indian empire was transferred to the Crown; was secretary of state for foreign affairs from July, 1866, to Dec., 1868, and during this period conducted the negotiations for the settlement of the Luxemburg difficulty; lord rector of the University of Glasgow, April, 1869; was again appointed foreign secretary in Feb., 1874, but resigned in March, 1878; in Dec., 1882, he joined Mr. Gladstone's administration as secretary of state for the colonies; elected lord rector of the University of Edinburgh in Nov., 1874; was a member of the royal commission on army purchase in 1856-57, of the Cambridge University commission in 1856-60, and of the commission on the organisation of the Indian army in 1858-59; chairman of the commission on the sanitary state of the Indian army in 1859-61, and of the commission on patents in 1863-64; has also served on the royal commissions on capital punishment, on railways, on city companies, and for the London Exhibition of 1886.

DE RENZY, ANNESLEY CHARLES CASTRIOT, Surgeon-General, C.B., late Bengal Medical Service.—B.A., Trinity College, Dublin; entered the Bengal medical service, 1851; served through the Burmese war, 1852-53 (medal and clasp), and in the Mutiny campaigns, 1857-8, including capture of Lucknow (medal and clasp); appointed first sanitary commissioner, Punjab, 1868; surgeon-major, July, 1871; in 1877 undertook an inquiry into the causes of the great mortality among coolies proceeding by steamer to Assam, and made recommendations which led to a great reduction in the number of deaths; deputy surgeon-general, Nov., 1877; sanitary commissioner, Assam, 1878; served in the expedition against the Nagas, 1879; clasp and C.B.; deputy surgeon-general, Punjab Frontier Force, 1880; retired, Dec., 1882; author of sanitary reports to government on the Punjab and Assam; and of a paper on the sanitary state of British troops in Northern India.

DEY, GEORGE GOODAIR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at North London Collegiate School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1869; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate, joint magistrate, and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1882; also served in Assam, in 1880, as officiating judge of Sylhet and Cachar; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Sept., 1887.

DHANJISHA NAVROJI PARAKH, Surgeon-Major, L.R.C.P., M.R.C.S. (London), Bombay Medical Service.—Joined the service, Sept., 1874; arrived in India, 5th May, 1875; was employed under the military department till 1881; served subsequently as assistant civil surgeon, Poona, and acted as deputy sanitary commissioner in 1881, as obstetric physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of midwifery, Grant Medical College, in 1883 and 1886, as presidency surgeon in 1884, and as civil surgeon at Surat, April, 1886; surgeon to the Gokuldas Tejpal native general hospital, 1886.

DIACK, ALEXANDER HENDERSON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1882, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating district judge.

DICKENS, CRAVEN HILDESLEY, Lieutenant-General, C.S.I., late R.A.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal artillery, June, 1838; adjutant and quartermaster, 1846; captain, March, 1853; assistant to secretary, government of India, public works department, June, 1855; chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, April, 1864; secretary to government of India, public works department, March, 1865, to Feb., 1877; retired 31st Dec., 1878; is a member of the Royal Indian engineering college, Cooper's Hill.

DICKINSON, RICHARD, Financial Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 1851; junior clerk, minute branch, secretary's department, 1853; private secretary to chairman and deputy chairman, 1855-58; senior clerk, financial department, India office, 1858; assistant secretary in the financial department, June, 1867.

DIXON, JAMES, Burma Police Department.—Appointed inspector of police, Sep., 1870; assistant district superintendent, Oct., 1877, and district superintendent, Jan., 1883; deputy inspector general of civil police, July, 1889.

DOBIE, WILLIAM HERBERT, Financial Department.—Joined the financial department, 23rd May, 1872; on famine duty as district grain accountant, Chumparun, July, 1874, and at Purneah, Jan., 1875; assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1875; from Jan., 1876, served in Bengal, as acting deputy accountant-general, and as assistant comptroller-general; served in Madras, 1878-83, and in the Punjab, Oct., 1883, to Nov., 1884; assistant accountant-general and examiner of local accounts, Bengal, in 3rd class of the financial department, Dec., 1884; assistant accountant-general, Punjab, April, 1885; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, March, 1886; comptroller, Assam, April, 1887.

DODD, CHARLES, Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as officiating professor of English literature, Agra College, 4th Aug., 1866; appointed to 4th grade of Educational department, 17th Dec., 1874; inspector of schools, Allahabad division, Sept., 1884, and Benares division, Oct., 1888; appointed to 3rd grade, Aug., 1888.

DODD, CHARLES ALBERT, Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 23rd Royal Welsh Fusiliers, 12th Nov., 1857; medal and clasp for service during the Mutiny; from Feb., 1860, served in the police department, and was employed on special duty at Lucknow, 1860; personal assistant to inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, March, 1861; district superintendent, Aug., 1861; secretary to committee at Calcutta for revising forms of police statistics, Feb., 1869; from April, 1870, served as superintendent, government press, and curator of government books, N.W. Provinces; also superintendent of emigration, Jan., 1883.
DODERET, WILLIAM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University College School, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1830; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1832; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1833; compiler of Bombay Administration Report, 1836-7; forest settlement officer, May, 1838.

DODGSON, CYRIL GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1831; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1833; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1834; forest settlement officer, July, 1837.
