DONALD, WILLIAM, late Financial Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1856; from 23rd May, 1859, served in the central public works office, and the civil paymaster's office, Madras, and was appointed to 5th class of financial department, Aug., 1862; examiner of claims, July, 1865; secretary to committee for examination of assistants, June, 1868; assistant accountant-general, Madras, Aug., 1869; director of incorporated bank of Madras, March, 1871; 3rd class of financial department, Feb., 1874; appointed assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Nov., 1874, and subsequently at Madras, (June, 1875), and acted on several occasions as accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency; member of board of examiners, May, 1883; deputy accountant-general, Madras, Dec., 1884; officiating accountant-general, Madras (class 3) May-July, 1886, and Aug.-Nov., 1887; confirmed in class 2, March, 1887; compiled the manual of rules and regulations for the use of junior members of Madras civil service; retired, 1889.

DONOVAN, CHARLES, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1863; from Feb., 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; and was placed on special duty at Cawnpore, May, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1879; served in Assam, Sept., 1879, to June, 1882, as deputy commissioner, 1st grade; judge, 3rd grade, Benares, Jan., 1885; 2nd grade, April, 1887; retired, June, 1889.

DOSABHAI FRAMJI, C.S.I., late Presidency Magistrate, Bombay.—Served from 6th Oct., 1860, as income tax assessor; police magistrate, July, 1866; special officer for the Imperial licence tax, May, 1867; collector of income tax and certificate tax, May, 1869; sheriff of Bombay, Dec., 1871; member of the town council, Sept., 1873; from June, 1874, served as second magistrate of police, Bombay, and also held the posts of chairman of the municipal corporation (Sept., 1875, to Dec., 1876), chairman of the justices of the peace, additional member of the governor's council for making laws and regulations (Sept., 1877), special officer to hear appeals against the licence tax assessment (Aug. 1878), special collector of licence tax, and acting collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery (Aug.-Sept., 1882); joint commissioner of income tax in addition to his duties as presidency magistrate, April, 1886; retired, 1888; author of 'Moral and Miscellaneous Essays,' 'The British Raj,' 'History of the Parsees,' and 'Travels in Great Britain.'

DOUGLAS, SHOLTO JAMES Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1878; served in Assam as assistant commissioner and inspector of labourers; from April, 1885, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1890.

DOUIE, JAMES McCrone, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the High School, Edinburgh, University of Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1876, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, secretary to the financial commissioner (1881-82), and settlement officer (2nd grade, April, 1884); senior secretary to financial commissioner, April, 1889; has published a translation of the Biluchinama, with a Biloch grammar.

DOVETON, JOHN CHADWICK, Colonel, M.S.C., Forest Department, Central Provinces.—First commission, Oct., 1858; assistant conservator of forests, 1st grade, Central Provinces, 6th April, 1864; deputy conservator May, 1865; conservator, 1st grade, Sept., 1882.

DOWDEN, THOMAS FREEMAN, Colonel, R.E., Railway Branch, Government of India.—1st commission, Dec. 1856; joined the Bombay public works department, Aug., 1859; under secretary to government, 1865; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, 1872; officiating manager Rajputana state railway, April, 1878; manager, Dhond and Mummad state railway, Dec., 1878; officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, Oct., 1879; served in the Afghan war, 1879-80 (medal); officiating superintending engineer and secretary to agent to governor-general, Biluchistan, April, 1880; acting senior deputy consulting engineer, and under secretary to government, Bombay, Nov., 1881; assistant to director-general of railways, 1884; superintending engineer, 3rd class, July, 1886; deputy consulting engineer, Calcutta, April, 1886; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, Feb., 1887; superintending engineer 2nd class, March, 1889.

DOWNING, SAMUEL F., M.A., A.M.I.C.E., Education Department, Bengal.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin. Appointed, 15th July, 1869; assistant professor, Presidency College, 16th Sept., 1869; professor, April, 1877; principal, government engineering college, Howrah, April, 1880; 2nd class, education department, March, 1884.

DOYLE, B., Surgeon-Major, B.A. M.B., M.C.H., Political Department, Punjab.—Appointed to the Indian Medical Department, and arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1876; served in military department to April, 1881, and afterwards as civil surgeon and deputy sanitary commissioner; served in Burma, Nov., 1886 to Feb., 1887; medical adviser to Maharaja of Jhind, 26th Sept., 1887; surgeon-major, March, 1888.

D'OYLY, WARREN HASTINGS, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 28th May, 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; inspector-general of jails, May, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, July, 1876; officiating opium
agent, Behar, March-Dec., 1878, and July, 1889, to May, 1890; and again in Nov., 1885; officiating commissioner, Bhagulpore, 1884-85, and April, 1889.

DRAKE-BROCKMAN, EDWARD FORSTER, Brigade-Surgeon, F.R.C.S., L.R.C.P. (London), M.R.C.S., Madras Medical Dept.—Assistant surgeon, 1st Oct., 1866; arrived, 23rd April, 1867, and served under the military department, Madras, and also as acting civil surgeon, superintendent of jail, and superintendent of fish liver oil factory, Calicut; was also in medical charge of lock hospital, Madras, and central cholera hospital, Vepry, 1869-70; resident assistant surgeon, general hospital, and professor of pathology in medical college, Madras, Oct., 1870, to Feb., 1875; also acting professor of medical jurisprudence, Sept., 1872; ophthalmic surgeon, general hospital, and professor of ophthalmic surgery and physiology, March, 1875; surgeon-major, Oct., 1878; fellow of Madras University, March, 1885; brigade-surgeon, April, 1890.

DRAKE-BROCKMAN, ELLIOT GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1888, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

DRAKE-BROCKMAN, HENRY VERNON, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at the Charterhouse, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1886; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Central Provinces; acting under secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1890.

DRAKE-BROCKMAN, RALPH RHENIUS EVANS, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., A.I.C.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Arrived in India, 1st March, 1864, and joined sappers and miners, and from Dec., 1864, served in the public works department; assistant engineer, Nov., 1865; executive engineer, March, 1870; superintending engineer, Nov., 1888; acted in 1889 as joint secretary to government and chief engineer, general buildings and roads branch.

DREW, WILLIAM WILSON, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner; from May, 1882, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, and railway magistrate, and was permanently transferred to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885; appointed inspector of factories, town of Bombay, May, 1887; acting junior collector land revenue, customs, &c., June, 1888; and assistant collector, Nov., 1888.

DRIBERG, JOHN JAMES STREET, Assam Commission.—Joined the service as deputy magistrate, and deputy collector, in Bengal, Nov., 1861; from Dec., 1863, served in Assam as extra assistant commissioner, and was placed on special duty as assistant civil and political officer with the Bhutan Duars Field Force, Oct., 1864, to June, 1865 (medal and clasp); assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, May, 1880; deputy superintendent of census in Assam, Oct., 1880; superintendent of emigration, June, 1882; deputy commissioner, May, 1886; has officiated as inspector general of jails, police, and registration, superintendent of stamps, &c.

DRUMMOND, HON. SIR EDMUND, K.C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1831; arrived in India, 6th March, 1833; assistant collector and magistrate, Monghyr, Jan., 1834; on special resumption and settlement duty, Dec., 1835, to Sept., 1839; officiating magistrate of Behar, Sept., 1839; collector of Burdwan, July, 1850; collector, magistrate, and salt agent, Pooree, 1852; accountant, government of Bengal, military accountant, deputy accountant-general, government of India, member of mint committee, and director of bank of Bengal, 1854; accountant-general, government of India, 1856; auditor-general, government of India, president of board of audit, government director of bank of Bengal, and member of mint committee, 1860; financial secretary, government of India, 1862; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, March, 1863; retired, 1868; member of council of secretary of state, 1875-85, K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

DRUMMOND, JAMES RAMSAY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, University of Glasgow, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, Nov., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Aug., 1886, and 1st grade, March, 1889; district judge, 2nd grade, March, 1890.

DRURY, GEORGE MARSTON, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed traffic superintendent, class iii., state railways revenue establishment, 30th Jan., 1878, and served chiefly on the Eastern Bengal State Railway; class ii., grade 1, 1889.

DRYSDALE, ALEXANDER TOVEY, late Forest Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Arrived in India, Dec., 1864; from April, 1865, served in the Central Provinces as head master of government school and officiating inspector of schools; from June, 1868, served in the forest department, Berar, as assistant conservator, deputy conservator, and conservator (3rd grade, Sept., 1882); retired, Jan., 1887.

DRYSDALE, THEODORE, Central Provinces Commission.—Assistant master, government school, Saugor, April, 1861; served in the Central Provinces commission from 19th Jan., 1863, as assistant commissioner; superintendent of the judicial commissioner's office, June, 1864; registrar of the judicial commissioner's court May, 1865; held executive charge of the jail, Saugor, 1877; deputy superintendent of census operations in the Central Provinces, April, 1880; judge, small cause court, Nagpur, Nov., 1884; on special duty in connection with the settlement of the Sarangarh State, Jan.-Feb., 1885; deputy commissioner, 4th class, April, 1885; cantonment magistrate, Kamptee, Dec. 1885; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Sept., 1889.

DU BOULAY, JAMES HOUSEMAYNE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1889, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.
DUCAT, WALTER MARSDEN, Col. R.E., late Bombay Public Works Department.—Joined the service as second lieutenant, 13 June, 1856; arrived in India, May, 1858; assistant engineer, Aug., 1859; special assistant engineer, Jan., 1860; executive engineer, Aug., 1863; captain, Feb., 1863; lieutenant-colonel, Jan., 1884; and colonel, July, 1885; superintending engineer, Nov., 1886; retired, April, 1890.

DUFF, ALAN COLQUHOUN, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1881, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner; acting under secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1885.

DUFFERIN AND AVA (MARQUIS OF), RIGHT HON. FREDERICK TEMPLE HAMILTON BLACKWOOD, K.P., G.C.B., G.C.S.I., G.C.M.G., G.C.I.E., D.C.L.—Educated at Eton and Christ Church, Oxford; specially attached to Lord John Russell's Mission to Vienna in 1855; in 1860 was appointed British commissioner in Syria to enquire into the massacre of Christians, and for his services on this occasion was nominated a K.C.B.; under secretary of state for India, 1864-1866; under secretary for war, in 1866; Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, Dec., 1868, to April, 1872; governor-general of Canada, May, 1872, to Oct., 1873; ambassador at St. Petersburg, Feb., 1879; ambassador at Constantinople, May, 1881; from Nov., 1882 to April, 1883, he was engaged in Egypt in the settlement of the various questions, arising out of Arabi's rebellion; viceroy and governor-general of India, 13th Dec., 1884; left India to take up post of ambassador at Rome, Dec., 1888; K.P. in 1863; lord-lieutenant of the county of Down, 1864; privy councillor, Dec., 1868; earl of the United Kingdom, Nov., 1871, and Marquis, 1883, taking the style of Ava in addition to Dufferin by special command of Her Majesty; president of the Royal Geographical Society May, 1878; LL.D., Harvard University, June, 1878; LL.D., Dublin University, Jan., 1879; D.C.L. Oxford University, June, 1879; G.C.B., 1883; chancellor of the Royal University, Ireland, 1886; has published 'Narrative of a Journal from Oxford to Skibbereen during the year of the Irish Famine,' 1846-47; 'Letters from High Latitudes,' the result of a yacht voyage to Iceland in 1859; 'Irish Emigration and the Tenure of Land in Ireland'; 'Mr. Mill's plan for the Pacification of Ireland examined;' 'Contributions to an Enquiry into the State of Ireland;' is also the author of various works in light literature.

DUKE, CHARLES JOHN ASHETON, Burma Commission.—Arrived in India, 7th Feb., 1866; served in the Burma commission from March, 1867, as assistant commissioner; town magistrate, Akyab, July, 1876; superintendent of Arakan Hill Tracts, March, 1880; deputy commissioner, March, 1882.

DUKE, FREDERICK WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Arbroath High School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Hooghly, Dec., 1884; has also acted as magistrate and collector.

DUMERGUE, JOHN WILLOUGHBY FRANCIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant resident and acting resident in Travancore; Malayan translator to government, March, 1884; head assistant collector and magistrate, Nilgiris, Feb., 1885; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nov., 1886; acted as collector and magistrate, and district and sessions judge.

DUNCAN, DAVID, M.A., D.Sc. (Edinburgh), Education Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras education department from 20th May, 1870, as professor of logic and moral philosophy at the Presidency College, and was registrar of the Madras University from April, 1875, to March, 1879, and again 1881-86; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1877; 3rd class of the education department, April, 1886; principal and professor, Presidency College, from March, 1884; also acted for various periods as director of public instruction, and as commissioner for the unconv. civil service examinations; second class of the education department, Aug., 1885; 1st class, Dec., 1888.

DUNCAN, HARVEY TUCKETT, Major-General, C.S.I., late Madras S.C.—Ensign, 46th regt., N.I., Madras, June, 1848; was employed in the Mofussil police, 1860; inspector-general of police, British Burma, March, 1862; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1873; political resident, Mandalay, 1875 to 1878; retired from the army, Feb., 1880.

DUNLOP, ALEXANDER JOHNSTON, Berar Commission.—Appointed assistant to cotton commissioner, Central Provinces and Berar, 1st May, 1869, and assistant commissioner, Feb., 1876; from 1869-74, held charge in addition to other duties of a government experimental farm; served as officiating secretary for Berar to the resident, 1877-8, and as judge of small cause court, June, 1878; inspector-general revenue department, to Nizam's Government, April, 1885, and survey and settlement commissioner, Nizam's Government, April, 1887; deputy commissioner, Berar, July, 1889.

DUNLOP-SMITH, J. R., Lieut., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1879; admitted to the Bengal staff corps from March, 1882; from March, 1883, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; private secretary to the lieut.-governor of the Punjab, Dec., 1883-Nov., 1885; settlement collector, April, 1888.

DUPERNEX, HUBERT EMILE LEOCE PAUL, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at St. Paul's School and Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

DURAND, EDWARD LAW, C.B., Major, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 10 Oct., 1865; arrived in India, June, 1866; served with the 96th regiment, and was transferred to Bengal staff corps, Oct., 1868; A.D.C. and private secretary to lieut.-governor of the Punjab, June, 1870; from Feb., 1871, served in the foreign department under the Government of India in Rajputana and Central India; served as political agent of Manipur, and as first assistant on special
duty in foreign office; political agent, 3rd class, May, 1881; assistant commissioner, Afghan boundary commission, Oct., 1885; on special duty to England, Oct. to Dec., 1886; political agent, 2nd class, and resident sub. pro. tem., Nepal; author of report on 'Fars and Sketch Map of part of the Country.'

DURAND, Sir Henry Mortimer, K.C.I.E., C.S.I. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1873; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, March, 1873; on famine duty, Nov., 1873; from June, 1874, served in the foreign department of the government of India, and was appointed officiating 1st assistant to the governor-general's agent, Rajputana, July, 1876; officiating assistant secretary, foreign department, Nov., 1877; political assistant, 1st class, Dec., 1877; political secretary to major-general Sir F. Roberts with the Kabul field force, Sept., 1879 (medal and two clasps for Afghan campaign); under secretary, government of India, foreign department, March, 1880; C.S.I., Feb., 1881; officiating private secretary to the Viceroy, June, 1880; secretary to government of India, foreign department, Feb., 1883; is secretary of the orders of the Star of India, and of the Indian Empire; published a life of Sir H. Durand, 1883; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

DURRANT, William S., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at Whitgift, and Lycée St. Omer; junior clerk, India office, 18th Sept., 1879.

DUTHOIT, William, D.C.L., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; called to the bar at the Inner Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1857; served from Sept., 1858, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed deputy superintendent, family domains, Maháraja of Benares, May, 1862; officiating inspector-general of registration and commissioner of excise and stamps, March, 1875; magistrate and collector, Shahjahanpur, April, 1877; on special duty under the government of India, financial department, Dec., 1879; on special duty under the orders of the high court, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1881; officiating puisne judge, high court, June, 1881; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Aug., 1881; officiating judicial commissioner, Oudh, May, 1882; employed on the opium commission, under government of Bengal, March to Oct., 1883; judicial commissioner of Oudh, March, 1884; retired, Aug., 1886.

DYSON, John, Oudh Commission.—Joined the service, 8th June, 1858, as deputy magistrate and deputy collector in Bengal; from Dec., 1861, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; officiating city magistrate of Lucknow, Sept., 1866; also officiating superintendent of excise and stamps, Aug.-Oct., 1867; small cause court judge, Lucknow, 1869; on special duty on committee for compiling the laws and regulations in force in Oudh previous to 1861, Jan., 1870; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Sitapur, April, 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1886; officiating commissioner, Fyzabad, Sept., 1886; officiating judicial commissioner, Oudh, Aug., 1889.

EADES, F. T., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Jan., 1875.

EALES, Charles Lindstedt Modellier, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1878, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating cantonment magistrate, Fyzabad, March-Aug., 1885; joint magistrate, Nov., 1887.

EALES, Herbert Lovely, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dulwich College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1879; served in British Burma as assistant commissioner; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1885; deputy commissioner, May, 1888; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1890.

EARLE, Archdale, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Uppingham, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; officiating private secretary to the lieutenant-governor, Feb., 1886; under secretary to Government of Bengal, judicial, political and appointment departments, Feb., 1886.

EAST, William Albert, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived 26th Nov., 1863, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant registrar, and deputy registrar and sealer of the high court, assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; superintendent of Panchgani, Nov., 1876; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Dhárwar, June, 1881; senior collector, June, 1885.

EBDEN, Edward James, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Queen Elizabeth's School, Ipswich, and Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Sept., 1872, served in the forest department as acting deputy conservator in the Kanara district; employed on famine duty, Dharwar, April, 1877, and in Mysore, Oct., 1877, to July, 1878; from July, 1878, served as assistant collector, railway magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector and magistrate, Aug., 1881; junior collector, magistrate, June, 1888; acting senior collector, April, 1889.

EDGAR, Sir John Ware, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; assistant magistrate and collector July, 1863; served in Cachar from Dec., 1863, as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; on special duty with the Lushai expeditionary force, Oct., 1871; officiating junior secretary to the government of Bengal, June, 1872; magistrate and collector, Shahabad, Feb., 1878; officiated as commissioner in various divisions in Bengal, 1880-83; 1st grade magistrate and collector,
Nov., 1831; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointment departments, Sept., 1834, and subsequently in the financial department, May, 1835; commissioner of Chittagong, Dec., 1835; chief secretary to government of Bengal, Aug., 1837; K.C.I.E., May, 1839.

EDGE, Sir John, Knt., O.C., B.A., LL.B., Trinity College, Dublin. Called to the bar, Middle Temple, 1856; Q.C., 1856; went the northern and north-eastern circuit, and was appointed chief justice, high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1866; vice-chancellor, Allahabad University, Nov., 1887.

EDGELL, W., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley; writer, India office, 31st July, 1869; temporarily employed as shipping inspector of railway stores, Jan., 1872; receiver of wharf stores, Jan., 1873; supervisor, 2nd grade, March, 1877; 1st grade, June, 1886.

EDGERLEY, Steynning William, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and officiating cantonment magistrate; from May, 1881, served in Sind as acting deputy collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration, and acting Sindi translator to government; 2nd assistant collector in Sind, 1885 and 1886; under secretary to Government of India, home department, Oct., 1888; private secretary to the Governor of Bombay, March, 1889; officiating under Secretary to Government of India, foreign department, April, 1889.

EDIS, Frederick, late Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; writer, India Office, 29th July, 1872; clerk under the inspector-general of railway stores, March, 1877; retired, Dec., 1889.

EDMONSTONE-MONTGOMERIE, Charles Waterlow, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Copenhagen and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1835; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1837, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

EDWARDS, A. C., B.A., Bengal Educational Service.—Arrived in India, 23rd Sept., 1878, and served as professor in the presidency college, and principal, Rajshahiye College, and afterwards of the Dacca College; class 3 of educational service, Jan., 1889.

EDWARDS, Herbert, India Office Stores Department.—2nd class clerk, March, 1887.

EDWARDS, William, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1837; assistant commissioner, Cuttack, 1838; assistant registrar, Sudder court, Calcutta, 1839; deputy secretary to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, 1840; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor, 1842, and assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces in all departments, and in attendance on the governor-general; under secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1843, and attended the governor-general in his tour to the N.W. Provinces; superintendent of the Hill states, and magistrate and collector, Simla, 1848; civil and sessions judge, Futtahpore, 1858; judge, Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlat, N.W. Provinces 1862; judge, high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, 1866; retired 1867; author of a book of Indian treaties (reprinted by order of the House of Lords, 1853), and of several other works relating to India.

EGERTON, Sir Robert Eyles, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy, and Exeter College, Oxford, and appointed to the Bengal civil service from the East India College, Haileybury, in 1850; served in the Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed to the charge of the settlement of the Lahore district, 1854-55; deputy commissioner, 1856; officiating commissioner, Lahore, 1863; additional commissioner, Peshawur, Nov., 1863, to Feb., 1864; commissioner, Nagpur, Central Provinces, March, 1864; officiated as judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, at various times from 1865 to 1867; financial commissioner of the Punjab, March, 1868; additional member, governor-general's council, July, 1871, and again in 1872 and 1877; lieutenant-governor of the Punjab, April, 1877, to April, 1882, when he resigned the service.

ELIAS, Ney, C.I.E., Political Department.—Extra attache, foreign department, March-Sept. 1874; second in command, Yunnan expedition, and assistant to resident in Mandalay, Sept., 1874, to May, 1875; officiating political agent, Bhamo, April-Aug., 1875, in addition to other duties; extra attache, foreign department, Oct., 1875; from Oct., 1877, has served as joint commissioner of Ladakh; political assistant, 1st class (supernumerary), June, 1879; on special duty to Yarkand, June-Aug., 1879; on special duty to Kashgar, March-Aug., 1880; political agent with the Kashgar Mission, May, 1885; political agent, 3rd class, March, 1886; C.I.E., Jan., 1888; on special duty in foreign department in 1889 and 1890.

ELIOT, John, M.A., Educational Department, Bengal.—Joined the service, June, 1859; from 27th Dec., 1869, to Feb., 1876, served in the N.W. Provinces as professor of mathematics, Thomason College, and also at Muir College; superintendent of the Meteorological Observatory, Allahabad, and meteorological reporter to government; from Feb., 1876, served in Bengal, as professor, Presidency College, and meteorological reporter, also as officiating meteorological reporter to government of India, April, 1878, and Dec., 1881; 2nd class, Bengal education department, March, 1881; officiating principal, Presidency College, and registrar of Calcutta University, Jan., 1883; appointed meteorological reporter to Government of India, May, 1889.

ELLENOR, T. R., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

ELLERCAMP, H. McD., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 16th Oct., 1879.

ELLIOT, Algernon, Berar Commission.—From 23 Jan., 1869, served in the police department of the Central Provinces, and as assistant commissioner, Berar; deputy commissioner, April, 1889.

ELLIOT, Frederick Augustus Hugh, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served
as assistant collector and magistrate; from June, 1873, to Nov., 1875, served in Berar as educational inspector, and acting director of public instruction; principal of the Raja's school, and tutor and governor of the Gaekwar, Baroda, Dec., 1875; on special duty, Baroda, April, 1882; on duty in England, in connexion with H.H. the Gaekwar of Baroda, 1887.

ELLIOT, FREDERICK EDEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, 16th March, 1858; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Hamirpur, April, 1877, and civil and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1881; 1st grade, Jan., 1887.

ELLIOTT, SIR CHARLES ALFRED, LL.B., K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1856, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from April, 1858, to May, 1861, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner, and from Feb., 1863, to Oct., 1866, in the Central Provinces as settlement officer, Hoshangabad; served subsequently as settlement officer, Farakhabad, and as secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, 1870-1877; commissioner, Meerut, Oct., 1877; famine commissioner, Mysore, Sept., 1877; additional secretary to government of India, famine branch, May, 1878; secretary to famine commission, June, 1878; census commissioner, Oct., 1880; chief commissioner of Assam, March, 1881; president of the committee for the retrenchment of public expenditure, Feb., 1886; K.C.S.I., Feb., 1887; ordinary member of governor-general's council, Jan., 1888; appointed Lieutenant-Governor of Bengal, Oct., 1890; author of 'Chronicles of Unao' and of the Famine Commission Report, 1879, and the Finance Commission Report, 1887.

ELLISON, THOMAS EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at St. Andrew's College, Bradford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 19th Oct., 1864; assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Delhi, Aug., 1865; transferred to Central Provinces, Oct., 1868; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Oct., 1881; judge, small cause court, Nagpur, Sept., 1883; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Bilaspur, Nov., 1884; 3rd class, Sept., 1889.

ELPHINSTON, JOHN, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 5th Feb., 1855, and served in Bombay and Sind as assistant collector and magistrate, deputy collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and collector and magistrate (Jan., 1873); senior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, Oct., 1876; collector and magistrate and political agent, Kolaba, Sept., 1880; retired, Nov., 1886.

ELPHINSTONE, GRAHAM WARBURTON, Madras C.S.—Educated at Eton and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 10th Nov., 1887, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

ELSMIE, GEORGE ROBERT (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1858, and was appointed assistant commissioner, Punjab; officiating judge small cause court, Lahore, Nov., 1863; on special duty at Lahore, July, 1867; officiating under secretary to government of India, Oct., 1868; deputy commissioner, May, 1870; from 1871 to 1877 officiated as additional commissioner of Jullundur and Amritsar, and of Peshawur; civil and session judge, March, 1877; officiating judge, chief court, 1878-79; commissioner and superintendent, Lahore, Nov., 1880; judge, chief court, Punjab, Jan., 1882, to Feb., 1886; commissioner and superintendent, Lahore, Feb., 1886; 2nd financial commissioner, May, 1887; additional member of governor-general's council, May, 1888, which office he resigned, Dec., 1888; first financial commissioner, March, 1889; on special duty at Rawal Pindi Durbar, March, 1889; author of 'Notes on Peshawur Crime.'

ELWIN, EDGAR ALFRED, Madras C.S.—Educated at Dover College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1883, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; manager Jeypore estate, June, 1890.

ENTHOVEN, REGINALD EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Wellington College and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1889, and served in Bombay as assistant magistrate and collector.

ERSKINE, CHARLES ELLIS HAY.—Burma 1st commission Lieutenant, 7th Feb., 1855; appointed cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Mandalay, June, 1860.

ERSKINE, CLAUDIUS JAMES, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1840; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge; private secretary to governor of Bombay, 1844; oriental translator to government, 1847; also deputy secretary to government of Bombay, Persian department, 1847; secretary to government of Bombay in the general and judicial departments, 1854; civil auditor, 1854; director of public instruction, 1855; senior assistant judge and sessions judge, Konkan, 1857; judge and sessions judge, Konkan, 1859; member of legislative council of India, 1860; also puisne judge of court of Sudder Dewani, Bombay, 1862; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, 1863; member of council, Bombay, 31st Oct., 1865; retired in 1867.

ERSKINE, GEORGE ELPHINSTONE, Colonel, North-Western Provinces (Oudh).—Arrived in India as cornet, Bombay light cavalry, 9th Dec., 1857; was employed under the military department including service with the Rajputana field force, till Feb., 1863, when he joined the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner; from May, 1865, to July, 1871, served as assistant settlement officer, and acting settlement officer; also officiated as personal assistant to financial commissioner in 1867-69, and as superintendent of excise and stamps in 1868-69; personal assistant to chief commissioner, Oudh, July, 1871, to April, 1878; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, May to Aug., 1879; secretary to
government of N.W. Provinces, in forest branch, and Oudh revenue department, 7th April, 1878; commissioner, Sitapur division, Jan., 1882; Lucknow division, March, 1883, and Kumaun division, Jan., 1890; on special duty to inquire into condition of tenantry in Oudh, Dec., 1882, to May, 1883.

ERSKINE, HENRY NAPIER BRUCE, C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 23rd Sept., 1853, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, special officer for income tax, assistant-commissioner and acting educational inspector in Sind, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; collector and magistrate, Nasik, July, 1866; acting revenue and police commissioner, northern division, June, 1877; from June, 1879, acted as commissioner in Sind, and was confirmed in this appointment, Oct., 1882; on special duty at Bombay, Dec., 1880; 1st grade commissioner, July, 1881; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired, Aug., 1888.

ETESON, A., M.D., Deputy Surgeon-General, late Medical Department, Assam.—Joined the Indian medical department as assistant surgeon, May, 1854; arrived in India, 30th June, 1854; held various military medical charges, and was promoted to surgeon-major, May 1874; medal for services during the mutiny; secretary to surgeon-general, Indian medical department, March, 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Eastern frontier district, and sanitary commissioner, Assam, Jan., 1884; retired, Jan., 1889.

EUAN-SMITH, SIR CHARLES BEAN, Colonel, K.C.B., C.S.I.—Ensign, Madras infantry, March, 1859; arrived in India, June, 1859; served in Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68, and was present at capture of Magdala (medal); secretary to Sir F. Goldsmid's mission to Persia, Aug., 1870, to Nov., 1872; C.S.I., Nov., 1872; private secretary to Sir Bartle Frere, on special mission to Zanzibar and Muscat, Nov., 1872, to July, 1873; on special duty in India office, 1873-74; political agent and consul-general, Zanzibar, May, 1875; on special duty, foreign department on occasion of Prince of Wales' visit to Calcutta, 1875; first assistant resident, Hyderabad, March, 1876; political agent, and consul-general, Muscat, July, 1879; during the Afghan War, 1879-80, was on special political duty on the staff of Lieutenant-General Sir D. Stewart, and subsequently with General Hill's division, May, 1880, and with the Kabul-Kandahar force under General Roberts, Aug., 1880; medal with two clasps, bronze star, brevet of lieutenant-colonel; acted as resident, Meywar, in 1882 and 1884; assistant political agent, Banswara, Dec., 1882; from May, 1883, served as additional political agent, Bhurtpur and Karauli; appointed consul-general at Zanzibar, 1888; K.C.B., Nov., 1890.

EVANS, HENRY FARRINGTON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from May, 1870, to Sept., 1879, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Sept., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1880; officiating district and sessions judge, July, 1881; special judge, Jhansi, July, 1882; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Oct., 1882; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1887.

EVANS, LOFTUS GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner, district judge, &c.; joint magistrate, Sept., 1886.

EVANS-GORDON, WILLIAM EDEN, Captain, Madras S.C., Political Department of Government of India.—1st commission, 15th July, 1876; admitted to Madras staff corps, 3rd July, 1877; from Feb., 1883, served under the foreign department of the government of India with the Central India horse; boundary settlement officer Central India, Oct., 1883, to March, 1884; and from the latter date served as officiating political assistant; attached foreign department Government of India, Oct., 1883; officiating translator of foreign European languages in addition to other duties, Dec., 1883; assistant secretary foreign department, 1887; appointed political officer in charge of Sardar Ayub Khan, 1883.

EVERETT, STEPHEN H. Audit Department, India Office.—Educated at Dulwich College; writer, India office, May, 1872; junior examiner, audit department, Dec., 1873.

EVERS, BENJAMIN, M.D., C.M., Medical Department (Central Provinces).—Joined service, April, 1863; arrived in India, 27th Oct., 1863; served with the 18th and 11th Native Infantry; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, April, 1876; surgeon-major, April, 1880.

EWART, CHARLES HENRY, Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 26th Feb., 1857; arrived in India, 2nd April, 1857; from Feb., 1861, served in the police department, Punjab, as district superintendent, and was promoted to deputy inspector-general, 2nd grade, May, 1881, 1st grade, March, 1883.

EWBANK, ALFRED LLOYD VANDYKE, M.A., Educational Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 16th Jan., 1868; arrived, 28th Feb., 1868; served as professor, Patna College, and as officiating inspector of schools; principal, Dacca College, March, 1876; 2nd class, education department, Aug., 1878; professor, Patna College, Oct., 1879; principal, Patna College, Oct., 1881.

EYRE, GERVAS SELWYN, Major, B.S.C. (Burma), 1st commission, 12th June, 1869; served in military department until July, 1879, when he was appointed assistant commissioner in Burma; with the Burma Field force, Nov., 1887; on special duty with the force operating against the Chins, May, 1888; deputy commissioner, May, 1888; Royal Humane Society's medal for saving lives of two brother officers.

FAGAN, PATRICK JAMES, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1886, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

FAICHNIE, A. G., Post Office Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the post office department, Jan., 1858; served for some time as superintendent of the Rawal Pindi military horse van, and bullock train; deputy post-
master-general, Central Provinces and Berar, 8th Nov., 1879.

FAIRRIE, J. S., Registry Department, India office.—Educated at Clapham Grammar School, and King's College, London; writer, India Office, 1st Jan., 1859; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

FAIRWEATHER, JAMES, M.D., Deputy Surgeon-General, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 20th March, 1856; in civil charge of Rawal Pindi and its jail, April, 1866; civil surgeon at Gurdaspur, April, 1874, and subsequently at various other stations in the Punjab; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; officiated as sanitary commissioner in 1878, 1879, and 1883; officiating surgeon-general, Punjab, April, 1885; officiating inspector-general of prisons, July, 1886; acted as medical adviser to His Highness the Maharaja of Patiala in 1884, 1885, and 1886; retired, 1886; has contributed papers on professional subjects to the 'Indian Medical Journal' and the 'Lancet.'

FANSHAWE, ARTHUR UPTON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, Nov., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, and acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, July, 1880, and acted as secretary in 1880 and 1881; in charge of model farm, Nagpur, July, 1880, to Jan., 1881; from April, 1881, served in the postal department as officiating postmaster-general, Bombay, and was confirmed in this appointment, March, 1882; also officiated as director-general of the post office of India, Aug., 1884, postmaster-general, 1st grade, Feb., 1883; director general of the post office of India.

FANSHAWE, HERBERT CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Bedford, Tonbridge, and Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1873, and was appointed assistant commissioner in the Punjab; served temporarily in Bengal on famine duty Feb.-Nov., 1874; officiating settlement officer, Rohtak, Aug., 1875, to Feb., 1876, and again in 1877; under secretary to government, revenue department, Punjab, March, 1879; assistant to the officer on special duty in Kashmir, June, 1879; officiating junior secretary to government, Oct. to Dec., 1882, and again in 1883 and 1884; officiating secretary to government, Jan., to April, 1884; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1885, 1st grade, Sept., 1887; officiating junior secretary to government, Punjab, Dec., 1887, confirmed, Nov., 1888; revenue secretary to government of Punjab, March, 1890; officiated in 1890 as chief secretary.

FARMER, HENRY RICHARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at Loughborough, Bromsgrove, and Uppingham Grammar Schools; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1868, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; acted as Tamil translator to government, Feb., 1880, to Sept., 1881; on special duty completing treatise on Madras Act viii. of 1865, July, 1882; acting district and sessions judge, Kurnool, Oct., 1886; confirmed, Dec., 1887.

FARQUHAR, WILLIAM, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., late Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 28th May, 1858; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1858, and served under the military department in Madras, Burma, and the Straits Settlements; also held civil medical charge, Toungoo, in 1859; medical officer, Ootacamund, from Nov., 1882; promoted to brigade surgeon, April, 1885; deputy surgeon-general, Belgaum and Western Districts, July, 1885; retired, July, 1890.

FARRAN, C. F., B.A. Barrister-at-Law, late Judicial Department, Bombay.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin. Served as reporter, high court, Bombay, 1868-1874, also as acting government professor of law, April, 1868, to June, 1870, and Perry professor of jurisprudence, June, 1870, to Jan., 1872; acted as clerk of the crown, Sept., 1874, to Sept., 1876, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1880; acting advocate general, Bombay, May-Dec., 1884; additional judge of the high court, Bombay, Nov., 1885.

FARRAN, G. H., M.A. (Dublin), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 17th May, 1866, as head assistant in the prothonotary's office, high court, Bombay, acting prothonotary, ecclesiastical and admiralty registrar, acting official assignee of the insolvent debtors' court, and acting clerk and sealer of the insolvent debtors' court; deputy registrar, commissioner for taking affidavits, and judge's clerk, Nov., 1873; assistant commissioner for taking accounts and assistant taxing master, July, 1876; also acted as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts, and taxing officer.

FARRELL, G., Deputy Surgeon-General, C.B., Punjab Medical Department.—Joined the service as assistant-surgeon, 4 Aug., 1856; deputy surgeon-general, Sept., 1886; appointed officiating inspector-general to civil hospitals, Punjab, Nov., 1883, and was confirmed in the appointment, March, 1889.

FARRER, HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Heversham Grammar School, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1875; served in revenue and judicial department as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; postmaster-general, Madras, June, 1886.

FASSON, HERBERT JOHN HAMILTON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the High School, Quebec, and Bray College, Wicklow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on famine relief duty at Dinagapore, March, 1874; assistant settlement officer, Chittagong, June, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1885.

FAULDER, CECIL JOSEPH SALKELD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1876; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy
collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Dec., 1887, 1st grade, Aug., 1889.

FAWCETT, GEORGE WILLIAM, Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown School, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1874, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, deputy commissioner of salt revenue, forest settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate; head assistant collector and magistrate, Malabar, July, 1883; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nov., 1883; district and sessions Judge, Feb., 1890.

FAYRER, SIR JOSEPH, Surgeon-General, K.C.S.I., LL.D., M.D., F.R.S.S. (London and Edinburgh), F.R.C.P., F.R.C.S., Medical Board, India Office.—Acting assistant surgeon, R.N., Aug., 1847; assistant surgeon, royal artillery, 1849; joined the East India Company's service April, 1850, and served under the military department, also holding civil surgeoncy of Cheera Poonjee, Nov., 1850; served in the Burma campaign, and officiated as civil surgeon, Rangoon, Feb., 1853; appointed residency surgeon, Lucknow, by Lord Dalhousie, for services during war in Burma; honorary assistant resident at Lucknow, Sept., 1854; civil surgeon, Lucknow, March, 1856; brevet rank of surgeon for services in defence of Lucknow residency during the siege, Sept., 1858; officiating professor of surgery and ex-officio 1st surgeon of Medical College Hospital, Calcutta, May, 1859; confirmed in these appointments, June, 1860; medical charge of Mysore princes, June, 1860; fellow of University of Calcutta and member of the senate, March, 1861; served for two years as president of the medical faculty, and received the public thanks of the faculty; surgeon, July, 1863; consulting surgeon to Howrah General Hospital Nov., 1865; president of the Asiatic Society; Bengal, 1867; J.P. for Calcutta, Feb., 1868; government trustee for India Museum, 1866; officiating surgeon to viceroy, Jan.-Feb., 1866; accompanied H.R.H. the Duke of Edinburgh in his tour through India, Jan.-March, 1870; surgeon-major, June, 1870; honorary physician to the Queen, July, 1871; accompanied H.R.H. the Prince of Wales to India, 1875-76, in medical charge of his party; retired, 1874; president of medical board, India Office, Dec., 1874; member of army sanitary commission; member of senate of Army Medical School at Netley; consulting physician to Charing Cross Hospital; author of 'Clinical Surgery in India,' 'Clinical and Pathological Observations in India,' 'Thanatophobia of India' (presented to the Indian government, by whom it was published in 1872), and other works; has also published numerous papers, monographs, and addresses, on medical and scientific subjects.

FENNER, HENRY ALGERNON SHRAPNEL, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed 2nd assistant engineer, 20th June, 1861; 1st assistant engineer, April, 1865; executive engineer, Sept., 1868; superintending engineer, May, 1886.

FENTON MICHAEL WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1883, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Nov.-Dec., 1885; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, revenue department, April, 1887; confirmed as under secretary, Oct., 1887.

FENTON, T. C., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 22nd May, 1873; attached to the store department till Aug., 1879, and subsequently to the registry department.

FERARD, HENRY CECIL, Bengal C.S. (North Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1885, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

FERET, C. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Jan., 1875.

FERGUSON, HENRY TANNER, late Railway Department, Government of India.—Joined public works department as locomotive superintendent, Rangoon and Irrawaddy Valley Railway, Oct., 1870; Punjab Northern State Railway, Aug., 1881; class i, state railway, revenue establishment, Jan., 1886; deputy locomotive superintendent, North-Western Railway, Jan., 1886; deputy locomotive superintendent, Eastern Bengal Railway, Oct., 1887; officiating locomotive superintendent, Feb., 1888; retired, 1888.

FERGUSSON, Rt. Hon. Sir James, Bart., G.C.S.I., K.C.M.G., C.I.E., M.P.—Born in 1832; educated at Rugby, and University College, Oxford; entered the Grenadier Guards, and served in the Crimean campaign, 1854-55 (medal and three clasps); retired from the army in 1855; represented the county of Ayr in parliament in the Conservative interest from Dec., 1854, to April, 1857, and from Oct., 1859 to 1868; under secretary of state for India, June, 1866, to July, 1867; under secretary for the home department, July, 1867, to Aug., 1868; governor of South Australia, Aug., 1868; governor of New Zealand, March, 1873-1874; governor of Bombay, April, 1880, to March, 1885; parliamentary under secretary of state, foreign office, Aug., 1886; royal commissioner for the Adelaide Exhibition of 1887.

FERRAR, MICHAEL LLOYD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Belfast Academical Institution, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1863; from Jan., 1864, to Sept., 1865, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Oudh, Sept., 1865, and served as assistant commissioner; from July, 1868, to April, 1875, served in the settlement department, and was appointed to take up lands for railway purposes in Lucknow, Aug., 1870; officiating commissioner, Fyzabad, in 1882 and 1883; and 1889; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1883; magistrate and collector, Etah, March, 1884.

FFINCH, BENJAMIN TRAILL, Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the Indo-European telegraph department, 5th Nov., 1857; deputy director of the Persian Gulf section, from April, 1875; director Persian Gulf, March, 1884; also acted as assistant political agent, Gwadar, Aug., 1879, and as political agent, Aug., 1884; employed in connection with renewals of Persian Gulf telegraph cables, 1890.
FIDDIAN, James Paul, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Birmingham Grammar School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Bellary, Dec., 1884; also acted as collector and magistrate, and district and sessions judge; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1889.

FIDDIAN, William, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Huddersfield College, Shrewsbury Grammar School, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal; on famine duty, May, 1874; officiating commissioner, Soonderbunds, Jan. 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1881; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, April, 1886; 2nd grade, March, 1883.

FIELD, Charles Dickenson, M.A., LL.D. (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1860; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating judge of the principal court of small causes, Kishnagurh and Jessore, officiating magistrate and collector, and registrar, high court (July, 1867); from Dec., 1870, served in the judicial department, and was placed on special duty in connection with a commission to consider the question of amending the rent law of Bengal, May, 1870; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1879; lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1879; judge, high court, Oct., 1880; retired, Sept., 1886; author of 'Rent Law Procedure in Bengal,' 'Essays on Indian Topics,' 'Chronological Table of, and Index to, the Indian Statute Book,' 'The Law of Evidence in British India,' 'The Law relating to Protestant Curates,' 'The Regulations of the Bengal Code,' 'A Digest of the Law of Landlord and Tenant in Bengal,' and 'Landholding and the Relation of Landlord and Tenant in various Countries.'

FIELD, George A., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; supernumerary writer, 30th May, 1859; copying clerk, Sept., 1860; assistant to registrar, March, 1882.

FILGATE, Alexander Jerome, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—First commission, 1857; served in the China war, 1860 (medal and clasps); joined the Madras public works department, Oct., 1863, as assistant engineer, South Canara; deputy controller public works accounts, July, 1865; deputy consulting engineer for railways, and examiner of accounts, Feb., 1866; from March, 1867, served in the public works department of the Government of India, as assistant accountant-general; deputy accountant-general, and ex-officio under secretary to government, March, 1872; officiating accountant-general and deputy secretary to government of India, March, 1879, to Nov. 1886; confirmed as accountant-general, and deputy secretary, Sept., 1881; member of finance committee, April, 1886, to March, 1887; retired, Nov., 1890.

FILGATE, Townley P. H. Macartney, Registration Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 1st March, 1867, and served as military secretary to governor of Bombay, and registrar-general of assurances, Bombay Presidency (from Aug., 1870); from July, 1871, served as inspector-general of registration; on special duty, Nov.-Dec., 1876, engaged in selecting prisoners for release from the jails of the Bombay Presidency on the occasion of the proclamation of the Empress of India, 1st Jan., 1877; on special duty, Dec., 1879, as member of the committee on the registration law, at Calcutta; acting inspector-general of prisons, Dec., 1886; confirmed as such in addition to his other duties, April, 1887; registrar-general of births, deaths, and marriages, Bombay, Sept., 1888.

FINCH, C. T., Accounts Department, India Office, Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

FINK, W. R., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Assistant to the taxing officer and registrar, high court Calcutta, 1878; chief clerk, high court of judicature, 1885; 1st assistant or deputy registrar.

FINLAY, Herbert Blakey, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, Dec. 1865; from May, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Oct., 1873, to April, 1880, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Banda, July, 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1880; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, July, 1885; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1885; officiated as commissioner of division in 1887.

FINLAY, James Fairbairn, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy and University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; on special duty in the public works department, Oct., 1880; transferred to finance department of government of India, May, 1881, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, as officiating assistant accountant-general and officiating deputy accountant-general; assistant comptroller-general in 4th class of financial department, July, 1882; under secretary to government of India, financial department; officiated also as secretary to government of India, financial department; and again, Sept.-Nov., 1886; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, June, 1886, deputy auditor-general, Nov., 1887; and accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Dec., 1887; deputy secretary to Government of India, financial department, 1889.

FINNEY, Stephen, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as assistant engineer, Oct., 1874; served in various divisions, and as personal assistant engineer-in-chief's office; assistant manager, Northern Bengal State railway, May, 1881; and deputy manager Eastern Bengal State railway in class I, grade 3, July, 1889.

FINUCANE, Michael, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Munchin's College, Limerick,
Limerick Collegiate Academy, and Queen's College, Cork; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1872; manager, Raj Durbhunga, Sept., 1879; settlement officer, Jan., 1880; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointment departments, Jan., 1882; on special duty, Midnapore, May, 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1884; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, and director of the agricultural department in Bengal, Dec., 1884; member, central examination committee, April, 1886; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1888; edited Bengal Tenancy Act viii. of 1885.

FIREBRACE, FREDERICK, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, Dec., 1861; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces, May, 1865; assistant principal Roorkee College, 1865-68; officiating assistant consulting engineer for railways, Bengal, May, 1868; manager, Calcutta and S.E. Railway, Feb., 1870; executive engineer, Sept., 1870; Neemuch railway survey, Feb., 1871; assistant director of state railways, March, 1875; manager, Rajputana state railway, Nov., 1876; 1st class, state railway revenue establishment, April, 1877; on duty at the Royal Engineering College, Cooper's Hall, Sept., 1878, to Nov., 1879; under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Jan., 1880; superintending engineer, 2nd class, July, 1883; consulting engineer and joint secretary, Bombay, Feb., 1887; 2nd superintending engineer, 2nd class, sub pro tem., May, 1888; 1st class (permanent), March, 1889; author of a "Manual of Surveying."

FISCHER, FRANCIS NORTON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1889, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

FISHER, CECIL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887.

FISHER, FREDERICK HENRY, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Boston Grammar School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent and small cause judge of Dehra Dun, March, 1879; officiating civil and sessions judge, Saharanpur, Oct., 1881; on special duty in connection with the preparation of the 'Provincial Gazetteer,' Dec., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1885; retired, Aug., 1885.

FISHER, JOHN HADDEN, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1861; from June, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating small cause court judge; from Jan., 1872, to April, 1879, served in the Central Provinces as deputy commissioner; from April, 1879, served in the N.W. Provinces as joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade; magistrate and collector, April, 1880; retired, July, 1890.

FISHER, WILLIAM ROGERS, B.A., Forest Department, N.W. Provinces.—Appointed assistant conservator, 28th Sept., 1872; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1872; deputy director of forest school, Dehra Dun, April, 1881, and Feb., 1884; conservator and director of the school, March, 1885; conservator of the 3rd grade, Dec., 1888.

FITZGERALD, EDWARD AMBROSE, Brigade Surgeon, late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th July, 1859; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1860, and was employed under the military department, 1860-63; from Feb., 1868, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail, Jaunpur; rank of surgeon, July, 1871; surgeon-major, July, 1873; served subsequently as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at various stations in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh; brigade surgeon, Dec., 1887; retired, March, 1890.

FITZGERALD, SIR GERALD, K.C.M.G., Admiralty, late Financial Department of the Government of India.—Educated at St. Mary's College, Galway, and in France; appointed to the late ordnance office, Aug., 1855; junior clerk, war office, Jan., 1856; was estimate clerk, war office, 1861-1863; assistant commissioner for the investigation of the system of accounts in the public works department, India, Sept., 1863; officiating deputy comptroller-general of military expenditure, March, 1864; transferred to the financial department, India, Feb., 1868; personal assistant to financial member, governor-general's council, July, 1869; assistant comptroller-general, Aug., 1869; officiating deputy comptroller-general, Sept., 1870; deputy accountant-general, Madras, April, 1871; in charge of the office of accountant-general, British Burmah, Dec., 1871; officiating deputy comptroller-general, March, 1872; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Aug., 1872; and deputy comptroller-general, Nov., 1876; allowed to accept temporary service under the Egyptian government, Jan., 1877, and appointed director-general of accounts in Egypt, Dec., 1878, and member of the committee of finance, 13th March, 1884; accountant-general of the navy, 1st June, 1885, and deputy and assistant to the parliamentary and financial secretary, by order in council of 18th Nov., 1885; was attached to the intelligence department for the military operations at Alexandria in 1882; commissioner of the royal patriotic fund; member of the pensions commutation board; C.M.G., 1880, and K.C.M.G. in 1885; 3rd class of the order of Osmanieh, 1880; 2nd class of the order of the Medjidie, 1884; grand cordon of the order of the Medjidie, 1885; war medal and Egyptian bronze star for service in the Egyptian campaign, 1882.

FITZGERALD, JAMES, Colonel, B.S.C., late Berar Commission.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, June, 1856; arrived in India, Sept., 1859; was employed under the military department up to 1862, including service in the mutiny, 1857-59; and was present at the siege and capture of Delhi (medal and clasp); served in the China
war, 1860, and was present at the capture of Pekin (medal and two clasps); from Aug., 1862, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, railway magistrate, and deputy commissioner; retired, April, 1889.

FITZGERALD, JAMES RICHARD, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Uppingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Aug., 1875, served under the foreign department, government of India, as assistant general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti department, and assistant to resident, Hyderabad; on special duty in connection with control of Moghias, Jan., 1878; political assistant, 1st class, March, 1878; officiating 1st assistant and secretary for Berar to resident, Hyderabad, March, 1882; held charge of the office of resident, May, 1882; from July, 1882, served in Ajmere, as assistant commissioner, and acted as commissioner, Aug.–Oct., 1882; magistrate of the district of Ajmere, Oct., 1882; first assistant, governor-general's agent, Biluchistan, May, 1883; political agent, 3rd class, Oct., 1883; held charge of the agent's office in 1883–84, and of the Kalat Political Agency, Nov.–Dec., 1884; from April, 1885, acted as 1st assistant and secretary for Berar, Hyderabad; retired, 1888.

FITZGERALD, Sir W. GERALD SEYMOUR VESEY, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., India Office.—Educated at Harrow, and Oriel College, Oxford; called to the bar (Lincoln's Inn, 1865); private secretary to governor of Bombay, 1867–72; political aide-de-camp to the secretary of state for India, 14th Aug., 1874; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; K.C.I.E., Aug., 1887.

FITZMAURICE, JOHN DAY STOKES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, Jan., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1884; forest settlement officer, May, 1886; acting assistant judge and sessions judge, July, 1887.

FITZPATRICK, Sir Dennis, K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and small cause court judge, and was placed on special duty in England in connection with Begum Sumroo's case, March, 1869, and at Calcutta in the legislative department of government of India, May, 1873; deputy secretary to the government of India in the legislative department, 1874; secretary in the legislative department from 1877 to 1885; was also secretary to the governor-general's council; acted as judge of the chief court, Punjab, in 1876–77 and as secretary to government of India, home department, Jan.–April, 1885; acting chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1885; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; member of the public service commission, 1887, and acting resident in Mysore; chief commissioner of Assam, Sept., 1887; resident at Hyderabad, Aug., 1889; K.C.S.I., May, 1890.

FLEET, JOHN FAITHFULL, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, educational inspector, acting assistant political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector, Dec., 1873; on special duty in England, Jan.–May, 1879, and again in 1884 and 1885; epigraphist to the government of India, Jan., 1883; junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Sholapur, June, 1886; senior collector, Nov., 1889.

FLEMING, ALLAN STOPFORD, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Harrow, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1882, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner; officiated as deputy commissioner for various periods; officiating under secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1883.

FLETCHER, WILLIAM MORRIS, Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India 2nd June, 1865, and served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant superintendent of revenue survey, acting assistant settlement officer, and acting deputy superintendent of survey; on special duty in connection with the famine, Nov., 1876; superintendent of survey, Sept., 1879.

FOORD, EDWARD ARCHIBALD, Lieutenant-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—Second lieutenant, Madras Engineers, 9th Dec., 1842; arrived in India, July, 1844; assistant civil engineer, Oct., 1846; adjutant of engineers, 1850–52; assistant to secretary board of revenue, public works department, Madras, Aug., 1852; served as 1st class district engineer in South Arcot and Tanjore, Dec., 1856, to May, 1863; superintending engineer, Tanjore and Trichinopoly, May, 1863; inspecting engineer for civil and military buildings, Madras, Dec., 1872; superintending engineer, Kistna and Nellore, June, 1874; deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government of Madras, Dec., 1875; chief engineer, 2nd class, and joint secretary to government, buildings and roads branch, Feb., 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government, public works department, April, 1877; resigned the public works department and retired from the army, 31st Dec., 1878.

FOOTE, ROBERT BRUCE, F.G.S., Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined 28th Sept., 1858; served in various districts of the Madras Presidency, the Nizam's territory, and Bombay; deputed to Vienna Exhibition in joint charge of the survey collections, 1873; 1st grade officer, April, 1876; deputy superintendent, June, 1881; fellow of the Madras University and member of the faculty of engineering, 1884; designation changed to superintendent of survey; officiated as director in 1887; author of contributions to the survey publications.

FORBES, ARTHUR, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sedbergh School, Yorkshire, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, Dec., 1867; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Sept., 1873; also secretary to the central relief committee, Jan., 1874; assistant commissioner in Assam, Nov., 1874, to May, 1876; on special duty at Sibsaugor, Jan., 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade,
Oct., 1880; junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1882; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, May, 1887.

FORBES, ARTHUR TREVOR, Madras C.S.—Educated at Thame Grammar School, Oxford, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 18 Oct., 1887, and served as assistant to magistrate and collector.

FORBES, GEORGE FOREST GREENLAW, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1883, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Nov., 1889.

FORBES, GEORGE STUART, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen Grammar School and University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1872, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting principal assistant, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue; from Sept., 1880, to Jan., 1883, was employed in the Madras secretariat as acting under secretary in the revenue department, assistant secretary, judicial and legislative department, and under secretary in the departments under the chief secretary, and also served on the board of examiners from Jan., 1882; from Jan., 1883, served under the government of India in the home department as officiating under secretary, also in the foreign department, on special duty, Dec., 1884, and as junior under secretary, Jan., 1885; also in charge of duties of press commissioner, March, 1885; officiating under secretary to government of India, foreign department, March, 1887; 1st assistant and secretary for Berar to the resident at Hyderabad; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Sept., 1888; district and sessions judge, March, 1890.

FORBES, JOHN GREENLAW, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 9th Dec., 1854; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1857; during the mutiny, 1857-58, served at the siege of Delhi, the relief of Lucknow, the siege and capture of Lucknow, and various engagements (medal and three clasps); served in the public works department, Punjab, from 21st June, 1858, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and from July, 1863, in the N.W.
