Provinces; on special duty in the Madras Presidency, Feb., 1867, reporting on the Kaveri, Krishna, and Godavari canals; superintendent of irrigation works, Oudh, Dec., 1867; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Oudh, July to Nov., 1872; from Nov., 1872, served as superintending engineer in the irrigation branch in the N.W. Provinces, in the Punjab (Bari Doab Canal), and in Bengal (Sone circle), and officiated as chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation branch, Bengal, May to July, 1877; on special duty under the government of India to prepare a revised scheme for the Sardah canal, June, 1878; on special duty on the Scinde, Punjab, and Delhi, and Indus valley railways, Nov., 1878; superintending engineer and secretary to resident, Hyderabad, Dec., 1879; chief engineer and joint secretary, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, buildings and roads branch, April, 1881, and in the irrigation branch from Nov., 1881; chief engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886; 1st class, March, 1887; secretary to governor of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Nov., 1887; officiated as inspector-general of irrigation and deputy-secretary to government of India, public works department, Feb.-May, 1889, and was appointed to that office, Dec., 1889.

FORBES, L. R., Bengal Non-Regulation Commission.—Served in the judicial department, Bengal, from March, 1864, and on the 1st May, 1875, was appointed assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1887, and at the Chittagong Hill Tracts, Jan., 1888.

FORBES, WILLIAM A., C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1847; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces, Punjab, and Oude; served as political officer throughout the mutiny; medal with clasp for Lucknow; magistrate and collector, Jaunpore, 1862; commissioner, Allahabad division, 1872; officiated as member board of revenue, N.W. Provinces; retired, 1875.

FORBES, WALTER ERNEST, Colonel, B.S.C., late Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, 13th April, 1859; served from Oct., 1860, in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1876; commissioner, Lucknow division, July, 1883; Fyzabad division, Oct., 1883; retired, June, 1889; author of report of the Partabgarh Settlement.

FORD, WILLIAM, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1842; arrived in India, 7th July, 1842; attached to the N.W. Provinces, and served in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner and joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty in the Sikh states, April, 1846; assistant to the governor-general's agent, N.W. Frontier, May, 1846; served subsequently in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and superintendent, cis-Sutlej territory, and officiating deputy commissioner; magistrate and collector, Goorgaon, 1856; deputy commissioner, 1st class, 1858; deputed on special duty to Cashmeer, March-Nov., 1860; commissioner and superintendent, Hissar division, Oct., 1864; Mooltan division, March, 1865; placed in charge of the state of Bhawalpoor, 1866; retired 1869; author of a report on native government as contrasted with the English system.

FORDHAM, JOHN WILLIAM, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department as assistant accountant, July, 1859; assistant controller, July, 1869; deputy controller, Holkar and Neemuch State Railways, Dec., 1871; examiner, 4th class, Jan., 1880; ditto, 2nd grade, Sept., 1881, and 1st grade, Feb., 1883; officiating examiner of accounts, Rajputana-Malwa railway, Sept., 1884; examiner, 3rd class, May, 1886; retired, 1889.

FOSTER, CHARLES J., General, C.B.—Served with the 16th Lancers during the campaign in Afghanistan under Lord Keane, including the siege and capture of Ghuznee (medal); served also at the battle of Maharajapore, 9th Dec., 1843 (bronze star); and in the campaign on the Sutlej in 1846, including the battles of Buddiwal, Aliwal
(as aide-de-camp to Brigadier Cureton), and Sobraon (medal and clasp); appointed to the council of the secretary of state for India, July, 1878; retired, 1888.

FOSTER, HERBERT WILLIAM, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Liverpool Institute, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting principal assistant collector and magistrate, and acting registrar high court; appointed head assistant, Jan., 1890.

FOSTER, WILLIAM SHRUBSOLE, M.A., late Madras C.S.—St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in Madras from Nov., 1861, as assistant magistrate and collector, and sub-collector; fellow of University of Madras, April, 1873; collector and magistrate and political agent, Godavari, April, 1875; retired, 1885.

FOSTER, W., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Sept., 1882; B.A. London University, 1883.

FOWLER, JAMES TOWNSEND, F.R.G.S., F.S.A., late Education Department, Madras.—Principal, Government Normal School, Madras, 2nd Dec., 1855; fellow of Madras University, Sept., 1857; on special duty superintending formation of normal schools, May, 1858; from Jan., 1859, served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to 1st class of educational department April, 1880; on special duty to Calcutta as member of the educational committee, Feb., 1882, and again, Aug., 1882, to March, 1883; acting director of public instruction, Madras, April-June, 1883; retired, Dec., 1883.

FOX, CHARLES EDMUND, Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Burma.—Officiated as government advocate, British Burma, 1879-80, and 1884-5, and as additional recorder, Rangoon, Dec., 1885 to Jan., 1886, and Jan., 1888; confirmed as government advocate, March, 1886.

FOX, CHARLES EDWARD, M.A. (Cantab), (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 9th Jan., 1866, as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts and local investigations, and taxing officer, high court, Bombay.

FOX, FRANCIS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Independent College, Taunton, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873, and served in the Central Provinces, and from March, 1877, in Burma, as assistant commissioner; superintendent of central jail, Moulmein, in 1877 and 1878; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1883, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, and acting district and sessions judge; assistant commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, May, 1885, 1st class, Nov., 1887; judge of the small cause court, Allahabad, Jan., 1889; district and sessions judge, April, 1890.

FOX, G. J. B., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 6th July, 1877.

FOX-STRANGWAYS, MAURICE WALTER, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Charterhouse, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1882; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Nagpur, Nov., 1882; assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Oct., 1887; settlement officer, Nov., 1887; assistant commissioner, 2nd class, Sept., 1889.

FOXTON, WILLIAM, B.A. (Oxon), late Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Aug., 1857; from Oct., 1857, served in the educational department as acting professor at the Poona and Elphinstone College, and headmaster of the English school, Ahmednagar, and was appointed tutor to ex-Amerees of Hyderabad, Sind, July, 1860; from Oct., 1860, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, deputy collector of income tax, acting judge and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; appointed judge of the court of small causes, cantonment magistrate, and superintendent of jail, Karachi, also Sindi translator to government, May 1876; acting collector of customs and shipping master, Karachi, and assistant collector of salt revenue in Sind, April, 1886; retired, April, 1887.

FRANCIS, EDWARD BELCHAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Repton Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; transferred temporarily to Bengal on famine duty, Feb. to Nov., 1874; officiating superintendent of Chamba, April-Aug., 1879; officiating secretary to financial commissioner Aug., 1879, and again in 1883-84; officiating judicial assistant in various districts, 1880-83; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1885; 1st grade, May, 1887; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, May, 1889.

FRANKLIN, BENJAMIN, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Central Provinces.—Appointed to the service, 1st April, 1869; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served in the medical department as civil surgeon, and on jail duty; on special duty with the Viceroy in 1880.

FRANKS, CHARLES N. B., Public Works Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 19th Nov., 1856; junior clerk, railway department, India office 1860; senior clerk, Feb., 1875.

FRANKS, EDWARD, Military Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 1st Sept., 1858; junior clerk, financial department, India office, Dec., 1866; funds department, 1867; senior clerk, military department, Aug., 1881.

FRASER, ALEXANDER, General, C.B., R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 8th Dec., 1843; joined the public works department, Sept., 1850, as executive engineer, Lower Provinces; executive engineer, Arracan, 1853, and subsequently at Rangoon; garrison engineer, presidency, Feb., 1856; under secretary to government of India, public works department, 1859; superintendent, Alguda Reef and other lighthouses, 1860; chief engineer, 2nd class, Feb., 1862; officiating secretary to government of Bengal, and chief engineer, 1862; chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, Aug., 1867; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1873; chief engineer and secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, May, 1871, to Jan., 1879; secretary to government of
India in the public works department, Jan., 1879, to Feb., 1882.

FRASER, ALEXANDER THOMAS, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Arrived in India, 2nd March, 1860, and served from that date in the public works department, Madras; executive engineer, Oct., 1866; transferred to Central Provinces, Dec., 1866; and to Rajputana, June, 1867; posted to N.W. Provinces, military works branch, April, 1872; served also in Jhansi and Mysore; returned to Madras, as executive engineer, March, 1881; acted also as superintending engineer, and deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government, public works department; in charge of West Coast Division, Jan., 1883.

FRASER, ANDREW HENDERSON LEITH, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces Commission).—Educated at the Academy, Institution, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1871; served in Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acting registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, Jan., 1877; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1877; commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Central Provinces, Aug., 1881; junior secretary to the chief commissioner, and director of agriculture, Feb., 1882; acting secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1882, and again at intervals in 1883-86; acting deputy commissioner, Wardha, March, 1884; acting commissioner, April, 1883.

FRASER, EDWARD ALEXANDER, Major, M.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 13th Sept., 1864; served with the 7th dragoon guards and in India with the 18th hussars; joined Madras staff corps, May, 1867; served under the foreign department of the government of India from July, 1874, as assistant resident in the Persian Gulf, assistant to the agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, assistant general superintendent Thagi and Dakati Jolna, and assistant to resident, Hyderabad; 2nd assistant agent in Central India, May, 1878, to April, 1879; officiated for various periods as political assistant, 1st class, and was confirmed, Oct., 1883; British joint commissioner, Ladakh, April, 1884; assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, Nov., 1884; assistant resident in Mysore, and secretary to the chief commissioner of Coorg, April, 1886; additional political agent, 1st class, and guardian to the heir apparent of Jodhpur, Dec., 1886; officiating political agent, 2nd class, and 1st assistant to the agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, and to the chief commissioner, Ajmere Merwara, June, 1887; political agent in the eastern states of Rajputana.

FRASER, HENRY, Colonel, Police Department, Central Provinces.—First commission, Madras cavalry, 1854; arrived in India, 14th March, 1854; assistant to general superintendent, Thuggee and Dacoity department, Nagpur, July, 1860; joint magistrate, Nagpur and Berars, Aug., 1861; from Nov., 1861, served in the police department, Central Provinces; acted as inspector general, July-Aug., 1863; 1st class, district superintendent, Nov., 1885.

FRASER, HUGH, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, June, 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Feb., 1888; acting registrar of high court, N.W. Provinces, in 1888; confirmed, April, 1889.

FRASER, STUART MITFORD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885; forest settlement officer, Aug., 1887; tutor and guardian to the Raja of Kolhapur, the Chief of Kajal, and Kunvar, Sahab of Bhavnagar, May, 1889.

FRAZER, ROBERT WATSON, B.A., LL.B., M.R.I.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Rathmines School, Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, engineer and manager of the Parla Kumedi estate (Jan.-Feb., 1882), acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting deputy director of revenue settlement; retired, 1886.

FRENCH, FRANCIS COOPE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Marlborough and Eton, and at Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal C.S., after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1889, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner.

FRENCH, Right Rev. T. LOUIS VALPY, D.D., Bishop of Lahore, 8th Feb., 1878; retired, Dec., 1887.

FRIZELLE, JOSEPH, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1863, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Punjab, May, 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating cantonment magistrate; judicial assistant, July, 1876; deputy commissioner, Ferozepore, April, 1877; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1883; officiating judge, chief court, Punjab, May, 1888; divisional judge, 1st grade, and additional judge of chief court, March, 1889; confirmed as judge of chief court, May 1890.

FROST, CHARLES EVITT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, and foreign schools; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate and political agent, acting railway magistrate, and acting forest settlement officer; second assistant collector, Dec., 1884; first assistant collector, Aug., 1887.

FRY, HENRY J. W., Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 18th Aug., 1873.

FRY, THOMAS DUNCAN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1889.

FRYER, FREDERICK WILLIAM RICHARD, C.S.I.
Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at foreign schools, and at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; officiating settlement secretary to financial commissioner, Oct., 1875; on special duty with the Quetta field force, Oct., 1878, and again, Feb., 1879; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Jan., 1882; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, May, 1883; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Dec., 1884; commissioner in Burma, Aug., 1886; financial commissioner, Burma, June, 1888; C.S.I., May, 1890; author of a report on the settlement of the Dera Ghazi Khan district.

FRYER, GEORGE EDWARD, Colonel, M.S.C., late Burma Commission.—Joined the Madras army as ensign, and arrived in India, 27th Feb., 1853; assistant superintendent of police in Madras presidency, June, 1861; officiating assistant engineer, Madras public works department, May, 1862; from Jan., 1864, served in Burma as officiating assistant superintendent of police, and from Jan., 1865, as assistant commissioner and assistant secretary to the chief commissioner; cantonment magistrate, Thayetmyo, Nov., 1883.

FULLER, JOSEPH BAMPFYLDE, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875; from Nov., 1875, to July, 1882, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and acting joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty as assistant director of agriculture and commerce, Feb., 1878; transferred to Central Provinces, July, 1882, and appointed acting director of agriculture and commerce, and junior secretary to the chief commissioner; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Aug., 1882; commissioner of settlements and agriculture, Oct., 1885; author of 'A Primer of Agriculture,' and 'Field and Garden Crops of the N.W. Provinces and Oudh.'

FULTON, EDMUND McGILDDOWNY HOPE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner, branch inspector-general of registration and educational inspector in Sind, acting judge and session judge, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan; appointed registrar of the high court, Bombay, Feb., 1881; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Ratnagiri, Feb., 1886; acted as 1st grade judge and legal remembrancer.

FURLONG, MALCOLM, Colonel, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—Joined the Madras army as ensign, and arrived in India, 10th Feb., 1857; served at the capture of Copul, 1858, and with the Bellary movable column, 1859 (medal); personal assistant to inspector-general of police, Burma, June, 1865; served in the Burma commission from Aug., 1867, as assistant commissioner, assistant secretary to the chief commissioner (July, 1866, to Feb., 1871), and town magistrate of Prome; from Jan., 1880, acted as deputy commissioner of Moulmein, also officiating as judge in 1880; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, May, 1884; president, Moulmein municipal committee, Jan., 1885; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Dec., 1888.

FURNIVALL, W. C., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, May, 1869, as supervising engineer on the Delhi and Rewari railway; 1st grade supervising engineer, Rajputana railway, March, 1874; under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Oct., 1873, in charge of Rajputana railway as engineer-in-chief; officiating director of railways, central system, and joint secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, May, 1877; joint secretary and officiating chief engineer, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1879; director of construction for state railways, March, 1880; chief engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, Oct., 1880; services lent to the Bengal Central, and Bengal and N.W. railway companies, May, 1883; Nizam's guaranteed railway company, March, 1884; chief engineer, 2nd class (supernumerary), March, 1882; retired from public works department, 1886.

FYTCHE, ALBERT, General, B.S.C., C.S.I., F.R.G.S.—Educated at Rugby and Addiscombe; ensign in 70th regiment, Bengal army, Dec., 1838; was employed on the Arracan frontier in 1841-2, and captured the Walling Hill stockade; from July, 1845, served in the Arracan commission, as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Sandoway, July, 1846; took part in the second Sikh war, 1848-49, and was present at the actions of Chilianwallah and Goojerat (medal and two clasps); in Dec., 1852, was appointed deputy commissioner of Bassein, and took part in various military operations in that district, 1853-54 (medal and clasp, and brevet of major), and also in the operations against the Karen tribes, 1857; commissioner of Tenasserim and Martaban, April, 1857; chief commissioner of British Burma, and agent to the governor-general, March, 1867 to 1871; major-general in the army, Nov., 1868, and a companion of the order of the Star of India; general, 1881.

GAFFNEY, JOHN BURKE, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Central Provinces.—Appointed to the Indian medical service, 1st Oct., 1866, having previously served as assistant surgeon, Her Majesty's home service, 1864-65; arrived in India, 27th April, 1867; was employed under the military department, including service in the Nicobar expedition, 1867; house surgeon, medical college hospital, Calcutta, March, 1868; from June, 1868, served in the Central Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, and assistant to the deputy commissioner, Upper Godavery district; from June, 1878, served as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at Raipur, and afterwards at Seoni and Saugor.

GAISFORD, GILBERT, Major, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Joined the service 22nd Feb., 1868; admitted to staff corps, March, 1870; from May, 1870, served with the Punjab frontier force, and throughout the Jowaki expedition, 1877-8 (medal); assistant superintendent of levies in Baluchistan, April, 1883; assistant political officer on expedition to Zhob, Sept., 1884; officiating political agent, Quetta, April, 1889; served throughout the Afghan war, 1878-80 (medal).

GAIT, EDWARD ALBERT, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open
competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1884, and served as assistant commissioner in Assam.

GAITSKELL, ARTHUR, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Cheltenham, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Burma division of the Bengal civil service, after open competition of 1887; arrived in Burma, 9th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant commissioner.

GALBRAITH, EDGAR, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portora Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent and small cause court judge, Dehra Dun, March, 1885; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Dec., 1886; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, June, 1889; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Feb., 1890; has officiated as district and sessions judge, and as magistrate and collector.

GALTON, CHARLES ARTHUR, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley, Magdalen Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in Madras from Aug., 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant commissioner (Nilgiri Hills), acting under secretary to government in the revenue department (March, 1872, to March, 1873), secretary to the board of revenue (Oct., 1879, to March, 1881, and in 1881–82), and acting collector of sea customs at Madras, and protector of emigrants; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Dec., 1883; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Oct., 1884; district and sessions judge, North Arcot, Nov., 1885; acting commissioner of salt and abkari revenue, April, 1886; acting additional member, board of revenue; acting secretary to government revenue department, July, 1882, confirmed, Nov., 1883.

GAMBLE, JAMES SYKES, M.A., F.I.S., Madras Forest Department.—Educated at Magdalen college, Oxford; appointed assistant conservator of forests, Oct., 1871; arrived in India 27th Dec., 1871, and served in British Burma; transferred to Bengal, Aug., 1872; served under the government of India as assistant to the inspector-general of forests, April, 1877, to Jan., 1879; deputy conservator, Bengal, July, 1880; conservator, 3rd grade, Sept., 1882; transferred to Madras, Dec., 1882; conservator, 2nd grade, Dec., 1884.

GAMBLE, REGINALD ARTHUR, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1885.

GANPATRAO BHASKAR, RAO BAHADUR, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from Aug., 1874, as 4th judge of the court of small causes, Bombay; appointed 3rd judge, May, 1883; and 2nd judge, May, 1889.

GANPATRAO DAMODHAR PANSE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, and assistant collector and magistrate, 13th Dec., 1881; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, June, 1884.

GARBETT, COLIN HUBERT, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission in army, 27th June, 1859; from 4th Dec., 1866, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1877, and deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1886, 1st grade, Aug., 1888.

GARBETT, HUBERT, Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department Nov., 1854; executive engineer, Bari Doab canal, Feb., 1860; Western Jamna canal, Aug., 1863; executive engineer, 1st grade, on the inundation canals, Punjab, Feb., 1870; superintendent of works, Derajet circle, Punjab, 1870; superintending engineer, July, 1878; superintending engineer, Bari Doab circle, Jan., 1880; and in the Derajet circle, April, 1882; superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1881; officiating as superintending engineer, 1st class, at intervals, from May, 1881.

GARDINER, JOHN WILLIAM, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Lycée Impérial Bonaparte, Paris; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty under financial department of government of India, Sept.–Nov., 1873; again on special duty, Nov., 1880; promoted to judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1880, and to deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1885; settlement officer in addition to his own duties, March, 1887; officiating divisional judge, Rawul Pindi, June, 1888; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, April, 1889; retired, Nov., 1889.

GARDINER, RICHARD, Major R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, 8th Jan., 1863; 2nd assistant engineer Rajputana state railway, 10th Nov., 1870; 1st assistant engineer, Sept., 1872; executive engineer, Western Rajputana section, Feb., 1875; deputy manager Class II. state railway revenue establishment, July, 1882; in the office of director-general of railways, Jan., 1885; officiating under secretary to government of India public works department, railway branch, Nov., 1886; class I. grade, 3rd April, 1887; manager and engineer-in-chief, Bharanagar-Gondal railway, June, 1887.

GARRETT, CHARLES BAZZETT, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 2nd March, 1858; from Jan., 1859, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating registrar of assurances, district and sessions judge, and magistrate and collector; judge of the principal court of small causes in Nuddea and Jessore, Dec., 1882; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Feb., 1883; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, April, 1884, and Aug., 1888; lieutenant-governor's council, 26th Nov., 1884.

GARRETT, H. W., Political Department, India Office.—Educated at the King's School, Ely; clerk, 2nd class, accountant general's department, India office, 12th April, 1882; transferred for service in the political department, June, 1880.

GARRETT, JAMES HUGH ELIOT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Reading Grammar School, Clifton College and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

GARSTIN, JOHN HENRY, C.S.I., Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service
from Haileybury College, 1857; served in revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed private secretary to H.E. Lord Napier, March, 1866, acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Jan., 1871, and collector and magistrate, South Arcot, and political agent, Pondicherry, May, 1871; served as acting secretary, and additional secretary to government, revenue department, 1876-80; wrote the review of the Madras famine of 1876-78; C.S.I., May, 1878; compiled South Arcot district manual; collector and magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, March, 1880, to April, 1881; board of revenue, July, 1882; appointed to revise the establishments of collectors and divisional officers in Madras Presidency, Feb., 1883; member of the committee in connection with the draft tenancy bill, July, 1883; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886; second member of board of revenue and commissioner of land revenue, April, 1887; acting first member, July to Sept., 1887; member of council of Governor of Madras, Jan., 1889; acting governor of Madras, 1st Dec., 1890, to 23rd Jan., 1891.

GARTH, Sir Richard, Knight, M.A., Q.C.—Educated at Eton, and Christ Church, Oxford; called to the bar in Lincoln's Inn in 1847, and went the home circuit; represented Guildford in Parliament, 1866-68; nominated chief justice of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, March, 1875; retired, March, 1886.

GARTHAWE, Liston, B.A. (London), late Education Department, Madras.—Served from 8th April, 1857, as head master of the Zillah School, Cuddalore, of the Provincial School, Calicut, and of the normal school, Cannanore, and as deputy inspector of schools; also acted as Malayan translator, and Canarese translator to government; from Sept., 1869, served as inspector of schools; compiled Canarese and Malayan Arzis for the secretary of state, and also various text-books; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884; 2nd class, education department, May, 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with preparation of a scheme for development of technical and scientific education, in 1884-85, and again in 1885-86; retired, Dec., 1888.

GATES, Frank Campbell, Bengal C.S., Burma.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; from Aug., 1884, served in Burma as assistant commissioner; on special duty in Upper Burma, March, 1887; junior secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1887; under secretary, Oct., 1887; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Aug., 1889.

GATHERER, Arthur Brander, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1864, and served in the public works department, Madras and Mysore; executive engineer, Sept., 1873; assistant secretary to resident public works department, Hyderabad; superintending engineer, March, 1880; transferred to Burma, April, 1889.

GAY, Edward, M.A. (Oxon), Financial Department, Government of India.—Appointed by the secretary of state as assistant in the finance department, Sept., 1865; assistant comptroller-general of accounts and acting assistant commissioner of paper currency, Calcutta, June, 1867; acting deputy accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1868; deputy comptroller-general, Calcutta, Sept., 1869; 1st class of the financial department, Jan., 1871; on special duty in England, March, 1872, to Dec., 1873; acting accountant-general, Bengal, May, 1874, to Jan., 1875; accountant-general, Bombay, and commissioner of paper currency, April, 1879; officiating comptroller and auditor-general, April, 1885; comptroller and auditor-general and head commissioner of paper currency (provisionally), Nov., 1887.

GEAKE, Edward, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Plympton College and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884. Arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1886, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

GEE, Walter Herbert, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Sherborne School and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1887, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

GEIDT, Bernard George, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, Dec., 1876; transferred to Assam, Oct., 1877, and served as assistant commissioner and assistant inspector of immigrants; personal assistant to the chief commissioner, Jan., 1882; officiating deputy commissioner, Lakhimpur; re-transferred to Bengal as joint magistrate and deputy collector, Jan., 1888; has also officiated as district and sessions judge.

GELL, Right Rev. Frederick, D.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Madras.—Fellow of Christ College, Cambridge; nominated lord bishop of Madras, 6th May, 1861; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1861; acting metropolitan bishop, Calcutta, March, 1876, to Feb., 1877.

GEOGHEGAN, Henry Thomas, B.A., M.I.C.E., late Railway Branch, Government of India.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; joined the public works department, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer, Punjab Northern state railway; superintending engineer, Indus valley railway, May, 1877; officiating consulting engineer to government of India for state railways, Feb., 1879; engineer-in-chief, Bhopal railway, June, 1879; engineer-in-chief, Madras state railway surveys, Feb., 1885; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1885, retired, 1890.

GEORGE, Edward Claudius Scotney, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dulwich and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1884; arrived in Burma, 7th March, 1887, and served as assistant commissioner.

GEORGE, James Morgan Tomkins, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Malvern College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma), after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner in Burma.

GIBB, Malcolm Couper, LL.B., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1883; acted
as junior collector in 1886 and 1887; on special duty, Surat, June, 1887.

GIBSON, EDWARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Alban's Grammar School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in Madras revenue and judicial department from Feb., 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate and acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, and was on special duty, Jan., 1868, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, North Arcot, and on famine duty in Kurnool, Nov., 1876, to March, 1878; acting under secretary to government, chief secretary's department, Feb., 1880; private secretary to governor of Madras, Dec., 1880; sub-collector and joint magistrate, June, 1882; secretary to the board of revenue, Jan., 1884; acting collector, district magistrate, and government agent, Tanjore, July, 1886; collector and magistrate, Sept., 1888.

GIBSON, FREDERICK EDWARD, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School, London University, and Edinburgh University.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nellore, Oct., 1883; retired, Aug., 1887.

GIBSON, HENRY WILLIAM (Barrister-at-Law), Oudh Commission.—Volunteer in the Meerut light horse, 1857-58; served subsequently in the military police, 1858-61; assistant district superintendent of police, Oudh, June, 1861; district superintendent, 4th grade, April, 1863; from July, 1864, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, and officiated as settlement officer, Feb.-Dec., 1865; acted as superintendent of encumbered estates, Sitapur, July to Oct., 1874; deputy commissioner, Sultanpur, Nov., 1877; 1st grade, July, 1883.

GILES, ARTHUR HENRY, Police Department, Bengal.—Joined the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, 14th Feb., 1863; district superintendent, Jan., 1866; officiating personal assistant to inspector-general, March, 1869; officiating deputy commissioner of police and justice of the peace for the town of Calcutta, May, 1870; 1st grade district superintendent, April, 1885; has officiated as deputy inspector-general; served temporarily under the Government of Ceylon in 1883.

GILES, EDWARD, M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 14th May, 1873, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of history and political economy, Elphinstone College, Bombay; from May, 1875, served as educational inspector, and was promoted to the 2nd grade of the department, March, 1883.

GILES, FRANK, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; under secretary to Government, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1886; senior assistant commissioner, May, 1888.

GILES, ROBERT, M.A., Sind Commission.—Arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1868; assistant settlement officer, Indus survey, March, 1869; served from Jan., 1870, as deputy collector, superintendent of police, and educational inspector in Sind; 2nd assistant collector in Sind, July, 1884; deputy commissioner, Upper Sind frontier, Dec., 1885.

GILL, JOHN EDWARD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 23rd Jan., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Aug., 1887; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov. 1889; settlement officer, 2nd grade, March, 1890; author of 'Gazetteer of the Ghazipur District.'

GILLAN, G. G., Rev., M.A., late Ecclesiastical Department, Bengal.—Assistant chaplain of the Church of Scotland, 4th Jan., 1866; served under the military department with the 91st Highlanders at Dum Dum, 1866, and with the 72nd Highlanders at Umballa, 1871; chaplain, Jan., 1876; senior chaplain of the church of Scotland in Bengal, and of St. Andrew's Church, March, 1880; retired, 1889.

GILLAN, ROBERT WOODBURN, Bengal C.S. N.W. Provinces.—Educated at Ayr Academy and Christ's Coll., Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 11th November, 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

GILLILAND, J. H., B.A., Bengal Educational Service.—Appointed to the service, 15th June, 1877, and served in the Presidency and the Howrah colleges as professor of civil engineering; class 3 of educational service, June, 1887; professor in Presidency College, Nov., 1883.

GILLMAN, HERBERT FRANCIS WEBB, Madras C.S.—Educated at Dulwich College and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed member of the Madras civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in Madras, 1 Dec., 1888, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

GIRINDRA NARAIN DEB, KUMAR, Bengal C.S.—Officiating deputy magistrate and deputy collector, Burdwan, Aug., 1878; appointed to the Bengal civil service under the native civil service rules, and served as probationary assistant magistrate and collector from Dec. 1880; confirmed in his appointment in the civil service, Feb., 1886.

GLADSTONE, CECIL ERNEST, Bengal C.S. (Burma)—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty at Delhi in the Imperial assemblage, Dec., 1876, and again, in the foreign department of the government of India, Feb., 1877; from Sept., 1885, acted as district judge, Rawul Pindi; transferred to Burma as deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Sept., 1886; 1st grade, May, 1889, officiated as commissioner, Southern Division, April, 1889.

GLASS, JAMES GEORGE HENRY, C.I.E., M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—2nd assistant engineer, Central Provinces, 27th June, 186; executive engineer, April, 1871; secretary to chief commissioner,
Central Provinces, and superintending engineer, Aug., 1888; appointed C.I.E., May, 1890.

GLAZIER, EDWARD GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at North London Collegiate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; from April, 1862, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1879; author of 'Report on the district of Rungpore,' 'Further Notes on the Rungpore Records,' 'Report on the Famine in Rungpore.'

GLENNY, WILLIAM HENRY, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Newry School, Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and acting district and sessions judge, and was placed on special duty, Jan., 1868, enquiring into the condition of the poorer classes, South Arcot; collector and magistrate, Kurnool, April, 1880; acting director of revenue settlement and agriculture, Oct., 1885; in charge of the Inam department, Oct., 1885; collector and magistrate, North Arcot, May, 1886; retired, 1888.

GODFREY, CHARLES WILLIS, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1853, and served in the Bombay artillery; from Aug., 1864, served in the Bombay revenue survey department as assistant superintendent, and acting deputy superintendent, and was promoted to superintendent of survey, Jan., 1883; colonel, Dec., 1883; acted as survey and settlement commissioner, June, 1889.

GODFREY, GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Bengal, Oct., 1873; on famine duty, May, 1874; transferred to Assam, Dec., 1874, as assistant commissioner, and acted as assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, July to Oct., 1877; from Jan., 1880, served in Bengal as officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; again transferred to Assam, Oct., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Lakhimpur; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, March, 1886; and grade, July, 1888.

GODELEY, ARTHUR, C.B., Under Secretary of State, India Office.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; Hertford scholar, 1868; Ireland scholar, 1870; Eldon law scholar, 1874; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn, 1876; private secretary to the first lord of the treasury, 1872-74, and again, 1880-82; commissioner of inland revenue, 1882-83; permanent under secretary of state for India, 30th Sept., 1883.

GODELL, WILLIAM, Audit Department, India Office.—Junior examiner, 30th Sept., 1860; senior examiner, June, 1863; junior inspector Dec., 1868.

GOLDINGHAM, JOHN DALRYMPLE, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1853; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-judge, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; from July, 1862, to July, 1865, served as judge of the court of small causes, Madura, and from Oct., 1868, to Oct., 1872, as civil and sessions judge at the same place; district and sessions judge, Nellore, Nov., 1872, to Feb., 1881, and afterwards at Bellary; retired, Sept., 1888.

GOLDSMITH, SEPTIMUS JESSIE, Surgeon-Major.—Joined the Bombay medical service, April, 1873; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1873; served as civil surgeon in North Canara and Guzerat; agency surgeon, Baghelkhand, Sept., 1875; also tutor to Maharaja of Rewah from Oct., 1883; afterwards in medical charge of Bhagelkhand Agency and dispensaries.

GÖMPERTZ, HENRY JAMES COLLEY, Madras Revenue Department.—Appointed to the revenue survey department, 10th Aug., 1859; served as assistant superintendent on special duty on boundary questions, Bellary, April, 1871-1872; deputy superintendent, 1st class, July, 1887; employed in Oct., 1888, on special duty on boundary questions, Puducottah, and in Jan., 1889, Karikal and Tanjore.

GONESH, CHUNDER CHOWDHUR, L.L., late Bengal Judicial Department.—Served in the Judicial department in Bengal from 18th Feb., 1863, as subordinate judge and small cause court judge; appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, April, 1887.

GONNE, CHARLES, C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1853; arrived in India 10th March, 1854; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed judge of the small cause court, Ahmednagar, May, 1861; joint judge and sessions judge, Thana, March, 1863, and acted as judge and sessions judge June, 1863, to March, 1864; acting judge and sessions judge, Poona, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan, April-June, 1864; acting registrar, high court, Bombay, June-Oct., 1864; from Oct., 1864, served as secretary to Government of Bombay in the judicial and political departments; chief secretary to government in the political, secret, judicial, and separate departments, April, 1879; temporary member of council, Bombay, March-April, 1884; retired in 1885.

GOODFELLOW, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, Major-General, R.E., V.C., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, July, 1853; lieutenant, June, 1855; arrived in India, March, 1857; served with the Central India field force, 1857-58 (medal and clasp, V.C.), and with the Okhamandal and Kattiarwar field force, 1859; joined the public works department as special assistant engineer, harbour defences, Bombay, April 1860; executive engineer, Feb., 1862; joined the Abyssinian Expedition, Dec., 1867, as brigade major of Royal Engineers (medal); executive engineer, 1st grade, Jan., 1877; superintending engineer, 3rd class, May, 1884; 2nd and 1st class, Nov., 1886; chief engineer for irrigation and officiating superintending engineer, September, 1887; chief engineer, 1st class, Aug., 1888.

GOODFELLOW, GEORGE RISTO, Colonel, Bombay S.C., C.I.E., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Dec., 1854; arrived in India, Oct., 1854, and was employed on military duty till Jan., 1863, also serving as personal assistant to inspector-general of prisons, Poona, Oct., 1859, to March, 1860;
from Jan., 1863, to April, 1870, served in the political department at Aden, as Arabic interpreter to the resident, and as assistant resident, and acted for various periods as resident; acting special assistant political agent in charge of Rajkot and Gondal states, Kathiawar, April, 1870; from March, 1871, to Feb., 1872, served in Central India as officiating political agent, Baghelkhand; from May, 1872, served under the government of Bombay as acting political agent, Cutch, acting political superintendent, Akalkot, and assistant resident and acting resident at Aden; political agent, Mahi Kantha, Sept., 1880; political agent and collector of stamp revenue, Cutch, Sept., 1881; 2nd grade political agent, Feb., 1885; C.I.E., Aug., 1887; political superintendent, Palanpur, 1st grade, Feb., 1889.

GOODFELLOW, WILLIAM WEST, Lieut.-General, C.B., R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay Engineers, Dec., 1851; arrived in India, Oct., 1853; joined the public works department, July, 1854; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-7 (medal and clasp), and with the Abyssinian expedition, 1867 (C.B. and medal); executive engineer, Bombay defences, Jan., 1860, to May, 1870; acting controller of public works accounts, June - July, 1870; served subsequently as executive engineer at Aden and in the Poona districts; from June 1876, served as superintending engineer, and was promoted to 1st class, March, 1882; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government of Bombay, public works department, April, 1885; returned to Europe, 1887.

GOODRICH, HARRY ST. AUBYN, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras from July, 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, deputy director of revenue settlement, acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting district and sessions judge, Nellore, Feb.-Sept., 1881; appointed collector and magistrate, March, 1882, in South Canara, and subsequently in the districts of Ganjam and Vizagapatam; on duty to Calcutta as additional member of governor-general's legislative council, Dec., 1884, to March, 1885, and again, Nov., 1885, to March, 1886; on special duty at Madras conferring upon proposals for legislating on relation of landlord and tenant in Malabar, March, 1885; member of the draft tenancy bill committee, July, 1885; collector and magistrate, Bellary, Nov., 1885; retired, Feb., 1890.

GOODRICKE, G. M., late Bengal Customs Department.—Served from 30th Nov., 1859, as preventive officer and appraiser, Calcutta custom house, and was appointed assistant collector of customs, 24th July, 1871, and deputy collector of Calcutta, March, 1880; is also superintendent of excise revenue, collector of stamp revenue, and a collector under the Licence Tax Act; retired, 1889.

GOODRIDGE, JOHN PERCH, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1866; served as assistant commissioner in the Central Provinces, and held acting appointments at various dates as district superintendent of police, inspector of schools, cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, and was deputed on famine duty to Madras, Sept., 1877; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Bilaspur, Nov., 1884; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Sept., 1886; officiated as commissioner of settlements and agriculture in 1889.

GOPAL DAS, RAJ BAHADUR, Punjab Commission.—Served in the settlement department and subordinate judicial department of the Punjab from 6th July, 1851; appointed extra judicial assistant, Oct., 1888; author of a Manual for preparation of Records of rights and of histories of the Gudranwala and Peshawur districts.

GOPEN德拉 KRISHNA, KUMAR, M.A., B.L., Bengal C.S.—Served in the subordinate executive service, Bengal, from Jan., 1877, and officiated as registrar of Calcutta and second inspector of registration offices; appointed to the Bengal civil service under the native civil service rules, Nov., 1882, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and deputy collector.

GORDON, ALEXANDER EVANS, Major, B.S.C.—First commission, 18th April, 1865; from May, 1872, served in the Bengal non-regulation commission as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty with H.H. the Maharajah of Johore, Dec., 1875; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Dum-Dum, March, 1876; tutor to the Maharajah of Durbhunga, June, 1877; on special duty in Calcutta, Jan., 1880, and in the foreign department, Nov., 1880; on deputation to Cooch Behar, Dec., 1883; deputy commissioner, March, 1886.

GORDON, DONALD CLUNES, Public Works Department, government of India.—Joined the public works department in 1868, as assistant controller of accounts, N.W. Provinces; served subsequently as deputy controller in the Punjab; controller, 3rd class, on the Indus Valley state railway, July, 1874, and afterwards on the Punjab northern railway; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, 1877-79, and afterwards in Madras; examiner, P.W. accounts, Madras, May, 1881; examiner, 1st class, Sept., 1886; examiner, public works accounts, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, March, 1887.

GORDON, GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Radley College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1885; assistant commissioner, Assam, Dec., 1885.

GORDON, HAMILTON WINKUP, B.A Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 12th Nov., 1864; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1866, officiating inspector of schools, July, 1872, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1879, and district and sessions judge, and grade, Nov., 1881; 1st grade, Jan., 1883, officiating judge of high court, Calcutta, April, 1883, April, 1889, and March, 1890.

GORDON, HUNTLY PRYSE, late Madras C.S.—Educated at New College, London, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, small cause court judge, assistant
commissioner (Nilgiri Hills), and acting district and sessions judge; appointed collector and magistrate, Kurnool, Dec., 1878, and afterwards at Bellary, April, 1880; and in South Arcot, Nov., 1885; retired, Oct., 1887.

GORE, ST. GEORGE CORBET, Major, R.E., Survey of India Department.—Joined the service, 8th Jan., 1870; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1872; from March, 1873, served on the great trigonometrical survey of India; on service in Afghanistan, Feb., 1879 to May, 1880; with Sir D. Stewart's column on march, from Kandahar to Kabul, as officer in charge of survey; attached to Afghan boundary commission, Aug., 1884; deputy superintendent, March, 1886; on military duty in Europe, Feb., 1888 to Jan., 1889; charge of trigonometrical branch office, drawing section, Jan., 1889; appointed to Calcutta survey detachment, Oct., 1889.

GORST, THE Rt. Hon. SIR JOHN ELDON, Q.C., M.P.—Graduated at St. John's College, Cambridge; 3rd wrangler, 1857; M.A., 1860; fellow of his college; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1865; Q.C., 1875; civil commissioner of Waikats, New Zealand, 1861 to 1863; represented Cambridge (borough) in the House of Commons, April, 1866, to Nov., 1868, and Chatham, for which he now sits, from Feb., 1875; solicitor-general in Lord Salisbury's first administration, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; under secretary of state for India, in Lord Salisbury's second administration, Aug., 1886; was British Plenipotentiary at the labour conference at Berlin, 1890; author of 'The Maori King.'

GOUGH, ARCHIBALD EDWARD, M.A., Educational Service, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the department, 2nd Nov., 1868, and served as Anglo-Sanskrit professor, Benares College, and as professor of English literature and professor of history and philosophy at the Muir College, Allahabad, and also officiated for various periods between 1872 and 1878 as principal, Benares College, and held charge of the meteorological observatory; served in Bengal, 1878-1886, as professor in the Hooghly and Presidency Colleges, and principal of the Calcutta Madrassa; education officer, 2nd grade, and principal, Muir Central College, Allahabad, July, 1886; author of 'Papers relating to the Collection and Preservation of the Records of Ancient Sanskrit Literature in India,' 1878.

GOVAN, GEORGE MONCRIEFF, Surgeon-Major, M.D., L.R.C.S., L.R.C.F.E., late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, Dec., 1851; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1852, and served under the military department up to 1883, in Bengal, Burma, and Assam, and throughout the Bhootan campaign, 1864-1866 (medal and clasp for Burma); rank of surgeon, June, 1864; surgeon-major, Dec., 1871; from Jan., 1883, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil surgeon, 2nd class, Fatehgarh, and posted to Azamgarh; officiating deputy sanitary commissioner, Aug., 1883; superintendent of Pilgrim Hospitals in Kumaun and Garhwāl in addition to other duties, Aug., 1883; served subsequently as civil surgeon at Budan and at Almora; retired, March, 1887.

GRACE, CHARLES HALLYBURTON, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, as ensign, Madras infantry, March, 1854; served in the Central Provinces from Sept., 1859, as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and settlement officer, and was appointed deputy commissioner, 1st class, Sept., 1883, at Jubbulpore; acted as commissioner of the Jubbulpore division, May-June, 1882.

GRACEY, HUGH KIRKWOOD, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at City of London School and London University and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

GRACEY, THOMAS, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Educated at Enniskillen Royal School; 1st commission, 17th Dec., 1862; 1st assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1867; executive engineer, Sept., 1870; engineer-in-chief, Pindi to Kohat Section Punjab Northern Railway, 1879; engineer-in-chief, provincial railways under construction, N.W. Provinces and Oudh Railway Branch, Oct., 1882; special superintending engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, public works department, Burma April, 1887; superintending engineer, Feb., 1888.

GRAHAM, JAMES, late Store Department, India Office.—Served in the Bombay artillery and ordnance department, 1834 to 1844; during which he served four years as chief clerk in the adjutant-general's office, also in auditor-general's office, and in charge of Mulligama depot, and in grand arsenal, Bombay; examiner of stores, India store depot, London, 25th May, 1866; sub-inspector of stores, Dec., 1866; supervisor, 1st grade, March, 1877, retired, July, 1888.

GRAHAME, WILLIAM FRANCIS, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from Oct., 1866, and was placed on special duty in July, 1868, with Dr. Janssen in connection with the solar eclipse; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, June, 1882; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1882, in North Tanjore, and afterwards in the districts of Kurnool and Cuddapah.

GRANT, ARTHUR JAMES, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Berkhamstead Grammar School, Dulwich College, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1889, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

GRANT, SIR CHARLES, K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, Trinity College, Cambridge, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1858; arrived in India, 8th April, 1858; attached to the N.W. Provinces, and served in the revenue and settlement departments; transferred to Central Provinces, Nov., 1863, and served as settlement officer and acting deputy commissioner; in charge of settlement commissioner's office, Jubbulpore, Jan., 1868; secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Nov., 1861; compiled the 'Provincial Gazetteer'; commissioner of Chattisgarh division, Nov., 1870, and subsequently of the Jubbulpore and Narbada divisions; acting judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1877; acting chief commissioner, April to Nov., 1879; additional
member of governor-general's council, Dec., 1879; acting secretary, government of India, home, revenue, and agricultural departments, May, 1880; foreign secretary, government of India, Sept., 1881; retired, Feb., 1885.

GRANT, Charles, Colonel, late Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 4th Jan., 1857; arrived in India, 6th Feb., 1857; served with the Guzerat Horse, and subsequently with the Mahratta Horse; special officer in charge, Kathiawar local battalion, and extra assistant political agent, Dec., 1867; in charge state prison, Asirgarh, March, 1870; assistant resident, Persian Gulf, June, 1871, and acted as resident in 1877; political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, April, 1878; political agent, Muscat, Feb., 1880; superintendent Rajputana railway police, Dec., 1880; from Feb., 1881, served as cantonment magistrate, Nimach; retired, Jan., 1887.

GRANT, George, Brigade-Surgeon, M.B., late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 10th Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 11th July, 1859, and served under the military department till 1866; from June, 1866, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, Bijnor, and was in medical charge of the lieutenant-governor's camp, Nov., 1861; civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail, Farakhabad, March, 1862; on special deputation to Calcutta to give evidence in a criminal case at the high court, Jan., 1864; officiating superintendent, government press, and curator, government books, N.W. Provinces, and chemical examiner, N.W. Provinces, Oudh and Central Provinces, Aug., 1866; superintendent of new central prison, Farakhabad, Dec., 1866; rank of surgeon, Feb., 1871; representative of N.W. Provinces at the prison committee, Calcutta, Jan., 1877; officiating inspector-general of prisons and civil hospitals, N.W. Provinces, in 1877, 1879, and 1882; superintendent, central and district jails, Bareilly, Dec., 1877; deputy sanitary commissioner, 1st circle, Dec., 1883; retired, Oct., 1885.

GRANT, George Francis Myton, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Brighton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1864, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner, branch registrar-general, education inspector in Sind, and acting talukdari settlement officer; in charge of the Sachim state, May, 1879; acted as collector, magistrate, and agent at Surat, 1879-80, and subsequently in the Panch Mahals, and at Broach, Kaira, and Kaladgi; junior collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Dec., 1882; acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Nov., 1883; acting collector of customs, Bombay, May, 1884; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Thana, March, 1885; senior collector, Sept., 1886; acting commissioner, Northern Division, May, 1889, southern division, June, 1889; appointed commissioner northern division, April 1890, and 1st grade commissioner, June, 1890; retired, Nov., 1890.

GRANT, Gregory Colquhoun, Colonel, Bombay S.C., late Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1853; on military duty till Nov., 1860, including service with the Okhamandal field force, in Oct., 1859; served subsequently as deputy collector and magistrate in Sind; judge and sessions judge, March, 1865; also acted as judicial commissioner in Sind, and judge of the sardar court.

GRANT, J.G. Garrow, Dr., late Emigration Department, Bengal.—Served in the emigration department from 22nd May, 1863, as medical inspector and protector of labourers, Kooshtea; on special duty at the Presidency, Oct., 1870; protector of emigrants and superintendent of labour transports, Calcutta, Feb., 1871; superintendent of emigration, Calcutta, Jan., 1874; retired, 1880.

GRANT, John Andrew, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; served under the foreign department, government of India, at Kurram, May-Aug., 1880; transferred to Umballa-Karnal settlement as assistant settlement officer, Dec., 1883; officiating settlement officer, Aug., 1884; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Sept., 1884; officiating registrar, chief court, June, 1885; officiating deputy commissioner, Umballa, July, 1885; on special duty at Sialkot, Nov., 1885; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Sept., 1887, and 1st grade, April, 1890.

GRANT, John Hay, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived, 6th Feb., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, railway magistrate, assistant revenue and police commissioner, acting collector and magistrate, and acting commissioner of customs, salt, and opium; junior collector, Kaladgi, Sept., 1877; municipal commissioner, Bombay, Nov., 1877 to Feb., 1881; collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Aug., 1883; special commissioner for Bombay for purpose of international exhibition at Calcutta, Nov.-Dec., 1883; president of a commission to make certain enquiries in connection with Abkari act, July, 1885; commissioner of income tax for town and island of Bombay, in addition to his other duties, April, 1886; retired, Jan., 1888.

GRANT, Sir John Peter, G.C.M.G., K.C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1826; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces and Bengal; deputy collector of Sarun, 1833; officiated as secretary, Sudder board of revenue, Calcutta, and as assistant secretary and deputy secretary to government, 1834; deputy accountant and civil auditor, Agra; deputy secretary to governments of India and Bengal, judicial and revenue departments, and officiating superintendent of the botanical gardens, 1835; junior member and secretary, prison discipline committee, 1836; officiating secretary, Indian law committee, 1837; officiating secretary to government of India, legislative, judicial, and revenue departments, 1838; private secretary to governor-general, and deputy secretary, general and financial departments, 1839; deputy accountant-general, ex-officio director of bank of Bengal, and junior secretary, financial branch, 1840; commissioner for payment of Mysore debts 1844-47; commissioner for enquiry into bro-
ceedings regarding Meriah sacrifices in Ganjam, 1847; secretary to Indian law commission, 1848; secretary to government of Bengal, 1849; secretary to government of India, home department, and foreign department, 1852-54; governor-general's council, 1854 to 1857; temporarily lieutenant-governor of Central Provinces during mutiny, 1857-58; governor-general's council, 1858-59; lieutenant-governor of Bengal 1859 to 1862, when he resigned the service; governor of Jamaica, 1866 to 1874.

GRANT, JOHN PETER, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1855; assistant magistrate and collector, Jessore, June, 1857; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Sept., 1862; officiating comptroller of government salt chowkeys, Nov., 1862; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1863; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Dec., 1863; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1867; small cause court judge, Kishnaghur, April, 1874; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1875; 1st grade, district judge, Jan., 1878; officiating judge, high court, February, 1886; retired, Jan., 1889.

GRANT, JOHN PYNE, Colonel, Bombay S.C., late Revenue Survey of Mysore.—First commission as ensign, Bombay infantry, Jan., 1856; joined the revenue survey, 1860; superintendent of revenue survey, Mysore, Jan., 1868; retired, Jan., 1890.

GRANT, TREVOR JOHN CHICHELE, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and was promoted to magistrate and collector, May, 1874; officiating secretary, board of revenue, April, 1874; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1878.

GRANT, T., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk 2nd class, India office, 28th May, 1875.

GRANT-DUFF, Rt. Hon. Sir MONTSTUART ELPHINSTONE, P.C., G.C.S.I., C.I.E., F.R.S.—Born, 1829; educated at Edinburgh, and at Balliol College, Oxford; M.A., in 1853; called to the bar at the Inner Temple in 1854; represented the Elgin burghs in parliament from Dec., 1857, to July, 1881; under secretary of state for India, Dec., 1863, to Feb. 1874; under secretary of state for the Colonies, April, 1880, to Aug., 1881; governor of Madras, Nov., 1881, to 1886; was lord rector of the university of Aberdeen, 1866, to 1872; author of 'Studies in European Politics,' 'Elgin Speeches,' 'A Political Survey,' &c.

GRAVES, SOMERSET HENRY PAUL, Major, B.S.C.—Late Burma police department:—first commission, 2nd Sept., 1868; served in the 26th native infantry, and in June, 1885, was appointed superintendent of police, Port Blair; deputy inspector-general of police, Upper Burma, May, 1887; reverted to military duty, 1888.

GRAY, EVELYN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; forest settlement officer, Nasik, March, 1884; acted as junior collector and magistrate in 1886 and 1887; 2nd assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1889.

GRAY, MALCOLM ALEXANDER, B.A., Major, Assam Commission, Ensign, 3rd (Buffs) Regt., 7th Nov., 1868.—Arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1870; served in the Assam commission, from Aug., 1873, as officiating assistant commissioner and assistant inspector of immigrants; confirmed as assistant commissioner, July, 1877; forest settlement officer, Oct., 1885; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, June, 1889.

GRAY, PERCY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 30th December, 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating cantonment magistrate, Roorkee, Oct., 1883; junior secretary, board of revenue, April-July, 1885; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Sept., 1887, and assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Feb., 1890; also officiated as magistrate and collector.

GRAY, R., Brigade Surgeon, M.B., Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1859; arrived in India, 11th March, 1860; civil assistant surgeon, Gujranwala, Feb., 1863; superintendent, central jail, Jan., 1864; civil surgeon, Mooltan, May, 1868; officiated as inspector-general of prisons, March, 1869, to March, 1871, and again in 1877; surgeon-major, July, 1873; in medical charge of lieutenant governor's camp, Nov., 1877; served afterwards as civil surgeon of Murree, Mooltan, and Lahore; inspector-general of prisons, Punjab, Sent., 1884.

GRAY, WELLINGTON, Brigade-Surgeon, L.M., L.Ch. (Dub.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1866; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1866, and was appointed professor of anatomy and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, and 2nd surgeon at the Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, Bombay; curator of Victoria and Albert Museum, and professor of botany, Grant Medical College, June, 1871; also acted as professor of chemistry and medical jurisprudence, and chemical analyser to government; secretary to the surgeon-general, Indian medical department, June, 1878; senior surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery, Grant Medical Hospital, May, 1883; brigade-surgeon, June, 1888; principal of the Grant Medical College, Dec., 1888.

GREAVES, Lieut.-Gen., Sir GEORGE RICHARDS, K.C.B., K.C.M.G.—1st commission, 30th Nov., 1849; Captain, Oct., 1859; Major, March, 1864; Colonel, Sept., 1872; Major-Gen., Oct., 1882; served in the Indian mutiny of 1857-8, and in the Eusofzy expedition of 1858 (medal with clasp); served in the war in New Zealand as D.A. Quartermaster-Gen., 1862-66 (brevets of Major and Lieut.-Col., and medal), chief of the staff of Ashantee expedition of 1873-4, present at battles of Omoaful and Ordahsu, and capture of Coomassie (medal with clasp and C.B.); served in Soudan campaign in 1885 as chief of the staff to Sir Gerald Graham (K.C.B., medal with clasp); appointed commander-in-chief of Bombay army, and second member of council of governor of Bombay, and took his seat, 13th March, 1890.

GREAVES, RICHARD HERBERT, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service
after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 19th Jan., 1870; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1884; transferred to Assam for employment as district and sessions judge, Sylhet, Nov., 1887.

GREENE, WALTER JAMES, Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 1st July, 1867; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878; attached to the financial department; clerk for examination of army non-effective accounts, March, 1885.

GREENSHIELDS, ROBERT SCOTT, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Birkenhead School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1879; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1879; transferred to Assam, March, 1882, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, Assam, March, 1886; officiated as director of agriculture, Assam.

GREENSTREET, WILLIAM LEE, Major R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission as lieutenant, Oct., 1864; arrived in India, Jan., 1870; joined the public works department, Feb., 1871, as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces; transferred to military works branch, 1872; executive engineer, Nov., 1874; superintending engineer, 3rd class, July, 1885, and 2nd class, Dec., 1880.

GREER, ARTHUR CHRISTIAN, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Portora Royal School, Enniskillen and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1834; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1836, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

GREER, RICHARD TOWNSEND, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Erasmus College, Drogheda, and Kingstown School, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1877, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, assistant secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; returned to Bengal, Oct., 1883, as joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade.

GREEVEN, RICHARD, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Dulwich and at Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1835; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1835, and served in the N.W. provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

GREGG, WILLIAM HENRY, M.B., M.R.C.P., London, Dep. Pub. Health, Camb.—Surgeon-Major, Bengal medical service; first commission, 1869; served in the 4th Bengal native infantry, May, 1870-Dec., 1873; in the Looshai campaign, 1871-2 (medal and clasp); civil surgeon, Dinajpore, 1873, Jessore, 1875, Hooghly, 1876-86; lecturer on botany, Hooghly government college, 1877-86; officiating protector of emigrants, Calcutta, 1888; sanitary commissioner, Bengal, Jan., 1889.

GREIG, G., late Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India, 20th Sept., 1857, as a lieutenant, 93rd Sutherland Highlanders; retired from the army, June, 1865; joined the forest department, Dec., 1868, and was appointed assistant conservator, Aug., 1869, deputy conservator, March, 1871, and conservator, Nov., 1876; promoted to 1st grade of conservators, April, 1883; retired, 1889.

GREY, CHARLES, Political Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, military department, India office, 18th May, 1864; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, April-July, 1866; financial department, 1866; assistant précis writer to the secretary of state, 1872; accompanied Sir Bartle Frere on his mission to Zanzibar, 1872-1873; political department, 1874; reading clerk to council from 1875 to 1890; senior clerk, April, 1877.

GREY, LEOPOLD JOHN HERBERT, Colonel, C.S.I., B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1857; assistant commissioner in Assam, Feb., 1865; officiating civil officer with Bhootan Dovar field force, Dec., 1865; from April, 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, but was employed under the government of Bengal, Dec., 1868, to June, 1869; on special duty, Oct., 1869, to March, 1870; political agent, Bahawalpur State, March, 1871, to Jan., 1873, and again in 1877; judicial assistant, 1st grade, July, 1876; on special duty in connection with Imperial assemblage, Sept., 1876, to Jan., 1877; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1876; officiating civil and session judge, Peshawur, Aug., 1881; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Sept., 1881; secretary to board of examiners (under government of India), March, 1882; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi division, March, 1886.
