GREY, WILLIAM FRANCIS HUNGERFORD, Major, B.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, 2-10th regiment, Aug., 1863; served in the Burma commission from April, 1874, as assistant commissioner, and acted as assistant secretary to chief commissioner, June-Oct., 1876; boundary officer, Paungde, Aug., 1881; cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, Sept., 1882; was elected president of the Kyaukpyu town committee, March, 1884; and of the Akyab municipal committee, Dec., 1885; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1886.

GRIERSON, GEORGE ABRAHAM, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Bees, Shrewsbury, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1873; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; on famine duty, March, 1874; officiating inspector of schools Oct., 1880; on special duty in the revenue department, Dec., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1886; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, April, 1890; has published various works in connection with the Behari language and its dialects, translations, collections of folk songs, &c., also 'Behar Peasant Life,' 1885; 'Report on Colonial Emigration from the Lower Provinces of Bengal,' 1883; 'Curiosities of Indian Literature,' 1885; 'Vidyapati and his Contemporaries,' 1885.

GRIERSON, JOHN, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Public Works Department.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay artillery, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, 24th Jan., 1858; joined the P.W. department, Feb., 1864; executive engineer, Jan. 1871; from May, 1872, served as deputy controller of ac-
counts, Bombay; deputy examiner, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1875; examiner of accounts, Dec., 1876; transferred to Burma, July, 1880, and subsequently to Bombay (Sept., 1884), and to N.W. Provinces; examiner of telegraph accounts, Aug., 1885; 2nd class, examiner, May, 1886.

**GRiffin, Henry Daly, B.A., Bengal, C.S. (North West Provinces).—Educated at French College, Blackrock, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces; assistant superintendent Dehra Dun, April, 1889.**

**GRiffin, Sir Lepel Henry, K.C.S.I., late B.C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; on special duty compiling the 'Punjab Chiefs,' Oct., 1867; under secretary to government, Punjab, April, 1870; on special duty to frame track rules between Punjab and Rajputana states, Feb., 1873; superintendent, Kapurthala state, April, 1875; deputy commissioner, 1st class, April, 1877; acted as secretary to government, Punjab, from Feb., 1876, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1878; on special duty at the Paris exhibition, July, 1878; during the occupation of Afghanistan, held the special appointment of chief political officer in north and west districts of that country (Afghanistan medal); resident, 1st class and agent to the governor-general, Central India, Feb., 1881; K.C.S.I., May, 1881; royal commissioner, Indian and colonial exhibition, 1886; retired, Jan., 1889.**

**GRiffith, Hugh, Brigade-Surgeon, late Medical Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian medical department (Madras establishment), 1859; served under the military department from 1859 to 1871, and also held civil surgeoncies of Thayetmyo and Hoshungabad during that period; civil surgeon and health officer, Rangoon, April, 1871; also superintendent of lunatic asylum, and in charge of state prisons and lock hospital, June, 1871; in medical charge of Rangoon Jail, Nov., 1871, to March, 1885; also superintendent of vaccination, May, 1875; in medical charge, Burma state railway, Nov., 1885; brigade-surgeon, March, 1886; retired, May, 1890.**

**GRiffith, Ralph Thomas Hotchkiss, M.A., C.I.E., late Educational Department North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1853, and served as professor and head master, Benares College, also as officiating inspector of public instruction, 3rd circle; principal, Benares College, Jan., 1861; superintendent of observatory, Benares, May, 1866; promoted to 1st grade April, 1873; on special committee under government of India, for selection of text-books, May, 1877; inspector-general of schools, N.W. Provinces, March, 1878; director of public instruction, Feb., 1879.**

**GRiffiths, W., M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Education Department, Bengal.—Appointed to the education department, 1st July, 1869; arrived in India, 20th Jan., 1870, and served as assistant professor, civil engineering department, Presidency College; professor, Presidency College, Feb., 1876; principal, Hooghly College, April, 1880; 2nd class, education department, July, 1883.**

**GRigg, Edward Evans, Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, Dec., 1861; served under the military department till Jan., 1864, and subsequently as assistant commissioner in Assam up to March, 1867, when he was transferred to the Oudh commission, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner in various districts officiating cantonment magistrate, Lucknow, May–June, 1881; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Sultanpur, May, 1885; 2nd grade, Feb., 1888; 1st grade, Dec., 1888.**

**GRigg, Henry Bidewell, M.A., C.I.E., Madras C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1866; acting inspector of schools Feb., 1867; from March, 1872, to Feb., 1876, served as assistant commissioner and acting commissioner, Nilgiris; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, Feb., 1876, and acting secretary, March, 1877; on special duty, preparing Annual Administration Report, Oct., 1877; under secretary, public department, Oct., 1879; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1880; fellow of University of Madras, March, 1880; director of public instruction and commissioner for the uncov. civil service examinations, July, 1880; acting resident in Travancore and Cochin, June-Oct., 1890; compiled the 'Nilgiri District Manual'; member of the local self-government committee, June, 1882; C.I.E., Jan., 1890.**

**GRimes, Henry Robert, late Jail Department, Madras.—Assistant deputy commissioner of paper currency, Vizagapatam, 29th Nov., 1864; from April, 1866, served as superintendent of the central jail, Coimbatore; inspector-general of jails, Madras, July, 1884; retired, April, 1889.**

**GRimley, William Henry, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward's School, Birmingham, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India 12th Dec., 1863; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiated as superintendent of surveys, Feb., 1869, and as inspector of schools, Aug., 1870; on special duty in connection with the examination of candidates for the native civil service, Jan., 1874; officiated as secretary to the board of revenue, 1874 to 1877, and again in 1879 and 1883-84; junior secretary to the board of revenue, 1877-79; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1879; officiating collector of customs and ex-officio shipping master, Calcutta, April, 1881; served under the financial department from April, 1885; commissioner of income tax in Bengal, March, 1886; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1887; officiating commissioner, Chota Nagpur, April, 1889; confirmed, Oct., 1889; author of 'The Sea Customs Law,' 1878, 'Tariff Act, with notes,' an 'Income Tax Manual,' being Act II of 1886, with notes, 'Manual of Revenue, Sale, Law, and Certificate Procedure.'**

**GRimwood, Frank St. Clair, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Winchester, and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 27th Nov.,
1876; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1876; transferred to Assam, July, 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, inspector of labourers, and officiating deputy commissioner, also officiated as political agent, Manipur; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, June, 1880.

GRINDLAY, Walter, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1881; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; retired, 1888.

GRISH, Chunder Chowdhri, B.L., Bengal Judicial Department.—Served in the judicial department from 9th March, 1866, as subordinate judge, and judge of small cause courts; appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, April, 1888.

GROSE, James, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the revenue department, secretary to commissioner for uncov. civil service examinations, secretary to the central committee for the examination of assistants, sub-secretary board of revenue (Aug., 1867), and receiver of the Carnatic property; fellow of the Madras University, May, 1868; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, March, 1870; secretary to board of revenue, 1870 to 1877; collector and magistrate, Nellore, March, 1877; acting member, board of revenue, April, 1886; acting director of revenue settlement, Nov., 1886; on special duty to Delhi, March, 1888; acting Imam commissioner, May, 1822; additional member of legislative council of Governor of Madras, Oct., 1888; fourth member of board of revenue, and commissioner of land revenue, Jan., 1889; third member, &c., Oct., 1889.

GROVES, Frederick W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Associate of King's College, London; M.A. and L.L.B., University of London; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn; temporary clerk, India Office, 1st Aug., 1863; junior clerk May, 1864; senior clerk, Aug., 1879.

GROVES, Henry Samuel, B.A., Bombay Financial Department.—Joined service as probationer financial department, July, 1873; served in the offices of the accountant-generals of Bombay, Punjab, Madras, and Bengal; assistant accountant-general of Bombay, Nov., 1887.

GROWSE, Edward Frederick, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 18th Nov. 1881; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

GROWSE, Frederick Salmon, M.A., C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Oriel and Queen's Colleges, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860; from Dec., 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector Bulandshahr, Jan., 1879; officiated as sessions judge in 1887 and 1888; has published a translation of Tulsi Dass's 'Rāmāyaṇa,' also 'Mathura: a District Memoir,' 'Bulandshahr: Sketches of an Indian District,' and 'Indian Architecture of To-day.'

GUBBINS, Frederick Bebb, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1835; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, Delhi division; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Moradabad, 1842, and subsequently in Rohtuk and Banda; magistrate and collector of Benares, 1852; civil and sessions judge, Benares, 1857; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Benares, agent to governor-general, and superintendent of ex-rajah of Coorg, 1858; retired 1863.

GUN, William Henry Maffett, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Greenock Academy, and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1871; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions' judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884; district and sessions judge, December, 1888.

GUPTA KALI PADĀ, M.B., F.R.C.S., Surgeon-Major Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service, 13th June, 1872, on inspection duty, medical relief measures, Burdwan District; served as superintendent of vaccination and on general and jail duty; on special duty to Nuddea medical fever relief operations in 1881; superintendent of vaccination, metropolitan circle, Nov., 1886.

GUPTA KRISHNA GOVINDA (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Mymensingh Zilla School, and Pogose School, Dacca, and matriculated at Calcutta University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, March, 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1886; has also officiated as magistrate and collector, and as junior secretary to the board of revenue, and was confirmed in the latter appointment, May, 1890.

GURDIAL SINGH, Sirdar, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 26th Jan., 1880; assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Jan., 1882, 2nd grade, April, 1889, and has officiated as deputy commissioner, district judge, and assistant commissioner, 1st and 2nd grade.

GURDON, Evelyn Pulteney, Colonel, B.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 2nd April, 1852; from Aug., 1860, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and small cause court judge; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1881; additional commissioner, Jullundur, Umballa, and Amritsar divisions, Nov.–Dec., 1881, and subsequently in the Lahore and Rawal Pindi divisions; promoted to commissioner and superintendent, Aug., 1884; divisional judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1885; retired from civil employment, Jan., 1890.

GÜTERSLOH, Frederic Nicholas, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1874, as assistant engineer on the Indus Valley state railway;
in charge of locomotive and carriage department, Holkar state railway, Oct., 1875; officiating manager and locomotive superintendent, Holkar state railway, 1877; manager, Wardha Valley Railway, Dec., 1878; locomotive superintendent, Rajputana railways, March, 1880; 1st class, 2nd grade, locomotive department, state railways Jan., 1886, and 1st grade, March, 1890.

GUTHRIE, THOMAS KEY, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, March, 1855; arrived in India, 11th July, 1855; served with the Madras Rifles in Bengal, N.W. Provinces, and Central India, Oct., 1857, to Jan., 1860, and was present at several engagements (medal and clasp); served in the Madras police department from Dec., 1862, as assistant superintendent and superintendent; deputy inspector-general, Dec., 1881; commissioner of police, Madras, July, 1883; inspector-general of police, Madras, Dec., 1885.

HABIB-ULLAH, MAULVI SAIVID, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (North Western Provinces).—Appointed by the government of India to be an assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces, under the Statutory Rules, 14th Feb., 1887.

HACKETT, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, late Geological Survey Department.—Joined the department as assistant, 15th Nov., 1861; served in the Sone Valley, on the Vindhya, in Central India, and in Jabalpur and South Rewah; promoted to 2nd grade, June, 1881; designation changed to deputy superintendent of the geological survey of India; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, Dec., 1887; officiated also as superintendent.

HACKETT, ARTHUR LUKE, Surgeon-Major, Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, April 1, 1867; arrived in India, Oct. 26, 1867; served under the military department, also acting as civil surgeon at various stations, and as superintendent of jail; surgeon, April, 1873; from June, 1874, acted as presidency surgeon, also as ophthalmic surgeon at the General Hospital, Sept., 1874; garrison assistant surgeon, Bangalore, and superintendent of jail, 1877-78; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Bellary, 1878-81; surgeon-major, April, 1879; surgeon, 3rd district, Madras, Feb., 1881, and acted as superintendent of prisons, in 1881 and 1883; was subsequently appointed civil surgeon at Cannanore, April, 1883, at Salem, July, 1883, and at Negapatam; principal medical storekeeper, Madras, 1885; surgeon, 2nd district, Madras, health officer, and superintendent of Lock Hospital, Oct., 1885.

HAIG, CHARLES THOMAS, Major-General, R.E., late Survey of India.—Obtained his first commission from Addiscombe, June, 1854; lieutenant, Bombay engineers, May, 1856; arrived at Bombay July, 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-57 (medal and clasp), and with the Rajputana field force, 1857 (medal and clasp); assistant executive engineer at Nee-much, May, 1858; appointed as assistant in the great trigonometrical survey of India, Sept., 1859; served with the Okhamandal field force in 1859, and was subsequently variously employed in the survey department in Cutch, Kattywar, Guzerat, Meywar, Malwa, the Deccan, and Kanara; deputy superintendent, Oct., 1867; on deputation as commissioner, Venice geographical exhibition, April-Nov., 1881; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, Nov., 1883; officiating deputy surveyor-general in charge of trigonometrical survey branch, Oct., 1884; confirmed, Feb., 1887; retired from civil employment, 1890.

HAINES, Sir FREDERICK PAUL, Field-Marshal, G.C.B., G.C.S.I., C.I.E.—Entered the army as ensign in 1839; captain in 1846; lieut.-colonel in 1850; colonel in 1854; major-general in 1864; military secretary to Sir Hugh Gough in the war on the Sutlej, 1845; was present at the battles of Moodkee and Ferozeshah (medal and clasp); served through the Punjab Campaign of 1848 and 1849, and was present at Ramnuggar, the passage of the Chenab, and the battles of Chillianwallah and Goojerat; served with the 21st fuzilier through the campaign of the Crimea, 1854-1855 (medal with four clasps, 5th class of the Medjidie and Turkish medal); K.C.B., 1871; lieutenant-general, 1873; brevet-general, and G.C.B., 1877; commander-in-chief of the Madras army, and member of the governor's council, May, 1871 to 1875; appointed colonel of the 104th regiment, 1874; commander-in-chief of the forces in India, with local rank of general, and extraordinary member of the governor-general's council, April, 1876 to 1881, and directed the military operations of the Afghan campaigns of 1878-9, and 1879-80; thanked by both houses of parliament, 4th Aug., 1879 and 5th of May, 1881.

HAINES, HERMANN A., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Wellington College, and Keble College, Oxford; junior clerk, financial department, India Office, 15th Nov., 1881; political department, 1886; precis writer, Dec., 1889.

HALL, CHARLES FREDERICK, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from May, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating superintendent of jail, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Bareilly, Dec., 1882; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Budaun, Feb., 1883; retired, Dec., 1886.

HALL, M. S., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, India Office, 21st Jan., 1875; clerk, 2nd class, Oct., 1878.

HALL, WALTER ERNST, Madras, C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Madras, 29th Nov., 1889, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

HALL, WILLIAM THOMAS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Rossall, Kings-town School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1878, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner and settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; director of land records and agriculture, Oct., 1887.

HALLETT, HENRY HONYWOOD HUGHES, Colonel, M.S.C., Jail Department, Central Provinces.—First commission as ensign July, 1858; arrived in India, 11th Aug., 1858; was employed under the military department up to 1868, including service with the Bundel-cund field force, 1859; from Dec., 1868, served in the Central Provinces as assist-
tant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, acting district superintendent of police, acting cantonment magistrate, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and was appointed superintendent of the school of industry and central jail, Jubbulpore, Aug., 1878; acting small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, 1883.

HALLETT, John Revans, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the University of Melbourne; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 17th Oct., 1864; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, May, 1865; inspector of schools, Aug., 1870; officiating judge of the small cause courts, Bhagulpore and Monghyr, March, 1876; second inspector of registration offices, March, 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Sept., 1880, and 1st grade, Dec., 1887; retired, Feb., 1890.

HALLIDAY, Sir Frederick James, K.C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1824; arrived in India, 8th June, 1825; served in Bengal as junior assistant to the agent in the Saugor division and assistant registrar of the Sudder court; joint magistrate and deputy collector in Bundelcund, and afterwards in Noacolly and Bullooh, 1831-35; magistrate and collector of the Zillah Court at Dacca, Feb., 1835; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, Feb., 1836; secretary to the Sudder board of revenue, April, 1836; secretary to the government of Bengal, judicial and revenue departments, May, 1838; member of the general committee of public instruction, June, 1838; junior secretary to the government of India, revenue, judicial, and legislative departments, in addition to his other duties, March, 1840, to 1843; secretary to the government of India, home department, 1849; member of governor-general's council, Dec., 1853; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1st May, 1854; retired in 1859; member of council of secretary of state for India, 30th Sept., 1868, to Dec., 1886.

HALLIDAY, Frederick Mytton, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived, 30th Oct., 1856; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating civil and sessions judge, and magistrate and collector (1st grade, May, 1871); officiated as opium agent, Benares, in 1876 and 1877; commissioner, Presidency division, April, 1878, and Patna division, June, 1878; officiating member, board of revenue, Sept., 1884, to April, 1885, and from July, 1886 to Feb. 1887, and again in Nov., 1887, and March, 1888; chairman, Port Commissioners, Calcutta, April, 1887; additional member of governor-general's council, Dec., 1887; confirmed as member of board of revenue, April, 1889.

HALIFAX, Arthur George, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887.

HALIFAX, Charles Joseph, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, and All Souls' College, Oxford; appointed member of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1888, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

HAM William James, Postal Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, and attached to the sea post office, Bombay, 6th May, 1868; supernumerary inspector, 1st grade, Director-General's office, Oct., 1877; deputy postmaster-general, Central India, May, 1880, and at Calcutta, attached to the railway mail service, April, 1882; assistant director-general, June, 1887; postmaster-general, 2nd grade, April, 1883; inspector-general, railway mail service.

HAMBLIN, Richard Ebb, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, and Christ College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, June, 1887; 1st grade, July, 1889.

HAMILTON, Frank Sumner, Bengal, C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service, after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, December, 1885.

HAMILTON, Right Hon. Lord George Francis, M.P.—Born Dec., 1845; educated at Harrow; ensign, Rifle Brigade, 1864; transferred to the Coldstream Guards, 1868; was elected member for Middlesex, Dec., 1868, and represented that county in parliament, until the election which followed the Reform Bill of 1885, when he was returned for the Ealing Division; under secretary of state for India, Feb., 1874; vice-president of the committee of council on education, April, 1878; first lord of the admiralty in the Marquis of Salisbury's first administration, June, 1885, and again, Aug., 1886.

HAMILTON, Richard Erris, Financial Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the financial department, 1st Aug., 1868; served as assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, March, 1869, also in British Burma, May, 1870; assistant comptroller-general, June, 1872; from July, 1873, to March, 1876, served in Bombay as assistant accountant-general and as assistant commissioner of paper currency, and subsequently in Calcutta, March, 1876, to Dec., 1877; reposted to Bombay, March, 1878; officiated as deputy accountant-general in Bombay, the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, the Punjab, and Madras, 1879-81; officiating assistant secretary, government of India, financial department, March, 1882; controller and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; 3rd class of the financial department, Feb., 1883.

HAMILTON, Thomas Sharp, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Old Trafford School, Manchester, the College, Chester, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant judge and sessions judge; promoted to and assistant collector, Feb., 1883; 3rd grade, assistant judge, Nov., 1887; acted as 1st grade assistant judge, 1887, and as judge and sessions judge, 1888.

HAMMICK Murray, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; from Jan. to June, 1882, served in
Coorg as acting 1st assistant commissioner and district magistrate; from Jan., 1883, served in the Madras secretariat as assistant secretary, judicial and legislative departments, and acting under secretary in the revenue department; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, South Canara, April, 1885; acting postmaster-general, Madras, Jan.-May, 1886; secretary to the commissioners of land revenue, Oct., 1887; has also acted as secretary to the board of examiners, and to the board of revenue, and as collector and magistrate.

HAMMICK, STEPHEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough, and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant educational inspector, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; assistant political agent, and tutor to the Maharaja of Kolhapur, Feb., 1873; on famine duty, Kaladgi, Sept., 1877; judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, Aug., 1883; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, Shikarpur, Feb., 1885; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, June, 1885; and grade judge, Surat, Sept., 1885.

HANKEY, HERBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1856; served in the Punjab till 1862, and subsequently in the Lower Provinces, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Maldah, 1867, and subsequently at Chittagong; superintendent of transport during famine of 1874; inspector-general of police, Lower Provinces, 1876; retired, 1878.

HANCOCK, GEORGE EDWARD, Colonel, Bo.S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1850, and served under the military department till Nov., 1863; from Nov., 1863, to March, 1868, served as assistant superintendent of revenue survey, and assessment, Gujarat; from March, 1868, acted as political and personal assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar; acting superintendent of the Rajkot and Limbi states, Aug., 1869; acting assistant resident at Aden, May, 1870, and at Baroda, May, 1871; assistant general superintendent for thuggery and dacoity, Oct., 1871; acting cantonment magistrate, Baroda, Oct., 1871; assistant political agent, Mahi Kantha, July, 1872; from Oct., 1873, served as superintendent of surveys under Rajasthani court, Kathiawar, and acted on various occasions as president of the court; on special duty at Delhi, Nov., 1876, to Jan., 1877; acting joint administrator of Gondal state, Nov., 1880, to Feb., 1881; on special duty with the Thakor Sahib of Gondal on tour in Europe, April, 1883; on special duty to inquire into administration of Rajpipla state, Nov., 1883; third assistant political agent, Kathiawar, Feb., 1885, continuing to be superintendent of surveys; president of the Rajasthani court, Kathiawar, Jan., 1886.

HANDLEY, FRANCIS FREDERICK (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sydenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 7th Oct., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating inspector-general of registration, and senior marriage registrar, Calcutta, Dec., 1880; first inspector of registration offices, Dec., 1881; officiating district and sessions judge, June, 1884, and Aug., 1888; inspector-general of registration, April, 1885; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1885; district and sessions judge, April, 1889.

HANDLEY, JAMES WILLIAM, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Madras.—Served in Madras as government pleader from 29th Oct., 1868, to July, 1881; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; first judge of the court of small causes, Madras, July, 1881; officiating judge of the high court, July to Nov., 1885.

HANNYNGTON, JOHN CHILD, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, small cause court judge, and acting collector and magistrate; district and sessions judge, Salem, Nov., 1873; on special duty, Dec., 1880, as arbitrator of boundary disputes between states of Travancore and Cochin; on tour with H.H. the Maharajah of Travancore on various occasions; resident of Travancore and Cochin, April, 1882.

HAPPELL, WILLIAM ALEXANDER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Crosshill School, Maybele.
Glasgow University, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and Magistrate, Nov., 1865; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Sept.-Nov., 1879; sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1880; acting commissioner of salt revenue, Madras, April to Nov., 1881; district and sessions judge, Nellore, Jan., 1883; collector and magistrate, Kistna, Nov., 1883; collector and magistrate, and government agent, Godaveri, Dec., 1885.

HARCOURT, ALFRED FREDERICK POLLOCK, Colonel, B.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 15th Oct., 1855; from Sept., 1862, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating small cause court judge; judicial assistant, 1st grade, March, 1877; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1883; retired, March, 1889; author of 'Down by the Drawl,' 'The Royal Umbrella,' and 'Kulu Lahoul and Spitti.'

HARDIE, R., Council of India.—Appointed to the council of the secretary of state for India on 17th March, 1887; was previously engaged in the profession of banking, and held the office of secretary and treasurer of the Bank of Bengal for 15 years; in 1886 was a member of the finance committee appointed by the government of India for the reduction of expenditure.

HARDING, FRANCIS HENRY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Tonbridge School, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Jan., 1885; 1st grade, Dec., 1887; has also acted as district and sessions judge.

HARDING, HERBERT OLIVE DENMAN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1886; and served in the revenue survey and settlement department, and as assistant to magistrate and collector.

HARDING, HERBERT W., Audit Department, India Office.—Associate of King's College, London; writer, India office, 27th April, 1868; junior examiner, audit department, Nov., 1873.

HARDINGE, Hon. Sir ARTHUR EDWARD, K.C.B., C.I.E., General.—1st commission, 7 June, 1844; captain 16th Foot, 1849; served as A.D.C. to Lord Hardinge in Sutlej campaign, 1845-6, and was present at the battles of Moodkee, Ferozeshah, and Sobraon (medal and 2 clasps); served in the eastern campaign of 1854-5, as D.A.Q.M.G. to the 1st division; and from the spring of 1855, as assistant quartermaster-general at headquarters, including the battles of Alma, Balaclava, and Inkerman, and siege of Sebastopol (medal with 4 clasps); knight of legion of honour, Turkish medal, 2nd 5th class of the Medjidie, (2nd class of the Medjidie in 1876); was commander-in-chief, and member of council, Bombay, 30th March, 1881 to 1886, when he was appointed governor of Gibraltar.

HARDY, RICHARD GILLIES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Witney Grammar School, and Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Aug., 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, May, 1885; magistrate and collector, July, 1889; officiated as commissioner of Jhansi, 1889.

HARE, LANCELOT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. John's College, Hurstpierpoint, and City of London School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments in Bengal and Assam as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; on famine duty, July, 1874; assistant secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, March, 1879, and officiating secretary March, 1880; officiating inspector-general of police, jails, and registration, commissioner of excise, and superintendent of stamps, Assam, July, 1880; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884, 1st grade, Aug., 1887; has also officiated as magistrate and collector.

HARE, ROBERT DOUGLAS, Berar.—Extra assistant commissioner, Chota Nagpur (Bengal), 8th June, 1869; served on famine duty, May, 1874, and in Berar from Oct., 1875; assistant commissioner, May, 1878; judge of small cause court, June, 1883; deputy commissioner, July, 1889.

HARINGTON, ARTHUR HENRY, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; served in Oudh from Aug., 1863, as assistant commissioner and junior secretary to chief commissioner; from Dec., 1866, to Jan., 1868, served under the government of India as officiating assistant secretary, foreign department, and officiating under secretary, home department; officiating superintendent of excise and stamps, Oudh, July, 1868; appointed to take up lands for railway purposes, Nov., 1868; officiating personal assistant to financial commissioner, March, 1869; officiating settlement officer, Hardoi, March, 1870; manager of encumbered estates, Fyzabad and Gonda, 1872-75; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1879; magistrate and collector, Saharanpur, Oct., 1883; acted as commissioner in the Lucknow, Sitapur, Rae Bareli, Fyzabad, and Allahabad divisions; commissioner in Oudh, June, 1880; and was appointed commissioner, Allahabad division, Nov., 1889; author of 'Hardoi Settlement Report,' and 'Economic Reform in Rural India.'

HARINGTON, HERBERT BARING, M.A.—late of Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1857, as assistant in telegraph department; for services during the mutiny at the relief of Lucknow received medal and clasp; from Feb., 1860, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating settlement officer; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, 1869-73; also officiating director of public instruction, April-July, 1870; deputy commissioner, July, 1875; district judge, 2nd grade, Lucknow, Aug., 1879; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Sultanpur, Dec., 1881; officiated as commissioner of the Sitapur division in 1876, and of the Rae Bareli division in 1881, 1884, and 1885; retired, Nov., 1887.
HARMAN, C., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 19th Aug., 1878.

HARRIDANCE, H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 8th March, 1873.

HARRIS, EDWARD BRANSON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bedford Commercial School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1877; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1888, 1st grade, April, 1890; has also acted as magistrate and collector.

HARRIS, (BARON), Rt. Hon. GEORGE ROBERT CANNING HARRIS.—Educated at Eton, and at Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in 1874; is J. P. and D. L. for Kent, and deputy chairman of the East Kent Quarter Sessions; under secretary for India in Lord Salisbury's first administration, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; under secretary of state for war, Aug., 1886; took his seat as Governor of Bombay in succession to Lord Reay, 12th April, 1890.

HARRIS, ROBERT LISTON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at King's College School, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1877, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating district judge; deputed to settlement department, Dec., 1883, to Feb., 1884; officiating divisional judge and officiating deputy commissioner for various periods; 2nd grade district judge, Nov., 1889.

HARRISON, CHARLES WILLIAM INGLEBY, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as Lieutenant, 11th June, 1858; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1860; served in the public works department, irrigation branch, North-Western Provinces, from 10th April, 1863, as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and assistant to chief engineer, and was employed on the Eastern Jumna, Rohilkhund, and Ganges canals; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1881; deputed to Bengal as member of commission to enquire into system of canal administration in Orissa, Dec., 1884, to April, 1885; superintending engineer, 2nd class, May, 1886; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary to government, Bengal, July, 1886, and as secretary, April-June, 1888; superintending engineer, 1st class, Feb., 1888; 3rd chief engineer, Dec., 1889.

HARRISON, FRANCIS CAPEL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1884; served in Assam from Jan. to May, 1889, as assistant commissioner; officiating assistant accountant-general, Madras, May, 1889, and deputy accountant-general, Bengal, March, 1890.

HARRISON, HENRY ANTHONY, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College 1855; arrived in India, 3rd April, 1855; served from May, 1856, to Sept., 1858, in Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, Cuttack, and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1862; assistant, settlement department, Feb., 1864; magistrate and collector, Hamirpur, March, 1872; magistrate and collector, Farukhabad 1873-1877; officiating commissioner, Jhansi division, Sept., 1875; civil and sessions judge, Allahabad, March, 1878, and subsequently at Mirzapore, Farukhabad, and Meerut; 1st grade judge, March, 1884; retired, June, 1887.

HARRISON, SIR HENRY LELAND, Knt., B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments in the usual grades, and as inspector of schools (1864-1866); junior secretary, government of Bengal, 1867-71; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1868, and again in 1871; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1871; also superintendent of survey, Oct., 1876; secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1878, and again in March, 1881; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, May, 1879; on special duty in connection with the rent commission, Nov., 1879; commissioner of police, Calcutta, and chairman of the corporation of the town of Calcutta, Jan., 1882; member of the Bengal legislative council, Feb., 1886; member of Board of Revenue, April, 1890; author of 'Embankment Manual'; knighted, Feb., 1887.

HARRISON, JOHN HENRY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Erasmus Smith's School, and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun, Nov., 1876; officiating assistant director of department of agriculture and commerce, Nov., 1880; acting junior secretary, board of revenue, March, 1881; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Aug., 1885; 2nd grade settlement officer, Oct., 1887; has also officiated as magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1889.

HARRISON, PERCY, Bengal, C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at St. Paul's School and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HARRISON, RICHARD PRYCE, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1834; arrived in India, 16th Sept., 1835; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and officiating collector, Moorshedabad, 1849; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Bograh, 1850; officiating abkari commissioner, Dacca division, 1851; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, 1853-56; civil and sessions judge, 1856; accountant-general, government of Madras, and a government director of the Madras bank, 1859; accountant-general and auditor-general to government of India, and a government director of the bank of Bengal, 1860; also first member and president of the board of audit; comptroller-general, 1863-67; resigned, April, 1867.

HARRISON, WILLIAM PRINGLE, Lieut.-Col., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, 10th Feb., 1861; employed under the military department till Oct., 1867, from which date he
served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner, and acted as district superintendent of police in 1873-74, and as superintendent of encumbered estates in Sultanpur in 1874; sub-judge, Patialgarh, Aug., 1879; cantonment magistrate of Fyzabad, July, 1881, and subsequently of Lucknow, April, 1883; also acted as district judge in 1884-85; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1888.

HART, G. H. R., Financial Department, Government of India.—Probationer in financial department, 20th July, 1869; from Dec., 1870, served as assistant to comptroller-general; on special duty in Behar, Jan.-March, 1874; assistant to private secretary to viceroy, April, 1874, to April, 1876; assistant to accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1877; from Feb., 1878, acted as private secretary to governor of Bombay, and was confirmed in this appointment, March, 1880; placed in class 4 of financial department on return; appointed assistant accountant-general in charge of paper currency office, Bombay, Aug., 1887, class 3 of financial department.

HART, JOHN HENRY EUSTACE, M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1854; joined the Bombay public works department, Jan., 1855, and served as civil engineer at Satara, Nasik, and Dharwar; acting executive engineer for reclamations, Bombay, May, 1869; architectural executive engineer and surveyor, Bombay, May, 1871; acting superintendent, harbour works, Karachi, Nov., 1874; acting superintending engineer in Sind, April, 1876; acting chief engineer for irrigation, Sept., 1877; superintending engineer 1st class, March, 1880; joint secretary to government of Bombay for irrigation, March, 1880; chief engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1885; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government of Bombay public works and irrigation department, Sept., 1887; retired, 1888.

HART, WILLIAM, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1834; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge and sessions judge; commissioner for enquiring into claims, &c., South Mahratta country, 1847; secretary to government of Bombay, in the general and ecclesiastical departments, 1855, also in the public works department, and railway branch, 1856; puisne judge of the court of Sudder Dewani, 1860; revenue and police commissioner, Southern division, 1862; additional members of Bombay council for making laws and regulations, 1864; retired in 1865.

HART, WILLIAM ELLEFTHOR, B.A. (Cantab.), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Acting professor of English literature, Elphinstone College, Bombay, March, 1872, to Nov., 1873; from Nov., 1874, served in the Bombay judicial department as acting clerk and sealer of the insolvent debtors' court, and reporter to the high court; first judge of the small cause court, Bombay, Jan., 1878; also acted as judge of the high court, July to Oct., 1884, Dec., 1886 to April, 1887, and Sept. to Nov., 1889.

HART-DAVIES, THOMAS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from May, 1876, served in Sind as educational inspector, acting judge and session judge, and acting assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration; manager of encumbered estates in Sind, Oct., 1879, to Sept., 1885; 1st assistant collector, April, 1887; has acted as assistant judge and sessions judge.

HARTINGTON (MARQUIS OF), RIGHT HON. SPENCER COMPTON CAVENDISH, D.C.L., M.P.—Born 23rd July, 1833; educated at Trinity College, Cambridge (graduated B.A. in 1854, LL.D. in 1862); attached to Earl Granville's special mission to Russia in 1856; sat in the House of Commons for North Lancashire, from March, 1857, to Dec., 1863, when he was returned for the Radnor boroughs; D.C.L., Cambridge, 1862; appointed a lord of the admiralty, March, 1862; under secretary for war, April, 1863; secretary of state for war, Feb.—July, 1866; postmaster-general, Dec., 1868, to Jan., 1871; chief secretary for Ireland, Jan., 1871, to Feb., 1874; received the freedom of the city of Glasgow, Nov., 1877; lord rector of the university of Edinburgh, Jan., 1879; was returned for N.E. Lancashire in April, 1880, and became secretary of state for India; secretary of state for war, Dec., 1882, to June, 1885; was a royal commissioner for the Exhibition of 1886.

HARTNOLL, HENRY SULLIVAN, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Exeter Grammar School and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant commissioner, Burma, Dec., 1883; has officiated as deputy commissioner.

HARTT, WILLIAM EDWARD, Railway Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 19th April, 1876; assistant traffic superintendent, class 4, superior revenue establishment of state railways, 1878; class 3, Aug., 1879, and class 2, Jan., 1882; district traffic superintendent, 1882.

HARTWELL, SYDNEY CHARLES ELPHINSTONE, Railway Department, Government of India.—Appointed traffic superintendent, Oudh and Rohilkund railway, 1st Jan., 1889.

HARVEY, EDWARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India, 1st commission, 22nd Dec., 1859.—Served in the public works department from April, 1864; executive engineer, military works branch, June, 1871; served in the Lushai expedition, 1871-2 (medal and clasp), in the Jowaki Afridi campaign, 1878-9 (clasp), and in the Afghan war, 1879-80 (medal brevet of major); superintending engineer, May, 1889; member of accounts committee, 1888-9.

HARVEY, ROBERT, Brigade-Surgeon, M.B., late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission 1865; officiating civil surgeon, Sept. to Dec., 1865; officiating sanitary commissioner, Bengal, Jan., 1878; member of committee to report on management of the medical institutions, and on medical expenditure in Bengal, March, 1878; civil surgeon, Bankoora, May, 1878; officiating professor of midwifery, Medical College, Calcutta, and superintendent-general of vaccination, Aug., 1878; civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, and medical inspector of emigrants, Nov., 1878; also in medical charge of the Alipore and Russa jails, May, 1879; also superintendent of emigration, July, 1879; officiating professor of midwifery, medical college, and obstetric physician to the college hospital, Sept., 1880; confirmed in this
appointment, Sept., 1882; also officiating principal of the college, May to July, 1882; honorary surgeon on personal staff of H.E. the Viceroy, May, 1883; Brigade-Surgeon, Jan., 1889; retired, 1890.

HARVEY, WILLIAM LEATHEM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal Academical Institution, Belfast, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1884; forest settlement officer, April, 1887.

HARWARD, ALFRED EDGAR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rossall School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1885.

HASHMAT-ULLA, MAULVI, M.A., Bengal, C.S. (North-West Provinces.)—Appointed a probationer under the native civil service rules, March, 1886; assistant collector, Feb., 1888; confirmed as member of the civil service, June, 1889.

HASTED, JOHN ORD, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—2nd lieutenant, Madras engineers, Dec., 1853; arrived in India 2nd Dec., 1855; served in the Madras public works department from 30th Jan., 1856, as assistant engineer, and was promoted to executive engineer, April, 1865, and superintending engineer, Feb., 1877; officiated as chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government for various periods between 1875 and 1884; and was confirmed in this appointment and promoted to chief engineer, 2nd class, April, 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1883; chief engineer, 1st class, Sept., 1886; secretary to the government of Madras public works department general and buildings and road branches; retired, Nov., 1890.

HASTINGS, F. T. C., Political and Secret Department, India Office.—Educated at Haileybury College; admiralty writer, 8th Oct., 1868, to Jan., 1874; civil service copyist from Jan., 1874, to Feb., 1877; clerk specially attached to the political and secret department, India office, 7th March, 1877; resident clerk, July, 1888.

HASTINGS, CAPT. W., Bengal S.C.—1st commission, 28th Feb., 1874; served in Bengal as cantonment magistrate from Jan., 1881; 1st class, March, 1886; also judge of the small cause court.

HATCH, WILLIAM KEITH, Surgeon-Major, M.B.C.M. (Aber.), F.R.C.S. (London), Bombay Medical Department.—Arrived in India, 10 Nov., 1877; second surgeon of the Jamsetji Jijibhoy hospital, and professor of anatomy, &c., Grant medical college, May, 1884; acted as medical officer on the governor's personal staff, Jan. to March, 1885; surgeon-major, March, 1889.

HATCHELL, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 23rd July, 1858; arrived in India, 30th Sept., 1858; served in N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon from Dec., 1859, to Oct., 1864, and was subsequently employed under the military department, and served in the Bhootan expedition; served again under government of N.W. Provinces from Nov., 1869, and was appointed civil assistant surgeon, and superintendent of jail, Bulandshahr; rank of surgeon, July, 1870; served subsequently as civil surgeon at Bulandshahr, Jaunpur, Muzaffarnagar, Aligurh, and Farukhabad; senior surgeon-major, July, 1878; retired, Oct., 1888.

HATHORNTONTHWAITE, J. T., M.A. (Cam- tab.) Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 3rd Oct., 1872, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of mathematics at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, and also acted as principal of the college for various periods; promoted to 3rd grade of the education department, Dec., 1877.

HAWES, ARTHUR B., Captain, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster; ensign, Bengal army, 12th Dec., 1849; chief executive officer of telegraph from Baghdad to Constantinople, 1857-58; captain, May, 1858; retired, Oct., 1858; assistant auditor, India office, March, 1859; member of committee for valuation of military equipments, April, 1863; author of a work on small arms ammunition.

HAWKINS, CESAR RICHARD, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Harrow School, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1862; served in Bengal as assistant collector and magistrate, and from Feb., 1865, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Peshawur, March, 1870; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, 1876; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Jan., 1879; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; officiating divisional judge, Feb., 1885; officiating commissioner and superintendent, April, 1887; and again in Feb., 1888; confirmed, April, 1889; retired, Nov., 1889.

HAY, GEORGE WILLIAM ROBERTSON, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bombay Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1st April, 1868; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1868; served in the military, civil, and jail branches of the service, and was appointed port surgeon at Aden, June, 1876; also acted as secretary to the surgeon-general.

HAYWARD, MAURICE HENRY WESTON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1889, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

HAZLETT, HENRY JAMES, M.D.—Surgeon-major Madras medical department; joined the service 1st April, 1867; arrived in Madras 8th Nov., 1867, and was employed on general military and jail duty; on special duty as analyst to salt commission, Madras, Feb.-June, 1876; surgeon-major, April, 1879; surgeon 4th district, Jan., 1887, to May, 1888; also professor of medical jurisprudence in Medical College, Aug., 1887; employed in military accounts department of government of India, June, 1888.

HEATON, JOSEPH JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bradford Grammar School, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge; acting under secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, and educational departments, Oct., 1887; 3rd grade assistant judge and sessions judge, July, 1889.
HEAVISIDE, WILLIAM JAMES, Lieut.-Col., R.E., late Survey of India.—Joined Addiscombe, Aug., 1857; lieutenant, Bengal Engineers, June, 1859; arrived in India, Nov., 1861; served in the public works department as assistant engineer from Sept., 1862, to Feb., 1865; assistant field engineer with the Bhutan force, 1865-66 (medal and clasp); joined the great trigonometrical survey, as 2nd grade assistant, Jan., 1866; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1872; served with the Southern Afghanistan field force in 1878-79, on special survey duty (medal, brevet of major); served subsequently in Khandeish and Bombay native states, and was promoted to deputy superintendent, and grade, Nov., 1884; retired, July, 1888.

HEBERT, HENRY, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1832; arrived in India, 2nd March, 1833; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed deputy secretary to government in the Persian department, Jan., 1835; deputy collector of continental customs and excise, 1849; collector and magistrate of Broach, March, 1852; from March, 1853, served in the judicial department, and was appointed judge and sessions judge of Ahmedabad, July, 1853; judge and sessions judge, and agent for the governor, Surat, March, 1856; judge of the court of Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, 1857, and again in 1860; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, June, 1862; retired, May, 1863.

HENDERSON, EDWARD PIERCY (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and St. Peter's College, Radley; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; from Feb., 1878, has served as government advocate, Punjab.

HENDERSON, GEORGE, M.D., Surgeon-Major, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1859; arrived in India, 20th November, 1859; civil assistant surgeon, Shahpur, May, 1862; officiating professor of medicine and surgery, April, 1865, to Jan., 1867; superintendent of Lahore central jail, April, 1868; officiating superintendent, botanical gardens in Bengal, Dec., 1872; civil surgeon, Gujranwala, Dec., 1875, and subsequently at other stations in the Punjab; civil surgeon, 1st class, Oct., 1886; retired, Nov., 1889.

HENDERSON, PHILIP DURHAM, Colonel, C.S.I., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras cavalry, Feb., 1857; attache, foreign department, May, 1871; under secretary to the government of India, foreign department, Nov., 1872, to July, 1874; resident, 3rd class, on special duty in Cashmere, 1874; political officer on staff of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Sept., 1875; C.S.I., March, 1876; general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoity from March, 1878; graded as resident, 2nd class.

HENNESSY, SEPTIMUS HOPE, Judicial Department (Central Provinces). Joined the service as acting extra assistant commissioner, 13th July, 1864, and was confirmed 8th July, 1867; acted as deputy commissioner, and as judge small cause court for various periods, and was appointed to the latter office at Jubbulpore in Dec., 1889; acted also as cantonment magistrate in 1888-9.

HENNIKER, FREDERICK CHANDOS, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at St. Paul's School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885. Arrived in India 26th Nov., 1887, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner.

HENRY, CHARLES, Madras C.S.—Educated at the French College, Blackrock, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1885.

HENRY, EDWARD RICHARD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Edmund's College, Ware, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived, 22nd Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1882; on famine duty, Tirhoot, Dec., 1873; private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, July, 1879, to 1882; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, May, 1890.

HENSLOWE, CECIL WILLIAM EDWARD, late Railway Department.—Joined the public works department, June, 1866, as assistant engineer, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and in the Central Provinces (1870-71); transferred to railway establishment, Jan., 1880; engineer-in-chief and manager, Cawnpur-Farukhabad and Muttra-Hathras Railways, Dec., 1880; class 2, revenue establishment of state railways, May, 1881; manager, Cawnpur-Achneyra state railway, 1884; transferred to Burma state railway, Dec., 1886; retired, 1890.

HENVEY, FREDERICK, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Dec., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, under secretary to government, officiating secretary to board of revenue, and officiating junior secretary to government, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1869; placed on special duty for purpose of compiling a narrative of the famine of 1869-70, April, 1871; under secretary to government of India, foreign department, July, 1874; officiating resident, Nipal, Jan., 1877, to March, 1878; on special duty, Kashmir, April, 1878; resident, 2nd class, and commissioner, Hyderabad assigned districts, Jan., 1883; resident, Eastern Rajputana states, Dec., 1885; officiating agent to the governor-general in Central India, May, 1888; confirmed Jan., 1889.

HERALD, JOHN LUMGAIR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Arbroath High School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1883; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; assistant commissioner, Sylhet, Oct., 1888.

HERBERT, PATRICK C. H., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; junior clerk, accounts
branch, India Office, 11th March, 1872; judicial and public departments, 1877; resident clerk, 1885-88; editor of India Office list from July, 1887; compiled jointly with Mr. Newmarch the India Office cypher code.

HERRON, HERBERT GEORGE WHITBY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885. Arrived in India 27th Dec., 1887, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Nov., 1888, and officiating under secretary to chief commissioner.

HERSCHEL, JOHN, Colonel, F.R.S., R.E., late Survey of India.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1855; first commission, Dec., 1856; arrived at Calcutta, Jan., 1859; served in the great trigonometrical survey from Nov., 1859, in the grades of assistant surveyor and deputy superintendent; 1st grade deputy superintendent, Jan., 1884; retired, March, 1886.

HERVEY, HAMILTON LAW, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Giggleswick School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India 27th March, 1887; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1888.

HEWAT, RICHARD A., Military Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 13th Aug., 1858; junior clerk, military department, India office, Aug., 1866; senior clerk, Jan., 1875.

HEWETSON, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; served in Burma, from March, 1886, as assistant commissioner; judge, civil court, Mandalay, May, 1886; district officer, Kyaukpyu; returned to Madras, Oct., 1888; senior assistant to collector and district magistrate and agent, Ganjan, Aug., 1890.

HEWETT, JOHN PRESCOTT, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Winchester, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; in charge of provincial gazetteer, Aug., 1883; acted as assistant accountant-general, Jan., 1884; junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1884; officiating under secretary to government of India, home department, Oct., 1886, and confirmed in the appointment, Aug., 1887; officiated as private secretary to the viceroy, in 1888, and as secretary to Government of India home department, March, 1890; author of contributions to provincial gazetteer.

HEWISH, JOHN, Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 1st Feb., 1869; senior clerk (supernumerary) Sept., 1883.

HEWITT, JAMES FRANCIS KATHERINUS, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; arrived, 12th Feb., 1859; assistant magistrate and collector, Feb., 1860; officiating deputy commissioner, Lohardugga, July, 1863; settlement officer, Chuttergurh, Dec., 1864; deputy commissioner, wards' estate in Behar, Feb., 1873; officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1874; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Sept., 1874; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1878; commissioner, Chota Nagpur division, March, 1879; retired, July, 1885.

HEYWOOD, JOHN MAGEE, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined Addiscombe, Aug., 1854; 1st commission, Bengal engineers, June, 1856; arrived in India, April, 1858; served in the Bengal public works department from April, 1858, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; on special duty, Oct., 1866; deputed to examine reservoirs in France and Spain while on leave in 1867; ordered to report on arrangements connected with towing in inland rivers in Belgium; special survey duty, Sept., 1870; deputed on special duty to the N.W. Provinces and Punjab, Aug., 1876; superintending engineer, 2nd class, May, 1881; officiating chief engineer, and joint secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, April, 1883, to Feb., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1884; chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation branch, Punjab, 1886; chief engineer, 3rd class, Nov., 1886; retired, Dec., 1889.

HIGGENS, ALFRED WILLIAM BUCKLE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector; on famine duty, July, 1877, to Nov., 1878; on special duty as secretary to the draft forest bill committee, April-Nov., 1882; deputy conservator of forests, 1st grade, Cuddapah, Dec., 1882; also forest settlement officer, July, 1886; sub-collector and joint magistrate, June, 1890; has acted as district and sessions judge.

HIGGINS, JOHN JAMES, Police Department, Central Provinces.—Appointed acting adjutant military police, Narsinghpur, for services rendered during the mutiny under Sir Henry Havelock, Dec., 1858; from March, 1861, served in the police department of the Central Provinces, and was promoted to district superintendent, 1st class, June, 1879; on special duty at Kalahandi, June, to Aug., 1882.

HIGHAM, THOMAS, Public Works Department, Punjab.—Appointed probationary assistant engineer, July, 1867; arrived in India, Oct., 1867; served in the irrigation department, Punjab, and was promoted to executive engineer, Sept., 1873; assistant secretary to government, irrigation branch, Nov., 1882; superintendent of works, Derajat, Sept., 1883; superintending engineer, Aug., 1886; ditto, 3rd class, Jan., 1887.

HILDEBRAND, ARTHUR HEDDING, C.I.E., Burma Commission.—From Feb., 1868, to March, 1872, served in the Burma police department as assistant superintendent and acting superintendent; from March, 1872, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner, and was sent on special mission to Chiangmai, March, 1875, and in charge of expedition to Western Karenni, Jan., 1876; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1885; superintendent of the Shan States, Jan., 1886, C.I.E., May, 1888.

HILDEBRAND, GODFREY, Major, R.F., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, Oct., 1864; arrived in
India, Jan., 1868; joined the P.W. department, March, 1869, and served in Bengal and the N.W. Provinces; transferred to military works, May, 1872; secretary to defence committee, 1881; superintending engineer, March, 1886; headquarters staff deputy inspector-general, military works, Aug., 1887.

HILL, CLAUD HAMILTON ARCHER, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Mark's School, Windsor, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1835; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1837; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1838.

HILL, F. G., Funds Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 6th July, 1832.

HILL, HARRY CHARLES, Forest Department, Burma.—Arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1872, and appointed assistant conservator of forests; deputy conservator of forests, April, 1879; transferred to the Punjab as officiating conservator, Jan., 1883; conservator of forests, 2nd grade, and ex officio secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, in the forest department for Upper Burma, March, 1887; on deputation to India as officiating inspector-general of forests, July, 1889.

HILL, HENRY, Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy and Edinburgh University; India office writer, old establishment, 1859; junior clerk, financial department, 1860; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1867-74; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; revenue, statistics and commerce department, 1874; assistant secretary in the revenue, statistics, and commerce department, Sept., 1877; compiled the Annual Official Reports on Sanitary Measures in India from 1873-74 to 1877-78; and the Moral and Material Progress Reports from 1873-74 to 1875-76.

HILL, JOHN, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, royal engineers, June, 1862; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1865; appointed to the great trigonometrical survey of India as assistant surveyor, Dec., 1866, and was employed in Kumaon and Garhwal, and afterwards in Bombay, and on the eastern frontier; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Oct., 1870; deputy superintendent, July, 1882; attached to Afghan boundary commission, Sept., 1884; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Oct., 1884; in charge of Konkan topographical survey, Oct., 1884.

HILL, THOMAS COUTTS, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st Aug., 1857; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1867; superintendent, British Burma, Feb., 1879; 1st grade superintendent, March, 1885; employed in connexion with occupation of Upper Burma, 1886, class IV., 1st grade, Oct., 1887.

HILL, WILLIAM, Colonel, M.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Aug., 1853; served in the Mysore commission from July, 1859, as junior assistant; deputy superintendent, 3rd class, Mysore commission, Nov., 1862; deputy commissioner in Mysore, April, 1873; acted for various periods as commissioner in the Nandurdrug and Nagar Divisions; acting commissioner of Coorg, 1881; from March, 1885, served as civil and sessions judge of the civil and military station of Bangalore.

HILSON, ARCHIBALD HAMILTON, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the army medical department from Dec., 1855, to Oct., 1856; appointed assistant surgeon on the Bengal medical establishment, 29th Jan., 1857; arrived in India, 3rd June, 1857, and served under the military department in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab, including service in the Mutiny (medal), and in the Bhootan campaign (medal and clasp), also temporarily holding the civil surgeoncies of Moradabad, 1860, and Aligarh, 1863, and serving as civil assistant surgeon, Gorakhpur, 1864; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1869; from April, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, Naini Tal, and officiating civil surgeon at Bijnor and Moradabad; also held charge of the jails at Bijnor and Moradabad, and of the lock hospital at the latter place; civil surgeon, Naini Tal, Oct., 1874; civil surgeon, 1st class, and superintendent, lunatic asylum, and principal, medical school, Agra, March, 1876; brigade surgeon, Sept., 1884; deputy surgeon-general, Bengal, Dec., 1887; officiating inspector-general of civil hospitals from April, 1888; confirmed, April, 1889; deputy surgeon-general, Dec., 1888; author of various professional papers on snakebite, leprosy, and diseases of the eye, of a 'Memorandum on the Medical Education of the Native Women in India,' 1872, and of the annual reports of the Agra medical school, 1875 to 1886.

HOARE, HERBERT JAMES, Bengal C.S., (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at private schools and at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HOBART, ROBERT THOMPSON, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; deputy inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1873; inspector-general of prisons, Oct., 1882; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1886; retired, Dec., 1889.

HOBHOUSE (Baron), Rt. Hon. ARTHUR HOBHOUSE, Q.C., K.C.S.I., C.I.E.—Born 10th Nov., 1819; educated at Eton and Balliol College, Oxford, where he gained a first-class in classics in 1840; called to the bar, 1845, and practised in the Rolls court; Q.C. in 1855; appointed a charity commissioner in 1866; endowed schools commissioner, 1869; legal member of council of the governor-general of India, 1872-1877, K.C.S.I., Jan., 1877; arbitrator under the Epping Forest Act, 1878; privy councillor, and member of the judicial committee, 1881; created a baron in 1885; one of the quorum of the House of Lords for judicial purposes; author of 'The Dead Hand,' a collection of addresses connected with endowments and the settlements of land, 1880; contested Westminster unsuccessfully in the general election of 1880.

HOBHOUSE, ARTHUR F., late Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at Royal College, Boulogne; junior clerk, India board, political and secret department, 30th Oct., 1849; private secretary to the president, 1849-52; public department, 1852; private secretary to the permanent under secretary of state,
India Office (Sir George R. Clerk, K.C.B.), 1853-60; senior clerk, public department, 1860; assistant secretary in the public department, June, 1867; retired, June, 1887.

HOBHOUSE, Sir Charles Parry, Bart., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1844; arrived in India, 22nd July, 1844, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and in the financial department, government of India, as assistant to the sub-treasurer, and assistant to accountant-general; collector of Burdwan, 1857-59; magistrate and collector, 1859; officiating civil and sessions judge, 1859-60; deputed on special duty in 1860 to adjudicate on suits arising out of the indigo disturbances, Nuddea and Jessore; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, and government advocate, 1862, and also member of council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal for making laws and regulations, 1863-64; civil and sessions judge, 1864-66; on special duty in Calcutta to revise law relating to stamp duties; additional member of governor-general's council, 1866; on special duty as chairman of the Orissa famine and orphan relief fund, 1867; judge of the high court of judicature, 1868 to 1871; retired 1872.
