HODGKINSON, George James Spence, C.S.I., Bengal C.S., Burma.—Educated at Middle School, York, and Louth Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived 25th Nov., 1864; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Nov., 1865; manager of the Hutwa estates, Jan., 1872; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Feb., 1877; from March, 1877, to April 1878, acted as magistrate and collector of Moorsheadabad, and was in charge of office of agent to governor-general, June, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1878; transferred to British Burma as officiating commissioner, Arakan division, Dec., 1878; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, June, 1879; specially appointed a judge under the Land Acquisition Act, June, 1881; on special duty at Rangoon, June, 1881, and again in 1886; commissioner, Irrawaddy, July, 1881; additional sessions judge, Pegu and Irrawaddy, March, 1886; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; commissioner of Pegu division, May, 1888.

HODGSON, J., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 19th Aug., 1878.

HODSON, Richard George, Education Department, Burma.—Joined the education department as deputy inspector of schools, Mysore, April, 1861; inspector of schools, April, 1867; was for two years in special charge of all Canarese normal schools in the province; acting director of public instruction, Mysore and Coorg, April, 1879, to April, 1880; transferred to Burma as acting principal, government high school, Rangoon, April, 1880; from Oct., 1881, served as inspector of schools in Burma, and officiated as director of public instruction in 1884, and again in 1887 and 1888; has translated Munshi Srinivasaya's 'Dialogues in Canarese.'

HOEY, William, M.A., D.L., M.R.A.S., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Wesleyan Connexional School, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 18th Oct., 1872, and served in N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner, and assistant magistrate; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Sept., 1879; joint magistrate, 1st grade, s.p.t., March, 1885; has acted as magistrate and collector of Banda, Fatehpur, and Etawah, and was employed on archaeological explorations in Gonda in 1884; officiating deputy commissioner, Partabgurh, March, 1887; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Aug., 1887; deputy commissioner, March, 1890; author of contributions to the 'Gazetteer of Oudh,' and to the Imperial 'Gazetteer of India,' 'A Monograph on Trades and Manufactures in Northern India,' and 'A History of Asaf-ud-Daulah, Nawab Wazir of Oudh.'

HOGG, Adam George Forbes, Major-General, C.B., Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Jan., 1854; served with the Persian expedition, 1857 (medal and clasp), in the Indian mutiny, the China war, 1860, the Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68, as deputy adjutant quartermaster-general (medal and brevet of major), and in the Afghan war, 1870-80, as director of transport with Bombay reserve and brigade on Kandahar line, and, subsequently, with the Kabul field force (medal and clasp, brevet of colonel); appointed political resident and collector of stamp revenue with charge of the Vice-Admiralty court, Aden, May, 1885; reverted to military duty, 1890.

HOGG, Sir Frederic Russell, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India 12th Feb., 1857; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; postmaster-general, Punjab and Sind, July, 1863; officiating postmaster-general, Bombay, April, 1867; postmaster-general, Bengal, Nov., 1868; officiating deputy director-general of post office of India, March, 1870; officiating director-general, 1871-72, and again, 1873-76, and 1880-82; representative of the Government of India at the postal congress, Paris, 1878; confirmed as director-general of post office of India, March, 1882; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; K.C.I.E., May, 1888; retired, April, 1890.

HOGG, Stapleton C., Financial Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 25th July, 1861; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, 1862; financial department, 1863; senior clerk, Dec., 1875.

HOGG, Sir Stuart S., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1853; arrived in India, Jan., 1853; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner till 1859, and afterwards in Oudh as deputy commissioner; magistrate and collector, Burdwan, Bengal, 1861; chairman, justices of the peace, Calcutta, 1866; commissioner of police, Calcutta, and member of council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1874; retired 1878.

HOGG, Theodore William, Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, 28th Jan., 1858; served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner from Aug., 1867, and acted as cantonment magistrate, Jubulpore, 1874-80; also acting at various times as small cause court judge at the same place; small cause court judge, Nagpur, and deputy commissioner, 4th class, 1885.

HOJEL, Abraham Nickson, Brigade Surgeon, M.K. and Q.C.P., L.R.C.S. (Ir.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical ser-
vice 27th July, 1859; arrived in India, 16th Feb., 1860, and served under the military department till Feb., 1865; professor of anatomy and physiology, and curator of the museum, Grant Medical College, and assistant surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, Feb., 1865; also acted as surgeon to coroner of Bombay, and professor of medicine at the Grant Medical College; from July, 1866, to Nov., 1871, served in the Persian Gulf as civil surgeon, Bushire, and assistant to the resident; served subsequently under the military department, and as acting ophthalmic surgeon, presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay; appointed professor of physiology, Grant Medical College, and second physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, Sept., 1876; also acted as 1st physician of the hospital and principal of the college, March-April, 1878, as surgeon of the Gokuldas Tejpal Native General Hospital, Oct., 1883, to May, 1884; brigade surgeon, and confirmed as physician of the European General Hospital, April, 1887.

HOLDERNES, THOMAS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 17th Feb., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, March, 1877; junior secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1878, and officiated as secretary in 1879 and 1881; under secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Sept., 1881, to 1885; joint magistrate, N.W. Provinces, April, 1885; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1886; officiated as secretary to government in the financial department in 1887 and 1888; director of land records and agriculture, Nov., 1888.

HOLDICH, THOMAS HUNGERFORD, Lieut.-Colonel R.E., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, royal engineers, Dec., 1862; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1865; served on special survey duty in the Bhutan campaign, 1865 (frontier medal and clasp); joined the topographical survey as assistant superintendent, July, 1866; on special survey duty with the Abyssinian expedition, 1867-58 (medal); served subsequently in the Gwalior and Central India topographical survey, and was appointed to the charge of the Vizagapatam agency and Central Provinces' survey, Dec., 1873; joined the Afghanistan field force in 1879, and was in charge of survey operations in Northern Afghanistan during second period of the campaign, and was assistant field engineer during defence of Sherpur (medal and clasp); in charge of Kohat topographical survey, Feb., 1881; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1883; in charge of Biluchistan topographical survey, Oct., 1883; attached to the Afghan boundary commission, Sept., 1884; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, March, 1886; author of contributions to the records of the Royal Geographical Society, on the subject of the geography of Afghanistan and the Indian frontier; also to the journal of the Royal United Service Institute, on military instruction in topography.

HOLLIDAY, FREDERICK C., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 17th June, 1861; junior examiner, June, 1863; senior examiner, Dec., 1868.

HOLLOWAY, WILLIAM, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1848; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate till 1857, when he was appointed subordinate judge of Calicut; civil and sessions judge, Tellicherry, 1861; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, 1862; retired in 1877.

HOLMES, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Windermere College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating superintendent of Dehra Dun; appointed to take charge of H.H. Amir Yakub Khan, March, 1880; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, April, 1881; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, March, 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Dec., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, June, 1884; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Aug., 1887; magistrate and collector, Dec., 1888.

HOLMES, WILLIAM CUTHBERT, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; from June, 1881, to Aug., 1882, served in Bombay as officiating assistant accountant-general; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Coimbatore, Dec., 1884; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1890; has acted as district and sessions judge.

HOLMS, JOHN MITCHEL, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1883, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, April, 1889.

HOLMWOOD, HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Uppingham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1879; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1890.

HOLROYD, WILLIAM RICE MORLAND, Colonel, B.S.C., Educational Department, Punjab.—First commission as ensign, Dec., 1853; served from 11th Aug., 1858, in the Punjab educational department as inspector of schools, and was appointed director of public instruction, Punjab, Feb., 1868; 1st grade, education department, April, 1870; under secretary to government of Punjab, educational department, Oct., 1884.

HOLT, JAMES RICHARD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Becce College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1880, and served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating deputy superintendent, family domains of Maharaja of Benares, Oct., 1884; officiating under secretary to government, Nov., 1884, to Feb., 1885; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Nov., 1888; officiated in educational department, 4th grade, as professor in Muir Central College, May, 1888.
HOME, Alexander Lefevre, Bengal Forest Department.—From 1st March, 1864, served in the Forest Department in the Punjab, Central Provinces, and Bengal, and was appointed deputy conservator, 1st grade, and assistant comptroller-general of forests, Sept., 1882, and conservator of forests, 3rd grade, Bengal, April, 1883, 2nd grade, June, 1886.

HOME, Frederick Jervis, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 11th June, 1858; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1860; served in the public works department, N.W. Provinces, irrigation branch, from Feb., 1861, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and was employed on the Ganges, Eastern Jumna, and Agra canals, and other works; supervising engineer, irrigation branch, and joint secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, 1885; supervising engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886; on special duty in the Bhurtpur state, Oct., 1886; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary, Punjab, Nov., 1886; supervising engineer, class I., Nov., 1887; 3rd chief engineer and joint secretary to Government of the Punjab, Dec., 1889.

HOME, Robert, Colonel, C.I.E., R.E., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1853; assistant engineer, irrigation department, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1856; transferred to Punjab, Nov., 1858; executive engineer, July, 1861; superintendent of works, Sutlej canal, Nov., 1867, and afterwards on the Sirhind canal, Jan., 1869; supervising engineer, Sirhind canal circle, Dec., 1869; officiating chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government of Punjab, Dec., 1876, to Jan., 1879; chief engineer and joint secretary for irrigation, Punjab, 1882; officiating inspector-general of irrigation, and deputy secretary to government of India, public works department, in 1884 and 1885; confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1886; chief engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886; retired, Dec., 1889.

HOOKER, W. H., Store Department, India Office.—Supervisor, 2nd grade, India store depot, Aug., 1877; 1st grade, July, 1883.

HOOPER, John, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1871, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; settlement officer, Basti, Nov., 1884; 1st grade, April, 1889; magistrate and collector, April, 1890.

HOOPER, William Roe, Brigade Surgeon, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, Feb., 1859; arrived in India, Aug., 1859, and served in Bengal, holding various military medical charges; from July, 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, and was appointed superintendent of central prison, Benares, Dec., 1864; rank of surgeon, Feb., 1871; civil surgeon of Benares, Sept., 1874; senior surgeon-major, Feb., 1879; brigade surgeon, March, 1887.

HOPE, Charles William Webley, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Mannamead School, Plymouth, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, and Dec., 1885, and served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HOPE, James, B.A., late Madras C.S.—Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1863; served in Bombay from Oct., 1864, to July, 1867, and subsequently in Madras, and was appointed principal assistant collector, Ganjam, Sept., 1870; acted as collector and magistrate and political agent in the districts of Ganjam, Kurnool, and Godavari, 1870-77; from Jan., 1877, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge of Chingleput, and from Dec., 1882, in South Arcot; retired, 1888.

HOPE, Sir Theodore Cracraft, K.C.S.I., C.I.E. (Barrister-at-Law), late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 5th June, 1853, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and educational inspector; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May, 1860; president of committee on finances of educational department, March, 1861; joint commissioner with the secretary in the public works department to receive North Kanara from the Madras government, Feb., 1862; deputy commissioner of customs, salt, and opium, Oct., 1862; collector and magistrate, Kaira, Jan., 1867; collector and magistrate and agent to governor, Surat, March, 1867; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, Nov., 1871; acting commissioner of customs and opium, Nov., 1874; member of tariff committee at Calcutta, Dec., 1874; from July, 1875, served as additional member of the governor-general's council for making laws and regulations, also acting as secretary to the government of India in department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, and was appointed additional secretary for famine, Dec., 1876; reappointed as additional member of governor-general's council in 1877 and 1878; commissioner, Northern division, and agent to governor, Surat, Jan., 1878; on special political duty in England, Oct.-Nov., 1878; provisional member of council of governor of Bombay, Oct., 1880; commissioner, 1st grade, July, 1881; from April, 1881, acted as secretary to government of India, finance and commerce department, and was confirmed in this appointment, Aug., 1881; ordinary member of governor-general's council in charge of public works department, July, 1882; retired, Jan., 1888.

HOPKINS, E. S., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 14th Nov., 1883.

HOPKINS, Henry Mayne Reid, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dulwich College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1887, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HOPKINS, John Arthur, B.L., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived, 14th Oct., 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; also served as officiating district superintendent of police, March, 1872, inspector of schools, 1872-76, and officiating...
inspector-general of registration, July, 1875, to March, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1884; officiating commissioner, Chota Nagpore division, June, 1888; and of Orissa division, and superintendent of tributary mehals, Cuttack, Feb., 1889.

HOPKINSON, WILLIAM, Colonel Bengal Infantry.—First commission, 1859; from 28th Nov., 1867, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, as assistant commissioner, and sub-registrar of assurances; cantonment magistrate, Dinapore, March, 1874, and subsequently of Barrackpore, and small cause court judge, Nov., 1875; deputy-commissioner, 3rd grade, April, 1886; cantonment magistrate, Dinapore, March, 1887.

HORDERN, PETER, B.A., late Educational Department, Burma.—Appointed to the education department, 10th Nov., 1861; arrived in India, March, 1862; assistant professor of English literature, Presidency College, Calcutta, March, 1862; director of public instruction, British Burma, Nov., 1867; fellow of Calcutta University, April, 1876; retired, 1889; author of a 'Handbook of Rules and Practice of the Education Department, Burma.'

HORNE, WILLIAM OGILVIE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting deputy registrar, high court, Sept., 1886, to July, 1887; head assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1890.

HORSFALL, JEREMIAH GARNETT, C.I.E., B.L., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Giggleswick Grammar School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed district and sessions judge, South Malabar, April, 1878, and collector and magistrate, Kistna, Jan., 1879, and afterwards in Vizagapatam and Ganjam; retired, April, 1890; C.I.E., May, 1890.

HORSFALL, THOMAS MENDELSSOHN (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at the Wilhelms-Gymnasium, Berlin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1880, and again, Sept., 1881; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, Madura, Dec., 1884, also forest settlement officer, Nov., 1885; acted as collector and magistrate; member of the board of examiners, May, 1888; registrar of high court (appellate side) Sept., 1888.

HORSFORD, NORMAN MACLEOD THOMAS, Colonel B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, Bengal Infantry, 29th Dec., 1857; served at the siege and capture of Lucknow, March, 1858, at the action of Nawabganj, June, 1858, and at the capture of Fort Oomerin, in Oudh, Dec. 1858 (medal and clasp); from Aug., 1861, to Dec., 1867, served in the police department, N.W. Provinces, as assistant inspector-general, and district superintendent; from Dec., 1867, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; junior secretary, to chief commissioner, Aug., 1869, to Jan., 1874; and acted for various periods as personal assistant to chief commissioner; officiating director of public instruction, Oct., 1873, to Jan., 1874; superintendent of encumbered estates, Rae Bareli, 1874-76; officiating superintendent of excise and stamps, and inspector-general of registration, April, 1876; cantonment magistrate, Lucknow, March, 1878; city magistrate and Wasika officer, Lucknow, April, 1883; officiating assistant director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Aug.-Nov., 1884; district judge, 3rd grade, April, 1886; deputy commissioner, March, 1887.

HORSLEY, WILLIAM HENRY, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's School, Canterbury, and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870; served as assistant collector and magistrate, and was in charge of the forests in Khandaish, Oct., 1872, to Feb., 1874; employed from March to Oct., 1874, on famine relief operations in Dinapore, in Bengal, and subsequently on forest demarcation work in Khandaish; on famine duty, Kaladgi, Aug., 1877; forest settlement officer, Nov., 1878; second assistant collector and acting junior collector and magistrate, Sept., 1883; from June, 1884, acted as assistant judge and sessions judge, and from May, 1886, as 2nd grade judge; joint judge and sessions judge, May, 1887.

HORSPPOOL, W. P., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Educated at the Newark Collegiate School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th Aug., 1878.

HÖRST, HENRY, late Survey Department, Government of India.—Librarian and accountant, Thomason College, Roorkee, Jan., 1853; sub-assistant, great trigonometrical survey, Sept., 1854; in charge of picket which repulsed night attack on Murree Sanitarium, Sept., 1857 (mutiny medal); transferred to topographical survey, senior department, April, 1868; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Oct., 1869; served in various parts of India, and was appointed deputy superintendent, Burma topographical survey, Sept., 1882; 3rd grade, deputy superintendent, Nov., 1884; retired, 1889.

HOSE, JOHN WALTER, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dulwich and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1886; and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HOSKING, EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1869, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and registrar of the high court; judge and sessions judge, Khandaish, Jan., 1884; and grade judge, Sept., 1885; district judge, Thana, March, 1888; judge and sessions judge, Karachi, April, 1890.

HOSKING, W. H., late Store Department, India Office.—Assistant to supervisor of stamps, 1st Aug., 1861; superintendent of stamps, June, 1869; retired, Dec., 1886.
HOSKINS, WILLIAM HENRY, Colonel M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras infantry, July, 1853; arrived in India, 7th Sept., 1853; served in Madras police department from May, 1863, as assistant superintendent and superintendent (1st grade, Feb., 1885).

HOUGHTON, BERNARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at All Saints, Bloxham, Wellingborough Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 23rd Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1885; transferred for employment in Burma, Aug., 1886; assistant commissioner, and grade, Dec., 1888; also acted as deputy commissioner.

HOUSE, HENRY FREDERICK, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bristol Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Jan., 1890.

HOUSLEY, ARTHUR W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th Feb., 1872; junior clerk, June, 1882.

HOUSTON, JOHN, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., late Madras Medical Department.—Appointed, 4th Aug., 1855; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1856, and served in Mysore in various military charges, and also as civil surgeon, chemical examiner, and superintendent of jail; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; from July, 1871, served as surgeon to the Mysore commission; brigade surgeon, June, 1881; officiating residency surgeon, May, 1883; surgeon to the Mysore government; retired, March, 1886.

HOWARD, EDWARD STAFFORD.—Educated at Harrow, and Trinity College, Cambridge; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1875; represented East Cumberland in the House of Commons from April, 1876, till the general election of 1885, when he was returned for the Thornbury division of Gloucestershire, but lost his seat in the succeeding election of 1886; under secretary of state for India, April-Aug., 1886.

HOWARD, WILLIAM STUART, Bombay Public Works Department.—Joined the service as probationer, 10th June, 1839; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; assistant engineer, 1st class, April, 1864; executive engineer, Dec., 1865; acted as principal, engineering college, Poona, 1867; acting secretary to the Government of Bombay, public works, Sept., 1867; chief engineer, Aug., 1888.

HOWELL, ARTHUR PEARSE, M.A., late Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces.)—Educated at St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1858; from May, 1859, to April, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, assistant secretary, and acting under secretary to the government; from April, 1864, to March, 1878, served in the secretariat of the government of India, first as under secretary, financial department, and then as under secretary and acting secretary, home department; also as acting deputy secretary, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, and was placed on special duty March, 1869; commissioner, Jubbulpore division, Central Provinces, April, 1877; secretary, famine commission, March, 1878; on special duty, June, 1878; commissioner, Nerbudda division, Sept., 1878; acting judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1879, to Feb., 1880, and again in 1883; commissioner Hyderabad assigned districts, June to Dec., 1882; member of education commission under the government of India, Dec., 1882, to Sept., 1883; commissioner, Nerbudda Division, Sept., 1883; officiating resident, 1st class, Hyderabad, March, 1888, retired, Aug., 1889; author of notes (2) on education in India in 1866-67 and 1870-71, the former of which was presented to parliament; of a note on jails and jail discipline in India, and of a paper on educational legislation.

HOWELL, MORTIMER SLOPER, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from Jan., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating inspector of public instruction, April, 1867; assistant superintendent and small cause court judge, Dehra Dun, March, 1868; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Feb., 1871; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1879; from March, 1880, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge in various districts; author of a grammar of the classical Arabic language.

HUDLESTON, WILLIAM, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; assistant collector and magistrate, Canara, July, 1847; head assistant, Chingleput, May, 1854; head assistant and acting deputy registrar, court of Sudder Adawlut, Sept., 1854; deputy secretary to government in the departments under the chief secretary, Feb., 1855; secretary to board of examiners, March, 1855; acting deputy secretary in the revenue and public works department, Dec., 1857; acting deputy collector of sea customs, Madras, May, 1858; sub-secretary, board of revenue, July, 1858; secretary, board of revenue, April, 1861; secretary to government, revenue department, Jan., 1867; chief secretary to government, Nov., 1872; member of council, June, 1877; acted as governor of Madras, May to Nov., 1881; retired, June, 1882.

HUDSON, CHARLES WILLIAM MAITLAND, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Doveton Protestant College, Madras, Madras University, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1887; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1888.

HUDSON, WILLIAM HERBARD, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1861; from Jan., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; from Dec., 1873, to Jan., 1875, served under the government of Bengal on famine duty in Behar; from May, 1880, served in the judicial department, N.W. Provinces, as civil and sessions judge; retired, Jan., 1890.

HUGHES, ARTHUR JOHN, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service 11th July, 1862 and arrived in India 7th Dec., 1862; executive engineer Dec.,
1869; assistant secretary to Government of Bengal irrigation branch, May, 1872; on famine works, Salem district, Sep., 1877; served under the foreign department in Kashmir, Dec., 1883 to Feb., 1885; superintending engineer, Nov. 1888.

HUGHES, David Eskeine, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., F.R.C.S. (Ed.), Bombay Medical Service.—Joined the service, March, 1866; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1866; served under the military department, and also acted as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Satara, 1880-81, as surgeon of the European general hospital, Bombay, 1881, and as civil surgeon at Surat, 1881-82; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Belgaum, from May, 1882; brigade surgeon, Oct., 1888; has acted as deputy sanitary commissioner, and as first physician of the Jamsetji Jijibhoy hospital.

HUGHES, Edward William Mackenzie, Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, April, 1871, as assistant engineer, Punjab, irrigation, and was employed on the Sirdh canal; locomotive superintendent, Dhond-Manmad state railway, May, 1879; locomotive superintendent, Indus valley railway, Feb., 1881; class i., state railway locomotive establishment, Jan., 1886; deputy locomotive superintendent, North-Western railway, Jan., 1886.

HUGHES, George, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Liverpool Institute, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating district judge; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Nov., 1887; posted to Ferozepore settlement, Feb., 1888; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, May, 1889.

HUGHES, Theodore William Hughes, A.R.S.M., F.G.S., Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined, 11th Nov., 1862; was employed chiefly in the Central Provinces, Central India, and Bengal, in connection with coal and iron deposits; 1st grade officer, April, 1883; superintendent Rewah coal explorations from March, 1883; designation changed to deputy superintendent of the geological survey of India; superintendent, April, 1887; author of contributions to the survey publications.

HUGHES, William Gwynne, Colonel, M.S.C., late Burma Commission.—First commission as ensign, June, 1853; arrived in India, 11th Sept., 1853; was employed on military duty and in the police department Burma, till June, 1864; transferred to the Burma commission, June, 1864, and served as assistant commissioner in the Amherst district, cantonment magistrate of Rangoon, town magistrate of Akayab, superintendent of the Hill Tracts, Arakan (Nov., 1871), and deputy commissioner (1st grade, July, 1886); author of 'The Hill Tracts of Arakan,' retired, June, 1889.

HUGHESDON, Joseph Charles, Barrister-at-Law, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Sutton Valence Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, small cause court judge, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; on famine duty, June, 1877; appointed district and sessions judge, Tinnevelly, March 1880; retired, Aug., 1888.

HUME, Allan Octavian, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1849; arrived in India, 7th March, 1849; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Etawah, March, 1858; officiating civil and sessions judge, Bareilly, May, 1857; commissioner of customs, N.W. Provinces, Punjab, and Central Provinces, July, 1867; officiating secretary to government of India, home department, 1870-71; secretary to government of India in department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, June, 1871; member of board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1879; retired, 1882.

HUME, William Wheler, Colonel, B.S.C., late Bengal Police.—1st commission, 5th Aug., 1854; served in the Indian mutiny with the Meerut volunteer cavalry; afterwards as a volunteer with the artillery during siege and capture of Delhi (medal and clasp); district superintendent of police, Aug., 1863; 1st grade, April, 1888; reverted to military duty, 1889.

HUMPHREY, John, Major, Bombay Police Department.—Joined the service, 2nd June, 1865, and arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1865; Lieutenant in staff corps, Nov., 1863; served in the Abyssinian expedition in charge of commissariat camel train (medal), Nov., 1863; assistant superintendent of police, Aug., 1873; on special duty in political department for short periods in 1873, 1874, 1876, 1877, 1883; superintendent of police, Aug., 1875; inspector-general of police, Bombay, February, 1890; on special duty to England with Thaker Sahib of Morvi's eldest son, March, 1890.

HUMPHRYS, I. H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the Royal School, Raphoe, and Trinity College, Dublin (exhibitioner and prizeman); clerk, 2nd class, 5th July, 1872; junior clerk, Feb., 1876.

HUNT, Samuel, Funds Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, East India House, examiner's office, 18th June, 1851; revenue department, India office, 1858; senior clerk, Aug., 1860; financial department, 1867; funds department, 1882.

HUNT, Samuel Bradshaw, Brigade-Surgeon, Madras Medical Service.—Assistant surgeon, 31st March, 1865; arrived, 10th Dec., 1865, and served under the military department, and also as civil surgeon at Coimbatore and at Vizagapatan with charge of the jail and lunatic asylum; from May, 1875, served as surgeon in the 4th, and subsequently in the 3rd district, Madras, also as medical officer of Coonoor and Kotagiri, Feb., 1881, to April, 1883; surgeon-major, March, 1877; brigade surgeon, Aug., 1886.

HUNTER, Frederick Mercer, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., C.S.I., C.B., Political department, Bombay.—Arrived in India as ensign, Bombay infantry, June 1861; was employed on military duty up to Aug., 1871, from which date he served as assistant political resident at Aden; also acted on various occasions as political resident, as cantonment magistrate, and as Arabic interpreter; first assistant at Aden, Sept., 1880; also political agent for the Somali coast, and collector of abkari and deputy collector.
of salt revenue; acting political agent at Aden, 1887, and at Cutch, July, 1888; confirmed in latter appointment, Feb., 1889.

HUNTER, GEORGE YEATES, Brigade-Surgeon, M.R.C.S. (Lon.), L.S.A., late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 23rd July, 1858; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1858, and served in the military department, and as civil surgeon in various stations; acting second surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, acting professor of anatomy, Grant Medical College, and curator of the museum, Bombay, April-Oct., 1872; acting superintendent of lunatic asylum, Colaba, Nov.-Dec., 1872; civil surgeon, Karachi, Feb., 1882; presidency surgeon, Bombay, in medical charge of jail, house of correction, Byculla Schools and Elphinstone College, May, 1884; brigade surgeon, Feb., 1885; retired, Oct., 1888.

HUNTER, JOHN MUIR, Lieut.-Col., Bombay, S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, R.A., April, 1864; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1865; boundary settlement officer, Baroda and Mahi Kantha states, Oct., 1866; from June, 1872, served as assistant political agent in Mahi Kantha, Kolhapur, and Kathiawar; assistant to the political agent and magistrate of Kathiawar state railway, Jan., 1880; from Feb., 1883, served as superintendent of surveys under the Rajasthani court, Kathiawar, and was employed on special duties in settling claims in dispute between native states, from Dec., 1884; acting president, Rajasthani court, May, 1887.

HUNTER, SIR WILLIAM GUYER, Surgeon-General, M.D., K.C.M.G., F.R.C.P., F.R.C.S., M.P.—Educated at King's College, London, Aberdeen University, and at various hospitals; joined the Bombay medical service, 1859; served in the Burmese war and Indian Mutiny; principal of the Grant Medical College, Bombay, 1868; surgeon-major, Feb., 1870; surgeon-general, Bombay, Feb., 1877; vice-chancellor of the university of Bombay, 1879; retired, March, 1880; consulting physician to Charing Cross Hospital, 1883; served on the cholera commission in Egypt, 1883; British delegate to the international sanitary conference at Rome, June, 1885; hon. commandant of the volunteer medical staff corps, Sept. 1885; was returned to the House of Commons for Hackney (central division) in 1885, and again in 1886; is a member of the London school-board.

HUNTER, SIR WILLIAM WILSON, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., M.A. (Oxford), and LL.D. (Cambridge), late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Universities of Glasgow, Paris, and Bonn; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 10th Nov., 1862; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1863; superintendent of labour transport, Kooshtea, July, 1865; on deputation for compiling a history of Beerbboom, March, 1866; officiating inspector of schools, May, 1866; officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, Dec., 1868; compiler of 'Bengal Gazetteer,' and on deputation in home department, government of India, July, 1869; compiler of 'Gazetteer of India,' Jan., 1871; officiating under-secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1871; director general of statistics, government of India, Sept., 1871; on special duty to England for purpose of compiling statistical account of Bengal, and 'Imperial Gazetteer,' March, 1875, and March, 1876; on special duty in England, March, 1877, to Nov., 1881; director-general of gazetteers, Oct., 1877; C.I.E., 1878; director-general of gazetteers and statistics, June, 1878; director-general of statistics, Dec., 1881; additional member, governor-general's council, Dec., 1881, and again Dec., 1883 and Dec., 1885, president of the education commission, Feb., 1882 to Nov., 1883; deputed to England to give evidence before the committee of the House of Commons on Indian railways, May, 1884; C.S.I., 1884; member of the finance committee, Feb., 1886; K.C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired, Sept., 1887; author of 'The Annals of Rural Bengal,' 1868; 'A Dictionary of the Non-Aryan Languages of India and High Asia,' 1868; pamphlets on Indian legislation and finance, 1869; memorandum on the older records of the board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, 1870; 'The Indian Mussulmans,' 1871; The Province of Orissa, 1872; Famine Aspects of Bengal Districts, 1874; a Collected Edition of Essays on the External Policy of India, by the late J. W. S. Whyte, 1875; 'A Life of Lord Mayo,' 2 vols., 1875; 'A Statistical Account of Bengal,' 20 vols., 1875-77; summary of certain of the older M.S. Records in the India Office, 1878; a Statistical Account of Assam, 1879; a brief history of the Indian people, 1880; The Imperial gazetteer of India, 9 vols., 1881; The Indian Empire, 1881; 'England's Work in India,' 1881; 'A Brief History of the Indian People,' &c.

HURRY, ARNOLD EARDLEY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at City of London School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1882, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner. Transferred to Burma, 1886; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Dec., 1888; deputy commissioner, May, 1890.

HUTCHESON, G., Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.M., I.M.S.—Joined the service as assistant surgeon, 1st Oct., 1866; surgeon, July, 1873; surgeon-major, Oct., 1880; served on general and military duty, and from Feb., 1870, to Sept., 1871, on special duty as chemical analyst; on special duty, cholera enquiry, Sept., 1872, to Dec., 1873; officiated as statistical officer to the Government of India, in the sanitary and medical department; sanitary commissioner and superintendent-general of vaccination, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1889; author of 'Cholera, its causes, and mode of dissemination.'

HUTCHINGS, F. S., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 23rd June, 1879.

HUTCHINS, PHILIP PERCEVAL, C.S.I. (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acted as deputy secretary to government in the revenue department in 1862 and 1863, and in the departments under the chief secretary in 1862, as secretary to board of examiners in 1863, and as judge of the court of small causes, Chittoor, Sept., 1863; private secretary to governor of Madras, Nov., 1863; registrar, high court, March, 1865; from Feb., 1869, acted as civil and sessions judge in various places, and was appointed district and sessions judge, Madura, April, 1873; member of rent law committee, Sept., 1882; acting secretary, revenue department, Dec., 1882; on special duty
in connection with reorganization of judicial establishments, March, 1883; board of examiners, May, 1883; judge of the high court, Madras, Nov., 1883; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1883; member of governor's council, Dec., 1886; C.S.I., Jan., 1883; member of the council of the governor-general, Nov., 1883.

HUTCHINSON, H. S., Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C. Survey of India, 1st Commission, Lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, 9th Dec., 1859.—Arrived in India, 9th April, 1860; served with the artillery until Aug., 1867, when he was admitted to the staff corps, and appointed to the survey department, as assistant superintendent; received charge of Bassein district cadastral survey, May, 1883; deputy superintendent, Aug., 1884; 3rd grade, April, 1889.

HUTCHINSON, JAMES BIRD, Lieut.-Col., B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 26th May, 1864; from March, 1868, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; district judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Dec., 1883; services placed at the disposal of the Government of India, Aug., to Oct., 1887; deputy-commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1888; 1st grade, Dec., 1889; has published a Guide to Dalhousie, and a general index of regulations and acts in force in the Punjab.

HUTTON, EDWARD, Postal Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as superintendent of mails, Jubbulpore, 10th Feb., 1858; superintendent travelling post office, Nov., 1877; inspector, field force Peshawur column, Feb., 1879; presidency postmaster at Calcutta, April, 1881.

HYNES, G. J., Post Office Department.—Entered the post office department, 4th May, 1868; assistant director-general of the post office of India, Oct., 1880; deputy postmaster-general, Burma, June, 1887.

IBBETSON, DENZIL CHARLES JELF, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Collegiate School, Adelaide (South Australia), and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; deputy superintendent, census, Punjab, Aug., 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1889; compiler, 'Punjab Gazetteer,' March, 1883; officiating director of public instruction, March, 1884; deputy commissioner 3rd grade, April, 1885; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, Nov., 1885; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Oct., 1889; officiated as 2nd financial in the Punjab in 1890; has published 'Census Report of the Punjab,' 'Report on the Settlement of the Karnal District,' 'Outlines of Punjab Ethnography,' 'Gazetteer of the Districts of the Punjab.'

ILBERT, COURTENAY PEREGRINE, C.S.I., C.I.E.—Educated at Marlborough, and Oxford; scholar, and afterwards fellow of Balliol College; first class (classics), moderations, 1862, and in the final schools, 1864; Hertford scholar, 1861; Ireland scholar, 1864; Craven scholar, 1864; Eldon Law scholar, 1867; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn, 7th June, 1869; counsel to education department, 1878-82; took his seat as law member of the council of the governor-general of India, 1st May, 1882, and was president of the council, 3rd Feb. to 8th March, 1886; resigned, 13th Nov., 1886; vice-chancellor of Calcutta University, Feb., 1885 to Nov., 1886; assistant parliamentary counsel to the treasury, 1886.

IMPEY, WILLIAM HENRY LOCKINGTON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, Naini Tal, Nov., 1886; under-secretary to government of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Dec., 1887; settlement officer, 2nd grade, Oct., 1889.

INAM ALI, MAULVI, Punjab Commission.—Appointed assistant professor, Government College, Lahore, 31st Oct., 1887; appointed probationer under native civil service rules, 4th Feb., 1888; and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

INCH, G. F., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 9th Oct., 1879.

INGLIS, JOHN FORBES DAVID, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1840; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed junior under-secretary to the government of India, foreign department, in 1846; assistant to resident at Lahore, 1847; deputy commissioner in the Punjab, 1849; magistrate and collector of Barcilly, 1858; judge of Moradabad, 1862; commissioner of Rohilkund 1864; member of board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, 1867; additional member of governor-general's council, 1870, and was reappointed in 1873 and 1875; temporarily finance member of governor-general's council, April to Dec., 1874; officiating chief commissioner of Oudh, March-Nov., 1875, and again in July, 1876; retired, Feb., 1877.

INGLIS, THOMAS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Wellington College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1880; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

INNES, JAMES JOHN McLEOD, Lieutenant-General, V.C., R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—First commission in Bengal engineers, 1848; served under the civil engineer, Punjab, from 1852; assistant engineer, Bari Doab canal, 1854; assistant to chief engineer, Oudh, Jan., 1857; during the mutiny served at the defence of Lucknow, the battle of Cawnpore, the action of Sultanpur, and the siege of Lucknow (medal and two clasps, V.C.); executive engineer, Cawnpore, Dec., 1857; garrison engineer, Presidency, April, 1858; controller and examiner of accounts, Lahore, Feb., 1861; officiating accountant-general, public works department, 1865-66, and again 1867-68; on special duty on Bank of Bombay committee, 1868-69; superintending engineer, Punjab, Oct., 1869; accountant-general and deputy secretary, public works department, June, 1870; chief engineer, 1st class, Sept., 1881, and deputy inspector-general, military works; inspector-general of military works, 1882; retired, 1886.
INNES, Lewis Charles, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Haileybury, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1844; served as assistant collector and magistrate in various districts till Jan., 1855, and afterwards in the judicial department, and was appointed sub-judge of Combaconum, Feb., 1856, and civil and sessions judge of Nundial, July, 1858; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, Feb., 1865, to Sept., 1883, and officiated on several occasions as chief justice; fellow of the University of Madras, 1865 to 1883, and was on the syndicate, 1873-83; vice-chancellor of the university, 1874 to 1880.

INNES, William, Railway Department, Government of India.—Appointed class II, superior revenue establishment state railways, July, 1884; served on the Eastern Bengal and the Punjab Northern state railways, and was appointed traffic superintendent, Burma state railway, Nov., 1885; class I, grade 3, July, 1889.

IRELAND, William de Courcy, B.A., LL.D., Burma Commission.—Joined the service as accountant in office of commissioner of Pegu, April, 1859; assistant superintendent of forests, Toungoo, April, 1860; collector of customs, Nov., 1860; from April, 1861, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, town magistrate, and deputy commissioner (1st grade, June, 1879); on special duty, Aug., 1878; acted as inspector-general of police in 1875, 1881-1883, and 1885, and as commissioner of Arakan, June-Sept., 1880; boundary officer, Akyab district, Sept., 1880; additional sessions judge, Tenasserim, Jan., 1886; commissioner Irrawaddy division, July, 1886, and Arakan division, Jan., 1890.

IRVINE, George Duncan, Madras C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from May, 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting collector of sea customs at Madras and protector of emigrants, and acting collector and magistrate; district and sessions judge, Kurnool, July, 1882, and afterwards in Trichinopoly.

IRVINE, Robert Hamilton Grant, Bengal Police.—Joined the service as deputy magistrate and deputy collector, Aug., 1861; appointed assistant superintendent of police, April, 1863; district superintendent, July, 1869; 1st grade, July, 1889.

IRVINE, William, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. Anne's School, Brixton, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from May, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting cantonment magistrate, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty under the board of revenue, Jan. to April, 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Ghazipur, Dec., 1881; 1st grade, July, 1885; retired, 1888; author of 'Canal Rates versus Land Revenue,' 'The Rent Digest: or the Law Procedure relating to Landlord and Tenant, Bengal,' 'Bangash Nawabs of Farukhabad,' and settlement report of Ghazipur district.

IRVING, L.A., Surgeon-Major, Army Medical Department.—Medical officer on the personal staff of the governor of Bombay (Rt. Hon. D. J. M. Lord Reay, LL.D., C.I.E.), 31st March, 1885.

IRWIN, Alfred Macdonald Bulteel, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1876, and served in the Punjab till June, 1877, and subsequently in British Burma as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Aug., 1886 and 3rd grade, Dec., 1888.

IRWIN, George Robert, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Uppingham, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1878, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating city magistrate, Lucknow; assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, Dec., 1886; officiating junior secretary, Nov., 1887, and May, 1888, and under secretary, Foreign department, April, 1889.

IRWIN, Henry, C.I.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Joined the service as assistant engineer, Central Provinces, 1st Feb., 1868; executive engineer, Sept., 1872; superintendent of works, Simla imperial circle, Oct., 1881; transferred to Madras public works department as superintending engineer, and appointed consulting architect to government, Sept., 1889.

IRWIN, Henry Crossly, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School, St. Edmund's Hall, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1871, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Oct., 1886; deputy commissioner, July, 1889; magistrate and collector, Nov., 1889; author of 'The Garden of India,' or Chapters on Oudh History and Affairs.

ISAACSON, S. H. H., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Writer, India Office, 15th April, 1869; clerk, 2nd class, Sept., 1878.

ISMAY, Stanley (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1871; served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting inspector of schools, acting district superintendent of police, and acting deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty in the Kalahandi state, Jan., 1882; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, May, 1884; officiating inspector-general of police and jails, May to Nov., 1885, and again in April, 1890.

IZAT, Alexander, M.I.C.E. late Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1863, as assistant engineer, Hyderabad; executive engineer, March, 1868; transferred to railway branch, 1870, as executive engineer, Nizam's state railway; Holkar state railway, Oct., 1874; transferred to Dhoond and Manmad railway, Bombay, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Kathiawar state railways, 1879; engineer-in-chief, Bombay Eastern Deccan state railway, Aug., 1879; superintending engineer, 3rd
class, April, 1880; officiating under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Jan., 1883; services lent to Bengal and N.W. Railway company as agent and chief engineer, Feb., 1883; 1st superintending engineer, Feb., 1887; retired, 1889.

JACKSON, ARTHUR MASON TIPPEETS, BOMBAY C.S., B.A., B.L.—Educated at Westminster School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India 17th December, 1885, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

JACKSON, CHARLES JULIAN, Brigade-Surgeon, M.D., late Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1855; served in Bengal from Sept., 1859, as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon at various stations; also officiated as sanitary commissioner, Bengal, Jan., 1872; civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, with medical charge of Alipore and Russia jails, and medical inspector of emigrants, Feb., 1883; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail and lunatic asylum, Moorshe-dabad, 1885; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; brigade surgeon, Jan., 1881; retired, April, 1887.

JACKSON, FREEMAN HENRY, Lieut.-Colonel, BOMBAY S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay Infantry, 1861; arrived in India, 10th Jan., 1862; from Jan., 1867, acted in charge of office of assistant resident, Amreli, and was appointed to settle boundaries in Eastern Káthiáwar, Jan., 1868; acting assistant-resident, Dwárka, and commandant of H.H. the Gáekwar's battalion, March, 1869; assistant resident, Baroda, in charge Okhámandal, July, 1874; on special duty, Baroda, Jan., 1875; treasury officer, Baroda Residency, Feb., 1875; acting cantonment magistrate, Baroda, April, 1875; extra assistant general superintendent, thuggee and dacoity department, June, 1875; from May, 1876, served as assistant agent to the governor-general, Baroda, and from Feb., 1879, as superintendent of the Gáekwar's contingent, Káthiáwar, assistant in charge of Amreli Mahals, and superintendent for the improvement of the breed of horses in Káthiáwar; officiated for various periods as resident 2nd class and governor-general's, agent Baroda.

JACKSON, WILLIAM GRIERSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Feb., 1877, to Jan., 1880, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, 4th grade; deputy superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, March, 1882; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Nov., 1887 and 1st grade, April, 1889; also officiated as magistrate and collector and as district and sessions judge; author of Mirzapur volume of N.W. Provinces' Gazetteer.

JACOB, GEORGE, BOMBAY C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; in charge of forest settlement and demarcation officer's office, Khandesh, Oct., 1881, to Feb., 1882; from May, 1883, served as assistant judge and sessions judge, and also from Dec., 1884, to Oct., 1885, as assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; from March, 1886, served as senior assistant judge, and from Nov., 1886, as joint judge and sessions judge; acting registrar, high court, appellate side, Feb., 1888.

JACOB, HERBERT BRUCE, Colonel, Bo. S.C., Educational Department, Central Provinces.—First commission, Dec., 1857; served from 26th June, 1869, in the educational department, Central Provinces, and was appointed inspector of schools, 3rd grade, April, 1871; acting inspector-general of education, 1882-84; cantonment magistrate, Karachi, 1889.

JACOB, STEPHEN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, officiating registrar in the judicial commissioner's court, and officiating deputy commissioner, till Dec., 1878, when he was transferred to Bengal; on special duty, legislative department, government of India, April, 1879, and again in March, 1880; officiated as under secretary and as assistant secretary in department of finance and commerce, government of India, in 1880 and 1881; assistant comptroller-general, in class III. of the financial department, Nov., 1880; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1881, and in 1882; on special duty with the government of India in department of finance and commerce, Jan. and Dec., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, June, 1882; under secretary, government of India, finance and commerce department, July, 1882; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, July, 1883; deputy auditor-general, Dec., 1884; officiating accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oude, Feb., 1885; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1885; secretary to the finance committee, March, 1886; on special duty, financial department, Feb., 1888; accountant-general, class I., and commissioner of the department of state paper currency, Bombay, May, 1888; comptroller and auditor-general and head-commissioner of paper currency, April, 1890.

JAMES, HENRY EVAN MURCHISON, BOMBAY C.S.—Educated at the Cathedral School, Carlisle, and Durham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and as acting assistant commissioner, branch inspector-general of registration and educational inspector in Sind; from May, 1873, acted as under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1875; also acted as postmaster-general, Bombay, from Nov., 1875; 2nd grade, postmaster-general, Bombay, Nov., 1877; postmaster-general, Bengal, March, 1882; acted as director-general of the post office in India; 1883-85; on special duty in England, Aug., 1884, to April, 1885; deputy director-general, Nov., 1885; senior collector and collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, April, 1888; 2nd grade commissioner, June, 1890.

JAMES, STEPHEN HARVEY, M.R.A.S., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Probus Grammar School, and Shrewsbury Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 30th Oct.,
1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1875, and officiated as secretary, 1877; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, and officiating junior secretary, Aug., 1877; on special duty under the orders of the high court, Feb., 1881, and under the orders of the local government in 1882-83; registrar, high court, May, 1881; legal remembrancer, N.W. Provinces, May, 1884; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India, legislative department, March, 1885; officiating secretary to the government of India, legislative department, Dec., 1885; confirmed as secretary, Sept., 1887.

JAMESON, ROBERT, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Sanitary Department, N.W. Provinces.—Joined the Bengal medical service as assistant surgeon, Oct., 1865, arrived in India, 11th April, 1866, and was employed on civil and military duty; in 1868, was in medical charge at Calcutta of troops and coolies, en route to Abyssinia; served in Abyssinia with 12th Bengal cavalry; served in Bombay and Punjab, 1868 and 1869, and in the N.W. Provinces from 1870 on civil and jail duty; deputy sanitary commissioner, Nov., 1886.

JAQUET, ROBERT G., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 11th May, 1877.

JARDINE, JOHN, BOMBAY C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived 30th October, 1864, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; acting under secretary to government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, June, 1869, to May, 1871; from May, 1871, to Oct., 1873, served in Kāthiāwar as political assistant, and was in charge of the agency in Sept., Oct., and Dec., 1871; also appointed judicial assistant in Kāthiāwar, June, 1873; acting registrar of the high court, Bombay, Oct., 1873; secretary to the Baroda commission for the trial of the Gāekwār, Feb.-May, 1875; acting judge and sessions judge at Ratnagiri, Tanna, and Khan-deish, Oct., 1875, to Feb., 1877; secretary to the delegates of the government of India in the negotiations for a commercial treaty with Portugal, March to Sept., 1877, also acting as deputy secretary to government of India, legislative department, April, 1877; acting secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, educational, secret, and Persian departments, Nov., 1877, to Jan., 1878; from Feb., 1878, served in British Burma as judicial commissioner, and also presided in court of recorder of Rangoon, Oct.-Nov., 1881; president of the educational syndicate, Sept., 1881; president of the Poungha reformatory committee, Nov., 1881; acting chief secretary to government of Bombay, Oct., 1885; judge of the High Court, Bombay, Nov., 1885; author of 'Notes on Buddhist Law'; editor of Moung Tet Pyo's Customary Law of the Chin Tribe, also of a reprint of Dr. Tandy's translation of Father Sangermano's description of the Burman Empire, and a compilation of printed judgments of the judicial commissioner of British Burma; wrote a preface to Dr. Forchhammer's 'King Wagaru's Dhamma-Satham.'

JARDINE, WILLIAM ELLIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in Madras, 20th Feb., 1889, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

JARRETT, HENRY SULLIVAN, Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, Dec., 1856, 3rd European Infantry, Bengal; during the mutiny was present at the outbreak at Mooltan, 1858, and was engaged in the pursuit of the mutineers under Brigadier-General Farquharson (medal); also served in the Mahsud Waziri expedition, 1860 (received medal and clasp), and the 2nd Eusufzai expedition, 1863 (received clasp); secretary to board of examiners, Fort William, 1871; assistant secretary, legislative department, government of India, from Aug., 1875.

JEFFREYS, WILLIAM, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 8th June, 1854; arrived in India, 24th Jan., 1856; served in the irrigation branch, Punjab, from May, 1857, as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and officiating superintendent, Western Junna canal; also officiated as assistant principal, Roorkee College; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1862; temporarily transferred to P.W. secretariat, government of India, Nov., 1864, to April, 1865; transferred to Bengal, and specially deputed to investigate a project of irrigation and navigation for the river Gandak, Oct., 1867, to April, 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1869; officiating assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1869; supervising engineer, 3rd class, April, 1872; 1st class, Jan., 1880; acting chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation branch, March, 1887; retired, Nov., 1887.

JEHANGIR, K. M. KABRAJI, BOMBAY C.S.—Appointed in India as probationer under native civil service rules, 14th Jan., 1888; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1888.

JEHANGIR, PESTANJI C.I.E., KHAN BAHAADUR, late BOMBAY C.S.—Joined the service as assistant master, Elphinstone institution, Bombay, 10th Oct., 1853; served in the settlement department from April, 1857; 1st grade, deputy collector, Aug., 1869; C.I.E., Jan., 1882; talukdari settlement officer, May, 1889; retired 1889.

JENKINS, JOHN LEWIS, B.A., BOMBAY C.S.—Educated at Bristol Grammar School, and Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 15th Jan., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from June, 1881, served in Sind as acting deputy collector, and acting city magistrate, Karachi; 3rd assistant collector in Sind, June, 1885; manager of encumbered estates in Sind, and educational inspector, September, 1885; 2nd assistant collector, June, 1889.

JENKINS, ROBERT GEORGE, Colonel, M.S.C., Madras Police.—Ensign Madras infantry, Dec., 1856; arrived in India, 8th Feb., 1857; served in the Madras police, from July, 1863, and was promoted to superintendent, 1872; on special duty at Madras, July-Oct., 1874, and in the Godavari District, June-Sept., 1879; acted as assistant inspector-general in 1874 and 1879, and as deputy inspector-general in 1885; 1st grade superintendent, Feb., 1886.
JENKINS, THOMAS LOWTEN LAYTON (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1877; served in revenue and judicial departments in Bengal, and Assam (in 1882), as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

JENKINS, THOMAS MORRIS, Major, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, March, 1866; arrived at Madras, 16th Sept., 1866, and served with the 2-19th regiment; joined the Madras staff corps, June, 1869; served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner from April, 1874; acted as port officer and collector of customs, Bassein, in July, 1881; settlement officer, 1st grade, Dec., 1884, to June, 1885; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Nov., 1883; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1886.

JENKINSON, SIR EDWARD GEORGE, K.C.B., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow and Haileybury College; appointed to the East India company's service in 1856, and served in the N.W. Provinces as joint magistrate and deputy collector of Benares, and afterwards of Farukhabad; served through the Indian mutiny, for which he received medal and the thanks of the Queen and the Governor-General; served also as settlement officer, magistrate, and collector; commissioner of revenue in Jhansi, and commissioner in Oudh; retired, 1880; was private secretary to Earl Spencer when lord-lieutenant of Ireland, and assistant under secretary police and crime, 1882-5; C.B. in 1883, and K.C.B., 1888.

JENKYNS, EDWARD S., Accounts Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 25th Feb., 1846; junior clerk, audit department, India office, Sept., 1858; accountant-general's department, 1860; senior clerk, Dec., 1868.

JEROUSE, ALAN ARTHUR CLARKE, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived, 23rd March, 1857, and served in various districts of Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, political agent and collector of stamp revenue, and acting deputy commissioner of customs and opium; junior collector and magistrate, Belgaum, Sept., 1877; senior collector and magistrate, March, 1879; retired, April, 1887.

JOBBINS, W.H.—Superintendent of Government School of Art, and Art Gallery, Calcutta, July, 1887.

JODU NATH ROY, Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 13th July, 1861, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, and small cause court judge, Midnapore, June, 1873; judge of the court of small causes at Kooshtea, Chooadanga, and Meherpore, May, 1883; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1883.

JOHNSON, SIR ALLEN B., Lieut.-General, K.C.B., B.S.C., late Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Winchester; joined the service (infantry), July, 1846; appointed to 4th Sikhs as volunteer for service in Burma; medal and clasp for Pegu; in civil employ in Punjab, 1854; Indian Mutiny in 1858; medal and clasp and brevet for Lucknow; assistant adjutant-general, 1861; military department, Calcutta, 1862; assistant secretary to government of India in the military department, 1875; deputy military secretary, 1876; secretary in the military department, India Office, from 18th Jan., 1877; temporarily employed as military secretary to the government of India, 1879-1881; C.B., 1881; retired from India office and made K.C.B., May, 1889.

JOHNSON, The Most Rev. EDWARD RALPH, D.D.—Appointed Bishop of Calcutta, 14th Dec., 1876; metropolitan of India.

JOHNSON, SIR EDWIN BEAUMONT, General, G.C.B., C.I.E., R.A.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, June, 1842; served in the Sutlej campaign, 1845-46, including battles of Ferozeshah and Sobraon (medal and clasp), and in the Punjab campaign, 1848-49, and in pursuit of the Sikhs and Afghans (medal and two clasps); deputy judge advocate-general, Sirhind division, April, 1849; served in the Indian mutiny (medal and two clasps), and was assistant adjutant-general of artillery, Jan., 1856-63; assistant military secretary, Horse Guards, 1865-72; quartermaster-general, Bengal, July, 1873; adjutant-general, March, 1874; member of council of secretary of state for India, 1st Sept., 1874, to Feb., 1877; military member of council of governor-general of India, March, 1877-80; director-general of military education, War Office, Dec., 1884.

JOHNSON, EVANS CHARLES, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from Jan., 1868, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner and acting commissioner (Nilgiris), acting sub-collector, and acting district and sessions judge; on special duty, Rumpa disturbances, 1879-80; sub-collector and joint magistrate, South Arcot, Jan., 1883; from Feb., 1883, acted as principal assistant in Vizagapatam, and as collector, magistrate, and agent in the same district, and afterwards in Kurnool; acting district and sessions judge, Vizagapatam, May, 1884, to April, 1885; collector and magistrate, May, 1886; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1886.

JOHNSON, JOHN, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872; junior clerk, June, 1882.

JOHNSTON, CHARLES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at High School, Dublin, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 5th Jan., 1889, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

JOHNSTON, JOHN LEECH, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Raphoe, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting political superintendent of Akalkot, acting collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Kanara, Jan., 1884; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Thana, Feb., 1886.

JOHNSTONE, DONALD CAMPBELL, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1879, and served in
the Punjab as assistant commissioner; served under the government of Bombay from May, 1882, as assistant collector and magistrate, to Feb., 1884, when he was re-transferred to Punjab; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Oct., 1887; confirmed, Nov., 1888.

JOHNSTONE, FREDERICK JOHN, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Assam.—Served in the public works department, Central Provinces, from July, 1861, and was appointed executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; assistant to the chief engineer, Aug., 1873; officiating controller of public works accounts, April to Nov., 1875; transferred temporarily to Punjab, Oct., 1879; promoted to superintending engineer, Nov., 1880; posted to British Burma, Jan., 1881; transferred to Assam as superintending engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner in the public works department, Jan., 1884; 1st class superintending engineer, March, 1886; 3rd chief engineer, June, 1888.

JOHNSTONE, HUGH, Surgeon-Major, A.M., M.D., Medical Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian medical service, 30th Sept., 1867; arrived in India, 2nd May, 1868, and served in Calcutta at the General Hospital and as house surgeon at the Medical College Hospital; in medical charge of the British residency, Mandalay, Upper Burma, July, 1869; civil surgeon of Akyab, March, 1877; from April, 1878, officiated as civil surgeon, Rangoon, and was appointed junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, April, 1880, and civil surgeon, May, 1890; also port health officer and in charge of the lock hospital and meteorological observatory.

JOHNSTONE, SIR JAMES, Colonel, K.C.S.I., late Assam Commission.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, 1858; assistant superintendent of police, 1864; in charge of Keddahs in the Gurjat Mehalas of Cuttack, 1868-74; assistant commissioner in Assam, 1874; political agent, Manipur, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1884; K.C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired from Assam Commission, 1888.

JOHNSTONE, JAMES WILLIAM HOPE, Colonel, B.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1853; from March, 1858, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; officiated as commissioner and superintendent, Peshawur, in 1880 and 1883; also in the Jullundur division, Sept., 1880; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Rawal Pindi, Feb., 1881; civil and sessions judge, Peshawur, Sept., 1881; 1st grade divisional judge, Nov., 1884; retired, Feb., 1886.

JOLLIFFE, E. W., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 2nd April, 1885.

JONES, H. H., India Office, Stores Department.—2nd class clerk Store Depot, July, 1838.

JONES, JOHN ALFRED, Madras Sanitary Department.—Joined the service as executive engineer, public works department, Madras municipal commission, Jan., 1877; acted as president of the municipal commission in 1886 and 1888; appointed sanitary engineer to Government of Madras, April, 1890; author of 'Switches and Crossings,' a manual for railway and tramway engineers, and of a manual for district and Municipal boards.
