JONES, THOMAS (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Department.—Assistant secretary, government of Bengal, 7th April, 1866; clerk and officiating 5th judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Jan., 1873; registrar and chief ministerial officer of the court, June, 1882; 4th judge Oct., 1884; and 3rd judge, Oct., 1889.

JONES, WILLIAM BRITTAIN, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 15th Sept., 1856; from March, 1857, to April, 1865, served in the N.W. Provinces, and Punjab, as assistant magistrate and assistant commissioner; from April, 1865, served in the Central Provinces as deputy commissioner, acting superintendent of cotton affairs, secretary to the chief commissioner, and acting commissioner in the Jubbulpore, Nerbudda, and Nagpore divisions; on special duty as commissioner for drawing up land revenue and tenancy bills for Central Provinces, Sept., 1874; on special duty in the home department, Calcutta, Nov., 1876, also in April, 1877, and at Simla, May, 1877; commissioner, Hyderabad assigned districts, April, 1877; resident, Hyderabad, June, 1882; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1st May, 1883; retired, 27th Jan., 1885.

JONES, W. R. S., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Deputy superintendent, Roorkee workshops, Nov., 1867; joined the public works department, Feb., 1873, as executive engineer, N.W. Provinces, irrigation; transferred to the locomotive department, Rajputana state railways, April, 1879, as deputy locomotive superintendent; carriage and wagon superintendent, Ajmere, in 2nd class of the state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1880; class I., grade 3, revenue scale, Jan. 1886.

JONES - BATEMAN, HERBERT BURLETON, Bengal C.S. (North - Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1876, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Aug.-Nov., 1883; joint magistrate, Aug., 1886.

JOPP, A. ABERCROMBIE, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy, and Royal Indian Military College, Addiscombe; entered the Royal Engineers, 19th Dec., 1860; retired Feb., 1879; secretary, office of agent-general for government of New South Wales, London, Feb., 1874, to March, 1879; director-general of stores, India office, April 1879.

JOPP, CHARLES HENRY, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 19th Oct., 1873; second assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1886; and first assistant, Nov., 1889.

JOPP, JOHN, Brigadier-General, Political Department, Bombay.—1st commission, 20th Oct., 1856; served at capture of fort of Sheik Othman, near Aden, in 1858, and in the Abyssinian war of 1868 (medal), and in the Afghan war, 1879-80, as assistant quartermaster-general, and took part in march to Candahar (medal); deputy quartermaster-general, Bombay, May, 1883, to May, 1890; brigadier-general, May, 1890; political resident and collector of stamp revenue, in charge of and commandant Aden Brigade, May, 1890.
JOSEPH, HUGH GORE, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; transferred for employment as deputy-commissioner in Burma, Aug., 1886; re-transferred to Madras, Oct., 1887, as head assistant to collector and magistrate; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Feb., 1890.

JWALA PRASAD, Pandit, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North Western Provinces).—Appointed a probationer under native civil service rules; assistant commissioner, Feb., 1888; confirmed in the civil service, March, 1889.

KASHINATH, TRIMBAK TELANG, M.A., LL.B. (Bom.), C.I.E., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay Judicial Department.—Served from 15th June, 1887, as government professor of law; appointed judge of the High Court, Bombay, 25th Nov., 1889.

KAVASJEE JAMASJEE BADSHAH, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Elphinstone High School, Bombay University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1879; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating embarkation agent and superintendent of emigration, Oct., 1882; postmaster-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1887.

KAYE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, 8th April, 1858; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating small cause court judge, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Bareilly, April, 1877, officiating civil and sessions judge, Gorakhpur, March, 1880, and commissioner of the Jhansi division, Dec., 1881; commissioner of the Jhansi division, July, 1885, and of the Rohilkund division, Nov., 1889; acting member of board of revenue, Jan., 1890.

KAY-SHUTTLEWORTH, Rt. Hon. Sir Ughtred James, Bart., M.P.—Educated at Harrow, and at the London University; sat in the House of Commons as member for Hastings from Oct., 1869, till 1880; served for two years on the London School Board, and was also a member of the royal commission on reformatory and industrial schools; in 1885 was returned for the Clitheroe division of N.E. Lancashire, and was appointed under secretary of state for India in Feb., 1886, and shortly afterwards Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster; in the election of 1886 was returned for N.E. Lancashire; is vice-president of University College, London.

KEATINGE, RICHARD HARTE, Lieut.-General, V.C., C.S.I., R.A., Bombay Staff Corps.—First commission, Bombay artillery, June, 1842; from 1847 was employed in civil duties on the N.W. frontier, and was appointed assistant superintendent, Nimar, Dec., 1851; in the Mutiny of 1857 served in Central India, and was present at the sieges of Dhar and Chendarce, and in the fighting near Mundesore (dangerously wounded, brevet of Major, medal and clasp and V.C.); also took part in pursuit of Tantia Topec, 1858-59; political agent, Nimar, 1860; political agent, Gwalior, and subsequently in Kattywar, 1862; served in Kattywar against the rebel Wagheers in 1865; agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, 1868; also ex-officio chief commissioner of Ajmere; chief commissioner of Assam, 1874 to June, 1878.

KEDAR, NATH ROY, M.A., (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—From 1878 served as munsiff, and on 23rd May, 1888, was appointed member of the statutory civil service; assistant magistrate and collector, June, 1888.

KEDAR, NATH MOZOOMDAR, B.L., Bengal Judicial Department.—Served in the subordinate judicial department from 15th December, 1865, and was appointed subordinate judge of 1st grade, July, 1890.

KEEFER, WILLIAM NAPIER, Surgeon-Major, late Indian Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, Bengal Medical Establishment, 1st Oct., 1869; served under the military department up to 1884, when he was appointed senior medical officer, Port Blair and the Nicobars; served in the Looshai campaign, 1871-72 (medal and clasp), the Duffla expedition, 1874-75, the Jowaki campaign, 1877-78 (clasp), the Afghan campaign, 1878-79-80 (medal and clasp), the Zaimush expedition, 1879, and the Egyptian campaign, 1882 (medal and clasp, Khedive's bronze star, and 4th class, Order of the Osmanich); retired, Dec., 1889.

KEEGAN, DENNIS FRANCIS, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Indian Medical Service.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; joined the Bengal medical service in 1866; arrived in India 13th Dec., 1866; from Nov., 1868, served with the Central India Horse, and acted as residency surgeon, Indore, 1877-78; served in the Afghan War, 1879-80, in the march from Kabul to, and action at, Kandahar (medal and clasp, bronze star); residency surgeon, Indore, and civil administrative medical officer, Central India, June, 1881.

KEELAN, BERNARD CALLASE, Surgeon-Major, L.K. and Q.C.P., M.R.C.S., L.M.K. and Q.C.P. (Ir.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867, and served under the military department, and also as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at various stations; served in the Abyssinian campaign, and was present at the storming of Magdala (medal); civil surgeon, Sukkur, Jan., 1881; civil surgeon, superintendent of jail, lunatic asylum, and medical school, Hyderabad, April, 1884.

KEENE, CHARLES JAMES, Railway Department, Government of India.—Joined the service 29th Dec., 1874, as assistant traffic superintendent, Punjab northern state railway; served also on the Northern Bengal state railway, the North-Western and other railways; district traffic superintendent, class ii., grade i., 1889.

KEENE, HENRY G., C.I.E., M.R.A.S., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1847; arrived in India, 3rd Oct., 1847; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dün, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; superintendent, Dehra Dün, May, 1856; magistrate and collector, April, 1860; civil and sessions judge April, 1867; officiated as commissioner of the
Agra division in 1872 and 1875; and of the Allahabad division in 1874; retired, 1883; fellow of the Calcutta University; member of committee of the Muhammadan College of Aligurh; medal from the zoological society; medal and diploma from the Austrian Exhibition of 1863; author of 'Indian Administration,' 1867; 'History of Hindustan,' 1885; and numerous contributions to the periodical press.

KEENE, HENRY GEORGE HARRIS, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the department, and was attached to the accountant-general's office, Rangoon, 14th March, 1874; assistant accountant-general, Feb., 1878, and assistant comptroller-general, March, 1878; class iv. of financial department, Jan., 1890.

KEESS, JAMES, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., M.R.C.P., and L.M. (London), and M.R.C.S., late Madras Medical Department.—Served in the subordinate medical department as warrant officer from 11th Sept., 1848, to May, 1855; assistant surgeon, 4th Aug., 1856; arrived 11th Sept., 1856, and served under the military department up to May, 1862, and subsequently as civil surgeon and superintendent of district jail, Kurnool, and was placed on special duty experimenting on alkaloids in Gudalur and Wynad, June, 1866; fort surgeon, Madras, and professor of anatomy and physiology in the Medical College, April, 1867; medical inspector of seamen, Aug., 1868; acting principal medical storekeeper and inspector of emigrants, May, 1869; acting health officer and superintendent, lock hospital, Madras, April, 1880; fellow of Madras University, May, 1882; principal and professor of medicine in the Medical College, and senior physician, General Hospital, Aug., 1883; retired, Jan., 1887; author of 'Syllabus of Medicine for use of Medical Students,' 'Notes on Zoology and Comparative Anatomy,' 'History of the Madras Medical College,' a pamphlet on the 'Prevention of Cholera,' and a 'Calendar of the Medical College.'

KEITH, STANLEY, Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Lancing College; writer, India Office, 6th June, 1873; clerk, 2nd class, April, 1879.

KEITH, THOMAS W., Accountant-General, India Office.—Educated at Highgate School; East India House writer, old establishment, 20th Aug., 1845; junior clerk, Treasury, 1848; senior clerk, Sept., 1858; accountant-general's department, 1860; accountant, Jan., 1872; assessor of income tax, 1872; accountant-general, Feb., 1879.

KELLAKKA COVILAGOM MANAVEDAN RAJA, B.A., Madras C.S.—Madras University; appointed by government of India as probationer for the civil service, 4th June, 1880; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1882; acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant, Aug. 1888.

KELLEHER, JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Catholic University of Ireland; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 29th Sept., 1869; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1882; transferred to Assam as district and sessions judge of Sylhet, March, 188 services replaced at disposal of government of Bengal, Sept., 1887; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Dec., 1887.

KELLEY, W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India Office, 9th Oct., 1879.

KELLNER, EDWIN WELSH, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department as assistant comptroller-general, 20th April, 1870; served as deputy accountant-general, and, for a short period, as accountant-general, Bengal, 1874-76; deputy comptroller-general, Jan., 1877; assistant commissioner of paper currency, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; deputy comptroller-general in 1st class of financial department, Aug., 1878; acted as accountant-general, Bengal, in 1883, 1886, and 1887; officiating comptroller and auditor-general, Aug., 1887; officiated as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh in 1887; and Madras, 1888; class i., finance department, enrolled list, July, 1889; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, in 1889, and Punjab, 1890.

KELLY, CHARLES ARTHUR, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, June, 1868; also served as assistant-superintendent of survey, 1863-64, and officiating inspector of schools, 1865; appointed small cause court judge, Bhagulpore, Jan., 1876, and served subsequently in the judicial department; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1879; retired, Jan., 1888.

KELSALL, JOHN, late Madras C.S.—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; from March, 1865, to Jan., 1867, served as probationary assistant-superintendent of police, and subsequently, in the revenue and judicial departments in various districts of Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, principal assistant, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled the Bellary 'District Manual'; appointed district and sessions judge, Aug., 1880, in the Godavari district, and afterwards in South Malabar and Vizagapatam; retired, Nov., 1889.

KEMBALL, Sir ARNOLD BURROWES, General, K.C.B., K.C.S.I., late Political Department, Government of India.—Educated at Addiscombe; 2nd lieutenant, Bombay artillery, Dec., 1837; served in the Afghan war, 1838-39, and was present at the siege and capture of Ghuznee (medal); appointed assistant to the resident at Bushire, Feb., 1842; political resident, Persian Gulf; May, 1852; consul general, Bagdad, and political agent, Turkish Arabia, April, 1855, to 1873; served in the Persian expedition of 1857, and was present at the capture of Mohumrah (medal and clasp, C.B., and brevet of major); served with the Turco-Persian boundary commission, 1873; during the Russo-Turkish war, 1876-77, was British military attache at the headquarters of the Turkish army.

KEMBALL, CHARLES GORDON, Barrister-at-Law, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1850; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1850; served in the grades of assistant collector and magis-
trate, assistant judge and sessions judge, judicial assistant commissioner (in Sind), and deputy magistrate; collector and magistrate, Karachi, Nov., 1861; served as judge and sessions judge, Surat, from Jan., 1866, to June, 1870, and from the latter date acted as judge of the high court-Bombay, in which appointment he was confirmed in Aug., 1871; acted as member of council, Bombay, in 1880, and again in 1881; retired in 1885.

KENBLE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 8th April, 1838; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Oct., 1873; inspector-general of jails, July, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1878; officiating opium agent, Benares, April, 1881; opium agent, Behar, May, 1884; officiating commissioner, Patna, May, 1890.

KEMP, FRANCIS BARING, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at foreign schools, and at Eton; appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1830; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1831; served in the revenue and judicial departments in various districts of Bengal; collector, Tirhut, 1851; civil and sessions judge, Backergunge and Jessore, 1855 to 1862; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1862 to 1878; retired, 1878.

KENNEDY, JAMES, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1865; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1879; magistrate and collector, Gorakhpur, March, 1881; retired, April, 1890.

KENNEDY, JOSEPH, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1874; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty, Madras, July, 1878; transferred to Assam, Nov., 1883, as assistant commissioner, 1st class; deputy commissioner, July, 1886.

KENNEDY, SIR MICHAEL KAVANAGH, General, K.C.S.I., R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, 11th June, 1841; arrived in India, Nov., 1842; assistant engineer, roads and tanks, June, 1843; executive engineer at Surat, Aden, and Satara, 1843-60; on special duty, Ceylon, Madras, and Calcutta, Oct., 1860 to April, 1861; superintending engineer, Southern division, April, 1862; secretary to government of Bombay, public works and railway departments, July, 1863; resigned the public works department in 1880; controller-general of supply, Kabul expedition; additional secretary to government of India for supply and transport, 1880.

KENNEDY, ROBERT MUIRHEAD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1877; and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate, and railway magistrate, Bandra; appointed 2nd assistant collector, April, 1888.

KENNEDY, THOMAS JOHN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Liverpool Institute, Balliol College, Oxford, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1880, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; transferred to Central Provinces, Oct., 1885; settlement officer, Raipur, Oct., 1885; retransferred to the Punjab, and appointed assistant commissioner, Lahore, Nov., 1887; officiating deputy commissioner, Montgomery, Feb., 1888.

KENNEY-HERBERT, ARTHUR ROBERT, Colonel, Madras Cavalry.—Cornet, Sept. 20, 1859; arrived in India, Oct. 31, 1859; served on regimental duty with various cavalry regiments; adjutant, Governor's body guard, Sept., 1865; deputy assistant quarter-master general, 1873-76; major, Sept., 1879; military secretary to the governor of Madras, May, 1881, to April, 1884; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, military department, Dec., 1881; from April, 1884, acted as secretary to the government of Madras, military department, and was confirmed in that appointment, Dec., 1885; lieutenant-colonel, September, 1885; colonel and local rank of brigadier-general, March, 1887.

KENSINGTON, ALFRED, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Marlborough, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; on special duty in civil secretariat, Oct., 1882; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Nov., 1882; promoted to settlement officer, April, 1884; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1887, and 1st grade, March, 1890; appointed under-secretary to government of India, finance and commerce department, April, 1890.

KERNAN, JAMES, M.A., Q.C., late Judicial Department, Madras.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin. Judge of the high court, Madras, 3rd May, 1870; fellow of the Madras University, Feb., 1871; vice-chancellor of the Madras University, June, 1885, and 1887; officiating chief justice, July to Nov., 1885, and in July, 1888; retired, July, 1889.

KERR, T. COULTER, Captain, Store Department, India Office.—Surveyor of shipping, 1st April, 1881.

KETTLEWELL, G., B.A., Inspecting Veterinary Surgeon, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1854; served under the military department till Dec., 1881, when he was appointed principal, Veterinary School, Lahore.

KEYS, ARTHUR INNES, Registry Department, India Office.—Appointed clerk, London office, Indo-European Telegraph Department, 1880; on abolition of that office, services transferred to India office, 1st Jan., 1889.

KEYSER, ALFRED, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Guildford Grammar School, and Royal Academy, Gosport; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1865, and served as assistant-collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate and political
agent, Surat, Dec., 1884; senior collector, &c., April, 1887; acting commissioner, Southern division, March, 1890.

KHARSEDJI MANEKJI KHARSEDJI, KHAN BAHAUDUR, B.A. (Oxon.), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 29th May, 1874, as judge of the court of small causes, Ahmednagar, and subsequently at Ahmedabad; appointed 4th judge, Bombay small cause court, June, 1888, and 3rd judge, May, 1889.

KHARSEDJI RATANJI BAMANJI, Bombay C.S.—Probationer under the native civil service rules, and assistant-collector and magistrate, Nov., 1882; confirmed as member of the Bombay Civil Service, Jan., 1885.

KIEHNANDER, CHARLES ROBERT CAMPBELL, Financial Department, Government of India.—Assistant accountant-general, British Burma, 5th Aug., 1864; officiating deputy accountant-general, Central Provinces, April, 1870; assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1870; from Feb., 1874, to Jan., 1876, served as deputy accountant-general in the Punjab, and subsequently in Bombay, N.W. Provinces, British Burma, and Bengal; officiated as accountant-general, Bengal, in 1878 and 1879; inspector of local offices of account, Oct., 1878; deputy comptroller-general in 1st class of financial department, Feb., 1883; assistant secretary, government of India, financial department, Nov., 1884, to Jan., 1885; deputy auditor-general, Jan., 1885; comptroller of Indian treasuries, April, 1885; officiating deputy comptroller-general, 1886-90.

KILBY, G. C. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Service.—Deputy superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, 28th Feb., 1876.

KILBY, SANDFORD JAMES, Bengal Preventive Service.—Assistant collector of customs, Chittagong, 30th June, 1865; deputy magistrate and deputy collector, July, 1866; from Aug., 1868, to Dec., 1876, served in the police department, and was appointed assistant superintendent, 1st grade, May, 1874; on famine relief duty, Dec., 1873, and March, 1876; on special duty in Chumparam, April, 1874; from Dec., 1876, served in the customs' preventive service, and was appointed superintendent, Jan., 1877; also in charge of the Sulkea salt golahs, April, 1880; served in Madras, Sept.-Nov., 1885, as deputy commissioner, abkari and salt department.

KIMBERLEY (Earl of), RIGHT HON. JOHN WODEHOUSE, K.G.—Born Jan. 7, 1826; educated at Eton, and Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in 1847, with 1st class in classics; succeeded to title of Baron Wodehouse, May, 1846; under secretary of state for foreign affairs, Dec., 1852, to 1856; ambassador at St. Petersburg, 1856-58; under secretary for foreign affairs, June, 1859, to Aug., 1861; on a special mission to the North of Europe, in connection with the Schleswig-Holstein question, 1863; under secretary of state for India, April-Nov., 1864; Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, Nov., 1864, to July, 1866; raised to earldom of Kimberley, May, 1866; elected governor of the Hudson's Bay Company, April, 1868; lord privy seal, Dec., 1868, to July, 1870; secretary of state for the colonies from July, 1870, to Feb., 1874; member of the royal commission to enquire into the working of the Penal Servitude Acts, Feb., 1878; secretary of state for the colonies, May, 1880; held provisionally the office of chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, on Mr. Bright's resignation, June, 1882; secretary of state for India, Dec., 1882, to June, 1885, and again Feb. to Aug., 1886; was a royal commissioner for the exhibition of 1886; has been a member of the senate of the University of London since 1859, and was for some time president of University College, London (resigned, 1887).

KINCAID, WILLIAM, Major-Gen., M.S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Madras Army, March, 1849; appointed to adjust boundaries disputes, Bhopal agency, March, 1854; assistant political agent, Bundelcund, small cause court judge and cantonment magistrate, Nowgong, 1866; second in command, Malwa Bheel corps, Nov., 1870; political agent, Bhopal, Aug., 1876; political agent, Bhopawur, and commandant, Malwa Bheel corps, Oct., 1879, political agent, Bhopal, June, 1881; returned to Europe, 1887.

KINDERSLEY, JOHN ROBERT, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1847; served in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector till 1857, when he was appointed assistant judge of Mangalore; subordinate judge, Bellary, 1859; civil and sessions judge, Rajahmundry, March, 1865, and subsequently at Bellary; officiating judicial commissioner, Mysore, Sept., 1866, and again 1868; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, June, 1877; retired in 1884.

KING, GEORGE, C.I.E., M.B., Brigade Surgeon Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1865; house surgeon, Medical College Hospital, from 9th May to 25th Aug., 1866, when his services were placed at disposal of government of India, military department; superintendent of Royal Botanical Gardens, ex-officio professor of botany in Calcutta Medical College, and ex-officio superintendent of cinchona plantation in British Sikkhim, from July, 1871; surgeon-major, Oct. 1877; also officiating quinologist, Dec., 1879; brigade surgeon, April, 1889; C.I.E., Jan., 1890; superintendent of botanical gardens, Calcutta, and professor of botany in Calcutta medical college; author of 'Manual of Cinchona Cultivation in India.'

KING, JOSHUA, M.A., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 26th Oct., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant judge and session judge; in charge of the small cause court, Ahmedabad, April-May, 1864; acting under secretary to Government, revenue, financial, and general departments, May, 1866; acting collector and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Bombay, July, 1869, to Jan., 1870; talukdari settlement officer, Dec., 1874, to Feb., 1876, and again, Feb., 1876, to Nov., 1877, for carrying Bombay Act VI of 1862 into effect, and manager under Act XV of 1871; on special duty, Baroda, Nov., 1877, to June, 1879; junior collector and magistrate, Ahmednagar, May, 1879; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Satara, May, 1884; retired, 1886.

KING, LUCAS BLACKE BURNET, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 11th Oct., 1860; from Nov., 1861,
served in the Bengal revenue, survey, and judicial departments, and was appointed superintendent of survey, Aug., 1866, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1877, and district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1880; retired, Aug., 1885.

KING, Lucas White, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Ennis College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Sept., 1882; revenue officer, Swat River Canal, Feb.-May, 1883; transferred to foreign department as officiating political agent, and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, June, 1885; political agent, 3rd class, sub-pro-tem., Oct., 1885; boundary settlement officer Meywar Tonk border, Feb., 1887; also in charge of the Dewas State.

KING, William, D.Sc., Geological Survey of India.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway. Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined the service, 4th March, 1857; served in various districts of the Madras presidency, and was appointed deputy superintendent for Madras, Nov., 1868; served subsequently in the Godavari district and the Nizam's territories, and discovered the Singareni coal-field, 1871-72; deputed to Vienna in joint charge of the survey collections at the Exhibition, 1873; 1st grade officer, April, 1875; fellow of the Madras University and member of the Faculty of Engineering, 1884; officiated as superintendent of the geological survey, May-Nov., 1884; designation changed to superintendent of survey; appointed director, April, 1887; author of contributions to the survey publications.

KINGS MILL, James, Central Press, Bombay. Joined the service as general superintendent of "Government Central Press," and editor of the "Bombay Government Gazette," 16th March, 1872.

KIPLING, John Lockwood, C.I.E., Education Department, Punjab.—Joined the government service as architectural sculptor, Bombay, May, 1865; from April, 1875, served in the Punjab as principal of Mayo School of Industrial Art, and curator, Lahore Museum.

KIRKHAM, T. B., Barrister-at-Law, Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the educational department, 1st Jan., 1862; arrived in India, 21st June, 1862, and served as headmaster of the Poona High School, principal of the Elphinstone High School, Bombay, and professor of English literature at the Elphinstone College; was also a member of the first municipal corporation of Bombay, Aug., 1873; from April, 1878, served as educational inspector, and was promoted to 2nd grade of the department, April, 1885; on special duty in England in connection with technical education, Nov., 1886.

KIRKWOOD, Townsend Molloy, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, 2nd Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1876, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1880; served temporarily under the public works department, Oct., 1869, to Oct., 1871, and was employed on famine duty, Bhagulpore, March, 1874; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, April, 1886; retired, 1888.

KISCH, Hermann Michael, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Bengal, Nov., 1873; on famine duty, Patna, March, 1874, and at Bellary, Feb., 1877; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, May, 1878; under secretary, judicial and political departments, Jan., 1880; officiating secretary in the financial department, June, 1881; officiating under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Dec., 1883; postmaster-general, Bengal, Nov., 1885; postmaster-general, 1st grade, April, 1888.

KITTS, Eustace John, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Portland Grammar School, Mill Hill Grammar School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Berar, Aug., 1875, and served as assistant commissioner and also as small cause court judge of Akola; on special (famine) duty, in Madras, 1877-78; assistant commissioner, Ajmere, May to Nov., 1883; from April, 1884, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed joint magistrate, 2nd grade, May, 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1887; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1888; district and sessions judge, March, 1890.

KNIGHT, Raymond, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's College, Stony Stratford, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1883; assistant collector, April, 1885.

KNOWLYS, Henry Bold, Berar Commissioner.—Served as a writer in the Ceylon civil service, 15th Feb., 1859, to Aug., 1866; from Sept., 1866, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Sept., 1873; deputy commissioner, May, 1886.

KNOX, George, late Punjab Administration.—Assistant engineer, May, 1854; from June, 1856, served in the Punjab commission, and was appointed personal assistant to commissioner of Jullundur, April, 1864, assistant commissioner, 1st class, Oct., 1864, and deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1877; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Rawul Pindi, Nov., 1878, to April, 1879; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; retired, 1890.

KNOX, George Edward, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from June, 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from March, 1877, served in the judicial department, and was appointed small cause court judge, Allahabad, Aug., 1877; judge, 3rd grade, March, 1884; officiating legal remembrancer, Feb., 1885; member of the lieutenant-
governor's council for making laws and regulations; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, continuing to be legal remembrancer; judge of the High Court, N.W.P., Nov., 1890; author of a 'Digest of the Criminal Law of the Bengal Presidency,' a 'Digest of Civil Procedure,' 'The Legal Remembrancer, 1879-82,' and 'Treatise upon the Indian Stamp Law.'

KNOX, Hubert Thomas, Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1868, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, acting principal assistant, joint sessions judge for trying Rumpa cases, and assistant commissioner (Nilgiris); acted as district and sessions judge, Ganjam, April-Sept., 1884, and afterwards in North Arcot; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Malabar, Oct., 1884; district and sessions judge, Trichinopoly, Nov., 1887; collector and magistrate, Nov., 1888.

KNYVETT, William Leycester Nathaniel, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 10th June, 1854; served in the Bengal police department from June, 1863, as district superintendent (1st grade, April, 1875); officiating personal assistant to inspector-general, July, 1875; deputy inspector-general, April, 1885; officiating inspector-general of police, Bengal, July, 1883.

KOUGH, Charles, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1867, and served in various districts of Madras in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, head assistant, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; forest settlement officer, March, 1884; acted for various periods as collector and magistrate in the districts of Madura, Cuddapah, and North Arcot; collector and magistrate, Kurnool, Nov., 1887.

KRISHNA CHUNDER CHATTERJEE, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 10th Dec., 1865, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, May, 1877; small cause court judge, Backergunge, Dec., 1877; subordinate judge, 1st grade, May, 1884.

KRISHNA MOHUN MOOKERJI, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, from 28th March, 1865, and was appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, Dec., 1884.

KUNWAR BHARAT SINGH, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 16th Feb., 1880; confirmed as covenanted civil servant, March, 1882; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Oct., 1888.

KUNWAR JWÁLA PRASÁD, Bengal C.S.—Appointed a probationer under the native civil service rules, Dec., 1884; probationary assistant magistrate, Gorakhpur; confirmed as assistant magistrate and collector, Feb., 1887.

KUSHWAKT - RAE, Rae (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Civil Service (N.W. Provinces).—Appointed by the Government of India under the native civil service rules probationary assistant magistrate and collector, 16th April, 1890.

LAFFAN, Edward Sidney, Madras C.S.—Educated at Wimbledon School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector; on famine duty, 1877-78; from June, 1882, served in the Madras secretariat, and was appointed assistant secretary in judicial and legislative departments, July, 1884; has also acted for various periods as under-secretary and as secretary in the revenue department, and as under-secretary in the chief secretary's departments; on special duty, preparing Madras administration report, Nov., 1882; Canarese translator to government, Sept., 1885; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1885, to March, 1886; acting secretary, board of revenue, Nov.-Dec., 1885; under secretary to government in the departments under the chief secretary, Sept., 1888; deputy commissioner of salt revenue, Nov., 1888; has acted as collector and magistrate.

LAING, James Anderson, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, 1st April, 1870; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1870, and served in the Madras medical department as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and acting resident surgeon at the General Hospital, Madras; deputy sanitary commissioner and inspector of vaccination, Feb., 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1882; officiating sanitary commissioner, April, 1886; confirmed in appointment, June, 1888.

LAIRD-MACGREGOR, James Listor, Forest Department, Bombay.—Appointed an assistant conservator of forests, Punjab, Dec., 1871; arrived, 16th Jan., 1872; transferred to Bombay, June, 1873; deputy conservator, Aug., 1879; conservator, 3rd grade, Dec., 1886.

LAKSHMAN GOPAL DESHMUKH, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, 16th April, 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, June, 1885.

LAL BEHARI DE, Rev., late Bengal Education Department.—Served from 3rd Sept., 1867, first as head master, and afterwards as assistant professor, in the Berhampore College; assistant professor in the Hooghly College, Jan., 1872; 3rd class of the education department, May, 1885; author of 'Govinda Samanta, or Bengal Peasant Life,' 'Folk Tales of Bengal,' 'Recollections of Alexander Duff.'

LAMB, Richard Amphlett, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; forest settlement officer, Khandeish, March, 1885; transferred to Burma as deputy commissioner, March, 1887.

LAMBE, William, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1886; magistrate and collector, June, 1887.
LAMBERT, John, C.I.E., Police Department, Bengal.—Served from 23rd Nov., 1863, as assistant superintendent, district superintendent, and officiating personal assistant to the inspector-general; on special duty, March, 1872; visitor of the presidency jail, and of the lunatic asylums, July, 1872; deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, Feb., 1874; served under the government of India, foreign department, from March, 1882, to March, 1884, as officiating political resident, 2nd class, and general superintendent of the operations for the suppression of thuggee and dacoity; acted as commissioner, Calcutta, and president of the boiler commission, 1885-86; commissioner of police, Calcutta, April, 1889.

LAMBERT, Parry, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1857; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, 8th Jan., 1858, and served in Oudh, and the Punjab; executive engineer, Dec., 1863; officiating controller of Punjab northern state railway accounts, Sept., 1875; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Madras, May, 1876; examiner, 3rd class, Oct., 1878; transferred to the office of examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, March, 1879; transferred to Bombay, as officiating examiner, public works accounts, Dec., 1879; from Dec., 1881, served in the N.W. Provinces as examiner, public works accounts, and officiated in Bengal, Feb.-Dec., 1882; examiner, 1st class, May, 1885; transferred to Bombay, May, 1884; and to the Punjab, Sept., 1886.

LANE, Clayton Turner, Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Ensign Bengal army, 11th Dec., 1853; from March, 1863, served in the Punjab as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent of police; transferred to Berar police, Sept., 1865; inspector-general of police and jails, Hyderabad assigned districts, April, 1877; is also inspector-general of jails, and registration and stamps, and registrar of joint stock companies.

LANE, James Horsburgh, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st Feb., 1857; superintendent, 1st grade, Bombay, Aug., 1870; officiating deputy director-general, March, 1872, and again Feb.-April, 1886; director of traffic, Feb., 1879; officiating deputy director-general, Feb., 1886, and Jan., 1890; confirmed, March, 1890.

LANE, John Macdonald, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 2nd Sept., 1862; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Bengal, Oct., 1866; served subsequently in the Malabar Coast and Nagpur divisions; 1st grade superintendent, British Burma, Sept., 1883, and afterwards in Bombay; charge of Bengal division, Dec., 1889.

LANE, Wilmot (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 13th January, 1855; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; from Aug., 1863 to March, 1866, served in Oudh as officiating deputy commissioner, Lucknow; magistrate and collector, Mainpuri, Jan., 1872; civil and sessions judge, Moradabad, Aug., 1877; commissioner, Rae Bareli Division, Sept., 1880, and subsequently of the Agra and Meerut divisions; officiating as member, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Oct.-Dec., 1883; retired, April, 1889.

LANG, Arthur Moffatt, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, N.W.P.—1st commission, June, 1852; arrived in India, July, 1854; assistant engineer, Punjab, Nov., 1855; superintendent, civil buildings, Lahore, Aug., 1856; executive engineer, March, 1857; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Delhi, the relief and capture of Lucknow, and various engagements (medal and clasps); assistant to chief engineer, Oudh, April, 1858; assistant secretary, public works department, to chief commissioner, Oudh, July, 1865; principal, Thomason Engineering College, March, 1871, to May, 1877; superintending engineer, 1st grade, deputy inspector-general military works, and secretary, defence committee, Feb., 1879; secretary to agent to governor-general, Beloochistan, public works department, Feb., 1881; chief engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, public works department, Jan., 1883; chief engineer and joint secretary, buildings and roads and railway branches, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, July, 1885; chief engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; retired, Nov., 1887.

LANG, George Lukis, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, March, 1858; from Nov., 1858, to Nov., 1866, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; from Nov., 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, deputy commissioner, Jhansi, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; appointed magistrate and collector, Aligarh, April, 1877, and was subsequently posted to Bulandshar; officiating district and sessions judge, July-Sept., 1880; has acted for various periods as commissioner in the Agra, Rohilkund, and Fyzabad divisions; commissioner of Jhansi, July, 1889.

LANG, Richard Tickell Montgomery, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Cavalry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; from May, 1862, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, Mooltan, April, 1877; officiating additional civil and sessions judge, Peshawur, April-Nov., 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, March, 1881, and subsequently in the Rawal Pindi Division; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1884.

ANGLEY, Edward Hartley Raynsford, Brigade-Surgeon, B.A. (Dub.), M.R.C.S. (Lon.), late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 23rd July, 1858; arrived in India, 23rd Sept., 1858; was employed under the military department, and as acting civil surgeon in various stations; served with 5th regiment, N.L.I., in China in 1860-62; appointed presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay, Oct., 1876; also in medical charge of the European General Hospital, May-June, 1882; brigade-surgeon, June, 1884; retired, Nov., 1889.

LANDSDOWNE (Marquess of), Rt. Hon. Henry Charles Keith FitzMaurice, G.M.S.I., G.M.I.E., G.C.M.G., Honorary D.C.L., Oxford.—Born, 1845; educated at Eton, and Balliol!
College, Oxford; succeeded to the marquisate in 1866; a lord of the treasury, 1868 to 1872; under secretary for war, 1872 to 1874; under secretary for India, April to July, 1880; governor-general of Canada, May, 1883; appointed governor-general of India, and assumed office, 10th Dec., 1888; hon. D.C.L., Oxford, 1888.

LARMINIE, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 2nd Aug., 1873; retired, 1887.

LARMINIE, WILLIAM REA, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 28th Dec., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1879; officiating commissioner, Orissa division, and superintendent of Tributary Mehals, Cuttack, June, 1883; officiating commissioner, Dacca, April, 1885; commissioner, Dacca division, Oct., 1886; retired, Aug., 1889.

LARYMORE, ALEXANDER DOUGLAS, Jail Department, Bengal.—Served in the Behar cavalry as trooper, 1857-8; joined the Bengal police as assistant superintendent, 31st July, 1862; district superintendent, June, 1872; on famine relief duty, Nov., 1874; superintendent, Midnapore jail, Jan., 1877; superintendent of Alipore jail, March, 1884; has also officiated as inspector-general of jails.

LATHAM, F. L., M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Service, Bombay.—Served as acting remembrancer of legal affairs, 23rd May, 1872, to 1st Jan., 1873; also acted as advocate-general, and as judge of the high court, Bombay, for various periods between 1st Jan., 1880, and 5th March, 1884; advocate-general, Bombay, 6th March, 1884; additional member of the Bombay Legislative Council.

LA TOUCHE, CECIL D'URBAN, Colonel, Bombay S.C., late Cantonment Magistrate, Bombay.—Ensign, 29th July, 1850; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1850, and served on military duty up to Nov., 1883, and subsequently as cantonment magistrate, Poona; returned to Europe, 1888.

LA TOUCHE, HENRY CHRISTOPHER DIGGES, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer, Punjab northern state railway; Agra-Gwalior railway survey, Nov., 1872; engineer-in-chief, Sindia state railway, construction division, Nov., 1879; Bundelcund railway surveys, 1881; engineer-in-chief, Jhansi-Manikpur state railway, Sept., 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; engineer-in-chief, Bellary-Kistna and Cuddapah-Nellore railways, March, 1886; lent to Southern Mahbatta Railway Company, Jan., 1888; superintending engineer, and class, March, 1889, and 1st class, Feb., 1890.

LATOUCHÉ, JAMES JOHN DIGGES, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer, till Dec., 1871, when he was transferred as settlement officer to Ajmere; also served as officiating assistant commissioner of Bewar and officiating deputy commissioner, Ajmere; returned to N.W. Provinces, 1875, and was appointed district superintendent of police, 1st grade, Bulandshahr, Sept., 1875; served subsequently in various districts in officiating appointments as settlement officer, magistrate and collector, and district and sessions judge, and was promoted to joint magistrate, 1st grade, July, 1882; settlement officer, 1st grade, Gorakhpur, Nov., 1883; from Aug., 1886, served in Burma as commissioner of the Southern division.

LATOUCHE, WILLIAM PAGET, Colonel, Bombay S.C., late Salt Department, Bombay.—1st commission, Bombay army, Sept., 1854; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1855; was employed on military duty, and served in the Persian war, 1856, and the mutiny campaign, and was also appointed assistant magistrate, Dec., 1859 and assistant district superintendent of police, Jan., 1865; acting political superintendent, Palanpur, June-Nov., 1867; from Dec., 1867, served in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent (1st grade, May, 1882), and also acted as superintendent of the Bombay, Baroda, and C. I. railway company's police, Nov., 1868, to Nov., 1869; on special duty, June, 1879, to Feb., 1880; from Feb., 1883, served as deputy collector of salt revenue; returned to Europe, 1887.

LAUDERDALE (Earl of), Rt. Hon. FREDERICK HENRY MATTLAND, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, 4th Hussars, Feb., 1861; served in Central India on civil employ from 1866 as boundary officer, and political assistant; 2nd assistant agent, Indore, 1877; 1st assistant agent, Indore, 1878; additional political agent and superintendent, Charkhari, 1880; retired, Jan., 1886.

LAUGHLIN, ROBERT CAMPBELL, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as assistant superintendent, Oct., 1865; held charge of various divisions, chiefly in Madras and Bengal, and charge of the telegraph stores, Calcutta; class iv., 2nd grade, Oct., 1887.

LAUGHTON, DANIEL WILSON, Major-General, M.S.C., late Berar Commission.—First commission in the army, Jan., 1854; arrived in Madras, April, 1854; from Jan., 1865, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and cantonment magistrate; acted as inspector-general of registration, Jan., 1873; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Feb., 1885; retired, May, 1886.

LAURIE, HENRY MONTAGUE, B.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1834; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1887, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

LAURIE, LEWIS KOSUTH, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 27th Oct., 1873; from Nov., 1873, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, and acting district superintendent of police; acted as registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, July, 1880, to March, 1883, and as small cause court judge, Nagpur, in 1881, 1882, and 1887; acting assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, 1883-85; acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, July-Oct., 1883, and again, March, 1885; acting director of agriculture, and junior secretary to
chief commissioner, Sept.-Oct., 1834; under secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1835; assistant commissioner, 2nd class, Oct., 1837; acted as secretary to chief commissioner in 1839 and 1840; author of 'digest of rulings of judicial commissioner,' and some manuals relating to the central provinces.

LAURIE, MAXWELL, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Watson's College, Edinburgh, and Edinburgh University, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Burma division of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Burma, 9th Dec., 1839, and served as assistant commissioner.

LAW, VICTOR EDWARD, Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras cavalry, April, 1850; acted as government agent at Chepak, paymaster of Carnatic stipendiaries, and Persian and Hindustani translator to government, July, 1869; attached foreign department, July, 1872; served in Rajputana as superintendent of railway police, 1872 to 1877; political agent, Jeypoor, 1877, and afterwards in Ulwar, 1877-1883; officiating political agent, Charkhari, 1883; assistant at Sujangarh to governor general's agent in Rajputana, Feb., 1884; agent to governor general with king of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, March, 1884; appointed to the political charge of ex-Amir Muhammad Yakub Khan of Kabul, Aug., 1884; graded as political agent, 3rd class.

LAWRENCE, ALEXANDER JOHN, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1856; served from March, 1858, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from March, 1864, served in the Central Provinces as settlement officer of Bhandara; re-attached to N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1869, and served as settlement officer and officiating magistrate and collector; member of the commission under the military department on the Lawrence asylums, June to Nov., 1872; on special duty with the government of India, home department, Dec., 1872; officiating civil and sessions judge, Mainpuri, June, 1874; magistrate and collector, Etawah, Oct., 1874, and subsequently of Agra; officiated for various periods as commissioner, Agra division; commissioner of the Allahabad division, April, 1885, and Meerut division, April, 1889; C.I.E., May, 1888.

LAWRENCE, EDWARD, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; acted as assistant to the political resident at Aden, March, 1882, and as under secretary to Government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the governor's council for making laws and regulations, April, 1885; compiler of general administration report for 1884-85; acted as assistant judge and sessions judge, and as under secretary to government, in revenue, financial, and general departments; under secretary to the Government of India; finance and commerce department, April, 1889; deputy accountant general, Bombay, April, 1890.

LAWRENCE, HENRY JOHN, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 14th February, 1862; from Aug., 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; district judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884, Amritsar; additional divisional judge, Amritsar, Jan., 1885; officiating divisional judge, Jullundur, Jan., 1887; appointed 3rd grade, divisional judge, April, 1886.

LAWRENCE, RICHARD CHARLES, General, C.B., Bengal S.C., late Punjab Commission.—First commission, Bengal infantry, June, 1834; served in the Sutlej campaign in 1846, and was present at the battle of Sobraon (medal); second in command, Loodianah regiment, Dec., 1847; assistant commissioner, Punjab, April, 1849; captain of police, Lahore division, Jan., 1853; served in the Indian mutiny as political officer in charge of the Cashmere contingent, under General Wilson, in 1857, and was present at the assault and capture of Delhi (brevet of major, C.B., medal with clasp); military secretary to lieutenant governor of the Punjab, 1860; deputy commissioner, Simla, April, 1862; resident, Nepaul, 1867 to 1872.

LAWRENCE WALTER ROPE, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Sept., 1881, to April, 1884, served in Ajmere and Merwara as officiating political assistant and assistant commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; in charge Ajmere treasury and office of registrar of assurances, May, 1882; under-secretary to government, Punjab, April, 1886; under secretary to government of India, revenue department, Sept., 1886; C.I.E., Jan., 1891.

LAWRIE, EDWARD, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Indian Medical Department.—First commission, Bengal medical service, 1872; surgeon-major, March, 1884; residency surgeon, Hyderabad, April, 1885; is also superintendent of vaccination, superintendent of medical school, and surgeon to the Afzalganj hospital.

LEA, JAMES HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1888, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

LEARY, A.S., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at the Moravian colleges of Fulneck in Yorkshire, and Neuwied on the Rhine; temporary clerk, India Office, 15th Nov., 1860; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

LE BRETON, WILLIAM INGLIS, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined the royal artillery, Dec., 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; joined the public works department, Nov., 1866, and served as assistant engineer in the Bombay presidency till Nov., 1869, and subsequently as assistant controller and deputy controller of accounts in the Punjab, N.W. Provinces, and Bombay; controller, 3rd class, and examiner of railway accounts, Bombay, Sept., 1874; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, Nov., 1877; from Dec., 1879, served as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, and was promoted to 2nd class, May, 1886; also officiated as examiner of public works accounts, Sept.-Dec., 1883, and
port storekeeper, state railways, March-June, 1884; examiner, public works accounts, Bombay, Feb., 1887; retired, June, 1890.

LEE, HARRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Yarmouth Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, March, 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1885; 1st grade, Feb., 1888; chairman of the commissioners, Calcutta, April, 1890; has also officiated as magistrate and collector.

LEE, WILLIAM HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1887; and served as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Assam, May, 1890.

LEEDS, ROBERT JAMES, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1861; served from Aug., 1862, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating deputy superintendent of the family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1879, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge; retired, April, 1887.

LEEDS, WILLIAM HENRY ARTHUR ST. JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1883; transferred to Burma, as assistant commissioner, Nov., 1883.

LEE-WARNER, JOHN, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in various districts of Madras from April, 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate and acting cantonment magistrate; on special duty, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, North Arcot and Salem, Jan., 1868; boundary arbitrator between the Kalastri Zemindari and Madras district, Sept., 1868; special assistant collector, Madura, for the management of the Rammad estate, Dec., 1871, to March, 1873; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1882; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, May, 1884; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Oct., 1884; collector and magistrate, Dec., 1884; retired, Jan., 1890.

LEE-WARNER, WILLIAM, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th November, 1869; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1870; officiating director of public instruction, Berar, Feb., 1872; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May, 1872, to Nov., 1874, and Jan.-Dec., 1876; on special duty in the secretariat, Nov., 1874; acting under secretary to government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and acting secretary to the legislative council, Bombay, Nov., 1874; from Dec., 1876, to Aug., 1878, served in Sind as assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration, acting educational inspector, and acting commissioner; acting junior collector and magistrate, Satara, March, 1881; on special duty as member of the education commission, Calcutta, 1882; on special duty at the Nira canal, April, 1882; from Jan.-Oct., 1884, acted as junior under secretary to government of India, foreign department, and as private secretary to the president in council of the governor-general (Jan.-Feb.), and was on special duty in the foreign department, March-June, 1884; acting press commissioner, Sept., 1884; acting under secretary to government of India, foreign department, Oct., 1884; first assistant collector and acting director of public instruction, Bombay, March, 1885; on special duty in the Hyderabad State, Nov., 1885; acting political agent, Kolhapur, and Southern Mahratta country, Jan., 1886; also president of the Regency Council, Kolhapur, May, 1886; secretary to government of Bombay, Aug., 1887.

LE FANU, WILLIAM JOSEPH HENRY, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown School, Tipperary Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; served in Madras revenue and judicial departments from Oct., 1866, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled Salem district manual; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Dec., 1885; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1886.

LEGEYT, PHILIP HARRISON, Colonel, Bombay S.C., late Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 27th March, 1851; was employed under the military department, including service with the Persian expeditionary force (medal and clasp); served subsequently with the Gujerat Irregular Horse, and also acted as assistant political agent, Mahi Kantha (April, 1858); from May, 1863, served in the political department as assistant political agent, Káthiáwar and Cutch, and magistrate of the district of Bhávnagar; political agent, Mahi Kántha, 1872-1880; political superintendent, Pálanpur, Sept., 1880; 1st grade, political agent, Feb., 1885; returned to Europe, 1886.

LEGGATT, EDWARD OWEN EVERY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, and Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1883; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and was appointed assistant superintendent and judge of the small cause court, Dehra Dun, April, 1890.

LEITNER, GOTTLIEB WILLIAM, Dr., M.A., Ph.D., LL.D., D.C.L., Barrister-at-Law, late Education Department, Punjab.—Served in education department as principal of the Lahore College from 12th Nov., 1864, and was promoted to 2nd grade of the department, Nov., 1880; in July, 1867, was deputed to Kashmir for a philological examination of the Kashmiri and Chilasi dialects; on special duty in connection with the school text-book committee at Simla, May, 1877; attended the congress of Orientalists at Florence.
Oct., 1873; officiating director of public instruction, Punjab, July, 1879; on special duty with education commission, May, 1882; retired in 1886.

LELY, Frederic Styles Philipin, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th December, 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting city survey and inquiry officer at Ahmedabad, acting Talukdari settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; in charge of the Sachin state, Oct., 1881; first assistant collector, Surat, Dec., 1884; administrator of the Porbandar State in Kathiawar; junior collector, June, 1890.

LEMAN, George Downton, late Madras C.S., appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed principal assistant to the collector and magistrate and agent, Ganjam, Dec., 1866; acting civil and sessions judge, Guntoor, July, 1867, and afterwards at Tellicherry; acted as collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, in 1868, and again in 1875 and 1881-82, and as Inam commissioner in 1869; from Feb., 1872, to Nov., 1877, served as collector and magistrate of Kistna, and subsequently in Ganjam and Coimbatore; retired, March, 1883.

LE MESSURIER, Augustus, Colonel, R.E., C.I.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st Commission, Bombay Engineers, Dec., 1856; served in the Indian Mutiny at the sieges of Forts Beyt and Dwarka; joined the Bombay public works department, as assistant engineer, May, 1860; was employed on the Karachi harbour works, on irrigation in Sind, on the Bombay harbour defences, &c.; executive engineer, March, 1863; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, Aug., 1864; served in the Abyssinian expedition, 1868 (medal); deputy consulting engineer for railways in Sind, Aug., 1871; acted as consulting engineer, Lahore, April-July, 1875; acted as secretary to the railway transport committee at Delhi, in 1875-76, and to a similar committee at Agra, 1876-77; deputed to Brussels exhibition to report on continental system of transport by railways, Aug., 1876; superintending engineer, May, 1877; officiating under secretary to government of India, railway branch, May, 1877, to Nov., 1878; served in the Afghan war, 1879-80, (medal and brevet of lieutenant-colonel); engineer-in-chief, Mysore State railway, Nov., 1879; joint secretary to chief commissioner, Mysore, 1880; on special duty reporting on timber-cutting operations in east of France, April, 1880; manager, Mysore State railway, Feb., 1881; consulting engineer to Mysore Government, and secretary to chief commissioner, Coorg, March, 1882; superintending engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1883; engineer-in-chief, Bangalore-Hariharpur railway; 3rd chief engineer, March, 1887; on special duty, military department, Dec., 1887; officiating consulting engineer, railways, Calcutta, Feb., 1888; 2nd chief engineer, April, 1888; on special railway duty, Dec., 1888; 1st chief engineer and secretary to Government of Punjab, May 1889.

LE MESURIER, Havilland, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1886; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Assam, Nov., 1886.

LE MESURIER, John, Lieutenant-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1852; second lieutenant, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1855; served in the public works department in Sind from June, 1856, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and was employed on the Nara works and the Rohri canal, Hyderabad; served with the Persian expedition, 1856-57 (medal and clasp); on special duty, Karachi, Jan., 1867; acting superintending engineer for irrigation in Sind, April, 1871, to Dec. 1873, and for various periods between 1875 and 1880; superintendent of works, Western Indus, Karachu, Dec., 1873; superintending engineer, Jan., 1879; officiating chief engineer for irrigation and under secretary to government of Bombay, June-Aug., 1883; (temporary) chief engineer, 3rd class, and chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government, public works department (irrigation), March, 1884; superintending engineer in Sind, Jan., 1886; retired, March, 1887.

LETHBRIDGE, Alfred Swaine, C.S.I., Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1867; served from March, 1872, as superintendent of central jail and officiating civil surgeon, Bhagulpore; officiating inspector-general of prisons, sanitary commissioner, and superintendent of vaccination, British Burma, July, 1876; officiating sanitary commissioner, Bengal, May, 1877; inspector-general of jails, Bengal, Jan., 1878; rank of surgeon-major, Sept., 1879; C.S.I., May, 1890; president of the factory commission, Bombay, 1890.

LETHEREN, S. K., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 6th July, 1877.

LEUPOLT, John Cunningham, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from Aug., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from Aug., 1882, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge; retired, April, 1889.

LEVESON, Henry George Ashworth, Bengal C.S., (Burma).—Educated at Marlborough college and Clare college, Cambridge; appointed to the Burma division of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Burma, 14th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant commissioner.

LEVINGE, Edward Vere, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885, arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1885, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

LEVY, Frank, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton School, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 15th Nov., 1887, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

LEWIS, E. M. — Superintendent, Bengal secretariat press, April, 1869; superintendent of government printing, Bengal, Sept., 1877.
LEWIS, THOMAS CROMPTON, M.A. (Cambridge), Punjab Educational Service.—Appointed professor government college, Lahore, 18th Oct., 1881; promoted to 3rd grade of graded staff, Feb., 1886; 2nd grade, April, 1886; principal of government college, Lahore, 3rd May, 1886.

LIARDET, CHARLES AYLMER, Colonel, M.S.C., late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras infantry, Oct., 1855; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1855; Madras staff corps, Sept., 1866; served in the Madras revenue survey department from Oct., 1868; on famine relief works, Jan., 1877, to March, 1878; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Sept., 1884; retired, April, 1888.

LIDDERDALE, ROBERT, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1858; superintendent of vaccination, 8th November, 1869; in medical charge, Jalipgoree, in addition to his own duties, June, 1872; sanitary commissioner, Bengal, April, 1880; professor of hygiene, Medical College; rank of surgeon-major, Jan., 1870; deputy surgeon-general (local rank), Bengal, Jan., 1884; retired, Jan., 1889.

LIGHTFOOT, JABEZ, Railway Department, Government of India.—Appointed from the Scinde, Punjab, and Delhi railway as deputy manager, North-Western state railway, Jan., 1886; class 1, revenue establishment, state railways, July, 1886; manager, Punjab section, March, 1887; Sind section, May, 1887; auditor Oudh and Rohilkund railway, Jan., 1889; transferred to superior accounts establishment, Sept., 1889; acted as manager, Oudh and Rohilkund railway in 1890.

LILLINGSTON, EDWARD GORDON, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission in army, 30th Aug., 1859; from 5th Feb., 1864, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1867, officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, Feb., 1874, superintendent of the central jail, and the European penitentiary at Hazaribagh, May, 1875, and deputy commissioner, and grade, March, 1886; 1st grade, Aug., 1887.

LIMOND, DAVID, Major-General, C.B., R.E., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1850; assistant engineer, public works department, Bengal, Feb., 1853; during the mutiny, served at relief and defence of Lucknow (medal and clasp); executive engineer, Cawnpore, 1858; officiating superintending engineer, Allahabad, April, 1867, and in Bengal, western circle, from March, 1868; transferred to Rawal Pindee, Jan., 1869; superintending engineer, military works, Rawal Pindee, April, 1872; in 1879-80 served as commanding engineer, Peshawur Valley field force (medal, C.B.); chief engineer, 3rd class, military works, April, 1881; chief engineer and secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1883; chief engineer, 1st class, July, 1884; retired, 1886.

LINDSAY, BENJAMIN, Bengal C.S., N.W. Provinces.—Educated at the Methodist College, Belfast, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

LINDSAY, CHARLES ROBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Woolwich, and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1844; arrived in India, 1845; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Farakhabad, 1858; magistrate and collector, Farakhabad, 1862; extra judge of the Sudder court, Agra, 1863; civil and sessions judge, Mynpoorie, 1865, and subsequently of Goruckpore and Moradabad; judge of the chief court, Punjab, 1869; retired, 1880.

LINDSAY, JAMES GAVIN, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department.—Lieutenant, Madras engineers, Aug., 1855; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, Dec., 1857; during the mutiny served at the battle of Banda, (medal and clasp), served subsequently as executive engineer in Banda and Orissa; deputy consulting engineer for railways, 1855; executive engineer, 1st grade, railway survey, Mysore, April, 1870; officiating superintending engineer, and engineer-in-chief, Northern Bengal railway, 1872; acted as director of state railways, N.E. system, and joint secretary to Bengal government, Nov., 1878, to March, 1879; engineer-in-chief, Harnai and Gulistan-Karez sections of Kandahar railway, Feb., 1880; served in the Afghan Campaign, 1879-80, (medal); superintending engineer and secretary to resident, Hyderabad, March, 1881; engineer-in-chief, Southern Mahratta railway, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, 1st class (supernumerary), April, 1881; services lent to Southern Mahratta railway company, from May, 1884; engineer-in-chief, Bolan railway, April-June, 1885; 3rd chief engineer, March, 1887; 2nd chief engineer, April, 1888.

LINDSAY, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Winchester; junior clerk, India Office, 31st Jan., 1867; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, 1877-81; senior clerk, Jan., 1882.
