LISTER, ALLEN LINDSAY, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Rossall School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from March, 1865, in the grades of assistant and sub-collector, and was placed on special duty in connection with the relief of the poorer classes, South Arcot, Jan., 1868; on famine duty, Sept. to Dec., 1877; on special duty, Irrigation and Canal Company, Jan., 1878; collector and magistrate, South Canara, July, 1882; district and sessions judge, Nov., 1882, in Vizagapatam, and afterwards in the Godavari district; retired, March, 1890.

LISTON, JOHN, Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 29th May, 1856; served with the Bundelcund field force in the campaign of 1859; from Aug., 1863, served in Jhansi, Kumaon, and Ajmere, as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Lalitpur, Dec., 1879; officiating commissioner, Jhansi, Aug. to Nov., 1882; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1887; retired, Nov., 1889.

LITTLE, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, M.D., M.C., L.R.C.S., L.M., Madras Medical Service.—Arrived in Madras, 1st Nov., 1872, and served under the military department; civil surgeon, Akola, Jan., 1877; sanitary commissioner, inspector-general of dispensaries, superintendent of vaccination, and administrative medical officer of the Hyderabad assigned districts, July, 1881; surgeon-major, March, 1884.

LITTLE, F. A., Judicial Department, Bom-
bay.—Acted as government solicitor and public prosecutor, Bombay, Oct.–Nov., 1879, and May to Nov., 1883, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1884.

LITTLE, THOMAS DAVID, M.I.C.E., Bombay Public Works Department.—Joined the service June, 1859, and arrived in India, Oct., 1859; appointed assistant engineer, Aug., 1862, and executive engineer, Jan., 1869; superintending engineer, Sept., 1889; was an additional member of the governor's council for making laws and regulations, Dec., 1859 to May, 1860; acted also as chief engineer.

LIVESAY, JOHN JAMES, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; from Jan., 1863, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner, and was appointed magistrate and collector, and grade, Oct., 1878; employed on famine relief duty, March to Oct., 1874; retired, March, 1883.

LLOYD, ERNEST THOMAS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and Shrewsbury, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Feb., 1882; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1885; and served as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Dec., 1886; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, March, 1889.

LLOYD, FRANCIS, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at the College School, Gloucester; appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1844; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and session judge; judicial assistant to magistrate, Satara, 1860; judge and session judge, Dharwar, 1861; judge and session judge, Poona, and agent for Sirdars in the Deccan, 1866; judge of the high court, Bombay, 1869; retired in 1873.

LLOYD, R. A., B.A., late Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the education department, from 1st May, 1864, as professor and officiating principal, Agra College; from Oct., 1867, served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to the 2nd grade of educational officers, April, 1870; acted as principal of the Bareilly College, 1875–76.

LOCH, FRANCIS ADAM ELLIS, General, C.B., Bombay S.C., late Political Department, Bombay.—Educated at Edinburgh High School, and Rochester School; 1st commission as cornet, Bombay cavalry, 7th April, 1844; served in the Punjab campaign, 1848–49, and was present at the siege and capture of Mooltan (medal and clasp); served subsequently as adjutant of the Southern Mahratta horse, 1850, and of the 1st regiment Bombay light cavalry, 1850–57; in the mutiny of 1857–58 was wounded at the outbreak of the Bengal troops at Nusserabad, May, 1857; was present at the siege and capture of Awah and Cotah, the recapture of Chandaree, the action at Kotah-ke-Serai, the capture of Gwalior, the siege of Poria, the pursuit of rebels under Maun Sing, and the action of Koondrye (brevet of major, medal and clasp), served in the Abyssinian expedition of 1867–68, and was present at the battle of Arogee, and the capture of Magdala (brevet of colonel, medal and clasp); C.B., May, 1875; political superintendent and commandant, Upper Sind frontier, 1873 to 1876; commanded Hyderabad contingent, 1876, and the station at Ahmednugger, 1876–77; political resident, Aden, and commanding Aden brigade, May, 1877, to March, 1882.

LOCH, JAMES HENRY, M.D., Deputy Surgeon-General, late Central Provinces.—Joined the Bengali medical service, Dec., 1854; arrived in India, 31st Jan., 1855; served under the military department till Aug., 1859, including service with the Oudh field force in 1855, and at the relief of Azamgarh, 1858 (medal), and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon in various stations and superintendent of jail, and held medical charge of the lieutenant-governor's camp in 1869–70, and again, 1872 and 1873; brigade-surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Central Provinces, Jan., 1884; retired, Jan., 1886.

LOCH, WILLIAM, Major, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, March, 1866; served in the 10th Foot; joined the Bombay staff corps, May, 1868, and served subsequently in the Sind horse; assistant political superintendent, Sawantwari, May, 1877; assistant to general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggery and dacoitie, 1878; 2nd assistant to governor-general's agent, Indore, 1879; assistant at Banswarra and Pertabgurh, 1880; during the Afghan war was on political duty with Major-General Sir R. Phayre's force, marching to the relief of Kandahar (medal); 2nd assistant agent, Beloochistan, in charge of Pishin valley, Nov., 1880; assistant resident, Western Rajputana, and boundary settlement officer in Marwar, Dec., 1881; graded as additional political agent, 3rd class.

LOCH, WILLIE WALKER, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; acting principal of the Raja's school, and tutor and governor of the Gaekwar, Baroda, April–Nov., 1880; first assistant collector and railway magistrate, Thana, Oct., 1882; junior collector and magistrate, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kantha, Sept., 1888.

LOGAN, ALEXANDER COCHRANE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1889; served in the Central Provinces from 1859 to 1881, in the grade of assistant commissioner, and officiated as district superintendent of police, March, 1872, inspector of schools, Dec., 1873, to March, 1874, and registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, April, 1874, to Dec., 1876; from April to Nov.,
1831, served in the financial department in Bengal as deputy accountant-general and officiating accountant-general; appointed assistant comptroller-general in class III of the financial department, Sept., 1831; acted as under-secretary, government of India, finance and commerce department, from Nov., 1831, and was confirmed in this appointment, July, 1833; officiated as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Aug.–Oct., 1833, and as deputy accountant-general, Feb., 1834, and again in 1835; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, March 2, 1834; officiating deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Sept., 1834; officiating accountant-general, Punjab, March, 1835; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Dec., 1835; officiating accountant-general, Punjab, April, 1837; class 2 of enrolled officers, Nov., 1837; accountant-general, Bombay, and commissioner of the issue of state paper currency, March, 1839.

LOGAN, WILLIAM, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Musselburgh Grammar School, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and acting district and sessions judge; collector and magistrate of Malabar, March, 1876; on special duty, Feb., 1881, as commissioner for inquiring into certain important matters in the Moplah districts; fellow of University of Madras, March, 1881; member of Forest Draft Bill Committee, March, 1882; acting member, board of revenue, Nov., 1882; acting resident of Travancore and Cochin, May, 1883 to Feb., 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with Report on Land Tenures of Malabar, Feb., 1884, and again in connection with the Attipadi Valley suit, July, 1884; retired, 1888; has published a collection of treaties, engagements, &c., relating to British affairs in Malabar, 1879; and edited Mr. Graeme's glossary of Malayalam words and phrases, 1882.

LOKENDRO, NATH PALIT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1834; arrived in India, 15th Dec., 1836, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

LORD, WALTER FREWEN, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; retired, Feb., 1889.

LOVE, HENRY DAVISON, Captain, R.E., Madras Education Department.—Educated at University College, Bath, and Royal Military Academy, Woolwich; Lieutenant, R.E., 12th September, 1872; acted as inspector of schools for science and art department, 1875–76; admitted to Madras establishment, Oct., 1876; arrived in India, 5th December, 1876; first assistant master civil engineering college, July, 1877; on special duty in connection with Madras harbour works, Dec., 1877; served subsequently in the P.W. Department, and acted as deputy consulting engineer for railways in 1878 and 1879, and as deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government, irrigation branch, June–Nov., 1879; assistant examiner of accounts, Nov. 1879; principal, civil engineering college, Jan., 1880; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; member of committee in connection with scheme of technical education, Sept., 1885.

LOVETT, BERESFORD, Colonel, C.B., C.S.I., R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1858; arrived in India, Sept., 1860; joined the public works department, April, 1861, and served in the Punjab till Sept., 1866, when he was transferred to the Persian telegraph department; assistant commissioner, Seistan boundary commission, Sept., 1870; rejoined P.W. department as executive engineer, Sept., 1872; C.S.I., Feb., 1873; attached to Bori Valley field force, Nov., 1877 to Jan., 1878; served in the Afghan war, 1878–79; transferred to Bengal, Feb., 1881; British consul at Astrabad, Sept., 1880 to Jan., 1881; superintending engineer, Bengal, 1885; transferred to military works, Rawal Pindi command, April, 1886; commanding engineer, Hazara field force, Sept., 1888; C.B., 1889.

LOVETT, SACKVILLE HALTON HARRINGTON VERNEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sherborne, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner.

LOWIS, CECIL CHAMPAINE, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Newton College, Devonshire, Government Gymnasium, Gottingen, and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1885; arrived in Burma, 8th Jan., 1888, and served as assistant commissioner and registrar to judicial commissioner, Burma.

LOWIS, EDMOND ELLIOT, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1857; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1858; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Sept., 1861; deputy commissioner, Western Dooars, Oct. 1867; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Oct., 1867; magistrate and collector, Maldah, Dec., 1867; officiating civil and sessions judge, Aug., 1868; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1872; commissioner, Chittagong division, March, 1875; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1879; officiating opium agent, Behar, Jan. to Nov., 1879; commissioner, Dacca division, Dec., 1885, and in the Rajshahiye division, Oct., 1886.

LOWNDES, THOMAS, Major-General, M.S.C., late Police Department, Burma.—Joined the Madras army, and arrived in India, Dec., 1854; served in the Burma police department from March, 1861, as superintendent; on special mission to Chingme, March–May, 1871; political agent, Bhamo, May, 1872, to Oct., 1873; 1st grade, superintendent, May, 1875; inspector-general of police, British Burma, Jan., 1876; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1885; retired, Aug., 1887.

LUARD, CHARLES HENRY, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1855; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, Lower Provinces, Nov., 1857; deputy superintendent, Western Jumna canal, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1859; assistant principal, Thomason College, 1862; assistant secretary, government of India, public works department, officiating as deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bengal, March,
1865; deputy superintendent, Ganges canal, 1865; confirmed as deputy consulting engineer, Bengal, Oct., 1867; officiating under secretary, government of India, railway branch, Oct., 1873 to 1875; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, June, 1874; officiating mint master, Calcutta, July to Oct., 1876; officiating consulting engineer, Lucknow, 1877; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, 1884, and subsequently at Calcutta, Dec., 1885; chief engineer, 2nd class, May, 1886; 1st class, March, 1887; while on leave, in 1887, deputed to attend railway conference at Milan; consulting engineer for railways, Dec., 1889; retired, Jan., 1890.

LUCAS, ARTHUR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1884; forest settlement officer, March, 1886.

LUCAS, WILLIAM HENRY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service, after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1888; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1889.

LUDLAM, JOSEPH T., late Registry Department, India Office.—Served under the India Board from 1838; registrar at India Board, 1859, and continued in charge of the records till 1867, when he was transferred to the registry department, India Office, as extra assistant to registrar; retired, May, 1883.

LUDLOW, EDMOND SAMUEL, C.I.E., Colonel, M.S.C., Hyderabad Administration.—Served with the Madras Native Infantry from 1858 to 1864 and with the Sangor Field Division in 1859; from Oct., 1864, served in Mysore and Coorg as assistant superintendent; judge of the small cause court, Bangalore, 1874 and 1875; assistant commissioner, June, 1874; cantonment magistrate, Secunderabad, Sept., 1881; services lent to H.H. the Nizam's government, and appointed judge of the suburban court, Hyderabad, Feb., 1884; inspector general of police to the Nizam's government, April, 1884; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, May, 1887; 2nd class, July, 1889.

LUFKIN, GEORGE, India Office.—Clerk to the clerk of the works, India office, 21st June, 1860; clerk of the works, Aug., 1874; surveyor and clerk of the works, April, 1882.

LUGARD, HENRY IBBETSON, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1853; was employed under the military department till 1864, also serving in the Madras police in 1857 and 1863-61; from Jan., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as superintendent of the school of industry, Jubbulpore, May to Sept., 1869; cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, March 1873; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Dec., 1885.

LUKE, STEPHEN PAGET WALTER VYVYAN, C.I.E., M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as assistant superintendent, 16th Jan., 1868; arrived in India, 29th Feb., 1868, and served in Bengal, Madras, and N.W. Provinces; had charge of field telegraph with Peshawur Valley force, Nov., 1878, and with Afghanistan force, Sept., 1879; appointed C.I.E.; superintendent, April, 1880; on special duty in director-general's office in connexion with field telegraphs, Jan., 1887; officiated as director, construction branch, in 1887 and 1888; has held charge of various divisions, including Madras, July, 1889; on special duty, Calcutta, Jan., 1890; director construction branch March, 1890.

LUMSDEN, JOHN JAMES FOOTE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Gorakhpur, July, 1874; on special duty to Naini Tal, July-Sept., 1875; commissioner, Fyzabad division, Dec., 1879, and subsequently of the Benares division, and agent to the governor-general; senior member of board of revenue, Nov., 1889.

LUMSDEN, SIR PETER S., General, G.C.B., C.S.I.—Ensign, Bengal army, Dec., 1847; assistant executive engineer, 1849; served with the force employed in various expeditions against the frontier tribes in 1852-6; deputy assistant quartermaster-general at the action of Punghao, 15th April, 1852; served in the expeditions against the Boree Afrereedeees in 1853; against Mohmund tribe in 1854; and the Meranzaie and Kooran expeditions of Nov., 1856; on a special military mission to Afghanistan, 1857-1858 (medal and clasp); assistant quartermaster-general, Sept., 1858; accompanied China expedition in 1860; and present at actions of Sinho and Tangchow, assault and capture of Taku forts and advance on Pekin (medal, 2 clasps, and brevet of major); deputy quartermaster-general, April, 1863; with Bhootan field force in 1865 (clasp); quartermaster-general, May, 1868; officiating resident, Hyderabad, 1872; adjutant-general, Sept., 1874; chief of the staff, 1879; member of council of India, 1st Dec., 1883; Afghan boundary commissioner, Sep., 1884, to June, 1885.

LUSHINGTON, EDWARD HARBOURD, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1841; arrived in India, 22nd June, 1841; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate of Chittagong in 1847, and afterwards of Patna; deputy collector of government sea customs, Calcutta, 1855; collector, Nuddea, 1856; junior secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, 1857; acting commissioner of the Burdwan, Manbhoom, and Singbhoom district, 1857-58; Mutiny medal; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Nuddea, 1861; secretary to government of Bengal, 1861; secretary to government of India in the financial department, government director of Bank of Bengal, and member of mint committee, 1863; retired, 1871.

LUSON, HEWLING, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Olave's, Southwark, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Nuddea, Jan., 1885; has officiated as magistrate and collector.

LUTTMAN-JOHNSON, HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Winchester, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of
1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, April, 1872; acting under secretary, government of Bengal, department of scarcity and relief, Oct., 1873, to Feb., 1874; transferred to Assam, Feb., 1874, as deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, and secretary to chief commissioner; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, July, 1879; judge and commissioner, Assam Valley districts, May, 1886.

LYALL, Sir Alfred Comyns, K.C.B., K.C.I.E., D.C.L., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Central Provinces, April, 1864, and served as deputy commissioner, officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating commissioner of the Nagpur division; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, July, 1867, and appointed commissioner, West Berar, Aug., 1867; secretary to the government of India, home department, March, 1873; from Nov., 1874, served in the foreign department of the government of India, and was appointed resident, 1st class, and agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, and chief commissioner of Ajmere; on special duty in England, Aug., 1876; secretary to government of India, foreign department, April, 1878; on special political duty in Kabul, March, 1880, and again in Sept., 1880; K.C.B., May, 1881; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, and chief commissioner of Oudh, 17th April, 1882; C.I.E., May, 1882; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887; retired, Dec., 1887; appointed member of the Indian council, 17th Jan., 1888; D.C.L. (Oxon.), 1880.

LYALL, Charles James, M.A., LL.D., C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at King's College School, King's College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiated at various times as under secretary to government, and as junior secretary, Oct., 1872; assistant under secretary to government of India, foreign department, April-June, 1872; from April, 1873, served under the government of India in the department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, and was appointed under secretary to government, Sept., 1873, and was placed on special duty, Sept., 1873; transferred to Assam as officiating secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1880; officiating judge and commissioner, Assam Valley districts, 1883, and July, 1888; secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1883; officiating secretary to Government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Feb.-Nov., 1886, and in the home department, Sept., 1886; on special duty to report on penal settlement, Port Blair, Dec., 1886; author of article on 'Hindustani Literature' in Encyclopaedia Britannica, 1880; 'Sketch of the Hindustani language,' 1880; 'Translations of ancient Arabic Poetry,' 1885; and 'Guide to the transliteration of Hindu and Muhammadan names in the Bengal army,' 1885.

LYALL, David Robert, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; officiating commissioner, Dacca division, March, 1878, and Presidency division, Feb., 1882; inspector-general of police, March, 1883; officiating commissioner of Chittagong, Oct., 1884; confirmed, Aug., 1887; C.S.I., 1 Jan., 1891.

LYALL, Sir James Broadwood, K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1858; arrived, April 8, 1858; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and deputy commissioner; settlement commissioner, Mooltan and Derajat, March, 1874; financial commissioner, Punjab, Jan., 1879; resident in Mysore and chief commissioner of Coorg, Dec., 1883; also judicial commissioner of Coorg; graded in the political department as resident, 1st class; lieutenant-governor of the Punjab, April, 1897.

LYLE, Henry Ward, LL.B., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Winchester, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1887, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, Nov., 1889.

LYNCH, Sidney S., late Medical Department, Bengal.—From 16th Nov., 1858, served in Assam as civil medical officer, and inspector of landing of native labourers, and from Jan., 1866, in Bengal, as superintendent, presidency jail; superintendent of the Alipore jail, and ex-officio deputy inspector-general of jails, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1871; officiating health officer, port of Calcutta, May, 1879; confirmed in this appointment, April, 1882; retired, 1889.

LYON, George Kenneth, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1885.

LYON, Isidore Bernadotte, C.I.E., Brigade-Surgeon, F.C.S., M.R.C.S., L.S.A., F.I.C., Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 1st March, 1866; acting professor of anatomy and curator of museum, Grant Medical College, March, 1866; professor of chemistry, Grant Medical College, and chemical analyser to government, Jan., 1867; in addition to these appointments was also third physician at the Sir Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, July, 1867, to Oct., 1872, professor of medical jurisprudence, Grant Medical College, from July, 1868, and professor of chemistry at the Elphinstone College from Dec., 1875; on special duty conducting petroleum experiments, Oct.-Nov., 1882; brigade surgeon, Sept., 1887; acting principal Grant Medical College, June to Dec., 1888; C.I.E., May, 1889.

LYON, Percy Comyn, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at King's School, Bruton, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of
LYTTELTON, Hon. Neville Gerald, Col., Rifle Brigade.—1st commission, ensign, Rifle Brigade, 14th Jan., 1865; Major, Feb., 1882; Col. (army), Nov., 1886; A.D.C. to lord lieutenant of Ireland, Jan., 1869, to Oct., 1873; served in the Jowaki expedition of 1877, medal with clasp; private secretary to secretary of state for war, April, 1880, to Aug., 1882; A.D.C. to chief of staff expeditionary force, Egypt, Aug.-Oct., 1882, including battle of Tel-el-Kebir, medal with clasp, bronze star, brevet lieutenant-colonel, 4th class Osmanich; assistant military secretary to governor of Gibraltar, Jan., 1883, to March, 1885; military secretary on personal staff of governor of Bombay, 31st March, 1885, to 11th April, 1890.

LYTTON (Earl of), Right Hon. Edward Robert Bulwer-Lytton, G.C.B., G.C.S.I.—Born Nov. 8, 1831; educated at Harrow, and afterwards at Bonn; entered the diplomatic service in 1849, and served as attaché successively at Washington, Florence, Paris, the Hague, St. Petersburg, and Constantinople; from Jan., 1859, to Jan., 1863, he was attached to the Vienna embassy, during which period he acted as consul-general at Belgrade (Feb.-March, 1860), and was employed on a special mission to prevent the renewal of hostilities between the Turks and Servians; and secretary in the diplomatic service, Oct., 1862; secretary of legation at Copenhagen, Jan., 1863, at Athens, May, 1864, and at Lisbon, April, 1865; successfully concluded the negotiation of a commercial treaty with Austria; transferred to Madrid, Feb., 1868; secretary of embassy at Vienna, Oct., 1868, and at Paris, Oct., 1872; during the periods of his service at Copenhagen, Lisbon, Vienna, and Paris he acted on several occasions as chargé-d'affaires, and during the absence of the ambassador at Paris, was accredited there as minister plenipotentiary; ambassador at Lisbon, Nov., 1874; viceroy and governor-general of India, April 12, 1876, to April, 1880; during his tenure of office as governor-general he presided at the Delhi assembly, on the proclamation of Her Majesty the Queen as Empress of India, Jan. 1, 1877, and was the object of an attempt at assassination, Dec., 1879; G.C.B., Dec., 1877; created an earl, April, 1880; a royal commissioner for the London exhibition of 1886; was appointed ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary to the French Republic, Nov., 1887; his published literary works include: 'Clytemnestra, the Earl's Return, the Artist and other Poems,' 1855; 'The Wanderer: a Collection of Poems in Many Lands,' 1859; 'Lucile,' 1860; 'Tannhauser, or the Battle of the Bards' (written in collaboration with the Hon. Julian Fane), 1861; 'Serbski Pesme,' a collection of the national songs of Servia, 1861; 'The Ring of Amasia,' 1863; 'Poetical Works of Owen Meredith,' 1867; 'Chronicles and Characters,' 1868; 'Orval, or the Fool of Time,' 1869; 'Julian Fane, a Memoir,' 1871; 'Fables in Song,' 1874; and 'The Speeches of Edward, Lord Lytton, &c.,' 1874.

MACAULIFFE, Michael, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Newcastle School (Limerick), Springfield College, and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 9th Feb., 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; promoted to deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1882; divisional judge, Nov., 1884 (2nd grade, Jan., 1887) and 1st grade, Nov., 1889; author of 'Life of Baba Nanak,' and of articles on the Sikh religion in the 'Calcutta Review,' 1880-81.

MACAUSLAND, Captain R. C. S., Bengal S.C. (Punjab).—Lieutenant, 13th Nov., 1872; arrived in India, 9th March, 1873, and served in the military department, and in the Punjab as cantonment magistrate; 1st class cantonment magistrate, Dec., 1887.

MACCARTIE, Charles Falkiner, Madras C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served in Bombay till Nov., 1872, and subsequently in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting principal assistant, additional sessions judge, and acting collector, magistrate, and agent, and was placed on special settlement duty, Nov., 1882; transferred permanently to the Madras civil service, Jan., 1882; officiating postmaster-general, Madras, April-Dec., 1883; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, May, 1884; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1884; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Chingleput, Feb., 1885; acting secretary, board of revenue, Dec., 1885, to May, 1886; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1889.

MACCARTIE, Frederick Fitzgerald, Surgeon-major, M.B., B.Ch. (Dub.), Bombay Medical Service.—Joined the service, 30th March, 1878, and arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1878; served on general military and jail duty and as deputy sanitary commissioner; appointed health officer of Port of Bombay, June, 1884; served under the Government of India in the finance department as assay probationer in Bombay in 1886 and 1889; reverted to his appointment as health officer, Jan., 1890; surgeon-major, March, 1890.

MACDONALD, Donald, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—First commission, Bengal infantry, Oct., 1853; arrived in India, Dec., 1853; appointed to the survey department, revenue branch, Dec., 1866; revenue surveyor, Jan., 1865; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1866; promoted to 2nd grade, Jan., 1873, and 1st grade, Jan., 1887; in charge of the N.W. frontier survey, 1879-1884; officiating assistant surveyor-general, March, 1886; confirmed, Sept., 1887.

MACDONALD, Robert Graham, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Served in the subordinate accounts establishment, Oct., 1863, to Dec., 1867; examiner of railway accounts, Oudh, Dec., 1867; auditor, Oudh and Rohilkund railway accounts, Jan., 1870; examiner, railway accounts, Madras, 1875; W. Rajputana railway, 1876; assistant accountant-general, Calcutta, Jan., 1878; examiner of accounts, Punjab, 1881; N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1882; examiner of military works accounts, 1883; inspector of public works accounts, 1884; officiated as deputy accountant general,
and under secretary to government, Nov., 1885; to Feb., 1886, and April, 1886, to March, 1887; and again May, 1887; examiner, 2nd class, in the accounts establishment, May, 1886; examiner, 1st class, May, 1887; officiating accountant-general, public works department, and deputy secretary to Government of India, accounts branch, May, 1888, and April, 1890; deputy accountant-general and under-secretary, Sept., 1888; president of public works accounts committee, Oct., 1888.

MACDONNELL, Anthony Patrick, C.S.I., M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 3rd Nov., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1866; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, May, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1874; officiating magistrate and collector, 1875; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, May, 1881, and again, Jan.—April, 1882; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Sept., 1881, and again, April, 1882; confirmed as secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, July, 1884; lieutenant-governor's council, Nov., 1884; officiating secretary, government of India, home department, March, 1886; confirmed in this appointment, March, 1887; chief commissioner, central provinces, Nov., 1890; author of 'Food Grain Supply and Famine Relief in Behar and Bengal, 1876'; C.S.I., June, 1888.

MACDOUGALL, James William, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, June, 1858; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1858; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted at various times as cantonment magistrate of Kamptee, and as small cause court judge of Nagpur, April, 1871, to March, 1873; held charge of the model farm, Nagpur, in addition to other duties, 1873-79; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Sept., 1883, and 2nd class, Jan., 1890.

MacEWEN, Robert Sutherland Taylor (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Department.—Sub-assistant commissioner, Sonthal commission, Sept., 1862; officiating assistant commissioner, May, 1863; clerk of the Calcutta court of small causes, July, 1866; served from Dec., 1870, as judge, Calcutta court of small causes, and was promoted to 2nd judge, Oct., 1884; served temporarily as recorder of Rangoon, April—Oct., 1884, and again in 1885-86; published 'The Practice of the Presidency Courts of Small Causes under Act XV. of 1882,' June, 1883.

MACFARLAN, John, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury, 1857; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, Satara, till 1860; deputy collector and magistrate, in Sind, 1860-61; second assistant collector and magistrate at Poona and Dharwar, 1862 to 1864; acting collector and magistrate, Kanara, April, 1866; first assistant collector and magistrate, Nasik, July, 1869; acted as postmaster-general, Bombay, 1870-72, and from Feb., 1873, and was appointed postmaster-general, Madras, in 1875; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, April, 1877, to Dec., 1878; retired, Dec., 1878.

MACGEORGE, Henry John, Central Provinces.—Joined the service as deputy superintendent of Jhansi, 10th June, 1854; deputy collector, Betul, Nov., 1856; assistant commissioner, Wardha, Dec., 1860; in charge of settlement duties, Wardha and Chanda, Dec., 1862, to April, 1863; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1877.

MACIVOR, Ivar, Captain, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Sub-lieutenant, 18th Hussars, Oct., 1872; arrived in India, March, 1873; 1st regiment, Central India Horse, Aug., 1877; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, Oct., 1878; assistant to political resident, Persian Gulf, Feb., 1880; 1st assistant to governor-general's agent, Baluchistan, Jan., 1885; political agent, Ziboh, Jan., 1890.

MACKAY, Duncan Lachlan Macpherson, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Madras College, and University, St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1875, and was appointed assistant commissioner at Jubbulpore; transferred to Burma, July, 1876; 1st grade assistant commissioner, Aug., 1886; cantonment magistrate, Rangoon, May, 1888.

MACKENZIE, Sir Alexander, B.A., K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward VI.'s Grammar School, Birmingham, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 11th Dec., 1862; assistant magistrate and collector, Shahabad, Sept., 1863; from Feb., 1866, to Dec., 1873, served as under secretary, junior secretary, and officiating secretary to government of Bengal; on famine duty, Dec., 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1875, and again in 1877; magistrate and collector, and grade, Moorschedabad, July, 1876; also in charge of office of agent to governor-general; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, general and revenue departments, July, 1877; secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, Oct., 1877; lieutenant-governor's council, Jan., 1879; secretary, government of India, home department, April, 1882; C.S.I., May, 1886; chief commissioner of Central Provinces, March, 1887, and of Burma, Nov., 1890; K.C.S.I., 1 Jan., 1891; author of 'History of the Relations of the Government with the Hill Tribes of the N.E. Frontier of Bengal.'

MACKENZIE, Gilbert Proby, M.B., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1st April, 1870; served in Bengal and N.W.P. and Oudh on general and military duty, from May, 1889; served as officiating senior medical officer in Port Blair and the Nicobars.

MACKENZIE, Gordon Thomson, Madras C.S.—Educated at King William's College, Isle of Man, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1869, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; assistant commissioner, Nilgiris, Aug., 1881; acting collector and magistrate, Kistna, Sept., 1881; head assistant collector, Nilgiris, Feb., 1882; acting registrar, high court, July, 1883; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1883, and acting secretary, Nov., 1884; president of the municipal commission, Jan., 1885; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nov., 1886; acting district and sessions judge, Nov., 1887; confirmed Oct., 1888; compiled district manual of Kistna.
MACKENZIE, KENNETH JAMES LOCH, Colonel, M.S.C., Berar Commission.—Joined Madras artillery from Addiscombe, 11th June, 1853; from April, 1862, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts, as assistant commissioner, assistant conservator of forests, and deputy commissioner (2nd class, Feb., 1885); judicial commissioner, July, 1889.

MACKENZIE, STEPHEN COULL, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1866; served from 15th Oct., 1869, as professor of hygiene, Calcutta Medical College, also officiating as assistant surgeon at the Presidency General Hospital; superintendent, presidency jail, in addition to his own duties, Jan., 1871; junior surgeon, Presidency General Hospital, Dec., 1872; officiating health officer, port of Calcutta, Feb., 1877; superintendent of Campbell Medical School and Hospital, Sealdah, professor of medical jurisprudence, Calcutta Medical College, and police surgeon, Calcutta, Jan., 1878; also appointed, in addition to his other duties, superintendent of lock hospitals in Calcutta and its suburbs, Nov., 1879, and of lunatic asylums, Dec., 1880, and coroner's surgeon; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1883.

MACKENZIE, THOMAS DUNCAN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served in the Bombay presidency as assistant collector and magistrate; secretary, Baroda Inquiry commission, Nov., 1873; from Nov., 1875, acted as under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1877; member of civil and military examination committee, April-Oct., 1879; from Nov., 1879, served as acting collector and magistrate, and was placed on special duty at Baroda, March-Aug., 1880, in connection with the settlement of the affairs of Mir Zulfiqar Ali; acting junior collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Nov., 1882; junior collector and magistrate, Broach, May, 1884; collector, magistrate and political agent, Khandesh, Feb., 1886; acted as chief secretary to Government of Bombay for various periods from May, 1886; commissioner, Southern Division, May, 1889.

MACKENZIE, SIR WILLIAM, Inspector-General of Hospitals, M.D., K.C.B., C.S.I., late Madras Medical Service.—A.M. of King's College, Aberdeen, 1830; M.R.C.S., London, 1832; M.D., University of Aberdeen, 1836; assistant surgeon in the Madras medical service, 1835; served with the 8th light cavalry, Madras, 1837-1839, and with the army of His Highness the Nizam of Hyderabad, 1839-1862; was superintendent of the Bolarum Medical School, 1842-44; served with the Ellickpoor field force, against the insurgent Rohillas in 1841, and again in Nov., 1851, with the cavalry field force, under Brigadier W. Mayne; staff-surgeon with the Central India field force, 1857-58, and with the Berar field force, Nov., 1858, to March, 1859, and was present at numerous engagements; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, Mysore Division, March, 1863; inspector-general, Aug., 1866; inspector-general and head of the medical department, March, 1867; retired, Aug., 1871; appointed honorary physician to the Queen, July, 1867; author of a treatise on the medical topography of Ellickpoor, and papers on the Indian Materia Medica, and has translated into Hindustani, 'Gregory's Practice of Physic,' and 'Thomson's Conspectus of the British Pharmacopoeia.'

MACKIE, ANDREW WALLACE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Universities of Edinburgh and St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, March, 1874, and again, in Nellore, March, 1877; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1887; transferred temporarily to the Punjab, July, 1888; district and sessions judge; 2nd grade, Feb., 1890.

MACKINTOSH, JAMES SIMON, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Royal Academy, Inverness, Edinburgh University, and Oriel College, Oxford; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant secretary, and officiating under secretary to government; private secretary to the lieutenant-governor, Feb.-April, 1874; officiating secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Aug.-Nov., 1875; junior secretary to government, July, 1876; secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1877; magistrate and collector, Jan., 1886.

MACLAGAN, EDWARD DOUGLAS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Winchester and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1886, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiated as under secretary to government of Punjab in 1883, 1889 and 1890; superintendent of census operations in the Punjab, April, 1890.

MACLEAN, ALEXANDER THOMAS, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1856; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Poorooe, Oct., 1866; from July, 1869, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge and district judge in various districts of Bengal, and officiated as superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs in 1878; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, July, 1880; retired, 1885.

MACLEAN, FREDERICK GURR, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the department as assistant superintendent, 1st Sept., 1868; studied submarine telegraphy in England for four months; arrived in India, Feb., 1869; held charge of various sub-divisions, and of construction of line on Kandahar state railway, 1879; held charge of various divisions, and was graded class iv., grade 3, Oct., 1887, and grade 2, April, 1890; personal assistant to director of telegraphs, April, 1890.

MACLEANE, CHARLES DONALD, Mus. Doc., M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School, Shrewsbury Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; acting inspector of schools, Oct., 1866; assistant collector, Dec., 1867; acting cantonment magistrate, Sept., 1868; acted for various
periods as under secretary to Government of Madras, and sub-secretary to the Board of revenue; on special duty in preparing annual administration report, Nov., 1876, and again, Sept., 1878; on special duty revising standing orders of the board of revenue, Oct., 1877, and again in June, 1886; under secretary to government in chief secretary's department, July, 1880; fellow of the University of Madras, March, 1881; Canarese translator to government, April, 1881; member of board of examiners, Jan., 1882; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1883; on special duty at Madras in connection with preparation of 'Manual of Administration,' Nov., 1883, and again, Aug., 1884 and 1886; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1884; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, Feb., 1884; on special duty as president of the committee on Muhamadan Educational Endowment, Aug., 1885; Tamil translator to government, Sept., 1885; collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886; on special duty in the general record department, Feb., 1886, and also to collect information for the finance committee, June, 1886.

MACLEOD, BANNATYNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Collegiate School, Edinburgh University, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector, and forest settlement officer; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Jan., 1880.

MACLEOD, DONALD GRANT, M.A., LL.M. (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Burma.—Trinity College, Cambridge, and Inner Temple; judge of the court of small causes, Rangoon, Sept., 1869; judge of Moulmein, March, 1876.

MACLEOD, Roderick, Bengal Medical Officer.—House physician, Medical College Hospital, Calcutta, 24th June, 1865; served as medical officer at several stations, and was appointed health officer of the port of Calcutta, Oct., 1880.

MACLEOD, Roderick Henry, Bengal C.S. (North-West Provinces).—Educated at University College, London, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate, and district and sessions judge; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Dec., 1886, and 1st grade, Feb., 1890; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, July, 1880.

MACNABB, Sir Donald C., K.C.I.E., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1853; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Peshawur, 1865; commissioner, Hisar division, 1872, and subsequently in the Lahore, Rawal Pindi, and Peshawur divisions; retired, 1881; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

MACNABB, James William, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1852, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, Aug., 1861; commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, Nov., 1875, and afterwards in the Hissar and Delhi divisions; retired, March, 1886.

MACNAGHTEN, Chester, M.A. (Cantab.), Educational Department, Bombay.—From July, 1866, to Dec., 1870, held the appointment of tutor to the minor Maharajah of Durbhanga under the court of wards, Bengal; joined the Bombay educational service, 19th Dec., 1870, and served from that date as principal of the Rajkumar College, Kathiawar.

MACONACHIE, George Archibald, Brigade-Surgeon, M.D., C.M. (Aber.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867; was employed under the military department till Jan., 1872, including service in the Abyssinian campaign (medal), and subsequently as ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic medicine and surgery and comparative anatomy at the Grant Medical College, Bombay; also presidency surgeon from June, 1880; brigade-surgeon, May, 1889.

MACONACHIE, James Robert, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 9th Jan., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating judicial assistant; officiating settlement secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1880; officiating postmaster-general, Punjab, July, 1884; on special duty under the government of India, foreign department Sept.-Oct., 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1886; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Feb., 1887, and 2nd grade, Nov., 1889; author of report on the settlement of the Delhi District.

MACONOCHE, Alexander Francis, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Westminster, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883; acting joint administrator, Rajpipla, Oct., 1886.

MACONOCHE, Evan, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Sherborne School, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1889, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

MACPHERSON, Sir Arthur George, K.C.I.E., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at the University and King's College, Aberdeen, and University of Edinburgh; called to the bar, Inner Temple, 1852; 1st judge of Calcutta small cause court, 1859; secretary to the government of Bengal, legislative department, 1862; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India in the home department (legislative), 1863, and appointed assistant secretary, Oct., 1864; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1865; acted as chief justice, 13th Feb. to 25th June, 1875; retired, 1877; legal adviser to the secretary of state, Nov., 1879; secretary in the judicial and public department, India Office, Feb., 1882; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

MACPHERSON, Andrew Kennedy, Major B.S.C.—First commission, 19th Dec., 1865; arrived in India, 9th March, 1866; from April, 1871, served as cantonment magistrate at various stations in the Punjab, and was promoted to the 1st class, Dec., 1879; officiating in the judge advocate-general's department, May, 1889,
MACPHERSON, CHARLES GORDON WELAND, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and superintendent of police; supernumerary under secretary to government of Bombay in the public works department for relief purposes, Nov., 1876; on famine relief duty in Madras, as secretary to personal assistant to the governor, Sept., 1877, to Jan., 1879; from April, 1879, acted as under secretary to government of Bombay, political and judicial departments, and secretary to the governor's council for making laws and regulations, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1881; acting private secretary to governor of Bombay, Dec., 1880, to March, 1881; acted as secretary to government, political, secret, judicial, and educational departments, in 1884 and 1885; acting special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, April-July, 1885, and again in 1886; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, Shikarpur, Nov., 1885; on special duty in the political department of the secretariat, Dec., 1885; 2nd grade judge, May, 1887; acting district and sessions judge, Jan., 1888.

MACPHERSON, DUNCAN JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the High School and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Aug., 1883; on special duty under board of revenue, Nov., 1882.

MACPHERSON, GEORGE MORISON, M.A., LL.D., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, small cause court judge, and judge and sessions judge in various districts; 1st grade judge, Jan., 1881; judicial commissioner in Sind, and judge of the sadar court, Feb., 1885.

MACPHERSON, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Gymnasium, Old Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty under board of revenue, July, 1875; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, May, 1884; superintendent of Dehra Dun, Aug., 1886; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1888.

MACPHERSON, J. M. (Barrister-at-Law), Legislative Department, Government of India.—Educated at Westminster School; advocate of the high court, Calcutta; served from Dec., 1877, as deputy secretary to the government of India in the legislative department; officiated as secretary from Oct., 1887, to Jan., 1888, and again in 1889; editor of 7th edition of 'Macpherson's Law of Mortgage in British India.'

MACPHERSON, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1856; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating civil and sessions judge, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1872, and district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Aug., 1878; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 10th Jan., 1885.

MACPHERSON, WILLIAM CHARLES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877; assistant magistrate and collector, Patna, Dec., 1877; transferred to Assam, July, 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, assistant secretary and officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating inspector of schools; transferred to Bengal, Oct., 1884; under secretary to government of Bengal, Nov., 1885; officiating under secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Jan., 1888, and home department, April, 1888; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, May, 1888; officiating magistrate and collector, June, 1888.

MACRAE, JOHN KENNETH, Burma Commission.—Joined the Burma commission as officiating assistant commissioner, 20th July, 1860; registrar to the court of the recorder, and judge of the court of small causes, Moulmein, May, 1864; deputy commissioner, July, 1869; town magistrate, Akyab, Nov., 1874; boundary officer, Nov., 1880; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Sept., 1883; president, Akyab municipal committee, Jan., 1885; acted as commissioner of Arakan, Nov.-Dec., 1885; of the Irrawaddy division, Feb.-April, 1887.

MACRURY, COLIN WILLIAM, Surgeon-Major, Bombay Sanitary Department.—Joined the service, 1st April, 1866, arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1866; on general duty in Sind, deputy sanitary commissioner, Feb., 1878; deputy superintendent of census in Sind, 1881; surgeon-major, April, 1881; sanitary commissioner to the government of Bombay, May, 1888.

MADDOX, STUART LOCKWOOD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Worcester College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1888; and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

MADDEN, JOHN MELLISH, Colonel, Bombay Infantry.—Ensign, Bombay army, Sept., 1859; employed on military duty, including service in Abyssinia in 1868, up to 1876; served subsequently as assistant cantonment magistrate, Poona; appointed cantonment magistrate, Ahmadabad, January, 1880; colonel, Sept., 1880.

MAGRATH, HENRY MARSH SEPTIMUS, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C. (Mysoor).—First commission, 1st Feb., 1859; major, March, 1878; lieutenant-colonel, March, 1884; officiated as magistrate and president of the municipal commission, Bangalore, May, 1884, to March, 1885; district magistrate and president municipal commission, Bangalore, Feb.-May, 1887; civil sessions judge, May, 1887.

MAGUIRE, HUGH FITZJOHN TYRREL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1878; served
in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and deputy collector; member, central examination committee, April, 1886; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Jan., 1889.

MAHADEV GOVIND RANADE, Rao Bahadur, C.I.E., M.A., LL.B. (Bombay), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 23th May, 1866, in the educational department, and was appointed assistant professor of English literature at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, Oct., 1868; also served in the judicial department as assistant reporter to the high court, Bombay, acting magistrate of police, acting small cause court judge, and subordinate judge (June, 1872); acting presidency magistrate, Bombay, Jan.–March, 1881; appointed under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act to inspect and supervise the lower courts in districts of Poona and Satara, Aug., 1881; judge of the court of small causes, Poona, Feb., 1884, and was in charge of duties of law lecturer, Deccan College, Jan.–April, 1885; member of a committee on public expenditure; C.I.E., Feb., 1887; confirmed as special judge under Deccan Agriculturists Relief Act, May, 1887.

MAHESH CHUNDER NYARATNA, Mohamahadhya Pundit, C.I.E., Bengal Education Department.—Served in the education department from 10th January, 1864, as assistant professor, and professor in the Sanskrit College, and was appointed principal of the college, June, 1885; 3rd class of the education department, March, 1884.

MAITLAND, JOHN, Surgeon-Major, M.B., M.C. (Edinburgh), Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service 31st March, 1876; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1876, and served on civil, military, and famine duty; 2nd surgeon, general hospital, Madras, Feb., 1882; professor of materia medica and pharmacy, Medical College, April, 1882; surgeon-major, March, 1888; surgeon to the governor of Madras, March, 1889.

MAITLAND, WILLIAM J., C.I.E., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy, and abroad; temporary clerk, 3rd Nov., 1866; junior clerk, July, 1867; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1878; private secretary to the secretary of state (Viscount Cross), August, 1886; C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

MALLETT, FREDERICK RICHARD, F.G.S., F.C.S., late Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined, 12th Feb., 1859; was employed in various districts of Bengal, Central India, the Central Provinces, Assam, Sikkim, and Bhutan; keeper of the mineral collections in the museum, Oct., 1875; 1st grade officer, Jan., 1883; deputy superintendent, April, 1883; designation changed to superintendent of survey; author of contributions to the survey publications; retired, 1889.

MALLETT, ROBERT TREFUSIS, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the Bombay public works department, Jan., 1868; executive engineer on the Punjab northern state railway, Nov., 1868; superintendent of works, Ravvee section, April, 1873; temporary superintending engineer, Indus Valley railway, Jan., 1877; engineer-in-chief, Indus Valley railway, April, 1879; director of stores, railway branch, Oct., 1880; engineer-in-chief, Rewari Ferozepur railway, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1883; engineer-in-chief, Ferozepur bridge, in 1885; transferred to North-Western railway as chief engineer, Jan., 1886; chief engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; engineer-in-chief, Chenal bridge project, May, 1887; temporarily held office of director-general of railways, Aug., 1887; officiating consulting engineer, Sept., 1887; chief engineer, 2nd class, March, 1889.

MALLOCK, HENRY ARCHIBALD, Colonel, B.S.C., Indian Telegraph Department.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1853; joined the telegraph department, Jan., 1861; superintendent, 1st grade, and storekeeper, Dec., 1866; director of construction, April, 1868; deputy director-general, June, 1883; officiating director-general, Nov., 1886, to Feb., 1887, and March, 1888; reverted to military department, 1889.

MALTBY, EDWARD PENNYCUICK, Lieut.-Col., late Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Jan., 1861; arrived in India, 7th Feb., 1861; served in civil employ in the Mysore commission from Jan., 1864; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1877; small cause court judge, and town and cantonment magistrate, Bangalore, March, 1879; district magistrate and collector, and president, municipal commission, in the civil and military station of Bangalore from March, 1881; retired, Jan., 1887.

MAN, EDWARD HORACE, Port Blair administration.—Joined the service as assistant superintendent, 3rd Nov., 1869; was in charge of Nicobar Islands in 1871 and 1874, and from 1883 to 1888; officiated for various periods as deputy superintendent, and was appointed 1st assistant superintendent, Jan., 1888; joint author of a work on the South Andaman language, and of various papers relating to the Andamanese.

MANCE, SIR HENRY CHRISTOPHER, C.I.E., late Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the Indo-European telegraph department, July, 1863; superintendent, Kurrachee, Persian Gulf section, Sept., 1866; engineer and electrician, Sept., 1879; C.I.E., Jan., 1883; retired, 1886.

MANCHERJI PESTANJI KHAREGHAT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Xavier's College, Calcutta, University College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1884; assistant collector, March, 1885.

MANDER, ALFRED THOMAS, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1854; 2nd lieutenant, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1857; served in the Bombay public works department, from March, 1858, as assistant and executive engineer; superintending engineer, Nov., 1866; retired, Sept., 1889.

MANDERSON, THOMAS CLARIDGE, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Aug., 1858; joined the public works department, July, 1860, as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces; executive engineer, Punjab, April, 1866; transferred to military works, 1872; served in the Rawal Pindi, Meerut, and Lahore commands, and was promoted to superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886; officiating inspector general, military works, April-Nov., 1886; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1889.
MANISTY, GEORGE ELDON (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Ruabon Grammar School, Marlborough College, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1873; served in Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Dec., 1884; has also officiated as magistrate and collector.

MANN, GUSTAV, Forest Department, Assam.—Assistant in government cinchona plantations, Darjeeling, Nov., 1863; assistant conservator of forests, Bengal, Dec., 1864; from Nov., 1868, served in the Assam forest department, and was promoted to conservator, 3rd grade, Sept., 1882; 2nd grade, Jan., 1888.

MANSER, ROBERT, Surgeon-Major.—Joined the service, 1st Oct., 1877; served in the military department, and on civil and jail duty; from May, 1882, served in the European General Hospital as assistant surgeon, and professor of materia medica in the Grant Medical College; professor of pathology and curator of museum of that college, April, 1887; second physician of Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital and professor of physiology, Nov., 1888; first physician, Nov., 1889.

MANSFIELD, SAMUEL, C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1834; served as assistant collector and magistrate in various districts, and was appointed political agent, Rewa Kantha, 1847; collector and magistrate, Kandeish, 1852; revenue commissioner, northern division, 1859; commissioner, Sind, 1862; member of council, Bombay, 14th May, 1867; retired in 1872.

MANSON, ALEXANDER, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 12th Nov., 1864; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating district and sessions judge, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1885; also served as second inspector of registration offices, Aug., 1876; officiating commissioner, Chittagong division, Nov., 1885, and July, 1886; retired, July, 1889.

MARDOON, EVELYN JOHN, Bengal C.S., N.W. Provinces.—Educated at Clifton College, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

MARETT, JAMES RICHARD, Col., B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—First commission, ensign 2nd Grenadiers, 4 Feb., 1858; from July, 1867, served under Foreign Department of Government of India; assistant commissioner, Oudh, July, 1867; sub-judge, 2nd grade, Aug., 1879; and 1st grade, Dec., 1881; Officiated for various periods as district judge, deputy commissioner, and judge of the small cause court, and was confirmed as district judge, March, 1887; Colonel, Feb., 1888.

MARINDIN, CHARLES RANDAL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on famine relief duty, Tirhoot, Feb., 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1885; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, April, 1889.

MARKBY, SIR W., K.C.I.E., late Judge of the High Court, Calcutta.—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; doctor of civil law fellow of All Souls College, fellow of Balliol College; recorder of Buckingham, 1864-66; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1866 to 1878; vice-chancellor of the university of Calcutta, 1877-78; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1889; justice of the peace for county of Oxford; author of "Elements of Law" (Clarendon Press, Oxford).

MARKHAM, ALEXANDER MACAULAY, F.R.G.S. Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Down and Connor Diocesan School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; from Jan., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating cantonment magistrate, settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Allahabad, Nov., 1880; member of committee for considering revised rules for Patwariis and Kanungos, Nov., 1880; member of grass supply committee under military department of government of India, Oct., 1881; officiating commissioner, Rae Bareli division, March to July, 1882; and of Jhansi division, May to Sept., 1887; district and sessions judge, April, 1889.

MARKHAM, CLEMENTS ROBERT, C.B., F.R.S.—Educated at Westminster School; appointed a naval cadet, 28th July, 1844; midshipman, July, 1846, and passed for lieutenant, R.N., Dec., 1851; served in the Arctic expedition in search of Sir John Franklin, 1850-51; explored Peru and the forests of the Eastern Andes, 1852-54; from July, 1854, served as clerk under the India board of control, and on the transfer of the government of India to the crown, in 1858, was appointed a clerk in the correspondence department of the India office; private secretary to the parliamentary under-secretary of state (Mr. T. G. Baring), 1862 to 1864; assistant secretary in the public works department, 1867-71, and in the judicial, public, and revenue department, from 1871 to 1877, when he retired from the service; appointed C.B. (civil), May, 1871; was employed in introducing cinchona cultivation into India, 1859-66, and visited India and Ceylon; geographer to the Abyssinian expedition, 1866-67, and was present at the storming of Magdala; secretary to the Hakluyt Society, 1858 to 1866; secretary to the Royal Geographical Society, 1863 to 1877; in 1874 was created by the King of Portugal a commendator of the order of Christ; and by the Emperor of Brazil a chevalier of the order of the Rose; author of "Franklin's Footsteps," 1853; "Cuzco and Lima," 1855; "Travels in Peru and India," 1862; "Quichua Grammar and Dictionary," 1863; "Threshold of the Unknown Region," 1874; "History of the Abyssinian Expedition," 1869; "Life of Lord Fairfax;" "Life of Admiral Fairfax;" "A Naval Career in the Olden Time;" "History of Persia," 1873; "History of the War between Peru and Chili;" "Peru," 1880; "The Sea Fathers;" "Irrigation in Eastern Spain," 1867; "Memoir of the Indian Surveys," 1871; "Life of the Countess..."
of Chinchon,' 'Peruvian Bark;' and 'Missions to Thibet,' 1877; has also translated and edited various works, including 'Embassy of Clavijo to the Court of Timour;' 'Royal Commentaries of Garcilasgoa de la Vega;' 'Chronicle of Cieza de Leon;' 'Memoir of Alonso Henriquez de Guzman;' 'Report of Pascual de Andagoza;' editor of 'Early Voyages of the East India Company;' and Voyages of Baffin;' wrote the 'Reports on the Moral and Material Progress of India,' for 1871-72 and 1872-73, and edited the 'Geographical Magazine,' 1872 to 1878.

MARRETT, CHARLES RICHARDSON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Wellington College, and Pembroke College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1875; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; confirmed as joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Dec., 1887; 1st grade, Jan., 1889; has also officiated as magistrate and collector.

MARRYAT, ERNEST LINDSAY, Lt.-Col., R.E., late Railway Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1859; probationary assistant engineer, Mhow, Bombay, Nov., 1862; assistant engineer, Central Provinces, Oct., 1864; executive engineer, Bombay public works department, Jan., 1866; assistant consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, June, 1869; consulting engineer for reclamation, Bombay, April, 1870; acted for various periods as deputy consulting engineer, Bombay; acting under secretary to government of Bombay, public works department, April, 1874; acting manager, Dhond and Manmad state railway, Dec., 1878; confirmed as deputy consulting engineer, Bombay, March, 1879; executive engineer, 1st grade, June, 1880; manager, Punjab northern state railway, in 1st class of the state railway revenue establishment, Nov., 1880; retired from the public works department, 1887.

MARSDEN, F. J.—Clerk of the crown, 14th May, 1873; officiating magistrate, Calcutta police, and coroner, Oct., 1874; presidency magistrate and coroner, Dec., 1877; chief magistrate, Calcutta, March, 1878; also judge of the court for the trial of pilots, and of the court of survey, port of Calcutta.

MARSHALL, ALEXANDER CHALMERS (Barrister-at-Law), Punjab Commission.—From 2nd Feb., 1867, served in the subordinate executive and judicial departments as assistant commissioner and officiating judge, small cause courts, and judicial assistant; appointed judge, small cause court, Sept., 1881, and judicial assistant, Nov., 1884.

MARSHALL, CHARLES HENRY TILSON, Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; from July, 1865, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and judicial assistant; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor, Oct., 1878; superintendent, Chamba state, Oct., 1879; divisional judge 3rd grade, Sept., 1886; from Dec., 1886, served under foreign department, Government of India; returned to the Punjab, Nov., 1888, and appointed 2nd grade divisional judge, May, 1889; author of a 'Monograph of the Capitonidae, or Sconsorial Barbets,' 'The Game Birds of India' (with A. O. Hume), 'The Ornithology of the Hills about Murree,' and 'The Ornithology of Chamba.'

MARSHALL, GEORGE FREDERICK LEYCESTER, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1860; joined the public works department, 28th March, 1864, and served in the irrigation department, N.W. Provinces; executive engineer, Sept., 1868; special assistant, irrigation branch, N.W. Provinces secretariat, 1876; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, civil works branch, Oct., 1876, to May, 1877, and again in 1878; confirmed in this appointment, Sept., 1879; officiating under secretary, government of India, public works department, railway branch, Nov., 1881, to Feb., 1882; under secretary, government of India, civil works branch, June, 1882; member of committee on reorganisation of the public works department, Sept., 1883; superintending engineer, Dec., 1884; officiating superintending engineer and secretary to agent, governor-general, Rajputana, April, 1887; superintending engineer and secretary, Rajputana and Central India, 1888; Lieutenant-colonel, July, 1888.

MARTELLI, NORTON CHARLES, Major, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, 15th foot, Oct., 1864; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, Oct., 1870; served in civil employ from 1872 as assistant cantonment magistrate, Morar, and political assistant in Rajputana; magistrate of Aboo, and assistant in the thuggee and dacoity department, 1875; guardian and tutor to Maharaj of Alwar, Aug., 1876; served in Beloochistan, 1880-81, as political officer, Jacobabad, Quetta, and the Bolan; assistant at Banswarra and Pertabgurh, and superintendent of operations for control of Moghias, Oct., 1881; officiating political agent, Baghelcund, 1882, and in 1886; political agent, Bhopawar, 1885; political agent Eastern States Rajputana.

MARTIN, CAULFIELD AYLMER, LL.D., Educational Department, Bengal.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed, 22nd Nov., 1864; served as professor at the Dacca College, and at the Krishnagurh College; inspector of schools, Aug., 1877; 2nd class, educational service, Aug., 1877.

MARTIN, CHARLES WILLIAM WALL, B.A., LL.D., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from March, 1865, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; collector and magistrate, South Canara, Nov., 1882; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1883, in Cuddapah, and afterwards in Salem; retired, April, 1889.

MARTIN, EDWARD JAMES, M.I.C.E., and F.R.I.B.A., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the secretary of state, May, 1859; arrived in India, 6th Sept., 1859; served in the Punjab in the buildings and roads branch as assistant engineer and executive engineer till 1869-70, when he was transferred to the N.W. Provinces, and posted to the Rajputana state railway; officiated as engineer-in-chief, Tirhoot state railway, April, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Rangoon and Irrawaddy Valley state railway,
Aug., 1877; also ex-officio manager of the line, April, 1878; transferred to Bengal, railway branch, and appointed engineer-in-chief of the Central Bengal system of state railways, Nov., 1878; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1880; transferred to Bengal provincial branch, Jan., 1880; on special duty under the chief engineer, Bengal, as government architect, April, 1881; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Feb., 1882; deputed to Indore on special duty, Jan., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1885; officiating chief engineer, and secretary to government of Bengal public works department, June, 1883; and chief engineer, May, 1889; chief engineer and joint secretary to Government of Bengal, Jan., 1890.

MARTIN, GERALD WARD, Major, Bo.
