S.C., Assay Master, Bombay Mint.—Ensign, 88th Foot, 22nd June, 1867; joined Roorkee College, Nov., 1869, and obtained certificate as civil engineer; admitted to the staff corps, March, 1871; from March, 1871, to July, 1878, served as assistant superintendent of survey in Assam, in the Deccan topographical survey, and in the Soane irrigation survey; transferred to the financial department for employment in the assay department, July, 1878, and acted as deputy assay master in the Calcutta and Bombay mints; appointed assay master, Bombay mint, May, 1884; also served with the Afghan expeditionary force as assistant superintendent of survey, 1879-80 (medal and clasp for Kabul), and with the Waziri expeditionary field force.

MARTIN, HENRY, Surgeon, M.B., Staff of Governor of Bombay.—Surgeon to March, 1880; served with the Zohb Valley expedition of 1884; appointed medical officer to Lord Harris, Governor of Bombay, April, 1890.

MARTIN, WILLIAM THOMAS (Barrister-at-Law) Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Regent's Park College, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865; from July, 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1881; judge, 3rd grade, April, 1885; 2nd grade, Sept., 1887.

MARTINDALE, ARTHUR HENRY TEMPLE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; served in the foreign department of the government of India from Oct., 1877, to Oct., 1879, and from June, 1881, to May, 1882, as attache, officiating political agent, 3rd class, and assistant secretary to government, and was placed on special duty Dec., 1881; officiating under secretary to government of India, home department, May-Aug., 1882; from Aug., 1882, served again under the foreign department of the government of India as political agent at Kotah, and assistant secretary to government; junior under secretary, Oct., 1884; officiating assistant to resident in Mysore and secretary to the chief commissioner of Coorg, Feb., 1885; officiating resident and chief commissioner, May-June, 1885; political agent, 3rd class, April, 1886; first assistant and secretary for Berar to the resident, Hyderabad, Nov., 1886; political agent, Quetta and Pishin, April, 1887; 1st assistant to governor-general's agent, central India, Oct., 1888.

MARTINEAU, ALFRED EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1889, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

MASSY, CHARLES FRANCIS, Major, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 11th June, 1868; from Aug., 1870, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty to settle boundary disputes in Feb. and Oct., 1874; on a deputation to Kashmir, Aug.-Dec., 1876; political officer with the Punjab native chief contingent, Nov., 1878; on special duty in connection with Viceregal Durbar, at Lahore, Nov., 1880; on special duty to inspect the Punjab Rajputana border, Nov., 1883; officiating divisional judge, Jullundur, April, 1885; superintendent, Kapurthala state, Aug., 1886.

MASSY, GEORGE, Brigade-Surgeon, Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 11th April, 1866; from April, 1867, served in the Punjab as civil surgeon, superintendent of jail, and superintendent of vaccination; deputy sanitary commissioner (sub pro tem.), Nov., 1880; civil surgeon, 1st class, Rawa Pindi, Oct., 1881.

MASTER, CHARLES GILBERT, C.S.I., (Barrister-at-Law), late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate from Sept., 1855; deputy secretary to government in revenue department, Dec., 1859; commissioner of income tax, 1860-1865; secretary to the board of examiners, April, 1861, to Jan., 1866; acting sub-secretary to the board of revenue for various periods between 1862 and 1866; acting civil and sessions judge, Calicut, May, 1869; on special duty in Godavari and Kistna on irrigation works, May to Nov., 1869; from Nov., 1869, to May, 1877, served as collector and magistrate of Nellore, and other districts; secretary to government, revenue department, June, 1877; chief secretary to government, June, 1882; additional member of the legislative council, June, 1882; ordinary member of council, Madras, Jan., 1884; president of the committee in connection with the Draft Tenancy Bill, July, 1885; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired, Jan., 1889.

MASTERS, JOHN, Bengal Police.—Joined the service, 21st July, 1861; assistant superintendent of police, June, 1863; district superintendent, April 1870; 1st grade, Feb., 1890.

MATHEW, GEORGE FELTON, C.I.E., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1876, as assistant to the manager, Rajputana state railway; officiating traffic superintendent, Indus Valley state railway, June, 1879; 2nd class, traffic department, Jan., 1880; Kandahar Railway, March, 1880; C.I.E., Jan., 1882; officiating manager, Nizam's railway, March, 1882; Rajputana-Malwa railway, Dec., 1884; 1st class, 3rd grade, April, 1887; North-western railway, April, 1888; attached to office of secretary to Government of India, public works department, Oct., 1888; deputy manager, North-western railway, May, 1890.
MATHEWS, Henry Montagu, C.I.E., M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Burma.—Appointed 4th grade executive engineer, 8th Oct., 1868; arrived in India, Dec., 1868; served in British Burma, and was promoted to 1st grade executive engineer, Oct., 1877; employed in examining, repairing, and reporting on lighthouses, British Burma, Jan.–March, 1878; transferred to railway branch as engineer-in-chief and manager of the Rangoon and Irrawaddy Valley state railway, Nov., 1878; officiated as chief engineer and secretary to the chief commissioner, public works department, Oct., 1880, and again in 1886; 1st class, 1st grade, state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1882; also chairman, Rangoon port trust; C.I.E., Feb., 1887; retired, 1887.

MATHIAS, Henry Vincent, Colonel, B.S.C., late Police Department, Central Provinces.—Ensign Bengal infantry, Dec., 1849; in command, Nagode divisional military police, Oct., 1862; from 1st July, 1865, to 1866, served in the police department, Central Provinces, and was promoted to district superintendent of police, 1st class, April, 1875.

MATTHEW, Right Rev. Henry James, M.A., Ecclesiastical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 15th Feb., 1867, and served in N.W. Provinces and Bengal as chaplain of Allahabad and Fort William, and as domestic chaplain to the Lord Bishop; from Jan., 1877, served in Punjab as senior chaplain, and was appointed archdeacon, Aug., 1878, and bishop's commissary, March, 1883; appointed Bishop of Lahore, Dec., 1887.

MATTHEWS, Harold Francis, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Tonbridge School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1871; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal and Assam; officiating superintendent of emigration and embarkation agent, Sept., 1878; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1885; has also served as officiating deputy commissioner, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; confirmed as district and sessions judge, Jan., 1889.

MAUDE, Henry, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating senior secretary to financial commissioner, Nov., 1884; under secretary to government, Punjab, April, 1885; officiated as junior secretary to the Government of Punjab in 1889 and 1890.

MAUDE, Walter, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1883; acting under secretary to Government of Bengal general, revenue and statistical departments, April, 1889, and March, 1890.

MAXWELL, Henry St. Patrick, Major, Bengal S.C.—Arrived in India, 26th March, 1869; joined as ensign, 106th Foot, April, 1869; from May, 1873, served in civil employ in the Assam commission; served in the Dalla expedition, 1874-75; acted as political officer, Naga Hills, Feb. to July, 1878; political officer with the Naga Hills expedition, Oct., 1879, to April, 1880 (medal); inspector of immigrants, Jan., 1881; from May, 1881, acted as deputy commissioner in the Garo Hills; political officer with the Aka field force, Dec., 1883, to Feb., 1884; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, May, 1886; 2nd grade, Nov., 1888.

MAYHEW, Alfred Hercules, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C.—First commission as ensign, Madras army, June, 1861; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1862; from July, 1865, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, acting political superintendent of Thar and Párkar, head assistant collector, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty in the military department, March, 1882; in charge of office of district superintendent of police, Jacobabad, May–Aug., 1883, and March–May, 1884; deputy commissioner, Upper Sind frontier, Dec., 1884; collector and magistrate and district registrar, Shikarpur, and political agent, Khairpur State, Dec., 1885; lieutenant-colonel, June, 1887.

MAYNARD, Herbert John, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883. Arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1886, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating under secretary to Government of Punjab, April, 1890.

MAYO, John H., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College; East India House writer, old establishment, 28th Feb., 1855; junior clerk, administrator general's department, 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; military department, 1875; assistant secretary in the military department, Dec., 1882.

McANDREW, John, Police Department, Punjab.—From 8th Nov., 1860, served in the police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, July, 1880; deputy inspector-general, 2nd grade, March, 1885.

McBLAINE, Frederick, Bengal C.S.—Educated at private schools and at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884. Arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1886, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Jan., 1890.

McCABE, Robert Blair, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Oct., 1884; author of an outline grammar of Angami Naga language, 1887.

McCALLUM, Edwin, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Wesleyan Connexional School, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate; second assistant collector, May, 1884; first assistant collector April, 1887.

McCarthy, Samuel Trant, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Patrick's College, Carlow; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments, and
was appointed sub-collector and joint magistrate, Chingleput, Oct., 1877; acted as collector and magistrate, Cuddapah, Sept., 1879, to March, 1881; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1882, in the district of Vizagapatam, and afterwards in Kistna and Madura.

McCLEVERTY, WILLIAM ANSON, General.—Entered the army from the Royal Military College, Sandhurst, and obtained a commission in the 48th regiment, March, 1824; brigade major to the western auxiliary column, Coorg field force, March-April, 1834; temporarily attached to the engineer department at Gibraltar, 1840-41; deputy quartermaster-general in the Australian Colonies, July, 1846, to April, 1857; commanded the troops in New Zealand during the native disturbances in 1847 (medal); assistant adjutant-general in Scotland, Jan., 1859, to Feb., 1860; in command of the presidency division of the Madras army, April, 1860, to April, 1865; in command of the southeastern district of England at Shorncliffe and Dover, 1866-67; commander-in-chief of the Madras army, with local rank of lieutenant-general, and member of the governor's council, July, 1867, to April, 1871.

McCONNELL, JAMES FREDERICK PARRY, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1870; house-surgeon to the Calcutta Medical College Hospital, Oct., 1871; professor of pathology in the medical college, and resident physician to the College Hospital, March, 1872; also officiated as professor of the comparative anatomy section of the college museum, in July, 1873; officiating civil surgeon, 24-Pergunnahs, and medical inspector of emigrants, Sept.-Nov., 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1882; superintendent of vaccination, Feb., 1883; officiating professor of materia medica and clinical medicine, Medical College, and medical inspector of emigrants, April, 1883, and again, July, 1885; civil surgeon, 24-Pergunnahs, medical officer, Alipore jail, and ex-officio deputy sanitary commissioner, 1885.

MCORKELL, GILMOUR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Foyle College, Londonderry, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting educational inspector, acting district superintendent of police, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting district judge; 1st grade, assistant judge, Feb., 1886.

McCULLAGH, J. R., Lieut.-Col., R.E., India Survey Department.—First commission, 18th Dec., 1861. Arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1865, and served with the Bengal sappers and miners; appointed to the public works department, Nov., 1863, and to the great trigonometrical survey of India, March, 1869; assistant superintendent, Jan., 1872; deputy superintendent, July, 1882; 3rd grade, Jan., 1887.

McDERMOTT, BENJAMIN KENICOTT SELBY, Burma Commission.—Was appointed preventive officer on the Mandalay line, 20th Dec., 1872; superintendent of wharves, Rangoon, Port Trust, ril., 1872; and chief inspector of police, July, 1875; assistant superintendent of police, Oct., 1880, and district superintendent, Oct., 1882; appointed to the commission as assistant commissioner, Jan., 1887.

McDONELL, WILLIAM FRASER, V.C., late Bengal C.S. — Appointed from Haileybury College, June, 1849; arrived in India, 10th Jan., 1850; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector (1st grade, Champaran, April, 1864); on special duty, May, 1858; settlement officer, Shahabad, July, 1859; superintendent of stamps and stationery, Dec., 1863; civil and sessions judge, 1st grade, Nudra, March, 1868; commissioner, Bhagalpore division, April, 1874; judge, high court, Calcutta, Aug., 1878; retired, April, 1886.

McDOUGALL, H. R. L., Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., L.R.C.S., L.M. (Ed.), late Bombay Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1858; civil surgeon, Rajkot, Oct., 1878; acted as superintendent of vaccination, Oct.-Nov., 1882; brigade-surgeon, May, 1883; superintendent of Matheran, March, 1884; retired, May, 1886.

McINTOSH, HENRY JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and the University of Edinburgh, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1886, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

McIVER, C. M., Bombay Police Department.—Joined the service as assistant superintendent of police, Karachi, 10th March, 1867; superintendent, March, 1873; district superintendent, Aug., 1875; 1st grade superintendent, July, 1883; district superintendent, Hyderabad, March, 1885.

McKEON, GEORGE, late Store Department, India Office.—Served in the Bombay ordnance department, Sept., 1831, to May, 1859; sub-inspector of stores, India store depot, July, 1860; supervisor, 1st grade, March, 1877; retired July, 1888.

McLAUGHLIN, FREDERICK HUBERT, LL.M., B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury grammar school, and Magdalen College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 21st Jan., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1877; from April, 1876, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, March, 1884; retired, March, 1890.

McLEAN, JOHN JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the International College, Ealing, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1875, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating district judge; also acted as deputy commissioner, Lalitpur; joint magistrate, 1st grade, July, 1880.

McLEOD, G. E., Assam Commission.—Appointed extra assistant commissioner in Oudh, 14th Feb., 1870, and assistant commissioner in Assam, March, 1875; inspector of labourers, Feb., 1882; officiated for various periods as deputy commissioner, and was confirmed in the 4th grade, May, 1888; 3rd grade, Oct., 1888.

McLEOD, KENNETH, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, March, 1865; civil surgeon, Jessore, 20th Feb., 1866; on special duty as member, cattle plague
commission, Dec., 1869; secretary to inspector-general of hospitals, Jan., 1871; officiating professor of surgical and descriptive anatomy, Calcutta Medical College, and ex-officio 2nd surgeon, College Hospital, April, 1874; also officiating medical inspector of emigrants, Calcutta, and officiating marine surgeon, Jan., 1875; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877; professor of surgery, Medical College, and ex-officio 1st surgeon at the hospital, Jan., 1880; health officer for town of Calcutta, Feb., 1880; brigade-surgeon, June, 1888; author of several publications on cattle diseases, including the report of the cattle plague commission, 1871, and on medico-legal subjects; also of 'History of the Medical Schools of the Bengal Presidency,' 'The Sanitary Past, Present, and Future of Calcutta,' 'Operative Surgery in the Calcutta Medical College.'

McMILLAN, Alexander, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Aldenham grammar school, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; officiating assistant secretary to government, Aug., 1874; under secretary to government, March, 1876; deputy superintendent, family domains of Maharaja of Benares, March, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1883; from April, 1884, served as officiating district and sessions judge and small cause court judge; district and sessions judge, April, 1887.

McMINN, Charles William, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces Commission).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1863; from July, 1864, to Feb., 1879, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, assistant commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty for completion of Oudh gazetteer, July, 1872, also at Simla, July, 1873; from March, 1879, served in the Central Provinces and was appointed deputy commissioner, 1st class, Jubbulpore, Nov., 1884, officiated as commissioner in 1887.

McNEILE, Charles, Colonel, B.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1858; from Dec., 1861, served in the Punjab police department as assistant superintendent and officiating district superintendent; from May, 1865, served in the commission as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and judicial assistant; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Sept., 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1886; retired, March, 1888.

McNEILE, John Magee, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Joined at Addiscombe, Aug., 1834; 1st commission, Bengal Engineers, June, 1856; arrived in India, 10th April, 1858; from May, 1858, served in the public works department as assistant engineer, and executive engineer in Bengal; also as assistant superintendent, Alguada Reef Lighthouse works, 1860-65; officiating superintendent of works, Ajmere and Mairwara, 1874-1876; re-transferred to Bengal, Nov., 1876; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, Jan., 1879; transferred temporarily to Punjab, Oct., 1879; officiating superintending engineer and secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, public works department, Jan., 1880; confirmed in this appointment, Jan., 1882; chief engineer, 3rd class, special, and joint secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, Jan., 1884; officiating chief engineer and secretary to government of Bengal, July, 1885, to Oct., 1886; 2nd chief engineer, Nov., 1887; secretary to the government of Bengal, Jan., 1890, and 1st chief engineer, Feb., 1890.

McQUEEN, Sir J. W., Brigadier-General, K.C.B., A.D.C., B.S.C.—1st commission, Bengal Infantry, April, 1854; arrived in India, 15th May, 1854; employed in military department up to 31st Dec., 1852; served throughout Indian mutiny campaign of 1857-8, including siege and capture of Delhi, relief of Lucknow; commanded 4th Punjab infantry in Oudh and Rohilkund campaign of 1858; served against the Kabul Kheyl Waziris in 1860 (medal and clasp), and in the Jowaki Afreedee expedition, 1877-8 (clasp); served in Afghan war, 1878-80 (medal and two clasps, C.B.); served in Mahsud Waziri expedition, May, 1881; military secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1883; brigadier-general, commanding Hyderabad contingent, Sept., 1885; commanding Punjab frontier force, Oct., 1886; commanded Hazara expedition, 1888 (medal); K.C.B., April, 1889; aide-de-camp to the Queen.

McRAE, John Graham, Colonel, Bombay S.C.—Arrived in India, 10th July, 1858, and served in the Bombay Presidency on military duty till March, 1867, and subsequently in the revenue survey department as assistant superintendent; on military duty, Nov., 1867, to July, 1868 (field service in Abyssinia), and again Dec., 1870, to Nov., 1871; from Nov., 1871, served in the Bombay forest department as deputy conservator; conservator of forests in Sind, Aug., 1878; 2nd grade conservator, Dec., 1886.

McWATTERS, George, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at Newry Collegiate School, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1865; acting under secretary to government of Madras, public department, May-Sept., 1872; sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1879; district and sessions judge, Salem, Jan., 1883; collector and magistrate, Salem, Jan., 1884; collector of sea customs, Madras district; protector of emigrants, superintendent of stamps, &c., and chairman of harbour trust board, Jan., 1890.

MEAD, Charles Clement, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885.

MEAD, Henry Robert, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1857, and served in the Madras public works department from Jan., 1858, as assistant engineer, and executive engineer (4th grade, Jan., 1866), and was placed on special duty on the Neringipeth Anicut project, March, 1871; superintending engineer, Oct., 1878; on special duty in Travancore,
Feb., 1882; 1st class superintending engineer, April, 1886; chief engineer, 2nd class, and joint secretary to government, public works department, irrigation branch, March, 1887; acting chief engineer and secretary to Government, Oct., 1888; retired, Sept., 1889.

MEADE, Malcolm John, Captain, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 9th Ang., 1873; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1873; served under the military and foreign departments, and was appointed officiating political assistant, Rajputana, March, 1878; assistant to resident Hyderabad, and assistant general superintendent in Thuggee and Dacoity department, Aug., 1878; from 1879, was assistant to governor-general's agent in Central India for various periods; boundary settlement officer, Bhopal, June, 1875; superintendent of operations for control of Monghyas, July, 1885; additional political agent, 1st class, and political agent, Baghelkhand, and superintendent of Rewah State, May, 1887; political agent in Bhopawar, Dec., 1889.

MEADE, Sir Richard John, General, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., Bengal Staff Corps.—Educated at Royal Naval School; appointed a cadet, Bengal Infantry, 1st March, 1838; arrived in India, July, 1838; served with the 65th and 54th regiments, N.I., and also temporarily in the commissariat department; interpreter and quartermaster, 65th regiment, N.I., Jan., 1844; station staff at Nowgong, Oct., 1845; and in command, 6th Infantry, Gwalior Contingent, Dec., 1845; brigade major, Gwalior Contingent, postmaster, Gwalior, and cantonment magistrate, Morar, Nov., 1851; also paymaster and commissariat officer, May, 1853; served with 65th Regiment, N.I., in Burma, 1853-1855, and was appointed assistant adjutant-general, Pegu division, Oct., 1854; on the mutiny of the Gwalior contingent, escaped to Agra, where he raised a body of cavalry, subsequently known as "Meade's Horse;" in June, 1853, escorted Maharaja Sindha back to Gwalior, and was present at the battle at that place, Sindha's palace being surrendered to him personally; was afterwards employed as special commissioner in Gwalior to deal with the Gwalior State troops; in 1859 joined brigadier-general Sir R. Napier's force, and received the surrender of Raja Man Sing, and captured the rebel leader, Tantia Topec; in July, 1859, surprised and routed a large body of rebels at Gurroya in the Jhansi district; brevet-major, mutiny medal and clasp for Central India; political agent, Gwalior, April, 1860; governor-general's agent in Central India, and opium agent, Malwa, Nov., 1861; chief commissioner of Mysore and Coorg, Feb., 1870; president of special commission to inquire into charges against the Gaekwar of Baroda, Oct., 1873; member of the commission to investigate the charge preferred against the Gaekwar of attempting to poison the resident Colonel R. Phayre, C.B., Feb., 1875; appointed, to the charge of the Baroda state as agent and special commissioner, April, 1875, and superintended the measures necessary for the reorganisation of the administration, and the selection of a successor to the deposed Gaekwar; resident at Hyderabad, Dec., 1875, to March, 1881; C.S.I., June, 1886; K.C.S.I., May, 1874; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; lieutenant-general in the army, Sept., 1884; General, Jan., 1889.

MEADOWS, Charles John Walford, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1860; from 26th April, 1872, served as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon in Bengal; surgeon-major, Oct., 1881; civil surgeon, Backergunge, with charge of jail, Feb., 1883.

MEDLICOTT, Arthur Louis, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1889, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner.

MEDLICOTT, Henry Benedict, M.A., F.R.S., F.G.S., late Geological Survey of India.—Engaged for service in India from the geological survey of Great Britain; joined appointment in India, March, 1854; professor of geology, Roorkee College, Aug., 1854, to Oct., 1862, when he rejoined the geological survey as deputy superintendent for Bengal; received the Indian mutiny medal for special services in Rohilkund; was variously employed in Bengal, Assam, Central India, Rajputana, Central Provinces, &c.; superintendent of the geological survey (subsequently designated director of the geological survey), April, 1876; fellow of Calcutta University, and member of the faculty of arts and engineering, April, 1876; retired, April, 1887; author of numerous contributions to the survey publications, and of a manual of the geology of India (in part).

MEIKLEJOHN, David Ogilvy, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector, Hoogly, Dec., 1870; from Oct., 1871, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting district superintendent of police, and acting deputy commissioner, and was placed on special famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, Dec., 1882; judge, small cause court, Jubulpore, April, 1885; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Sept., 1889.

MELHUISH, William Francis, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as inspector, 29th May, 1865; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1865, and served in Bengal and Bombay; accompanied Persian Gulf cable expedition, Oct., 1869; superintendent, April, 1880; personal assistant to director-general, Dec., 1881; held charge of various divisions, including Bengal, Madras, Bombay; class IV., 1st grade, April, 1889; electrician, May, 1889.

MELITUS, Paul Gregory, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at St. Marylebone, and All Saints' Grammar School, Marlborough, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1880; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; assistant commissioner in Assam, Nov., 1886; 2nd grade, May, 1888, and 1st grade, April, 1890; acted assistant secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1889.

MELLOR, Charles Warren, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Pro-
vinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1879; 1st grade, Feb., 1882; retired, Aug., 1887.

MELVILL, Sir Peter Melvill, Major-General, K.C.B.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; ensign, Bombay army, 1819; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1819; was employed with the revenue survey of Guzerat, 1822 to 1827; fort adjutant of garrison of Bombay, and A.D.C. to the governor, 1828; on special duty in Calcutta as assistant to the Bombay military member of the financial commission, 1829; 1st assistant to resident in Cutch and Sind, 1836; political agent in Cutch, 1838; secretary to government of Bombay in the military and marine departments, Dec., 1840, to April, 1859; appointed K.C.B., 1860; retired with honorary rank of major-general, Dec., 1861; was a member of Lord Hotham's committee on the amalgamation of the Indian with the British army in 1860, and of the royal commission appointed to report on the memorials of the Indian officers in 1863.

MELVILL, Philip Sandys, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1846; arrived in India, 4th Oct., 1846; attached to the Punjab, and served as assistant to the resident at Lahore, and assistant commissioner; settlement officer in the Hoshypur and Amballa districts, 1850-54; deputy commissioner, Amballa, Jan., 1854; commissioner, Hissar division, 1860 to 1862, and subsequently of the Delhi and Rawal Pindi divisions; officiated as financial commissioner of the Punjab in 1860, and again in 1873, and as judicial commissioner of the Central Provinces, in 1870-71; commissioner, Jullundur division, 1872 to 1875, and officiated as judge of the chief court of the Punjab in 1873 and 1874; member of commission for investigating the charges brought against the Gaekwar of Baroda, 1875; agent to the governor-general and resident, 1st class, at Baroda, Oct., 1875; retired, Jan., 1882.

MENZIES, Hugh Christian, Colonel, M.S.C., late Berar Commission.—Ensign, Dec., 1849; Arrived in India, 7th June, 1850, and served under the military department in Madras, and took part in the operations against the insurgents in the Parla Kimedi District, 1857; served in Burmah from Aug., 1859, as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; from Oct., 1860, served as superintendent of police in Madras, and was engaged in the organisation of the police in the South Malabar districts, and in the Hyderabad assigned districts from Oct., 1862; from Dec., 1864, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, and small cause court judge at Amraoti; inspector-general of registration, Aug., 1871; deputy commissioner, April, 1878.

MENZIES, Oswald, Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 26th Aug., 1854; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1854; from March, 1861, served in the police department, Punjab, as district superintendent, and was promoted to deputy inspector-general, July, 1880; inspector-general of police in the Punjab, and under secretary to government, March, 1885.

MEREDITH, Arthur, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner and district judge; officiating under secretary revenue department, Dec., 1886; officiated as deputy commissioner and as district judge for various periods in 1887-90.

Meres, William Fitzpatrick, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived 29th Nov., 1864; from Sept., 1865, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and in Assam (March-Dec., 1881), and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1878, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1883, and 1st grade, Aug., 1888; retired, 1890; acting judicial commissioner, Burma, Feb., 1885; president of the educational syndicate, Burma, Feb., 1885.

Merk, William Rudolph Henry, C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kornthal, Wurtemberg, the Grammar School, Old Aberdeen, and the University of Aberdeen; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty, Jhelum, March, 1877, and in the Khyber Pass, 1879, and again as assistant political agent, Sept., 1879; assistant resident, Kandahar, Nov., 1880; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Sept., 1882; on special duty with the Afghan boundary commission, Aug., 1884; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; officiating deputy commissioner, Peshawar, Nov., 1887.

Merriman, Charles James, General, C.S.I., R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, June, 1850; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1852; assistant engineer, Sept., 1853; field engineer, Persia, Nov., 1856; executive engineer, Hyderabad, Sept., 1857, and subsequently at Kurrachee and at Aden, 1866; superintending engineer in Sind, May, 1868; in N.W. Provinces to examine irrigation works, Sept.-Nov., 1869; acting chief engineer for irrigation and under secretary to government of Bombay, 1871, and again in 1873 and 1877-79; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bombay, general, and buildings and roads branches, March, 1880; retired from the public works department in 1885.

Merriman, John Henry, Salt Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras revenue survey department from June, 1868, to Oct., 1880; on special duty in Ganjam for settling boundary disputes, March, 1877; from Nov., 1880, served in the Salt Department as assistant commissioner, and was on special duty in the office of the commissioner of salt and akbari revenue, Jan.-April, 1883; deputy-commissioner, salt revenue, Dec., 1885.

Merriman, William, C.I.E., Colonel, R.F., Military Works Department.—Joined the service 12th Dec., 1856, and arrived in India, Feb., 1859; appointed special assistant engineer, harbour defences, Bombay, Nov., 1862; executive engineer, Jan., 1864; acted as under secretary to government in 1864; served under the home government, May, 1866, to March, 1882; re-
turned to India as executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1882; served as superintending engineer of West of India coast defences in 1888; chief engineer, May, 1890; services placed at the disposal of military works branch.

MESTON, JAMES SCORGIE, Bengal C.S. (North West Provinces).—Educated at Grammar School, and University of Aberdeen, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 23 Nov., 1885; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, June, 1890.

METCALFE, CHARLES THEOPHILUS, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1857; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; deputy commissioner and civil officer, Bhutan field force, Oct., 1864; senior superintendent of survey, May, 1869; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, June, 1871; additional commissioner, Patna division, March, 1874; officiating inspector-general of police, Oct., 1876; officiating commissioner of police, Calcutta, Nov., 1876; officiating opium agent, Behar, July, 1884; officiated as commissioner in various divisions between 1876 and 1884, and was appointed commissioner of the Orissa division, and superintendent of tributary Mchals, Cuttack, Sept., 1884; retired, Oct., 1889.

METCALFE, EDWARD PARK, M.A., Madras Educational Department.—Appointed, 16th Nov., 1872, and served as head-master of Rajahmundry school, and acting inspector of schools; fellow of Madras University, March, 1880; 3rd class educational department, May, 1884; principal of Rajahmundry college, Oct., 1887.

MEYER, WILLIAM STEVENSON, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Missionary School, University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, Oct., 1886; confirmed, Nov., 1888; acting under secretary to government revenue department, Nov., 1889-Jan., 1890; member of board of examiners, May, 1890.

MICHAEL, JAMES, Lieut.-General, C.S.I., M.S.C.—Educated at the Temple School, Brighton; also studied on the Continent, and at the Military Academy, Edinburgh; ensign, Madras infantry, Dec., 1844; in 1848 was appointed to organise a scheme of forest conservancy, which he superintended till the establishment of a regular forest department in 1856; assistant chief engineer, Hyderabad, March, 1857; executive engineer, Secunderabad, Sept., 1862; superintendent of family payments and pensions, and curator of government books, Madras, 1865 to 1876; commissioner for Madras at the Universal Exhibition, Paris, 1867; acted as deputy secretary to government of Madras, military department, 1869; commissioner for India to the Vienna Exhibition, 1873 (appointed commander of the Order of Francis Joseph of Austria); fellow of the University of Madras, 1874; attached to the staff of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales during his visit to Madras, 1875; secretary to the government of Madras, military department, Feb., 1876 to 1883; C.S.I., March, 1876; commissioner for India to the Edinburgh Forestry Exhibition, 1884; royal commissioner for the Colonial and Indian Exhibition, 1886.

MICHAEL, WALTER HENRY, Madras, C.S.—Educated at Newark grammar school, and at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 5th December, 1887, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

MICHELL, THOMAS BERNARD, Colonel, B.S.C., late Assam Commission.—First commission as ensign, Feb., 1848; arrived in India, 29th Jan., 1860; from March, 1866, served in the Assam commission, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Jan., 1885; also served temporarily in Bengal as cantonment magistrate, Dum-Dum, July, 1877, to Nov., 1878; retired, March, 1886.

MIDDLETON, JAMES RUSSELL, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Andrew's, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate, Kaladgi, Aug., 1883; senior collector and magistrate, Nov., 1886; acted as commissioner, southern division, March to June, 1889; collector and magistrate and district registrar, Nasik, June, 1889; also political agent of the Surgana state.

MIDWINTER, WILLIAM COLPOYS, Burma Commission.—Assistant conservator of forests, June, 1868; from Sept., 1869, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, officiating judge of the small cause court at Rangoon, settlement and boundary officer in the Tharrawaddy district, and cantonment magistrate of Thayetmyo (July, 1883); deputy commissioner, Sept., 1883.

MILES, SAMUEL BARRETT, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Bombay infantry, Aug., 1857; from Nov., 1867, served as cantonment magistrate and assistant resident, Aden; assistant political agent, Meckran Coast, 1871; from Oct., 1872, served as political agent and consul, Muscat; officiating political agent, Turkish Arabia, and consul-general Baghdad, 1879-80; political agent, Zanzibar, 1881; returned to agency of Muscat, 1883; graded as political agent, 1st class; acting political resident, Persian Gulf, April, 1886; political resident in Meywar and Oodeypore.

MILLER, A., Library, India Office.—Writer, 11th Oct., 1867; clerk, 2nd class, March, 1880.

MILLER, Sir Alexander Edward, Kt., B.A., LL.D., Government of India.—Educated at Rugby and Trinity College, Dublin, where he obtained scholarship, 1st gold medal in mathematics and physics, and 2nd gold medal in classics, besides the Berkeley medal in Greek; hon. LL.D. in 1875; called to the bar (Lincoln's Inn) 1854; Q.C. in 1872; examiner in law, London University, 1874-9, and for council of legal education, 1877-8; legal member of railway commission, 1877-88; master in lunacy, 1880; appointed legal member of the Government of India, Dec., 1890.

MILLER, John Ontario, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's Col-
lege, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, and assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1883; under secretary to government, May, 1884; private secretary to the lieutenant-governor of the N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1886; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1887; settlement officer, 3rd grade, Oct., 1888.

MILLER, LESLIE CREERY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1884; acting head assistant collector, Oct., 1885.

MILLETT, H. (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal Judicial Service.—Professor of English law, Presidency College, Calcutta, April, 1870; officiating 2nd judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Oct., 1871; receiver, high court, April to Dec., 1873; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, legislative department, Dec., 1873, to April, 1875; first judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Jan., 1876; retired, 1889.

MILLETT, MONTAGUE, Colonel, Bengal Infantry, late Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 1857; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1857; from Sept., 1864, served in the police department, Punjab, as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, June, 1884; services placed at the disposal of government of India military department, Oct., 1887.

MIRZA, ABBAS ALI BEY, Bombay C.S.—Appointed in India probationer under the native civil service rules, and joined the service as assistant to the collector of Thana, 1st April, 1890.

MITCHELL, HORACE, Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Paul's School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 27th March, 1885.

MITCHELL, THOMAS CANDY, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal; from May, 1876, served in Burma as assistant commissioner and boundary and settlement officer; on special forest demarcation duty, Nov., 1880; on special duty in connection with waste land grants in Arakan division, March, 1882; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Aug., 1886; assistant commissioner, April, 1888.

MOBERLY, CHARLES MORRIS, Colonel, M.S.C., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 2nd European regiment Madras, May, 1855; joined the public works department, May, 1867, as examiner of railway accounts, Madras; controller of accounts, Calcutta, 1873; officiating deputy accountant-general, March, 1876; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, March, 1878; Rajputana railway accounts, 1879; acted as manager, Rajputana railway, May-Aug., 1881; on special duty as secretary to railway conference, Jan.-March, 1884; examiner, 1st class, in the accounts establishment, Jan., 1886; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, March, 1887.

MOBERLY, HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Andrew's College, Bradfield, and King's College School, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and forest settlement officer; special assistant to collector and magistrate, Dec., 1888.

MOCKLER, EDWARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Aug., 1859; served as assistant resident, Aden, Dec., 1866-1873; on civil employ, Makran coast, from 1873; assistant to the governor-general's agent, Beloochistan, Oct., 1879; assistant agent and consul, Busreh, Turkish Arabia, Nov., 1881; acted as political agent, Muscat, 1883, and again April, 1886, and April, 1887; graded as political agent, 2nd class; assistant political agent, Bishure, Nov., 1886, and Basra, Nov., 1887.

MOHENDRO NATH BOSE, Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 26th Feb., 1859, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, Sept., 1868; small cause court judge, Midnapore, Feb., 1872; 1st grade subordinate judge, and small cause judge, Hooghly, Serampore, and Howrah, May, 1877; officiating judge, highcourt, Jan., 1882; judge of the principal courts of small causes in Nudda and Jessore, and of the courts of small causes at Krishnagur, Ranaghat, and Bongong, Oct., 1884.

MOHSIN BADRUDDIN TYABJI, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Mary's Institute and St. Xaviers College, Bombay, and at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1887; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1888.

MOIR, WILLIAM, M.A., M.B., Brigade Surgeon, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 20th Jan., 1860; arrived in India, 27th April, 1860, and was employed in various military medical charges; from June, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail at Mainpuri, and afterwards at Meerut, and was placed in medical charge of the lock hospital at the latter place; held medical charge of camp of lieutenant-governor, 1863-64; superintendent, meteorological observatory, Meerut, June, 1868; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1872; surgeon-major, Jan., 1875; officiating chemical examiner, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1878 to March, 1879, and again in April, 1888; brigade surgeon, April, 1888.

MOIR, WILLIAM ROBERT GRAY, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Charterhouse and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

MOLESWORTH, SIR GUILDFORD LINDSAY, K.C.I.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Educated at the College of Civil Engineers, Putney; in 1852 was chief assistant engineer on the London, Brighton, and South Coast Railway, which he left in order to superintend the construction of buildings and machinery in the Royal Arsenal at Woolwich, during the Crimean war; afterwards practised
as a consulting engineer in London for some years; was awarded the 'Watt' medal and the 'Manby' premium by the Institution of Civil Engineers in 1838, for a paper read before the institution on the 'Conversion of Wood by Machinery'; engineer on the Ceylon railway, 1859; chief engineer, Ceylon government railway, 1862; director-general of the railway, 1865; director of public works in 1867; consulting engineer for state railways to the government of India, April, 1871; acted as director-general of railways and deputy secretary to government of India, March-June, 1880; K.C.I.E., June, 1888; retired, 1889; fellow of the University of Calcutta; is the author of many publications on engineering, monetary, and other subjects, including a 'Pocket-book of Engineering Formulae,' which has passed through twenty-one editions; of 'Proposals for the Establishment of Decimal Coinage,' in Ceylon, 1865, and in India, 1871; of Reports on the Public Works of Ceylon, 1869, on Light Railways in Ceylon, 1870, on the Festiniog Railway, 1871, on State Railways in India, 1872, and on the Madras Harbour, 1884; 'Iron Manufacture in India,' 1884; 'Suggestions for the Establishment of an Engineer Volunteer Corps for India,' 1865; 'Imperialism for India,' 1885; 'Text-book of Bi-metallism,' 1886, &c., &c.

MOLONY, EDMUND ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1886, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

MONAHAN, FRANCIS JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Oratory School, Birmingham, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service, after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885.

MONAHAN, JAMES HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oratory School, Edgbaston, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881.

MONEY, ALONZO, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1843; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Backergunge, 1846; superintendent of survey, Monghyr, 1850; magistrate and collector, Behar, 1857, and afterwards of Shahabad and Tirhoot; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Pooree, 1859; controller of government salt-chowkies, 1860; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Bhaugulpore, 1863; commissioner of Patna, and member of council of the lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1869; member of revenue board, Lower Provinces, 1869; district and sessions judge, Bareilly, and member of revenue board, 1875; retired, 1878.

MONEY, ROBERT COTTON, Major-General, B.S.C.—First commission in army, 20th March, 1855; from 1st March, 1861, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed deputy commissioner, and grade, April, 1877; manager of the Durbhunga Raj estate, April, 1876, to Jan., 1878, and again, Jan., 1880; retired, April, 1886.

MONEY, WILLIAM JAMES, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1853; served in the revenue and survey departments in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant superintendent of survey, and was employed as civil officer with the troops in the Sonthal insurrection, 1855-56; private secretary to Sir James Outram, chief commissioner of Oudh, Aug., 1857; during the mutiny was present at several engagements, and was a member of the garrison of Lucknow; mutiny medal; served subsequently in Bengal and N.W. Provinces, and was appointed superintendent of revenue survey, 1860, in Jessore, and afterwards in other districts; magistrate and collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, 1861; officiated as district and sessions judge, Mymensingh, from 1869, and was confirmed in that appointment, Sept., 1873; retired, 1879.

MONRO, ALEXANDER, M.A., B.C.L., B.L., Education Department, Central Provinces.—Arrived in India, 2nd June, 1879; Inspector of schools, 4th class, graded educational department, June, 1879; fellow of Madras University, March, 1885; member of the conference on the school fee question, Aug., 1886; inspector-general of education, Central Provinces, Jan., 1889.

MONRO, JAMES, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Arrived in India, and appointed a junior civil servant, 27th Jan., 1858; served as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating under-secretary to the government of Bengal, and in April, 1864, was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector; from Sept., 1864, served for various periods as officiating magistrate and collector, deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, and secretary to the board of revenue; appointed magistrate and collector, Feb., 1872, and district and sessions judge, April, 1874; inspector-general of police, Bengal, Jan., 1878; on special duty to report on the system of village police, Nov., 1882; commissioner of the presidency division, March, 1883; retired from the Bengal civil service, 1884, and was appointed director of criminal investigations in Scotland Yard; in Nov., 1888, he was appointed chief commissioner of metropolitan police, but resigned that office, June, 1890.

MONTEATH, ALEXANDER M., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, Edinburgh University, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1856; arrived in India, 1857; assistant magistrate and collector, Allahabad, 1858; assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1859; under secretary to government of India, financial and home departments, 1861; director-general of the post office of India from 1867 till his retirement in 1881, during which period he was placed for about two years on postal duty in England, including the representation of India at the postal conference at Berne in 1876.

MONTEATH, JAMES, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Royal Academical Institution, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty in Bombay in connexion with the Kanara land assessment case, Nov., 1873; also acted for various periods as under secretary to government of Bombay in the revenue, financial, and general departments, under secretary to government in the political,
judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the Bombay legislative council, and as assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; appointed under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, May, 1884, and acted as secretary, Sept.-Dec., 1884 and March, 1889; acting private secretary to the governor, Oct., 1889.

MONTGOMERY, JAMES ALEXANDER LAWRENCE, Major, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 26th Feb., 1868; from Nov., 1870, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; settlement officer, 1st grade, Sept., 1880; director of settlement and revenue records in the Punjab, Dec., 1883; author of a report on the settlement of the Hoshiarpur district; promoted to deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, May, 1887; 2nd grade, May, 1889.

MOORE, ERNEST ANDREW, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Bradfield College and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Burma division of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Burma, 25th Nov., 1889, and served as assistant commissioner.

MOORE, GEORGE MONTGOMERY J., Lieut.-Col., R.A.—Military secretary on personal staff of the governor of Madras (Rt. Hon. Sir M. E. Grant Duff), G.C.S.I., C.I.E.), 1st April, 1884 to 1886; president of Madras municipal commission.

MOORE, JOHN GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1856, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector, magistrate, and political agent; served in Sind from Dec., 1862, to Nov., 1870, as assistant commissioner, educational inspector, branch registrar-general, and acting commissioner; junior collector and magistrate, Sattarra, Oct., 1876; senior collector and magistrate, Sept., 1877; on special duty as president of the jail commission, July-Sept., 1878; was subsequently collector and magistrate of Poona, and acted on several occasions as commissioner of the southern and central divisions, Bombay, and as commissioner of customs, salt and opium, Feb., 1885; acting commissioner of customs, salt, opium, and abkari, and reporter-general of external commerce, May, 1887; 2nd grade commissioner, and commissioner, central division, July, 1888; 1st grade, Sept., 1888; temporary member of governor's council, March, 1890.

MOORE, LEWIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1869, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate (Dec., 1884), acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; district and sessions judge, Dec., 1888; compiled 'Trichinopoly District Manual.'

MOORE, ROSS ARTHUR LESLIE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Dulwich, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883.

MOORE, SIR WILLIAM JAMES, Surgeon-General, K.C.I.E., late Medical Department, Bombay.—First commission, Indian medical department, 1852; was employed on regimental and other military duty till April, 1862, when he was appointed residency surgeon at Joudpur, and afterwards at Marwar; served from Aug., 1867, in Rajputana as agency surgeon and superintendent-general of dispensaries and vaccination; acting deputy surgeon-general, Bombay, 1877; deputy surgeon-general, Oct., 1877; surgeon-general with the government of Bombay, 1st April, 1885; hon. surgeon to the Viceroy; retired, Feb., 1888; K.C.I.E., May, 1888.

MORELAND, WILLIAM HARRISON, Bengal C.S., N.W. Provinces.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Cambridge, appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

MORGAN, CHARLES, Registry Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 22nd April, 1857; assistant to registrar, Oct., 1874.

MORGAN, SIR WALTER, late Madras High Court.—Called to the bar, Middle Temple, 18th Nov., 1844; clerk of legislative council of India, 1854-59; master in equity of the supreme court, Calcutta, 1859-62; puisne judge of Calcutta high court, 1862-66; chief justice of the high court of the N.W. Provinces, 1866-71; and of the high court of Madras from 1871, until his retirement in 1879.

MORIARTY, ARTHUR STEPHEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge.

MORISON, WILLIAM THOMSON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; transferred to Burma as assistant-commissioner, 1887; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Dec., 1888.

MORLAND, SIR HENRY, Captain, late Indian navy, Port Officer, Bombay.—Joined the service in the late Indian navy, 5th June, 1852; arrived in India, 16th Sept., 1852; served on various vessels of the Indian navy, including the steamers 'Semiramis' and 'Dalhousie' (lieutenant commanding); was appointed registrar of seamen, Aug., 1850; served for various periods as dock-master, agent for transports, secretary harbour and pilotage board, and signaller for the port and island of Bombay; deputy conservator and master attendant of the port of Bombay, registrar of shipping, and president of the marine board of examiners Dec., 1878; designation of office changed to port officer, Aug., 1879.

MORRIS, SIR JOHN H., K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1847; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1848; served in the Punjab as assistant resident, Lahore, assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer in the Trans-Sutlej division; settlement officer, Mooltan, 1854; magistrate and collector, Allahabad, May, 1862; settlement commissioner, Central Provinces,
Sept., 1863; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, June, 1863; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, May, 1870; retired, 1883.

MORRIS, MATTHEW, Punjab Police Department.—Appointed to the police department, 12th Feb., 1861, as assistant district superintendent, served in the various grades of the department, and was promoted to be district superintendent, 1st grade, March, 1888.

MORRIS, ROBERT, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at High School, Glasgow, University of Glasgow, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1885.

MORRISON, FRANK, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Served in the telegraph department, Sept., 1863, to Feb., 1864; rejoined government service, and was employed in the accounts establishment (public works) in Bombay, Sindh, the Punjab, and Calcutta; deputy controller, Nov., 1874; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Lahore, Dec., 1875; examiner, Indus Valley railway, June, 1878; examiner of P.W. accounts, Hyderabad, Dec., 1879; Northern Bengal railway accounts, May, 1882; examiner, 3rd class, May, 1886; acted as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, 1886-87; examiner, southern Mahratta railway company, March, 1887; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Madras, March, 1888.

MORSHEAD, LEONARD FREDERICK, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1889, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

MORTON, BOYCE WILLIAM DUNLOP, Major-General, B.S.C., late Non-regulation Commission, Bengal.—First commission, 9th June, 1843; served in Assam from June, 1854, as junior assistant and principal assistant to the commissioner; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Goalpara, April, 1861; superintendent of Darjeeling, Dec., 1866; on special duty for conducting the prosecution of Captain Playfair, Aug., 1876; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; retired, Aug., 1885.

MOSCARDI, EDWARD HENRY, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Somersetshire College, Bath, and Worcester College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty compiling the general administration report of the Bombay Presidency, Aug., 1881; from Dec., 1881, served in the judicial department, and was appointed 2nd grade assistant judge, Oct., 1883, and 1st grade, April, 1890; acting district and sessions judge, May, 1888; and Jan., 1889.

MOSLEY, HERBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bishop's Stortford Collegiate School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from April, 1865, served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, May, 1884; and 1st grade, March, 1888; retired, Jan., 1891.

MOULIE, HORACE FREDERICK D'OVILY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces)—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty in 1872 to conduct the prosecution of the sub-judge of Mirzapur; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, June, 1884; 1st grade, Dec., 1886; officiated, district and sessions judge, July and Oct., 1887, and May-Aug., 1888; secretary, board of revenue, Jan.-May, 1886; officiating commissioner, Lucknow division, March, 1890.

MOUNSEY, CHARLES HERBERT, Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at King's College School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant sessions judge, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; head assistant, Anantapur, May, 1886; compiled and edited the 'Reports of the Meriah Agents (Ganjam),' and wrote a 'History of the Ganjam Maliaks.'

MOWAT, M., M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Professor, Presidency College, June, 1876; Dacca College, Jan., 1878; officiating inspector of schools, Nov., 1879; professor, Patna College, Feb., 1880; officiating principal, Patna College, May, 1883; 3rd class of the education department, July, 1883; officiating principal, Hooghly College, April, 1885.

MUHAMMAD ABBAS MIRZA, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 16th Feb., 1880; confirmed as covenanted civil servant, March, 1882; and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd class; 2nd class, Oct., 1883.

MUHAMMAD AFZAL KHAN WAZIR-ZADAH, C.S.I., Sirdar, Lieutenant-Colonel, 11th Bengal Lancers, Political Department, Punjab.—Appointed British agent at the court of H.H. the Amir of Kabul, March, 1882; A.D.C. to governor-general.

MUHAMMAD AFZAL KHAN, Sirdar, Khan Bahadur, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 3rd March, 1881; assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Oct., 1885.

MUHAMMED ALI SAIVID, B.A. (Calcutta University), Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Appointed to be a probationary assistant magistrate and collector under the statutory rules, 4th April, 1887; confirmed in the civil service, and appointed assistant commissioner, April, 1880.

MUHAMMAD ASLAM KHAN, Kazi, C.M.G., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Officiating extra assistant commissioner, 10th Sept., 1881; on special duty in civil secretariat, Dec., 1881; probationer under native civil service rules, Nov., 1882; assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; on special duty with Afghan boundary commission, Aug., 1884, to Nov., 1886; appointed Mir Munshi to Punjab government, May, 1887; native attache to Foreign Office, April, 1888.

MUHAMMAD HADI, SAIVID, Bengal (N.W. Provinces).—Appointed under the native civil service rules probationary assistant magistrate and collector, 5th April, 1890.

MUHAMMAD HYAT KHAN, C.S.I., Pu'tub commission.—Extra assistant commissioner,
Punjab, March, 1862; promoted to assistant commissioner, Jan., 1872; C.S.I., May, 1872; served as officiating judicial assistant in the Punjab, and was employed on special duty with the camp of exercise at Hasan Abdal, 1873; also as officiating political assistant with the Kuram field force, 1878; and as political officer with the staff of Sir F. Roberts, Kabul field force, 1879-80; district judge, and grade, Punjab, Dec., 1886, and 1st grade, April, 1889; has officiated as divisional judge.

MUHAMMAD ISHAK KHAN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed a probationer under native civil service rules, Jan., 1884; confirmed in the civil service, Aug., 1886; assistant magistrate and collector, April, 1888; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1889.

MUHAMMAD RAZA KHAN SAHIB, Madras C.S.—Served from Jan., 1874, in subordinate posts in the Madras revenue and educational departments, and in Hyderabad as attache to the resident; appointed by the government of India to be a member of the Madras civil service, 3rd Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1883; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Feb., 1890.

MUHAMMAD SAMI ULLA KHAN, Maulvi, C.M.G., Bengal Judicial Department (N.W. Provinces).—Joined the service as sub-judge, 1st May, 1873; district judge, sub-problem, April, 1885 and April, 1886, officiated as district judge in 1886 and 1887, and was confirmed in the appointment, May, 1887.

MUIR, ARCHBOLD MUNGO, Major, B.S.C., Hyderabad Administration.—Cornet 4th hussars, 30th Sept., 1868; served in the Afghan war, 1878-80, including the action of Takht-i-Pul, and siege of Kandahar (medal and clasp) in Sept., 1873; appointed private secretary and A.D.C. to lieut.-governor N.W. provinces, from Aug. 1878; served in the foreign department in 1873, as assistant agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, and afterwards as political officer at Kandahar, and as assistant general superintendent for the suppression of thuggee and dacoity; assistant boundary settlement officer, Central India, Nov., 1883, and in Rajputana, Nov., 1885; cantonment magistrate at Nasirabad, April, 1886, and afterwards at Hyderabad; 2nd assistant and assistant secretary for Berar to the resident, Jan., 1889.

MUIR, JOHN FAIRLIE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Rugby School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Sept., 1869, to April, 1874, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting assistant secretary and personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and acting deputy commissioner; from April, 1874, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; 1st assistant collector, May, 1880; junior collector and magistrate, April, 1887; senior collector, June, 1890.

MUIR, JULIUS WOOD, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dumfries Academy, and Edinburgh University, called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate, and grade, July, 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st grade in Oudh, Sept., 1885; district and sessions judge, Sept., 1887.

MUIR, Sir WILLIAM, K.C.S.I., D.C.L., LL.D., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kilmarnock Grammar School, and Edinburgh and Glasgow Universities; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1837; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1837; settlement officer in Cawnpore and Bundelkund, 1840-1843; officiating collector, Futtehpore, 1844-1845; secretary, Sudder board of revenue, 1847; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1852; member, board of revenue, 1856; in charge of intelligence department at Agra during mutiny, 1857; secretary with Lord Canning at Allahabad for N.W. Provinces, 1858; reverted to board of revenue, 1859; member of legislative council of governor-general, 1864; foreign secretary, government of India, 1865; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, 1868-1874; financial member of governor-general's council, 1874-76; member of council of secretary of state, 1876-85; principal, Edinburgh University, 1885; honorary D.C.L. of Oxford, and LL.D. of Glasgow and Edinburgh; author of 'Life of Mahomet and History of Islam to the Era of the Hegira,' 1838; 'Annals of the Early Caliphate,' 1883, and other works on the same subject; pamphlet on indigenous education in Futtehpore, 1845; papers on revenue settlement in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, &c.

MUIR, WILLIAM JAMES WEMYSS, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1858; assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, Sept., 1863; assistant general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti, June, 1864; political superintendent, Sirohi, Sept., 1865; officiated for some time as agent of Haraoti and Tonk; political agent, Moorshedabad, 1876; cantonment magistrate, Neemuch, 1879; Haraoti and Tonk, 1880; graded as political agent, 1st class; cantonment magistrate, Ajmere Merwara, May, 1880.

MUIR-MACKENZIE, John William Pitt, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent in charge of Jath state, and forest settlement officer; on famine duty in 1876 and 1877; on duty at Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester, Oct., 1886, to Oct., 1887; 2nd assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1887; acting director of land records and agriculture, Feb., 1888; under secretary to Government of India in revenue and agricultural departments, March, 1889.

MULLALY, CHARLES MYLNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Southampton Grammar School, Hartley Institution, Southampton, and London University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1883; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1887;
acting collector and magistrate, Aug., 1883.

MULLEN, Surgeon-Major Douglas French, M.D., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 31st March, 1877; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1877, and served on general and military duty; from April, 1878, served under the foreign department in medical charge of the Meywar Bhil corps, and officiating residency surgeon, Meywar; was confirmed in the latter appointment, Nov., 1886.

MULLICK, Basanta Kumar, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College School, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 13th Jan., 1890, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

MULLINS, John, Lieut-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—2nd lieutenant, Madras engineers, 8th Dec., 1848; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1850; assistant civil engineer, Feb., 1852; served as 1st class district engineer in Nellore and Tanjore, 1858-64; consulting engineer for the irrigation and canal company, Madras, May, 1864, to Aug., 1869; under secretary to government, public works department, Feb., 1869; chief engineer for irrigation and joint secretary to government of Madras, public works department, Nov., 1870; acted as chief engineer and secretary to government in 1875 and 1877; president, irrigation committee, famine commission, Oct., 1878, to Jan., 1879; on special duty for drawing up the Bangalore water supply scheme, Oct., 1883; services replaced at disposal of military department, in 1884; retired, 1886.

MULOCK, Francis Berry, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portora Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, and Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty as assistant private secretary to lieutenant-governor on occasion of visit of H.R.H. Prince of Wales, Dec., 1875, to March, 1876; on special duty for arrangements connected with Imperial assemblage at Delhi, Nov., 1876; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, April, 1886; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1887; magistrate and collector, Feb., 1890.

MULOCK, Henry Pilkington, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; from Feb., 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred temporarily to Bengal for employment on Behar famine relief works, Dec., 1873, to Oct., 1874; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1878; judge, 3rd grade, April, 1885.

MULOCK, William Bury, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin.
