(Punjab).—Educated at King's College School, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1856, and served in the Punjab, and temporarily in Oudh, as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to financial commissioner, Punjab, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty, Dec., 1864; promoted to deputy commissioner, April, 1866; commissioner and superintendent, Amritsar, April, 1877, and afterwards in the Mooltan and Rawul Pindi divisions; retired, Nov., 1886.

PERROTT, FINCH, Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 24th Dec., 1880.

PERT, FREDERICK JAMES, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces, &c.).—Educated at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1885, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

PETERSON, FRANCIS WILLIAM, F.C.S., Mint Department, Bombay.—Joined the mint department as assistant in the bullion office, Calcutta; between Jan., 1869, and Oct., 1881, acted for various periods as deputy assay master at the Calcutta mint, and at the Bombay mint, and also as assay master at the latter mint; appointed deputy assay master, Calcutta mint, Oct., 1881; acting assay master, Oct., 1882, to Jan., 1883.
and again in 1834; deputy assay master, Bombay mint, Oct., 1837.

PETERSON, FREDERICK WILLIAM VOYSEY, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Leicester Collegiate School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived 7th Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1875, and deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Dec., 1877; from May, 1877, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Sept., 1885; retired, April, 1889.

PETERSON, HERBERT PARSONS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Loughborough Grammar School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1875; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Dec., 1887; has also acted as district and sessions judge.

PETERSON, PETER, M.A. (Ed.), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1873, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of oriental languages, Elphinstone College, Bombay; also acted as professor in the Deccan College, Poona, Oct., 1875-Nov., 1876; university registrar, Bombay, Jan., 1878; promoted to 3rd grade of the educational department, July, 1879; on leave to attend international oriental congress at Leyden, Aug.-Nov., 1883; acting principal of Elphinstone College, April, 1888.

PETHERAM, SIR WILLIAM COMER, K.T., Q.C.—Called to the bar (Middle Temple), 1850; as chief justice of the high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, 1st Nov., 1884; chief justice, Calcutta, 24th March, 1886; vice-chancellor of the University of Calcutta, June, 1887.

PETLEY, E. W., Commander, R.N.—Deputy conservator of the port of Calcutta, and river surveyor, Oct., 1881; port officer and master attendant, April, 1888.

PETRE, FRANCIS LORAIN (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oscott College, and University of London; appointed after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating cantonment magistrate, Bareilly, April-Nov., 1880; officiating under secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Aug. to Nov., 1882; junior secretary, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1882; from April, 1885, served under the foreign department, Government of India, as assistant agent to government-general in Central India; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, March, 1888; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Dec., 1888; officiated as magistrate and collector in 1889-90.

PETTY, A. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 16th July, 1883.

PEYTON, WILLIAM, Colonel, M.S.C., late Forest Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, March, 1851, and served in Madras on military duty till Jan., 1866, and subsequently as deputy conservator of forests; from Oct., 1870, served in the Bombay presidency as conservator of forests (2nd grade, Dec., 1883).

PHAYRE, SIR ROBERT, Lieutenant-General, K.C.B., B.S.C.—Educated at Shrewsbury; ensign, Bombay army, 26th Jan., 1839; served in the first Afghan War and the Scinde campaign, 1840-1845, and was present at the action of Kotra and the battle of Meanee (medal); deputy assistant quartermaster-general in Scinde, 1844-50; assistant quartermaster-general, 1850-1855; deputy quartermaster-general, Bombay army, Dec., 1855; in the Abyssinian expedition of 1867-68, served as quartermaster-general to the pioneer force, and conducted the reconnaissance of the Magdala position, and was present at the action of Aroge (C.B., medal, and aide-de-camp to the Queen); political superintendent and commandant of the Scinde frontier field force, July, 1868 to 1872; resident at Baroda, March, 1873-74, during which period he brought charges of maladministration against the Gaekwar, which were investigated by a commission of enquiry; returned to military duty after the attempt of the Gaekwar to poison him at the end of 1874; brigadier-general, and in command at Nusseerabad, April, 1875; served in the Afghan War in 1879-80 in command of the reserve division, and the line of communication to Quetta, and took part in the relief of Candahar (thanks of both Houses of Parliament, K.C.B. and medal); major-general, Jan., 1880; in command of Mhow division, March, 1881, to Feb., 1886; lieutenant-general, Nov., 1881; acted as commander-in-chief, Bombay, Nov., 1885, to Feb., 1886; returned to England, March, 1886.

PHEAR, SIR JOHN BUDD, KNT.—Educated at Pembroke College, Cambridge; graduated 6th wrangler in 1847, and was elected fellow, and afterwards appointed mathematical lecturer and assistant tutor of Clare College; M.A., 1850; called to the bar at the Inner Temple in 1854; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1864 to 1876; knighted in 1877; chief justice of Ceylon, 1877 to 1879; is justice of the peace and a chairman of quarter sessions for the county of Devon; unsuccessfully contested the Honiton division of Devon in 1885, and the Tavistock division in 1886; is fellow of the Cambridge Philosophical Society, and of the Geological Society, and president of the Devon association for the advancement of science, literature, and art; author of 'Elementary Mechanics,' 'Elementary Hydrostatics,' 'Rights of Water,' 'The Aryan Village in India and Ceylon,' 'International Trade,' and a presidential address to the Devonshire association of science, &c., on 'Domesday and the Early English Land System.'

PHELPS, W. E., Store Department, India Office.—Entered the royal artillery, 30th Oct., 1860; served in the Bombay ordnance department, from Feb., 1876; served in the Quetta field force, 1878-80; transferred to Bengal ordnance department, May, 1881, and was promoted to sub-conductor, Aug., 1882; assistant in office of inspector-general of ordnance, Bengal, 1880-84; supervisor, 2nd grade, India store depot, 17th June, 1884.

PHILIPPS, HERBERT REES, Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Trinity College, Cambridge; Porson (Greek) University prizeman, 1871 and 1872; B.A., 1873; M.A., 1877; junior clerk, General Post Office, 1867; junior clerk, correspondence department, India office, estates and will branch,
1868; transferred to public works department, 1869; statistics and commerce department, 1874; attached in 1876 to select committee on the depreciation of silver, and edited report of committee; transferred to military department, 1883; senior clerk, July, 1883; compiled Parliamentary papers, Nos. 8 to 16 of statistical abstract relating to British India, Nos. 13 to 16 of statement exhibiting the moral and material progress of India.

PHILLIPS, A. (Barrister-at-Law).—Advocate, high court, Calcutta, from 1871; secretary to Government of India, legal department, June to Nov., 1877; author of 'Tagore Law Lectures'; standing counsel, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 1880.

PHILLIPS, Augustus Marshall, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Ensign, Bombay infantry, June, 1855; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1855; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-57 (medal and clasp); from March, 1863, served as assistant political superintendent, Savantvadi; assistant political agent, Mahi Kantha, Sadra, Gujerat, Feb., 1867; special assistant political agent in charge of estate of Gondal, Kathiawar, July, 1872, to April, 1875; served subsequently as assistant political agent in Kathiawar, and acted as superintendent of the Gaekwar's contingent, assistant in charge of Amreli Mahals, and superintendent, stud department, Kathiawar, June, 1881; first assistant political agent, Kathiawar, Sept., 1881; also acted as political agent in Kathiawar, in Cutch, and in Mahi Kantha; political superintendent Savantvadi, March, 1889.

PHILLIPS, Arthur Noel, Colonel.—Ensign, 19th Bengal native infantry, 8th Dec., 1858; served with the 73rd Foot and the 14th and 4th Punjab native infantry; assistant commissioner, Assam, May, 1862; officiated as deputy commissioner at various places in Assam, and in June, 1880, returned to the N.W. Provinces as officiating cantonment magistrate; confirmed, Aug., 1881; retired, April, 1890.

PHILLIPS, Francis Angelo Theodore, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Winchester, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1880, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and acting deputy commissioner; acted as judge, small cause court, in 1883 and 1887-8.

PHILLIPS, Henry Arthur Deuterros, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1874; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on famine relief duty, Bellary, Aug., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Dec., 1885; 1st grade, Aug., 1888; under secretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1886; author of 'Indian Criminal Law,' 'Manual of Revenue and Collectorate Law,' 'Our Administration of India,' and 'Comparative Criminal Jurisprudence.'

PHILLIPS, Henry Dominic, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service in 1829; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge, and was appointed junior deputy secretary, board of revenue, 1837; acted as registrar, Sudder Dewani and Foujdari Adawlut, 1842-43; sub-judge, Madura, 1846; agent to governor of Madras, at Kurnool, 1847; collector and magistrate, Salem, 1850; civil and sessions judge at Mangalore, and at Madura, 1857; collector and magistrate and resident commissioner at Tanjore, 1858; puisne judge, Sudder Dewani and Foujdari Adawlut, 1858; president of the board of examiners; commissioner for the affairs of the late Raja of Tanjore, 1859; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, 1862; provisional member of council of governor of Fort St. George, 1864; member of Madras council, 16th Dec., 1864; resigned the service, 12th Nov., 1869.

PIGGOTT, Theodore Carl, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kingswood School, Bath, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed member of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner, Jhansi.

PIGOT, J. O., B.A.—Advocate, high court, Bombay, 1870-82; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Bengal, 1882.

PIKE, Herbert Watson, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Honiton Grammar School, Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1885; attached to the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, 1890; acted as under secretary to government, Nov., 1890.

PILCHER, Jesse Griggs, Deputy Surgeon-General Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1860; officiating sanitary commissioner for Bengal, 26th April, 1875; officiating health officer for the port of Calcutta, April, 1876, to Feb., 1877; civil surgeon, Burdwan, June, 1876, and at Howrah, from Feb., 1877, with medical charge of the government engineering college, from April, 1880; civil surgeon Howrah, Oct., 1882, and Darjeeling, Jan., 1888; deputy surgeon-general, central provinces, March, 1890.

PINHEY, Arthur Francis, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived, 3rd Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Nov., 1888; has officiated as deputy commissioner.

PINHEY, Robert Hill (Barrister-at-Law), late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 23rd Feb., 1851, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, joint judge and sessions judge, and registrar of the high court, Bombay; judge and sessions judge, Thana, Sept., 1863; acting judicial commissioner, and judge of the sadar court in Sind, Nov., 1869, to June, 1871; judge and sessions judge, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan, Poona, April, 1873; judge of the high court, Bombay, Feb., 1875; retired, 1885.

PINHEY, R. W. S., B.L., Bombay Judicial Department.—Joined the service as acting judge of small cause court, Karachi, 10th April, 1886; and was confirmed as such, 14th April, 1887; acted as government pleader and public prosecutor and city magistrate, Karachi, and was appointed fourth judge of the small cause court, Bombay, May, 1889.
PINKERTON, John, Surgeon-General, M.D.—Bombay Medical Department.—Joined the service, 4th Aug., 1855, and arrived in India, 17th March, 1856; joined Indian navy, Bombay harbour and Persian Gulf, Dec., 1856; and served in Persia during the war in 1857; served on civil and military duty, 1858 to 1861; acting superintendent of vaccination, Sind, March, 1863; surgeon, Aug., 1867; superintendent-general of vaccination, Bombay presidency, April, 1868; surgeon-major, May, 1873; surgeon in European general hospital and deputy sanitary commissioner; deputy surgeon-general, Sind, Aug., 1882; surgeon-general of Bombay, Feb., 1888.

PITCHER, Duncan George, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as cornet, Bombay light cavalry, 3rd Sept., 1859, having previously served in the royal marine light infantry and artillery, 1856-59; served under the military department till Aug., 1868, from which date he was employed in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating city magistrate, Lucknow; small cause court judge, Lucknow, April, 1873, to March, 1882, also serving as registrar, Lucknow, from Sept., 1873; member of commission appointed to inquire into the rights and privileges in Oudh forests, 1876; on special duty at Naini Tal, July, 1878; deputed to inquire into mortality statistics of the Rohilkund division, Nov., 1878; deputy director of agriculture and commerce for Oudh, June, 1882, and for N.W. Provinces and Oudh, July, 1886; deputy commissioner, June, 1887.

PITMAN, Charles Edward, C.I.E., F.R.G.S., M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as assistant superintendent, 16th Jan., 1868; arrived in India, March, 1868, and served on various lines; on special duty in connexion with Lushai expedition, Sept., 1871, and with the Hasan Abdal camp of exercise, 1872-3, and on the Jacobabad-Quetta line, Oct., 1876; with Southern Afghanistan field force, Nov., 1878-9; C.I.E., 1879; Superintendent, April, 1880; held charge of various divisions, class iv., 2nd grade, April, 1889; officiating director, construction branch, June, 1890.

PITT, Alfred Thomas, Madras, C.S.—Educated at Derby School and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

PITTAR, Charles William Erskine, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Dacca, Nov., 1884; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Feb., 1889.

PLACE, George William, B.A., L.L.B., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1875, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; from Jan., 1886, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Feb., 1888; 1st grade, Aug., 1888; has officiated as magistrate and collector and district and sessions judge.

PLANCK, Charles, F.R.C.S., F.S.S., Surgeon-General.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 4th Aug., 1855; arrived in India, 21st Feb., 1856, and served under the military department till June, 1859; civil assistant surgeon, Fatehgarh, July, 1859; superintendent, central prison, Agra, Feb., 1862; inspector-general of prisons, British Burma, Oct., 1864; sanitary commissioner and compiler of mortuary returns, N.W. Provinces, April, 1868, also in Oudh, April, 1877; also superintendent-general of vaccination, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Aug., 1881; retired, Aug. 1886.

PLANT, William Charles, Colonel, M.S.C.—Joined the Madras army as ensign, and arrived in India, 9th June, 1855; served in the Burma commission from March, 1860, as assistant magistrate of Rangoon, assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and officiated at various times as commissioner in the Arakan, Pegu, Tenasserim, and Irrawaddy divisions; appointed commissioner, Tenasserim, Sept., 1883.

PLAYFAIR, Archibald Lewis, Major-Gen., B.S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, Aug., 1856; arrived 22nd Nov., 1856; during the mutiny served at the Alam Bagh, and siege and capture of Lucknow (medal and clasp); served with the Hyderabad contingent, 1862-1873; served subsequently in civil employ as cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; superintendent of central jail, and penitentiary, Hazareebagh, March, 1874; cantonment magistrate, Neemuch, 1878; cantonment magistrate, Morar, 1879-84, and subsequently at Mhow; retired, Feb., 1887.

PLOWDEN, Charles Henry, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Feb., 1854; arrived in India, 28th April, 1854; was employed under the military department till May, 1860, including service in the mutiny, 1858-9; served from May, 1860, in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, in 1867-68, and was appointed commissioner of excise, inspector-general of registration, and superintendent of stamps, Sept., 1880, and deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Nov., 1884; 1st class, Sept., 1889.

PLOWDEN, George Ward Chichele, Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India, as cornet, Bengal light cavalry, 4th April, 1854; was employed under the military department till Sept., 1874, including service in the mutiny campaign; present at the siege and capture of Delhi, the relief of Lucknow, Cawnpore, &c. (medal and three clasps); from Sept., 1874, served in the N.W. Provinces as cantonment magistrate of Bareilly, and subsequently of Meerut; promoted to 1st class cantonment magistrate, March, 1876.

PLOWDEN, Sir Henry M. Kt. (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Punjab.—Served in the Punjab from 17th March, 1871, as government advocate and officiating judge of the chief court; confirmed as judge, chief court, Jan., 1878; knighted, Feb., 1887.

PLOWDEN, Trevor John Chichele, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1868; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Nov., 1868; on special duty
in the Bengal secretariat, March, 1872, and Jan., 1873; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1872; officiating under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1873; inspector-general of police, Assam, Nov., 1876; on special duty as secretary to the prison conference, Jan., 1877; acted as under secretary, government of India, foreign department, from Jan., 1877, and was confirmed in that appointment, Dec., 1878; resident, 2nd class, and political agent, Turkish Arabia, March, 1880; consul-general, Baghdad, June, 1880; made a tour on Turco-Persian frontier, June-Sept., 1881; visited Karbala and Najaf, Nov., 1881, and Samara, Takrit, and the Upper Tigris, in April, 1885; commissioner of Ajmere-Merwara, June, 1885; resident in Meywar, Nov., 1885; officiating resident in Kashmir, April, 1886; confirmed, Nov., 1887; commissioner, Hyderabad assigned districts, Nov., 1888.

PLOWDEN, Sir William Chichele, K.C.S.I., F.S.S., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College, 1852; arrived in India, 29th Sept., 1852; from Nov., 1853, served in the revenue and judicial department in the N.W. Provinces, Oudh, and Punjab; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1858, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1863; secretary, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, July, 1864; on special duty on the census report, April, 1866, and again, May, 1872; magistrate and collector, March, 1870; civil and sessions judge, March, 1877; on special duty at Calcutta as president of census committee, Jan., 1878; commissioner, Meerut division, Sept., 1879; officiating member, board of revenue, Aug., 1880; census commissioner for India, March, 1881; additional member, governor-general's council, Dec., 1881; retired, July, 1885; M.P. for Wolverhampton (West), since 1886.

POLLEN, Arthur Daniel, B.A., LL.D., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting remembrancer of legal affairs; on special duty as joint sessions judge at Surat, Aug., 1878; special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, Jan., 1880; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Jan., 1884; 1st grade judge, Feb., 1886.

POLLEN, John, B.A., LL.D., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 22nd Oct., 1871, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting railway magistrate; on famine relief duty, Dinagapore, Bengal, March, 1874, and in Khandesh in 1878; on special settlement duty, March, 1879; acting under secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, and educational departments, Dec., 1880; assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration and stamps in Sind, April, 1881; also Sind translator to government, Nov., 1881; acting collector and magistrate, Hyderabad, May, 1887; on special duty in connection with Zamindari rights, Shikarpur, Dec., 1887.

POLLOCK, Sir Frederick Richard, Major-General, K.C.S.I.—Educated at King's College School; appointed an Indian cadet of infantry, June, 1844; assistant resident, Lahore, Nov., 1847; on the Sikh outbreak in 1848 accompanied the Ferozepore column to Mooltan as political officer, and served during the double siege of Mooltan, under Sir H. Edwardes (medal and clasp); assistant commissioner in charge of Kohat district, April, 1849, and afterwards at Peshawur and Bannu; employed in the expedition under Sir Charles Napier against the Affreedecees in the Kohat Pass, 1850 (medal and clasp); civil and political officer with the expedition against the Omurzye Wuzecerces; deputy commissioner, Dera Ghazi Khan, March, 1854, and afterwards at Rawul Pindi; accompanied Brigadier-General Chamberlain's expedition to the Border Hills as civil officer, 1857; commissioner and superintendent, Peshawur, 1867; political commissioner with the Hazara field force, 1868; employed in Afghanistan and Persia with the Seistan Commission, 1871-72; commissioner of Peshawur up to 1878; retired from the army, May, 1879.

POLLOCK, George D., Store Department, India Office.—Examiner of surgical instruments, store depot, Oct., 1857.

PONNUSWAMI PILLAI, Tiru Venkata, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from the 15th April, 1854, in various subordinate posts in the public works, military, and judicial departments, and was appointed 1st grade district munshi, April, 1866, principal sudr amin, July, 1872, and sub judge, June, 1874; from May, 1880, acted as presidency magistrate for the town of Madras, and was confirmed in this appointment, Aug., 1883; board of examiners, June, 1884; judge of the court of small causes, Madras, March, 1885.

PONTIFEX, Charles, Legal Adviser, India Office.—B.A., Trinity College, Cambridge, 1854, called to the bar, May, 1854; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, May, 1872; retired in 1882 on appointment as legal adviser to secretary of state for India.

POPE, J. Van Someren, M.A. (Cantab.), Education Department, Bengal.—Joined the service, 17th June, 1876, and served as professor at the Patna and Presidency Colleges, and as principal, Dacca College, Oct., 1881, and was promoted to 3rd class, education department, April, 1883; inspector of schools, April, 1884; fellow of the Calcutta University, March, 1886; appointed director of public instruction in Burma, April, 1889.

POPE, Richard Rodney, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Oratory School, Edgbaston, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1879; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, transferred to Assam as assistant commissioner, April, 1885; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1890; has also acted as district and sessions judge.

POPERT, Edwin Philip, Forest Department, Burma.—Arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1872, and appointed assistant conservator of forests; deputy conservator of forests, 5th July, 1880; conservator of forests, 3rd class, March, 1887.

PORTEOUS, Alexander, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 16th Jan., 1879; served in Assam as assistant commissioner.
and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, May, 1890.

PORTEOUS, Charles Arkcoll, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Arrived, 26th Nov., 1856; ensign, 1st regiment of native infantry, Madras, Dec., 1856; was employed in the suppression of the mutiny, and was present at several engagements, 1857-1859 (medal and two clasps); served in the Madras police department from May, 1860, as assistant superintendent, and superintendent; in charge of the Madras police at the Imperial assemblage, Delhi, Dec., 1876; deputy inspector-general, July, 1883; acting inspector-general, April, 1887; acting inspector-general of Jails, Oct., 1888, confirmed, Jan., 1889; acting inspector-general of police, Feb., 1890.

PORTEOUS, William, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the High School, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and political agent; from Jan., 1874, to April, 1878, served in Mysore as assistant commissioner, acting town and cantonment magistrate, and acting deputy commissioner, also acting as deputy inspector-general of police, July-Oct., 1876, and assistant sessions judge, Oct., 1877-March, 1878; from April, 1878, served in the Bombay presidency as assistant collector and acting collector and magistrate; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1879; acting collector of salt revenue, Bombay, July to Nov., 1881, and Feb.-Nov., 1882; junior collector and magistrate, Kaira, and political agent, Cambay, Nov., 1886; senior collector, April, 1890.

PORTER, Alexander, Deputy Surgeon-Gen., M.D., F.R.C.S.I., M.R.I.A., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1865, and served under the military department in the Central Provinces, also holding the civil surgeoncy of Akola, with charge of the jail, from May, 1866, to April, 1874, and acting as sanitary commissioner, Berar, 1870-71; from April, 1874, served in Madras, and acted as fort surgeon and professor of anatomy and physiology in the Medical College, and as chemical examiner to government, and professor of chemistry and hygiene, March, 1876, to Jan., 1877; surgeon-major, March, 1877; from Jan., 1877, served as surgeon, 4th district, Madras, and also as professor of medical jurisprudence in the Medical College; fellow of Madras University, March, 1883; principal and professor of medicine, Medical College, Dec., 1886; author of 'Notes on the Pathology of Famine Diseases.'

PORTER, Fortescue Willoughby, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Felstead Grammar School, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from March, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from March, 1869, to 1878, served in the settlement department, and was promoted to settlement officer, 3rd grade, April, 1877; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1881; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1885; magistrate and collector, Nov., 1886.

PORTER, George Edward, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Felstead Grammar School, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 11th Dec., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1874; also served as inspector of schools, Feb., 1866, to Nov., 1868, and as deputy commissioner, wards' estate, Patna, May, 1874, to April, 1875; from April, 1879, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge; and was promoted to 1st grade, Sept., 1884; officiated as judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur, from March, 1884, and was confirmed in that appointment, Oct., 1885; officiating judge, high court, Calcutta, Feb., 1886; retired, Sept., 1887.

PORTER, John Sinclair, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from June, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; deputy commissioner, Lalitpur, Oct., 1874; settlement officer, 2nd grade, Jhansi, Jan., 1876; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, April, 1877; magistrate and collector, Shahjahanpur, April, 1879; acted as opium agent, Benares, May-Aug., 1886, and as commissioner of the Allahabad division, Sept.-Oct., 1886; retired, July, 1889.

PORTER, Leslie Alexander Selim, M.A., L.L.D., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Royal Academical Institution, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Nov., 1878, to Jan., 1883; joint magistrate, April, 1886; settlement officer, and grade, Nov., 1887.

PORTER, Ludovic Charles, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Eton, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1890, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

PORTER, William Ninus, Burma Commission.—Joined the service as inspector of police, Oct., 1870; was appointed assistant district superintendent, April, 1875, and district superintendent, Jan., 1880; was appointed assistant commissioner, April, 1886.

PORTMAN, Augustus Berkeley, Bombay S.C., late Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 11th April, 1866, and was employed on military duties till May, 1866, and subsequently served in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent, district superintendent, and superintendent of railway police on the Bombay, Baroda and C.I. and Great Indian Peninsula railways; on special duty, Bombay, Feb.-March, 1874; acting inspector-general of registration and stamps, March to June, 1879, and March, 1880, to Sept., 1883; promoted to 1st grade superintendent of police, Jan., 1885; retired, Dec., 1890.

POSFORD, Joseph, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Finchley, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil
service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1869; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1883; district and sessions judge, Aug., 1883.

POTTINGER, Brabazon Henry, Major-General, Royal (late Bombay) Artillery, Second Lieutenant, 12th Dec., 1857.—Secretary to government of Bombay in the military marine and ecclesiastical departments, 10th June, 1887; had acted as such, Oct. and Nov., 1882, and from Sept., 1883, to Feb., 1885.

POULTON, Henry D., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Junior examiner, 26th Dec., 1873.

POWER, Ambrose William Bushe (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated in Germany, and at Kingstown School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, deputy commissioner and political agent, Hill Tipperah; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, January, 1880; officiating magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Shahabad, March, 1885; confirmed, Aug., 1887; officiating as commissioner in the Dacca division, April, 1890.

POWER, Guy Francis Thomas, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Somersetshire College, Bath, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting principal assistant; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Oct., 1884; additional sessions judge in the agency tracts of Vizagapatam, May, 1885; principal assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1888; sub-collector and joint magistrate, May, 1890; has acted as collector and magistrate.

POWLETT, Percy William, C.S.I., Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 58th native infantry, Bengal, April, 1855; during the mutiny, 1857-58, served at the siege and capture of Lucknow and other operations (medal and clasps); assistant commissioner, Punjab, 1862; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Berar, 1865; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, 1866; settlement officer, Ulwar, Jan., 1871; political agent, Kota, Jan., 1877; political agent for the Western Rajputana states, 1880; resident, Western Rajputana, Dec., 1881. C.S.I., Jan., 1891.

PRATT, Edward Millard, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Dulwich College and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1886; assistant to collector, Nov., 1887.

PRATT, James, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen, and London Universities; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th Oct., 1869; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, January, 1883; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1883.

PRATT, William Dering, Police Department, Bengal.—Joined the service as assistant superintendent of police, 6 Sep., 1863; appointed district superintendent, Aug., 1868; acted as personal assistant to inspector-general in 1877 and 1878; 1st grade, district superintendent, March, 1889; has officiated as deputy inspector-general.

PREECE, H. C., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, Dec., 1885.

PRENDERGAST, General Sir Harry North Dalrymple, K.C.B., V.C.—Entered the service as 2nd lieutenant 8th June, 1854, colonel in 1875, major-general in 1882, general in 1887; served in the Persian war in 1857 (medal with clasp), with the Malwa field force in 1857, with the Central India field force in 1858 (medal with clasp and Victoria cross), in the Abyssinian war 1867-68 (medal); in command of sappers in the Indian expedition to the Mediterranean, 1878; commanded the expedition that resulted in the annexation of Upper Burma in 1885-86 (clasp); has received the distinguished service reward; has held appointments in the department of public works and in the railway department; commanded the Madras sappers and miners for ten years; has acted as quartermaster-general of the Madras army and as secretary to government in the military department; he commanded the western district 1880, and ceded districts 1881, the British Burma division 1883, the Hyderabad subsidiary force 1884, and the forces in Burma in 1885-86; officiated as British resident in Travancore and Cochin in 1887, and as British resident in Mysore and chief commissioner in Coorg in 1887 and 1888; agent to the governor-general, Baroda, Jan., 1889; officiating resident of the 1st class, and governor-general's agent at Beluchistan, March to Oct., 1889.

PRENDERGAST, Hew Lindsay, Major-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—1st commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1850; arrived in India, 27th Feb., 1853, and served in Burma on military duty, and as executive engineer, Bassein, till Nov., 1854, and subsequently in Madras as assistant engineer; on military duty, Feb., 1855, to Nov., 1857; from Nov., 1857, served in the public works department as garrison engineer, Madras, district engineer, and acting deputy consulting engineer for railways, and was promoted to 1st grade executive engineer, July, 1863; acting controller and auditor, public works accounts, Madras, Jan., 1864; acting consulting engineer for railways, April, 1870; on military duty, May, 1874, to May, 1876; superintending engineer, Oct., 1878; superintendent of works, presidency, July to Oct., 1880, and again in 1881; in charge of Buckingham canal, 1880; superintending engineer, 1st class, April, 1884; officiating chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government, Sept.-Dec., 1885; retired, May, 1887.

PRICE, G., M.D., Surgeon-Major Bengal Opium Department.—Served in the medical department from 29th July, 1875, as civil surgeon and on jail duty; appointed principal assistant to opium agent, Behar, Aug., 1887.
PRICE, JAMES CATTARALL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Nov., 1862, served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; settlement officer, Midnapore, Dec., 1871; also superintendent of survey, March, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; author of 'Notes on the History of Midnapore.'

PRICE, JOHN FREDERICK, Madras, C.S.—University of Melbourne; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and acting district and sessions judge; collector and magistrate, South Arcot, and political agent for Pondicherry, April, 1878; collector and magistrate, Chingleput, Sept., 1878; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; acting director of revenue settlement and agriculture, Madras, April, 1885; acting secretary to government revenue department, Oct., 1885; confirmed, Oct., 1887; acting chief secretary, July, 1888; additional member of legislative council, Oct., 1888; chief secretary to Government of Madras, Nov., 1888.

PRIDEAUX, WILLIAM FRANCIS, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bo. S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Jan., 1860; assistant political resident, Aden, from April, 1864; attached to mission to King Theodore of Abyssinia, March, 1865, and was in captivity at Magdala, July, 1866, to April, 1868; officiated as political agent, Zanzibar, 1873-75; fellow of Bombay University, Jan., 1874; assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1875; officiating political resident, Persian Gulf, 1876-79; political agent, Bhopal, March, 1879; agent to the governor-general with the King of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, Calcutta, Nov., 1880; officiating resident, Eastern Rajputana states, Feb., 1882, to Jan., 1883; appointed in 1887, agent to the governor-general for the affairs of the late King of Oudh, and for the purposes of Act 19 of 1887, and superintendent of political pensions; resident of the 2nd class and resident at Jeypore; acting resident, Kashmir.

PRIEST, HENRY HALSTED, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at the Real-Schule, Marburg; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd December, 1879, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, and acted as registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, July, 1883, to May, 1884; acted as political agent, Bhowani Patna, in 1884 and 1885, and as deputy commissioner, March, 1885; acted as commissioner of excise, &c., 1889 and 1890.

PRINGLE, ROBERT KEITH late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1820; arrived in India, 1821, and served in the Bombay revenue department; superintendent of revenue survey and assessment of the Deccan, 1826; first assistant to collector of Ahmednagar, 1831; sub-collector and magistrate, Sholapur, 1831; acting deputy civil auditor and deputy mint-master, 1838; collector and magistrate, and political agent, Khandeish, Dec., 1840; secretary to government, Bombay, general department, June, 1843; revenue commissioner, July, 1843; chief secretary to government, Bombay, revenue and finance departments, government director of the Bank of Bombay, and master of the mint, April, 1845; acting member of council, Bombay, April, 1846; chief commissioner of Sind, July, 1847; resigned, Feb., 1851.

PRINSEP, HENRY THOBY, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1853; assistant magistrate and collector, Midnapore, Nov., 1856; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, April, 1860; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Sept., 1861; registrar of the Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, Feb., 1862, and subsequently of the high court, July, 1862; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, May, 1866; officiated as superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, May, 1866; served in the judicial department from Feb., 1867, as district and sessions judge, and officiated as judicial commissioner of Mysore, March, 1875, to July, 1876; lieutenant-governor's council; 1st grade district judge, Sept., 1875; judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, July, 1878.

PRITCHARD, CHARLES BRADLEY, C.S.I., Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 24th Jan., 1858, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty at Poona for investigating frauds committed by subordinates in the public works department, Oct., 1870, to Oct., 1871; collector of salt revenue, Bombay presidency, Feb., 1873; on special duty in Madras as president of the salt commission, Jan.-Sept., 1876; on special duty to submit a scheme for the working of the abkari system, May, 1877, to March, 1878; commissioner of customs, opium, abkari, and reporter-general of external commerce, April, 1881; 1st grade commissioner and commissioner of salt revenue, Oct., 1882; C.S.I., March, 1886; acting commissioner in Sind, April, 1887; confirmed Aug., 1888; temporary member of council of governor of Bombay, May, 1889; appointed provisional member of council.

PROPERT, WILLIAM HENRY, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1856, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate and political agent; from Feb., 1876, served as collector and magistrate and political agent, Khandaish; senior collector, Sept., 1877; also acted as commissioner, Northern division, April, 1883; was on special duty, Poona, July-Oct., 1883; commissioner, Southern division, April, 1886; and of Northern division, May, 1889; retired, April, 1890.

PUCKLE, RICHARD KAYE, C.I.E., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Tonbridge School, and Haileybury College; entered the Madras civil service in 1851, and was appointed deputy director of revenue settlement in 1859; collector and magistrate, Tinnevelly, 1866; director of revenue settlement, 1874, and member of board of revenue, 1879; was engaged for 22 years in preparing data for the re-assessment of the lands, and for the revision of government establishments in the ryotwari villages of Madras; published a handbook on revenue matters and the duties of village officers; was specially employed in the dis-
RESSED DISTRICTS IN FAMINE OF 1877; C.I.E., 1878; RETIRED IN 1881.

PULFER, J. W., Store Department, India Office.—Writer, 3rd Aug., 1865; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878; India store depot.

PULLAN, AYRTON, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Arrived in India, 29th April, 1856; first commission as ensign, Bengal infantry, June, 1856; was employed under the military department till April, 1862, including service during the mutiny, and was present at the siege of Delhi (medal and clasp); officiating assistant political agent and bazaar master, Morar, April-June, 1862; joined the great trigonometrical survey as 2nd assistant, Jan., 1863; acted as deputy superintendent from Dec., 1871, and was appointed to the charge of the Kathiawar survey, April, 1873; was afterwards employed in the survey of Cutch; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

PUNNETT, HENRY BEATSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Falmouth Grammar School, and Boston Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Nov., 1886; deputy superintendent, family domains of Maharaja of Benares, April, 1888; has also acted as district and sessions judge.

PURSER, WILLIAM EDWARD, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Enniskillen Royal School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer, and was placed on special duty, May and Dec., 1879; senior settlement officer and deputy commissioner of settlement, Jullundur, Sept., 1880; confirmed as deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Dec., 1885, and as deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1886; retired, Aug., 1890; author of 'Reports on the Settlement of the Montgomery District, and on the Settlements of the Muktsar and Mamdot Parganas.'

PURVES, HENRY BLACK, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—1st commission, 1865; from 12th March, 1867, served as civil assistant surgeon, and civil surgeon, in various stations in Bengal; surgeon-major, Oct., 1877; civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, Aug., 1885; officiating inspector of emigrants, July, 1885; civil surgeon, Patna, and superintendent, Temple Medical School, Oct., 1885; civil surgeon, Howrah, March, 1890.

PUTNAM, P., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 28th July, 1881.

PYCROFT, SIR THOMAS, K.C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School, and Trinity College, Oxford, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1828; served in various offices in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from 1829 to 1839; acting sub-secretary to the board of revenue, Madras, 1843-44; secretary to the board of revenue, 1845-50; secretary to government of Madras in the revenue and judicial departments, 1850-55; chief secretary to government of Madras, 1855-62; member of Madras council, 1862 to 1867, in which year he retired from the service.

QUIN, HENRY OSBORNE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service, after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1883; assistant collector, Jan., 1886.

QUIN, THOMAS JAMES, Jhansi Commission.—1st commission, ensign, 13th April, 1859; from May, 1869, served under the Government of the N.W. Provinces as officiating assistant commissioner, cantonment magistrate, and deputy commissioner, and was confirmed as deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1889; served during the Bhutan campaign of 1865 (medal).

QUINLAN, FRANCIS PETER, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the accounts branch, Oct., 1870, and was employed on the accounts of various railways in the grades of accountant, assistant examiner, assistant controller, and deputy examiner; Northern Bengal state railway, Dec., 1879; acting manager, June-Sept., 1881; promoted to examiner, Sept., 1881; Punjab northern state railway, March, 1883; on special duty, Sept.-Oct., 1883, to revise state railway revenue code; examiner and auditor of accounts, Eastern Bengal state railway, July, 1884; also acted as examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, Aug.-Oct., 1884; examiner, 3rd class, Dec., 1886; acted as examiner East India railway accounts, Oct., 1887.

QUINN, CHARLES CAMPBELL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, 8th Jan., 1864; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1884, and 1st grade, April, 1889; officiating commissioner, Bhagulpore division, March, 1890.

QUINN, JOHN, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from April, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate, and was appointed deputy commissioner, Oudh, April, 1877, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Ballia, Dec., 1881; commissioner, Lucknow division, March, 1884; officiated as judicial commissioner, Oudh, in 1884; retired, March, 1888.

QUINTON, JAMES WALLACE, B.A., C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Enniskillen Royal School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces from Oct., 1857, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; served in Oudh from March, 1865, to April, 1875, as deputy commissioner, and officiated as commissioner, Lucknow division, March, 1869; officiating judicial commissioner, British Burma, April, 1875, to March, 1877; magistrate and collector, Allahabad, April, 1877; officiating civil and sessions judge, April, 1878; on special duty at Nain Tal as member of N.W. Provinces famine commission, July, 1878; commissioner, Jhansi division, April, 1880, and Lucknow division, Feb., 1882; additional member of governor-general's council, Feb., 1883, and again in 1884 and 1886 and 1889; commissioner, Agra division, April, 1884; junior member, board of revenue, March, 1885, and
April, 1889; member of the council of the lieutenant-governor of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and of the Public Service Commission, 1886; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; chief commissioner of Assam, Oct., 1889.

RADICE, CHARLES ALBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1890, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

RADICE, EVASIO HAMPDEN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Bedford school, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service, after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

RAGHUNATH SHIVRAM TIPNIS RAO SAHEB, B.A., LL.B., Bombay C.S.—Born 10th Oct., 1853; having served in the various grades of subordinate judge from July, 1878, was appointed an assistant collector in the Bombay presidency, under the native civil service rules, April, 1887; acting assistant judge and sessions judge.

RAI NUND KISSORE DAS BAHADUR, Bengal C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules; continuing to act as assistant superintendent of the tributary Mehals, Cuttack, 18th Feb., 1890.

RAIKES, FREDERICK DUNCAN, Major, C.I.E., Bombay S.C., Burma Commission.—Arrived in Bombay, as ensign, H.M.'s 66th regiment, 1st April, 1870; acted as superintendent of bazaars and commissariat officer, Hyderabad, Sind, 1871; Bombay staff corps, Feb., 1873; acting assistant superintendent of police, Panch Mehals, March, 1873; from May, 1873, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, and acted as assistant town magistrate, Rangoon, 1874-75; transferred to Upper Burma, Feb., 1886; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1886; officiating commissioner, central division, Feb., 1888; additional sessions judge, Dec., 1888, and on special duty with the Chin field force; served in the Burmese campaign, 1885-7 (medal and clasp).

RAJGOPALA CHARI, PERUNGAVUR, Madras C.S.—Madras University; served in the judicial department from 13th May, 1886; deputy collector, Dec., 1887; appointed by government of India probationer for civil service, 10th Jan., 1888; served as assistant to collector and magistrate; and was confirmed in the Madras civil service, May, 1890.

RAJANINATH RAY, M.A., Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, and was attached to the office of the comptroller-general, Nov., 1872; served in the Central Provinces, May, 1874, to Jan., 1876, and afterwards in Bombay as assistant to the commissioner of paper currency, and assistant to the accountant-general; assistant comptroller-general, Nov., 1882; classiv., financial department, April, 1885; has also served as deputy accountant-general, Bombay, Aug.-Nov., 1885, and in Bengal, March, 1886; deputy comptroller-general, April to June, 1887; officiating deputy accountant-general, Bombay, Jan., 1888; assistant comptroller-general, Nov., 1888; deputy accountant-general, March, 1889.

RAJARATHNA MUDALIYAR, P., RAI BAHADUR, Madras Revenue Department.—Born Dec., 1839; served in the salt department, from Oct., 1860; Tahsildar, May, 1866; deputy collector salt revenue, May, 1877; head Sarishtadar, board of revenue, Aug., 1882; member of committee on Draft Tenancy Bill, July, 1885; secretary to the commissioner of revenue settlement, and director of the department of land records and agriculture, Nov., 1887.

RAJENDRA CHANDRA CHANDRA, Brigade-Surgeon, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1858; from July, 1863, served as civil assistant surgeon, also officiating as sub-assistant commissioner, Deogurh, from July, 1864; surgeon-major, Jan., 1870; officiating civil surgeon, Midnapore, July, 1874; professor of materia medica and clinical medicine, Medical College, Calcutta, and ex-officio 2nd physician to the College Hospital, Feb., 1875; was also appointed surgeon to the mint and officer of the customs preventive service, Jan., 1878, and medical inspector of emigrants, May, 1881; has also officiated as principal medical college, Calcutta.

RAMACHANDRA AIYAR, CUDDALORE, Madras C.S.—Served in the judicial department, Madras, from 10th Jan., 1860; district munshi, March 1866; sub-judge, Nov., 1880; 4th presiding magistrate, Madras, March, 1885; appointed by government of India to be assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1887; sub-collector and joint magistrate, March, 1889; has acted as district and sessions judge.

RAMACHANDRA RAOPANAMALAI, B.L., Madras, C.S.—Served in the education department, 1864-1867, and from Feb., 1868, in various subordinate posts under the revenue department; assistant to deputy superintendent of census operations, Madras, April, 1881; acting personal assistant to commissioner of salt revenue, 1882-1885; appointed by the government of India to be assistant collector and magistrate in the Madras Presidency, Dec., 1885.

RAMACHANDRA RAO R., Madras, C.S.—Appointed by the Government of India, probationer under the native civil service rules, 13th June, 1890, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

RAMA SHANKAR MISRA PANDIT, M.A. (Calcutta University), Bengal C.S.—Officiating professor of mathematics, Benares College, Feb., 1877, resigned Jan., 1878, rejoined as professor, Agra College, 23rd Aug., 1879; appointed under the native civil service rules assistant magistrate and collector, 29th Dec., 1887; author of a 'Treatise on Mensuration' in Hindi, and a 'Manual of Rent and Revenue Law.'

RAM AUTAR PANDE PANDIT (Calcutta University), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Joined the service as officiating deputy collector, 13th March, 1884; appointed by the Government of India assistant magistrate and collector under the statutory service rules, 12th Feb., 1887.

RAMESHWARA SING, RAJA BAHA-DOOR, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules, and served as assistant magistrate and collector on probation in Bengal from March, 1878; confirmed in his appointment in the Bengal civil service, March, 1881; resigned, 1886.

RAMPINI, ROBERT FULTON, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Academy, Institution, and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 28th Nov., 1864;
served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1880, district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, July, 1880, and officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, April, 1883; also served as officiating inspector of schools, Sept., 1873; district and sessions judge, Burdwan, April 1887; edited Bengal Tenancy Act (VIII.) of 1885; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Sept., 1887; acting judge of high court, Calcutta, April, 1888, March, 1889, and March, 1890.

RAMSAY, Hon. Sir Henry, General, K.C.S.I., C.B., Bengal S.C.—First commission, Bengal infantry, June, 1834; from Aug., 1840, served as junior assistant to commissioner in Kumaon; senior assistant to commissioner in Gharwal, Nov., 1845; served in the Punjab campaign of 1848-49 (medal); commissioner, Kumaon, Feb., 1856 to 1884.

RAMSAY, Henry Lushington, Captain, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Sub-lieutenant, Feb., 1874; served with the 6th royal regiment at Sialkot, and subsequently with 9th Bengal cavalry; acted as assistant to agent to governor-general, Rajputana, Dec., 1877, to March, 1878; junior attaché, foreign department, March, 1878; political officer on staff of Major-General Sir F. S. Roberts with the Kuram field force, Sept., 1879; present at defence of Sherpur (medal and clasp); senior attaché, foreign department, June, 1880; acted as assistant secretary, foreign department, June-July, 1880; assistant to agent, governor-general, Rajputana, Oct., 1880; magistrate at Abu, and assistant general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti department, Nov., 1880; assistant agent, Beloouchistan, June, 1882, to May, 1883; consul at Basra, May-Oct., 1883; cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, Nov., 1883; British joint commissioner of Ladakh, Sept., 1885.

RAMSAY, Herbert Maynard, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Infantry.—First commission, 1860; from 2nd July, 1863, served in the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, district superintendent, and personal assistant to the inspector general; on special duty to Cachar, March, 1866; 1st grade district superintendent, April, 1886.

RAMSAY, James, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as assistant engineer, 8th Oct., 1868; executive engineer, March, 1871; served on the Indus valley railway, and had charge of the Nagpur and Chhattisgarh state railway, Nov., 1879; engineer in chief, Indus valley state railway, Nov., 1880, and of the Sind Sagar railway, April, 1886; officiating under-secretary to Government of India, public works department, June, 1887; superintending engineer, Feb., 1890.

RAND, Walter Charles, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Dulwich, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1884.

RANSOM, Henry Edward, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bedford School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service, after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived, 12th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885; transferred to Assam, as assistant commissioner, April, 1889.

RATTON, James Joseph Louis, Surgeon-Major, M.D., M.R.C.S., late Madras Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, 30th Sept., 1867; arrived in India, 16th April, 1868; served in the Abyssinian expedition (medal), and in various military medical charges; also as civil surgeon, Central Provinces, 1869-70; on special duty for the board of revenue, Madras, in connection with salt manufacture, from Jan., 1872, to Nov., 1876 (including one month in South of France); in medical charge of East Coast canal, famine relief works, Dec., 1876; Zillah surgeon and superintendent of jail, Chittoor, April, 1877; surgeon-major, Sept., 1879; acting president, board of medical examiners, Oct., 1884; surgeon, General Hospital, Madras, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery in the Medical College, Feb., 1885; acting principal, Medical College, and senior physician, General Hospital, Aug.-Sept., 1885; member of salt committee, Feb., 1886; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886; retired, Jan., 1888; besides official reports on salt manufacture, &c., has published a 'Handbook on Common Salt,' a 'Treatise on Tetanus,' and a 'Syllabus of Surgery.'

RAVENSCROFT, Edward W., C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at King Henry VIIIth Grammar School, Ottery St. Mary, and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bombay civil service, 1851; arrived in India, 25th May, 1851; served as assistant collector and magistrate at Surat and Ahmedabad, and was placed on special duty under the settlement officer in Guzerat to inquire into alienations, Oct., 1855; was specially appointed acting collector and magistrate of Surat in 1860, to carry out provisions of income tax law; inspector-in-chief under the Cotton Frauds Act, Bombay, Feb., 1864; president of the municipal commission, Bombay, June, 1864; officiating chief secretary to the government of Bombay, in the revenue, financial, and general departments, 1864, and acted in that appointment at intervals till 1877, when he was confirmed in the same; collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, March, 1868; additional member of council, Bombay, March, 1871, and again, March, 1873; collector of salt revenue, Oct., 1871; senior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, Dec., 1871, and subsequently of Colaba; on special duty as member of the Baroda commission to investigate the charges brought against the Gaekwar; member of governor's council, Bombay, April, 1879; retired, March, 1884.

RAVENSHAW, Charles Withers, Captain, B.S.C., Berar.—First commission, 8th May, 1872; served in the military department, and from Dec., 1875, officiated as assistant cantonment magistrate at various places; from Feb., 1877, served under the foreign department as assistant political agent, and officiating political assistant; on special boundary duty in 1879-80; from Feb., 1880, served under military department in Afghan war (medal), and from Sept., 1880, under the foreign department as superintendent of Rajputana railway police; officiating political assistant and assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India; assistant commissioner, Merwara, Dec., 1885; 1st assistant political resident, Persian Gulf, July, 1887; cantonment magistrate and judge, small cause court, Berar, May, 1890.

RAWLINS, Thomas William, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Clare
College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1863; from Jan., 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; small cause court judge and subordinate judge, Allahabad, Nov., 1872; from March, 1877, served under the government of India in the financial department as officiating accountant-general, Punjab, and deputy commissioner of paper currency, and was confirmed in this appointment, Aug., 1880; also held substantively, while officiating in the Punjab, the posts of assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, and deputy accountant-general, Madras; officiated as accountant-general, 1st grade, and commissioner of paper currency, Bombay, from March, 1885; accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency, Madras, Oct., 1888.

RAWLINSON, Sir Henry Creswicke, Bart., Major-General, G.C.B., F.R.S.—Educated at Ealing School; served in the Bombay army, 1827 to 1833, and in Persia from Nov., 1833, to Dec., 1839; major in Persia, 1836; political agent at Kandahar, June, 1840; political agent in Turkish Arabia, 1843; consul, Bagdad, March, 1844; military C.B., and K.L.S., 1st class, 1844; consul-general, 1851-55; lieutenant-colonel in Turkey, 1851; director of the East India Company and civil K.C.B., 1856; retired from Indian service as lieutenant-colonel, 1856; member of the council of India, Sept., 1858, to April, 1859, when he was sent as envoy to the court of Teheran with local rank of major-general; member for Reigate in the liberal interest, Feb.–Sept., 1858, and for Frome, 1865-68; reappointed to the council of the secretary of state for India, 1868; is hon. D.C.L. of Oxford, and LL.D. of Cambridge and Edinburgh, a chevalier of the 'Order of Merit' in Prussia, and associate member of the French Institute, and academy of Munich, &c.; author of papers on the antiquities of the east, and on the interpretation of the cuneiform inscriptions of Persia, Assyria, and Babylonia, in the journals of the Geographical and Asiatic Societies; also of 'England and Russia in the East: a series of papers on the Political and Geographical Condition of Central Asia,' 1875; trustee of the British Museum, March, 1878; created a baronet 1st Jan., 1891.

RAWSON, Edward Creswell, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rossall School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Jan., 1889.

RAYE, Daniel O'Connell, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1866; from 1st Sept., 1875, served as first resident surgeon, Presidency General Hospital, also acting as civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, and as surgeon-superintendent of the General Hospital, Jan., 1877, and also held temporary medical charge of the Alipore and Russa jails, Nov., 1879; officiating professor of surgical and descriptive anatomy, Medical College, and ex-officio 2nd surgeon to the College Hospital, Jan., 1880; confirmed in this appointment, May, 1881; also medical examiner of candidates for the public service, Feb., 1880; officiating professor of surgery, Medical College, and ex-officio 1st surgeon, College Hospital, May, 1884.

REAY (Baron), Right Hon. Donald James MacKay, LL.D., G.C.S.I., G.C.I.E.—Took his seat as governor of Bombay, 30th March, 1885; G.C.S.I., March, 1890; returned to Europe, April, 1890; was lord rector of the University of St. Andrew's, 1894.

REDFERN, Thomas Robert, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at New College, Oxford; called to the Bar at the Inner Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1886; arrived in India, 2nd Oct., 1870; served in Oudh, and was appointed assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1870; officiating junior secretary to chief commissioner, Aug., 1872; officiating settlement officer, Kheri, 1875; assistant commissioner, and grade, Feb., 1881; also served as officiating district and sessions judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate, 1st grade, May, 1883; district and sessions judge, Sept., 1887.

REED, J. H. F., Accounts Department, India Office.—B.A., London University; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872; junior clerk, June, 1887.

REES, Frederick William Joseph, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 11th Jan., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, July, 1869; also officiating collector of income tax, Sept., 1871; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, April, 1878; from Dec., 1880, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge; 1st grade, Jan., 1885; retired, Dec., 1887.

REES, John David, C.I.E., F.R.G.S., M.R.A.S., Madras C.S.—Educated at King's College School, London, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting deputy registrar of the high court, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; from April, 1882, to Dec., 1884, served in the Madras secretariat as assistant secretary in the judicial and legislative departments, under secretary in the revenue department, Telugu and Tamil translator to government, acting private secretary to the governor (July-Oct., 1884), and acting under secretary in the chief secretary's department; from Dec., 1884, to March, 1885, served in Mysore as acting civil and sessions judge; served subsequently in Madras as under secretary to government in the chief secretary's department; Persian and Hindustani translator to government, Sept., 1885, to March, 1886; private secretary to the governor of Madras, Dec., 1886; fellow of Madras University, March, 1887; fellow of the Royal Geographical Society, and member of the Royal Asiatic Society and of the Société de Géographie de France; on special duty in connexion with visit of H.R.H. Prince Albert Victor, Nov., 1889, to Feb., 1890, C.I.E., May, 1890; appointed collector and magistrate and sessions judge, Aug., 1890, continuing to act as private
secretary; author of 'Notes of a Journey from Kasween to Hamadan in North-West Persia,' 1885 (published by order of government), also of papers on Persia, China, and Corea, communicated to various reviews and periodicals.

REID, GEORGE BOILEAU, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty to take up land for the Khadakvasla lake, Oct., 1869; first assistant collector, July, 1878; on special duty as settlement officer at Baroda, June, 1879, and Sept., 1882; junior collector and magistrate, Broach, March, 1886; collector and magistrate, and district registrar, Khandish, April, 1883; senior collector, May, 1889.

REID, JAMES ROBERT, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1860; from Aug., 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating deputy commissioner in Oudh; from Aug., 1868, to April, 1877, served as assistant settlement officer, and settlement officer, Azamgarh; magistrate and collector, Jan., 1878; member of committee for considering revised rules for Patwaris and Kanungos, Nov., 1880; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1883; chief secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, May, 1884; commissioner, Kumaon division, Nov. 1888; member of board of revenue, Feb., 1890; C.I.E., May, 1890.

REID, JOHN WILLIAM (Barrister-at-Law), late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served from July, 1856, in the revenue and judicial department, Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; from June, 1869, served in the judicial department in the district of Malabar as civil and sessions judge; district and sessions judge, Coimbatore, Oct., 1884; retired, 1886.

REILLY, C. H. (Barrister-at-Law).—Advocate of high court, Calcutta; assistant secretary, legislative department, government of Bengal; sub pro tem. chief presidency magistrate, Calcutta, judge of the court for the trial of pilots, and judge of the court of survey for the port of Calcutta, in 1885.

REILLY, Henry Maxwell, late Police Department, Bengal.—From May, 1853, to July, 1863, served as deputy magistrate and deputy collector; from July, 1863, served in the police department, and was appointed district superintendent, 1st grade, Dec., 1882; on special duty, Garo Hills expedition, Nov., 1872; retired, 1890.

RENDEL, Sir Alexander Meadows, K.C.I.E.—Educated at King's School, Canterbury, and Trinity College, Cambridge (scholar and wrangler); studied as a civil engineer, and in 1856 became engineer to the London Dock Company, the Leith Harbour and Dock Commissioners, the East Indian Railway, and other companies; visited India in 1857-58, and on various occasions; built the Shadwell new basin, the Royal Albert Dock, and other works on the Thames; the Albert and Edinburgh Docks at Leith, the Workington Dock and Harbour, and other works; member of the commission appointed by the secretary of state for India in 1870, to determine the narrow gauge for Indian railways; is consulting engineer to the secretary of state for India, and to the East Indian, and other Indian railway companies; designed the Sukkur bridge over the Indus (opened, 1889); member of the institution of civil engineers.

RENDELL, Alan Wood, late Public Works Department, Bengal.—Arrived in India, March, 1874; joined the department as locomotive superintendent, Northern Bengal state railway, 8th Nov., 1877; surveyor of government steamers of the Northern Bengal and Tirhoot railways; locomotive superintendent of north-eastern system of state railways, June, 1881; class I, grade 3, of state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1882; locomotive superintendent, Eastern Bengal state railway, July, 1884; 1st class, 2nd grade, April, 1887; retired, 1890.

RENNICK, Albert De Clancy, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, 6th July, 1864; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1866; from Oct., 1870, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating cantonment and camp magistrate; cantonment magistrate, 1st class, Dec., 1880; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, June, 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, May, 1889.

RENNICK, Henry De Parney, Colonel, B.S.C., Hyderabad Administration.—1st commission, 5th Aug., 1859; served on regimental duty, and was admitted to staff corps, June, 1867; joined Berar commission, April, 1869, and was appointed assistant commissioner, May, 1873; deputy commissioner, April, 1889; served in the China campaign, 1860-61; and in the Abyssinian expedition, 1867 (medal).

RENNIELL, Henry de Parny, Lieutenant-Colonel B.S.C., Berar Administration.—Ensign 44th regt., Aug., 1859; served in the China campaign of 1860-1, and the Abyssinian expedition, 1867 (medal); admitted to Bengal staff corps, June, 1867; joined the Berar commission, April, 1869, and served as assistant commissioner, and from April, 1889, as deputy commissioner.

RENNIE, John George Mackworth, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Winchester, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1881, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating district judge.

RENNY, Robert Home, Bengal Commission.—Served in the executive department from 12th Nov., 1864, as deputy magistrate and deputy collector and assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, April, 1866.

RENOUF, Winter Charles, Bengal C.S., Punjab.—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1889, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

REPTON, Herbert Mills, Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—Arrived in India, 3rd June, 1854; was employed under the military department up to 1862, including service during the Mutiny 1857-58, and in the Bundelcund campaign, 1859 (medal); from May, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces and Ajmere as assistant commissioner and deputy commissi...
sioner; on famine duty, 1870; from July, 1877, served in the Central Provinces, and was appointed deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Sept., 1883.
