REYNOLDS, CHARLES HENRY, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as assistant superintendent, 7th Jan., 1868; arrived in India, 13th May, 1868; personal assistant to director-general, April, 1870, and 1872; in charge of famine division, April, 1874; attached to director-general's office for various periods, and in April, 1886, appointed superintendent; delegate for India at the International Telegraph Conference of Berlin, Aug.–Sept., 1885; has held charge of various divisions; director, class 3, in charge of construction branch, July, 1889; charge of traffic branch, Jan., 1890.

REYNOLDS, EDWARD SWATMAN, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department.—Joined the service (Bombay infantry), Oct., 1859; served with the Scinde horse, 1863–77; assistant superintendent and magistrate, Upper Scinde Frontier, 1871–77; assistant to agent to governor-general, Beloochistan, 1877; political agent in Pishin, 1883; political agent at Jacobabad, April, 1883; on special duty to Mekran as member of a court of enquiry to investigate Rind and Gwadar disputes, Feb.–April, 1885; deputed to Gwadar in connection with that matter, Feb., 1886; political agent, 1st class.

REYNOLDS, HERBERT JOHN, C.S.I., B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1856; from March, 1857, to July, 1874, served as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, superintendent of survey, and magistrate and collector (1st grade, June, 1872); between 1874 and 1880 served as secretary to the government of Bengal, general and revenue departments, and as secretary to the board of revenue; additional member, governor-general's council, Jan., 1880, and again in 1882 and 1884; officiating member, board of revenue, June, 1880; officiating president, board of examiners, Dec., 1880; lieutenant-governor's council, Jan., 1881; and again Jan., 1883, and Jan., 1885; board of revenue, July, 1884; member of lieutenant governor's council, Jan., 1885, and Jan., 1887, chairman of port commissioners, Calcutta, Oct., 1887; retired, April, 1889.

REYNOLDS, HERBERT WILLIAM WARD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; second assistant secretary to Government, July, 1880; junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1883; officiating deputy superintendent, family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, May–Oct., 1884; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Aug., 1887; 1st grade, Nov., 1889; has also acted as district and sessions judge.

RHIND, ROBERT HUNTER, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed probationer by the secretary of state, June, 1862; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1862; served as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and officiating superintendent of works on the Upper Godavary works till Aug., 1872, when he was transferred to Bengal, and served in the Orissa, Sone, and South-Western circles; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1873; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Nov., 1886; 1st class, June, 1889.

RHODES, FRANCIS WILLIAM, Colonel, 1st Royal Dragoons, military secretary to the governor of Bombay.—1st commission, Lieut., 23rd April, 1875; Major, Sept., 1885; Colonel, Sept., 1889; served in the Soudan expedition in 1884 under Sir Gerald Graham as aide-de-camp to Sir Herbert Stewart, and was present at engagements of El Teb and Tamai (medal with clasp and Khedive's star); served in Nile expedition of 1884–5, and in the operations near Suakin, Dec., 1888 (3rd class of the Medjidie); appointed military secretary to Lord Harris, Governor of Bombay, 1890.

RIBBENTROP, B., C.I.E., Forest Department, Government of India.—Appointed by the secretary of state for India as an assistant conservator of forests, Dec., 1866; conservator of forests, Burma, Oct., 1876; 2nd grade conservator, Sept., 1882; transferred to Punjab, 1883; inspector-general of forests; author of 'Hints on Arboriculture.'

RICE, WILLIAM GEORGE LEWIS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Oscott College, and Jesus College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; transferred to Burma, Feb., 1886, as assistant commissioner.

RICE, WILLIAM ROCHE, Surgeon-General, M.D.—Joined the Bengal medical service, Nov., 1856; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1857; was employed under the military department, including service during the Mutiny, at Indore (medal); civil assistant surgeon, Central Provinces, June, 1859; civil surgeon, Jubbulpore, May, 1871; acting assistant to sanitary commission, Central Provinces, July, 1872; superintendent, central jail, Jubbulpore, April, 1873; surgeon-major, Nov., 1876; civil surgeon and in medical charge of central jail, school of industry, and lunatic asylum, and superintendent, meteorological observatory, Jubbulpore, July, 1879; brigade-surgeon, April, 1884; officiating inspector-general of civil hospitals, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1887; and confirmed in the appointment, Oct., 1887; deputy surgeon-general, Oct., 1887; sanitary commissioner and surgeon-general to Government of India, March, 1890.

RICHARD, HENRY JOSEPH, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, July, 1868, and arrived in India, Oct., 1868; assistant engineer, Rangoon, 28th Oct., 1868; served in various divisions in Burma, and was appointed executive engineer, April, 1875; had charge of Rangoon division, May–Dec., 1879; served with the Burma expeditionary force, Mandalay, 1885–6; superintendent of works, Upper Burma, Jan., 1886; superintending engineer, Sept., 1889.

RICHARDSON, JOHN, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.B., M.A., Medical Department, Central Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th July, 1859; arrived in India, 23rd Feb., 1860, and was employed under the military department up to 1866,
including service with the Bhootan field force (medal and clasp); from April, 1866, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, and officiated as superintendent of the central and district jails at Agra, Farakhabad, and Allahabad; superintendent of vaccination, March, 1867; rank of surgeon, July, 1871; surgeon-major, July, 1874; deputy sanitary commissioner and superintendent of vaccination, 3rd circle, Jan., 1879; sanitary commissioner, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Aug., 1886; deputy surgeon-general, Central Provinces, May, 1889; inspector-general of civil hospitals, March, 1890.

RICHARDSON, THOMAS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Brighton College, Cheltenham College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1886, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

RICHEY, Sir JAMES BELLETT, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived 7th Dec., 1856, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, educational inspector, assistant revenue commissioner, officiating under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, Talukdari settlement officer, acting collector and magistrate, and assistant to the agent and special commissioner at Baroda; on special duty in connection with the disturbances in the Ahmednagar and Poona districts, July, 1875; junior collector and magistrate, Ahmednagar, Jan., 1879; senior collector, May, 1880; collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, May, 1881; on special duty at Khárághoda, Dec., 1883, and Feb., 1884, and at Baroda, Jan., 1884; acting 2nd grade commissioner of customs, March, 1884; acting member of council, Bombay, March, 1885, and again, Oct., 1886; chief secretary to government, political, secret, judicial, educational, and separate departments, May, 1885; confirmed as member of council, Bombay, Aug., 1887; retired, March, 1890; K.C.I.E., May, 1890.

RICKETTS, GEORGE H. M., C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1847; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and as assistant to the governor-general's agent, S.W. frontier; from 1853, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and from 1858 in the N.W. Provinces as magistrate and collector, and civil and sessions judge; C.B. for service in the Punjab in 1857, and medal for service with the troops; commissioner, Allahabad division, 1873; junior member, board of revenue, 1878; retired, 1879.

RICKETTS, MONTAGUE POYNTZ, Colonel, B.S.C., late Central Provinces Commission.—Arrived in India, 22nd March, 1855; served in the Central Provinces from Sept., 1859, as assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, Aug., 1862; deputy commissioner, May, 1867; acting inspector-general of police, Nagpur, in 1876-77; deputy commissioner, 1st class, March, 1880; acting commissioner of the Jubbulpore and Nagpur divisions successively, Dec., 1882, to Nov., 1883; additional commissioner, Central Provinces, Nov., 1883; acting commissioner for various divisions from 1884 to 1888; retired, April, 1890.

RIDDELL, ROBERT VANSITTART, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Mint Department, Calcutta.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1858; lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1859; arrived in India, March, 1861; from Aug., 1862, served in the topographical survey of India as military assistant, and was employed in Gwalior and Central India, and in the Khasi and Garo Hills; deputy superintendent, Oct., 1867; assistant surveyor-general with charge of the mathematical instrument department and workshops, and of the lithographic branch, Calcutta, Oct., 1876; acted as mint master at Calcutta, July-Oct., 1881, and at Bombay, Oct., 1882, to Jan., 1883; appointed mint master, Calcutta, Jan., 1884, and mint master and mint engineer, Bombay, Aug., 1889.

RIDGWAY, The Right Honourable Sir JOSEPH WEST, Colonel, K.C.B., K.C.S.I., late Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bengal infantry, Dec., 1860; on civil employ from May, 1868, in the Central India and Rajputana agencies; attaché, foreign department, government of India, 1873; assistant agent to governor-general in Rajputana, 1875; political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, Aug., 1876; political agent, 3rd class, Aug., 1876; on special political duty with the field force in Afghanistan, under General Sir F. Roberts, 1880, and was present at the action of Saidebad; accompanied General Roberts' force in the march from Kabul to Kandahar, and was present at the battle of Kandahar, Sept., 1880 (medal with clasp, bronze star, brevet lieutenant-colonel); from Sept., 1880, served in the secretariat of the foreign department, and was appointed assistant secretary, Nov., 1880, junior under-secretary, Dec., 1881, and officiated as under-secretary in 1880, 1882, and 1883; from Aug., 1884, served as assistant with the commission for the delimitation of the Afghan frontier, and was appointed Her Majesty's commissioner for this purpose, Sept., 1885; subsequently was Her Majesty's commissioner for this purpose at St. Petersburg, and was promoted to the rank of colonel for his services; returned to Europe, 1887, and was appointed under-secretary for Ireland; retired from the army, 27th Aug., 1889; K.C.B., 1st Jan., 1891.

RIGG, HENRY, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 13th June, 1862, and arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1862; assistant engineer, Feb., 1864; served in various divisions in Madras, and was appointed executive engineer, March, 1868; personal assistant to manager and engineer-in-chief, Rangoon and Sittang valley state railway, Burma, Aug., 1881; on special duty, Upper Burma, Dec., 1885-Jan., 1886; manager and engineer-in-chief, Burma state railway, June, 1889; class I, grade 3, revenue establishment of state railways, June, 1889.

RIGHY, VANS, M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed probationary assistant engineer, Feb., 1856, and served in the Central Provinces, Punjab, and Bengal; Nizam's state railway surveys, Nov., 1869; executive engineer, March, 1871; on special duty, Nilgiri state railway, Oct., 1874; from Jan., 1875, was employed on Tirhoot state railway, and was appointed manager and superintendent of way and works, Tirhoot and Patna Gya state railways, March, 1880; executive engineer, 1st grade, Feb., 1881; transferred to superior re-
venue establishment, 1st class, 3rd grade, Oct., 1882; superintendent of way and works, N.W. railway, 1886.

RILEY, H. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 3rd April, 1882.

RIPON (Marquess of), the Right Hon. GEORGE FREDERICK SAMUEL ROBINSON, K.G., G.C.S.I., C.I.E., D.C.L.—Born 24th Oct., 1827; attached to a special mission to Brussels, 1849; sat in the House of Commons (as Viscount Goderich), as member for Hull, 1852 to 1853, for Huddersfield, 1853 to 1857, and for the West Riding of Yorkshire, 1857 to 1859, in which year he succeeded to the Upper House; under-secretary for war, June, 1859; president of the royal geographical society, 1860; under-secretary for India, Jan.–July, 1861; sworn a privy councillor, April, 1863; lord high steward of Hull, Oct., 1863; secretary for war, April, 1863, to Feb., 1866; secretary of state for India, Feb.–July, 1866; lord president of the council, Dec., 1868, to Aug., 1873; K.G., 1869; chairman of the joint high commission which arranged the treaty of Washington, 1871; Viceroy and governor-general of India, 8th June, 1880, in which office he was succeeded by the Earl of Dufferin, in Dec., 1884; honorary D.C.L. of Oxford, 1870; created Marquis of Ripon, June, 1871; grand master of the Freemasons of England, 1870 to 1874; president of the Yorkshire College, Leeds, 1882; is a magistrate and deputy-lieutenant for the north and west ridings of Yorkshire, and for the county of Lincoln; was a royal commissioner for the London Exhibition of 1886; first lord of the admiralty, Feb.–Aug., 1886.

RISLEY, HERBERT HOPE, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1873; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, Nov., 1876; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, Oct., 1877; under-secretary, revenue and general departments, Jan., 1878; officiating under-secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1879; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1880; served temporarily under railway branch, public works department, on special duty, Dec., 1882; superintendent of survey of Ghatwali and other service tenures in Manbhoom, Feb., 1884; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Nov., 1884; employed on the special duty of compiling statistics relating to the castes and occupations of the people of Bengal, Jan., 1885; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, April, 1886; and grade, May, 1888.

RITCHIE, JOHN GERALD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1875; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1887; has also officiated as magistrate and collector and inspector-general of registration.

RITCHIE, JAMES HUTTON, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1st April, 1867, and arrived in Madras, 8th Nov., 1867, and served on general and military duty; in charge of 25th regiment native infantry at Malta and Cyprus, April–Sept., 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1879; in charge of jails at Trichinopoly, Cuddalore, and Tanjore; district surgeon, Madura, Aug., 1888; acting senior medical officer, general hospital and principal of medical college, April, 1889.

RITCHIE, RICHMOND T. W., India Office.—Educated at Eton, and Trinity College, Cambridge; junior clerk, financial department, India office, 18th May, 1877; revenue, statistics and commerce department, 1881; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, 1883.

RIVAZ, CHARLES MONTGOMERY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1870; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, May, 1874; under-secretary to government, April, 1875; superintendent, Kapurthala state, April, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1885; appointed secretary to Punjab government, May, 1887, but to officiate as commissioner and superintendent, Lahore division; confirmed as commissioner and superintendent, Nov., 1888.

RIVAZ, GEORGE WILNOT, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; registrar, chief court, Punjab, 1877–1884; officiating inspector-general of registration and superintendent of stamps, Oct., 1884; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; district judge, 2nd Aug., 1886; additional divisional judge, May, 1889; edited the 2nd edition of the circular orders of the chief court.

RIVAZ, HENRY TULLIE, Barrister-at-Law, Punjab Judicial Department. Officiated as judge of the Punjab chief court from 23rd April, 1889, and was appointed additional judge of the court, 1st Nov., 1889.

RIVETT-CARNAC, CHARLES JAMES, Financial Department, Bengal.—Joined the financial department, 21st May, 1872; served in the N.W. Provinces till 1876, as assistant to the accountant-general, and officiated as personal assistant to the financial member of the governor-general's council, June, 1872; assistant to accountant-general, Punjab, Jan., 1876; officiating deputy accountant-general, Punjab, Aug., 1876; served again in the N.W. Provinces from March, 1878; assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Oct., 1882; 4th class, financial department, Feb., 1883; assistant comptroller-general (in charge of forest branch), Oct., 1884; assistant accountant-general, and examiner of local accounts, Bengal, March, 1885; officiating comptroller central provinces in 1889–90.

RIVETT-CARNAC, JOHN HENRY, C.I.E., F.S.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, May, 1886; officiating secretary to income tax committee, June, 1881; officiating under secretary,
government of India, home department, Sept., 1861; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, Central Provinces, June, 1862; settlement officer, Chandah and Wardha, Aug., 1864; cotton commissioner, Central Provinces, Sept., 1866, and Berars, April, 1867; commissioner of cotton and commerce with the government of India, Dec., 1871; member and honorary secretary of central committee of international exhibitions; on duty in England, July, 1872, to Jan., 1873; special commissioner of transport, Bengal famine; opium agent, Benares, March, 1875; author of 'Reports on the Indian Cotton Cultivation and Trade, and the Cotton Trade generally and on the Interchange of Traffic on Indian Railways.'

ROBB, JOHN, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.M. (Aber.), late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 1st Oct., 1868; from Nov., 1873, to July, 1882, served as civil surgeon, Zanzibar, and acted as assistant political agent, in 1874-75 and again in 1881; from July, 1882, served under the government of Bombay, as civil surgeon, and superintendent of jail at Aden, and at Surat; acting deputy sanitary commissioner, Sept.-Oct., 1883; civil surgeon, superintendent of lunatic asylum, and of the Medical School, Ahmedabad, April, 1884; retired, Nov., 1889.

ROBERTS, Allan Scott, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal infantry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 2nd April, 1862; from June, 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; 2nd grade, Jan., 1887; 1st grade, May, 1889.

ROBERTS, Arthur William, Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—Cornet, Bengal cavalry, Feb., 1859; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, 1864; acted as political superintendent of Sirohi in 1868-69, and subsequently as political agent in various states of Rajputana; cantonment magistrate, Morar, Feb., 1875; assistant commissioner, Merwara, April, 1881; political assistant, Sujangarh, Aug., 1881, in charge of Bikanir and the Upper Rajputana Thagi and Dakaiti Agency; in 1881-82 was employed in operations against the rebellious Bikanir Thakurs and received the surrender of the Fort of Nahargarh; assistant political agent, Banswara and Partabgarh, Aug., 1883; political agent and superintendent, Charkhari, Sept., 1884; cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, Dec., 1885; political agent, Alwar, April, 1886.

ROBERTS, David Thomas, LL.B., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Liverpool, Liverpool Institute, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, April, 1879; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Dec., 1886; magistrate and collector, June, 1887.

ROBERTS, Sir Frederick Sleigh, Bart., Lieut.-General, V.C., G.C.B., G.C.I.E., R.A.—First commission, Bengal artillery, 1851; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Delhi, the operations connected with the relief of Lucknow, at Cawnpore, and the capture of Lucknow, and was present at numerous engagements (medal and three clasps, brevet of major, V.C.); deputy assistant quartermaster-general, Bengal, April, 1858; served in the N.W. frontier expedition, 1863 (medal and clasp); assistant quartermaster-general, Bengal, Feb., 1863; served with the Abyssinian expedition, 1868 (medal, brevet of lieutenant-colonel), and with the Looshah expedition, 1871-72; deputy quartermaster-general, Bengal, Jan., 1872; quartermaster-general, Bengal, Jan., 1875; during the operations in Afghanistan in 1878-9-80, commanded the Kurram Valley field force, and subsequently the Cabul field force at the occupation of Cabul and battle of Charasiab, and in the march to the relief of Kandahar; received thanks of both houses of parliament, and was created a baronet (medal with four clasps, bronze star, K.C.B., G.C.B.); commander-in-chief, Madras, and member of governor's council, Nov., 1881; commander-in-chief in India, and member of the governor-general's council, 28th Nov., 1885.

ROBERTS, R. P., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 22nd Aug., 1873.

ROBERTS, Thomas, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, Nov., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, 1st grade, April, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Sept., 1883; additional commissioner, Jullundur, Aug., 1884; divisional judge, Nov., 1884 (2nd grade, Sept., 1886, and 1st grade, May, 1889).

ROBERTS, William Howland, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 23rd July, 1858; arrived, 24th Sept., 1858, and served in the Central Provinces till Sept., 1864, and subsequently in Madras as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at Salem; acted as Zillah surgeon, Coimbatore, July, 1866, to Jan., 1868; was also in charge of meteorological observatories at Coimbatore and Salem; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and superintendent of fish-liver oil factory, Calicut, Aug., 1869; surgeon-major, July, 1870; superintendent of lunatic asylum, Calicut, May, 1872; surgeon, 2nd district, Madras, and health officer, and superintendent of lock hospital, April, 1881; brigade-surgeon, June, 1885; deputy surgeon-general, July, 1888; surgeon, Secunderabad district and Hyderabad contingent.

ROBERTSON, Benjamin, Bombay, C.S.—Educated at the Institute, Elgin, the Grammar School and University of Aberdeen, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1885; assistant collector, June, 1886.

ROBERTSON, Charles, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., late Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 4th Aug., 1856; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1856; served under the military department from Dec., 1856, up to May, 1874, and also as Zillah surgeon, Masulipatam, Jan., 1862, to March, 1865; from May, 1874, served as Zillah surgeon, and superintendent of jail, Cuddalore; retired, Dec., 1885.

ROBERTSON, Donald, Major, M.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Royal Scots Fusiliers, Aug., 1865; arrived in Madras, Oct., 1865; subaltern, 4th
light cavalry, Madras, March, 1868; served from Nov., 1869, as assistant commissioner in the Central Provinces; transferred to Rajputana, June, 1872; cantonment magistrate, Nusseerabad, May, 1877; officiating assistant commissioner, Merwara and Ajmere, 1877-78; officiating superintendent, Jhallawar, 1879; 1st assistant agent to governor-general, Indore, 1881; political agent, Bhopawur, Feb., 1885; political agent, Bundelkhand, May, 1885; assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to the chief commissioner of Coorg; afterwards political agent in Baghelkhand, and superintendent of the Rewah State.

ROBERTSON, Elphinstone Pourtales, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 27th March, 1851, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, deputy commissioner of customs, salt, and opium, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty in Bombay to report on abkari lands, March, 1868; senior collector and magistrate, Dhárwar, Jan., 1873; revenue and police commissioner, Nov., 1876; commissioner of the central division, Jan., 1878; commissioner, 1st grade, July, 1881; retired, 1886.

ROBERTSON, Frederick Alexander, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 15th Dec., 1876, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Feb., 1882, served in the settlement department as assistant settlement officer; promoted to settlement officer, 3rd grade, April, 1884; settlement officer, 2nd grade, April, 1885; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1887; special duty Maler Kotla settlement operations, Nov., 1888; officiating director, land records and agriculture, March, 1889, and was confirmed in that appointment, Dec., 1889.

ROBERTSON, James Casamajor, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 31st Jan., 1855; from Jan., 1856, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent, Dehra Dün, small cause court judge, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Allahabad, Oct., 1871; officiating inspector-general of registration, and commissioner of excise and stamps, July, 1876; civil and sessions judge, April, 1879; commissioner, Agra division, Jan., 1882, and subsequently of the Rohilkhund division, Feb., 1883; officiated as member of the board of revenue, on various occasions, 1885-9; retired, Jan., 1890.

ROBERTSON, John Herbert, Madras C.S.—Educated at Sir Roger Cholmeley's School, Highgate, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Madras, 29th Nov., 1889, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

ROBERTSON, William, Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 27th Feb., 1886.

ROBERTSON, William Rowntree, M.R.A.C., late Madras Education Department.—Arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868; superintendent, government farms, Nov., 1868; on special duty to Mysore and Bangalore, Jan., 1876; superintendent of the school of agriculture, Saidapet, Oct., 1876; fellow of Madras University, May, 1882; superintendent, government farms and school of agriculture, and agricultural reporter to government of Madras, Nov., 1882; principal, agricultural college, Saidapet, April, 1884; member of committee in connection with scheme of technical education, Sept., 1887; retired, 1890.

ROBINSON, Alexander, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1865; from Jan., 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1879; deputy commissioner, and grade, Fyzabad, Nov., 1883; magistrate and collector, April, 1887; author of 'Memoirs of the Ballia and Jaunpur District.'

ROE, Charles Arthur, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Sept., 1881; additional commissioner, Lahore and Rawal Pindi divisions, May, 1883; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; officiating judge, chief court, March, 1885, April, 1887, and Nov., 1887; divisional judge, 1st grade, Feb., 1887; additional judge, chief court, Punjab, Nov., 1888; judge, chief court, Punjab, April, 1889; author of 'Reports on the Settlement of various Districts,' and of 'Customary Law of the Mooltan District.'

ROGERS, Alexander, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1845; served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department, and was appointed 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Broach, Oct.; 1851, and afterwards at Ahmedabad, Oct., 1852; settlement officer, Guzerat, Nov., 1852; collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, March, 1860, and afterwards at Surat; revenue and police commissioner, north division, April, 1865; member of council, Bombay, June, 1872; retired in 1878.

ROGERS, Ernest, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Bedford Grammar School and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1887, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

ROGERS, Henry Thomas, Major-General, R.E., late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—2nd lieutenant, Dec., 1849; arrived in India, 28th Aug., 1852; served in the public works department, Bengal, from 1853 to 1859, and subsequently in Madras as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and acted as comptroller of public works accounts, 1864, and as principal of the Civil Engineering College, Feb. to Aug., 1865; acting mint master, July, 1865; officiating superintending engineer, Sept.-Oct., 1870; fellow of the University of Madras, March, 1872; principal, Civil Engineering College, April, 1871, to Jan., 1880; member of the committee for the management of the school of arts, March, 1877; from Nov., 1879, served as superintendent of revenue survey, Madras; retired, July, 1886.
ROGERS, Malcolm, W., Lt.-Col., R.E., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, royal engineers, Dec., 1861; arrived in India, Oct., 1865; assistant surveyor, great trigonometrical survey of India, July, 1866; served with the Quetta field force as survey officer, 1873-79 (medal, brevet of major); deputy superintendent of survey, July, 1882; assistant surveyor-general in charge of mathematical instrument office, and correspondence office, Calcutta, May, 1884; 3rd grade, deputy superintendent, Aug., 1884; and 2nd grade, June, 1889; appointed assistant surveyor-general in charge of surveyor-general's office and mathematical instrument office, May, 1889.

ROLLAND, Alexander Tulloch, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras infantry, April, 1856; arrived in India, 11th May, 1856; served in the Madras police department from Dec., 1862, as assistant superintendent, and superintendent; deputy inspector-general of police, Feb., 1883; acted as commissioner of police, Madras city, March, 1889.

ROMESH Chunder Dutt (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Coleotola Branch School, Calcutta, Presidency College, Calcutta University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Sept., 1871; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, March, 1888, and 2nd grade, Oct., 1889; has published the following works: 'Three years in Europe,' 1872; 'Peasantry of Bengal,' 1876; 'Literature of Bengal,' 1877; 'Satabarsa, (Historical Tales), and a 'Short History of India in Bengali,' 1878; a Bengali translation of the 'Reg Veda Sanhita;' a popular account of the gods of the 'Reg Veda;' and a social novel called the 'Sansar.'

ROMESH Chunder MitteR, Sir, B.L.—late Puise judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 30th March, 1874; acted as chief justice in 1882; retired, 1890; is additional member of the council of the governor-general for making laws and regulations.

RONSON, W. T., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 1st Sept., 1873; clerk, 2nd class, Feb., 1879; attached to revenue, statistics, and commerce department; author of the report on sanitary measures in India annually presented to Parliament for the years 1878-79 to 1888-89 inclusive.

ROSE, Edward, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Folkingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Oct., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1883; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1887.

ROSE, Horace Arthur, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India 4th Oct., 1888, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

ROSS, Alexander, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Academy and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1836; served in the judicial and revenue departments of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed superintendent of Dehra Dun, Jan., 1846; magistrate and collector, 1853; special commissioner, Farakhabad, Dec., 1857; civil and sessions judge, 1858; member of special commission for trial of Nawab of Farakhabad, 1859; commissioner of revenue and police, Agra division, May, 1859; judge of the Sudder court, N.W. Provinces, 1862; puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, 1866; retired, Oct., 1871.

ROSS, Edward Charles, Colonel, C.S.I., Bombay S.C.—Ensign, 3rd European regiment, Bombay, May, 1855; served in Central India during the mutiny, and was present at the siege and capture of Jhansi (medal and clasp); assistant to political agent, Muscat, 1863-69; assistant political agent, Gwadar, 1869; political agent and consul, Muscat, April, 1871; local lieutenant-colonel in Persian Gulf, May, 1872; political resident, Persian Gulf, from Oct., 1872; graded as resident, 2nd class; H.M.'s consul-general for the Province of Fars, and the coasts and islands of the Persian Gulf, Nov., 1878; officiating resident, Hyderabad, April, 1886; political resident, 2nd class, Persian Gulf, Oct., 1886.

ROSS, George Cumberland, Brigade-Surgeon, Medical Department, Punjab.—Served from Nov., 1867, as civil surgeon in various stations in the Punjab; surgeon-major, Oct., 1877; civil surgeon, 1st class, Oct., 1881; brigade-surgeon, April, 1890.

ROSS, Henry Thomas, M.A., LL.B., Madras C.S.—Educated at Perth Academy, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1873, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting district and sessions judge; special assistant to the collector and magistrate, Malabar, Sept., 1884; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1885; registrar, high court, Feb., 1886; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Sept., 1888; district and sessions judge, Nov., 1889.

ROSS, Hercules Grey, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1856; from April, 1858, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, city magistrate at Lucknow, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; superintendent, Dehra Dun, Dec., 1860; magistrate and collector, Benares, Oct., 1882; officiating commissioner, Benares division, and agent to governor-general, March, 1883; on special duty, Dehra Dun, March, 1883; settlement officer, 2nd grade, Dehra Dun, Oct., 1883; commissioner, Kumaon, April, 1885; retired, Nov., 1888.

ROST, Reinhold, C.I.E., LL.D., Ph.D., Librarian, India Office.—Educated at the Grammar School of Altenburg (1838-42), and the University of Jena (1842-46), where he graduated in 1847; came to London in the same year to continue his oriental studies; was appointed oriental lecturer at St. Augustine's Missionary College, 1851.
secretary to the Royal Asiatic Society, Dec., 1863; librarian, India office, July, 1869; published in 1850 an essay on the Indian sources of the Burmese laws edited (1862-65) Professor H. H. Wilson's selected works, H. B. Hodgson's essays (2 vols., 1880), and miscellaneous papers on Indo-China (2 vols., 1886); contributes articles on oriental philology to the 'Encyclopaedia Britannica,' and the 'Athenæum'; is honorary M.A. of Oxford and LL.D. of Edinburgh, honorary member of the Royal Asiatic Society, and of the Asiatic societies of Singapore, the Hague, and Batavia; corresponding member of the Royal Society of Munich and the German Oriental Society, and honorary fellow of St. Augustine's College, Canterbury.

ROUSE, ROBERT, Deputy Surgeon-General, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1854; arrived in India, 31st Jan., 1855; from May, 1869, served as civil surgeon and officiating superintendent of jail in the Punjab; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; retired, Dec., 1883.

ROWE, FREDERICK JAMES, M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the service, 15th June, 1870, and served as professor at Krishnagurh, Dacca, and Hooghly Colleges, also as inspector of schools and officiating principal, Krishnagurh College (May, 1877); 3rd class, education department, Jan., 1878; professor, Presidency College, July, 1880; 2nd class educational department, June, 1890.

ROWLANDS, PERCY J., Registry Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 1st Sept., 1858; assistant to registrar, June, 1877.

ROYLE, JOSEPH R. E. J., C.I.E., India Office.—Educated at King's College School, London; entered Indian army from Addiscombe, 7th June, 1861; lieutenant H.M.'s 107th foot, 1862; retired, Jan., 1867; on the extra staff of the India Museum, 1st Jan., 1867; secretary Indian commission for Vienna exhibition, 1873; superintendent India Museum, 1874-9; clerk to the special assistant in the statistics and commerce department, India office, Oct., 1879; assistant secretary, Indian section of the Colonial and Indian exhibition, 1886; also officiating as agent of the government of India from Jan., 1885; C.I.E., 1886; author of the official report on the Indian section of the Amsterdam exhibition of 1882, and of the Indian section of the Colonial and Indian exhibition, 1886; and of contributions on Indian art manufactures and other subjects to various periodicals; also of a lecture before the Society of Arts, June, 1882, on the 'Production of Tea, Cinchona, Wild Silks, and Rhea in India.'

RUDDOCK, EDWARD HARDCASTLE, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Leeds Grammar School and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, and 2nd Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Sept., 1884; and 1st grade, Sept., 1888; retired, 1890.

RULE, EDWARD, Financial Department, Government of India.—Served in England under the board of admiralty previous to joining the financial department of government of India; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1865, and served in the comptroller-general's establishment; from March, 1863, to Sept., 1869, served in Bombay as assistant accountant-general and assistant commissioner of paper currency; from Sept., 1869, to March, 1875, acted as deputy accountant-general in British Burma; from March, 1875, served as deputy accountant-general, Madras, and acted for some months as accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency; on special duty to Port Blair, Nov.-Dec., 1877; deputy accountant-general, Burma, Dec., 1877; deputy comptroller-general (afterwards designated comptroller of Indian treasuries) in 1st class of financial department, April, 1883; finance department, class 1, enrolled list, comptroller of Indian treasuries, Jan., 1890.

RUNDALL, FRANCIS HORNBLOW, General, C.S.I., R.E., late public works department, Government of India.—Madras engineers, 1841; assistant civil engineer, 1844; civil engineer, public works department, Ganjam, 1854; district engineer Rajahmundry, May, 1855; consulting engineer, Madras irrigation and canal company, Oct., 1859; chief engineer of irrigation and joint secretary to government of Bengal, July, 1867; chief engineer, 1st class, Aug., 1869; officiating inspector-general and deputy secretary to government of India, irrigation branch, Jan., 1871; inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, April, 1872, to April, 1874.

RUNDALL, JAMES WILLIAM, M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—Joined Madras public works department as supernumerary engineer, 2nd Aug., 1855, and served in the Godavari, Tinnevelly, and Bellary districts; executive engineer, July, 1863; on special duty under chief engineer, May, 1877; superintendent of works, Kistna, Aug., 1880; superintending engineer, Oct., 1881; member of committee for drawing up navigation rules, Nov., 1882; and 2nd class superintending engineer, April, 1884; retired, 1889.

RUSSELL, EDGAR GEER, M.B., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service, 10th Aug., 1883, as 1st resident surgeon, presidency general hospital; served on general and military duty, and as inspector of emigrants, and as superintendent of Campbell medical school and hospital; professor of medical jurisprudence Calcutta medical college, and police surgeon, Calcutta, July, 1888; officiating civil surgeon and superintendent of central jail, Rajshahiye, Nov., 1888; civil surgeon, Patna, and superintendent of Temple medical school, March, 1890.

RUSSELL, SIR EDWARD LECHMERE, General, K.C.S.I.—Ensign, 12th N.I., Bombay, Jan., 1838; served in the Afghan war of 1842, and the Sind campaign of 1842-43, and was adjutant of the Sind irregular horse in the battles of Meanee and Hydrabad, and the surrender of Omerkote; fort adjutant, Bombay, Jan., 1855; remount agent, May, 1857; commanding brigade, Deesa, March, 1863, and subsequently at Bombay; political resident and commanding brigade, at Aden, Dec., 1867; commanding northern division, Bombay, Dec., 1870 to 1876; placed on unemployed list, July, 1881.

RUSSELL, SAMUEL, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Santry School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; special assistant to collector, magistrate, and agent, Ganjam, Feb.,
1885; sub-collector and joint magistrate, March, 1890.

RUTHERFORD, James, Col., Mysore Revenue Survey.—First commission, ensign, 4th Aug., 1859; Joined the Mysore revenue survey department, Jan., 1865; deputy superintendent, April, 1881.

RUTHERFORD, John Muric, Railway Department, Government of India.—Was specially trained in Europe for the telegraph department, and was appointed assistant superintendent, 4th grade, Oct., 1869; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1870, and served in the Punjab, and in Rajputana; acted as assistant manager, Rajputana state railway, in addition to his own duties, June-Nov., 1870; transferred to traffic department of state railways, March, 1880, and served as district traffic superintendent on the Rajputana state railway; Indus Valley state railway, March, 1882; class I of the state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1886; deputy traffic superintendent, Lahore, North-Western railway, July, 1886; traffic superintendent, North-Western railway, Oct., 1888.

RYLAND, William Henry, late Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 10th Dec., 1852, served in the subordinate executive service, Bengal, and was appointed deputy magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1866; officiating collector of stamps, and superintendent of abkaree revenue, March, 1868; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1869; from Dec., 1874, served in the judicial department, and was appointed subordinate judge 1st grade, and judge of the small cause court at Sealdah, April, 1875; officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1880; retired, April, 1887.

RYVES, Thomas James, Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served as a volunteer in the Bengal yeomanry cavalry from July, 1857, to Jan., 1859, and received the mutiny medal and the local rank of lieutenant for distinguished services in the field; adjutant of military police, Bijnor, 1859; assistant inspector-general, Rohilkund, April, 1861; from Aug., 1861, served as superintendent of police in various districts, and was promoted to the 1st grade, June, 1885; assistant inspector-general railway police, June, 1888.

SABONADIERE, Alfred, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces, &c.)—Educated at Charterhouse and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 19th Jan., 1888, and served as assistant commissioner; and assistant magistrate and collector.

ST. JOHN, Sir Oliver Beauchamp Coventry, Colonel, K.C.S.I., R.E.—2nd Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1856; served in public works department, Oudh and N.W. Provinces, July, 1859, to Oct., 1863; superintendent, Persian telegraph, Oct., 1863, to Oct., 1871; boundary commissioner, Perso-Kalat frontier, Oct., 1871, to March, 1873; employed at India office in compiling map of Persia, March, 1873, to Jan., 1875; principal of Mayo College, Ajmir, Jan., 1875, to Aug., 1878; attached to General Sir N. Chamberlain's mission to Kabul, Aug.-Sept., 1878; chief political officer, Kandahar field force, Nov., 1878, to March, 1880; resident Southern Afghanistan, April, 1880, to April, 1881; gazetted H.M.'s Consul, Mazandaran and Ghilan, Aug., 1879, but did not join; officiating agent to governor-general, Beluchistan, 1881-83, and again from May, 1886; on special duty in Kashmir, Jan., 1883; acting resident in Hyderabad, April-July, 1884; resident in Kashmir, Aug., 1884; agent to the governor-general at Baroda, Dec., 1887; resident in Mysore and chief commissioner and judicial commissioner in Coorg, Jan., 1889.

ST. QUINTIN, William A., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Blackheath Proprietary School; temporary clerk, 31st Dec., 1866; junior examiner, Dec., 1868; senior examiner, Nov., 1878.

SAIYID MAHMUD (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as district judge, 3rd grade, Oudh, Aug., 1879; served temporarily under foreign department of government of India, June, 1881, to May, 1882; acting puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, May, 1882, and again in 1884 and 1886; served under education committee, Nov., 1882, to March, 1883; district judge, Rae Bareli, Nov., 1883; judge of high court, N.W. Provinces, 9th May, 1887; author of the 'Law of Evidence in British India.'

SALIG RAM, Rae Bahadur, late Postal Department, N.W. Provinces.—Served in the postal department, N.W. Provinces, from Mardh, 1847, as clerk, inspecting postmaster, and head assistant in the office of the postmaster-general; inspector, post offices, Agra division, July, 1876; superintendent, Agra division, April, 1881; postmaster-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, June, 1884; retired.

SALISBURY (Marquess of) Right Hon. Robert Arthur Talbot Gascoigne Cecil, K.G., D.C.L., LL.D.—Born in 1830; educated at Eton and Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated, and was elected a fellow of All Souls' College in 1853; represented Stamford in Parliament from 1853 to April, 1868, when he succeeded to the Upper House; secretary of state for India, July, 1866, to March, 1867; chancellor of the university of Oxford, Nov., 1869; in 1871-72 he acted with Lord Cairns in conducting the investigation into the affairs of the London, Chatham, and Dover Railway Company; secretary of state for India, second time, Feb., 1874; was sent as special ambassador to the Sublime Porte in 1876, and acted with Sir Henry Elliot as joint plenipotentiaries of Great Britain at the conference of Constantinople, Dec., 1876; was appointed secretary of state for foreign affairs on the resignation of Lord Derby, April, 1878, and afterwards accompanied the Earl of Beaconsfield to Berlin, as representative of Great Britain at the congress held there; invested with the Order of the Garter, July, 1878; prime minister and again secretary of state for foreign affairs, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; prime minister and first lord of the treasury, Aug., 1886; secretary of state for foreign affairs (3rd time), Jan., 1887; has served on the royal commissions on historical manuscripts, 1882; on the housing of the working classes, 1884; and for the Indian and Colonial exhibitions, 1886; is honorary colonel Bedfordshire regiment, and an elder brother of the Trinity House.

SALMON, William Arthur, Colonel, Bo. S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 11th May, 1859, and served on military duty till March, 1867, and subsequently in the political department as acting
assistant resident, Baroda, acting political agent Rewa Kantha, and acting assistant political agent in Káthiáwar on special duty; personal assistant to political agent, Káthiáwar, Jan., 1871; acting assistant superintendent for thuggee and dacoity, Baroda, Feb.-March, 1873; served as political assistant in Káthiáwar up to Jan., 1879, and was in charge of the Gondal state and of Hálá Pránt, July-Aug., 1877; from Feb., 1879, served as assistant political agent, Kolaba, in charge Janjira state; acting political agent, Mahi Kantha, Aug.-Nov., 1882; assistant political agent in charge of Southern Mahrátha country Jaghirs, Aug., 1883; joint administrator of Rajpipla, July, 1884; joint administrator of Sángli, Feb., 1885; assistant to the governor-general's agent in charge of the Okhamandal district, and commandant Wagheer corps, Nov., 1887; acted as political agent, Cutch, and Mahi Kantha.

SAMPSON, ARTHUR BISKS, B.A., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Assistant secretary, public works department, May, 1859; under secretary to Government of India, public works department, general branch, Sept., 1869; retired, May, 1887.

SAMUELLS, CHARLES ARCHIBALD (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College School, Blackheath Proprietary School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1869; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was placed on famine duty at Chumparun, March, 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1883; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, March, 1885; officiating port commissioner, Calcutta, April, 1886; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Oct., 1886; 2nd grade, Sept., 1888; port commissioner, Calcutta, March, 1887.

SAMUELLS, WILLIAM LEYCESTER, Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, 20th Nov., 1857; served from 18th Dec., 1864, in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; special boundary commissioner (Rewah and Chota Nagpur), 1868-71; officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Barrackpore, April, 1873; officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, April, 1875; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Aug., 1885; 2nd grade, Aug., 1887; retired, April, 1890.

SANDEMAN, J. E., Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Survey Department.—Joined at Addiscombe, 1860; ensign, Bengal infantry, 7th June, 1861; arrived in India, Oct., 1861; studied at Roorkee College, and obtained certificate qualifying for engineer, public works department, Sept., 1864, and served as assistant superintendent in the Central Provinces, Oudh, and the Punjab; served with the Hazara expedition, 1868 (medal); in charge of Midnapur survey, Bengal, 1873; Goalparah survey, Assam, Dec., 1873; Behar irrigation survey, Oct., 1874; in charge of British Burma cadastral survey, Dec., 1878; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, survey of India, Jan., 1879; in charge of Mirzapur and Gorakpur district cadastral survey, from Nov., 1883; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Jan., 1887.

SANDEMAN, Sir Robert Groves, Colonel, K.C.S.I., B.S.C.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, Feb., 1856; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Lucknow and other operations (medal and clasp); assistant commissioner, Punjab, May, 1859; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1875; on special duty in connection with Kalat affairs, Nov., 1875, to Feb., 1877, during which period he conducted two missions to Kalat; agent, governor-general, Biluchistan, from Feb., 1877; during the Afghan war held the chief political authority in Biluchistan, in the Zhob Valley expedition, Sept., 1884; resident of the 1st class, and governor-general's agent in Biluchistan, June, 1887; K.C.S.I., July, 1879; Quetta, Oct., 1889, agent to governor-general.

SANDERS, EDWIN, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Department.—Served under the government of Bengal from 1st Nov., 1869, to May, 1871; officiating civil surgeon, Chittagong, March, 1881; surgeon-major, April, 1881; civil surgeon, Moorshedebad, June, 1886.

SANDERS, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Collegiate School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant commissioner, 3rd grade; officiating city magistrate and wasika officer, Lucknow, May-Aug., 1886; joint magistrate, March, 1888.

SANDERS, RICHARD CARELESS, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1869; ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic surgery, Medical College, Calcutta, April, 1886.

SANDIFORD, C. T., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the P.W. department from Scinde, Punjab, and Delhi railway as locomotive superintendent, North-Western state railway, Jan., 1886; class, state railway revenue establishment, July, 1886; class I, grade I, state revenue establishment, permanent, April, 1887.

SANFORD, GEORGE EDWARD LANGLEHAM SOMERSET, Colonel, R.E., C.B., C.S.I., Military Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, R.E., Oct., 1856; served in the China war, 1858 (medal and clasp); served in the public works department (military works), April, 1872, to Jan., 1878, as assistant and executive engineer, and in the Jowaki campaign, 1878 (medal and clasp); assistant quartermaster-general, Bengal, Feb., 1878, to March, 1880; during this period served in the Afghan campaign, and was present at the capture of Ali Mujid (medal and clasp, brevet of lieutenant-colonel); deputy quartermaster-general, Bengal, March, 1880, to Nov., 1885; commanded Royal Engineers in Burmese expedition, 1885-86; C.B., Nov., 1886; inspector-general of military works, March, 1886; chief engineer, 2nd class, March, 1887; 1st class, March, 1889; C.S.I., Jan., 1890.

SANKEY, RICHARD HIERAM, Lieutenant-General, C.B., late R.E.—Ensign, 11th Dec., 1846; arrived in India as supernumerary second lieutenant, Madras engineers, Nov., 1848; officiating superintending engineer, Singapore subsidiary force, Feb., 1850, to June, 1853; superintendent of the east coast canal, 1850-57; additional under secretary, government of India, public works department, March,
1857; on outbreak of mutiny proceeded with special appointment to Allahabad, acting for a time as superintending engineer and consulting engineer for railways, N.W. Provinces; acted as field engineer at Cawnpore, and was subsequently senior engineer officer with the Gurkha force under Jung Bahadur; executive engineer and superintendent of convicts, Moulmein, Jan.-Nov., 1859, and subsequently garrison engineer, Fort William; assistant to chief engineer, Mysore, June, 1861; chief engineer, Mysore, 1866-1877; services placed by Lord Mayo at disposal of government of Victoria for specially reporting on the waterworks of the colony, March-Oct., 1871; deputy secretary to government of India, Sept., 1877; commanding engineer of the South Afghanistan expeditionary force under lieutenant-general D. Stewart, C.B., Oct., 1878, to Feb., 1879; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government of Madras, public works department, April, 1879; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; resigned the public works department in 1883; retired from the army, Jan., 1884; chairman, board of works, Dublin.

SAPTE, BRAND, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1843; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal, the Punjab, and N.W. Provinces; magistrate and collector, Bulandshahr, 1857, and subsequently at Meerut; C.B. in 1859; from 1864 to 1865 served as judge of Ghazecpur, and subsequently of Farakhabad; retired 1871.

SARGEAUNT, CHARLES CHESTER, Major-General, M.S.C., late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Ensign, 31st May, 1856; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1856, and served under the military department till Feb., 1867, and subsequently in the revenue survey department, Madras, as assistant superintendent; was on special duty in Madras, 1873, and 1875-1876, and in England, 1833; deputy-superintendent of revenue survey, Dec., 1876; on special duty at Coonoor to revise and publish the survey manual, April, 1886; colonel in the army, May, 1886; superintendent of revenue survey, June, 1886; retired, July, 1887.

SARGEAUNT, RICHARD ARTHUR, Lieut.-Col., R.E., railway department, government of India.—1st commission, Dec., 1861; joined the Bombay public works department, May, 1864; assistant consulting engineer, railways, Nov., 1864; examiner of railway accounts, Bombay, April, 1872; acting examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, Dec., 1875; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, May, 1877; acted as consulting engineer for railways in 1878; secretary to railway conference, Jan., 1879; executive engineer, 1st grade, Jan., 1880; revenue assistant, railway branch, public works secretariat, government of India, 1880; manager, Northern Bengal state railway, in class I of the state railway revenue establishment, July, 1882; officiating under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Feb., 1883; officiating manager, Punjab Northern state railway, June, 1884; officiating manager of East Bengal railway, June, 1887; officiating consulting engineer for railways, and officiating joint secretary railway department, Bombay, May, 1888; manager, Oudh and Rohilkund railway, Jan., 1889; served in the Abyssinian expedition of 1868 (medal).

SARGENT, Sir Charles, Knt., M.A. (Cantab), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Judge of the high court, Bombay, April, 1866; chief justice, Aug., 1882.

SATYANDRANATH TAGORE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Presidency College, Calcutta University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived, 12th Dec., 1864, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting judge of the small cause court, Ahmednagar, and judge and sessions judge; 1st grade judge, Sholapur-Bijapur, Aug., 1883.

SAUNDERS, Arthur Leslie, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at the Oratory School, Edgbaston, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to the Central Provinces, Oct., 1885; under secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1887; assistant commissioner, Oct., 1888.

SAUNDERS, Leslie Harry, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dulwich College and Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Burma division of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Burma, 30th Nov., 1889, and served as assistant commissioner.

SAVAGE, Henry, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Liverpool Institute; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Dec., 1885; 1st grade, Dec., 1887; has also officiated as magistrate and collector.

SCHARLIEB, WILLIAM MASON, Barrister-at-Law, late Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 25th March, 1847, in various subordinate posts, and was appointed first unencumbered assistant to the board of revenue, June, 1862; resigned the service to practise at the bar, Oct., 1867; acting administrator-general, Madras, in 1867 and 1874; acting government pleader, May, 1874; assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, Dec., 1874; from April to Oct., 1879, acted as first judge of the court of small causes, Madras, and again in 1885 and 1888, and served from 1885 as presidency magistrate for the town of Madras; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; has acted as chief presidency magistrate for various periods since 1884; retired, 1890.

SCHLICH, W., Ph.D., late Forest Department, Government of India.—Appointed by the secretary of state for India as an assistant conservator of forests, Dec., 1866; conservator of forests, Bengal, Dec., 1872; transferred to the Punjab, 1880; inspector-general of forests, April, 1883; retired, 1888, and appointed principal professor of forestry, at the Royal Indian engineering college, Cooper's Hill.

SCHNEIDER, Sir John William, General, K.C.B.—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and afterwards at the military college at Addiscombe; ensign, 2nd native infantry, Bombay, 20th Feb., 1841; served in the Southern Mah-
ratta campaign, 1845, and was present at the capture of the Panalla and Powanghur forts; second in command and commandant of the Kolhapur infantry, and also assistant political superintendent, 1852-1859; in 1857-58, took part in the suppression of the mutiny at Kolhapur, and the recapture of the city; mutiny medal; commissioner under Act XIV. of 1857 for the summary trial and punishment of offences against the State; president of the civil and military committee at Bombay for the examination of officers in native languages, 1859-1861; commanded 2nd regiment, Bombay infantry, 1859-1866; served in the Abyssinian expedition of 1867-8, and commanded a brigade at action of Arogee, and assault and capture of Magdala; medal, and C.B., Aug., 1858; judge advocate-general, Bombay army, 1868-72; political resident at Aden, 1872-77; also commanded Aden brigade; commanded northern division, Bombay army, 1877-1881; K.C.B., May, 1880.

SCOBLE, Sir Andrew Richard, K.C.S.I., Q.C.—Called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn, Jan., 1856; held the offices of clerk of the crown and commissioner for taking accounts and for local investigations, under the high court, Bombay, 1863-66; was an advocate of the high court, 1866-1876, and successively held the offices of sheriff, 1866-67, legal remembrancer, 1866-72, and advocate-general, 1872-77; conducted the prosecution of the Gaekwar of Baroda, 1875; was also additional member of the council of the governor of Bombay, 1870-76; Q.C., 1876; took his seat as an ordinary member of the governor general's council, 1st Dec., 1886; C.S.I., Jan., 1880; K.C.S.I., May, 1890.

SCONCE, Gideon Colquhoun (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Bengal.—Officiating magistrate, Calcutta, 12th Nov., 1856; clerk of the Calcutta court of small causes, Dec., 1870; judge of the Calcutta court of small causes, Jan., 1874; promoted to third judge, Oct., 1884; chief judge, Oct., 1889.

SCONCE, James, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey Department.—Joined at Addiscombe, Feb., 1852; Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, April, 1854; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Delhi, and in the operations leading to the relief of Lucknow, also during the capture of Lucknow, March, 1858, (medal and clasps); served from Oct., 1859, as assistant revenue surveyor in the Bundelcund and Central Provinces surveys; revenue surveyor, Jan., 1863; served in Bengal from March, 1866, in the office of superintendent of revenue surveys, Calcutta, and at Hazaribagh, Midnapur, and Arrah; deputy superintendent of survey, 2nd grade, Nov., 1868; deputy surveyor-general (revenue survey branch) Jan., 1879; has also officiated as surveyor-general of India.

SCORGIE, James, F.C.S., late Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the service as head master of the Akola High School, Berar, 12th Nov., 1866; in charge of the office of director of public instruction, Berar, April-June, 1872; principal, Jeypore school of arts, Oct., 1872; from Feb., 1875, served as professor of mechanism and applied science, Civil Engineering College, Poona; 3rd grade of the education department, March, 1883; retired, Aug., 1890.

SCOTLAND, Sir Colley H., Knight.—Educated at the Royal School, Raphoe; entered as a student at the Middle Temple in 1840, and was called to the bar in 1843; practised on the common law side of Westminster Hall, and on the Oxford circuit; appointed chief justice of the supreme court, Madras, 1861, and of the high court of judicature on its establishment in 1862; resigned, 1871; vice-chancellor of the Madras University, 1861 to 1871; contributed to the Law Journal reports of cases in the court of Queen's bench, 1848 to 1857, and is joint author of a work 'On the Crown Office Practice of the Court of Queen's Bench.'

SCOTT, Arthur Guillum, Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester, and at private schools; East India House writer, old establishment, 7th Nov., 1857; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, India office, Aug., 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1872.

SCOTT, Edwin, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884. Arrived in India, 15th Jan., 1887, and served in the revenue and survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

SCOTT, John, M.A. (Oxon), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Judge of the high court, Bombay, 18th Nov., 1882; services lent to the Egyptian government from April, 1890.

SCOTT, Mathew Henry, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived 16th Dec., 1863, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge and sessions judge; senior assistant judge and sessions judge, Kalagdi, July, 1876; 2nd grade judge, Khándoseh, Feb., 1881; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Ahmednagar, May, 1882; acting district judge, Khandesh, April, 1883; and Satara, Jan., 1889.

SCOTT, Ross, M.A., F.C.S. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Omagh Academy, the Royal Academical Institution and Seminary, Belfast, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating additional and district and sessions judge; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Nov., 1886; 1st grade, sub-pro tem., March, 1888, and Tatara, Jan., 1889; district and sessions judge, March, 1889.

SCOTT, Thomas Augustus, Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, June, 1857; arrived in India, 29th June, 1857; from Jan., 1862, served in the police department, Central Provinces, and was appointed district superintendent, March, 1864; from June, 1865, served as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Dec., 1882, and 3rd class, Aug., 1889.

SCOTT, William, Colonel, Bombay Political Department.—1st commission, 20th July, 1857; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1857, and served with the 19th regiment Bombay N.I.; admitted to the staff corps, Jan., 1864; served in the political department in Baroda, from March, 1865; president of special commission in Kathia-war, 1873; assistant political agent in charge of Gondal, June, 1875; colonel, July, 1887; political agent, Mahi Kantha, Feb., 1889; served in the Indian mutiny (medal and clasps.)
SCOTT MONCRIEFF, Sir Colin Campbell, K.C.M.G., C.S.I., Colonel, R.E., retired—joined the service as 2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 13th June, 1850; arrived in India, 10th June, 1853; served with the Bengal sappers and miners until Feb., 1859, through the campaign in Oudh, and was present at several actions (medal); joined public works department, Feb., 1859, and served in the N.W. Provinces in the irrigation branch; principal Thomason Civil Engineering College, Roorkee, Sept., 1861; assistant to chief engineer irrigation branch, April, 1869; from Nov., 1869, served on the Ganges canal as executive and afterwards superintendent engineer; major, April, 1874; in 1877, was sent on deputation to Mysore to serve as chief engineer and famine commissioner; C.S.I., May, 1878; member of an irrigation committee under the famine commission, Aug., 1878, to Feb., 1879, when he again joined irrigation department of N.W. Provinces; officiated as chief engineer and secretary to the chief commissioner of British Burma, May, 1881; promoted to superintending engineer, 1st class, Feb., 1882; retired, Jan., 1883; K.C.M.G., 1887; is under secretary public works ministry, Egypt.

SCULLY, John, Surgeon-Major, Indian Medical Department.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1872; served under the military department, and also as medical officer, Kashgar political agency, 1874-76; residency surgeon, Nipal, 1876-78; medical officer, Gilgit, 1878-80; acting deputy assay master, Calcutta mint, Oct., 1882, to Jan., 1883; from Nov., 1883, served as officiating assay master, and acting deputy assay master of the Bombay mint; confirmed in the latter appointment, May, 1884; assay master of the Calcutta mint, May, 1886.

SEABROOKE, James H., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London (Jelf medallist and associate, 1871); open classical scholarship, Queen's College, Oxford, 1871-74; B.A., Dec., 1874; junior clerk, financial department, India office, 13th Jan., 1876, military department, 1877; senior clerk, June, 1887.

SEATON, William John, Colonel, M.S.C., Forest Department, Burma.—Ensign, Madras infantry, Sept., 1855; assistant superintendent in the forest department, Dec., 1860; deputy conservator, 1st class, April, 1865; conservator, Nov., 1867; 1st grade conservator, Sept., 1882.

SECCOMBE, Henry L., Financial Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 14th May, 1856; junior clerk, financial department, India office, Dec., 1866; senior clerk, Dec., 1882.

SECCOMBE, Sir Thomas Lawrence, K.C.S.I., C.B.—Entered the home service of the Honorable East India Company in Jan., 1829, as a clerk in the department of auditor of India accounts (subsequently merged in the secretary's department); on the transfer of the government of India to the Crown in 1858 was appointed assistant financial secretary; financial secretary, 1859; director of military funds, and chairman of the consulting committee, 1866; in Jan., 1869, was elected chairman of a joint India office and war office committee for adjusting the charges against Indian revenues for services of H.M.'s regiments on the India establishment, and was nominated a member of a similar committee in 1874, and again in Feb., 1879; C.B., Dec., 1869; accountant-general, in addition to his other duties, Feb., 1872; assistant under secretary of state for India, July, 1872; K.C.S.I., June, 1877; appointed one of three commissioners to represent H.M.'s Government at the International Monetary Conference at Paris, 1878; continued assistant under secretary of state until 1881, but resigned his other offices on 31st Jan., 1879; member of a joint India office and admiralty committee on financial questions connected with the India troop service, June, 1879.

SELBY, Francis Gray, B.A. (Oxon), Education Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 7th Feb., 1877, and served from that date as professor of logic and moral philosophy in the Deccan College, Poona; also held acting appointments for various periods as principal of the college, and as principal of the Rajkumar College, Kathiawar; promoted to 3rd grade of the department, April, 1885.

SELLS, Arthur, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Muzaffarnagar, Aug., 1878, and civil and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Cawnpore, April, 1882; district and sessions judge, Meerut, Oct., 1886; retired May, 1890.

SETON-KARR, Walter Scott, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, where he gained honours, in 1842; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1842; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate of Jessore, 1847; under secretary, government of Bengal, 1847-53; member of council of education, 1853; collector of Tirhoot, 1857; civil and sessions judge, Jessore, 1858-60; president of indigo commission, 1860; secretary to government of Bengal, 1860-61; legislative council of India, 1861; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Chittagong, and member of council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1862; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, July, 1862, to April, 1868; foreign secretary, government of India, April, 1868; retired, 1870; vice-chancellor of the University of Calcutta in 1868 and 1869; is a member of the council of Marlborough College.

SEWELL, Ebenezer James, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India; 1st Nov., 1872, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting principal assistant collector and additional sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; on famine duty, June, 1877, to Sept., 1878; senior assistant collector and magistrate, Ganjam, June, 1882; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Dec., 1887; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1889; collector and magistrate, Feb., 1890.

SEWELL, Henry, M.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Radley, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras, as assistant magistrate and collector, acting small cause court judge, acting
under secretary to government in the revenue department, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting district and sessions judge, North Arcot, June, 1874, to April, 1875; from May, 1875, served as collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, and political agent, Pudukkottai; district and sessions judge, North Arcot, Nov., 1886; collector and magistrate, South Arcot, Nov., 1887; retired, Jan., 1891.

SEWELL, ROBERT, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1868, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-secretary to the board of revenue, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; on famine duty, Oct., 1877, and on special duty in connection with the archaeological survey of the Madras presidency, Jan., 1881, and again, Jan., 1883; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Tinnevelly, Sept., 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1887; acted as collector and magistrate, and in Sept., 1888, was appointed district and sessions judge, Kistna; collector and magistrate, June, 1890; is the author of the following works, published by order of government:—'A Report on the Amaraviti Tope, and Excavations on its Site,' 1880; 'Chronological Tables for Southern India from the 6th Century, A.D.,' 1881; 'A Sketch of the Dynasties of Southern India,' 1883; volumes I. and II. of the 'Archaeological Survey Series of Southern India,' 1882 and 1884; 'Early Buddhist Symbolism,' 1886.

SHAKESPEAR, ALEXANDER MURISON WAKE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Aug., 1887; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1890.
