Provinces.—Educated at Perth, and afterwards at the University of Edinburgh; called to the Scotch bar, July, 1840; and to the English bar at Lincoln's Inn, June, 1856; practised at the chancery bar as an equity draughtsman and conveyancer, and as an advising counsel; practised also in the House of Lords and privy council, and before parliamentary committees of both houses until 1868, when he was appointed Q.C., and soon after elected a bencher of his inn; appointed chief justice of the north-west provinces, India, and knighted, August, 1871; retired, March, 1884; is a member of the general council of the University of Edinburgh, and has been a frequent contributor to periodical literature, especially on legal subjects; author of many legal pamphlets.

STUART, R. G., Political Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 19th Feb., 1873; clerk specially attached to the political and secret department, Feb., 1876.

STULPNAGEL, CHARLES REBSCH, Dr., Ph.D., M.A., Education Department, Punjab.—Served in the Punjab education department from 25th April, 1867, in the Zillah schools at Peshawur, Delhi and Lahore, and in the government college, Lahore; assistant professor, government college, Lahore, Jan., 1875; was appointed professor, July, 1875, and officiated for various periods as principal of the college; inspector of schools, Lahore circle, May, 1885; and grade of the education department, Feb., 1886; principal, Government College, April, 1886; inspector of schools, May, 1886.

STURROCK, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at the High School, Dundee; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1866; acting secretary to government in the revenue department, Nov., 1873; boundary commissioner between Canara and Mysore, May, 1873, and again in 1880-81; Canarese translator to government, Jan., 1874; under secretary to government in the chief secretary's department, July, 1875; additional sub-secretary, board of revenue, for special duty with famine commission, Nov., 1878, also acting as secretary, Jan., 1879; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1879; collector and magistrate, South Canara, Oct., 1883; acting 4th member of board of revenue and commissioner of salt revenue, &c., July, 1888.

STURT, W. NEVILLE, Political Department, India Office.—Educated at Repton; temporary clerk, 1st May, 1862; junior clerk, store department, 1862; accountant-general's department, 1863; military department, 1863; private secretary to parliamentary under-secretary of state, 1863-64, and 1868-77; senior clerk, revenue department, April, 1877; transferred temporarily to political and secret department, April, 1890.
SULLIVAN, Henry Edward, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1850; served in revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed small cause court judge, Cuddalore, Sept., 1866; civil and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Dec., 1866; collector and magistrate, Bellary, March, 1868, and subsequently of Trichinopoly; officiating director of revenue settlement, Feb., 1874; acting member, board of revenue, and president of the committee for examination of assistants, April, 1876; in charge of the Inam department, May, 1876; acting resident of Travancore and Cochin, March, 1877, to Feb., 1878; board of revenue, April, 1878; famine commission, Jan., 1879; 1st member, board of revenue, and commissioner, uncovenanted civil service examinations, Jan., 1879; on duty studying records of famine commission, April, 1879; on special duty in Godavari district, investigating causes of the disturbances in Rumpa country, July, 1879; on duty to England as member of famine commission, Oct., 1879, to July, 1880; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, Jan., 1881; in charge of settlement department, Feb., 1881; ordinary member of council, June, 1882; president of local self-government committee, June, 1882; retired, Dec., 1886.

SURYA KUMAR AGASTI, M.A. Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules; assistant magistrate and collector, Purneah, on probation, March, 1885; confirmed in the statutory civil service, April, 1887.

SWAIN, W. H., B.Sc. (Honours) London, 1883, Military Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 4th June, 1881.

SWETENHAM, Edmund, Colonel, B.S.C., late Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined public works department from Roorkee college, Nov., 1853, and served in the Punjab; resigned on obtaining commission in the army, March, 1857; served in the N.W. frontier campaign, 1858 (medal); reappointed to public works department, Feb., 1859, and served in N.W. Provinces, buildings and roads branch; executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1860; transferred to British Burma, May, 1872; transferred to Central India, and served from Sept., 1874, to Aug., 1880, as executive engineer, Mhow division, and acted for various periods as chief engineer; and secretary to governor-general's agent; transferred to N.W. Provinces, buildings and roads branch, Aug., 1880, and promoted to superintending engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1880; 2nd class, July, 1884; 1st class, permanent, April, 1883; retired Feb., 1890.

SYAD ALAY MAHOMED, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Acting extra assistant commissioner, 4th class, 28th Jan., 1881; probationer for the native civil service, Dec., 1882; appointed member of the civil service, and acting assistant commissioner, 2nd class, Raipur, Dec., 1883.

SYAD NUR-UD-DIN KHAN, Bombay C.S.—Served in Hyderabad from May, 1879, as attaché to Resident, judge of small causes, &c.; assistant commissioner, Jan., 1883; undersecretary to Hyderabad state, Jan., 1883; appointed a probationer under native civil service rules, March, 1886; assistant collector, Jan., 1888; assistant commissioner, Khandesh, Dec., 1883.

SYAD NURUL HUDA, B.A., LL.B. (Barister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Officiating munshi, March, 1886; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1886.

SYKES, Robert, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Giggleswick Grammar School and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1888; and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

SYMES, Edward Spence, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1875, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma, Aug., 1876; served as assistant commissioner, and was placed on special duty in the secretariat, July and Nov., 1878; on special forest demarcation duty, Feb., 1879; personal assistant to chief commissioner, May, 1879; junior secretary to chief commissioner, June, 1881; also officiated as secretary to the chief commissioner for various periods, and as settlement secretary, March-May, 1882; secretary to chief commissioner and officer in charge of Delhi state prisoners, Apr., 1886; C.I.E., May, 1886; chief secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1887.

SYMNS, Robert Corser Montfort, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Westminster, King's College School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1883, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

SYMonds, William Powell, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Hereford Cathedral School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; member of the central committee for departmental examinations, April, 1884; acting under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, 1884; forest settlement officer, March, 1887; and assistant collector, and acting director of land records and agriculture, Aug., 1887; acting first assistant collector and magistrate, Poona, Nov., 1887; on special duty, Kathiawar, March, 1889; postmaster-general of Bombay, May, 1889.

SZCZEPANSKI, Henry Charles Anthony, Colonel, B.S.C., Berar Commission.—First commission, Bengal infantry, June, 1857; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1857; was employed under the military department up to 1860, including service during the mutiny (medal); assistant commissioner, Punjab, July, 1860; on special famine duty, Nov., 1861; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, Nov., 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner (1st class, Feb., 1885); officiating judicial commissioner, Feb.-May, 1883, appointed commissioner, sub-pro tem., May, 1883; confirmed, Aug., 1889.

TALBOT, Adelbert Cecil, Major, C.I.E., B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, royal artillery, Jan., 1867; joined the Bengal staff corps, 1869, and served with 4th cavalry, Hyderabad contingent; on special duty with the Afghan commissioner, Seistan Arbitration, 1872-73; officiating assistant
agent, Rajputana, 1873; attaché, secretariat, foreign department, 1874; officiating assistant secretary to the government of India, legislative department, and officiating secretary to board of examiners, Calcutta, 1875-76; acting assistant resident, and assistant-general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti department, Hyderabad, 1878; 1st assistant agent, Rajputana, Feb., 1878; fellow of Calcutta University, March, 1879; additional political agent, Eastern Rajputana states, 1881; political agent, Bhurtapore and Kerowlee, 1882; political agent, Bikaniir, 1883; graded as additional political agent, 1st class; officiated as resident in Turkish Arabia; political agent in Bikaniir.

TALBOT, GERALD H., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley; supervisor, 1st grade, India store depot, 19th June, 1877.

TANNER, HENRY CHARLES BASKERVILLE, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Survey of India.—First commission, Bombay artillery, June, 1854; accompanied the Persian expeditionary force of 1856 (medal and clasp); joined the survey department as assistant in the Sind revenue survey, Oct., 1862; was afterwards employed in the Central Provinces revenue survey, and was in charge of the Bombay city survey, Dec., 1869; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1870; was subsequently employed in the Bhawalpur revenue survey, and the Deccan survey, and accompanied the Lushai expedition in 1871-72, and the Khyber column in the Afghan campaign, 1878-79; was afterwards in charge of the Darjeeling and Nepal boundary parties, Nov., 1882; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Oct., 1884; employed with the Tibet mission from May, 1886.

TATE, ALEXANDER CHAMBERS, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant, Sept., 1888; and senior assistant, Nov., 1889.

TATE, WILLIAM JACOB, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1874, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant collector, Salem, Jan., 1883; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1889; district and sessions judge, March, 1890.

TAUNTON, A. G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the Jesuits' College, Tournay; writer, India store depot, 29th July, 1868; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

TAWNEY, C. H., C.I.E., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the department, Nov., 1864, and served as professor, Presidency College, up to Feb., 1877, when he was appointed principal of the college, and promoted to 1st class of the educational service; officiating director of public instruction, Aug., 1879, and again in 1885, and in 1889; is also registrar of the Calcutta University.

TAWNEY, JAMES WALTER, late Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Repton School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1863; served as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner, Bhootan, till Oct., 1865, and subsequently in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; also acted as small cause court judge, and cantonment magistrate, Jubulpore, in 1873, and as small cause court judge of Nagpur in 1876; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Oct., 1881; retired, April, 1889.

TAYLER, SKIPWITH HENRY CHURCHILL, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 2nd March, 1853; between July, 1854, and Sept., 1872, served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade; from Sept., 1872, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, March, 1875; retired, April, 1887.

TAYLER, WILLIAM VANSITTART GRAHAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 6th Nov., 1855; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Pubna, Oct., 1866.

TAYLOR, FRANKLIN EDEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge, appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1886; and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

TAYLOR, SIR ALEXANDER, G.C.B., General R.E.—Educated at Hofuzl, Switzerland, and Addiscombe military college; 1st commission, 9th June, 1843; major, Jan., 1858; colonel, March, 1864; lieutenant-general, Oct., 1877; and general (honorary rank), Dec., 1878; entered the Indian public works department, 26th Dec., 1846, as assistant engineer; executive engineer, Jan., 1848; superintendent of the Lahore and Peshawur road, Dec., 1849; superintending engineer, Nov., 1856; officiating secretary to the government of the Punjab, public works department, Jan., 1865, to Jan., 1867, and Feb., 1871, to Feb., 1872; chief engineer, April, 1872; deputy inspector-general of military works, 1879-1878; president of the defence committee of India, 1876, 1877, 1878; president of the royal Indian engineering college, Cooper's Hill, from Nov., 1886; served throughout the Sutlej campaign (medal with clasps for Ferozeshah and Sobraon), and throughout the Punjab campaign, 1848-9, being present at the action of Sooruj Khond, the capture of Mooltan, and the battle of Goojerat (medal with 2 clasps); served throughout the Indian mutiny of 1857-8; present at the operations before, and at the siege and capture of Delhi; commanded the Bengal engineers at siege and capture of Lucknow (medal with 2 clasps); served during the Umbeyla campaign, 1863; C.B. in 1858, K.C.B. in 1877, and G.C.B. in 1889.

TAYLOR, FREDERICK BEATSON, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector,
2nd grade, Apr., 1836; 1st grade, Jan., 1838, has also officiated as district and sessions judge.

TAYLOR, GEORGE NOBLE, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, in 1840; served in the grades of assistant and head assistant collector and magistrate, and was appointed secretary to the college and university boards, and assistant collector of customs at Madras in special charge of the salt department, 1840; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Rajamundry, 1851; acted as collector and magistrate of Nellore in 1857, and of South Arcot in 1858; Inam commissioner, 1858; special commissioner for railways, Calcutta, to report upon the affairs of the East Indian railway, May, 1863, and subsequently held a similar post at Bombay; provisional member of governor-general's council, 1864; ordinary member of council, March, 1865; retired, March, 1870.

TAYLOR, HERBERT DOUGLAS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886; manager of Jaypore Estate, Nov., 1889.

TAYLOR, JAMES, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, 1st Sept., 1865, and served in Bengal as assistant to the accountant-general, and deputy accountant-general; assistant comptroller-general, June, 1879.

TAYLOR, S. A., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Epsom College; junior clerk, India office, 31st Jan., 1867; senior clerk, Jan., 1890.

TEAGUE, GEORGE F., Funds Department, India Office.—Senior book-keeper, funds department, India office, 28th Sept., 1866; head book-keeper, March, 1873.

TEHEIRUDDIN AHMED, B.L., Bengal, C.S.—Appointed probationer under the Native civil service rules, 13th Feb., 1890.

TEMPLE, HENRY MARTINDALE, Captain, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Sub-lieutenant, 41st regiment, June, 1872; arrived in India, Sept., 1872; extra aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor, Bengal, Dec., 1875; junior attaché, foreign department, government of India, March, 1876; senior attaché, June, 1877; cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, Feb., 1878; assistant to resident, Hyderabad, and assistant general superintendent, Thagi and Dakaiti, Oct., 1880; officiating judicial superintendent of railways, Nizam's Dominions, June, 1881; assistant to governor-general's agent, Baroda, Nov., 1882; boundary settlement officer, Bundelkund, Nov., 1884; political agent, Kalat, May, 1885; political assistant, 1st class, March, 1886; political agent, South Eastern Baluchistan, May, 1887; and at Kalat, Nov., 1887.

TEMPLE, JAMES HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Burnley Grammar School, Repton School, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed member of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India 20th Dec., 1886; and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

TEMPLE, JOHN ALEXANDER, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1860; arrived in India, 10th Aug., 1861; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and acted at various times as cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Jubbulpore, and Kamptee; small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, May, 1872-74, and again, 1877; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Nov., 1884; 2nd class, sub-pro tem., Feb., 1888, and permanent, Sept., 1889.

TEMPLE, SIR RICHARD, Bart., G.C.S.I., C.I.E., D.C.L. (Oxon), LL.D. (Cantab), late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1846; served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab in the grades of assistant commissioner and assistant magistrate and collector; settlement officer, trans-Sutlej division, 1852; secretary to chief commissioner, Punjab, 1854; commissioner, Lahore, 1859; chief commissioner of currency and chief assistant to financial member of council, 1860; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1865; resident, Hyderabad, 1867; member of governor-general's council, 25th April, 1868; president of the statistical committee, 1868; lieutenant governor of Bengal, 1874; governor of Bombay, 30th April, 1877, to 1880; retired from the civil service in 1877; chairman of the board of visitors, Royal Indian Engineering College, Cooper's Hill, 1880; in the general election of Nov., 1885, was returned for Evesham, and again in the election of July, 1886; has been a member of the London School Board since 1884; vice-chairman, 1885-8; author of 'Men and Events of my Time in India,' 1882, and 'Oriental Experience,' 1883.

TEMPLE, RICHARD CARNAC, Major, B.S.C.—First commission, 4th Jan., 1871; from 11th Aug., 1879, served in the Punjab as assistant cantonment magistrate, and cantonment magistrate, and was promoted to 1st class magistrate, Oct., 1882; transferred to Burma as cantonment magistrate, Mandalay, March, 1887; assistant commissioner, April, 1887; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1888; provisional superintendent of census, 1890; author of "Notes on the Transliteration of the Burmese Alphabet," "A dissertation on the proper names of the Punjabis," "Wide awake stories" (Punjabi and Cashmiri Folk Tales), and other works; also founded and conducted "Indian Notes and Queries."

TENNANT, JAMES FRANCIS, Lieutenant-General, C.I.E., R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1847; arrived in India, 7th March, 1849; assistant engineer, Ganges canal, 1849 to 1851; assistant in the great trigonometrical survey of India, 1851 to 1859; was garrison engineer to the Delhi field force, and served at the siege and assault of Delhi, and at the siege and capture of Lucknow (medal with two clasps, and brevet of major); government astronomer at Madras, Oct. 1859, to Oct., 1860; commandant, sappers and miners, Oct., 1860, to Sept., 1863; served in the public works department, Sept., 1863, to July, 1871, as executive engineer in Burma, and in the Punjab and Bengal; while on leave was appointed to observe eclipse of the sun, 1867-68, and was deputed for a similar duty in 1871; served as mint master, Calcutta, from July, 1871, to Jan., 1884; on special duty in England, Feb.-April, 1872; superintended the observations of the transit of Venus at Roorkee and Lahore, 1876; C.I.E., Jan., 1879; retired from military service and civil duties on 10th Jan., 1884; is a fellow of the Royal Society, and of the Royal Astronomical Society.
TEUNON, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1884; transferred to Assam as assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Jan., 1888; and class, Sept., 1888.

THOM, WILLIAM, Surgeon-General, F.R.C.S., late Bombay Medical Service.—Educated at Marischal College, and University of Aberdeen, and at University College, London, and in Paris; F.R.C.S., England; fellow of university of Bombay; assistant surgeon on the Bombay establishment, 1841; served under the military department, first with the artillery, and then with the 3rd regiment native infantry, the 2nd Beloch battalion, the Bombay fustillers, and the 17th native infantry at Baroda; surgeon, 1854; served subsequently at Belgaum and Poona; in medical charge, marine battalion, Bombay, May, 1860; garrison surgeon, and surgeon to the European general hospital, 1861; served on the medical board of the India office, 1866-67; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, March, 1867; surgeon-general, Feb., 1874; retired, Sept., 1877.

THOMAS, GEORGE EBENEZER, M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Burma.—Appointed from the East India railway as assistant engineer, 28th Aug., 1867, and posted to the Central Provinces; transferred to the Punjab northern state railway, March, 1868; locomotive superintendent, Punjab northern state railway, April, 1875; executive engineer, April, 1876; transferred to Indus Valley state railway, Nov., 1878; 2nd class, revenue establishment, July, 1879; transferred to British Burma, Nov., 1881; class 1, grade 3, revenue scale, Jan., 1887; retired 1889.

THOMAS, HENRY SULLIVAN, F.L.S., F.Z.S., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting collector of sea customs, member of the board of examiners, and acting civil and sessions judge; from May, 1867, to Sept., 1874, served as collector and magistrate of South Canara, and subsequently at Tanjore, and as political agent for French settlement at Karikal; from April, 1878, served on the board of revenue, Madras, and acted as secretary to government in the revenue department in 1878-79; in charge of the Inam department, Jan.-April, 1879; president, board of examiners, Oct., 1881; on special duty as a member of the local self-government committee, Sept., 1882; on duty to Calcutta as an additional member of the governor-general's council for laws and regulations, Dec., 1882; and again, Dec., 1883; on special duty in connection with the pearl fisheries at Tuticorin, and deputed to study system of management in force in Ceylon, March-May, 1884; 1st member, board of revenue, July, 1884; on deputation to Tanjore district to report on necessity for granting remissions, April, 1885; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886; on special duty to Madura, March to Sept., 1886, and to Delhi, to attend conference on agricultural and veterinary questions, March, 1888; on special duty drawing Fisheries Bill, April, 1888; retired, Jan., 1889; has published 'A Report on Pisciculture in South Canara,' 1870; 'The Rod in India,' 1881; and 'A Report on Pearl Fisheries and Chauk Fisheries,' 1884.

THOMAS, ROBERT MOSELY BRYCE, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission as ensign, 6th Jan., 1859; arrived in India, 26th Feb., 1859; from Oct., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, and acting small cause court judge, and was appointed cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, Nov., 1876, and subsequently at Kamptee; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1885.

THOMAS, WILLIAM CHARLES, Lieut.-Colonel, Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as officiating adjutant of military police, Mainpuri, Dec., 1858, having previously served as a volunteer in General Havelock's cavalry, 1857-58; adjutant of military police, Oct., 1859; inspector of district police, Jan., 1861; district superintendent of police, May, 1861; officiated as assistant inspector-general of the government railway police, July-Oct., 1868; on special duty with the camp of the lieutenant-governor, Dec., 1876, and again in March, 1878, with the governor-general's camp; 1st grade superintendent, Lucknow, April, 1885; deputy inspector-general of police, May, 1886.

THOMASON, CHARLES SIMEON, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1852; joined the public works department, July, 1855, as deputy superintendent, Ganges canal; during the mutiny served at the battle of Budlekeserai and the siege of Delhi (medal and clasp); executive engineer, Oct., 1858; superintendent Rohilkund canals, Dec., 1864; officiating superintending engineer and deputy secretary, public works department, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1873; on special duty to Madras, in connection with harbours work, 1877-79; superintending engineer and secretary to governor-general's agent, Central India, Aug., 1880; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1882; retired, May, 1888.

THOMPSON, ARTHUR, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Cuthbert's, Ushaw, and University of London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting principal assistant, assistant sessions judge, acting sub-collector, and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate, and district and sessions judge, head assistant collector, Cuddapah, Nov., 1884; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1890.

THOMPSON, C. T., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th March, 1882.

THOMPSON, DANIEL ROBERT, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.I.E., M.R.C.S., and L.M., late Madras Medical Service.—Acting civil surgeon, Tellicherry, April, 1865, to Sept., 1866; joined the Indian medical service as assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1867; and served under the military department, also acting as Zillah surgeon and superintendent of jail at Chingleput, April, 1868; and at Tinnevelly, April, 1869, to Sept., 1870; in medical charge of garrison, lock hospital, and meteorological observatories, Bellary, Dec., 1873; resident surgeon, general hospital, Madras, and pro-
fessor of pathology and materia medica in Medical College, March, 1875; from May, 1875, served as surgeon, 1st district, Madras, and medical inspector of emigrants; also superintendent of auxiliary provincial medical school, and native infirmary, Royapooram; C.I.E. for special famine services in 1876-78, 1st Jan., 1879; surgeon major, April, 1879; retired, May, 1888.

THOMPSON, David William, Educational Department, Punjab.—Served in the education department from Jan., 1863, as master in the Zillah Schools at Lahore and Amritsar; inspector of schools, May, 1870; 3rd grade of the department, Nov., 1883.

THOMPSON, Frederick C., Public Works Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, accounts branch, 9th March, 1872; public works department, Aug., 1875; editor of India Office List, 1885-7; senior clerk, 1887.

THOMPSON, George, B.A., Educational Department, Central Provinces.—Head master, Saugor high school, Sept., 1869, to Oct., 1875; served from Oct., 1875, as inspector of schools, Central Provinces; was deputed to attend educational conferences at Naini Tal in 1885 and 1886; officiating inspector-general of education, May, 1889.

THOMPSON, Henry Edward, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as Morse assistant, 12th May, 1857; arrived in India, 12th Sept., 1857; superintendent, Dec., 1866; held charge of various divisions, including Malabar, Bangalore, Arakan, Nagpur.

THOMPSON, Ross, Colonel R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission, June, 1858; arrived in India, 14th Jan., 1861; joined the public works department, Aug., 1863; executive engineer, April, 1867; district engineer, presidency, April, 1875; consulting architect to government, May, 1875; commanded Queen's Own sappers and miners, throughout the Afghan war, 1879-80 (medal); rejoined public works department, Nov., 1880; acted as deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government, Oct., 1881; posted to West Coast division, Oct., 1884; and to presidency division, April, 1886.

THOMSON, A., Education Department, N.W. Provinces.—Served in Oudh, Aug., 1866, to April, 1877, as inspector of schools, and acted as director of public instruction in 1866 and 1868; from April, 1877, served as professor of English literature in the Agra College, and acted for various periods as principal; 3rd grade, educational department, May, 1886.

THOMSON, Andrew, Bengal, C.S., Burma.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, Dec., 1885; served in Burma as assistant commissioner; transferred to Upper Burma on special duty, March, 1886; personal assistant to chief commissioner, March, 1887; officiated as under secretary to chief commissioner, Feb. to April, 1888.

THOMSON, G., Brigade-Surgeon, M.B., Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, April, 1866; served in military department to July, 1879; services placed at the disposal of the Punjab government, and appointed officiating civil surgeon, 2nd class, Aug., 1879; confirmed in his appointment, Oct., 1880; medical adviser to H.H. the Maharaja of Patiola, in 1882 and 1888.

THOMSON, James, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Grammar School, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1871, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; sub-collector, joint magistrate and principal assistant to collector, magistrate and agent, Godaveri, June, 1885; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1890.

THOMSON, John Brown, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Academy, and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, Nov., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Feb., 1882; deputy superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, Nov., 1882; registrar of the high court, N.W. Provinces, May, 1884; magistrate and collector, April, 1886; officiated as secretary to government in 1886 and 1890.

THOMSON, Robert George, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Islington Proprietary School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; junior secretary to financial commissioner, Dec., 1882; officiating under secretary (revenue department) to government, Punjab, June, 1883; officiating junior secretary to government, Jan., 1884, and again in 1885 and 1886; senior secretary to financial commissioner, May, 1886; on special duty revising rules under the Punjab land revenue bill; postmaster-general, Punjab, Feb., 1888; junior secretary to Government of Punjab, and officiating revenue secretary, April, 1890.

THOMSON, Samuel John, Surgeon-Major, North-Western Provinces, Medical Department.—Joined the service as surgeon, 1st Oct., 1877; arrived in India, 27th April, 1878; served on military, general, and jail duty, and as officiating deputy sanitary commissioner, and was confirmed in that office, May, 1885; officiated as sanitary commissioner in 1887.

THORBURN, Septimus Smet, F.R.G.S., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating divisional judge, and settlement officer, and officiating commissioner and superintendent; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Jan., 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1885; 1st grade, March, 1889; author of 'Bannu, or Our Afghan Frontier,' David Leslie,' and a report on the settlement of the Bannu district.

THORBURN, Walter Miller, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Dalhousie College, and University, Halifax, University of Edinburgh, and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 26th Nov.,
1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nellore, Oct., 1884.

THORNHILL, EDMUND BENSLEY, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 16th Aug., 1854; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating small cause court judge; from Feb. to Sept., 1865, served in Oudh as officiating deputy commissioner, Fyzabad; magistrate and collector, Banda, March, 1872; civil and sessions judge, Banda, Nov., 1877; retired in 1885.

THORNHILL, GEORGE, C.S.I., late Madras Civil Service.—Educated at Rugby, and Haileybury, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1842; arrived in Madras, 7th April, 1843; served as assistant to collector and magistrate in various districts, and was employed as civil officer in connection with the construction of the Godavari and Kista anicuts; principal assistant to collector and magistrate, Ganjam, 1856; collector and magistrate, Kista, 1861; member of board of revenue, 1870-78, during which period he was frequently employed by government on special duties of various kinds; was also appointed director of bank of Madras, and commissioner for unencumbered civil service examinations, 1875; retired, 1878.

THORNHILL, HENRY BEAUFROY, Captain, Andaman and Nicobar Islands administration.—1st commission, 23rd April, 1873; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1873; on field service, Afghanistan, Oct., 1873, to April, 1879 (medal); cantonment magistrate, Feb., 1887; appointed deputy superintendent, Port Blair, May, 1888.

THORNTON, ARTHUR PARRY, Major, B.S.C.—Ensign, 14th foot, 14th Sept., 1867; arrived in India, Jan., 1868; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, Sept., 1871; served under government of Bengal in Purneah and Burdwan as relief circle officer during famine, March-Dec., 1874; served under the foreign department of the government of India from Jan., 1875, and acted as assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, and as magistrate, Mount Abu, and assistant general superintendent for suppression of thuggee and dacoity; in charge of office of political agent, Marwar, Jan.-March, 1877; attaché to foreign office during Delhi durbar, 1876-77; on military duty, 1878-79; from March, 1879, served under foreign department as cantonment magistrate at Morar, and at Nasirabad; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, Jan., 1882; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Secunderabad, Feb., 1884; political agent, Bhopawur, May, 1886, and afterwards in Harowte and Tonk.

THORNTON, EDWARD, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse, and at Haileybury College, where he obtained honours, and from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1829; arrived in India, Feb., 1830; served in the N.W. Provinces, first as settlement officer, and afterwards as magistrate and collector; commissioner in the Punjab, Jhelum division, 1849-58; made C.B. for his services during the mutiny; judicial commissioner of the Punjab, 1858; retired, 1860.

THORNTON, JAMES HOWARD, Deputy Surgeon-General, C.B., B.A. and M.D. (London), Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1856; from 9th Nov., 1861, served as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon, besides service under the military department; rank of surgeon-major, Jan., 1868, and brigade surgeon, March, 1882; principal medical officer with the Indian forces, Egypt, 1885; C.B., Aug. 1885; deputy surgeon-general, Punjab frontier force, June, 1886.

THORNTON, LESLIE MELVILLE, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1881, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Oct., 1883; under secretary to government, Oct., 1886.

THORNTON, THOMAS HENRY, C.S.I., D.C.L., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and St. John's College, Oxford (1st class moderations; Pusey and Ellerton Hebrew scholar; 2nd class, final schools); appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition, 1855; assistant commissioner, Punjab, 1857-59; personal assistant to financial commissioner, Punjab, 1859-60; personal assistant to judicial commissioner, 1860-62; small cause court judge, Lahore, 1862-63; deputy commissioner, Delhi, 1863-64; secretary to the government of the Punjab, 1864-78, and was on two occasions temporarily in charge of the administration of the province; acted as foreign secretary to the government of India, 1876-77; additional member of governor-general's council, 1877-79; judge, chief court, Punjab, 1878-81; retired, 1881; fellow of University of Calcutta, 1875; vice-president, University College, Lahore, 1879.

THUILLIER, SIR HENRY EDWARD LANDOR, General, Kt., C.S.I., R.A., F.R.S., late Survey of India.—Educated at Addiscombe, 1831-32; first commission, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1832; arrived in India, 19th Oct., 1833; served in the survey department, from Dec., 1836, and conducted the surveys of Jyntcah, the Pooree division of Cuttack, and the district of Cachar, and part of Sylhet; while on furlough to England, 1844-46, was orderly officer of Warley barracks for a year; deputy surveyor-general of India, Jan., 1847, to March, 1861, when he was appointed surveyor-general of India; retired Dec., 1877; lieutenant-colonel, 1861; companion of the Star of India, May, 1870; knighted in 1879; major-general in 1870; lieutenant-general, July, 1879; general, July, 1881; colonel commandant, R.A., Jan., 1883; joint author of the 'Manual of Survey for India.'

THUILLIER, HENRY RAVENSHAW, Colonel, R.E., Survey of India.—Addiscombe, Aug., 1855, to June, 1857; lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1857; arrived in India, 29th April, 1859; appointed to the survey department as assistant in the great trigonometrical survey, May, 1859; deputy superintendent, Sept., 1869; officiating superintendent, great trigonometrical survey, April-Oct., 1876; 1st grade deputy superintendent, Oct., 1878; deputy surveyor-general in charge of the revenue survey branch, Oct., 1884; acting surveyor-general from Feb., 1886; was confirmed, Feb., 1887.
TIDY, WILLIAM MEYMOOTT, M.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1860; served in the N.W. Provinces from Aug., 1862, as assistant magistrate and collector; and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Sept., 1878; retired, 1886.

TINNEY, G. F., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 4th July, 1882.

TIRUVARUR MUTTUSWAMI AIYAR, SWAMINATHA AIYAR, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Madras University; appointed probationer for the civil service, Nov., 1883; confirmed as a member of the Madras civil service, Jan., 1886; acting head assistant collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly.

TODD, JAMES HENTHORN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Worcester College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting district superintendent of police, and acting collector and magistrate; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1886.

TODD-NAYLOR, HENRY PAUL, C.I.E., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, March, 1886; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, April, 1886; officiating deputy commissioner; C.I.E., Jan., 1890.

TOMKINS, WILLIAM PERCVIAL, C.I.E., Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1860; joined the public works department, June, 1863, as assistant engineer, Assam; transferred to Rangoon, British Burma, Jan., 1865; acted as assistant to chief engineer and assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Jan., Aug., 1865; executive engineer, Oct., 1866; transferred to military works branch, Nov., 1873; assistant secretary to government of India, civil and military works branch, April, 1880; superintending engineer and secretary to agent to governor-general, Beloochistan, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Aug., 1884; 2nd class, May., 1888; 1st class, Dec., 1889; C.I.E., Jan., 1890.

TOMLINSON, THOMAS ARMSTRONG, Madras Revenue Survey Department.—Appointed 10th Aug., 1859, and served as assistant superintendent and acting deputy superintendent on special duty, Pudukota boundary, Feb., 1877, and June, 1888; deputy superintendent, 1st class, Nov., 1887.

TOTTEHAM, LOFTUS RICHARD, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 11th July, 1856; served as assistant, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; also as superintendent of stamps and stationery, Jan., 1866, and registrar of the high court, Dec., 1866; from Jan., 1874, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge, and officiated as superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Feb., 1878; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 16th July, 1879.

TOWERS, ROBERT MASON, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 21st Jan., 1863; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1863; from July, 1867, served in the judicial department as small cause court judge and district and sessions judge; judge of the principal courts of small causes in Nudda and Jessore, Feb., 1879; from Jan., 1878, to Feb., 1880, served as officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur; served subsequently as district and sessions judge, and was promoted to 1st grade, May, 1885; retired, 1888.

TOWNSEND, STEPHEN CHAPMAN, Surgeon-General, C.B., late Bengal Medical Service.—Educated at the Grammar School, Ottery St. Mary, Devon, and the London Hospital Medical School; assistant-surgeon in the Indian medical service, June, 1852; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1852; employed in regimental and other military duty to Feb., 1862, and served in the Burma campaign, 1852-53; civil surgeon, Nagpur, Jan., 1865 to March 1868; sanitary commissioner, Central Provinces, March, 1868, to Oct., 1878, and officiated as sanitary commissioner with the government of India, Feb., 1877 to March 1878; rank of deputy surgeon-general, Dec., 1878; principal medical officer with the Kuram field force under General Sir F. Roberts, April, 1879; and was wounded in action, Sept., 1879; surgeon-general with the Punjab government, April, 1880; Companion of the Bath, Feb., 1881; retired, Dec., 1883.

TOYNBEE, GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 27th Nov., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1866; superintendent canal revenue, Oct., 1871; on famine relief duty, Nov., 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, lower provinces, Dec., 1874; second inspector of registration offices, April, 1877; on special duty connected with compulsory irrigation rate, May, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1878; special duty at the Bengal secretariat, July, 1878; magistrate and collector, and grade, Dec., 1885, and 1st grade, Oct., 1889; author of 'Sketch of the History of Orissa from 1803 to 1828,' and 'A Chowkidari Manual.'

TOZER, H. J., B.A., London, (Honours), Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th Jan., 1882.

TRACY, THOMAS BURROWES, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1857; served in the N.W. Provinces from Nov., 1858, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Muttra, April, 1877; from Feb., 1883, served as civil and sessions judge, and acted as judicial commissioner in Oudh, 1884-85; retired, Sept., 1887.

TRAFFORD, RICHARD WYLME, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Sept., 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Dec., 1886, and 2nd grade, Nov., 1889.
TRAIL, David Henry, Colonel, R.E., late Bengal Public Works Department, Accounts Branch.—1st commission Madras engineers, 1856; from Sept., 1859, served in the Madras public works department; served in the China war, 1860, and was present at the battle of Sinho, and capture of Tangku and Taku forts (medal and clasp); employed in the great trigonometrical survey of India, March, 1862; assistant engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1865; from Jan., 1866, was employed in the accounts branch of the public works department, and served as controller of accounts in Mysore, Madras, Punjab, and Central Provinces; transferred to Bengal, Nov., 1882; examiner of public works accounts, 1st class, Feb., 1884; officiating accountant-general, and deputy secretary, government of India, P.W. department, April-June, 1883; examiner, public works accounts, Bengal, Dec., 1887; retired, Nov., 1890.

TREASURE, Henry, late Legal Department, India Office.—Solicitor of the supreme court, admitted, 1859; principal clerk to legal adviser to the secretary of state, May, 1877; retired, 1887.

TREASURE, W. H., Legal Department, India Office.—Clerk to the legal adviser to the secretary of state, June, 1877; solicitor of the supreme court, 1887.

TREMENHEERE, Charles William, Lieutenant-General, C.B., R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Educated at Adiscombe; 2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, 11th Dec., 1829; served as civil engineer in Dharwar, 1833-40, and as executive engineer Surat and Broach, and acting superintending engineer, Guzerat, 1843-45; assistant executive engineer, Aden, Jan., 1846, to Feb., 1847; from Dec., 1848 to March, 1850, served in Scinde as executive engineer, Kurrachee, and acting superintending engineer; dock yard, Bombay, March, 1850, to May, 1853; acting secretary, military board, May, 1853, to Jan., 1854; on special duty, Bombay, designing reclamations, docks, and fortifications, Jan., 1854, to Jan., 1855; major, Sept., 1855; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, Jan., 1855, to Aug., 1856; garrison engineer, Bombay, and acted as superintending engineer, Poona circle, 1856-57; was commanding engineer to the forces under Sir Hugh Rose, and General Roberts, 1857-58, and was present at the sieges of Awah and Kotah, and the engagements of Sanganeer and Kotare; Indian mutiny medal and clasp for Central India; military C.B., March, 1861; superintending engineer, southern provinces, Feb., 1860; chief engineer, Scinde, May, 1862; chief engineer, presidency, Nov., 1866; major-general, March, 1867; political resident, Aden, with command of the brigade, Dec., 1870; retired with hon. rank of lieutenant-general, July, 1874.

TREMENHEERE, James Henry Apperley, Madras C.S.—Educated at Lancing, and Cheltenham Colleges; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant commissioner (Nilgiris); from May to Aug., 1883, served in Mysore as acting civil and sessions judge; served subsequently in Madras as head assistant collector, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and was appointed acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, June, 1884; officiating private secretary to the governor of Madras, May to Aug., 1885; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Aug., 1888; collector and magistrate, and district and sessions judge.

TREMLETT, James Dyer, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and deputy commissioner; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Hissar, Aug., 1878; additional commissioner, Umballa and Jullundur, Nov., 1880; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st class, Sept., 1881; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, April, 1883; additional judge, chief court, April, 1884; divisional judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; judge, chief court, Punjab, Sept., 1886; retired, March, 1886.

TRETHEWY, Anthony William, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1885; served in the N.W. provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector.

TREVELYAN, Ernest John.—Advocate, high court, Calcutta, 1875-85; officiating secretary, board of examiners for pleaders, &c., 1875-82; officiating magistrate, Calcutta, N. division, 1876; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1885; president, board of examiners for pleaders and mookhtars, 1886.

TREVOR, Arthur Charles, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1861, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector of stamp revenue and political agent, acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, acting municipal commissioner, and deputy commissioner of customs and opium (June, 1877); collector of customs, Bombay, April, 1879; acting commissioner of customs, and collector of salt revenue, May, 1884, and July, 1888; senior collector, Dec., 1884; collector of salt revenue, Oct., 1885; 2nd grade commissioner and commissioner of customs, salt, opium, and abkari, and reporter-general of external commerce, Sept., 1888; 1st grade commissioner, and acting commissioner in Sind, May, 1889; also British delegate for the Portuguese treaty.

TREVOR, Charles Binny, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1830; arrived in India, 12th June, 1832; served in Bengal, in the grades of assistant commissioner, assistant collector and magistrate, and joint magistrate, and deputy collector; magistrate of Backergunge, June, 1840; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, 1849; judge of Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, presidency, 1859; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1863; retired in 1867.

TREVOR, Edward Walter, Colonel, Bombay S.C.—First commission, Infantry, April, 1855; arrived in India, 8th May, 1855; appointed acting superintendent of bazaars and cantonment magistrate, Neeruch, March, 1864; from Nov., 1864, served in Sind, as deputy collector and magistrate, acting district superintendent of
police, and acting collector and magistrate; on military duty, Oct., 1879, to Jan., 1881, as general transport officer, Khyber line, and director, Kuram transport; deputy commissioner, Upper Sind frontier, Jan., 1881; on special duty to Calcutta, in connection with the prosecution of commissariat frauds, Nov., 1881; collector and magistrate, Hyderabad, Dec., 1884.

TREVOR, FREDERICK G. B., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, and Marlborough College; East India House writer, old establishment, 10th March, 1858; junior clerk, public, educational, and ecclesiastical departments, Aug., 1860; senior clerk, July, 1875; judicial and public department, 1877; assistant secretary in that department, June, 1887.

TREVOR, GEORGE HERBERT, Colonel, M.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Joined the Madras artillery, 5th April, 1858; from June, 1862, served in the central provinces as inspector of schools, and was secretary to the Jabalpur exhibition committee in 1866; subsequently acted as cantonment magistrate, assistant secretary to chief commissioner, and assistant commissioner; from Oct., 1867, acted as assistant resident, Hyderabad; secretary for Berar, April, 1877; deputed to accompany Sir Salar Jung on his tour to Europe in 1867 as political officer; political agent, 1st class, July, 1881; officiated as resident at Hyderabad May-June, 1882; officiating resident 2nd class and commissioner, Ajmere-Merwara, Nov., 1885, and confirmed in those appointments, Nov., 1887; agent to governor-general, Rajputana, and Chief Commissioner of Ajmere-Merwara, March, 1890.

TREVOR, JOHN SALUSBURY, Major-General, C.S.I., late R.E.—Passed out of Addiscombe, June, 1847; 2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, April, 1848; assistant superintendent of roads and tanks, 1849-55; transferred to railway department in Aug., 1855, as deputy consulting engineer; municipal commissioner, Bombay, 1861; resigned appointment in railway department, 1864; rejoined the public works department in Nov., 1866, as executive engineer, 1st grade, Tapti irrigation; consulting engineer and under secretary to government of Bombay, railway branch, Nov., 1868; chief engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1870; acting deputy secretary to government of India in railway branch, 1871-72; resigned appointment in Bombay railway department, 1874; in England, 1874-78; officiating deputy secretary to government of India, railway branch, June, 1878; resigned the army, 1879, continuing in the public works department; director-general of railways, and deputy secretary, railway branch, 1880; retired in 1881; chairman of the Bombay, Baroda, and Central India, and the Rohilkund and Kumaon railway companies, and a director in several other Indian railway companies.

TREVOR, SALUSBURY THOMAS, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Bengal.—1st commission, Dec., 1852; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1854; from Jan., 1855, to Oct., 1863, served in British Burma as assistant engineer, executive engineer, assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to chief commissioner in the public works department; transferred to Bengal, Oct., 1863; served as garrison engineer, Fort William, and superintending engineer, 3rd class, and was appointed secretary to chief commissioner, Assam, public works department, July, 1869; chief engineer, and joint secretary public works department, Bengal, March, 1881; on deputation in connection with International Exhibition buildings at Calcutta, July, 1883; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, railways and roads and buildings, Jan., 1884; chief engineer, 1st class, July, 1885; retired, 1889.

TREVOR, WILLIAM SPOTTISWOODE, Major-General, V.C., R.E., late Public Works Department, India,—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1849; arrived in India, 5th Feb., 1852; served in the Burmese war, 1852-53 (medal with clasp); employed on the Pegu survey, 1854; executive engineer, Bassein, Nov., 1855; was subsequently posted to Darjeeling and Dinajpur; garrison engineer, Fort William, 1861; controller and examiner of accounts, Bengal, May, 1863; served the Bhutan campaign, 1865 (medal and V.C.); superintending engineer, Calcutta, Jan., 1867; consulting engineer to government of Bengal, irrigation, Jan., 1868; superintending engineer, military works, Calcutta, 1872; additional chief engineer for famine relief works, Bengal, 1874; officiating chief engineer and secretary to governor-general's agent, Indore, April-Dec., 1875; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, Feb., 1876; chief engineer and secretary, British Burma, Dec., 1878; director-general of railways and deputy secretary to government of India, March, 1881; secretary to government of India in the public works department, Feb., 1882; retired, 1887.

TRIMNELL, DAVID WILLIAM, Deputy Surgeon-General, late Central Provinces, Medical Service.—Joined the Madras medical service in 1856; served in the Saugor field division in 1857-58, and was present at the battle of Banda and other engagements; civil surgeon, Nar Singhpur, Central Provinces, 4th April, 1860; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Raipur, June, 1867; surgeon-major, Feb., 1876; brigade-surgeon, Aug., 1883; retired, Aug., 1887.

TROWARD, THOMAS, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 9th Oct., 1869, and served in the Punjab as assistant cantonment magistrate, assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1886; officiating divisional judge in 1887 and 1888, and appointed divisional judge, 3rd grade, May, 1889.

TRUEMAN, THOMAS, Colonel, Bombay S.C., late Cantonment Magistrate, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1856, and served on military duty up to June, 1872, including the mutiny campaign under Sir Hugh Rose (medal and clasp), and subsequently as assistant cantonment magistrate at Poona and Kirkee, and cantonment magistrate, and city magistrate, Káráchi; appointed cantonment magistrate, Ahmedabad, April, 1877, and subsequently at Belgaum; on famine duty, Sholapur, Sept., 1877; retired, Nov., 1883.

TUCKER, ALEXANDER LAUZUN PENDOCK, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and
Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1830; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1832; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1833; forest settlement office, Bijapur, Feb., 1836; services placed at disposal of government of India, foreign department, April, 1838; assistant to resident at Hyderabad, and assistant secretary for Berar; settlement officer, Kotputli (Jeyapore) in Rajputana; and afterwards assistant to the governor-general's agent, Central India.

TUCKER, Henry St. George, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1844; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; appointed commissioner in Burma, May, 1886; retired, Sept., 1890; author of 'Reports on the Settlement of the Dera Ismail Khan and Kohat Districts.'

TUCKER, Henry Pendock St. George, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, in 1842; arrived in India, 14th April, 1843; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge in various districts in the Bombay presidency, and acted as deputy registrar of the Sudder court in Bombay, in 1845-46, and as judge and sessions judge, in 1853, and in 1856-57; acting first assistant accountant-general, Bombay, July, 1858; acting civil auditor, Bombay, Dec., 1858 to March, 1859; collector and magistrate, North Canara, July, 1862; judge and sessions judge, Konkan, Aug., 1862; appointed to report on the measures necessary for a redistribution of judicial jurisdiction and modification of judicial establishments, Feb., 1863; officiating judge of the high court, Bombay, June, 1863; member of council, Bombay, 7th April, 1869; retired in 1876.

TUCKER, Louis Henry Emille, C.I.E., Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 1860; arrived in India, 11th April, 1861; from Sept., 1864, served in the police department, Punjab, as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; on special duty with Major Cavagnari in connection with Kabul war, Nov., 1878, and again with the staff of Major-General Bright, Sept., 1879; 1st grade, district superintendent, Sept., 1880; officiating deputy inspector-general, 2nd grade, March, 1885; confirmed in appointment, March, 1888; C.I.E., Jan., 1891.

TUDBALL, William, Bengal (N.W. Provinces, &c.).—Educated at Bedford Modern School and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

TUPP, Alfred Cotterell, B.A., F.S.S., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1862; from Oct., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty for the conduct of the case of the Munsif of Mahoba, Dec., 1867, and again, July, 1869, for the preparation of a statistical memoir of Futehpur; assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, April, 1871; also subordinate judge from March, 1873; held charge of Provincial Gazetteer of N.W. Provinces, March, 1876, to Feb., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Azimgarh, Aug., 1877; transferred to the financial department, government of India, Nov., 1878, and served in Madras, till 1881, as deputy accountant-general, deputy controller-general, and accountant-general, and commissioner of state paper currency; officiated as accountant-general in Bombay, Dec., 1881, to Dec., 1882, and in Bengal from the latter date; officiating comptroller-general, Sept.-Oct., 1883; from Nov., 1883, served as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and deputy commissioner of paper currency; accountant-general, class I., Nov., 1887; accountant-general of Bombay and commissioner of the department of state paper currency, Bombay, Dec., 1887; accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Nov., 1888; retired, Oct., 1889; author of 'The Indian Civil Service and the Competition System,' 1875; 'The Statistics of the North-West Provinces of India,' 1876; 'The Imperial Gazetteer of India—N.W.P. portion,' 1877; 'The Indian Civil Service List, and Record of Services,' 1880; 'The Paris International Monetary Conference of 1881, and Bimetallism,' 1881; 'The Competitive Civil Service of India, from 1856 to 1882,' 1882.

TUPPER, Charles Lewis, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Harrow, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating under secretary to government, and was placed on special duty in office of financial commissioner, Sept., 1874, and with H.H. the Maharaja of Patiala, Nov., 1875; appointed under secretary to government of Punjab, April, 1877; officiating under secretary to government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Sept., 1878; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1880; from Feb., 1880, served under the government of India as acting under secretary and acting secretary in the revenue and agricultural department, and was placed on special duty, Sept., 1881 (in connection with the Bengal Rent Bill), and again, Feb., 1882; junior secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1882; on special duty in connection with scheme of local self-government, June-Oct., 1883; acted as secretary to government, April, 1884, to Feb., 1886, and was on special duty in connection with the frontier crime commission, Feb.-March, 1886; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, Dec., 1887, confirmed, Nov., 1888; author of 'Customary Law of the Punjab.'

TURNER, Sir Charles Arthur, Kt., C.I.E., late Judicial Department, Madras.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford, fellow, 1855, B.A., 1856, M.A., 1859; called to the bar (Lincoln's Inn), 1858, and went the western circuit; appointed judge of the high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, and arrived in India, May, 1866; acted as chief justice in 1870, 1875, and 1878; chief justice of the high court of judicature, Madras, Jan., 1879; fellow of the University of Madras, Jan., 1879; member of the Indian law
commission, Bengal, Feb.-Sept., 1879; vice-chancellor of Madras University, April, 1880, and May, 1882; retired, 1st July, 1885; appointed member of the public service commission, 1885-6; member of the council of India, 2nd Feb., 1888.

TURNER, EDWARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in various districts of Madras from May, 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate, and was employed on state famine relief operations, Jan., 1877, to March, 1878; sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1882; collector and magistrate, Cuddapah, Jan., 1885; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Feb., 1885; collector and magistrate, Madura, Jan., 1886.

TURNER, HENRY GRIBBLE, Barrister-at-Law, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1866; from Aug., 1866, to Dec., 1867, served in the police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; on special duty, Madras, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, Jan., 1868; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, March, 1875; postmaster-general, Madras, March, 1875, to June, 1881; from June, 1881, acted as collector, magistrate, and political agent, Vizagapatam; appointed district and sessions judge, North Arcot, June, 1884, but continued to act as collector, &c., at Vizagapatam, and was confirmed in this post, Nov., 1885; retired, July, 1890.

TURNER, LAWRENCE HERBERT, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces)—Educated at City of London School, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service, after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

TURNER, SAMUEL COMPTON, Major, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 17th April, 1866; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1868, and joined the public works department as assistant engineer in Bombay, Jan., 1869; executive engineer, Feb., 1873; from Dec., 1873, served under the government of India; officiated as assistant secretary, military department in 1886 and 1887; 3rd superintending engineer, March, 1890.

TUTE, ARTHUR CLIFFORD, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871; assistant magistrate and collector, in Bengal, April, 1872; on famine relief duty, Salem, March, 1877, and at Trichinopoly, Sept., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1885; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, March, 1888; 2nd grade, April, 1890.

TWEEDIE, JOHN (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived 13th Dec., 1860; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, July, 1861; officiating superintendent, Chittagong hill tracts, June, 1863; deputy commissioner, Bhutan Dooars, Dec., 1864; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, Aug., 1870, to March, 1873; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dinapore relief works, March, 1874; from June, 1874, served in the judicial department, and was appointed judge of the small cause courts, Krishnagur, Ranaghat, and Meherpore, Oct., 1876; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Jan., 1881.

TWEEDIE, MAURICE, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, N.W. Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign, 23rd Oct., 1856; during the mutiny served with the field force in Central India, and subsequently with the mounted police in Oudh, and on the Nepal frontier (medal and clasp); from June, 1860, served as district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade, May, 1886; officiating junior deputy inspector-general, April, 1888; deputy inspector-general, Jan., 1890; Author of 'A Chapter on the Fauna of the Province of Oudh,' for incorporation in the Oudh Gazetteer.'

TWEEDIE, WILLIAM, Colonel, C.S.I., B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bengal infantry, Jan., 1857; during the mutiny served in Oudh, and was present at the siege and capture of Lucknow, and afterwards took part in the pursuit of Tantia Topee in Central India (medal and clasps); adjutant, 1st cavalry, Hyderabad Contingent, March, 1859; acted as assistant to resident, Hyderabad, from 1863; served in the Abyssinian Expedition, 1868 (medal and brevet of major); 1st assistant resident, Hyderabad, and general superintendent, Thagi and Dakiati department, Oct., 1868; agent to governor-general, Moorseshabad, 1876-77; political agent, Gwalior, 1878-79; during the Afghan war was senior political officer with Major-General Bright, during advance on Kabul, and was in charge of Jalalabad division, March, 1880 (medal, C.S.I.); officiating political agent, Western Rajputana states, 1880-81; acted subsequently as resident in Western Rajputana, in Gwalior, and Turkish Arabia; officiating commissioner, Ajmere, March-June, 1885; resident in Turkish Arabia, July, 1885, and consul-general, Baghdad.

TWEEDY, GEORGE ALFRED, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, Nov., 1887.

TWIGG, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; forest settlements officer; special assistant to collector and magistrate, Dec., 1887; and acting sub-collector and magistrate, Feb., 1888.

TWIGG, JOHN HILL, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from May, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was deputed on special duty under the commissioner of cotton and commerce for
the organisation of carriage and supply of fodder for Bengal, Feb. to Sept., 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1880; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Hamirpur, April, 1882; 1st grade, Aug., 1885; additional commissioner, Benares division, April, 1889; retired, July, 1890.

TWISADAY, CHARLES EDWARD JAMES, Public Works Department, India Office.—Appointed to the London offices of the Indo-European telegraph department on the 29th July, 1869; accompanied director-in-chief to Constantinople in 1880, as personal assistant, and to the Persian Gulf in 1885 with the third Persian Gulf cable expedition, and afterwards to India; on abolition of London office of the Indo-European telegraph company, his services were transferred temporarily to India office, 1st Jan., 1889.

TWOMEY, DANIEL HAROLD RYAN, Bengal C.S., Burma.—Educated at St. Stanislaus College, Tullamore, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1884; assistant commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1884; under secretary to chief commissioner, Jan., 1889.

TYRRELL, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 12th May, 1889; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating under secretary to government, officiating small cause court judge, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; registrar, high court, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1870; magistrate and collector, Jan., 1878; civil and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1882; puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1882.

UMESH CHUNDER BATABYAL, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Master in the Sanskrit College, Calcutta, Aug., 1873; deputy magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1883; appointed member of the statutory civil service, May, 1888; assistant magistrate and collector, June, 1888.

UDNY, RICHARD, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1869, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Feb., 1885; on special duty, March to April, 1885; and again from Aug. to Dec., 1888.

UNDERWOOD, WALTER GREGORY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rossall School, and Chester College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 17th Sept., 1870, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty to the Laccadives, Nov., 1881; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Tanjore, Dec., 1885; acting district and sessions judge, June, 1886; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1889.

UNWIN, ARTHUR HAMILTON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's School, Sherborne, and Tonbridge Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Feb., 1873, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, inspector of schools, acting judge of the small cause court, and acting director of public instruction; from Jan., 1880, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; 1st grade assistant judge, Oct., 1883; assistant judge and joint sessions judge, for Kaira and Panch Mehals, May, 1885; 3rd grade judge, and sessions judge, May, 1887.

UPTON, JOHN G., Registry Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 16th April, 1845; assistant to registrar, July, 1860; despatch clerk, 10th July, 1877.

UPTON, R. L.—Government solicitor, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 1881.

URQUHART, GEORGE MOORE, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1885; forest settlement officer, Feb., 1887.

VAN SOMEREN, GODLIB JAMES, Colonel, Madras Infantry, Forest Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Sept., 1859; appointed to the forest department, May, 1864; conservator of forests, Mysore and Coorg, Jan., 1869; transferred to Punjab, 1881; assistant comptroller-general of forest accounts under the financial department, Jan., 1883; conservator of forests, Berar, 1885; conservator, and grade, March, 1887; also director of the forest school.

VARADA RAO, T., B.A., B.L., Madras C.S.—Madras University; probationer for the civil service, July, 1885; assistant to collector and magistrate, Dec., 1886; confirmed in civil service, Aug., 1887.

VAUGHAN, ERNEST LLEWELLYN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Blackheath School, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 10th Jan., 1888, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

VEASEY, JOHN CHARLES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; assistant magistrate and collector, Sylhet, Dec., 1867; assistant settlement officer, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1880; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Aug., 1884; officiating inspector-general of police, Bengal, Oct., 1884; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, April, 1886; confirmed as inspector-general of police, Aug., 1887.

VENKATA JAGA RAO, CHENDIKA, B.A., Madras C.S.—Madras University; appointed by government of India as probationer for the civil service, 22nd Dec., 1880; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1883; forest settlement officer, Oct., 1883; acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1885.

VENKATRAS, RUKMANGAD INAMDAR, B.A., LL.B., Bombay C.S.—Served in the subordinate judicial department from 27th Feb., 1880; appointed assistant collector in Bombay presi-
