dency under native civil service rules, 9th April, 1889.

VENNING, Frederick, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864; served from Aug., 1865, to Nov., 1868, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Nov., 1868, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and acted as small cause court judge of Jubbulpore in 1874, and as secretary to the chief commissioner in 1878; inspector-general of police and prisons, Central Provinces, June, 1880; commissioner of the Jubbulpore division, Aug., 1881, and of the Nagpur division, Nov., 1883; acting judicial commissioner, June, 1889.

VENTRIS, Henry, Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at Highgate School and Brighton College; supernumerary writer, 2nd Feb., 1860; temporary clerk, Dec., 1860; clerk in registry department, Feb., 1864; junior clerk, revenue department, Jan., 1873; employed in records branch, 1879-1880; senior clerk, June, 1885.

VERNTER, WILLIAM HENRY, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1861; arrived 2nd Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed officiating assistant secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1867, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1877, and district and sessions judge, Nov., 1879; also served as inspector of schools, April, 1866, and officiated as under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1871, and as postmaster-general, Bengal, in 1871, 1872, and 1875; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1885; retired, Dec., 1883.

VERTANNES, JOHN CARADHET, M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the government of Bengal as apprentice engineer, 8th May, 1855, and served in the public works department in that province, and temporarily in the Central Provinces in 1862; executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1872; on famine relief works, Nov., 1873; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; south-western circle, Jan., 1887; retired, 1889.

VERTUE, WILLIAM, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Jan., 1857; from 2nd Dec., 1862, to May, 1865, served in the police department of the Central Provinces as acting district superintendent, and personal assistant to the inspector-general; from May, 1865, served as assistant commissioner, and acted as inspector of schools, and superintendent of the school of industry at Jubbulpore, 1867; cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Jan., 1877; small cause court judge, Nagpur, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Sept., 1883, and 3rd class, Jan., 1890.

VIBART, HENRY MEREDITH, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1859; assistant engineer in the Madras public works department, Sept., 1861; executive engineer, Dec., 1866; on special duty in Bangalore, Nov., 1877, to Feb., 1878; in special charge of the restoration of Tiroomal Naick's palace, Madura, Feb., 1878; acting deputy chief engineer for irrigation, and under secretary to government, public works department, March, 1879; superintendent of works, Presidency, April, 1880; superintending engineer, April, 1884; 1st class, June, 1888.

VIDAL, GEORGE WILLIAM, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty connected with the Jath state, March, 1873; first assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1878; on special duty as a British member of the mixed commission at Goa, March-May, 1880, and Jan., 1885; president of the Bombay forest commission, Dec., 1885; junior collector and magistrate, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kanta, Sept., 1886; collector of salt revenue, Sept., 1888.

VINCENT, WILLIAM HENRY HOARE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ College, Brecon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal.

VOWELL, CHRISTOPHER HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Dec., 1885.

VYANKATRAORUKMANGAD INAMDAR, Bombay C.S.—Joined the service as 3rd grade subordinate judge, 27th Feb., 1880, and served in the subordinate judicial department; was appointed assistant collector under the native civil service rules, and posted as 2nd grade assistant judge.

WACE, ALFRED AUGUSTUS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1881; also served as officiating inspector-general of registration, March, 1879; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; 2nd grade, Dec., 1887.

WADDINGTON, GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 21st Dec., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate, Kaladgi, Dec., 1878; senior collector, Aug., 1881; collector and magistrate, district registrar, and political agent, Sholapur, Oct., 1882; collector and magistrate, and district registrar, Ahmednagar, Nov., 1886.

WADE, EDWARD J., M.A.—Educated at Rugby, and Trinity College, Dublin; scholar and exhibitioner; first senior classical moderator and gold medalist; assistant librarian, India office, 23rd May, 1881; late editor 'Allen's Indian Mail.'

WAKE, HERWALD CRAUFURD, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1851; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector,
and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate of Shahabad, 1858; C.B., May, 1860; magistrate and collector, Patna, 1861; superintendent, Darjeeling, 1862; retired on invalid pension, 1868.

WALCH, GEORGE TURNER, M.I.C.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Appointed assistant engineer, 31st March, 1866; executive engineer, April, 1873; acted as deputy chief engineer, and under secretary to government, Feb., 1877; on special duty, Madras irrigation company's canal, July, 1882; had charge of Kurnool canal, and other works; superintending engineer, March, 1887; acted as chief engineer for irrigation, and as joint secretary and afterwards as secretary to government in 1888, 1889 and 1890; author of 'Notes on some of the Navigable Rivers and Canals of United States and Canada,' 1876.

WALKER, FRANCIS BLENNERHASSETT, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Appointed to the Bombay public works department, Sept., 1863; executive engineer, July, 1868; transferred to Punjab, January, 1870, and was employed on Punjab Northern state railway; served subsequently on the Neemuch and Western Rajputana state railways; transferred to Bombay railway branch, March, 1881, and subsequently to Bengal; engineer-in-chief, Northern Bengal and Tirhoot railway extensions, March, 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; 2nd class, May, 1889; engineer-in-chief, East coast railway survey, Nov., 1889; 1st class superintending engineer, Feb., 1890.

WALKER, GEORGE CASSON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Winchester College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; on special duty, Lahore, in connection with Viceregal durbar, Oct., 1880; from April, 1883, served in the financial department of the government of India, and was appointed assistant accountant-general, Punjab; transferred to office of accountant-general, Bengal, Dec., 1883; from Feb., 1884, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating district judge; served under the government of India from Sept. to Nov., 1886; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1887, and 1st grade, April, 1890; settlement collector, Lahore, Feb., 1888.

WALKER, GEORGE HERBERT DACRES, B.A., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant secretary to government N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1st May, 1874; officiating under secretary to government of India, public works department, Nov., 1882 and 1886 and appointed permanently, May, 1887; examiner in accounts branch, April, 1884.

WALKER, GEORGE WARREN, General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—Second lieutenant, Madras engineers, 9th Dec., 1842; assistant civil engineer, 1847; district engineer, Canara, Sept., 1859; superintending engineer, Coimbatore, May, 1863; chief engineer, and secretary to government of Madras, public works department, May, 1872; retired from the public works department in 1876.

WALKER, H. B., Store Department, India Office.—Matriculated at London University, 1875; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 6th July, 1877; 2nd grade, supervisor, July, 1888.

WALKER, JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at the University of Aberdeen, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in Madras, 1st Dec., 1885, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

WALKER, JAMES THOMAS, General, R.E., C.B., LL.D., late Survey of India Department.—Appointed to the Bombay Engineers from Addiscombe, 9th Dec., 1844; assistant chief engineer, Bombay, May-Sept., 1845; executive engineer, Upper Sind, May, 1847, to Oct., 1848; served throughout the Punjab campaign, 1848-49, and was present at siege of Mooltan, and battle of Goojerat (medal and clasps); from 1849 to 1853 served as military surveyor of the Trans-Indus frontier from Peshawur to Dera Ishmail Khan, and was present at numerous frontier engagements; from Dec., 1853, to March, 1861, served as assistant in the great trigonometrical survey; during the mutiny of 1857 served with the Punjab moveable column, and subsequently as field engineer at Delhi (brevet of major, medal and clasp); in 1866 accompanied the Mahsud Waziri expedition; medal and clasps for frontier service; from March, 1861, to Feb., 1883, served as superintendent of the great trigonometrical survey, and from Jan., 1878, to Feb., 1883 also held the appointments of surveyor-general of India, and superintendent of topographical surveys, and carried out the amalgamation of the three survey departments; fellow of the Royal Society, 1865; C.B., 1877; hon. LL.D. of Cambridge, 1885; superintended the preparation and publication of the first nine volumes of the account of operations of the great trigonometrical survey; author of occasional papers for the Royal Geographical Society and United Service Institution, presidential address to the geographical section, British Association, in 1885, and contributions to the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

WALKER, JAMES WILLIAM, LL.B., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1868, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; on special duty in connection with the Baroda commission, Feb.-March, 1875; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, Jan.-March, 1880; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, Feb., 1885; 1st grade judge, Nov., 1887.

WALKER, THOMAS GORDON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Gymnasium, Old Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner, and was settlement officer of Ludhiana from May, 1878 to 1884; attached to civil secretariat on special duty in April, 1883; officiating under secretary to government, revenue department, Punjab, April, 1883; officiating senior secretary to financial commissioner, Sept. to Dec., 1883; registrar of the chief court, Punjab, Nov., 1884; and again, April, 1887; officiating junior secretary to government, Aug., 1886, to Feb., 1887; on special duty Punjab civil
secretariat, Feb.–April, 1837; senior secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1838; commissioner of excise, and inspector-general of registration, &c., Nov., 1838.

WALKER, THORNTON, M.A., BOMBAY C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1833; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1835; assistant collector, Jan., 1836.

WALKER, WILLIAM, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.A., M.D., LL.D., F.R.C.S. (Ed.), late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 4th Aug., 1835; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1835, and held various military medical charges in Bengal and N.W. Provinces, including service in the mutiny campaign, 1857; superintendent, central prison, Agra, March, 1858; superintendent, government press, and curator, government books, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1862; also chemical examiner, Dec., 1864; rank of surgeon, Aug., 1867; honorary magistrate, Allahabad, Aug., 1867; inspector-general of prisons and dispensaries, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1871; also for Oudh, March, 1877, to April, 1879; brigade-surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general and inspector-general of civil hospitals, with local rank of surgeon-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Oct., 1882; officiating surgeon-general with the government of India, May, 1887; officiating in same appointment and as sanitary commissioner with the government of India, April, 1888; retired, Oct., 1889.

WALL, RICHARD, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Cork; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Benares, Feb., 1877; officiating civil and sessions judge, May, 1877, and in 1858; commissioner of excise and stamps, and inspector-general of registration, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1882; author of stamp, excise, and registration manuals.

WALLACE, A. C., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

WALLACE, SIR DONALD MACKENZIE, K.C.I.E.—Educated at the Universities of Edinburgh, M.A., Heidelberg, LL.D., and Berlin, and the Ecole de droit, Paris; was "Times" correspondent in Russia, Austria, and the East, 1878–84; private secretary to the Marquess of Dufferin and Ava, when governor-general of India, 1884–8; was member of mission to Kabul, 1888; appointed to accompany the Czarewitch during his visit to India, 1890–91; author of 'Russia,' 'Egypt and the Egyptian Question.'

WALLACE, WILLIAM ARTHUR JAMES, C.I.E., Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—1st commission, Dec., 1860; arrived in India, April, 1864; assistant engineer, public works department, April, 1864; officiating deputy consulting engineer, railway branch, Bengal, Jan., 1869; assistant consulting engineer, Feb., 1870; executive engineer, 3rd grade, Sept., 1870; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, Oct., 1871; acted as consulting engineer, Lucknow, and at Calcutta; special duty in connection with Imperial assemblage at Delhi, acting as under secretary to government of India, Oct., 1876, to Feb., 1877; on deputation to England in connection with Paris Exhibition, 1878; secretary to railway conference at Calcutta, Oct., 1878; acting under secretary to government of India, railway branch, 1878–79; served in the Afghan war, 1879 (medal); engineer-in-chief, and manager, Northern Bengal state railway, Nov., 1879; 1st class state railway revenue establishment, Nov., 1879; served in the Egyptian campaign, 1882 (medal and clasp, and bronze star, 4th class, Osmanieh); officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, Oct., 1884; class 1, grade 1, revenue establishment, Oct., 1885; director North-Western railway, May, 1887; deputed to Switzerland to examine the Abt system of railways, July–Oct., 1887; C.I.E., Jan., 1890.

WALLER, HARDRESS EDMOND, Major-General, B.S.C., late Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 10th Aug., 1852; joined the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, June, 1862; district superintendent, March, 1863; 1st grade, district superintendent, March, 1884; retired, June, 1886.

WALLER, RICHARD MAUNSELL, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1868; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Feb., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1878; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1879; magistrate and collector, Noakholly, Oct., 1885; 2nd grade, Oct., 1886.

WALLERSTEIN, PHILIP HERMAN, Major, B.S.C. (N.W. Provinces).—1st commission, 13th July, 1867; served with the 6th foot and 24th P.N.I.; admitted to the staff corps, Aug., 1866; officiated as cantonment magistrate, July, 1878, and Dec., 1880; confirmed, Jan., 1881; 1st class cantonment magistrate, March, 1887.

WALPOLE, HORACE G., C.B., Assistant Under Secretary of State, India Office.—Educated at Eton; temporary clerk, India office, 12th Dec., 1862; junior clerk, June, 1863; store department, 1863; accountant-general's department, 1863–64; public works department, 1864; resident clerk, 1870–77; senior clerk, April, 1877; private secretary to the permanent under secretary of state, 1866–74 (Mr. Herman Merivale, C.B.), and to the secretary of state, 1874–80 (the Marquis of Salisbury, 1874–78, and subsequently, to Viscount Cranbrook); C.B., 1880; also served as clerk of the council from 1877, and was appointed assistant to the under secretaries of state in addition to his other duties, Sept., 1881; assistant under secretary of state, Nov., 1883, continuing to be clerk of the council; royal commissioner of the Colonial and Indian Exhibition, 1886; secretary to the royal commission on civil establishments, 1886–1890.

WALSH, ERNEST HERBERT COOPER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trent College and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1884.

WALTER, CHARLES KENNETH MACKENZIE, C.S.I., Colonel, B.S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 73rd native
infantry, Bengal, Nov., 1852; assistant to commissioner, Ajmere, Jan., 1857; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, Feb., 1858; political agent, Bhurtore, Dec., 1862; political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, June, 1869; political agent, Marwar, Jan., 1873; resident, 3rd class, in the political department, 1876; officiating as agent to governor-general, Rajputana, and chief commissioner, Ajmere, in 1876, and 1881-82; resident, 2nd class, and political agent, Meywar, 1880; officiating agent to the governor-general in Rajputana; chief commissioner, Ajme-e-Merwara, April, 1887; retired 1890; C.S.I., May, 1890.

WALTON, F. T. G., C.I.E., M.I.C.E., Railway Department, Government of India.—Appointed to department as engineer-in-chief, Oudh and Rohilkhand railway, 1st Jan., 1883.

WARBURTON, HARRIS GRANT, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces, &c.).—Educated at Dover College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885. Arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1887, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

WARBURTON, ROBERT, C.S.I., Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1862; from Sept., 1869, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special political duty in Khyber, July, 1879; employed with Cabul force, Oct., 1879; officiating judicial assistant commissioner, Peshawur, Nov., 1881; political officer, Khyber, Feb., 1882; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, but to continue political officer, Khyber, Nov., 1884; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; author of an account of the Boner and Amazai tribes, and a report on the district of Sughman; C.S.I., Jan., 1890.

WARBURTON, WILLIAM PLEACE, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1866; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1866; assistant-surgeon, Jullundur, Sept., 1867; surgeon to H.H. the Raja of Kapurthala, June, 1874; surgeon-major, March, 1878; has also officiated as superintendent of Kapurthala state.

WARD, GEORGE ERNEST, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Sept., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Jaunpur, July, 1879; on special duty on the education commission under the government of India, 1882; commissioner, Jhansi division, July, 1885; retired, July, 1889.

WARD, HENRY CONSTANTINE EVELYN, C.I.E., Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—Arrived in India, as ensign, April, 1855; was employed under the military department up to 1864, including service at the siege and assault of Delhi, 1857 (medal and clasp), and at the battle of Narnoul, Nov., 1857; served also with Eusufye expedition, 1858; and in the campaign against the Mahsood Waziris, 1859-60 (frontier medal); assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Nagpur, Dec., 1864; deputy commissioner, May, 1870; acting inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Central Provinces, Nov., 1873; additional commissioner for the administration of affairs in Kalahandi, June, 1882; acting commissioner, Chhattisgarh division, March-Nov., 1883, and again in 1884; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1885; on special duty as special commissioner for the repression of dacoity in Nerbudda division, Feb., 1886; from June, 1886, served under the government of India, as minister of the Bhopal state; commissioner, Nerbudda division, Aug., 1889.

WARD, THEODORE METHUEN, Lieutenant-Colonel, Survey Department, Sind.—Joined the service, 9th Dec., 1859; lieutenant, Bombay artillery, April, 1860; admitted to Bombay staff corps, Nov., 1864, and from that date served in the revenue survey department; lieutenant-colonel, Dec., 1885; superintendent, Sind revenue survey, June, 1889.

WARD, WILLIAM ERSKINE, C.S.I., M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1861, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating under secretary to government of India, home department, Nov., 1865, to April, 1866, and again in 1867, and in department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, March, 1873; officiating magistrate of police, Calcutta, April, 1873; from Oct., 1873, served in judicial department as acting district and sessions judge, and was transferred to Assam, March, 1876, and served as judge and commissioner of Assam Valley districts; officiated temporarily as judicial commissioner of Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; fellow of University of Calcutta; officiating chief commissioner of Assam, July-Oct., 1883, and from Feb., 1885, to 1887; officiating judicial commissioner, British Burma, April, 1884; president of provincial committee for collecting exhibits of Assam for Calcutta Exhibition, 1883; judicial commissioner, Burma, May, 1886, continuing to act as chief commissioner of Assam; C.S.I., Jan., 1888; took charge of office in Burma, March, 1889.

WARDEN, AUGUSTUS BROOKE, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Kensington Grammar School, and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bombay civil service, 1842; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed judge and sessions judge of Ahmedabad, March, 1856; judge and sessions judge, and agent for governor, Surat, 1861; acting judge of the high court, May, 1863; judge and sessions judge of Poona, and agent for Sirdars in the Deccan, Sept., 1863; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, 1865; was also president of the departmental examinations committee for junior civilians for five years; retired, 1871.

WARDEN, CHARLES JAMES HISLOP, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1874; from 18th March, 1876, acted as civil surgeon of Bhagulpore, with medical charge of the central jail; on special duty in the excise department, board of revenue, Dec., 1876; officiating principal assistant to the opium agent, Behar, April-Oct., 1878; officiating superintendent, central jail, Bhagulpore, Nov.-Dec., 1879; professor of chemistry, Medical College, and
chemical and opium examiner to government, Dec., 1879; member of opium committee, Oct., 1880; surgeon-major, March, 1886.

WARDEN, Frederick, Captain, Marine Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian navy, 2nd March, 1852; from Dec., 1865, served as port-master of Canning, and, in addition (from Jan., 1867), as assistant collector of customs and ex-officio superintendent of customs; from Dec., 1866, acted as assistant master attendant, and agent for government consignments, Calcutta, and from March, 1870, as agent for transports; also government prosecutor for trial of pilots, May, 1873, to March, 1876; officiating deputy master attendant, Aug., 1875; officiated as port officer, March, 1876, to Aug., 1879, and performed duties of superintendent of dockyard, from March, 1876, to Nov., 1877; assistant port officer, Aug., 1879; examiner in navigation, Nov., 1879; transferred to Rangoon as port officer, March, 1882; also superintendent of lighthouses, superintendent of mercantile marine, and transport agent.

WARDEN, John Lodwick, B.A. (Oxon.), Barrister-at-Law, late Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 8th March, 1852, and served in the Bombay covenanted civil service as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and deputy magistrate in charge of the Adalat, Hyderabad; resigned the covenanted civil service, May, 1858; appointed extra assistant secretary to government of Bombay, in the judicial department, Dec., 1866; assistant judge and sessions judge, April, 1867, to June, 1868; acting magistrate of police, July-Oct., 1868; from Jan., 1869, served as small cause court judge, and was appointed 3rd judge, at Bombay, Dec., 1874, and second judge, May, 1883; retired, 1889.

WARRE, Sir Henry James, General, K.C.B.,—Obtained commission from Sandhurst, 1836; ensign, 54th foot, 3rd Feb., 1837; from 1839 served as aide-de-camp to commander of the forces in British North America (Sir R. Downes Jackson, K.C.B.); during 1845 and 1846 was employed by colonial office in exploring a route for transport of troops from Canada to the Red River settlement, by Ottawa, and in surveying and reporting on the various settlements in the Oregon Territory, and on various islands on the coast of the Pacific; served in the Crimea from March, 1855, and succeeded to the command of the 57th regiment; present at the siege and fall of Sebastopol, the assaults on the Redan, and the surrender of Kinbourn (medal with clasp, C.B., 5th class of the Medjidie and Turkish medal); in 1858 was in command of a mixed force on the Taptee River in co-operation with the Central India field force, and was subsequently appointed brigadier at Mhow; military secretary to the commander-in-chief in India (Lieutenant-General Sir Hugh Rose, K.C.B.), June, 1860; served in the Maori war in New Zealand, 1861, and acted for a short time as governor of the province of Auckland; was subsequently in command of the troops on the west coast, and in the province of Taranaki (under martial law), 1863-66 (medal); from 1870-74 was stationed in Ireland as brigadier-general; commander-in-chief, and member of governor's council, Bombay, Nov., 1878 to 1881.

WATERFIELD, Henry, C.B., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster; junior clerk, 1st Sept., 1853; India board, financial and railway department, 1853; political and secret department, 1856; private secretary to president of the India board, 1858; India office, financial department, 1858; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1860; financial department, 1863; senior clerk, April, 1863; assistant secretary in the military department, 1867; public works department, 1871; secretary in the statistics and commerce department, 1874; secretary, financial department, 1879; C.B., Dec., 1883; author of the first report on the moral and material progress of India, 1866, and of a memorandum on the census of British India of 1871-72, both of which were presented to Parliament.

WATERFIELD, William, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Westminster; appointed to the Bengal C.S. from Haileybury in 1852; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1852; served in Bengal in the revenue and survey departments till 1859, when he was transferred to the financial department as 1st assistant to the accountant-general for India; acted as sub-treasurer, Madras, and as civil auditor and superintendent of stamps, Madras, Calcutta, and Bombay; from 1864 to 1877 served successively as civil paymaster, deputy accountant-general, and accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh; comptroller-general, 1877-80; retired, 1881.

WATERFIELD, William Garrow, C.S.I., Colonel, B.S.C. (Barrister-at-Law), late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1852; from Sept., 1857, served in the Punjab as personal assistant to commissioner of Delhi, and assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Sept., 1863, to Nov., 1865; assistant settlement officer, Gujerat, Nov., 1865; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1867; on special duty for reporting on the Gujerat settlement, July, 1868; commissioner and sessions judge, Peshawur, Feb., 1873; commissioner and superintendent, Sept., 1878; on special duty, Nov., 1878 (with the Kurrum field force); served under the foreign department of the government of India, 1881-82; retired, Nov., 1888; author of a report on the settlement of the Gujerat district.

WATERHOUSE, James, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, June, 1859; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1859; assistant revenue surveyor, Lower Provinces, June, 1866; assistant surveyor with superintendence of the photoincographic operations in the office of the surveyor-general of India, July, 1866; assistant superintendent of survey, 1st grade, June, 1870; on special duty with the Indian eclipse expedition, Nov., 1871, to Jan., 1872, and for observing the transit of Venus, Oct., 1874, to Jan., 1875; in charge of Indian eclipse expedition to Nicobar Islands, March, 1875; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Jan., 1884; and 2nd grade, April, 1889; assistant surveyor-general in charge of lithographic and photographic offices, Calcutta; author of a pamphlet on 'The Application of Photography to the Reproduction of Maps and Plans.'

WATERS, George, Surgeon-Major, L.R.C.S., L.R.C.P. (Ed.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 1st Oct., 1869; arrived in India, 27th May, 1870, and served in the military department, and as acting ophthalmic surgeon, Bombay, and civil surgeon at Bushire (1871-75); on special duty under the government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, March-April, 1877;
surgeon to governor of Bombay, May, 1877; from Oct., 1881, served as third physician and registrar, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, curator of the pathological museum, and professor of pathology, Grant Medical College; also acted as first physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of medicine, clinical medicine and hygiene; confirmed as first physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of pathology and morbid anatomy, and Hygiene, Grant Medical College, Nov., 1888; presidency surgeon, 3rd district, Nov., 1889.

WATKINS, Lawrence Augustus, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1863; served in the Bombay judicial department from Jan., 1865, as deputy registrar of the high court, clerk to the high court judges, and commissioner for taking affidavits; also acted as assistant commissioner for taking accounts, and assistant taxmaster, Aug.–Oct., 1878.

WATSON, Herbert Edward, Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 29th June, 1864; from Nov., 1865, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, and acted as political superintendent of Thar and Parkar, June, 1879; in charge of the special duty of the salt department in Sind, July–Oct., 1880; on special duty in the military department, June, 1881; head assistant collector in Sind, July, 1884; deputy commissioner, Thar and Parkar, June, 1885.

WATSON, Sir John, Lieut.-General, K.C.B., V.C., Bombay S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay infantry, 1848; from Sept., 1871, served as commandant, Central India Horse and political agent; resident, 2nd class, and agent to the governor-general at Gwalior, April, 1877, also acting as agent for Central India; brigadier-general commanding cavalry brigade, Malta expeditionary force, 1878; commanding Punjab chiefs' contingent in Afghanistan, 1878-79; in political charge of the district of Kuram, Nov., 1879, to Nov., 1880; resident, 1st class, and agent to the governor-general, Baroda, Jan., 1882; retired from the political department, March, 1886.

WATSON, John Forbes, Dr., M.A., M.D., LL.D.—Educated at the University of Aberdeen; appointed to the medical service of the East India Company in August, 1850; in 1853, was appointed by the Secretary of State reporter on the products of India and director of the India museum. He represented India at the international exhibitions held at London in 1862, Paris in 1867, Vienna in 1873, and South Kensington in 1870 to 1874. He retired from the India office in 1880. Dr. Forbes Watson wrote and edited several works connected with the economic products of India, including 'Textile Manufactures of India.'

WATT, G., M.D., C.I.E., Educational Service, Bengal.—Appointed, 11th July, 1873; arrived, 4th Nov., 1873; served in the 3rd class of the Bengal education department as professor, Presidency, Hooghly, and Patna Colleges, and as officiating principal, Krishnagur College, and was placed on special duty in connection with the Burma-Munipore boundary expedition, Oct., 1881; services placed at disposal of executive committee of the Calcutta International Exhibition, Feb., 1883; served under government of India, revenue and agricultural department, from May, 1884; appointed to charge of imperial Indian economic court of Colonial and Indian exhibition; C.I.E., June, 1886; reporter of economic products, April, 1887.

WEBB, W. T., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the service, 6th April, 1875; professor, Dacca College, May, 1875; officiated as inspector of schools, Feb., 1877; professor, Presidency College, from Jan., 1878; officiating principal, Calcutta Madrassa, in addition to other duties, Oct., 1880; 3rd class, education department, Dec., 1880; has published 'Hints on the Study of English,' 'Indian Lyrics,' and translations.

WEBSTER, Edmund Forster, C.I.E. (Barister-at-Law), late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed small cause court judge, Madura, May, 1867, and afterwards at Cuddalore; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, June, 1873, and at Trichinopoly, Aug., 1873; collector and magistrate and agent, Tanjore, April, 1878; on special duty in connection with the famine commission, Oct., 1878, and again, Aug., 1881, as secretary to the famine code committee; member of the forest draft bill committee, March, 1882; secretary to government, revenue department, June, 1882; member of the local self-government committee, June, 1882; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, July, 1883, and again, July, 1885, and March, 1886; chief secretary to government of Madras, Jan., 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884; member of the committee in connection with the draft tenancy bill, July, 1885; retired, Oct., 1887; C.I.E., May, 1888.

WEBSTER, Henry Binny, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 17th June, 1854; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Saharanpur, Nov., 1867, and subsequently at Gorakhpur and Meerut; commissioner, Jhansi division, Jan., 1878; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1880; retired, 1886.

WEDDERBURN, Francis Edward Keir, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; officiating political agent and assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to chief commissioner of Coorg; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1888, and special assistant to collector and magistrate, Ganjam, March, 1890.

WEDDERBURN, Sir William, Bart., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived 25th Nov., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting judicial assistant to the commissioner in Sind, and small cause court judge; acting under secretary to government in the judicial and political departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations June, 1866; acting registrar-general of assur-
ances, Oct., 1866; acting secretary to government in the judicial, political, educational, secret, and Persian departments, Dec., 1866, and again in 1870 and 1874; under secretary to government, judicial and political departments, May, 1867; acting registrar, high court, Jan., 1869; acting judicial commissioner in Sind and judge of the sadar court, May, 1874, to Feb., 1876; and grade judge and sessions judge, June, 1875; on special duty in Bombay, Nov., 1876; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Poona, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan, May, 1882; on special duty under government of India, April-May, 1883; acting judge, high court, Bombay, Jan., 1883; acting chief secretary to government, Oct., 1886; retired, May, 1887.

WEEKES, ARTHUR, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 2nd Feb., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1885; on famine relief duty at Madras, Feb., 1877; retired, March, 1888.

WEIDEMANN, GEORGE LEVER, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1870, and served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; on special duty in Rangoon, July, 1879.

WEIR, CHARLES JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at Royal Academical Institution, Belfast, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant sessions judge; from May, 1884, served in Coorg as officiating first assistant commissioner and district magistrate; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, Oct., 1886; officiating under secretary to government of India finance department, May, 1887-April, 1888; officiating deputy accountant-general, Bengal, April, 1888; officiating principal assistant to collector and magistrate, Aug., 1888.

WEIR, JOHN WILLIAM ALLEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Godolphin School, Hammersmith, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885.

WEIR, PATRICK ALEXANDER, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service 1875; officiating 2nd resident surgeon, presidency general hospital, 22nd Aug., 1876; on special duty with lieutenant-governor on tour in cyclone districts, Nov., 1876; superintendent of vaccination, and ex-officio deputy sanitary commissioner, March, 1882; principal assistant to opium agent, Benares, May, 1882.

WEIR, THOMAS, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1867, and served in Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate; deputy registrar, high court, Jan., 1870, to June, 1872; acted as registrar, high court, Feb., 1874, to Feb., 1880; Tamil translator to government, Jan., 1879; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, Godavari, March, 1880; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; confirmed as registrar, high court, April, 1882; published the law of offences and criminal procedure, and the civil digest of rules and standing orders of the high court; from July, 1883, acted as district and sessions judge in the districts of Coimbatore, North Tanjore, and Madura, and was placed on special duty in connection with the reorganization of the subordinate judicial service, Nov., 1883; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1886; district and sessions judge, Madura, Nov., 1887; officiating judge of high court, Jan., 1890.

WEIR, T. S., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Bombay.—First commission, Indian medical department, 1870; health officer, Bombay, from 1874; surgeon-major, April, 1882.

WELD, MATTHEW RICHARD, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Dublin University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served in various districts of Madras, as assistant magistrate and collector, acting cantonment magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acted as district and sessions judge, Kistna, Jan.-March, 1885, and as collector and magistrate in the same district from April, 1885; appointed district and sessions judge, Ganjam, Sept., 1883.

WELDON, THOMAS, C.I.E., Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Joined Adiscombe, Jan., 1852; ensign, Madras infantry, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, 12th April, 1854; from July, 1860, served in the Madras police department as assistant superintendent and superintendent; senior magistrate of police for town of Madras, March, 1867; on special duty, in connection with the note forgery case, July, 1872, to Jan., 1873; chief magistrate of police, Madras, April, 1877, on special duty in Burma in connection with the commissariat case, Nov., 1879; chief presidency magistrate, Madras, Dec., 1880; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; commissioner of police for town of Madras Dec., 1885; C.I.E., May, 1888.

WELLS, WALTER FOX WILLIAMSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1875, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; city magistrate, Lucknow, Oct., 1885; joint magistrate, July, 1889; has officiated also as magistrate and collector.

WELSH, WILLIAM HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury; appointed after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in Madras, 20th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector, assistant sessions judge, &c.; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, Jan., 1885; senior assistant to collector and magistrate, Dec., 1887; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Aug., 1889; has acted as district and sessions judge.

WENLOCK (Baron) The RIGHT HON. BELBY LAWLEY.—Educated at Eton and Trinity College, Cambridge; M.P. for Chester, April to July, 1880; was vice-chairman of County Council, East Riding; appointed governor of Madras, Dec., 1890, and assumed charge of office, 23rd Jan., 1891.
WEST, Sir Raymond, K.C.I.E., M.A., Barrister-at-Law, F.R.G.S., LL.D., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 18th Sept., 1856, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, officiating under secretary to government in the judicial and political departments, and acting judge and sessions judge; registrar, high court, Bombay, June, 1863; judicial commissioner and judge of the sadar court in Sind, June, 1872; judge of the high court, Bombay, Sept., 1873; on special duty as member of the law commission, Calcutta, April-Nov., 1879; vice-chancellor of the University of Bombay, Oct., 1886; member of council of governor of Bombay, 12th Nov., 1887, K.C.I.E., June, 1888.

WESTERN, James Halifax, C.M.G., Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1860; arrived in India, Oct., 1862; assistant engineer public works department, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1863; Eastern Jamuna canal, Jan., 1864; executive engineer, Ganges canal, June, 1868; superintendent of works, Betwa canal, Nov., 1881; transferred to Punjab as temporary superintending engineer, Sihrih canal, May, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1882; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary for irrigation, Punjab, Nov., 1884; services lent to Egyptian government; retired, Jan., 1887.

WESTLAKE, Sidney St. John, Bombay C.S.—Educated in Germany, and at Cheltenham, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 19th Oct., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1886; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Oct., 1888; 2nd grade, May, 1890; settlement officer.

WESTLAND, James, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marischal College, Aberdeen, and Wimbledon School; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived 10th Oct., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1867, officiating magistrate and collector, Jessore, Aug., 1868, officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1869, and officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, June, 1870; under secretary, government of India, financial department, Dec., 1870; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, April, 1873; accountant-general, Central Provinces, and deputy commissioner, paper currency, Nagpore circle, Dec., 1873; on special duty in the home department, Nov., 1875; inspector of local offices of accounts, Nov., 1877; accountant-general, Bengal, Oct., 1878; acting comptroller-general and head commissioner, department of issue of state paper currency, April, 1880, and was confirmed in this appointment, Sept., 1881; officiating secretary, government of India, department of finance and commerce, Nov., 1883, to Jan., 1884, Nov., 1886, and again Nov., 1887; to England on special duty, April-Sept., 1884; member of finance committee, March, 1886; officiating member governor-general's council, Aug., 1887; temporary member, Nov., 1887; C.S.I., June, 1888; secretary to government of India, department of finance and commerce, Nov., 1889; chief commissioner of Assam, July, 1889; retired, Oct., 1889.

WESTMACOTT, Edward Vesey, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 8th Jan., 1863; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was on famine relief duty, Jan., 1874; officiating commissioner Dacca division, Aug., 1882; on special duty for the purpose of reporting on the existing chowkidary system, Nov., 1882; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1883; services placed temporarily at disposal of financial department, Oct., 1883; officiating inspector-general of jails, March, 1884; officiating commissioner, Burdwan division, April, 1887, and again March, 1888; port commissioner, Calcutta, April, 1887; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1887; commissioner of excise, Bengal, April, 1889.

WESTROPP, George Ralph Collier, Colonel, Bombay S.C., late Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Dec., 1850; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1851; was employed under the military department, including service in Khandeish against the rebel leader Tantia Tope, 1853; adjutant, Savantwadi local corps, Feb., 1859; acting assistant magistrate in Ratnagiri, May, 1860; assistant to political superintendent, Savantwadi, Nov., 1862; assistant political agent, Kolhapur, 1865-1869; in charge Southern Mahratta Jäghir states, 1869-1877; political superintendent, Savantwadi, and commandant of the local corps, Aug., 1877; deputed on special duty in the Savanur state in 1880; retired from civil employment, 1888.

WETHERILL, James Frederick, Madras C.S.—Educated at Dulwich, and at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in Madras, 19th Nov., 1886, and served in the revenue and survey department, and as assistant to magistrate and collector.

WHALLEY, Paul, M.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Nov., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating junior secretary, and under secretary to government; officiating under secretary to government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Dec., 1871, to Feb., 1872; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, in Oudh, Dec., 1877; magistrate and collector, Pilibhit, Nov., 1879; 1st grade magistrate and collector, Oct., 1883; retired, Feb., 1890; author of 'A Collection of the Laws and Rules of the Non-Regulation Provinces.'

WHEELER, Percy Cotterill (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant settlement officer, Jaunpur, Nov., 1882, assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1887; author of 'Settlement Report of the
Recent Revision of Records (1873 to 1886) in the Jaunpur districts.

WHISH, Charles William, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Tonbridge School, and Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oct., 1886; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1887; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1890.

WHISHAW, John Charles, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 23rd July, 1858; arrived, 3rd Sept., 1858, and held various military medical charges up to 1860; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, April, 1860; superintendent, central prison and district jail, Lucknow, Nov., 1867; also civil surgeon, Feb., 1868; officiating sanitary commissioner, Oudh, Oct., 1870, also ex-officio inspector-general of prisons, March, 1871; civil surgeon, and superintendent of lunatic asylum, Lucknow, Oct., 1873, also in charge of meteorological observatory, Lucknow, Dec., 1877; retired, Feb., 1886.

WHITE, Edmund, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating cantonment magistrate of Bareilly, Feb., 1880; deputy superintendent of census operations, N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, April, 1880; also under secretary to government in the census department; on special duty in connection with census, Sept., 1882; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1882; director of public instruction, N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, June, 1883; member of lieutenant-governor's legislative council, Feb., 1889; author of 'Report on the Census, N.W. Provinces and Oudh,' 1881.

WHITE, Henry Frederick, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 10th Dec., 1859; assistant engineer, Dec., 1860; 1st civil divisional engineer, April, 1865; executive engineer, Oct., 1866; charge of Rohilkund roads division; in charge of Mhow military works division, 1872, 1878, 1882; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, July, 1885; superintending engineer, May, 1888.

WHITE, H. R., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 4th Dec., 1872; graduated B.A., London University, with French honours, in 1882.

WHITE, Herbert Thirkell, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1878, and served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner; on special duty, Rangoon, April, 1880; officiating deputy commissioner, Thayetmyo, April, 1882; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, April-Sept., 1882, and again in 1883; officiated for various periods between 1880 and 1886 as assistant secretary, junior secretary, and secretary to the chief commissioner; also as director of agriculture, Aug.-Nov., 1884; secretary to the chief commissioner for Upper Burma, March, 1886; secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1887; officiating commissioner, Northern division, Upper Burma, Feb.-June, 1888; officiating chief secretary to chief commissioner, Aug., 1888.

WHITE, James, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Dec., 1873, to Nov., 1875, served in Rajputana under the foreign department of the government of India as officiating political assistant, 3rd class, and acted as superintendent, Rajputana state railway police, and also held charge of the office of political agent, Jaipur; served again under the foreign department of the government of India, May, 1876, to Dec., 1881, in Ajmere, as assistant commissioner and political agent, 3rd class, and officiated as resident (3rd class) and commissioner of Ajmere, May-Aug., 1878; also acted as general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggery and dacoity, Nov., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Gonda, July, 1883; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1887.

WHITE, John Hubbard, Colonel, R.E., late Mint-Master, Bombay.—Second lieutenant, Bombay engineers, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, Nov., 1855; from June, 1856, served in the Bombay public works department as assistant engineer and executive engineer (for irrigation); from May, 1865, to Feb., 1874, served as deputy consulting engineer and acting consulting engineer for railways, Bombay; acting superintending engineer, Feb., 1874; acting chief engineer, and under secretary to government of Bombay, railway branch, June-Dec., 1874; transferred to financial department of government of India as acting mint-master, Bombay, June, 1876; rejoined the railway department, Feb., 1878; from March, 1879, served as mint-master and mint-engineer, Bombay; senior mint-master from Jan., 1884; retired, March, 1890.

WHITE, Philip James, North-Western Provinces.—Signaller in telegraph department, July, 1854; was employed in various capacities in several government offices till outbreak of mutiny, when he served with a body of volunteer horse and was present at various engagements; mutiny medal; deputy collector and deputy magistrate, Gorakhpur, Sept., 1858; assistant settlement officer, Nov., 1859; from March, 1863, served in the Jhansi commission as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jalaun, Dec., 1879; settlement officer, 1st grade, June, 1885.

WHITESIDE, William Southey, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting deputy secretary to government, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting civil and sessions judge, small cause court judge of Cuddalore, 1866-67, and acting collector and magistrate;
collector and magistrate of North Arcot, Feb., 1873, and subsequently at Tanjore; on special duty as member of the forest draft bill committee in Ootacamund, May, 1882; served on the board of revenue from Aug., 1882, in charge of the Inam department; acting president of the board of examiners, Nov., 1882; acted as director of revenue settlement and agriculture, and Inam commissioner, April–July, 1884; on deputation in the southern districts for reporting on working of Licence Tax Act, Dec., 1884; additional member of the governor-general's council for making laws and regulations, Nov., 1886; acting 2nd member, board of revenue, March, 1888; appointed 3rd member, Jan., 1889, and 2nd member, Oct., 1889; retired, Dec., 1890.

WHITEWAY, RICHARD STEPHEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University of London, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting assistant secretary to government, assistant settlement officer, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1879; settlement officer, 3rd grade, on special duty at Aligarh, Nov., 1881; settlement officer, Ajmere and Merwara, Jan., 1883; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, March, 1888; magistrate and collector, April, 1888.

WHITMORE, JOHN (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1881; officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur, Dec., 1881; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Sept., 1885, and 1st grade, March, 1890.

WHITTALL, RICHARD HENRY CECIL, Forest Department, Punjab.—Appointed to the Department, 18th Oct., 1871; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces; transferred to Burma, June, 1875; deputy conservator, Oct., 1876; transferred to Central Provinces, Aug., 1880; served also in Baluchistan, Oudh and Berar; conservator of forests, Punjab, Jan., 1889.

WHITTEN, RICHARD JOHN, Salt Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service in Feb., 1862, as assistant patrol; deputy inspector, internal branch, Jan., 1867; on deputation to inquire into illicit manufacture of salt in Behar, 1869; personal assistant to commissioner of inland customs, Oct., 1869; collector of customs, Sept., 1871; on deputation to report on salt taxation in Sind, July-Aug., 1872; 1st grade collector, July, 1876; on deputation in Rajputana to report on salt sources in connection with proposed abolition of inland customs line, July-Oct., 1877; employed temporarily under government of Bombay in salt inquiries in Kutch and Kathiawar; deputy commissioner of inland customs, Dec., 1879; officiated as commissioner of Northern India salt revenue, May–June, 1885.

WHITWORTH, GEORGE CLIFFORD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Sandicrop School, Northwich, and Queen's College, Liverpool; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; acting under secretary to government of Bombay in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the governor's council, Jan., 1876; (pro tem.) under secretary to government in the public works department for relief purposes, Sept., 1877, to March, 1878; second assistant collector, Feb., 1881; judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, Nov., 1886; 2nd grade, judge and sessions judge, Nov., 1887; author of 'The Theory of Relevancy for the purpose of Judicial Evidence, an Anglo-Indian Dictionary,' 1885, and the 'Rajkumar Law Lectures,' 1888.

WICKES, THOMAS HAINES, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by government of India as special assistant engineer, April, 1861; engineer to the suburban municipality, Calcutta, Jan., 1865; re-appointed as executive engineer, public works department, Bengal, Nov., 1865; on special duty in the famine districts, May, 1874, and in connection with the Eastern Bengal railway, April, 1875, also with the secretary to the government of Bengal, March, 1878; assistant secretary to the government of Bengal, April, 1880; executive engineer, 1st grade, June, 1880; superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886; 1st superintending engineer, temporary, April, 1883, and permanent, May, 1889; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary to government of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, June, 1888, and again in May, 1890.

WIGHT, JOHN KNOX, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Queen's Collegiate School, Trinidad, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1872, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, April, 1874; transferred to Assam, Dec., 1874, and served as assistant commissioner and assistant inspector of immigrants; deputy commissioner, Sept., 1885; 2nd grade, May, 1888; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, June, 1890.

WIGNER, JOHN M., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at King's Lynn Grammar School; B.A. and B.Sc., London University; temporary clerk, India office, 17th July, 1862; junior clerk, Jan., 1867; senior clerk, July, 1885.

WILD, CHARLES EDMUND, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at City of London School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

WILKINS, CECIL ANSDELL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal; officiating registrar, high court, April, 1880, and again from 1881 to 1884; on special duty in the high court, July, 1880; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1884; officiating registrar, high court, March, 1885; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Beerbboom, April, 1886; compiled revised editions
of the High Court's Rules and Orders, in 1831 and 1833.

WILKINS, WILLIAM HENRY, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Joined the Bengal artillery, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, Jan., 1858; served with the Cawnpur field force, Feb.–March, 1858; studied at Thomason College, Roorkee, March, 1861, to Aug., 1862; served in the revenue survey from April, 1863, as assistant surveyor, and was employed in the Central Provinces, Punjab, Midnapur, Dearali, and British Burma surveys; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Oct., 1878; 2nd grade, Jan., 1887.

WILKINSON, ALFRED REGINALD, Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, late Bengal Police.—First commission, 1860; from 10th July, 1863, served in the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; attached to the special police levy for service in Bhutan, Oct., 1864; on special duty at the presidency, June, 1866; personal assistant to the inspector-general of police, 1869 to 1881; promoted to 1st grade district superintendent, June, 1886; also acted as deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, and as deputy inspector-general; retired, 1889.

WILKINSON, FRANCIS HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Milton Abbas School, Blackheath Proprietary School, and Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in Madras from Feb., 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, and acted as under secretary to government in the revenue department, Aug.–Nov., 1867; on special duty as arbitrator of boundary disputes, June, 1870; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Salem, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, South Malabar, June, 1882; judge of the high court, Madras, Nov., 1887.

WILKINSON, THOMAS ORMEROD, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Chudleigh Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; officiated as registrar of the chief court in 1878, 1879, and 1880; judicial assistant, 2nd grade, Dec., 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Jan., 1887, and 2nd grade, March, 1890; retired, Sept., 1890.

WILLCOCKS, ALEXANDER JOHN, Surgeon-Major Medical Department, N.W. Provinces.—Joined the service as assistant surgeon, 30th Sept., 1873; arrived in India, 5th May, 1874; served on military, civil, and jail duty, and was appointed civil surgeon, 2nd class, April, 1877; surgeon-major, Sept., 1885; civil surgeon, 1st class, Jan., 1889.

WILLIAMS, ALBERT, Bengal C. S. (Punjab)—Educated at Uppingham, Clifton, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1886, and was appointed assistant-commissioner, Punjab; under secretary to government of Punjab, April, 1890.

WILLIAMS, EDWARD C. S., Major-General, C.I.E., R.E., India Office.—Commission in Bengal engineers, 1848; arrived in India, 1850; adjutant of engineers, Fort William, and studying machinery in Calcutta mint, 1850; extra assistant secretary, military board, 1851; superintendent, iron bridge yard, Calcutta, 1851–52; served with the Pegu expedition, 1852–53, as adjutant of engineers and in charge of engineer park (medal and clasp); superintendent, Pegu topographical survey, 1854–56; principal, Civil Engineering College, Calcutta, 1856–60; member of senate, Calcutta University; acted as under secretary to government of India, public works department, for one year, during mutiny; principal, Thomason College, Roorkee, 1861–62; under secretary, government of India, public works department, 1863–69; member of Bengal sanitary commission; in charge of office of inspector-general of forests for one year; acting mint-master and commissioner of paper currency, Bombay, 1867; deputy secretary, government of India, public works department (railway branch), 1869–74, and again, 1877–78; director of state railways, 1874–77; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; deputy government director of Indian railway companies, India office, March, 1880.

WILLIAMS, FLEETWOOD, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1829; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1831; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant commissioner, assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Bareilly, 1845; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Meerut division, 1857; retired in 1870.

WILLIAMS, GEORGE ROBERT CARLISLE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North–Western Provinces).—Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from March, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, March, 1883; magistrate and collector, Dec., 1886; author of 'An Historical and Statistical Memoir of Dehra Dun.'

WILLIAMS, HENRY CLISSOLD, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Haileybury College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, officiating district superintendent of police, and officiating deputy commissioner; on famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; from Nov., 1878, served in Assam as assistant commissioner; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Jan., 1883; inspector-general of police and jails, superintendent of stamps and commissioner of excise, Assam, Sept., 1885; deputy commissioner, and grade, March, 1886, 1st grade, Sept., 1888.

WILLIAMS, RALPH KING, Public Works Department, Central Provinces.—From Nov., 1860, to Feb., 1873, served in the office of the consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, as accountant and deputy controller, and was appointed assistant examiner of guaranteed railway accounts in 1872; served in Madras from Feb., 1873, to March, 1878, and was appointed deputy examiner, May, 1876; acted as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts in Calcutta, March to May, 1878, and subsequently in Madras, and at Lahore, March, 1880; examiner, 4th class, Indus valley state railway accounts, Aug., 1880;
transferred to Nagpur, Central Provinces, March, 1885; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Lahore, April, 1885; examiner, North-Western railway accounts, Lahore, Jan., 1886; 2nd class examiner, Dec., 1886; 1st class, temporary, May, 1888.

WILLIAMS, WILLIAM, M.I.E.E., late Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as assistant superintendent, 16th Jan., 1868; arrived in India, 29th Feb., 1868; served in various divisions, and in 1874, was on special duty at Bombay in connection with introduction of duplex system; superintendent, April, 1880; attached to director-general's office for various periods, and was also personal assistant to director-general; held charge of various divisions, including Indore, Bombay, Nagpur, retired 1890; author of 'Manual of Telegraphy.'

WILLIAMS-WYNN, ARTHUR W., India Office.—Educated at Westminster School and Christ Church, Oxford; graduated B.A. in 1878; called to the Bar (Inner Temple) Aug., 1882; appointed assistant private secretary (unpaid) to the Secretary of State (Viscount Cross) Aug., 1886; assistant private secretary, Dec., 1889.

WILLIS, JOHN, Funds Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 3rd Nov., 1862; junior book-keeper, Nov., 1868; assistant book-keeper, Dec., 1881.

WILLOCK, WILLIAM ALEXANDER, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin, and Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th March, 1870, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty, Jan., 1876, as secretary to the salt commission; from March, 1879, served in the salt department as deputy commissioner and acting commissioner, and was also employed in suppressing the disturbances in the Gudum Hills, May, 1879; collector, and magistrate, Dec., 1888.

WILLOUGHBY, MICHAEL WEEKES, Major-General, C.S.I., Bo. S.C., late Bombay Secretariat.—First commission, Bombay army, June, 1849; acted as secretary to government of Bombay in the military, marine, and ecclesiastical departments, from 21st May, 1880, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1881; returned to Europe, 1888.

WILLSON, James, M.A., Bengal Educational Service (Assam).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin, 1870; Professor, Cathedral Mission College, Calcutta, Jan., 1870; assistant, geological survey of India, Sept., 1871, to Feb., 1873; professor, Hooghly College, March, 1873; Dacca College, Jan., 1874; Patna College, May, 1875; 3rd class of the education department, Aug., 1878; from Jan., 1879, served in Assam as inspector of schools, and was appointed director of public instruction, Assam, Jan., 1889.

WILMER, JOHN RANDAL, Col., B.S.C., Survey of India.—Joined the service as lieutenant R.A., 22 June, 1850; arrived in India, 27 Oct., 1860; served in the military department, and in Aug., 1869, was appointed to the staff corps and assistant superintendent topographical survey, deputy superintendent, July, 1882; in charge of Baluchistan survey party, Oct., 1885 to Oct., 1886; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Feb., 1887.

WILSON, ARTHUR.—Puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1878; president of the Crawford enquiry commission, at Poona, 1888–9.

WILSON, DAVID, M.A., Bengal C.S., Burma.—Educated at Hutcheson's Grammar School, Glasgow, University of Glasgow, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1886; served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

WILSON, FREDERICK ALEXANDER, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal S.C., Political Department of Government of India.—1st commission, Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, 8th June, 1860; arrived in India, Oct., 1860; admitted to the staff corps, April, 1869; extra A.D.C. to viceroy, Dec., 1866; from Nov., 1870, served under the foreign department of the government of India as guardian and tutor to the Nawab of Jaora, and from 1874, as additional political assistant and political assistant in Jaora, in Central India, and at Tehri; tutor to the Maharaja of Mysore, June, 1876; 1st assistant resident, Hyderabad, Oct., 1879; political agent, 3rd class, Oct., 1881; agent to the governor-general with the King of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, March, 1882; boundary settlement officer and assistant to political agent, Bundelkhand, Jan., 1883; political agent, 2nd class, Jan., 1884; officiated as resident, 2nd class, in Nipal, and political agent, Bharatpur and Karauli; political agent, Bundelkhand, Oct., 1886; served in the Bhutan campaign of 1864–65 (medal and clasp), the Hazara campaign of 1868, the Black Mountain (clasp).

WILSON, GEORGE HERBERT DASHWOOD, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Magdalen College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 26th Nov., 1863, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate, and political agent; junior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, May, 1880; senior collector, Broach, May, 1883; retired, Aug., 1887.

WILSON, JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Perth Academy, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty, April, 1879, and again, Oct., 1880, in the civil secretariat; officiating under secretary to government, July, 1881, and again in 1883; on special duty at Simla for the purpose of writing the final report on the Sirsa settlement, Aug., 1883; officiating senior secretary to financial commissioner, April-May, 1886; assistant commissioner, and grade, Sept., 1886; 1st grade, March, 1889; officiating deputy commissioner, Oct., 1886; author of 'A Code of Tribal Customs in the Gurgaon and Sirsa Districts.'

WILSON, JOHN HATTON, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Probationary assistant engineer, 5th March, 1856; served in the public works department in the Central Provinces, and temporarily in Oudh, 1865–67, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; temporarily transferred to military works branch, July, to Sept., 1879; in charge of the Nagpore and Chattisgarh railway reconnaissance survey division, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer,
and transferred to Bengal, Dec., 1881; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Dec., 1885; 1st superintending engineer, temporary, March, 1886.

WILSON, ROBERT HENRY, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 2nd Feb., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; officiating registrar-general of assurances, Sept., 1870; also officiating marriage registrar, Calcutta; officiating under secretary to the government of Bengal, Dec., 1870; inspector of registration offices, July, 1872; officiating inspector-general of registration, Sept., 1872; officiating secretary, board of revenue, July, 1877, and again in 1879; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1884; officiating commissioner, Burdwan division, Aug., 1884; employed under the public works department on the commission in connection with the Orissa canals, Nov., 1884; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, Feb., 1886; on special duty with the finance committee, 1886; retired, Sept., 1887.

WILSON, THOMAS CORBY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner, Central Provinces; acting district superintendent of police, Hoshangabad, Sept.-Nov., 1884; assistant settlement officer, June, 1886; settlement officer, May, 1888.
