WILSON, WILLIAM, M.A., late Madras C.S.—Marischal College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed district and sessions judge, Kistna, Feb., 1874, and collector and magistrate, June, 1877; on special duty for compiling irrigation accounts, Nov., 1875, and again, Oct., 1879, and Aug., 1881; acting director of revenue settlement, April, 1878, to Sept., 1879; collector and magistrate, Coimbatore, Oct., 1879, to Aug., 1881; collector, magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, July, 1882; acted as member of the board of revenue in 1882, 1883, 1884; director of revenue settlement, and agriculture, Nov., 1882; in charge of the Inam department, March, 1883; also an additional member, board of revenue, April, 1883; permitted to visit on duty agricultural institutions in N.W. Provinces, and Bombay, Nov., 1883; fellow of Madras University, March, 1885; acting secretary to government of Madras in the revenue department, April, 1885; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, Sept., 1885; acting chief secretary to government of Madras, Oct., 1885; 3rd member of board of revenue, April, 1887; has acted as 2nd and 1st member of board; appointed 1st member and commissioner of land revenue settlement, &c., Jan., 1889; retired, Oct., 1889.

WILSON, WILLIAM HENRY, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 22nd Jan., 1857, and was employed on military duties till April, 1864, when he was appointed acting assistant political agent, Sádra; from Nov., 1864, served as assistant superintendent of police, subordinate magistrate, superintendent of railway police on Bombay, Baroda, and Central India railway, and district superintendent; promoted to 1st grade superintendent of police, June, 1883; acted as commissioner of police for city of Bombay, Oct., 1885, to June, 1886; colonel, Dec., 1886; appointed commissioner of police, Bombay, July, 1888.

WILSON, WILLIAM HERBERT, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.G.S. (Heidelberg), Education Department, Madras.—Served from 4th Feb., 1875, as professor of physical science, Presidency College; fellow of Madras University, March, 1880; 3rd class, education department, June, 1882; registrar of Madras University, March, 1886; 2nd class, education department, Dec., 1888.

WILTSHIRE, CHARLES PALMER BLUETT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Proprietary School, Islington, City of London School, King's College, London University, and Middle Temple; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting port officer at Karwar, and superintendent, timber depot, Canara; boundary commissioner between Canara and Mysore, May, 1873; on famine duty, Dharwar, in 1876 and 1877; in charge of Huzair treasury in 1880 and 1881; 1st assistant collector, Sept., 1886; acting collector and magistrate, Belgaum, 1888.

WIMBERLEY, REGINALD JUSTUS, Colonel, late B.S.C.—Ensign, 3rd Bengal European regiment, 1859; served in the Punjab police force, Dec., 1861-67; commissariat department, March-Aug., 1867; from Aug., 1867, to 1872, served in Bengal as district superintendent of police; in command of police force to quell insurrection in the tributary Mechs, May, 1868; 1st assistant superintendent, Port Blair and Nicobars, April, 1872; called to the bar, Inner Temple, Nov., 1877; deputy superintendent, Dec., 1884; retired, Dec., 1887.

WINCHESTER, CHARLES BLAKE, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting forest settlement officer, and acting junior collector and political agent; on famine duty, Sept. 1877; and assistant collector, Nov., 1886; 1st assistant collector, March, 1890.

WINCHESTER, E. C., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 16th Dec., 1872; clerk, 2nd class, Nov., 1878.

WINDSOR, JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Old Trafford School, Manchester, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884. Arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1887; served as assistant magistrate and collector.

WINGATE, ANDREW, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, Kensington Grammar School, University of London, and University of Heidelberg; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled Bombay administration report for 1874-75, and for 1875-76; in political charge of the Jath state, Feb.-Sept., 1876; additional secretary in the famine department under chief
commissioner of Mysore, Aug., 1877; assistant secretary to famine commission, Aug., 1878; settlement officer in Oodeypore state, Aug., 1879; officiating resident, Meywar, Feb., 1887; settlement officer, Kashmir state.

WINGFIELD, Sir Charles John, K.C.S.I., C.B.—Educated at Westminster School, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1839; arrived in India, March, 1840; served in the revenue and judicial departments of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Moradabad, 1854; on the annexation of the kingdom of Oudh in 1856, was appointed commissioner of the trans-Gogra division, and was actively engaged in the suppression of the mutiny, 1857-59; chief commissioner of Oudh, March, 1859; C.B., 1860, and K.C.S.I., 1866; retired, 1866; sat in parliament for the borough of Gravesend, 1868 to 1874.

WINMILL, George, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as 2nd sub-engineer, Indus valley railway, 17th Nov., 1875; Class IV, superior revenue establishment, July, 1878; Class III, July, 1879, and Class II, Jan., 1886; locomotive superintendent, Oudh and Rohilkhand railway, Jan., 1889.

WINNY, Thomas H.—Appointed assistant to the surveyor and clerk of the works, India Office, Aug., 1885.

WINTER, Edgar Francis Latimer, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, Trinity Hall, Cambridge, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; under secretary to government, Nov., 1886.

WINTER, Henry Edward, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and King's School, Canterbury; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement and demarcation officer, Poona districts, Jan., 1883; and grade judge, Jan., 1885; junior collector, and collector, and magistrate, district registrar, and political agent, Kolaba, Nov. 1888.

WINTERBOTHAM, Henry Martin, Madras C.S.—Educated at Portland Grammar School, and London University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1869, and served in Madras in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, principal assistant, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting Malayalam translator to government, March-Dec., 1877; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, June-July, 1883; acted for various periods as collector and magistrate, and as district and sessions judge in various districts; and was appointed collector and magistrate, Malabar, Aug., 1883.

WODEHOUSE, Charles, C.I.E., Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, March, 1857; arrived in India, 6th April, 1857, and was employed under the military department, including service in the mutiny campaign, 1857-58 (medal and clasp for Central India); from March, 1867, served as boundary settlement commissioner, Baroda; from Sept., 1868, acted in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, director of public instruction, and small cause court judge; acting assistant resident, Hyderabad, April to Nov., 1870; acting cantonment magistrate and judge, Secunderabad, Dec., 1870; acting assistant resident, Baroda, Jan., 1873; acting political agent, Rewa Kantha, Feb., 1873; from March, 1873, served in Kathia-war as political assistant, acting judicial assistant, and acting political agent, and was placed on special duty for the settlement of boundary disputes in the Gheer forest, July, 1874; also acted as private secretary to the governor of Bombay from May, 1876, to April, 1877; political agent, Mahi Kantha, Sept., 1881; 2nd grade, political agent, Feb., 1885; acting political superintendent, Palanpur, April, 1885, and in Kathia-war, July, 1886; C.I.E., Aug., 1887; on duty in England in connection with the Jubilee, 1887; political agent, Kolhapur, &c., Feb., 1889.

WOLFE-MURRAY, Francis D'Arcy Osborne, Madras C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and St. Andrew's University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments, acting principal assistant collector, assistant sessions judge, forest settlement officer, sub-collector and joint magistrate, collector and magistrate, and district and sessions judge, appointed sub-collector, and joint magistrate, May, 1890.

WOLLASTON, Arthur N., C.I.E., Revenue and Statistics Department, India Office.—Educated at Stockwell Grammar School; entered the India office by open competition as writer, old establishment, 3rd March, 1859; junior clerk, political and secret department, 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1873; assistant secretary, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, Jan., 1884; in charge of the revenue and statistics department, May to Oct., 1886, and April, 1887, to March, 1888; in 1877 published a translation of the 'Anvar-i-Suhaili' or Fables of Bidpai; in 1879 edited Sir Lewis Pelly's miracle play of 'Hasan and Husain'; appointed to succeed Sir F. J. Goldsmid as examiner in Persian at the Royal Staff College, Sandhurst, 1880; selected in 1881 by the science and art department to superintend the translation of the oriental inscriptions in the South Kensington Museum; in 1882 published an English-Persian dictionary, and in 1889 a larger work of the same kind; C.I.E., 1st Jan., 1886.

WOMACK, Arthur Shaw, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; transferred to the Central Provinces, July, 1885, and served as assistant commissioner, and registrar of the judicial commissioners' court.

WOOD, Edward Septimus, Captain, Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as lieutenant, 93rd Sutherland highlanders, 20th Sept., 1857; from Dec., 1859, served in the public works department on irrigation works, N.W. Provinces; officiated as conservator of forests, 1864-66; reverted to his
regiment, Feb., 1866; appointed executive engineer, 4th grade, March, 1867; from April, 1867, served in the forest department, Oudh, and was appointed conservator, Oct., 1868; promoted to 2nd grade, Sept., 1882; 1st grade, Dec., 1888.

WOOD, G. P., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Marlborough, and Addiscombe; writer, India office, 25th Jan., 1866; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

WOOD, JULIUS JOHN, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1st May, 1863, and served on general and jail duty, and as superintendent of vaccination; on famine relief duty in April, 1874; deputy sanitary commissioner, Ranchi circle, Sept., 1883.

WOOD, HENRY MACKENZIE MACDONALD, Major, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1856; from April, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; 2nd grade, May, 1887; also district judge; officiating divisional judge, April, 1887; and divisional judge, Nov., 1889.

WOODBURN, ARCHIBALD FRANCIS, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Ayr Academy, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; also acted as forest settlement officer, and as junior collector and magistrate; second assistant collector, June, 1885; on special duty in judicial department in connection with Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, July, 1888; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Sept., 1888.

WOODBURN, JOHN, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Ayr Academy, Glasgow University, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Oudh, Feb., 1865, and served as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, officiating personal assistant, and officiating secretary to chief commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1879; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, and Oudh, in the Oudh revenue department and forest branch, Jan., 1882; also in the Oudh political department, March, 1882; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, judicial department, May, 1884; acted as chief secretary in 1884-86, and in 1887, and was confirmed in appointment, Nov., 1888; member of the lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1886.

WOODCOCK, ELBOROUGH MARTIN, Colonel, Bombays S.C., Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign, 9th March, 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-57 (medal and clasp); appointed to Oudh military police, 27th Nov., 1858; from March, 1860, served in the police department as district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade, Oct., 1880.

WOODWARD, HILLERSDEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School, and Birmingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and acting railway magistrate; on special duty in connection with the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, Dec., 1882, and again, Aug., 1883; forest settlement officer, Sholapur, Nov., 1883; acting junior collector and magistrate, Belgaum, Sept., 1884; second assistant collector, May, 1885; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1888.

WOODWARD, WILLOUGHBY, M.A., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1863, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting magistrate of police at Bombay, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; junior collector and magistrate, and district registrar, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kântâ, Aug., 1881; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Satara, March, 1886; retired, March, 1890.

WOOTTON, J. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 20th Feb., 1872.

WORDSWORTH, WILLIAM, C.I.E., M.A. (Oxon), late Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the educational service, May, 1861; arrived in India, 10th July, 1861, and served as head-master of the Elphinstone Institution, Bombay, acting professor of history in the Elphinstone College, and assistant inspector of schools; from May, 1862, served as principal of the Deccan College, Poona, and also acted as professor of English literature; from June, 1872, acted as principal of the Elphinstone College, Bombay, and was also appointed to select the government records at the secretariat; confirmed as principal of Elphinstone College, and professor of logic and moral philosophy, Nov., 1874; principal, and professor of history and political economy, from June, 1878; also sheriff of Bombay, Dec., 1885; C.I.E., Feb. 1887; retired, 1890.

WORGAN, JOHN BERNEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; from May, 1876, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1879.

WORSLEY, CHARLES FORTESCUE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884; on special duty, Dec., 1873 (famine), and in Nov., 1882, for the purpose of reporting on the existing chowkidary system; additional commissioner of Patna, Dec., 1884; officiating commissioner, Orissa, July, 1887, and Feb., 1888; and of Dacca division, Feb., 1889; appointed commissioner, Orissa division, Oct., 1889.

WRIGHT, FRANCIS NELSON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at
Eton, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 15th Jan., 1864; from Dec., 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and from May, 1870, to April, 1878, in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Cawnpore, April, 1876; officiating director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1878, and again, 1880-81; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1885; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Meerut, April, 1885; 1st grade, June, 1887; author of a memorandum on the 'Agriculture of Cawnpore,' 'Cawnpore Gazetteer,' 'Cawnpore Settlement Report,' and 'Report on Wheat.'

WRIGHT, FREDERICK, Police Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Arrived in India, 20th Aug., 1859; served as inspector in the Madras police from Jan., 1860; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, Aug., 1862, and served as assistant superintendent and district superintendent of police (1st grade, April, 1877); officiated for various periods as inspector-general of police, jails, and registration, author of 'Margpradurshuk' (a treatise on the Indian Penal Code, 1878), a police manual of laws in 1883, and a schedule to all the penal acts of the government of India, 1841 to 1883.

WRIGHT, FREDERICK C. B., Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 4th July, 1867.

WRIGHT, JAMES MCCALLUM, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North Western Provinces).—Educated at Fordyce School, University of Aberdeen, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service, after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces.

WRIGHT, JAMES WALKER, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the public works department in July, 1859; served in the Punjab as assistant and executive engineer; in charge of Madhopur workshops, March, 1868; executive engineer, military works, Chakrata road, and afterwards in the Jullundur division, 1872; transferred to the Punjab provincial list, Nov., 1879; supervising engineer, 2nd class, July, 1886; 1st class, May, 1889; officiating chief engineer, and secretary to Chief-Commissioner of Burma, April, 1890.

WRIGHT, WILLIAM H., B.A., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Appointed to the education department by secretary of state, 7th Aug., 1867, and served from 7th Dec., 1867, as professor, Benares College; professor of English literature, Muir Central College, Allahabad, July, 1872; 3rd grade of educational officers, July, 1872; principal, Bareilly College, Dec., 1873; officiating inspector of schools, June, 1875, to March, 1876; from Jan., 1877, served as professor at the Muir Central College, and officiated as principal of the Benares College, in 1878; 2nd grade of educational affairs, Aug., 1888; principal of Benares College, Oct., 1888; has published a handbook of the education department, an account of the Muir Central College, and various educational works.

WYER, FREDERICK, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 31st Dec., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, May, 1881; officiated as commissioner of the Burdwan division in 1883; and of the Dacca division, in 1885; retired, May, 1887.

WYER, THOMAS ROWLAND, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University of Glasgow, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer, and in acting appointments as joint magistrate, magistrate and collector, small cause court judge, and district and sessions judge; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; joint magistrate, 1st grade, March, 1888.

WYLIE, HENRY, Lieut.-Colonel, C.S.I., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Oct., 1861; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1861; served with various regiments, and took part in the N.W. frontier campaign, 1863, the 2nd Yusafzai expedition (medal and clasp), the Bhutan Campaign, 1865 (clasp), the Abyssinian expedition, 1868 (medal), and the Hazara campaign, 1868 (clasp); on special duty in Beloochistan, with Major R. Sandeman, Nov., 1875, to Feb., 1877; assistant to governor-general's agent, Beloochistan, 1877; served in the Afghan campaign, 1878-80 (medal); C.S.I., Feb., 1881; assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to chief commissioner, Coorg, 1882; political agent, Bhopawur, Feb., 1885; political agent, Jhalawur, April, 1885; political agent, Bhopal, March, 1887.

WYLLIE, WILLIAM HUTT CURZON, Major, C.I.E., B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 106th Foot, Oct., 1866; arrived in India, Feb., 1867; served in the Oude commission, 1870-1879, as assistant commissioner and officiating cantonment and city magistrate; staff corps, 1868; acted as inspector-general of registration in 1875, and as junior secretary to government, Oude, 1876-77; from Jan., 1879, served under the foreign department, government of India, as cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, assistant commissioner in Merwara and Ajmere, and as assistant to governor-general's agent, Beloochistan; served in Madras, 1880-81, as military secretary to the governor, and acted as private secretary; C.I.E., May, 1881; political agent, 3rd class, in political charge of ex-Gäckwar of Baroda, Mulhar Rao, 1881; assistant resident, Hyderabad, 1882; assistant commissioner, Ajmere, Nov., 1883; 1st assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, 1884; additional political agent, 1st class, Kotah, April, 1885; boundary settlement officer, Meywar-Marwar border; and additional political agent, 1st class, Nov., 1886.

WYNCH, LIONEL MALING, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886.

WYNDHAM, PERCY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Giggleswick
Grammar School and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 15th Dec., 1889, and served in the North-Western Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

WYNNE, SYDENHAM HENRY, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal Naval School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1873, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, South Arcot, Oct., 1882; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Dec., 1887; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1890.

YATE, CHARLES EDWARD, C.S.I., C.M.G., Major, Bombay S.C., Political department of Government of India.—1st commission, ensign 49th regiment, 9th Nov., 1867; arrived in India, 27th Feb., 1868; admitted to Bombay staff corps, March, 1871; from August, 1871, served under foreign department of Government of India at Serohi, and with the Erinpuna irregular force, and afterwards with the Bhil corps; on special duty, Sind border, Sept., 1872, and Nov., 1873; boundary settlement officer, Meywar-Marwar border, Sept., 1874; and Meywar Tonk border, Dec., 1875; officiated for various periods as political assistant, assistant political agent, magistrate, and assistant to superintendent for suppression of thuggee and dacoity; superintendent of operations for control of Moghias in Rajputana and Central India, Sept., 1879; served under the military department in Afghanistan, Feb. to May, 1880. When, under foreign department he was appointed political officer at Kalat-i-Ghilzai; political officer with Kabul-Kandahar field force under Sir F. Roberts on march to Kandahar, Aug., 1880, (bronze star); political officer with cavalry brigade at Kokeran, Sept., 1880; and in Argandab Valley, Oct., 1880; political officer in charge of City of Kandahar, and with southern Afghanistan field force, Nov., 1889 to April, 1891 (medal and clasp for Afghanistan); subsequently served in the political department in Bhopal, Central India, and Bhopawar; attache with Afghan Boundary Commission, July, 1884; political assistant, 1st Class, July, 1885; on duty at Herat in connection with the fortifications, July, 1885; employed on various special services in connection with the Afghan boundary commission; political agent Thal Chohali, March, 1890; author of Gazetteers of Meywar, Banswara and Partabgarh, &c.

YELD, HORACE PARR, Surgeon-Major, Mint Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1874; was employed in the military department up to Aug., 1884, when he was appointed probationer in the assay department, Bombay mint; transferred to Calcutta mint, Sept., 1884; surgeon-major, March, 1886; deputy assay-master, Bombay mint, May, 1886, and Calcutta mint, Jan., 1888; officiating assay master, Bombay mint, April, 1888.

YOUNG, G. EDGAR, India Office Registry Department.—Appointed 2nd class clerk, 22 May, 1888.

YOUNG, GEORGE GORDON, Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1856; from June, 1858, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and assistant settlement officer; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, April, 1877; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Jan., 1881, and subsequently in the Jullundur division, April, 1883; officiating 2nd financial commissioner, Feb., 1888.

YOUNG, WILLIAM, B.A., C.S.I., Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College, London; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Basti, March, 1875; was subsequently posted to Mainpuri, Moradabad, and Muzaffarnagar; civil and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Bareilly, Oct., 1880; and afterwards at Allahabad; judicial commissioner, Oudh, Aug., 1886; acting judge of high court, April, 1890; C.S.I., Jan., 1891.

YOUNG, WILLIAM MACWORTHY, M.A., C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Eton, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, officiating secretary to financial commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; attached on special duty to office of financial commissioner, Oct., 1872; under secretary to government, Punjab, Oct., 1873; settlement secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1875; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Jan., 1878; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, Feb., 1878; secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1880; promoted to commissioner and superintendent, May, 1887, but officiated as secretary to government until Dec., 1887; officiating secretary to government of India, Jan.-March, 1888; commissioner, Jullundur division, April, 1888; 2nd financial commissioner of the Punjab, April, 1889; C.S.I., Jan., 1890.

YOUNGHUSBAND, ARTHUR DELAVAL, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Clifton College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1877, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting junior collector and magistrate, talukdari settlement officer, and assistant political agent.

YOUNGHUSBAND, ROMER EDWARD, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby, Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, officiating judicial assistant, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating district judge; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1885; acted as junior secretary and as senior secretary to financial commissioner; confirmed as junior secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1886; under secretary to government of Punjab, Jan., 1888.
